title: BANKER INDICTED IN MISSOURI RIFT
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 28 The chairman of the board of Missouri's largest banking concern, the Mercantile Trust Company of St. Louis, was indicted here yesterday on four counts of perjury by a Federal grand jury investigating the administration of former Gov. Warren E. Hearnes.

title: CAMBODIA REBELS A MILE TO U.S Aides Say They Don't Know With Whom Phnom Penh Regime Could Negotiate
description: WASNINQTON, Feb. 28 With a growing sense of futility, the United States continues to urge a negotiated end to the Cambodian war, but State Departnient officials said today that they were not even certain with whom the Phnom Penh Government of President. Lon Nol could negotiate.

title: ARGENTINE REBELS KILL AILS. CONSUL
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 28 Leftist guerrillas tonight killed a United States honorary consul whom they had abducted, the police said.

title: Dr. Arnold V. Wolf Dead; Artificial Kidney Pioneer
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (UPI) Dr. Arnold V. Wolf, dean of the University of Illinois Medical Center's graduate college and a pioneer in the development of the artificial kidney, died yesterday at the age of 58.

title: Court Halts Effort to Close 62 Nursing Homes in State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28Operators of 62 nursing homes won court ruling today that the State Health Commissioner had displayed prejudice against them and also obtained a halt in the department's hearings to close them.

title: South Africa Denies Offering Any View on Naming of Davis
description: The South African Governinept denied yesterday that it had expressed any view on the appointment of Nathaniel Davis to be United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.

title: Hawks Take First; Defeat Flames, 43
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Chicago took over first place in the ??? Division of the National Hockey League tonight, overcoming a threegoal deficit to defeat Atlanta, 43, on Jim Pappin's thirdperiod goal.

title: SEYMOUR B. JACOBS
description: Seymour B. Jacobs, a senior partner in the Newark law firm of Balk, Jacobs, Goldberger, Mendell, Seligsohn & O'Connor, died yesterday in Beth Israel, Medical Center, Newark. He was 61 years old and lived at 895 Douglas Terrace, Union, N. J.

title: Lionel Makes a Switch To Plant in Michigan Lionel Makes a Switch To Plant in Michigan
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Feb. 28 (UPI)The last of 30 employes at the Lionel Train Manufacturing and Service Center here was terminated today as part of the relocation of the company to its plant in Mount Clemens, Mich.

title: Pas de Deeises
description: Resuscitation is one of the most difficult of the choreographic arts. In Pas des Deesses Robert Joffrey was attempting to breathe life into an 1846 Romantic lithograph by Jacques Bouvier, depicting four great dancers, Lucile Grahn, Fanny Cerrito, Marie Taglioni and Arthur SaintLeon.

title: Clemency Deadline
description: President Ford announced yesterday that he would grant a final extension until March 31 of the deadline for Vietnamera draft evaders and deserters to apply for clemency. Page 14.

title: Delinquencies at a Peak For Installment Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Delinquencies on installment loans reached a new high of 3.13 per cent in December, the American Bankers Association has reoorted.

title: Engineers Are Assessing Repair Needs
description: I Dozens of telephone engineers and technicians from various arms of the Bell System swarmed over the floors of the firedamaged Second Avenue switching center yesterday to begin the long process of restoring service by assessing damage and testing surviving, equipment:

1,600 Routed in Fire At Miami Beach Hotel
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 28 (AP)About 1,600 people were evacuated from the Carillon Hotel late today when a smoky electrical fire broke out on the first floor, city officials said.

title: Dubious Compromise
description: After winning a historic victory for the fundamental principle of majority rule, the United States Senate seems about to surrender that principle to bullyboy tactics.

title: Dow index Climbs 7.90; Turnover Rises Slightly
description: The stocx marxet registerea its third consecutive modest advance yesterday in stightly heavier trading.

title: A DYNAMIC BALANCE BY VIOLINPIANO DUO
description: Two talented young musicians now teaching in the northwest corner of Ohio appeared as a duo at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night and gave some of the most balanced performances of works for violin and piano that this listener has heard in a long time.

title: Market Place
description: Concord Fabrics, Inc., represents yet another case of a company that went public with high hopes in the days of the last great bull market and whose stock has since proved to be a disappointment in the protracted bear market.

title: EGYPTIANS IN RIFT WITH GUERRILLAS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28A controversy that has erupted, between Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization is regarded by Arab diplomats here as a foretaste of the strain that Secretary of State Kissinger's coming visit will place on President Anwar el Sadat's relations with the more radical forces in the Arab world.

title: PRUDENTIAL SETS DEAL FOR HOTELS
description: Insurer Acquires 50% of Six Units From Hilton Concern

title: 2 Nixon Aides Deny Guilt; McCord Jailing Is Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon's tax lawyer and a doeument appraiser pleaded not guilty to charges that they illegally conspired to backdate a deed for $576,000 worth of Mr. Nixon's prePresidential papers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Skeptical on Ford's Energy Plan
description: President Ford's program to free the United States by 1985 from the threat of an oil embargo has aroused serious doubts among leading energy experts as to its costs, relevance and achievability.

title: Westchester Airport Suffers From Nongrowing Pains Pains
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Feb. 28  A small, singleengine plane with a student at the controls touched down unevenly at Westchester County Airport yesterday and taxied slowly, too slowly, toward the far end.

title: CAMBODIA REBELS A PUZZLE TO U.S
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 With a growing sense of futility, the United States continues to urge, a, negotiated end to the Cambodian War, but State Department officials said today that they were not even certain with whom the Phnom Penh Government of President Lon Nol could negotiate.

title: CHARGES DROPPED AGAINST NEWSMEN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 28Marion bounty Prosecutor James F. Kelley dismissed today criminal charges against two investigative reporters of The Indianapolis Star who were indicted by a local grand jury last September for alleged conspiracy to bribe a police officer.

title: Litton Profit Down Despite Sales Rise
description: Litton Industries, Inc., repork yesterday a 24.8 per cent decline In earnings or the second fiscal quarter and 21.7 per cent for the six months ended Jan. 31. Sales up 15.1 and 21.4 per cent for the respective periods.

title: Reynolds Metals to Expand
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 28 (Renters)Reynolds Metals, Inc., said it would expand by more than 50 per cent its aluminum recycling smelter at Sheffield, Ala. The company said the ex, pansion was expected to be completed by early 1976, but could not give any estimate of the Sheffield plant expansion in terms of aluminum tonnage.

title: Mortgage Rates Cut By F.H.A. and V.A. To 8% From 8 1/2%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration reduced the maximum interest rate on their insured and guaranteed mortgages today to per cent from 8 1/2 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Leaders in Senate Back a Compromise On Filibuster Rule
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 28The Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate joined today to sponsor a compromise modification of the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: Police Kill Gunman After He Slays 2 lit New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP) man stopped for a traffic violation barricaded himself in a French Quarter apartment tonight and opened fire on officers, killing a woman and a policeman before he was shot to death.

title: Knicks Topple Braves
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 28  The Knicks, unpredictable as ever, put their whole hotcold season in miniature tonight with a madcap, 114106. victory over the Buffalo Braves at Memorial Auditorium. They played at their oldtime best in running up a 25point lead late in the third quarter, then committed all sorts of errors and nearly gave the Braves a chance to come back.

title: Analyst Warns of Pollution From Geothermal Projects
description: Analysis of environmental pollution by one of the world's largest geothermal power projects has led to a warning that, unless stringent precautions are taken, the widespread development of such energy sources could be as detrimental as the proliferation of conventional Dower Wants.

title: ARGENTINE REBELS KILL A A U.S. CONSUL Body of Kidnapped Official Found at Cordoba Draped in a Guerrilla flag
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 28Leftist guerrillas tonight killed a United States honorary consul whom they had abducted, the police said.

title: Vote Favoring Marcos He Has One Setback
description: MANILA, Feb. 28 (AP)Early official returns from the referendum on President Ferdinand E. Marcos oneman rule have given him nearly 90 per cent approval, but he has suffered a minor setback in one province.

title: Delinquent Youngsters Find New Life In Lindbergh's House Near. Hopewell
description: HOPEWELL, The large, twostory stone house still stands in 350 lonely, wooded acres near hereHighfields, the same house that 43 years ago on the chill night of March 1 suddenly was made a focus of world attention.

title: ERITREAN REBELS SAID TO WITHDRAW
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 28  The Ethiopian Army reportedly routed a seccessionist guerrilla force south of the town of Keren early today, after six days of the heaviest fighting of the 28dayold civil war in Eritrea Province.

title: Bridge:
description: Most strong oneclub systems, and especially those that bar fourcard major openings, make use of a nebulous diamond. One diamond simply denies the ability to make any other opening bid, and does not promise any diamond length: A singleton is quite possible, and a void is conceivable.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 1, 1975

title: WILLIAM deNEERGAARD
description: William deNeergaard, owner of the Neergaard Pharmacies of Brooklyn and a past president of the State Board of Pharmacy, died Thursday at his home in Lloyd Harbor, L. I. His age was 80.

title: Business Briefs
description: At least six Middle East states are considering construction of aluminum smelters, according to Metals Week, a trade publication. The states are said to be Abu Dhabi, Algeria, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

title: CHASE REALTY GETS WAIVERS OF DEFAULT
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP)The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust anounced today that it had obtained waivers of default under credit agreements. The default would have occurred as a result of the trust's decision to increase its reserve for loan losses and nonaccruing, loans as of today.

title: A Mozart Staging With Marxist Hints
description: BERLIN, Feb. 27waiter Felsenstein, who runs the Komische Oper in East Berline, is one of the legendary stage directors of Europe. He took over the Komische Oper shortly after World War II and made it, in the opinion of many connoisseurs, the supreme ensemble opera company of the world. He has also trained many directors and sent them out to carry on his theories. One of

title: 8 Weeks Here a Lifetime. For a Runaway Girl of 15
description: They held a funeral and buried Karen Baxter yesterday in Cambridge, Mas. It was a quiet postscript to a short, unhappy lifeone that few people knew much or cared much about, a life that was snuffed out by a strangler in a fleabag hotel here last Saturday night.

title: 97 IN LONDON DIE IN SUBWAY CRASH Train Hits End of Tunnel in System's Worst Disaster Rise in Toll Feared
description: LONDON, Feb. 28 A Subway train sped past its final stop this morning and smashed into the end of a tunnel. At least 29 people were killed and 80 injured.

title: Muriel H. Wright, 85, Dies; Author, Expert on Indians
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 28 (AP)Dr. Muriel Hazel Wright, historian, author, editor and authority on Oklahoma Indians, died yesterday. She was 85 years old.

title: The Weather for the Month of March
News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 1, 1975

title: Cordero Slips  Only 2 Winners
description: Angel Cordero visited the winner's circle twice at Aqueduct yesterday. It was quite a comedown for the jaunty Cordero, because he had five winners on Thursday and four on Wednesday.

title: Commodity. Index Declined By 199.0 for Latest Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 199.0 from 204.8 last week.

title: Westchester Airport Suffers From Nongrowing Pains
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Feb. 28 A small, singleengine plane with a student at the controls touched down unevenly at. Westchester County Airport yesterday and taxied slowly, too slowly, toward the far end.

title: SARAH THOMPSON
description: Sarah Dyer Thompson, a so cial science teacher at Port Richmond High School in Staten Island since 1958, died Monday of cancer at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond. She was 38 years old and lived at 36 Beacon Avenue. New Dorn. S. I.

title: GENETIC AID FAILS IN TEST ON HUMANS
description: An international attempt by scientists and doctors to treat a rare genetic disease by changing the hereditary makeup of the patientsbelieved to be the first genetic engineering experiment in human beingshas ended in failure, the researchers reported yesterday.

title: JERSEY BELL GIVES MONITORING DATA
description: NEWARK, Feb. 28Senior officials of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today defended their current and past telephonemonitoring practices as being done solely to audit the quality of our product, service.

title: Thailand's New Premier
description: When the King of Thailand and his friend and relatiye, die new Premier, get ..to7 gether, they may just be jaimning. King PhurniPhol. Aduldet, who is a noted jazz musician, plays the clarinet and saxophone. Premier Seth Pramoj plays the double bass. The Premier.

title: An Offering Of Bullets
description: While President Ford and Professor Kissinger were whooping it up for more war in Cambodia the other day, Sydney Schanberg was writing for The New York Times from Phnom Penh. If we juxtapose excerpts from Schanberg, Ford and Kissinger, we begin to understand how American policy relates to Cambodian reality.

title: NEWARK GIVES UP PLAN TO DROP 32
description: A suit charging Newark with violations of Civil Service regulations was dismissed yesterday by Judge Melvin P. Antell in Essex County Superior Court when the city agreed to rescind an order dismissing 32 Public Works employes.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford will nomi nate John E. Robson, a chicago lawyer born in New York; to a fouryear term on the Civil Aeronautics Board and designate him chairman upon his confirmation by the Senate; the White House announced yesterday.

title: INDUSTRY REDUCES PROPOSED OUTLAYS
description: American industry has cut back its announced capital outlays for expansion and modernization fo rthis year by nearly $7billion from the figures announced last fall, McGrawHill economists said yesterday.

title: J.D.L. MAN INDICTED ON ARAFAT THREAT
description: An official of the militant Jewish Defense League has been indicted in connection with his alleged treat last November to assassinate Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Pact Links 46 Poor Lands With the European Market
description: LOME, Togo, Feb. 28  A fiveyear treaty aimed at linking the European Common Market and 46 developing countries of Africa; the Caribbean and the Pacific in a trade and aid partnership was signed here today.

title: ARAB OIL EXPORTS TRAIL MS PACE
description: ROME, Feb. 28Arab oil exports have dropped to even less than they were during the oil embargo and production cutbacks of a year ago, and an element of competition has returned to world oil trading.

title: PESTICIDE RECALLED IN FEAR OF FUMES
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP )The United States Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had issued a recall order for defective pesticide cans that may be leaking dangerous and Potentially fatal fumes.

title: Mets Acquire Kingman in Cash Deal With Giants
description: ST.. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28The recent rush of baseball talent into New York continued today when, the Mets paid the San Francisco Giants close to $150,000 for the powerhitting Dave Kingman.

title: Big Antarctic Oil Field Is Possible, Navy Says
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 28 (UPI) The navy has disclosed the possible existence of an offshore Antarctic oil field that might be larger than Alaska's gigantic North Slope discovery.

title: FORD OPENS WAY FOR COMPROMISES ON ECONOMY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 President Ford, after meeting with Democratic leaders of Congress, said today that he was ready to negotiate a compromise on energy and economic programs and disclosed that he might postpone a second $1abarrel increase in the tariff on imported oil scheduled to go into effect tomorrow.

title: U.N. Narcotics Board Says Drug Abuse Grows Worse
description: GENEVA, Feb. 28The International Narcotics Control Board warned today that the abuse of drugs still continues to grow at a disturbing rate.

title: Dance: Kei Takei Light'.
description: Futility, despair, holocaust, eternity and, strangely enough, optimismthese are the words brought to mind by Thursday night's performance of Light by the company known as Kei Takers Moving Earth. Miss Taker's group is the latest in the experimental dance series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: E.C.D. Says a Price Cut Would Lessen Oil Woes
description: PARIS, Feb. 28The Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today that a floor price for oil at between $4 and $7 a barrel would stimulate enough new oil and fossilfuel development to greatly modify the entire energy situation.

title: Frightened Chinese Shut Most of Phnom Penh's Shops
description: PHNOM, PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 28The heavy steel grates of Phnom Penh's shops have been locked and barred for the last week. The stalls in the central market are deserted at what should be the afternoon rush hour. There is fear in the Chinese community and the economic heartbeat of this isolated city of two million people has come to a virtual halt.

title: Wisdom on the Hoof
description: WASHINGTONThe eminent scientist Rend Dubos has wisely remarked that human life with all its endearing qualities can prosper with rather spartan ways. I can bear witness to that statement, with a concrete personal experience that graphically illustrates the virtue or walking in contributing to a vigorous old age.

title: Concert
description: The Suite from Bartok's ballet The Wooden Prince brought to a close Pierre Boulez's uncommonly interesting program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. Rarely played today it is a relatively early creation of the Hungarian composer, a wey station on the road to his mature style.

title: Relatives Report Seeing Beating in a Nursing Home
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 28Relatives of a blind 93yearold Seneca Indian woman testified here today that when they had gone to visit her at a local nursing home they found she was being beaten by about 10 nurses.

title: Sir Neville Cardus Dies at 85; Music Critic and Cricket Writer
description: LONDON, Feb. 28Sir Neville Cardus, music critic and cricket writer, died in a London hospital today. He was 85 years old.

title: Bucher Urges Pueblo Crew to Aid Inquiry to Correct Errors
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 28The commander of the American spy ship Pueblo, captured by North Korean naval units seven years ago, urged former members of the vessel's crew this week to cooperate in a study being prepared by the Navy to determine the effects of their 11 months captivity.

title: Air Fare Discounts Backed On Flights Over 750 Miles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a modified air fare discount that would let the nation's airlines offer discounts pf 20 to 25 per cent over some 60 per cent of all domestic routes.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
Aussies Clinch Zone Net Final
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Saturday, March 1 (UPI)Australia won the Eastern zone final of the Davis Cup today when John Newcombe and Geoff Master defeated Onny Parun and Brian Fairlie of New Zealand. 64. 64.15.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE:
description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Texan Is Recorded Saying Gov. Hall Was to Get Payoff
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 28  A Federal court jury heard today a tape recording of a Texas man saying that the former Governor of Oklahoma, David Hall, was to receive part of $50,000 payoff as a legal fee.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $473.8million contract has been awarded by the Navy to the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation for the construction of two more Trident missilelaunching submarines. This will bring to three the number of such submarines under contract out of an eventual force of 10. The hulls will be built in Groton, Conn.

title: Ford Grants Final Clemency Extension
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28President Ford announced today a final extension until March 31 of the deadline for Vietnamera draft evaders and deserters to apply for clemency.

title: Prices That Farmers Get For Products Decline 4%
description: WASHINGTO Feb. 28The prices far, receive for raw agricultural products dropped 4 per cent from Jan. 15 to Feb. 15, their fourth consecutive monthly decline, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Events Today
Marriages on the Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The steeply declining rate at which American women have been bearing children over the last five years slowed and leveled off for the first time in 1974, according to provisional data released today by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, March 2

title: Rail TonMileage Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb: 28The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.3 billion tonmiles, 14.6 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period, which included the Washington's Birthday holiday totaled 430,123 cars, 16.7 per cent below last year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Transit Authority has opened an investigation into whether high officials of the transit police, including its acting chief, covered up reports of corruption within the force.

title: College, School Results
Eclair Pastry Shop Offers Cosmopolitan Calories
description: The Eclair, the pastry shop and restaurant at 141 West 72d Street, may not be to the West Side quite what Rick's splashy cafe and gambling den was to the hit film, Casablanca, but they both catered to a similar clientele, the World War II refugees from Nazi Europe.

title: 1,000 Attend Funeral for Jersey Priest Murdered by School Intruder
description: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Feb. 28About 1,000 relatives, friends, former students and clergymen from throughout New Jersey filled St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today for the funeral of the Rev. Thomas J. Quinlan, who was shot to death last Monday at the school where he was principal.

title: Carey Gives Thruway Job To His Campaign Director
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28Governor Carey today appointed his campaign manager, Gerald Cummins, as chairman of the State Thruway Authority, thus maintaining the post's tradition as a (leading patronage award.

title: Berlin Abductors Demand Release of 6 Jailed Leftists
description: BERLIN, Feb. 28The kidnappers of Peter Lorenz, the Berlin mayoral condidate who j was abducted in his car yesterday, today demanded the release of six radical German leftists from prison.

title: Nova Scotia Is Seeking Supertankers for a New Deepwater Port
description: PORT HAWKESBURY, Nova Scotia, Feb. 21When environmentalists all over the United States are battling the oil industry and blocking its development,, this maritime province is actively soliciting supertankers and refineries for a new deepwater port.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford will nominate John E. Robson, a Chicago lawyer born in New York, to a fouryear term on the Civil Aeronautics Board and designatehim chairman upon his confirmation by the Senate, the White House announced yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed legislation to provide about $25million to avert a shutdown of commuter rail and bus service in New Jersey. The Governor also signed a bill that would accelerate the state's collection of corporate income taxes to pay for the commuter program.

description: HAVE JUMP SHOT WILL TRAVEL. By Charles Rosen. 204 pages. Arbor House. $6.95. WALTZ ACROSS TEXAS. By Max Crawford. 393 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $8.95.

title: Experts Skeptical on Ford's Energy Plan
description: President Ford's program to free the United States by 1985 from the threat of an oil embargo has aroused serious doubts among leading energy experts as to its costs, relevance and achievability.

title: MANAGER OF A HOTEL SLAIN ON WEST SIDE
description: The 54yearold manager of a West Side hotel was shot to death during a robbery yesterday afternoon as he was returning from a bank with $4,050 to cash tenants March 1 welfare checks, the police said.

title: 29 IN LONDON DIE IN SUBWAY CRASH
description: LONDON, Feb. 28A subway train sped past its final stop this morning and smashed into the end of a tunnel. At least 29 people were killed and 80 injured.

title: ABRAHAM HELLER, RABBI. DIES AT 76
description: Rabbi Abraham M. Heller, since 1924 spiritual director of the Flatbush Jewish Center, Ocean Parkway and Church Avenue, Brooklyn, died Thursday, in Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 188 Stratford Roar Brooklyn.

title: Banks Cancel City's Sale Of $260Million in Notes
description: The sale of $260million in shortterm city notes successfully bid for last week by Chase Manhattan Bank and Bankers Trust was abruptly canceled yesterday. Controller Harrison J. Goldin said the cancellation, was because of a sudden demand by the underwriters, unprecedented in the history of the city, for data that could not physically be compiled, checked and verified in the short time available.

title: 1,000 Gather to Mourn Priest Slain in a School
description: SOUTH AMBOY, Feb. 28 About 1,000 relatives, friends, former students and fellow clergymen gathered in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today for the funeral of the Rev. Thomas J. Quinlan, who was shot to death last Monday morning at the parochial school in Penns Grove where he was principal.

title: PHONE DISRUPTION EXPECTED TO LAST AT LEAST 2 WEEKS
description: The New York Telephone announced yesterday that it would take at east two to three weeks to restore full service on the 173,000 telephones that were knocked out in a 300block area south of 23d Street by a fire that raged out of control for more than 15 hours Thursday in a major telephone switching center.

title: Nets Halt Spirit Rally, Win, 117110
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 28 The feeling throughout the American Basketball Association is that the Spirits of St. Louis are going to be one of the league's top clubs once they get some experience. They showed continued improvement tonight at the Nassau Coliseum despite a 117110 loss to the New York Nets

The 46th and perhaps the last.

title: Drug Dealer Sentenced to Life In 72 Stabbing Death of Model
description: A man convicted of wholesale narcotics dealing was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday for depriving a Manhattan model of her civil rights by stabbing her to death two years ago to prevent her from testifying against him in Federal drug case.

title: Antiques: Wooton Desks
description: A century ago this month the oneyearold Wooton Desk Company of Indianpolis advertised for 20 cabinetmakers to join its work force.

description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP)Eddie Pearce used an eightunderpar 64 today to take the secondround lead by one stroke in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Golf Classic

description: The New York Telephone announced yesterday that it would take at least two to three weeks to restore full service on the 173,000 telephones that were knocked out in a 300block area south of 23d Street by a fire that raged out of control for more than 15 hours Thursday in a major telephone switching center.

title: 3 BANKS CUT RATE ON LOANS TO 8 1/4 %
description: Three of the country's large st banksthe Bank of America, First National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reduced yesterdays the interest rates they charge on loans to corporations.

title: Cambodian Aid May Hinge on Issue of Secret Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Administration's requeSt for $222million in emergency military aid for Cambodia now rests with a House Appropriadons subcominittee so closely divided that the outcome could depend on whether the vote is taken in secret.

title: China Says She Ptedicted Big Quake
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 28 China says her scientists were able to warn the people of Liaoning Province in the northeast a few weeks ago that a major earthquake was about to strike.

title: SHOP. TALK
description: Lord & Taylor has a new model room on its eighth floor. Guess what it is bathroom.

title: Lockheed Plan Ends
description: A plan for Textron, Inc., to invest $100million in the debtburdened Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been called off. Page 33.

title: A 30Hour Day Follow,, Fire for Phone Officials
description: As dawn broke over the city yesterday morning, John Fallon woke up expecting to find his wife, his alarm clock and his bathrobe all within reach: Instead, he sat bolt upright on a plush couch in the middle of Room 2522 in the executive offices of the New York. Telephone company.

title: CBS Will Present Danny Kaye's Look At the Met Opera
description: Danny Kaye's Lookin at the Metropolitan Opera, a 60minute special starring the film and stage comedian, will be presented on The CBS Festival of Lively. Arts for Young People series on April 27 from 5 to 6 P.M. on the CBSTV network.

title: Pupil Killed in Bus Plunge
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 28 (AP)A bus carrying high school pupils home from a week's vacation veered off a road and plunged 170 feet down a steep bank today, killing one girl. Twentyeight other children were injured.

title: The Davis Appointment
description: Behind the uproar over the nomination of Nathaniel Davis to be Assistant Secretary of State for African. Affairs is the deeper problem of the American posture of insensitivity and inattention to Africa, tinged with reflexive tilt toward whitedominated southern Africa. Secretary Kissinger, like his Democratic predecessor, shows, relatively little interest in Africa despite the dramatic changes now occurring there. The Davis appointment symbolizes exactly what is wrong with the relationship. It is not so much that Mr. Davis was Ambassador to Chile during the Allende overthrowthough a more sensitive Secretary might have antici pated some African concern on the issue; it is rather that Mr. Davis has no background in African affairs.

title: Swiss Cut Discount Rate, Easing Pressure on Dollar
description: GENEVA, Feb. 28Switzerland's central bank announced today that its discount rate would be cut to 5 per cent from 5.5 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Art With Cancellations, Postal and Other
description: What is on at the wall at Llyn Foulkes's exhibition at the Willard Gallery, 29 East 72d Street, is not so much a group of paintings, in the traditional sense, as a group of objects in which painting plays a part. Somewhere within each object is a standard image: a miniature por trait of General Custer, President Taft or one of the Berrigan brothers, for instance or a photograph of a boy or a girl in anachronistic costume, or what looks like a Photomat portrait enlarged and painted freehand.

title: Seoul Sees an Ebb in Detente as Aiding Its Ties to U.S.
description: SEOUL, South KoreaA Korean troupe danced for soldiers of the United States; Second Infantry Division north of here recently and a Korean', veterans association threw a party in the capital with a fivetiered cake to commemorate the division's 5,000 days of; service in. South Korea.

title: SATURN ROCKET HIT BY CRACKS IN FINS
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Feb. 28 (UPI)Cracks were found in fins on the Saturn LB rocket that will launch three Americans to meet two Russians in orbit in July and all eight fins will be replaced, the space agency announced today.

title: What to Do About It?
description: In most other major cities, the trend has been in the opposite direction. For example, Atlanta has cut fares from 40 cents to 15 cents, Baltimore from 40 cents to 30 cents, Cincinnati from 50 cents to 25 cents and Los Angeles from 30 cents to 25 cents. Significantly, most of these reductions have been achieved with the help of new local taxes levied specifically to support transit operationssales taxes in Atlanta and Los Angeles, an earnings tax in Cincinnati. Boston sustains its 25cent fare partly through a realty levy in a special transit district.

His photographic achievements have long been established, both in the museums and in the world of photojournalism, among the classics of the medium. His name is a byword for distinction, and his pictures are avidly published and collected.

It could become a calamity for low and moderateincome families who depend on subsidized day care to provide learning opportunities for their children and protect job opportunities for working mothers.

description: And now it is March, the month named for the Roman god, Mars. Not the old ruffian with helmet and broadsword, but the young Mars who was god of green and growing things, a god of the fields. We forget that, as we forget that the vernal equinox, less than three weeks ahead, is nothing more than an index of daylight and darkness.

title: Old Dog Club Learns New Showing Tricks
description: The Rockland County Kennel Club is holding its 29th annual show next Saturday but it will be a first actually run by the club. In the past we always had a superintendent to stage our show, said of William Metz, a corporation lawyer and the club's delegate to the American Kennel Club. This year we decided to run it ourselves. We have drawn an entry of 1,546 the largest in our history. Financially, although the final figures aren't in, we will save at least $3,000, some of which will go to our scholarship fund for veterinary medicine and veterinary nursing.

description: To Trader Vic's practiced eye, there are certain exquisite vintages in used cars which he recognizes as surely as a master vintner recognizes a Chateau Mouton Rothschild, 1969.

description: In those longago days when the automobile was only a toy for the rich, the critic Vernon Lee pointed out that the fastmoving vehicle was unsatisfactory for the enjoyment of scenery. Later, Henry Ford himself described his car as something of a nuisance for it made a racket and scared horses. Soon the traffic fatalities began to mount. We know that the automobile's emissions are poisonous to health, so anything which can be done to lessen its impact on urban society will be to the good.

title: The Coming Siege of Concord, Mass.
description: IN the Town House at Concord, Mass., the countdown has begun, with zerohour only weeks away. On April 19 called Patriot's Day in MassachusettsConcord will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Battle at North Bridge. Here in 1775, Minute Men fired the shot heard 'round the world. Just as that skirmish marked the start of America's War of Independence, so the Concord celebration will kick off the nation's major Bicentennial observances. The townspeople look forward to the event with trepidation.

title: Quake Razes Jordan Village

title: The Master of The Nude Male Body in Action
description: LONDON, Five hundred years have passed since Michelangelo's birth, and the celebratory exhibition of his drawings on view at the British Museum until the end of April Is, In some ways, a reminder of how close Michelangelo was to the Classical and Christian wellsprings of our era. For many, the exhibition is unalloyed joy. In the discreetly decorated, somewhat hermetic rooms of the Prints and Drawings Department, the scholars come and go, talking happily of Michelangelo's motifs and enigmas, while connoisseurs of the high Renaissance and contemporary artists gaze with delight at the groundwork of the superhuman architect, sculptor, poet, painter and draftsman who did all those things well but one thing as perfectly as it has ever been donenamely, to draw the nude male body in action. That perfection, that concentrated skilland the passing of the time in which it was not only boldly wonderful but justified by the belief that bodily perfection equalled spiritual perfectionnow tend to give Michelangelo the remote grandeur of an Old Master. But one of the excitements of this exhibition is how close it comes to rescuing him from that unappealing status.

title: Reva Seybolt to Be a Bride May 31

March is no exception to this trend; fortunately there is no shortage of titles to fill this space.

title: Abortion Is a Bitter Issue in Italy, Too
description: ROMEThe raid by police on an abortion clinic in Florence last Jan. 9 that eventually resulted in the arrest of nine persons, with arrest warrants currently out for four others, set in motion a chain of events that politicians of nearly every shade of the Italian political spectrum would have preferred to avoid.

title: Heated Verbal Exchange
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 2 (AP)A meeting between members of the United States Congress and the North Vietnamese delegation in Saigon ended today in a heated verbal exchange.

title: The Ides Of March
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Everybody is telling Henry Kissinger as he leaves again for the Middle East to Beware the Ides of March, but he remains reasonably confident that this step will finally lead to a separate IsraelEgypt interim agreement.

title: Nicklaus Gains Lead on 66202
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 1  The thing about Jack Nicklaus that his fellow pros admire more than his superb golfing talent is his competitive spirit. Today the Golden Bear showed how, competitive he can be by working his way out of the field to take the lead in the third round of the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic.

title: 1.5 Million in Starts This Year Forecast
description: Housing starts will reach 1.5 million in 1975, compared with 1.35 million last year, according to the semiannual survey of housing markets by the Advance Mortgage Corporation of Detroit.

title: Carey and Beame Are Satirized Here By the Inner Circle
description: Mayor Beame was depicted as a supplicant Snow White and a stern budgetary taskmaster and Governor Carey was satirized as the woeful manager struggling to pull together a winning, dissessionfree presidential team last night in the annual lampoon show of the Inner Circle, an organization of past and present political writers in New York.

title: Feminists Continue Attack on Governor
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne is still under fire from feminist leaders in, the state, even though he moved quickly to nominate members of the Advisory Commission on the Status of Women after being criticized for not having acted promptly on the matter.

title: Abba Eban to Speak In Westfield Today
description: WESTFIELD  Abba Eban, former Foreign Minister of Israel, will speak today at Temple EmanuEl, 756 East Broad Street. The program, which will begin at 5 P.M., is open to the public without charge. It is being held under the sponsorship of the Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey, the Israel Aliyah Center of New Jersey and Temple EmanuEl.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Government has proposed a plan to do for the Penn Central and five other Northeastern railroads what they have been unable to do for themselves: run at a profit. But there already are warnings that the proposed startup cost, $1.5billion, will be just the beginning of an inevitably losing investment with the taxpayers' money.

title: Hugh Knowlton Fiance Of Susan English Galpin
description: The engagement of Susan English Galpin to Hugh Gilbert Knowlton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen K. Galpin of Southport, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Hugh Knowlton Jr. of New York and South Egremont, Mass., and Mrs. John Oldrin of Darien, Conn.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: There are several bright posies making their debut this year that deserve some special notice. Seedsmen appear to be filling the need for plants that carry on without much T.L.C. from busy gardeners who also like to play golf, picnic, sail, swim, travel, ride, hike and relax.

title: I Have This Railroad In the Palm of My Hand
description: When we approached the sleek, shiny Canadian National Railways diesel two years ago in Toronto's Union Station, we could not foresee that about a year later we would own one ourselves, complete with a string of four passenger cars just like the one that sped us across Canada.

title: Sunday Observer
description: We are gathered at home to watch the end of the world on television.

title: 2 Million Illegal Pistols Believed Within the City
description: Despite an intensified police effort to block the flow of illegal handguns into New York, Federal and city law enforcement officials say that the problem has worsened here in the last year.

title: PLAN ON HIGHWAY RUNS INTO SNARES
description: The city's plan for a sixlane Interstate System highway along the Hudson shore in Manhattan has begun to appear as shaky as the dilapidated old elevated West Side Highway that it would replace.

title: Passenger Slain on Hijacked Iraqi Jet
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 (AP)Security guards aboard an Iraqi airliner overcame three armed hijackers today in a shooting duel that left one passenger dead and 10 wounded, including a hijacker, an Information Ministry spokesman said.

title: Poem by Yevtushenko Assails Peking Policy
description: MOSCOW, March 1 (AP)In a poem about a young Chinese refugee who fled to Hong Kong, Yevgeny Yevtushenko has charged the Chinese leadership with turning its people into unthinking, uncultured, materially deprived automations.

title: WHAT WOMEN ARE BUYING
description: Back in the days when the stock market went up and the consumer price index stayed down, Claire Blasetti used to steer clear of the more expensive department stores on her shopping expeditions. But now, with the economy in recession and prices on the gallop, the 29yearold Connecticut hairdresser earnestly pores over the racks at Bloomingdale's for topnotch clothes and seriously contemplates spending nearly $100 on a good outfit.

title: Molloy Captures Catholic Track Title
description: Take the flavor of a Catholic High Schools championship, add the spice of half a dozen team contenders, serve it up to a wildlycheering crowd at the 102d Engineers Armory, and you have the ingredients for an exciting indoor track and field meet.

title: STARTING OVER AGAIN
description: hen Elizabeth Browning Karpf talks about changing styles, she doesn't mean skirt lengths. It's life style that interests her, and she has altered her own drastically.

title: Recital: Diverting Diva
description: According to Betty Allen, when she was asked to appear in the Divas and Diversions series at Hunter College, she wasn't quite sure whether she was to be a diva or a diversion, so why couldn't she be a diverting diva? The mezzosoprano was pretty much that in her recital in the series on Friday night.

title: Cher's Sonny, Wilbur's Fanne And Privacy?
description: Contemplating Cher's navel, I thought of Wilbur Mills. Now they are after me with nets end sedatives. But, on the run, I will try to explain. It was a Sunday night, and it was the second time that week I had been contemplating that navelfirst on Cher's special with Elton John and Bette Midler, then on the premiere of her weekly variety show, with Tatum O'Neal and Raquel Welch. Cher herself is something special, the vulgar princess, confected as it were out of materials left over from an old Susan Sontag essay on camp. CBS excels in the packaging of such materials. The result is snappy, and a hit in the Nielsens.

title: Valerie Clark Plans Wedding In June to Peter J. McNeely
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hays Clark of Deer Park, Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Leeds Clark, to Peter Jones McNeely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prentice McNeely of Haverford, Pa. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Albany Gets Bills Curbing OTB Sites
description: ALBANYOfftrack betting officials on Long Island have reacted strongly against proposed legislation giving local governing bodies and planning boards virtual veto power over the location of new betting parlors.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, March 1Before his full cabinet and the top leadership of the Philippine armed forces, President Ferdinand E. Marcos set forth a foreignpolicy program today that includes a personal visit to Peking later this year to establish full diplomatic ties betweeen the two countries.

title: The Program
description: BIG CITY. Book and chor??ography, Kurt Jooss; staged by Anna Markard; costumes and lighting, Rermann Markard; costumes recreated by Jennifer Tipton; music, Alexandra Tansman; conductor, Sung Kwak, pianists, Stanley Babin and Mary Roark. Presented by the City Center Jeffrey Ballet at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Ohrenstein Sees Passage Of More Jobless Benefits
description: Manfred Ohrenstein, minority leader of the State Senate, told an audience of unionists yesterday that he was confident the Legislature would vote to increase unemployment insurance benefits and extend the period they are paid.

title: Congress and the Fed
description: WASHINGTONThe slow dance of the United States Governmenta dance into immobility, in the view of some  took another agonized pirouette last week.

title: WILLIAM E. GAUNT
description: William E. Gaunt, executive president of the International Vitamin Corporation of Union, N.J., died Friday in Monroe County General Hospital, Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 62 years old and lived in Stroudsburg.

title: Bugner Keeps Title, Stops Cane in 5th
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 1 (AP)Joe Bugner of Britain retained his European heavyweight boxing title tonight by stopping 34yearold Dante Cane of Italy in the fifth round of their scheduled 15round bout at the Sports Palace.

title: Lower East Side story
description: Leben Zul Columbus. Who but Harry Golden would have the chutzpah to give a Yiddish subtitle to his book? I can just imagine an unknown author walking into a publisher's office and saying, Look, I've got this great Yiddish phrase. I want to put it on the cover. They would toss the meshuggener out.

title: Colby Won't Resign And Is Sure C.I.A. Will Come Through
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) William E. Colby, director of Central Intelligence, whose agency is under investigation by two Congressional committees and a Presidential commission, said today that the C.I.A. will come through it and he had no intention of resizning.

title: Sheila Wingerter Designer, Is Bride
description: Sheila Mary Wingerter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kernan Wingerter of South Orange, N. J., and Thomas George McIntyre, son of Mrs. William Davis McIntyre of Monroe, Mich., and the late Mr. McIntyre, were married yesterday morning by the Rev. William J. Nessel at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange.

title: How the Witch Got Alf
description: Is there among us one so crusted he cannot share the yearnings of Alf the donkey? Is there anyone (metaphoricallyspeaking) who has not felt overworked on the farm, outcast in the barn, too big to be cuddled, yet who carries a song in his heart to rival a canary'sbut which emerges as a raucous bray?

title: 62 AT WHITE HOUSE ARRESTED IN SITIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)Sixtytwo persons were arrested today when they refused to leave the White House grounds during a protest against United States policies in Indochina and what they called President Ford's shamnesty program.

title: Miss Nelson Victor in Cup Skiing
description: WHISTLER MOUNTAIN, British Columbia, March 1 (UPI)  Starting from 21st position, Cindy Nelson of the United States scored a surprise victory today in World Cup women's giant slalom here in driving rain.

title: Hiring Pact Clears Way For Building By York
description: A potentially serious roadblock to construction at York College was removed last week with the agreement between the city and state on which minorityhiring plan would be used at the site of the college's main building.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The Palisadium, 700 Palisadium Drive, Cliffside Park. (201) 2242211.

title: Old Firehouses Clang in the Past
description: Let it be said. at once: the ultimate architectural preservationists are firemen. New York's life and lifestyle are in their hands. Yet 1975 marks only the 110th anniversary of the fire department of a city three times as old.

title: Oil Producers Meet
description: ALGIERS, March 1 (UPI) Government ministers of the 13 top oil exporting nations, facing a world oil oversupply, opened a weekend of talks today to prepare next week's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: The Observation of Lent: Families Adapt to a Changing Church
description: Dr. Matthew Ferguson has sworn off liquor for Lent again. I usually give up booze, the 45yearold internist said, with a chuckle. Sometimes I wonder: Is it a religious thing or just a reminder that I don't need it?

title: School Financing Called Inadequate
description: BELLMOREAt two separate meetings last Thursday night, one in Nassau and the other in Suffolk, hundreds crowded into school auditoriums with their local legislators and listened to statements that denounced the effects of Governor Carey's proposed budget on education, urged reforms in the methods of financing the schools, and warned of sharp increases in local taxes.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Kenneth Cook is an Australian writer who, if BLOODHOUSE (St. Martin's, $6.50) is any indication, is a verist. He seizes upon the lower classes and depicts them with the eye of a Daumier or a Groszobjectively, without pity, ever, with a certain grim amusement. Bloodhouse in a way is a gimmick book. It uses the rather tired device of courtroom proceedings, though most of the narration is told in flashbacks. It ends with what the author hopes is an unexpectedly wry twist, though in reality it lands with the impact of a scoop of mashed potatoes.

title: LON NOL IS SAID TO OFFER TO QUIT
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sunday, March 2President Lon Nol indicated to a Congressional delegation yesterday that he would be willing to step down if he were an obstacle to a peace settlement. But American Embassy sources said they saw nothing really new in the President's remarks.

title: Friday's Fights
description: Marseille, FranceJean Mateo, Stockton Calif., knocked out Mike Morgan, Minneapolis, Minn., 4 rounds, middleweights.

title: Bayerische Staatsoper's Figaro a Delight
description: MUNICH, West GermanyGuenther Rennert is the manager of the Bayerisohe Staatsoper, the big opera house in Munich. He also stages operas for the international operatic community, which includes San. Francisco and the Metropolitan in New York. Naturally, he also stages for his own house, and this week saw his production Of Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro. It was the most coherent, intelligent and handsome staging of the great opera that this listener has ever across.

title: MORRIS GOLDBERGER, GYNECOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Morris A. Goldberger, director emeritus of gynecology at Mount Sinai Hospital and professor emeritus of gynecology at Mount Sinai's medical school, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 145 West 86th Street.

title: The Big Look (cont.)
description: The revolution started last fall. There were no battle cries, no protest marches. Not a single volley was fired. When fashion designers on both sides of the Atlantic decided on a big, loose silhouette and long hemlines, women took it calmly. Unlike the midi hysteria of 1970, this fashion revolution has been proceeding quietly, almost surreptitiously.

title: Forecasts Resumed for State Farmers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The weather forecast telephone service for NewJersey farmers has been resumed after a threemonth absence.

title: Salvatore Perconte Fiance of Miss Cucolo
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gabriel F. Cucolo of the engagement of their daughter, Gabrielle Cucolo, to Salvatore Perconte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Perconte. Both families are of Brooklyn.

title: LETTERS
description: Radicals

title: Islanders Trounce Seals, 61
Ellen Sheiman Plans Nuptials
description: Mrs. Milton Sheiman of Fairfield, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Barbara Sheiman, to. Kenneth Fredric Naidorf, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Naidorf of New York. A wedding in May is planned.

title: New Rochelle High Takes Track Title
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 1  Rudy Reavis in the field events and Steve Strother in the sprints led New Rochelle High School to the team title tonight in the Section 1 Class A indoor track and field championships at the West Point Field House.

title: The Good Word: New York Blues
description: To judge from various snarls and whimpers coming in on the West wind, antiNew York fever is getting worse out there by the minute. It has always puzzled me that hulking agglomerates like Detroit and Cincinnati, many times the size of ancient Athens, don't have their own distinctive cultures. But it seems that New York is in some way preventing them from this, and I'd like to know why.

title: Ellen Burstyn Plays Alice From the Inside Out
description: Alice makes all her own cothes, her son Tommy's too, as well as the kitchen curtains, the draperies, slipcovers. (The first glimpse we have of her is at the sewing machine, her blonde head ??ilted studiously, even lovingly, over the flowered fabric. She is smiling). Alice keeps her house scrubbed and shining. Alice has made roast lamb for dinner, her husband's favorite, with a picturebook peach shortcake for dessert. Alice's fork trembles as she watches Donald's face. Does he like it? Is he pleased?

title: Nancy Jones de Rohan Remarries
description: Nancy Jones de Rohan of Far Hills, N.J., and John VR. Strong of Bedminster, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Scott Kirby.

title: Gregory Rossi Becomes Fiance Of Miss McKay
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur R. McKay of Cincinnati and Weltfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann McKay, of New York, to Gregory Rossi also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Rossi of Warren, Ohio.

title: The World Is Alive With The Sound of Sounds
description: It was 6 P.M., already dark, and I could hear crickets, katydids and grasshoppers. But I wasn't in the country. I was in Iry Teibel's penthouse office in Manhattan's Flatiron Building.

title: FORD SIGNS 2 BILLS TO AID RAILROADS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) President Ford signed today two bills to provide financial aid for the nation's ailing railroads.

title: The Uneasy Partnership of Banks and REIT's
description: The banking industry, with about $11billion in shortterm loans at stake, is being forced by the threat of a rash of bankruptcies into taking half a loaf in its dealings with the financially troubled real estate investment trusts.

title: A guide to the plonking science
description: In this time of fear and trembling over the mysterious ailments of the economy, faith is sinking in the discipline that is supposed to provide cures for such ills. Economicssometimes called the dismal science,1 and, more recently, the plonking science or the black arthas come under blistering attack, not only from outside but also from within the economics profession.

title: A COAST MUSEUM IS OPENED AGAIN
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 1 Bright with a fresh coat of white paint and showing some of the 20thcentury and Southeast Asian masterpieces owned by its patron, Norton Simon, the Pasadena Art Museum quietly opened its doors this week after a ninemonth shutdown for repairs and renovation.

title: Misses Stambaugh, Cain, Stepsisters, Plan Bridals
description: Susan Reed Stambaugh and Roy Howard Beaton Jr. plan to be married in June, as do Miss Stambaugh's stepsister, Carolyn Day Cain, and James Catesby Ware Jr.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 2, 1875

title: One Look at Charlottesville Is Worth 3,000 Bicentennial Projects
description: Ready or not, here comes the Bicentennial. The celebration has been in the works for nine years, from the establishment of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission in 1966 to the setting up of its Congressionallysponsored replacement, the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration in January of last year. Bicentennial organizations exist in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam and American Samoa. More than 1,900 Bicentennial Communities have been accredited by the Bicentennial Administration. And there are now nearly 3,000 Bicentennial projects on the way, some of which are eligible for matching grants from the Federal government.

title: Victims of Violence
description: Violence and injustice are commonplace in the modern world, and they have the same immorality whether committed illegally or covered by a specious legality which contravenes the conscience of civilized humanity. Three examples this weekend stand out particularly.

title: Cab Driver Is Fatally Wounded In Attempted Midtown Robbery
description: A 34yearold taxi driver, the father of four children, was fatally wounded in an attempted midtown robbery late Friday night. Another cab driver was seriously wounded in an attempted theft early yesterday morning in the Bronx.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Television has never been at ease with Orson Welles. Watching Citizen Kane on TV is like looking at a moonlit Grand Canyon through a muddy windshield. Welles himself barely fits. The small screen seems to bulge at the sides when he's on it. Only his voice is adaptable but then, when he wishes, Welles can use his voice as resonantly and impersonally as he might a borrowed electric guitar. It sounds great playing The Wings of Man. Which explains the very odd effect of the telecast nearly two weeks ago of the Hollywood ceremonies at which the American Film Institute presented Welles with its third annual Life Achievement Award, given first to the late John Ford and then to James Cagney. The show looked and sounded like a Dean Martin roast at which the guest of honor was God.

title: Creating and Copying
description: The United States Supreme Court ruling on the nettlesome subject of photocopying has done little to remove confusion, encourage creativity in the free marketplace or allow equitable arrangements covering the various users of original works. Instead, a divided Court has thrown matters back to the years before the technological revolution resulting from xerography.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Assemblyman William P. Fitzpatrick of New Jersey, 34 years old, was killed early this morning in a twocar accident about six miles from his home in Point Pleasant. The police said the car driven by Mr. Fitzpatrick and a car driven by William E. Brufferm, 38 years old, of Brick Township, collided about 2:15 A.M. at State Highway 70 and Burnt Tavern Road.

title: Rail Plan Protests Expected
description: NEWARK  Although the dew Federal plan to create a viable railroad system in the Northeast provides for major Improvements in passenger and freight service across New Jersey, state transportation officials, industries and communities are concerned that the longterm proposal will have a traumatic effect on freight service within the state.

title: Joyce Johnson Becomes Bride
description: Joyce Elaine Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Johnson of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to William George Salatich Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Salatich of Wellseley Hills, Mass.

title: Florida and Divers Will Share Spanish Treasure
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 1 (UPI)A treasure of gold, silver and armament, which one source values at $6million, will be divided up Monday between the state and the private company whose divers retrieved it from the sea where it may have lain for 353 years.

title: $5Million Tax Loss Seen
description: BOSTON, March 1 (AP)A legislative committee charged this week that Massachusetts cities and towns had lost more than $5million in a year because of Registry of Motor Vehicles inefficiency in collecting auto excise taxes.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: One Way to Stop Fights
description: To the Sports Editor.

title: Sales Plan Would Cut Commission
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I.Two real estate brokers here are trying to establish a franchised chain of sales offices that would offer somewhat less service than the traditional brokerage, but would charge a significantly lower commission.

title: Rough Diamond
description: Jesse James is by this time a far safer proposition: we've long since stopped wondering what made him tick and what made him quit, settling for the fact that he's slipped into legend and all legend comes wrapped in a glory of cottonwool. The two rambunctious combosthe Southern States Fidelity Choir and the Red Clay Ramblersnow recelebrating his depredations and his untimely decease in Diamond Studs do not, in any case, mean to take man or myth seriously. They mean to use him as an excuse for whapping outon washboards, on banjos, on gutted pianos, on electrifying (and electrified) fiddlesas many tunes as possible, some in rhythms the desperado might have recognized, some stepped up for the Kid Champion diehards.

title: We Exist to Create A Real Black Theater
description: As the sounds of a jubilant prayer meeting died down in the small St. Marks Playhouse, the halfdozen rehearsing performers paused on the roughly improvised livingroom set and turned questioning faces toward their director, a tall black man with a white goatee, who was pacing thoughtfully. through the empty rows of seats. Was it too loud? someone asked.

title: G.O.P. ROLE SOUGHT BY CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  Conservative Republican leaders held a twoday strategy meeting this weekend in a retreat on the Chesapeake Bay to discuss ways to influence administration and party policies.

title: Mary Barrow, T. J. Hannigan Officer, to Wed
description: Maj. Gen. Robert Hilliard Barrow, U. S. M. C., commanding general of the Marine Corps Recruit Depot at Parris Island, S. C., and Mrs. Barrow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Eliza Barrow, to First Lieut. Timothy James Hannigan, U. S. M. C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Judson Hannigan of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Suffolk Police Commissioner Campaigning for Support of His Hiring Policies
description: HAUPPAUGEIn an effort to resolve the legal complications that are holding up the hiring of 123 additional police officers, Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk County Police Commissioner, has started an energetic campaign to resolve differences with plaintiffs and critics.

title: The Plant Lady: She Pays House And Office Calls
description: PRINCETONThree years ago, Till Miller bought a green jumpsuit, had her station wagon sprayed shiny green to match, placed advertisements in the local newspaper and began putting her long interest in plants to work for her. She billed herself, appropriately enough, as The Plant Lady, and started making house calls, her green satchel containing such items as snippers, cotton swabs, alcohol and florists' tape.

title: EDITH HOVER DIES; TRUSTEE AT SMITH
description: Edith Hopkins Hover, chairman of the development council of Smith College, and a trustee, died Thursday in New York Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Short Hills, N. J.

title: SHE CREATES HER OWN STYLE
description: Millie Johnstone is always looking for the importance of Now. A free spirit, she has no concern with what happened yesterday. An artist whose life style is her medium, it is what she does, the combinations of art, people, philosophies; the way she communicates with the world that make sparkling, sapphireeyed Mildred Johnstone the extraordinary person she is. The fact that she is 75 seems completely irrelevant in context with her life.

title: South Carolina's Educational TV Heads the Class
description: COLUMBIA S.C. It will come as a surprise to a great many northerners to learn that South Carolina enjoys probably the most outstandingand considering its relative wealth, certainly the most generously fundededucational television network in the entire country. Since its inception 17 years ago, South Carolina Educational Television (ETV) has been winning awards, pioneering new techniques and broadcasting so large a number of high quality instructional programs73 at presentthat it has been studied by representatives from all 49 other states and served as a model for similar systems in London and Glasgow.

title: Literati of the Playpen
description: MIAMI, March 1Jack Orr, an old friend who served his time in the press box before finding happiness as a freelance, has forwarded an essay on sportswriting that started on the front page of the Los Angeles Times and ran through the paper for 26 miles, 385 yards. It is by one David Shaw, who suggests that sports pages are better than they used to be because they pay less attention to the score than formerly and more to racism, drugs, sex, religion, gambling, psychology, cheating, dress styles and similar matters. David Shaw is a staff writer on the Times and a ghost writer who did a book for Wilt Chamberlain chronicling the sexual adventures of that roundball player. He concludes that the best sports section in the country isyou'll never believe thisin the Los Angeles Times.

title: Texaco Workers Return
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., March 1 (UPI)About 4,200 members of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union are to return to work tomorrow under a twoyear contract signed yesterday with Texaco, Inc. According to F. D. Dorr, manager of the Texaco plant here, the contract calls for increases of 75 cents an hour for hurly employes and $130 a month to salaried employes, effective yesterday.

title: College Schedules Alcoholism Series
description: EDISONA threesession minicourse, Alcoholism and Industry, will be offered at Middesex County College on three consecutive Mondays, beginning March 6. It will be conducted by Gail Gleason Milgram of East Brunswick, an associate professor at Rutgers.

title: 10,000 IN PROTEST AT GALLO WINERY
description: MODESTO, Calif., March 1About 10,000 members and supporters of the United Farm Workers converged today on the E. & J. Gallo winery here, ending a weeklong, 110mile march to focus attention on the union's nationwide boycott of Gallo products.

title: Fining of 700 Miners Ruled Abuse of a Judge's Power
description: CINCINNATI, March 1 (AP) A Federal judge in Columbus abused his power when he imposed contempt citations and fines on 700 southeastern Ohio miners last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has ruled.

title: The Dream Of Troy
description: These two books are both concerned with the discovery of the preClassical civilizations of the Aegean area. The Dream of Troy is a biography of Henrich Schliemann, the first excavator of Troy and Mycenae. The Secret of Crete tells the story of the excavation of the Minoan culture of Crete, and claims to interpret the Minoan palaces as necropolises.

title: The Rise And Fall of The DC10
description: The DC10 crash outside Paris a year ago was the worst air disaster of all time, and it was not just because the 346 deaths amounted to almost twice the highest previous toil. What made the disaster even much more shocking was that it could have been averted in so many ways. Probably never before has disaster been so inevitablea culmination of clearly manifest dangers and slovenly response, at many levels, to repeated advance warnings.

title: OFFICIALS LINKED TO BELL SCANDAL
description: ST. LOUIS, March 1State agencies in Missouri and Kansaa that regulate the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company and decide what rates it may charge have been rattled by disclosures that some of their members received gratuities from the phone company.

title: Reuss (D.Wis.), A Demanding Man
description: WASHINGTONExcept for the time the gun went off, the banking career of Henry Schoellkopf Reuss could hardly be called memorable.

title: NEW ILEITIS TEST AIDS IN DIAGNOSIS
description: The first diagnostic test to distinguish Ileitis from other common boweldiseases has been developed by a team of doctors at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sadat: III Squeeze Play
description: CAIROOne thing clear from any conversation with Anwar elSadat is the fact that Moscow is trying to subject the Egyptian President to a squeeze play because he has gone along with Henry Kissinger's stepbystep approach to negotiating a Middle East settlement. Russia prefers an immediate Geneva conference where its diplomacy and propaganda could play an influential role.

title: Two doomsdays and one silly ass
description: There are worse things than being alone, Ann Burden writes in her diarynotebook as a man in a strange green plastic suit approaches her home. How much worse she is about to find out.

title: Philippines Conducts A Vote Just For Marcos
description: MANILAThe most interesting question that can be asked about the referendum Ferdinand E. Marcos staged in the Philippines last week is why he bothered to hold it at all. Essentially the referendum gave the 27 million Filipino voters a choice between the President's faintly regal style of benevolent despotism and nothing, for there was never any commitment on Mr. Marcos's part to return to the open political system prescribed by the constitution if the voters said they didn't like his martial law regime.

title: ExC.I.A. Aide Denies Slayings Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) A former official of the Central Intelligence Agency who worked on an internal C.I.A. investigation denies a CBS News report that the inquiry uncovered evidence of agency involvement in the assassination of foreign officials.

title: EDITH WALTON, 71, A RADIOTV FIGURE
description: Edith Howard Walton, television and radio panelist and, magazine editor, died yesterday in Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived here and in Sandwich, Mass.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass market paperbacks are sold on newsstands, in supermarkets and varied; stores, as wit as bookstores. This analysts is based on reports from representative wcholesalers and chains with more than 9.000 outlets in the United Staten.

title: Penn Tops Brown for 6th Ivy Title in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1  The University of Pennsylvania won the Ivy League basketball championship tonight for the sixth straight year, routing Brown University, 8959, in the Palestra before 6,254 fans.

title: MAJOR REVISIONS IN CITY BUDGETING PROPOSED IN STUDY
description: A drastic overhaul of the city's budget process, providing for extensive public participation, a greatly enhanced role for the City Council, and an end to the Mayor's dual executive and legislative responsibility was proposed yesterday by the Temporary State Charter Revision Commission for New York City.

title: Unbeaten Foolish Pleasure Wins Flamingo as a 25 Shot Should
description: MIAMI, March 1Undefeated Foolish Pleasure won his ninth race today when he outran nine rivals in the $131,600 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah and swept past a milestone on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: EXAIDES IN GREECE FACING REPRISALS
description: ATHENS, Feb. 26Dr. Ioannis Koulis, a professor of economics at Athens University for 25 years, has been suspended from his teaching post and is living on half salary while a special tribunal decides whether to dismiss him permanently.

title: Singh One of Cordero's Five
description: Singh carried the silks of Cynthia Phipps to triumph in the $58,100 Swift Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, with the incredible Angel Cordero doing the riding. In guiding Singh to the success, at a return of $4 for $2, Cordero. scored his fourth of five victories of the afternoon.

title: ART VIEW
description: The news that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has severely abridged the scope of its longawaited exhibition of French Painting From 1774 to 1830: Age of Revolution has sent tremors of shock, disappointment and anger through art circles here. For some of us, certainly, the lastminute decision of Thomas P. F. Hoving, the director of the Met, to impose a 25 per cent cut on this exhibitiona cut from, a total of 206 items to approximately 150is convincing proof (if, indeed, further proof were needed after the cynically conceived Impressionist Epoch exhibition) that boxoffice considerations now hold sway over all other priorities in the museum's exhibition policy.

title: Stinger Captures Southern Ocean Racing Crown
Notes: Join a College And See the World
description: AN increasing number of travelstudy programs abroad are being offered by educational institutions throughout the United States these days. The programs, which use the cities and cultural institutions of the world as classrooms, combine vacation, travel and learning and range from oneweek seminars on music in Vienna, theater in London and archeology in Mexico to summer sessions in French literature at a chateau in France and a twomonth tour of India devoted to academic subjects.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Excavations at the Koster archeological site in West Central Illinois are providing a picture of the life of early man in North America that corrects several common misconceptions.

title: Upgrading Moves Ahead in Red Hook
description: After two decades of stagnation, the Red Hook section of Brooklyn is beginning to stir with new development.

title: Giants Also Conduct A Spring Training
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 1Henry Stuckey cut his hair and put on a few pounds, but he is not about to cut out the aggressive, psychic style that he hopes will settle the New York Giants' problems at right cornerback for next season.

title: Article 3  No Title
Civil Service Setup Assayed
description: TRENTONA special legislative report lends support to those skeptics who doubt that Civil Service jobs are filled purely on the basis of merit.

title: How to Order Tickets For Olympic Games In 1976 at Montreal
description: Montgomery Ward has been named the official and exclusive ticket agency in the United States for the 1976 Summer Olympic Games in Canada by the organizing committee of the Games and the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Letters: Us vs Them On Pseudospeciation
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: A Better English Creation
description: Franz Joseph Haydn was 65 years old when he completed The Creation in 1798, but the music is so optimistic, so vital, so fresh in content and style that it sounds as though it had come from a composer in the springof his life.

title: PRICE IS REDUCED FOR ABU DHABI OIL
description: PARIS, March 1 (AP)Abu Dhabi and Western oil companies have reached an arrangement to lower prices and increase production, the Persian Gulf emirate's Minister of Oil, Mani Caid alOtaiba, said today.

title: Chaplin Is in London For Knighthood Rite
description: LONDON, March 1 (AP)Charlie Chaplin flew into London today to be dubbed Sir Charlie at Buckingham Palace, and told newsmen that being knighted by Queen Elizabeth II Tuesday will be one of the proudest moments of my life.

title: Final Salute to 3 Troopers
description: WESTHAMPTON  Sundance, Shalom and Wilkerson were buried here last week by the men who rode and loved them.

title: Stopped Clock Clue to Start of Fire
description: A stopped clock and two feet of beaded wire were the clues that helped solve the case of the burnedout telephone company building.

title: Brazil Sees Terrorism Curbed, Stresses Development
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1The President of Brazil, Gen. Ernesto Geisel, announced today that his Government could now concentrate on economic, social and political development because security forces had brought internal terrorism under control.

title: Bonds Makes Debut With Yanks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1  When Bobby Bonds arrived at the ball park for his first Yankee workout today, Manager Bill Virdon told him to go out and play the way you can play and do the things you can do.

title: Encounter: A Visit With an Aged Sheik
description: AFTER a month in Jerusalem I visit Hebron to seek out the tombs of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, which are held sacred by the Moslems. I've had my fill of the war, of abrasive interviews with shrill V.I.P.'s and Black Panthers, of bereaved relatives and maimed, silent young men in hospitals. I've had enough for now of modern Israel, and drive out to the hills of Judea in search of the Holy Land.

title: Alyson Adler Is Betrothed
description: Alyson Koeppel Adler, who is in her third year at the Columbia University School of Law, and William Hadfield Green, who is completing his studies at the Suffolk University Law School in Boston, plan to be married in June. Both are graduates of Trinity College in Hartford.

title: CITY PUSHES DRIVE ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: Beame administration officials said yesterday that a new productivity drive stepping up field supervision by deputy commissioners had yielded a substantial increase in complaints against employes for malingering and unauthorized absences.

title: Booming Aspen Worries About the Los Angelization of the Rockies
description: LESS than a century ago, Aspen, Colo., was a boom town where hundreds of painted women nightly wooed cash from the pockets of miners who by day gouged silver from the surrounding hills. Between 1880 and 1890 the townnearly 8,000 feet high in the Rockiesbuilt no fewer than 75 proper Victorian bordellos, 200 saloons, three banks, the brick threestory Wheeler Opera House, the plush Hotel Jerome and 10 churches.
