Then, with the collapse of silver prices, Aspen's bubble burst. Its population plummeted from 12,000 to 700; the girls moved away to richer lodes.

title: Lehman Women Capture Tourney
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., March 1 (AP)Grace Johnson tossed in 20 points as Lehman College of New York won the state women's collegiate basketball tournament with a 5144 victory over Brockport State today.

title: U.S. REPORT FINDS EXCESSIVE ISSUING OF FOOD STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Errors in certification by state agencies gave a broad sample of food stamp recipients 23.2 per cent more assistance than they were legally entitled to in the six months ended June 30, 1974, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: PORNOGRAPHY FOR WOMEN
description: The handlettered cardboard sign, posted outside a new peepshow parlor in Manhattan's fashionable East 50's, bore the usual enticing message: ADULTS ONLY. Underneath, in smaller, cruder letters, the management had scrawled what it considered a liberated afterthought: Women Also Welcome.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: CHESS
description: As a budding 14yearold master in 1942, 1 used to think that a Frank Marshall swindle (that's what he dubbed his speculative combinations) was a punishable offense under chess law.

title: St. Peter's, Syracuse Triumph
description: With another victory, the last apparent ingredient necessary to gain admittance to the E.C.A.C. basketball playoffs, St. Peter's succeeded but Manhattan failed in yesterday's double  feature at Madison Square Garden.

title: The theory and practice of poetry
description: Neither as mixed nor lumpish as one glance suggests, this bag of books contains three items that might be marked Poetic Theory by Practicing Poets and two that might be labeled For Popular Consumption. Among the former the first in general interest is perhaps the collection of transcribed talks given by Allen Ginsberg on a tour of colleges he made in 1971. The second consists of statements and manifestoes designed to show the seminal theories behind the new poetry from the time of its first stirrings early in this century. The third offers a series of taperecorded interviews: poets telling how they work, What they think is important, how they see themselves among their contemporaries.

title: The Shattered Mind
description: In 1861, a young French physician named Paul Broca published an account of a patient who had suffered a stroke years earlier that had left him almost totally deprived of speech. Rather than rendering him completely mute, however, the stroke had spared until the end the patient's ability to speak in a short, laborious telegraphic style.

title: State Auditor Allows NursingHome Operator Half the Cost of RollsRoyce
description: The State Health Department and Dr. Carl Neuman confront a common problem: Is half a Rolls betten than none?

title: Drag Ballet: Can Men Make It In a Women's World?
description: To the strains of Glazunov's music for Rayrnonda, a ballerina wafts across the stage in clouds of tulle. She glances mysteriously from beneath bluelidded eyes, fringed with thickly mascaraed lashes. A haunting, ethereal smile plays across the generous scarlet mouth. She rises ecstatically, and with clumsy grace, to the tips of her satinshod toes. Her heavilymuscled arms caress the air. Soaring leaps and bounding jumps flex and swell the bulging muscles of her legs. As she dances, the sweat trickles down her brow, then down her strong neck and hairy chest.

title: New Hampshire Signs Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Gov. Meidrim Thomson has signed an agreement that makes an additional 2,000 New Hampshire citizens eligible for immediate unemployment benefits. Kew Hampshire is the last state to agree with the Labor Department on a contract making unemployment payments aivailable to persons not eligible for normal compensation.

title: PACT IS REACHED ON WATER TUNNEL
description: An agreement that could return 1500 construction workers to the job of digging the city's Third Water Tunnel is to be submitted to the Board of Estimate for approval next Thursday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Lon Nol of Cambodia, whose Government is threatened by Communistled insurgents, was reported yesterday to be willing to step aside if he is a barrier to a peace settlement. Senator Dewey F. Bartlett, an Oklahoma Democrat, said this was the interpretation that the United States Ambassador, John Gunther Dean, made of statements by Marshall Lon Not. Senator Bartlett is a member of a Congressional delegation that visited Phnom Penh yesterday. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: West Berlin Voting Today As Candidate Is Still Held
description: BERLIN, March 1A confused feeling of bafflement rules in this isolated, halfdecayed, halfdynamic city as 1.6 million voters prepare to elect a Mayor tomorrowwith the main opposition candidate somewhere in the hands of radical leftist kidnappers.

title: Fans to Get Close Look When Sets Open May 6
description: The New York Sets will open the 1975 World Team Tennis season at the Nassau Coliseum with a doubleheader on May 6.

title: STAMPS
description: The United Nations, in its first commemorative issue of the year, is heralding the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, some already serving mankind, others with a potential soon to be realized.

title: Teen Arts Festival To Be Held in May
description: TRENTON  Dr. Fred G. Burke, Commissioner of the Department of Education, has announced that the annual New Jersey Teen Arts Festival will take place at the State Museum here on May 5, 6, 7 and 12, 13, 14.

title: Executive Branch Is Now Many Blooming Twigs
description: WASHINGTONIf an expert on how the executive branch works had been put to sleep two years ago and awakened the last weekjust after the last of the Watergate defendants had been sentenced to prisonhe would have found major and perhaps surprising changes in the institution.

title: Stocks Turn Down After 5week Gain
description: Profittaking snubbed the stock market's recent strong advance last week as the list ended lower in active trading.

title: Nuisance Birds Leave Army Plant for North
description: MILAN, Tenn., March 1 (AP)  The millions of birds roosting on the grounds of the Milan Army Ammunition Plant that the Army wants to eliminate may get away without losing a feather.

title: BREAKING INTO THE WORLD
description: t isn't easy to get back in the world you once renounced so lightly for love and marriage and baby carriage, as Louise Feinsot found when she tried. All those hurtling bodies at rush hour are moving in lockstep up that pyramid. Even though there's not a public relations job anywhere that'more exacting than getting a bunch of untrained, unruly volunteers to work to a deadline and even though I've never met a crisis in business that could compare with the crises you have to deal with at home, it doesn't count. You aren't one Brownie point closer to a job in middle or upper management, she says with a note of indignation in the wellmodulated voice. Rather insulting to us, isn't it, when you think about it?

title: Louise Atwater, G. F. Reinhart 3d Marry in Jersey
description: Louise Christine Atwater, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Verne S. Atwater of Ridgewood and Cape May, N. J., was married last evening to George Frank Reinhart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reinhart Jr. of Wyckoff, N. J., and Wellfleet, Mass.

title: Washington Is Full, So Richardson's In London
description: For Britain, the arrival this weekend of the Bostonian Elliot Lee Richardson as the new Ambassador to the Court of St. James is much more than an offering in advance of the forthcoming bicentennial celebration, for he is a man of many accomplishments and many ambitions. He has been an Under Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, Attorney General and he has been mentioned as a possible successor to Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, and as a possible Presidential contender.

title: Mary Bonham Becomes Bride Of Jared Silver
description: Mary Faith Bonham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Bonham of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Drakes Island, Me., was married yesterday evening to Jared Neil Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Silver of New Rochelle.

title: Cordero at Aqueduct
Australia Gives Cyclones SexEquality Treatment
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 1 (Reuters)  Australia, which first began the practice of giving cyclones women's names, has decided to end this as a gesture to the United Nations International Women's Year.

title: PHONE WORK GETS GOAL OF 2 WEEKS
description: Hundreds of workmen yesterday began the vast, intricate task of replacing equipment in the fireravaged New York Telephone Company switching center at 13th Street and Second Avenue. The company set a goal of two weeks for the restoration of service to 173,000 dead phones.

title: BANK THEFT RISE AROUSES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The nation's bank robbery rate has soared nearly 52 per cent in the last year, setting off a growing dispute between the Justice Department and the nation's bankers over what to do about the problem.

title: Builders, Hurt by Rising Costs, Are Halting Many Big Projects
description: FORT LEE  Although sand, cement, cinder blocks and other construction materials are stockpiled at a building site here, the lifts that rise to the top of two unfinished 30story apartment houses are silent.

title: Ruling on Hair Transplant
description: LANSING, Mich., March 1 (UPI)Attorney General Frank J. Kelley says that the process of hair transplants by the use of skin grafts to the scalp constitutes the practice of medicine. Mr. Kelley's opinion this week on the question was requested by the Medical Practice Board.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLUMNathan H. March 2, 1972. A friend remembered. EMPLOYEES OF LAURRIET PRTG CO.

title: Suit Seeks Bilingual Education In Suffolk
description: PATCHOGUEA suit filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last Wednesday on behalf of Spanishspeaking children in the PatchogueMedford school district asks that the district establish bilingual programs to provide equal educational opportunities for students with Englishlanguage deficiencies.

title: MRS. JOHN HABBERTON
description: Dagmar Lundevall Habberton, wife of John Habherton, president of the Business Council for International Understanding, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She lived at 80 Park Avenue and in New Milford, Conn.

title: Hemophiliac Aid Blocked in Texas By Lack of Funds
description: FORT WORTH March 1A pioneer program here to supply the nation's largest colony of hemophiliacs with blood, but without using welfare funds, has been abandoned because of economic difficulties.

title: Design
description: Few people looking for a country home would consider buying a Victorian mansion, but thinking big instead of small turned up a good buy for graphic designer Arnold Saks and his wife, Joanna. Five years ago they bought a sixteenroom white clapboard house and eight and a half acres with 25 beautiful specimen trees for $38,000 in upstate New York. The size of the house had put off many prospective buyers, and it had dangled on the market for several years. It was a white elephant, says Arnold Saks, but he and his wife liked the spaciousness of the rooms, the seven fireplaces and the Victorian architectural details.

title: Some Easy NoWork Perennials
description: Many perennials are troublefree and permanent. They contribute flower color to the landscape, year after year and ask little in return.

title: Port Here Is Healthy In Spite of Recession
description: At a time when the nation's economy has been reeling with setbacks, the great seaport of New York and New Jersey appears in strong health.

title: St. John's Turns Back Providence
description: St. John's entered its final regularseason basketball game yesterday assured of a spot in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's metropolitan area playoffs and raced to a 8870 victory over Providence at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Hamptons Weigh Curb on Groupers
description: SOUTHAMPTONA tough, new ordinance that would require homeowners and realestate brokers to obtain licenses and file registration statements when they rent houses is under consideration in this East End town as part of its fight against groupers.

title: All the Tax Loopholes: How Much Do They Cost?
description: WASHINGTON  Tucked away in chapter F of a technical booklet accompanying the new Federal budget is a program that Costs $91billionyet does not appear in the budget itself at all.

title: BANK THEFT RISE AROUSES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The nation's bank robbery rate has soared nearly 52 per cent in the last year setting off a growing dispute between the Justice Department and the nation's bankers over what to do about the problem.

title: Cathy A. Kaufman Fiancee of Mark Iger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaufman of Kings Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathy Ann Kaufman, to Mark M. Iger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Iger of West Orange, N. J. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Picasso

title: 4 Council Hearings Set Here This Week
description: City Council committees will hold the following four public hearings this week:

title: Nassau Sets Study On Industrial Waste
description: H. John Plock Jr., the Nassau County Commissioner of Public Works, announced last week that the department's Division of Sanitation and Water Supply had begun a feasibility study to determine the most efficient and economical method of handling industrial waste sludge under revised Federal disposal restrictions.

title: Filing Form 1040 for a Recession Year
description: Taxes are an unpleasant subject in any yeareven more so in a recession year. But some individuals may find modest benefits in economic adversityunexpected tax deductions for employment agency fees, for example, or for the penalty imposed by savings institutions for premature withdrawal of time deductible for the first time this year on an unitemized return. For those hard hit in the stock market, there may be deductions for worthless holdings or for losses on securities transactions.

title: Steingut Seeks State Bank
description: ALBANY, March 1 (AP)Mr. Steingut today proposed the creation of a stateowned bank to compete with private banks. which he said were making too few mortgage loans, charging excessive interest rates and failing to meet their social and economic responsibilities.

title: MILITARY PAY PUT ABOVE CIVILIANS'
description: WASHINGTON, MAR. 1 Somewhat to its surprise, the Defense Department is coming to the conclusion that someone the military, rather than being underpaid, is earning substantially more than the average civilian worker.

title: SciencePrize Finalist in Family Tradition
description: Arthur Lander, a 16yearold senior at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn, was in Washington yeaterday demonstrating the biology project that brought him to the finals of the Westinghouse Science Talent Search and a possible $10,000 scholarship.

title: Novgorod Renovates Churches
description: NOVGOROD, U.S.S.R.The old churches of Novgorod are nearly all silent now. The best have been converted into tourist museums. Others have been bricked up as warehouses. One is a restaurant, another a tirerepair shop.

title: The Big Goals of the U.D.C.
description: Amid the controversy over the financial troubles and management of the Urban Development Corporation, little attention has been focused on the relationship between the current problems and the task for which the agency was originally created: to provide housing, particularly for lowincome families, increase job opportunities and upgrade blighted and deteriorating areas throughout the state.

title: REV. CHARLES KING, A BAPTIST OFFICIAL
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 1 (UPI)The Rev. Charles King, the first black elected to a high office in the Southern Baptist Convention, died here yesterday, three weeks after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old.

title: Rich Spend Away Recession Jitters in the Swiss Alps
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland One of the fastergrowing afterski sports here and in Gstaad is the purchase of fabulous jewels.

title: Some Glimmers of Hope
description: PERHAPS it's merely a seasonal optimism timed to the approach of spring, which always seems to spark the renewed enthusiasm of businessmen, but the fact is that a bit more confidence is being expressed in some quarters over the economic outlook now than was the case only a month or so ago.

title: Bidding a Billion for Peabody Coal
description: Within the next 30 days, the lid of secrecy may be lifted from one of the biggest business deals on recordthe sale of the Peabody Coal Company for an estimated $1billion.

title: The Moral Issues
description: As two Presidents have done before him, Gerald Ford is seeking continued American support for a Southeast Asian regime on grounds of morality and United States selfinterest.

title: Prize Sheep Killed in Fire
description: ACWORTH, N. H., March 1 (AP)A number of prizewinning Hampshires and Dorsets were among 187 sheep that died when fire swept through a barn owned by William Austin near here Thursday, members of the family said.

title: Food
description: In choosing a menu, the underlying rule is to Avoid redundancy: two sauces with the same base, two starches, two dishes with pastry dough, etc. The choice of recipes is a question of common sense and personal taste. The ones on these pages use a variety of flavors, from earthy onion to spicy pork to rich caramel. As a final complementary flavor, I would recommend a hearty red wine from the Loire Valley, such as a Bourgueil or Chinon.

title: Old Queens House Gets Reprieve
description: A preRevolutionary Dutch stone houseone of the oldest in the cityhas gained a reprieve from the wrecker's squad. The socalled Onderdonk house, at 1820 Flushing Avenue in Ridgewood was scheduled to be demolished early last week, but after an 11thhour effort by local residents the city's Housing and Development Administration postponed wrecking operations indefinitely.

title: Big Brother' at Hand
description: Daniel Schorr has reported for CBS News that President Ford fears current Investigations will uncover several assassinations of foreign officials by the Central Intlligence Agency. Mr. Schorr's report followed testimony by, Attorney General Edward Levi that the late J. Edgar Hoover, as Director of the Federal Bureau of Intelligence, had kept and used files of derogatory information on public personalities, and allowed the F.B.I. to be used by various Presidents for domestic political purposes.

title: Experts Doubt U.S. Weapons Sales to Arabs Will Tip Strategic Balance Against Israelis
description: The United States is providing weapons to Israel and some of her Arab enemies in the Persian Gulf area simultaneously, but, according to American and British experts, the military balance will be little affected immediately.

title: The End Of the World
description: Lest we do ourselves in first with some nuclear holocaust, there are any number of ways our planet can endall perhaps as terrible, some more fascinating and beautiful to contemplate than others. The moon could move too close to the earth, lifting up catastrophic tides; or the moon could shatter into rings much like Saturn's, shadowing the earth in an endless ice age. There is only one certainty the world will end.

title: Frank Robinson's Test
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 1As major league baseball's first black manager, Frank Robinson might be assumed to be an unchallenged ruler of his black players. But that is a racial oversimplification, as any white manager who has been challenged by a white player will confirm. The test for Robinson as the manager of the Cleveland Indians will be measured by many of his players, black and white, according to his success or failure in motivating a black teammate, George Hendrick, the casual center fielder. Robinson's predecessor, Ken. Aspromonte, failed. When a manager loses control of a player, says one of the Indians, he loges the respect of the other players. With it, Aspromonte also lost his job. Robinson's rsum included a rapport with Hendrick that will be under a microscope, beginning Monday when the Indians' full squad perspires for the first time.

title: French President Dines With Tracker's Family
description: PARIS, March 1 (AP)  A truck driver said today he had entertained President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his wife for dinner last night in his cottage west of Paris.

title: On Cambodia and the U.S.
description: PEKING At this moment, on the bloody land of small and unhappy Cambodia, the last act of a tragedy pitting countryman against countryman is being played. I urge the American people to take into consideration what I, in the name of the United National Front and the Royal Government of National Union of Cambodia, have the honor to tell them. These last days, the highest officials of the United States Government have spoken continually of the necessity for the American people to help the Cambodian people survive and to prevent Cambodia from falling.

title: Manufacture to Murder: The History of a Rossi .38
description: Since 1968, the importation of handguns into the United States has been prohibited by Federal law. But American companies can legally assemble these weapons from imported parts.

title: Hockey Violence: Who and Especially Why
description: There have been numerous cleanplaying craftsmen in the National Hockey Leagueskaters who would rather switch than fight, who believe that a deft feint or a spurt around the defense is more valuable to their team and more appreciated by the fans than a jab in the mouth or a spear in the groin.

title: Carole Riley Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Francis J. Riley of Manomet, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carole Ann Riley, to James Joseph Ford, son of Thomas P. Ford of New York and Madison, Conn., and the late Jean Smith Ford. A May 3 weddine in Manomet is planned.

title: Pirate Loot Still Sought In Canada
description: OAK ISLAND, Nova Scotia Deep in the rocky soil beneath this tiny island 600 miles northeast of New York an American contractor is digging for buried treasure.

title: Carolyn Lord Gives A Mixed Panorama Of Dance Elements
description: It never occurred to me that Betsy Ross, an Indian squaw and a woman in sciencefiction garb had a common meeting ground, any more than one of the Pilgrim fathers and a man in golfing plus fours. But Carolyn Lord grouped them and others together at the La Mama annex Friday evening in her production of The Mystic Writings of Paul Revere. The event was a puzzling panorama.

title: Fiscal Adversity Makes Beame and Goldin Strange Bedfellows
description: Mayor Beams and Controller Harrison J. Goldin, who half a year ago were feuding so bitterly that they stopped speaking, have lately struck a truce.

title: Data for Wouldbe Diggers
description: The Archeological Institute of America, 260 West Broadway, New York 10013, puts out a list of excavations at which volunteers are accepted. The list costs $1, is organized according to country and includes a brief description of the site, cost, living conditions and the person in charge. Many of its digs are for students who want university credit. The Institute advises that its list is incomplete, and that interested people should look at the advertisements in Archeology Magazine.

title: Jerseyan Robbed and Shot Near Aqueduct Race Track
description: A Somerville, N.J., man was shot during a holdup in a parking lot near the Aqueduct race track in Ozone Park, Queens, last night, the police reported. The two robbers, one of whom had a revolver, escaped with the man's wallet containing $400.

title: Soviet Dissident Reported Leaving for Canada Soon
description: MOSCOW, March. 1 (AP)Viktor Krasin, onceprominent in the Soviet civil rights movement; has been granted an exit visa and will soon emigrate to Canada, dissident sources said today.

title: City Seeking $1.7Million For Times Sq. Smut Fight
description: The city has applied for $1.7million in Federal funds to organize a study group for a oneyear fight against prostitutes, purveyors of pornography and socalled message parlors in Times Square and other midtown areas.

title: Syphilis High in Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 1 (UPI)Florida has the highest Infectious syphilis rate in the United States, according to the State Division of Health. In a survey released Tuesday, health officials reported 35,3 cases of infectious syphilis per 100,000 population last year a 73 per cent Increase since 1970.

title: Evan Krichevsky to Wed Nancy Heller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Heller of Larchmont, N. Y., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Susan Helder, to Evan John Krichevsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Mican Krichevsky of Wheaton, Md.

title: Museum Dissidents Plan Ouster Action
description: A petition drive aimed at ousting the chairman of the board of trustees of the Queens Museum and restructuring the museum's operation is under way, sponsored by an ad hoc committee of the Friends of the Museum.

title: April Marriage Set By Miss Wohlforth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Wohlforth of Demarest, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Wohlforth to Kenichi Tatsuno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenzo Tatsuno, also of Demarest.

title: Epilogue
description: On Sept. 1, 1974, about 10,000 people gathered in Branch Brook Park in Newark, N.J., for a Puerto Rican festival. Before the day was over, the festival had become a riot that lasted for three days. Newark police said they were putting down serious disorders; spokesmen for the Puerto Rican community said citizens were the victims of police violence.

title: On Keeping a Keen Edge
description: A properly sharpened cutting tool  regardless of whether it be a kitchen knife, chisel or plane blddenot only makes the work go faster and with less effort, it is actually also safer to use. Dull tools force one to exert more pressure than would normally be required, and hence the tool is more likely to slip and cause accidents.

title: Russian Captures Class A Ski Jump
description: IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., March 1 (AP)Vladimor Frolov and Gari Napalkov of the Soviet Union took top honors today in the first day of competition of the Pine Mountain ski jumping tournament.

title: BlackCulture Chorus Will Make Debut Tuesday
description: Seated with her back to the empty auditorium of Alice Tully Hall, Dorothy Maynor, the soprano, conducted with one small, graceful hand, the other at her mouth to hush the chorus.

title: 4 Die in Czech Explosion
description: PRAGUE, March 1 (Reuters) Four persons were killed and 28 injured in an explosion last night at a power plant at Brno, in southern Czechoslovakia, authorities announced today.

title: EDWARD W. SANDERSON
description: Edward W. Sanderson, who had been managing editor of two publications on diabetes for the last 20 years, was found dead Thursday, apparently of natural causes, at his home, 225 East 46th Street. He was 62 years old.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: The Enemy Is Red, Cruel and, After 5 Years, Little Known
description: PHNOM PENHOur side is more civilized the American embassy official was saying, as he sought to explain to a newsman why it was necessary for the United States to continue supporting the Government of Marshal Lon Nol in Phnom Penh against the Communistled Cambodian insurgents. If the other side took over, they would kill ali the educated people, the teachers, the artists, the intellectuals and that would be a step backward toward barbarism.

title: BYPLAY IS HEATED AT ATTICA TRIALS
description: BUFFALOAs the two major murder cases resulting from the 1971 Attica prison rebellion are being heard in the Erie County Courthouse here, one by a jury and another by a judge in pretrial hearings, the lesser contests to stem from the rebellion go largely ignored.

title: Soaring Costs Threaten Huge Center for Downtown Detroit
description: DETROIT, March 1In these waning days of winter, the wind slices off the Detroit River onto a muddy construction site next to the toll booths where a huge sign reads Tunnel to Canada.

title: DoItYourself Plan For Garage Killed
description: An automotive service center, stripped of a doityourself repair feature that drew vigorous opposition from neighborhood residents, was approved last week by the City Planning Commission over the strenuous objection of its Queens member.

title: About the Giants . .
description: The Giants have signed nine more free agents, including Ed Siewell, a 245pound center from Slippery Rock, and Sid Bond, a 270pound tackle who flunked a trial with the Philadelphia Eagles and is working as a jailer in a sheriff's office in Fort Worth . . . Arnsparger said he had talked to Eldridge Small after last season about a possible return to wide receiver (the position he played in college), but Small preferred staying on defense . . Arnsparger also appeared to rule out any shift of Pete Athas ffrom left cornerback, saying, I'm not sure he can play weak safety. Athas has played out his option and will become a free agent if he does not sign a new contract by May I . . . Robert Giblin, a defensive hack from Houston and a fourth round draft choice, was one of three drafted rookies who did not attend the camp. Giblin is recovering from minor knee surgery. The other missing rookies were John Tate and Mike Mahoney.

title: For Pitchers on Mets, Recession Not Problem
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1Randy Sterling doesn't see where there are any unemployment problems for pitchers in the New York Mets' camp.

title: Tizna, $25, Wins Run at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif. March 1 (AP)  Tizna, a 6yearold mare from Chile, today captured the $100,000 Invitational Santa Margarita Handicap for the second year in a row, reaching the wire 1 lengths in front of Susan's Girl.

title: Builders Glum on U.S. Subsidy Plan
description: Section 8 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974the rentsupplement program that is the cornerstone of the NixonFord approach to subsidized housingis, according to builders and municipal officials, simply unworkable in New York City.

title: The Opera
description: The Saturday afternoon Ring cycle at the Metropolitan Opera moved on to Die Walkre yesterday. Since it brings in Brnnhilde for the first time in the tetralogy, it meant the first appearance of Birgit Nilsson in the role this season.

title: Fighting the Recession. . .
description: President Ford's economic program, as spelled out little more than a month ago, was founded on the concept of a triple crisis of inflation, recession and energy shortagecrises of roughly equal urgency.

title: New & Novel
description: Dr. Lionel Humphrey Salt, J. B. Priestley's fusion of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, is about to shake the dust of Birkden from his shoes after seven years. It's really about time. Birkden is a scruffy Midlands mill town with little to interest Salt except crime. Then one of his patients disappears, a young girl with a severe kidney dysfunction, and Salt simply has to hang around long enough to do his stuff. It's a formidable exercise, distinguished by Priestley's undiminished gusto for storytelling. The Doctor's investigations snowball to include the daughter of another missing person, a bookseller. Also Sir Arnold Donnington, head of AngloBelgian Fabrics and the town's leading citizen, plus the cream of the Birkden underworld. When he is done intriguing, Priestley indulges his passion for pairing off all unattached survivors. Delicious.

title: Plastic Netting Raises Shellfish Yield
description: MONTAUKDr. Henry W. Moeller knows how to turn adversity into scientificand probably economictriumph. While unsuccessfully experimenting with the cultivation of seaweed, Dr. Moeller, a botanist at the New York Ocean Science Laboratory here and an associate professor of biology at Dowling College in Oakdale, has developed a mobile method of raising mollusks in plastic netting that not only allows growers to avoid polluted waters, but also increases the yield.

title: Unbeaten Indiana Five Records Victory No. 31
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 1 (AP)Steve Green scored Indiana's first 10 points of the second half today and finished with 29 in leading the topranking and undefeated Hoosiers to an 8678 Big Ten basketball victory over Ohio State.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT announced last Wednesday its preliminary plans to reorganize the bankrupt Northeastern railroads by stripping away unprofitable freight routes and investing more than $7billion in a longterm rehabilitation program.... Also on Wednesday the Senate passed two emergency measures to aid bankrupt railroads, mainly the Penn Central and Erie Lackawanna.

title: Art: Shows at 3 Colleges Cover a Wide Range
description: Three New Jersey colleges are currently offering art exhibitions of merit.

title: Art Deco Through the Camera's Eye
description: The current exhibition of Art Deco photographs at the Brooklyn Museum is a major contribution to the examination of this important architectural style because it sharpens and broadens our vision of Art Deco buildings in New York.

title: The Morality of SelfDestruction
description: When moral theologians in the mid1960's began questioning the validity of sets of absolutes governing human conduct, it was largely in the context of changing sexual morality. Very quickly, however, more substantive issues were joined, including the matter of death itself, particularly the individual's right to die with dignity.

title: Engagements
description: GriffithsRitter

title: How to Ice Skate: Stand, Hold On, Go
description: Many people ask whether they are too old to begin skating and, simultaneously, how old their children should be before they start them on the ice.

title: Ballet: Jooss's The Big City Offered by the Joffrey
description: It is nearly 30 years since Kurt Jooss's ballet The Big City was last seen in New Yorkon the stage of the City Center 55th Street Theater in January, 1947. Then the company was the Ballets Jooss, Mr. Jooss's own troupe. Friday night, on the same stage, The Big City returned, this time danced by the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

title: Who Shall Live?
description: The United States now spends almost 8 per cent of its Gross National Product on health caremore than any other nation in the world, almost double what it spent a few decades ago. The costs are rising by more than 10 per cent a year. We have more physicians per capita, and twice as many surgeons per capita, as most Western nations. Yet still we are not as healthy as we want to be, and the problems are human and social as well as economic.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks open a fourgame home stand Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. with a game against the Boston Celtics and John Havlicek, who reached the 20,000point career mark last month. The Knicks play the Detroit Pistons at 8 P.M. Saturday.

title: Leadership In the House: No Longer OrderGiving
description: WASHINGTON  As House Speaker, Carl Albert has the most exalted title of any Democrat in Congress. He has served there nearly 30 years. He comes from Oklahoma, from big oil country. Yet he sat mute and powerless Thursday night as the House of Representatives voted 248 to 163 to repeal the oil depletion allowance.

title: Where to write
description: If you suspect your child has a learning disability, talk to his teacher and to the school psychologist. Ask them to recommend that he be given a full battery of tests (a oneor twoday procedure) that can he used to pinpoint the difficulty. If this doesn't work, you can have him tested privately. For more information and help, write:

title: Columbia Alumni Return to Campus for Dean's Day
description: About 900 Columbia College alumni and members of their families returned to the Morningside Heights campus yesterday for a program of lectures and panel discussions on subjects ranging from Cervantes to Henry Kissinger.

title: Anne Blake Richardson Is Married
description: The marriage of Anne Blake Richardson to James F. Robertson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robertson Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., took place in Brookline, Mass., yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Richardson, parents of the bride, by the Rev. Thom Blair, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: Afterglow of L.I. Boat Show Buoys Spirits for Year
description: When the doors closed on the Long Island Boat Show, Eadie Van Nostrand sighed exhausted but relieved. Relieved because attendance had jumped by 25 per cent over last year to 70,000. Sales appeared to have rebounded as well, and the promoter said after the show ended last Sunday, This is a good indication of what the season will be like Mrs. Van Nostrand added that last year the show had not attracted the blue collar worker. We couldnn't sell a boat under $5,000, she said. But this year boats in all price categories were selling.

title: Rock Island Asks I.C.C. Aid
description: CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)The financially troubled Rock Island Lines could be taken over by other railroads under the Interstate Commerce Commission's power to force other carriers to assume the services, John W. Ingram, the president of the railroad, said today.

title: Freighter Missing 15 Days
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 (UPI)The Philippine freighter Transocean Shipper has not been heard from for 15 days when the vessel's last message sai dthat she had run into heavy storm, the United States Coast Guard disclosed today. In the ship's las tmessage, the skipper reported severe sea damage and winds up to 75 miles an hour, said the ship's agent in Seattle, where it was due Thursday.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Picture Credits

title: The World
description: There is further evidence of the mutual Interdependence among individual nations in a world economy. The oil cartel that eschewed international bargaining procedures when it unilaterally raised oil prices is now suffering the aftershocks of the worldwide recession that those higher prices produced: orders for oil have been greatly reduced; for some producing nations, painfully so. As a result, producers now seem as anxious as consumers for a plan that will prevent further economic disruptions.

title: Tour in Cambodia Fails To Sway Congressmen
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 1An American Congressional delegation visited Cambodia for less than eight hours today and spent much of the time traveling in heavily guarded motorcades and surrounded by television cameras.

title: Medical Center Challenged on Abortions
description: A woman in her 14th week of pregnancy and a Long Island activist on birth control have filed suit in Brooklyn Federal Court to force the Nassau County Medical Center to perform abortions on welfare recipients through the 24th week of pregnancy.

title: Christine Pollutro Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Pollutro of West Brighton. S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Chistine Marie Pollutro, to Matthew Henry Naitove, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Naitove of Hanover, N.H.

title: 2 Named to Election Board
description: WASHINGON, March 1 (UPI) The White House announced today that President Ford had appointed Thomas Curtis, a former Representative from Missouri, and Neil Stabler of Ann Arbor, Mich., to the Federal Election Commission. The commission is responsible for administering the Federal Campaign Practices Act of 1974.

title: New Rules Sought For Garbage Fills
description: TRENTONIn a move designed to determine the impact of garbage dumps on water supplies, the state's Department of Environmental Protection intends to require the installation of underground wells at landfills.

title: Mutilations of Cattle In Texas, Oklahoma Called Work of Cults
description: DALLAS, March 1Law enforcement officials and cattlemen are investigating numerous mutilation killings of cattle throughout North Texas and Oklahoma that some say may be the work of Satanist cults.

title: City Opera: Best and Worst Traviata
description: The first La Traviata of the New York City Opera's spring season Friday night was an evening of bests and worsts. The production, cleverly directed by Frank Corsaro and handsomely designed by Robert Fletcher (sets) and Patton Campbell (costumes), remains one of the best in the company's repertory.

title: Lebanese Report Two Soldiers Die In Violence at Port
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1 Two Lebanese soldiers were killed and six wounded today in clashes with armed men in the southern port city of Saida, according to a military communiqu issued here.

title: At Queens College, a New Ball Game
description: In the old days, the Queens College women's basketball team was thought of as the girls in bloomers who played a delicate game of roundball. Times have changed.

title: Consumers Press for Utility Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  Environmental and consumer groups are doing legislative battle throughout the country against the cheaperbythedozen rates that utility companies charge their biggest industrial users of electricity.

title: Finley ReAppoints Bando as Captain
description: MESA, Ariz,, March 1 (UPI) Charlie Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, had a change of heart and reappointed Sal Bando captain of the world champion baseball team today, despite having called his third baseman a village idiot only two weeks ago.

title: The Passing Scene in Majorca
description: LAST summer, instead of touring the ruins of vanished civilizations, I decided to participate in digging up one of them myself. Which is how I came to spend three weeks on the island of Majorca, off the Spanish coast, exercising head and hands in pursu?? of clues to the nature of a prehistoric cave culture.

title: 15% IN POLL FEAR A JOB LOSS SOON
description: Fifteen per cent of the nation's working people fear they may lose their jobs in the next year, the Gallup Poll reports.

title: Chic spires
description: Time was, you couldn't get anyone with any pretense to architectural knowledge to defend the Chrysler Building for all the radiatorcap gargoyles in its crown. To a serious modernistand at the time of the Chrysler's completion in 1930 the modern movement was just coming into maturitythe jumble of machineage ornament was a hopeless vulgarity. To a historicist architect, which most of New York's designers then were, the very idea of romanticizing modernism was distasteful.

title: OIL SPILLS CALLED THREAT TO COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1The Department of the Interior said this week that proposed development of ocean oil off Southern California would re suit each year in accidental spillage that would be four times greater than the oil that was released in the well blowout in Santa Barbara in 1969.

title: STYLE IS THE CHANGING WOMAN
description: Not long ago people like me, who made a study of female legs, noticed something new Down There. Squaretoed, low heavy shoes were coming into vogue among women. Glancing up, we saw that shiny plastics and hard, metallic fabrics had become fashionable. Pants suits were appearing  not cute slacks, but mannish slacks. What's more, the zippers or buttons were no longer on the side: they went straight down the front, and when Franoise Dorlac emerged from a dressing room in the film. Where the Spies Are, she reached for her crotch and casually zipped herself up in the presence of David Niven.

title: The Rebate
description: It seems quite clear from the temper of Congress in this recession year that taxpayers will be getting rebates on 1974 payments. It is also likely that there wit be payments out of tax revenues to United States citizens who earned too little to pay a tax.

title: Poor Southerner's Way of Death: Paying Pennies a Week to Depart in Style
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 1 Poor most of her life, Blanche Burge figures that the least she can do is depart it in style.

title: Lehman Five Reaches Final Against C.C.N.Y.
description: Stan Brown, contented after setting a tournament scoring record in Lehman's rout of Queens College in the opener of the City University of New York basketball semifinals, said he didn't care which team he would face in the finals.

title: 1 Engine, 2 Roads Still Gurney Dream
description: Dan Gurney has a dream. He would like to see one style of car for all openwheel motor races in this country a car that could run at Indianapolis and the next weekend be competitive in a road race with only minor suspension changes. That car and that type of racing may be only a year or so away, but sometimes Gurney gets impatient. Like so many fans, he's been waiting a long time.

title: Seasons With the Negro Ensemble Company
Article 4  No Title
Legislators Back TenantAid Bills
description: TRENTON  The Legislature moved last week to further endear itself to the hearts of New Jersey's estimated 3.8 million tenants.

title: Carmen Opera's Liberated Woman
description: Theoreticians of the feminist movement are tree to disagree, but if I were asked to name the the most modern woman in opera history the answer would have to be Carmen, even though Bizet's untamable gypsy will be all of 100 years old tomorrow. Carmen had its first performance on March 3, 1875, at the OpraComique in Paris, an event that will be commemorated in a 90minute television special tomorrow night at 8 on WNET/13 and other Public Broadcasting Service stations. The program, Carmen: The Dream and the Destiny, centers around a production at the Hamburg State Opera, directed by Regina Resnik with Huguette Tourangeau in the title part.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to HayonWye, take the train from London's Paddington Station to Hereford and change there for the bus to Hay; or, take a bus from London Airport to Reading, change there for the train to Hereford, then catch a bus to Hay. Either trip, barring waits, runs about fourandonehalf hours. However, if you rent a car, in London or in Hereford, you'll be able to tour, south and west of Hay, the Welsh countryside, which comprises Brecon Beacons (a 519squaremile national park with meadows, forests, lakes, streams, and mountains that rise as high as 2,900 feet), as well as visit monuments and buildings that date to prehistoric and Early Christian times. Visitors can also canoe, or fish for salmon, on the River Wye, or walk or ponytrek through the neighboring hills. As to lodgings, bed and breakfast is available in Hay at both the Swan and Crown hotels. The French and Italian cooking at the Three Cocks Hotel in Aberllynfi, about five miles away, is recommended. The specialties include trout fresh from the Usk, which flows through Brecon Beacons. You may also want to try one or more of Hay's 11 pubs, where the beer and cider are tasty and the local people friendly.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Following a roundup by ranchers of more than 30 horses on Federal land at Howe, Idaho, in February, 1973, the United States Bureau of Land Management stepped in on a citizen complaint. It seized 19 of the horses at a slaughterhouse in North Platte, Neb., before they could be butchered for dog food, and it returned the animals to Idaho.

title: Endpaper
description: TOPSHAM, Me. The wet snow drops straight and steadily. Somewhere between our home and the center of town, the burden of its beauty is too much for an aging wolf pine. A limb snaps and falls, taking the roadside utility lines down with it. Our lights blink and die; the furnace shuts down, as do our water pump and refrigerator. We have lost our power, as they say in Maine.

title: CONTEMPT RULING ON 2 UPHELD HERE
description: A decision has been affirmed holding two Connecticut women in contempt and ordering them to jail for their refusal to answer grandjury questions about two fugitives being sought in a 1970 Boston bank robbery and murder case.

title: Engineer From Montana
description: VALIER, Mont., March 1 (AP) Susan Sirokman, daughter of John Patrick Egan, said today that her father had had no political connections or ambitions.

title: Apartments Voted For Fulton Park
description: A $11.9million, MitchellLama apartment project for 242 families is planned for construction by a nonprofit communitybased corporation in the Fulton Park urban renewal area in Brooklyn.

title: Shingling as an Art Taken Up at a Home To Mark Bicentennial
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.Jean Craighead George, an author and naturalist who lives in this Westchester community, has found a personal and unusual way to celebrate the nation's bicentennial. She is having the outside of her austere nineroom home redone in carpenter gothic, an allbutforgotten method of shingling.

title: Article 1  No Title
Judge Goes to Station House At 3:45 A.M. to Free Suspect
description: A State Supreme Court justice made a personal visit to the 32d Precinct police station in Harlem at 3:45 A.M. yesterday and ordered the release of a private detective charged proceedings wherever and whenever he saw fit.

title: Lynn Homeier Sets June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lon Williams Homeier of Rosemont, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Frances Homeier, to Philip John Rauch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Rauch of Old Westbury, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: HOWARD C. FLYNN
description: Howard C. Flynn, who worked for The New York Times from 1910 to 1942 and had been a manager of its former Wide World Photo Service, died yesterday in Arlington, Va., where he lived. His age was 80.

title: Uncoordinated Children Are Putting It All Together
description: LONG BEACHFor klutzy Norman and chubby Patty and the legions of otter uncoordinated and overweight children, the agony of gym class and team sports may be reduced to an unhappy memory.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Income Tax Changes
description: New provisions in the Federal tax law, and recent tax rulings, are explained in articles on Pages 12 and 13 of Section 3 to aid in preparing income tax returns.

title: Aussies Seeking Roche For Next Cup Encounter
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 1 (AP)Neale Fraser said today he felt that Australia would win the Davis Cup. He voiced the hope that Tony Roche would be available for the next series, possibly against Czechoslovakia.

title: The American Bicentennial Begins With a Crowded Calendar and an Uncertain Focus
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1America's bicentennial officially began today amid a continuing debate over its shape, form and purpose, and still without a centerpiece for its celebration.

title: A Bird In the Hand It's Possible
description: A bird in the hand may be worth two in the bush, but try and get it there. Some birds like the solitary vireo and some waterfowl have such a strong attachment to the nest that they will let someone touch them while on it. Sometimes the birds can be pushed aside to count how many eggs mere are. On the other hand, if a blue jay sees a human form at the feeder window, it takes flight. Chickadees? They can be hand tamed and are the best bet.

title: Jazz Notes: The Acoustic Piano Can Be Electrifying
description: A division is developing in the jazz world, one that may become as bitter as, but possibly more rational than, the battle between the moldy figs and the beboppers in the 1940's. This time the battle is between the electricians and the acousticians.

title: People/Business
description: According to Dr. Max A. Geller, he became involved in the soft drink industry largely by accident. It happened in 1960, when he acquired control of the thenfledgling YooHoo Chocolate Beverage Corporation.

title: Penn Takes Heptagonal Track Title
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 1 Pennsylvania's track team once again turned an individual race into a team victory tonight in Cornell's Barton Hall. The Quakers swept the top three places in the 1,000 yard run at the Heptagonal indoor track and field championships, giving them a commanding lead which they never relinquished.

title: The Nation
description: Only a few weeks on the job, the new Attorney General, Edward Levi, has publicly confirmed what has long been rumored. Mr. Levi has said that Presidents of both parties misused the Federal Bureau of Investigation for their private or political purposes. And he has also confirmed that J. Edgar Hoover misused the F.B.I., compiling dossiers on Presidents and other public figures, for his purposes.

title: Publicity Campaign
description: I am a publicist. I make my living as the ticket taker on other people's ego trips. One of my specialties is customcreating book campaigns. Writers retain me to cajole or bully publishing houses into taking ads and making sure their books get into bookstores. Among the authors I've promoted are Jacqueline Susann, Cornelius Ryan, Richard Ney and Dan Wakefield. My latest client, however, is myself. I looked foward to taking on my recently published memoir, The Great Carmen Miranda LookAlike Contest, a snap job.

title: Headliners
description: From 1948 to 1958, Nikolai A. Bulganin was a member of the Soviet ruling group. As Premier, he played the front man while the other half of the B & K team, Communist party leader Nikita Khrushchev, wielded the real power. Then he made the mistake of siding with an antiparty group and was ousted into obscurity by Mr. Khrushchev. Last week the Soviet Government announced the death of Pensioner Bulganin at the age of 79.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: EVER since 1902, when the pioneer French filmmaker Georges Mlis shot a spacecraft into the eye of the Man in the Moon, the movies have had a prediliction for the fantastic. As such, they were a medium made to order for the early proponents of Dada and Surrealism, with their programs of dream or dreamlike imagery, esthetic dissociation and calculaed shock. There's no telling how many films were made in the heyday of this spirit, before diluted Surrealism became, in the late 1940's, a staple form of Hollywood kitsch. But a definite tradition has been established around a handful of movies, ranging from Bend Clair's riotous little Entr'acte (1924) to Luis Bunuel's searing classic, L'Age d'or (1930)

title: Paperbacks
description: COGAN'S TRADE, by George V. Hig&ins. (Warner, $1.75.) A murdererforhire at work in the Boston underworld; matter tough, style vernacular.

title: Barbara S. Lewis Wed to Bank Aide
description: Barbara Sandra Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Lewis of Wyckoff, N. J., was married yesterday morning to William Harry Yurasko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Harry Yurasko of Chatham, N. J. The Rev. Charles McCusker performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Midland Park. N. J.

title: Rebels Reported Gaining
description: CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)Rebel guerrillas appear to have the upper hand in the Eritrean independence struggle, says a correspondent of the Chicago Tribune who went behind rebel lines.

title: North Fork Housewives Start Coop to Beat Food Prices
description: SOUTHOLD  Just because we lived out at the tip of Long Island didn't mean that we couldn't have better food at better prices

title: Legislators Seek a Bipartisan Accord On Nominee List for Board of Regents
description: ALBANYMeeting in outoftheway rooms and speaking in elaborate, elliptical phrases to avoid the mention or names, a coalition of legislators is trying to fashion a bipartisan list of nominees to the Board of Regents, the education policymaking board that has been the focus of differences over busing for racial integration.

title: The Dirty Word on U.S. Railroads: Nationalize
description: Another step in this country's evolvement of a brand of privateenterprise socialism, distinct from anything ever envisaged by either Adam Smith or Karl Marx, is being taken in the proposed reorganization under Government auspices of the Penn Central and other sick railroads in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: New Maine Governor Undaunted by Clashes With Powerful Forces
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 28These have been the toughest days of my life, James B. Langley said cheerfully.

title: MIAMI SEEKS HELP TO COMBAT TERROR
description: MIAMI, March 1The Mayor of Miami, Maurice A. Ferr, has announced that he had asked Attorney General Edward H. Levi for immediate Federal assistance in helping local law enforcement agencies to combat violence in the Cuban exile community here that the police regard as politically motivated.

title: BRIDGE
description: It was a curious coincidence that the recent world team championship in Bermuda should have been the second in a quarter of a century to generate a major cheating accusation when it was the first to use bidding screens  which were designed to prevent cheating and accusations thereof.

title: The strange malady called learning disability
description: His son was a big disappointment to him. He wanted the boy to play baseball and football. The kid could hardly catch a ball, and when he did he didn't seem to know what to do with it. Almost as bad, he was doing poorly in school.

title: Record of Neediest Appeal
description: The fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases was started in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was publisher of The New York Times until his death in 1935. Contributions to the 64th annual appeal, which begins Dec. 7, can he sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York. N.Y. 10249.

title: State Panel Will Seek Accord on the Budget
description: TRENTON Now that the Legislature has adjourned for the month, the Joint Appropriations Committee will begin taking Governor Byrne's budget apart this week. Its goal will be to reach agreement on a compromise spending and revenue plan that both houses can hopefully approve upon their return.

title: Angry Italian Police Staging Protests
description: ROME, March 1Italian policemen, frustrated and angered by a surge of violent crime, have begun to hold unauthorized protest meetings throughout the country in defiance of regulations.

title: U.S. Embassy Aides in Argentina Fear More Killings
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 1The killing of John Patrick Egan, a consular agent, may be the first in a new wave of kidnapping and assassination attempts against United States officials in Argentina, according to sources at the United States Embassy here.

title: BQL Bulletin Board
description: BaysideA memorial exhibit of sculptures, cer??cs and paintings by Matthew Siok, through March 19, weekdays, 10 A.M. to noon and 2 to 4 P:M., Library Building, fourth floor, Queensborough Community College.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: $uccess stories (cont.). These days, we're told, book publishing is controlled by giants; the little man doesn't have a chance. Well, maybe. There always seems to be room for a man or woman with an idea whose time has come. Last week we reported on Helen B. Andelin, the Santa Barbara dentist's wife who published her own book, Fascinating Womanhood, and sold 400,000 hardcover copies before leasing it out to a paperback house. This week two more cases. . .

title: What They Are Saying
description: Lee Trevino after shooting a 78 in the second round of the Los Angeles open: I played like a dog. I'm going back to the hotel and have two cans of Alpo for dinner.

title: Linda Louise Morgan Betrothed to John Joseph Filz
description: The engagement of Linda Louise Morgan to John Joseph Filz, who is working his way through the University of Montana as City Clerk of Hamilton, Mont., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Pierpont Morgan 2d of Mill Neck, L.I., parents of the bridetobe.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The paint on the ceiling in my living room cracks and falls off in large pieces. The ceiling has been scraped and painted three times, but the same thing keeps happeningthough I live in a wellkept apartment house. Is there something I can do to prevent this?S.H., New York City.

title: NAPLES PRESSING RENEWAL PROJECT
description: NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 24Naples is not dead, and it is not dying, Bruno Milanes, the Mayor of Naples, said in a recent news coference. It is ill and in the process of recovering.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ANNIVERSARIES, by Uwe Johnson. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. $10.) An emigr woman alone (and free) among New York's 8millions, her memory shuttling back and forth between Nazi Germany and the present, profoundly exploring the meaning of both.

title: King of the Iron Merchants
description: LOS ANGELES. It is now 15 years since the subtly asked question Would you buy a used car from this man? possibly contributed to the narrow defeat of Richard M. Nixon in his run for the Presidency against John F. Kennedy. Today, a man named Victor Snyder, the owner and majordomo of Trader Vic's Used Cars in Pacoima, Calif., makes a daily effort to enact the antithesis of the Nixon innuendo, which hangs in poster form in his office as a reminder. Vic, his lean countryboy face and pink bald head radiating honesty and integrity, circulates like a gangling rural preacher among the flock that throngs his rather raunchy nofrills oar lot. He passes out lollipops to the babies, tells women to forget about buying any car without power steering, cheerfully knocks $50 off the price of a $499 jalopy which cost him only $75. His business card reads, with remarkable candor, Miracle Cars. If It's a Good Car, It's a Miracle. With equal candor, the windshield of a 1968 Pontiac on his front line bears the painted notice $299. BAD ENGINE.

title: C. W. Post Again Takes Collegiate Track Title
description: C. W. Post College won seven events and set records in five to retain the team title in the 22d Collegiate Track Conference championships yesterday in Columbia University's Airdome at Baker Field.

title: Gun Amnesty Program Produces 22 Weapons
description: The Police Department reported yesterday that in the first 12 hours of the city's 31day amnesty program for illegal firearms, the owners of 22 guns  19 pistols, a rifle and two machine guns  had volunteered to turn in their weapons.

title: SCIENTIST WITH SPIRIT
description: When Selmaree Oster first moved to New York from Afghanistan where she had been working for the Peace Corps, she could not get over how people dressed up to go shopping. Even being born and raised in Philadelphia had not prepared her to be a New York shopper.

title: Capers Island: A Priceless Haven
description: CAPERS ISLAND, S. C.Within minutes after nosing our boats ashore at a landing from which an old corduroy logging road led from the salt marsh to the woods, we were deep in the shade of a semitropical jungle, and the path on which we walked was strewn with the fragrant yellow blossoms of jasmine.

title: The Spruce Goose, Hughes's Plywood Airplane, to Go to Eight Museums
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)The Spruce Goose, the famed wooden airplane built by Howard R. Hughes in World War II, will be cut into pieces and distributed to eight prestigious pubic museums and the Smithsonian Institution, a Federal official has announced.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television prograins was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Frederic Jennings Jr. Fiance of Miss Giglio
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Giglio of Bernardsville, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, L. Candace Giglio, to Frederic B. Jennings Jr., son of Mrs. Ellen O. Jennings of Ipswich, Mass., and Mr. Jennings 3d of Idleyld Park, Oregon.

title: INDIANS VOW TO STAY IN FAIRCHILD PLANT
description: SHIPROCK, N.M., March 1 (UPI)Armed Indians holding an electronics plant on a Navajo reservation here said today that they would not leave the building even if company officials carried out a threat to close the plant permanently.

title: Beauty and Sadness
description: This is the last novel of Yasunari Kawabata, the Japanese master who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1968 and died, by his own hand, in 1972. The novel was begun in 1961 and Kawabata reportedly worked on it until the time of his death. It is the most consciously plotted of Kawabata's works and explores the relationship of art to life; it is a tale of fearful asymmetries and a terrifying nemesis, an inexorable linking of beauty and sadness.

title: Answers/Questions
description: BANANA PLANT (Feb. 2)

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BUFFALO, March 1 (AP)Larry Fogle and Charley Jordan of the Canisius five have been declared ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for all future competition because they received improper financial aid, the school said today. It said the decision had been appealed. Athletic Director Daniel P. Starr would not disclose details of the charge, but said the team was still eligible for postseason basketball games.

title: A California Ghost Town, Unimproved
description: THE abandoned buildings face dirt streets. Some are only piles of broken wood topped with the remains of a peaked roof. Others have endured, their rooms visible through partially missing walls. Peeling wallpaper hangs limply; broken antique furniture and cracked iron stoves are almost hidden under wild clumps of yellowed brush; sporadic desert breezes lift and whirl bits of debris about the floors.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: ISRAELIS RECEIVE BONN ASSURANCES
description: BONN, March 1West Germany has assured the Israeli Foreign Minister, Yigal Alton, who has just visited Bonn, of its continued diplomatic and economic support for Israel.

title: Vital Highway Link Periled
description: TRENTONThe construction of an important link in the Interstate Highway System has been stalled by the disclosure that the remains of prehistoric Indian settlements may lie in its path.

title: 28 LOVE LETTERS OP HISTORY SHOWN
description: WASHINGTON, March 1An assemblage of love letters, including some written by eight American Presidents and two Supreme Court Justices, is on display at the Libraryof Congress.

title: Where the Action Is
description: What city is the world's center of photography today? To some extent that depends on how one defines the center of photography. Is it the place where the most museums and galleries are ??cated? The place where one can find the greatest collections of photographs? The city where the greatest number of working photographers can be found? Or merely the place where the greatest number of manufacturing facilities is located?

title: Mayor Walling, Gravely Ill, Spurning Worry for Work
description: EAST BRUNSWICKEarly in February, Mayor Jean Walling called a special meeting of this township's 190 employes.

title: Eastern Opera Theater Offers Americana of 1900
description: As the bicentennial approaches, we can expect more and more concerts to delve into early Americana, but not many are likely to have the wit and imagination of the Eastern Opera Theater's Circa 1900, a recreation of the type of musical soire popular around the turn of the century. The nostalgic mood was set even as one entered the foyer of the Schimmel Auditorium at Pace College on Friday night, to be greeted by a receiving line of hosts and hostesses in period attire, while the Vieuxtemps String Quartet played such vintage trophies as Griffes's Indian Sketches and a Suite in Olden Style by one H. Waldo Warner.

title: California High School Panel to Urge Drastic Change in Traditional Studies
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.  A blueribbon California commission is expected soon to urge sweeping reforms in secondary schooling that would make educational progress depend on the student's demonstrated competence rather than on time in the class and would broaden the learning opportunities for teenagers beyond the dull, rigid and often ineffectual confines of tradition or a building.

title: Scheckter Takes Grand Prix
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 1  Jody Scheckter, driving a spare Tyrrell with an untested engine fitted 30 minutes before the flag dropped, drove what probably was the best race of his life to win the South African Formula One Grand Prix before a home crowd of 110,000 persons today.

title: ETHIOPIA SHROUDS NEWS OF FIGHTING
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopa, March 1Two foreign journalists here were recently asked how they could report the Ethiopian civil war being fought more than 450 miles away in Eritrea Province since the Government has refused to allow them to travel to the war zone and has declined to issue communiqus on the fighting.

title: Unseld Out for 10 Days
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  Wes Unseld of the Washington Bullets will be out of action for between 10 days and two weeks with a broken little finger on his right hand, a team spokesman said today. The spokesman said Unseld, the leading rebounder in the National Basketball Association, broke the finger in the third quarter of last night's game with Detroit.

title: Alison Hubby, P. E. Hoversten Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Winfield Hubby of Princeton, N. J., and Niantic, Conn., have announced the engagement of their laughter, Alison Adams Hubby, to Philip Everard Hoversten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moris T. Hoversten of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Mint Issues Presidential Medal
description: The Mint's medal store has a new item for salethe official Gerald R. Ford Presidential medal. In a brief White House ceremony late last month, President and Mrs. Ford inspected and gave final approval to the finished product, and the Mint is now offering it as medal number 140 in the official catalogue, Medals of the United States Mint, Issued for Public Sale. (The 1972revised edition of this profusely illustrated 305page Mintmedal catalogue can be purchased for $5.25 from the Superintendent of Documents, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20402.)

title: ROOMMATES IN MANHATTAN
description: hen New York City is just a comfy old hometown, the place where you still see most of the kids you went to high school with, East Side singles life is not defined by swinging bars and frantically batting eyelashes.

title: 76ers Win to Add To Knick Worries
Ford Condemns Killing
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)  President Ford said today that the kidnapping and killing of John Patrick Egan in Argentina was a vicious act which will be condemned by men of decency and honor everywhere.

title: LEO SAYER IS BACK AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: When Leo Sayer was last in New York, the British rock singer was arrayed in his thenstandard clown outfit, complete with whiteface, reddotted cheeks and circus gestures. The general reaction was favorable to his music and his performance, but disgruntled about his outfit.

title: Laura A. Kerrigan Is Betrothed to Kenneth G. Appel
description: Dr. Gerald A. Kerrigan, dean of the Medical College of Wisconsin, and Mrs. Kerrigan of Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Austin Kerrigan of New York, to Kenneth Goodrich Appel, a tax accountant with Arthur Young & Co. in New York. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Appel of Philadelphia, where his father has a medical practice.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: FMC Corporation, one of the country's largest industrial companies, will vacate about 100,000 square feet of office space in midtown as part of a move to consolidate its northeastern offices in Philadelphia.

title: Alternative Numbers Listed for Services
description: Following is a list of alternative telephone numbers for services and businesses affected by Thursday's fire at the New York Telephone Company's switching center at 13th Street and Second Avenue:

title: Complaints Flare Over A.A.U. Meet
The New Wave of AntiTrustism
description: Antitrust action, long one of the faded passions of American reform, in the phrase of historian Richard Hofstadter, is usually recorded in the business pages, not the front pages. Until recently; suddenly there appears to be something of an antitrust revival under way, or at least a combination of events that suggests that the Government means business with business. Among those getting attention:

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The National Ballet of Canada has practically been adopted by New York City. On July 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House, it will open its fourth season in three years, once more with Rudolf Nureyev in the driving seat. Before that it will undertake a European tour, including the company's second visit to London and its first tour of Holland. Although the company is nearly a quarter of a century old, it is only in recent years that it has been dancing in the major league.

title: Daisies to Grow Indoors in Pots
description: The daisy family is one of the largest plant families with over 800 genera and 15,000 species. And curiously, the largest group (genus) of daisies is Senecio, a classication that includes 1,200 species and is found in all parts of the world.

title: Ring Title Is Retained By Chacon
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP)Bobby Chacon of Sylmar, Calif., knocked out Mexico's Jesus (Papelero) Estrada in the second round tonight to retain his World Boxing Council featherweight championship. It was Chacon's first defense.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge. Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Route 124, Darien, Conn. Regular, amateurowner and local working hunters; open jumpers, pleasure horses, 8 A.M.

title: Linda Rathbun, D. G. Taylor Wed
description: Linda Kathleen Rathbun and Donald Gordon Taylor of Dallas were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. A. Allen Gardner Jr. in the First Presbyterian Church in Asheville. N.C.

title: Agavni E. Nigohosian, 100, Led Armenian Community
description: Agavni Ekmekjian Nigohosian, a former educator and leader of the Armenian community here, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 100 years old and lived at 501 West 123d Street.

title: Seoul Curbs Actions Of Protest Leaders On Historic Day
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 1South Koreans today commemorated the 56th anniversary of their resistance to the Japanese colonial rule, but last night and early this morning scores of plainclothes men sealed off the houses of leading opposition figures here in anticipation of an opposition demonstration.

title: High Inflation Plagues Chileans Despite a Surface Tranquility
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 28The second summer of military rule has brought a surface tranquility to Santiago that surprises visitors.

title: DR. JOSEPH C. LANE
description: Dr. Joseph C. Lane, a general practitioner who was on the staff of the Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital, died Friday at his home, 920 Plandome Road, Manhasset, L. I. He was 73 years old.

title: The Town of Books
description: HAYONWYE, a drowsy Welsh town near the English border, is nestled in the foothills of the Black Mountains amid gentle grazing slopes and fertile fields of wheat. Hay has no traffic lights: the streets are crowded only on market and sale days.

title: THE UPS AND DOWNS
description: When I was about 5, I made the connection between the shoes people wore and the way they walked. The grocery store manager, in brown shoes with thick soles run down at the heels, waiked differently from the lawyers wearing black shoes with pokedhole designs. Grannies in laceups and nurses in white oxfords walked differently from my kindergarten teacher, who wore penny loafers, and my mother, who, when going out, wore delicate shoes with high heels that went click click click delightfully.

title: Canadian Women Run With, Not After, Men
description: Thelma Flynn Wright prefers omelets and salads to meat, before or after running track. Kathy Gibbons prefers plenty of liquids and cheeses before a track meet, but afterward likes a nice juicy steak. But diets aren't the only differences between the two worldclass 1,500meter runners. Mrs. Wright, a native of Vancouver, British Columbia, has belonged to a coed track clubthe only kind they have in Canadasince she began running track 14 years ago. Miss Gibbons, from Phoenix, has belonged only to women's track clubs until recently joining the mixed Glendale Gauchos Club in Arizona.

title: Book Reviewers Group Sets Up Annual Prizes
description: Four annual book awards, established and judged by professional critics, will be given for works published this year. They are the creation of the National Book Critics Circle, founded last year to encourage and raise the quality of book criticism in all media and provide for exchange of, information between fellow professionals.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Gov. Thompson in Row Over Arts Grant
description: CONCORD, N.H. March 1A New York Citybased organization of lawyers interested in the arts plans to take the Govenor of New Hampshire to court and force him to approve a $750 grant to a literary periodical.

title: A Tale of Trading in Sugar, March Delivery
description: This is the story of the March, 1975, sugar contract, the most volatile on record.

title: Brennan Seeks Old Post, But He Faces Opposition
description: Peter J. Brennan, who has resigned as Secretary of Labor, plans to return at the end of March to his old job as president of the New York City Building and Construction Trades Council, but opposition to his return has developed among some of the construction union heads.

title: 50 Most Common Mistakes
description: There you sit, tax forms in hand and manuals lying about. Where are you likely to go, or where have you gone, wrong?

title: The Region
description: Governor Carey has taken a first, important step in the direction of judicial reform in New York State by ordering that nominating committees be set up to screen his prospective appointees to the bench.

title: WEST INDIANS SEE AREA UNITY LIKELY
description: THE VALLEY, AnguillaThere is a growing feeling of nationalism and regional consciousness in the Englishspeaking islands of the eastern Caribbean.

title: Hartford Teams Clash Over City Stadium
description: The Connecticut Yankees of the American Soccer League have scheduled their home games at Dillon Stadium in Hartford and so has the unnamed Hartford franchise in the North American Soccer League.

title: KISSINGER MAKES OVERTURE TO CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Secretary of State Kissinger declared today that the United States was prepared to move in a new direction in relations with Cuba, ending 14 years of boycott, provided a majority of hemisphere countries agreed.

title: Act Granting U.S. Wild Horse Rights Overruled in West
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 1  The 1971 Congressional act granting the Federal Government sole jurisdiction over freeroaming wild horses and burros was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a threejudge Federal panel that permanently enjoined the Government from enforcing it.

title: WEALTH DISTURBS ARABAFRICA TIES
