description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 1A few years ago the stumbling block to cooperation between black African and Arab nations on world affairs was the black Africans' insistence on retaining diplomatic relations with Israel

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Doing in BUCKS COUNTY
description: RUSTIC BEAUTYBucks County has traditionally attracted city dwellers with a yearning for countryside at its loveliest, although lately urbanization near Philadelphia has left only Upper Bucks pristine. The 40milelong county between Philadelphia and Bethlehem may have more of the fine old stone houses and barns of Colonial days than any other area of the country; 13 covered bridges still stand, one dating to 1832. The rolling hills and fertile valleys have made Upper Bucks a mecca for gentlemen farmers, artists, writers, actors and others who prize rural living. New Hope has been an artists' colony for half a century and draws tourists by the thousands on weekends. Unrelieved rusticity is not everyone's nirvana, but the county's appeal would vanish if Upper Bucks turned into Levittowns to the extent that Lower Bucks has.

title: Andruss in Final Of Title Tourney
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 1Bill Andruss of Fordham and Juan de Villafranca of the University of Mexico, the top seeded player, advanced today to the Division A final of the United States intercollegiate squash racquets championships at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Colonels Top Nets, Tie for First Place
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 1 On a rare off night by Julius (Doctor J) Erving, the New York Nets lost a 95.84 American Basketball Association decision to the Kentucky Colonels tonight at Freedom Hall, and dropped into a tie with the Colonels for the Eastern Division lead. A crowd of 16,198 watched.

title: Earlier Bids by Lon Nol
description: Marshal Lon Not offered to talk peace with the Cambodian insurgents last July, and restated the offer in even more conciliatory tones in November.

title: Bus Service Is Set For Ocean County
description: TOMS RIVERThe Ocean County Board of Chosen Freeholders, reacting to rising fuel prices and increased demands for masstransit facilities, plans to begin the county's first publictransportation system late this year.

title: 4 in Charity Marathon Killed on Florida Road
description: PERRY, Fla., March 1 (AP) Four University of Florida students participating in a 150mile run to raise money for charity were killed and 11 injured today when an empty tanker truck plowed into the back of their rented truck, the authorities said.

title: Pro Transactions
Mansfield Sees Possible Break
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Senate Democratic Leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today that a reported offer by President Lon Nol to step aside might be the bleak which might make it possible for negotiations to end the fighting in Cambodia.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, March 2

title: When Frankness Deteriorates Into Drivel
description: Four our of the more unusual characters wandering around the television screen recently were Gordon and George, and Fran and Wanda. The male pair was elevated to significance in a recent episode of Hot l Baltimore. The women Were given prominence in Hustling, a dramatization of Gail Sheehy's factual book about female prostitution in Manhattan. The conduit for both programs was the ABCTV network.

title: ... Planning for Energy
description: Though Congress was right to reject the President's very costly and untimely energy package, it has still to come to grips with a longterm program for energy conservation and development. However, the Congressional Democrats' energy program has one salient virtue over the Administration's proposals: automotive efficiency and gasoline consumption are specifically targeted as the most fertile field for energy conservation.

title: ARABS TO PERMIT BUT CURB NBC, CBS
description: CAIRO, March 1 (UPI)The Arab organization for the boycott of. Israel agreed today to allow two American networks, the NationalBroadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, to continue news activities under supervision in the Arab world.

title: P.T.A. Conference Warnedof Cutbacks
description: HEMPSTEAD  Unless Long Island school districts get substantially more state funding, they will be plagued by massive teacher layoffs and building closures.

title: Interest Rates Come Down, But Money Funds Roar Ahead
description: New investments in mutual funds topped $1billion in January. It was the biggest month in the history of the mutual fund business.

title: Accompanists of the World, Take a Bow
description: I don't like the word accompanist, says soprano Beverly Sills. The person I work with is a collaborator. We have fun together. There has to be rapport more than anything else.

title: Parent and Child
description: There are more than 122 million licensed drivers in the U.S., and in 1973the latest year for which figures are availablethey killed 55,800 people, slightly more than the number of Americans who died in 10 years of Vietnam. These 122 million drivers smashed up themselves or others a total of 31 million times, making one out of four licensed drivers a participant in a reported accident.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: A string us to weep for the ornery is becoming the principal theatrical occupation of our time. The bigger the heel, the more arrogant the antihero, the sorrier we are expected to feel for him in his demise, lending our hearts in lament to the shambles he has become. Does no one shed a tear any longer over a fellow believed to have been virtuous? Perhaps ?? don't believe any man virtuous, not in his privacy, not an inch beneath the skin. May be as simple as that

title: Soccer Results
Books of The Times
description: There is a kind of lovemaking that occurs only in novels. The lovers are uninterruptedly happy, never bored, satiated or restless. When they go somewhere for a weekend, they spend the whole time in their hotel room; their meals are sent in. These marathons are not inhibited by age: in Small Rain, Anthony is 58, and Maija 48.

title: Article 2  No Title
Cancer Victim,14, Dies on Way Home From Hawaii Trip
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill. March 2 (UPI)Fourteenyearold Heidi Biggs died of cancer today on the way home from a twoweek dream vacation in Hawaii.

title: C.A.B. Aide Faults Airlines on Election Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) memorandum written by the former chief of enforcement for the Civil Aeronautics Board right before he apparently committed suicide mentions possible election law violations by some domestic airlines, friend of the victim confirmed tonight.

title: JOHN T. CHADWELL
description: John T. Chadwell, a Chicago lawyer who often represented major companies in  antitrust suits, died Saturday in the Evanston (Ill) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Winnetka, Ill.

title: Long Layoff Embitters Linden G. M. Workers
description: LINDEN, N.J.On Jan. 4, 1974, about 2,600 workers at the General Motors assembly plant here were let go in what they were told was a temporary layoff. Now that temporary layoff has entered its second year, and those unemployed workers have become bitter toward the company and their union.

title: (1) Work. (2) Power.
description: With the exception of skilled craftsmena vanishing breedfew people work for pleasure. Most people don't mind working, but feel that it's both indecent and wasteful to enjoy openly.

title: Crushing Dissent in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Good men, nobly motivated by the spirit of reform, can more harm to our political system than the worst villains lusting after Dower.

title: Snorts News Briefs Westbury Seeks to Avert Strike
description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 2Negotiations continued late tonight between the Mutuel Ticket Agents Union and Roosevelt Raceway in an effort to avert a strike that would prevent the track from opening a 66night meeting tomorrow night. Almost 400 union members met yesterday Plumbers Hall in Mineola and voted to reject the track's latest offera threeyear contract in which the clerks, who sell and cash tickets, would receive a $1anight increase. The union was seeking a 7% per cent increase. The track says the clerks earn $53 a night, including $11 in fringe benefits. The union says pay scales vary.

title: Science Seeks Safe Bugs For Genetic Engineering
description: Scientists have begun developing less hazardous microorganisms and viruses to reduce the hazard of socalled genetic engineering, and the complexity of laboratory safeguards in such genegrafting research.

title: L.I.'s Construction Men Wait in Vain For Jobs
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.The man made an offer: carry a few panels up flight of stairs and make a quick $5. Two of the men hanging around Carpenters Hall here accepted; but John Martorano declined.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SEA VENTURE, Flagship Cruises; left St. Thomas Feb. 28, due 8 A.M. at W. 50th St.

title: Sonics Pin Defeat On Celtics, 10497
description: HARTFORD, March 2 (AP)  Spencer Haywood and Fred Brown combined for 60 points11 straight in the last 21/2 minutes  carrying the Seattle SuperSonics to a 10497 victory over the Boston Celtics today in the National Basketball Association.

title: BISHOP HAMILTON, 82, OF MORAVIAN CHURCH
description: The Right Rev. Kenneth G. Hamilton of the Moravian Church, a missionary, teacher, administrator and writer, died Friday in the Moravian Home, WinstonSalem, N. C. He was 82 years old

title: STRONG YEN TIED TO WEAK DOLLAR Japan's Currency Also Aided by Growth in Exports and Investing From Abroad
description: TOKYO, March 2The strong climb in the value of the yen, considered a leading indicator of the performan'e of Japan's economy, is suggesting to some members of the financial community that the recession here may have hit bottom. However, other indicators seem to say the opposite.

title: Job Advertising Index Dropped in January
description: The helpwanted advertising index of the Conference Board dropped sharply again in January, the businessresearch group reported yesterday.

title: TRUCE ENDS CLASHES IN A LEBANESE PORT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2Premier Rashid alSolh an nounced tonight that calm hac I returned to the southern Leba nese port of Saida after two days of fighting between troops anc gunmen in which five soldier: were killed and 10 wounded and an unknown number of civilian: injured.

title: New Slasher Victim
description: LOS ANGELES. March (UPI)The killing of a transient with a record of 35 Skid Row arrests for public drunkenness was handled by the police today as the possible 10th killing by the Los Angeles slasher. The body of Bennie Pasillas, 31 years old, was found outside a hotel yesterday. An autopsy showed that the manner of killing differed slightly from the previous slayings. The authorities believed it was the work of an imitator.

title: Nation's Schools Renewing Stress on the Basics
description: Because of falling test scores and parents demands for a nofrills education for their children, public elementary schools around the country are placing renewed emphasis on teaching basic reading and mathematics skills.

title: U.S. Inquiry Finds 37 In Weather Underground
description: United States Senate investigators identify 37 persons as current members in hiding of the militant leftist Weather Underground organization; a total of 158 are listed as having been members or associates since the group's founding in 1969.

title: The NegativeHeel ShoePro and Con
description: Some people swear by it other people wear at it. Some say it alleviates foot ailments and backaches; others say it provokes or aggravates them. Some say it fosters good posture, others say it throws the body out of kilter.

title: Personal Finance: Estate Planning
description: Planning for a family's financial security takes many forms. And perhaps none is more important than planning for the situation that will occur after the death of the primary wage earner.

title: PlIONELESS TO GET MESSAGE SERVICE
description: The telephone company will begin a special messenger service this morning for about 8,500 businesses and professional offices left without telephones after last Thursday's fire in switching center in Lower Manhattan.

title: Italy's Main Party Badly Split; Angry Members Waylay Chief
description: ROME, March 2The Christian Democratic party, for three decades the nation's strongest political force, is experiencing more than its usual factiousness, and many Italians are publicly asking whether it is in serious trouble.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLUES Murder Ink, which calls itself the only bookstore in the country deyoted exclusively to mystery wrjting, has announced a Sebes of six Monday evening programs of sherry, conversation and more, geared to het the appetite of whodunit readers. The scene of Operations will not be the uptown store, at 271 West 7th Street, but Steinway Concert Hall, 111 West 67th Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue). Starting tonight. there will be sipping and mingling from 7 P.M to 7:30 P.M., then a twohour panel discussion by some crime experts, moderated by Dilys Winn, who runs Murder Ink (with an onthepremises dog named Watson). Admission $5 at the hall or by store reservation (3628905).

title: For the Stylishly Stout, Portly or Just Fat, Life Is Not Easy
description: Many years ago, Ernestine SchumannHeink entered a concert stage in the Middle West, knocking over music stands as she went.

title: Theater: First Breeze of Summer
description: An old woman remembers and a young boy grows up: those are the bones of Leslie Lee's striking family drama The First Breeze of Summer, which opened last night the Negro Ensemble Company's new season at the St. Marks Playhouse.

title: About New York Shed a Tear When Digits Replace DIgby
description: It is 10 years and more since the telephone company said it would replace the old names with digits, making BUtterfield 8, for example the less interesting 288, and 10 years and more since people wept over PEnnsylvania 65000 becoming 7365000. The telephone company, citizens said, was taking away their heritage. Worse, it was killing romance.

title: Speed Skating to Detroit Woman
description: INZELL, West Germany, March 2 (AP)Sheila young of Detroit broke her world record in the foursprint speedskating event today, finishing with 172.540 points in the Golden Skates of Inzell competition.

title: Albany Leaders Adjust To Reversal of Fortune
description: ALBANY, March 2One measure of the shift of power this year in the Assembly is the dealings the two party leaders have with reporters. Last week, Stanley Steingut

title: Jewish Women Urge Volunteers To Fill Gap in  Social Services
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2  The head of the National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress called tonight on volunteers across the nation to fill what she described as a critical gap in essential social services caused by budget cutbacks resulting from the recession.

title: Staten Island Ferryboat Sails Again in Costa Rica
description: PUNTARENAS, Costa RicaA 35yearold Staten Island ferryboat, repainted a bright orange, is plowing the warm coastal waters of the Pacific these days carrying farmers and cattle trucks.

title: Arab Boycott Conference Warns Volkswagen
description: CAIRO, March 2 (AP)The Arab boycott conference warned the West German automaker Volkswagen today that it had three months in which to end its dealings with Israel or be blacklisted by Arab countries.

title: Strasbourg Philharmonic Proves Subtle and Solid
description: Paris so dominates France's cultural life that we do not often hear from touring ensembles from other French cities. But yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall the Strasbourg Philharmonic Orchestra made its first New York appearance and made a most winning impression, indeed.

title: SAMUEL D. LENOX
description: Samuel D. Lenox, senior partner in the Trenton law firm of Lenox, Giordano, Devlin, Delehey & Socey, died Saturday at the St. Francis Medical Center in Trenton. He was 77 years old and lived on Renfrew Avenue in Trenton.

title: Senators Charge 20 Million Needy. Lack Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Before dawn tomorrow, Amer0020;ica's new breadlines will begin forming as the newly unemployed and the chronically poor begin the monthly ordeal of applying for or buying food stamps.

title: Democratic Mayors Discuss Crime
description: ATLANTA, March 2Already at work on a platform for the 1976 Democratic National Convention, a dozen or so party officials from around the country gathered here this weekend to explore the crime issue and to take testimony from the experts.

title: DR. FREDERICK DAVIS, TEST DEVELOPER, 65
description: Dr. Frederick Barton Davis, a psychologist who since 1964 had been professor of education and director of the bureau of educational research and service at the University of Pennsylvania, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 10 Kent Road in Bronxville.

title: Owning Horses Is Foolish Pleasure
description: MIAMI, March 2John L. Greer is an understated millionaire from Knoxville, Tenn., who got most of his bread from bread. Though he has a variety of business interests, his chief concern is Kern Bakery, which sells $50million worth of bread and cake a year. He had owned thoroughbreds for 22 years but his appreciation of horses is least 70 years old, going back past World War I, when he served in the cavalry, to boyhood days when he hung over the rail to watch races at a halfmile track near home. He could pay $200,000 for a yearling but he is in racing for fun and doesn't care to buy that much heartburn, so he set a limit $30,000 long ago. Leroy Jolley is the yellowhaired son a horseman named Moody Jolley and it hard to say where he's from because when he was growing up 30 years ago the family kept moving with the horses from Florida to Kentucky to New York to Illinois and Leroy would attend four or five schools in a year. After high school he elected to become a trainer like his sire. They have worked together ever since. He is patient, conscientious and as courteous as Greer, whose horse he trains, but not as relaxed among strangers.

title: Nets Rout Sounds by 111 to 87
description: MEMPHIS, March 2 (AP) Julius Erving scored 8 of his 20 points, hauled in 5 of 13 rebounds and made 2 of his 6 assists in a fiveminute, thirdquarter stretch to lead the New York Nets in routing the Memphis Sounds, 11187, in the American Basketball Association today.

title: Kingman Joins Mets at Camp
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2The most heavily revamped team in the history of the New York Mets was finally assembled today when Dave Kingman reported from the San Francisco Giants and joined the army of strangers inside the locker room.

title: Pekingese
description: A black Pekingese came out of the West to triumph at the 115th specialty of the Pekingese Club of America, yesterday, He was Ch. Shady Acres Tux's Sambeau, shown and bred by his owner, Mrs. Cleda Olsen of New Lenox,

title: White Casts His Vote Against Trade Proposal
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2As soon as he arrived in camp, Roy White faced a dilemmaand it didn't have anything to do with nlavine first base.

title: MARCOS BIDS AIDES DISCLOSE ASSETS
description: MANILA, March 2Pronouncing himself overwhelmed by the heavy vote in his favor in the referendum he staged last week, President Ferdinand E. Marcos has promised a return to the discipline of the early days of martial law.

title: Carey and Beame Visit Liberty's Shrine to Pledge Support to Jews
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame took a ferry to the Statue of Liberty yesterday to proclaim April 13 Solidarity Sunday in New York in support of Jews in the Soviet Union who are denied the right to emigrate.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: World Bank Weighs New Aid Program Not Dependent on U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The World Bank and its richer member nations, including the oilproducing nations, are moving toward the first major international aid program for the world's poorer countries that would not depend on United States participation.

title: Taft, Lafayette P. S.A.L. Finalists
description: A basket by Anthony Price and an offensive foul by Reese Blount helped decide the finalists yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs.

title: FREEDOM SOUGHT BY PUERTO RICANS
description: NEWARK, March 2  The Puerto Rican Solidarity Day Committee, which last October, drew 20,000 people to a Madison Square Garden rally in support of independence for Puerto Rico, organized itself into a permanent body in a weekend conference on the Rutgers University campus here.

title: Business Briefs
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 2 (AP)Leonard Schnell, president of the Ohio Farm Bureau, warned farmers last night that they could be sealing their doom at market time if they comply with President Ford's request for allout grain production. He said corn prices could fall to $1.50 per bushel in the autumn if American farmers opted for maximum production and the nation received normal weather.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER NEW ENERGY PLAN; FORD MAY ACCEPT
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee formally issued proposals for a national energy program today, and Administration officials privately indicated that the plan offered a better basis for compromise with the White House than the program announced last week by two panels of Congressional Democrats.

title: Speed Limit Enforcement
description: BOSTON, March 2 (AP)The Massachusetts Turnpike; Authority said today that it had doubled its manpower for enforcing the 55mileanhour speed limit on the roadways. John T. Driscoll, chairman of the authority, said he had authorized purchase of a new radar unit and that seven additional state troopers had beer assigned to enforce the speed limit.

title: 76ers, Led By Carter, Top Knicks
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2 I love to get the ball down the stretch when the game is on the line, said Fred Carter of the Philadelphia 76ers. Carter, smiling broadly, was recalling the two crucial baskets he made in the late stages of a 9187 triumph over the New York Knicks today at The Spectrum.

title: Miss Banks Wed To Philip Grayson
description: Katherine Banks, daughter of Mr and Mrs. James Banks of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Palm Desert, Calif., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Schuyler Grayson. He is the son of Mr and Mrs. Morton Grayson of Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: Ocean County Drops Its Bounty for Foxes
description: TOMS RIVER, March 2 The Ocean County Board of Chosen Freeholders, trying to pare its budget, has eliminated its $1,000 annual appropriation for fox bounties.

title: High Tides Around New York
74 Held in Violation Of New Smoking Law
description: Seventy  four summonses have been Issued to violators of the city Health Code ban on smoking in elevators, supermarkets and other public places since the law went into effect last Dec. 16, according to a survey by the Health Department.

title: LOBOTOMY BY DRUG CHARGED TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (Reuters)  A physician who has made a study of the Soviet Union has testified to Senate staff members that secret police psychiatrists perform what he called chemical lobotomy on dissidents.

title: Ruth Warrick, Actress, Reweds
description: Ruth Warrick, the actress, and L. Jarvis Cushing Jr were married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn., at the home of Mrs. George Lowther 3d, the friend who introduced them last April.

title: Henry Heyl, Neurosurgeon, Dies; Associate Dean at Dartmouth
description: Dr. Henry L. Heyl, a former associate dean of the Dartmouth Medical School and editor of the Journal of Neurosurgery, died Saturday in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N. H. He was 68 years old and lived in Norwich, Vt.

title: Baird. Irvine Triumph
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 2Steve Baird and Hank Irvine of Short Hills, N.J., won the ninth Greenwich Invitation platform tennis tournament at the Greenwich Field Club today by defeating Keith Jennings and Chauncey Steele of Boston, 57, 62, 62, 86.

title: Assembly Bill to Seek FairTrade End
description: The state's fairtrade law, which prohibits a merchant from selling certain goods at prices below those stipulated by the manufacturer, would be epealed under a bill that 61 Assemblymen said they were cosponsoring in the Legislature.

title: A Turn for Worse Taken by Runner
description: Justin Gubbins of the New York Athletic Club took a wrong turn yesterday for the second straight week during the Road Runners Club of New York competition at Central Park, and for the second straight week it (cost him a victory.

title: Murphy Wins Golf By Stroke
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 2Six strokes behind Jack Nicklaus is no place to be on a Sunday afternoon, as Bob Murphy says. But Murphy closed that gap today with a 68 and won the Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic in one of the tightest finishes of this season's pro golf tour.

title: U.S. Aides Doubt Lon Not Will Resign in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 State Department officials said today that despite the apparent willingness of President Lon Nol to step aside if he was a barrier to a peaceful settlement in Cambodia, they doubted that it would occur so long as the Cambodian insurgents refuse to negotiate.

description: ALTA LAKE, British Columbia, March 2 (AP)Ingemar. Stenmark of Sweden won a men's World Cup giant slalom ski race today on Whistler Mountain.

title: tire Wipes Out 1,000 jobs And $2Million in Ratables
description: SHELTON, Conn., March 2For two long blocks by the Housatonic River, just above the place where it is joined by the Naugatuck on its winding course to Long Island Sound, people stood silent, almost shoulder to shoulder, watching firemen direct streams of water onto twisted machinery and the smoldering brick ruins of the old Sponge Rubber Products Company plant here.

title: Individuals Playing Big Role In Wall Street Trading Surge
description: During the first two months of 1975, the stock market erupted in its heaviest sustained trading in history. Prices rocketed upward along with volume, breaking the back of a bear market and astonishing customers and brokers alike.

title: Lindsay, at Worship, Tells of Advice in Israel
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay told evensong worshipers yesterday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine that he had advised young Israelis who had expressed concern to him about what their country stood for not to worry too much because the United States was on the brink of its bicentennial and still hadn't the foggiest idea of what to do about it or what it stands for.

title: Kerry Kleid Is Coast Bride
description: Kerry Kleid, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Lewis Kleid, was married Saturday evening to Richard F. Schroeder; son of Mr and Mrs. F. R. (Ted) Schroeder. Both families are of La Jolla, Calif. Justice of the Peace Thomas Gligorea performed The ceremony there at the Kleid home.

title: Ellis, Still on Feet, Stopped by Frazier
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, March 2 (AP)Joe Frazier stopped a weary and bleeding Jimmy Ellis in the ninth round today in his bid to gain a fight for Muhammad Ali's world heavyweight boxing title.

title: CONSERVATIVE BLOC IN WARNING TO FORD
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)A group of 28 conservative Republican leaders served notice on President Ford today that their support cannot be taken for granted and that neither he nor anyone else has a lock on the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976.

title: Critic's Notebook: All About Movies
description: Today, as many have noted, the public's response to movies is far more personal than it is to other forms of artyou don't hear people fighting about books or plays in the way that they clash over films. Friendships bruised by violently different opinions on the work of Michelangelo Antonioni or Stanley Kubrick or Sam Peckinpah may have easily weathered many genial disagreements about Vladimir Nabokov or Edward Albee or Muriel Spark.

title: Judith Young Married to Eliezer Amdur
description: The marriage of Judith Estelle Young, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Henry Young of New York and Winterton, N.Y., to Eliezer Nahum Amdur, son of Mrs. Joseph Amdur of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Cantor Amdur, took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: Brazil's Boom Is Clouded by Crisis in Textile Industry Big Producer Seeks Agreethent With Creditors as Output Drops
description: SAO PAULO, BrazilThis nation's important textile industry is in trouble, with a substantial drop in production, widespread dismissals and a number of small producers going bankrupt.

title: City Opera: Strasfogel's New Salome
description: Salome has never been an easy opera to stage in our jaded times. There is so much reallife degeneracy and sadism on every side that the Strauss musical version can seem mild stuff indeed. Moreove, there is so little worth one's attention under the theatrical surface of the work that unless it is presented as a fairy tale of some sort the vulgarity and foolishness of it all become too obvious to overcome.

description: SHELTON, Conn., March 2Three armed men, wearing ski masks and hinting a connection with the radical Weathermen, set off explosions that destroyed a multimillion dollar rubber factory here last night after abducting three employes from the plant.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter has been bothered by a hamstring problem in his right leg, but he reported it was improving. I've had the same problem in past springs, the pitcher explained. It comes from putting pressure on two of the toes on my right foot. That foot is the one that has only four toes, the result of a hunting accident... If the stiffness in the leg disappears. Manager Bill Virdon said Hunter could make his Yankee debut in the exhibition game against Baltimore Saturday . . . Roy White on one of the problems, he could face playing first base: Holding a runner on with Boog Powell 1250pound lefthanded hitterj at bat.

description: The National Lampoon Show, the successor to National Lampoon Lemmings, which had a long run several seasons ago Off Broadway, has just opened its doors in the New Palladium club on West 51st Street. Partisans are hurrying to be amusedand to be attacked. One of the show's primary objects is to insult its audience. We don't care about you is a laundered version of the cast's repeated charge to the paying customers.

title: Oklahoma Jury Hears Tapes of Former Governor
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 1 From midDecember until midJanuary, Oklahoma's Secretary of State, John Rogers, was virtually a walking radio station for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: GRANDFIELD, Okla., March 2 (UPI)A gunman who reportedly killed a man and held his wife and son hostage in their car for about an hour to day surrendered peacefully to officers. The police said that the man, whom they did not immediately identify, walked up

title: CONGRESS GROUP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 2A factfinding delegation of eight members of the United States Congress left for home tonight after a heated, theatrical encounter this morning with representatives of North Vietnam and the Viet cong's Provisional Revolutionary Government.

title: HERMAN H. BARR
description: Herman Henry Barr, retired head of Barr's Jewelers and Silversmiths, a countrywide chain, died Thursday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 89 years old and formerly lived in Philadelphia.

title: Middle East Lenders Bypassing Banks Direct Loans MadeCurrency Holdings Are Diversified
description: PARIS, March 2Lenders from the Middle East are increasingly placing their money directly with borrowers, skirting the banking system while Using the bankers as intermediary brokers, highly placed European bankers have reported.

title: KEY HEALTH POSTS REMAIN UNFILLED
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Almost three months after the nation's chief  health official submitted his resignation, the Ford Administration still has not named his renlacarnent.

title: Lampkin Hospitalized After Knockout in 14th
description: PANAMA CITY, March 2 (AP)Roberto Duran of Panama smashed Ray Lampkin of Portland, Ore., to the cans vas with a left hook in the 14th round today to retain his World Boxing Association lightweight champion shin.

description: 7 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Trumpet Concerto, ummel; Symphony No. 41, Mozart.

title: Oil Depletion Vote Reflects New South
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The thrashing taken by Southern Congressmen on the vote to kill the oil depletion allowance is fresh evidence of the winds of change that are blowing through the House of Representatives.

title: Chicago Law Students Decry a Use of Grades.
description: CHICAGO, March 2Law students at the University of Chicago are embroiled in a controversy over the reintroduction of grades as a criterion for selection to the staff of the school's Law Review.

title: Vermont Democrats Elect
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March (AP) State Senator Robert Branon of Fairfield was elected chairman of the Vermont Democratic party today.

title: LEILA V. CRAWFORD
description: Leila Varet Crawford, formerly directressgeneral of the Society of the Daughters of Holland Dames and president of the Society of Colonial Dames in New York, who had been active for 40 years in the Humane Society of New York, died Saturday at her home, 1130 Park Avenue. She was 73 years old.

title: Advertising
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, this country's largest worldwide advertising agency, has filed suit against a former executive vice president, alleging that he schemed to take away clients and employes while still on the Thompson payroll.

description: SHELTON, Conn., March 2Three armed men, wearing ski masks and hinting a connection with the radical Weather

title: Barlycorn Victor At Ox Ridge Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 2John Barlycorn, a smoothstepping 5yearold bay gelding, won his second championship in two weeks today, capturing the local working hunter title at the concluding session of the twoday Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor horse show.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nearly 50 representatives of Newark's city departments and agencies ended a threeday workshop at Point Pleasant yesterday with a plan to cut bureaucratic inertia and improve city services by setting up interagency liaisons and bettering communications with the public. It is to be implemented over the next six months.

title: French Call Meeting
description: PARIS, March 2France announced today that invitations had been sent out to the European Common Market countries and nine other nations for meeting here on April 7 to prepare for a projected international oil conference of both producers and consumers.

title: Quality of Justice
description: Chief Justice Burger's recent gloomy assessment of the state of the Federal judicial system, coming as it did the wake of the great coverup verdict, had a sad ironic quality. While the country was still warmed by the afterglow of its most successful law enforcement effort, the Chief Justice warned that it was forcing on the Federal judicial systemand thus on the quality of justicea condition of acute, progressive deterioration.

title: BAR GROUP SEEKS COURTS OVERHAUL
description: NEWARK, Mar. 2 (UPI)A preliminary report by a committee of the State Bar Association has called for an overhaul of New Jersey's court structure and judicialselection piucess, saying there is too much political interference.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
8 Tons of Fireworks Held
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP)  Eight tons of firecrackers, skyrockets and aerial bombs were seized by state fire marshals in a storeroom behind downtown machinery shop, the authorities said. An unidentified man was booked for investigation of possession of illegal fireworks yesterday, officials said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation's Schools Renewing Stress on the Basics
description: Because of falling test scores and parents demands for a nofrills education for their children, public elementary schools around the country are placing renewed emphasis on teaching basic reading and mathematics skills.

title: 100Mile USAC Opener Captured Easily by Foyt
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March (AP)A.J. Foyt of Houston the 40yearold threetime Indianapolis 500 winner, led virtually from start to finish today to win the first of the twin 100mile races at Ontario Motor Speedway, which opened the United States Auto Club Championship Car series.

title: Sony Buys German Concern
description: TOKYO, March 2 (Reuters) The Sony Corporation announced it has reached agreement with Wega Radio G. tn b. H. of West Germany to buy all shares in the company and its subsidiary, Wega HiFi G m. b. M. 'he company's annual sales are about $50million, Sony said.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city will appeal last month's decision by State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol that invalidated the landmarks designation of Grand Central Terminal, Mayor Beame announced yesterday. This case has great signifi, cance to the future of preservation in New York City and in the entire United States, the Mayor said in a statement.

title: Moss Panel Links Doctors to Abuses In Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Many abuses in American nursing homes can be laicrto doctors treating of elderly patients by telephone, with rare personal visits, according to a Senate subcommittee report released today.

title: L.L's Construction Men Wait in Vain for Jobs
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.The man made an offer: carry a few panels up flight of stairs and make a quick $5. Two of the men hanging around Carpenters Hall here accepted, but John Martorano declined.

title: Berlin Vote Sets Back Social Democrats, but Coalition Expected
description: BERLIN, March 2The opposition Christian Democrats, whose mayoral candidate, Peter Lorenz, has been in the hands of kidnappers for three days, made substantial gains in the Berlin elections today, but failed to win a majority and the Social Democratic mayor, Klaus Schutz, is expected to remain in office.

title: Jewish Youths Ousted From West Bank Site
description: JERUSALEM, March 2 (AP) Israeli troops evicted 60 young Jews today from a hill in occupied Jordan where they had tried to make their home.

title: Algerian Warns Oil Nations of a Western Crusade
description: ALGIERS, March 2Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria formally opened the ministerial conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here today with an appeal for united action to counter the Western crusade against the group of 13 countries.

title: Bruins Beat Hawks On Late 4Goal Rally
description: BOSTON, March 2 (AP) Wayne Cashman broke a 22 tie with a powerplay goal in, the third period and the Boston Bruins added three insurance scores today, top post a 62 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Long Layoff Embitters Linden G. M. Workers
description: LINDEN, N.J.On Jan. 4, 1974, about 2,600 workers at the General Motors assembly plant here were let go in what they were told was a temporary layoff. Now that temporary layoff has entered its second year, and those unemployed workers have become bitter toward the company and their union.

title: INFANT'S DEATH LAID TO COUSINS, 4 AND 5
description: SYRACUSE, March 2 (AP)  Police here said today that a 4yearold girl and 5yearold boy apparently killed their 11dayold cousin.

title: Bridge:
description: Two young experts vanquished a large field of New York stars here Saturday, winning the twosession open pair championship in the Greater New York Bridge Association's tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel. Kit Woolsey of Washington, who represented the United States in the world pair championship last summer, added another title to his collection with the aid of Karen Thomas of New York, who won her first major title here.

title: Ashe Downs Okker
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 2 (AP)Arthur she won the singles final of a World Championship Tennis Green Group tournament today, defeating Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 36, 62, 64

title: WrongWay Regents
description: At a time when education, at all levels and in all institutions, faces unprecedented problems which cry out for rational analysis and broad public understanding, antibusing ideologues on the Board of Regents continue to ride roughshod over common sense and legal requirements. Instead of letting the busing issue rest on the board's recent moderate clarification, Regent William Jovanovich has announced his intention to reopen the controversy at the next meeting.

title: Retail Chain Sales Rose a Scant 5.8.% During January
description: The nation's 40 largest retail chains had a sales gain of 5.8 per cent in January, one of their smallest year to year gains in several years, according to a survey released this week.

Television
description: Morning

title: About the Mets
description: Early casualty report: Joe Torre skipped yesterday's workout because his back was hurting, but he appeared at the Mets complex and said he'd be back today Dave Klenda, a 24yearold catcher who was invited to camp help warm up the pitchers, was struck by a line drive during batting practice but was not injured.In the annual OldTimers Game for the March of Dimes, the Mets supplied Ralph Kiner, who took his first swings since being voted into the Hall of Fame; Yogi Berra, who got into his catching gear again, and several coaches, including 58yearold Phil Cavaretta at first base. But the American League seniors, with Bob Feller pitching, outlasted the Nationals, 60.Willie Mays reported that he had visited youth groups in 28 cities this winter. He flew into camp briefly, then headed back to New York for one day officiate at a relay meet for children. They need help, man, he said with feeling.

title: Fed Begins to Moderate Its Pace of Easing Credit
description: The Federal Reserve continues to ease credit conditions, but this pace has begun to moderate for two reasons.

title: 27 Killed in Nairobi As a Crowded Bus Is Ripped by a Bomb
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2 (Reuters)A bomb explosion ripped open a crowded bus parked in the center of Nairobi last night, killing at least 27 people and injuring 90 in an apparently motiveless act of terrorism.

title: Rolfe Is Lost in Rangers 86 Setback
description: Dale Rolfe, the Rangers biggest and most experienced defenseman, shattered his left ankle last night. That gloomy fact far outweighed Pittsburgh York's 8.6 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins, as well as the disappearing margin between the Rangers and first place, which is now 10 points.

title: For Israelis on a Tense Border, Danger Is the Norm
description: METULLAH, IsraeL Feb. 26 Ask anyone along Israel's northern border with Lebanon what life is like these days and the answer is, Everything is normal.

title: A NEW CAREY PLAN ON U.D.C. SET TODAY Governor to Ask Legislature for $110Million to Maintain the Agency for 2 Months
description: Governor Carey, in a shift of policy, will ask the Legislature today for an immediate $110million appropriation to prevent chaos and keep the Urban Development Corporation's assets from being dismembered.

title: Mark Twain Is Said To Have Met Quota As Magnet School
description: Officials in Brooklyn's Community School District 21 yesterday claimed success in their drive to register enough students to attend Mark Twain Junior High School, which will become the city's first special magnet middle school for gifted studehts next fall under a courtordered integration plan.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame took a ferry ride to the Statue of Liberty yesterday to proclaim April 13 Solidarity Sunday in New York in support of Jews in the Soivet Union who are denied the right to emigrate. Whenever and wherever people who have committed no crimes are forbidden to leave a country, our Statue of Liberty stands threatened, said the Mayor as representatives of 60 Jewish organizations gathered in the cold near a lawn at the base of the statue and unfurled a 30foot red banner expressing of Soviet Jews.

title: Budget Cuts for Museum Protested

title: Ford Swims at Camp David And Works on Energy Plan
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., March 2 President Ford took an earlymorning swim today in the heated outdoor pool amid the icy temperatures of his mounaintop retreat before returning to work on a possible energy policy compromise with Congress.

title: By Stroke of Luck, Not by Law, Alien Avoids Deportation
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Felix Bendier, a 25yearold sometime shoemaker in Milwaukee has gained a victory over the Government that allows him to stay in the United States, where he has lived since he was 3.

title: Gunman Kills 4 at Coast Motel
description: SMITH RIVER, Calif., March 2 (UPI)  A gunman opened fire with a mailorder rifle from the balcony of a resort motel near the CaliforniaOregon border today, killing four persons And seriously wounding two others.

title: Pasadena Ready to Vote On School Board Recall
description: PASADENA, Calif, March 2 With all sides avoiding the mention of busing, voters in this suburban community northeast of Los Angeles prepared to hand down a further verdict on Tuesday on school integration.

West Berlin and West German authorities flew four convicted leftists and a hostage to Frankfurt, as they abductors demanded. The leftwing radical group that kidnapped Mr. Lorenz (Thursday morning told the police yesterday that his safe release would depend on passage out of West Germany by 9 A.M today for those of the four who desired it. The police asked the kidnappers yesterday to say Where they wanted them to go, but indicated that the deadline, could not be met.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is a kind of lovemaking that occurs only in novels. The lovers are uninterruptedly happy, never bored, satiated or restless. When they go somewhere for a weekend, they spend the whole time in their hotel room; their meals are sent in. These marathons are not inhibited by age: in Small Rain, Anthony is 58, and Maija 48.

title: Man Kind?
description: In today's crowded urban society the hunter and the trapper have become vestigial figures. Almost no one any longer hunts or traps animals to get essential food for himself and his family. Instead, the hunter has become a weekend or seasonal player acting out fantasies manliness. The trapper, meanwhile, plies a cruel and obsolete trade in a period when most, furbearing animals can be ranched and manmade furs are readily available.

title: Feminists Meet Here to Draw Attention To Condition of Women the World Over
description: The Jewelers who make and sell the official peace dove emblem know that it's going on. And so do a few highly placed women at the United Nations, who are supposed to be directing it. Most people, however, are probably unaware that 1975 is International Women's Year.

title: WILDCAT STRIKE HITS DAILY NEWS
description: The printing of this morning's editions of The Daily News was halted last night when the paper's deliverers, balking at new starting times posted by management, refused to report to work.

title: Film: 'Coup Pour Coup':A Realistic Appeal for Rights of Labor
description: Women's liberation, or better still, universal liberation from industrial injustice, is emphatically served in "Coup Pour Coup," which had its premiere yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room. The French feature made in and around Rouen in 1971 and dealing with a garment-factory strike is labeled "a fiction film." It is as realistic as a forceful documentary. And if "Coup Pour Coup" is pro-labor and shouts its pleas for justice with the fervor of Soviet agitprop films of the past, it nevertheless presents a strong case, even if passionately slanted.Despite subtitles, "Coup Pour Coup" calls for further explanation. According to program notes, it is a collective effort involving about 100 people, including some "60 unemployed working women, film makers and actors and actresses," who were paid the same $300 a month fee and who collaborated on the filming and dialogue.In shooting the film in a manner that was "a metaphor for the story of the film," the producers have achieved striking naturalism both in their, simple story line and from their unprofessional cast. Essentially, "Coup Pour Coup" traces the stultifying effects of the assembly line on these women, some of whom do double duty as mothers after work. Inadequate pay, a hard-driving management, lip-serving union officials and the dismissals of two workers finally serve to provoke a strike and a sit-in take-over of the plant, a revolt that leads to ultimate victory and the meeting of their demands.Although it is impossible to differentiate actor from authentic worker, the "performances" are, by and large, properly rough-hewn and seemingly ad lib. The old woman who reminisces about her strike experience in 1936 seems to be as real as the young, harried sit-in mother who rails at her husband's inability to handle their youngsters.Perhaps the seizing of the plant owner, whom the workers plague "blow for blow" with the indignities they have had to endure, is a bit melodramatic. But the cast appears to project truth as well as passion and understanding of their newly found camaraderie in their resistance to hired thugs and the police, their cynical put-downs of union leaders and in the help from friends, farmers and other workers who have joined them in sympathy strikes."Coup Pour Coup" does not list credits for either a writer or a director, but if the collaborators here have fashioned a tract, they have also invested it with a good deal of human drama.

title: The Kaplan Report

The question involves thousands of New Yorkers whose last days on earth were spent in misery and degradation because profiteers were permitted to carry on exploitation as usual as result of official carelessness, political ineptitude worse. It involves the further question of whether history, after this round of nursinghorie revelations, will repeat itself and leave the profiteers still free to evade their legal and human responsibilities.

Furthermore, he denies that some parents are reluctant to send their children to the camp because he might be their fielding instructor.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Senate took an important procedural step today toward resolving by early next week at the latest the dispute over a change in its filibuster rules.

A Rare Arctic Gull in Massachusetts
description: SALISBURY, Mass., March 3Telephones rang. The word was passed. Up and down the East Coast, dedicated men and women rose in the middle of the night, shouldered their equipment and drove hours through the darkness to take up their cold watches along the marshes and beaches here where the Merrimack River flows into the Atlantic.

title: Grants W on By 27 Girls At Garden
description: Chevelle Hartridge, an 11yearold fourth grade student at Public School 241, was the first winner of a $500 grantinaid for education yesterday at the Colgate Women's Games track and field meet at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON. March 3Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in, both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Argentine Farmers Call Strike In a Protest Over Low Prices
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 3Argentine farmers called a 24hour strike today to protest low prices for agricultural products and high taxes.

title: Chess
description: Woodchoppers, as they are called by the cognoscenti, are devotees of the game who, never raising their sights to the level of longrange plans like positional encirclements or mating attacks, frantically hack down the nearest target.

title: Bolshoi Ballet and Opera Will Tour U.S. Together
description: MOSCOW, March 3The Bolshoi Theater announced today that its ballet and opera companies would make a joint tour of the United States for the first time this summer.

title: Young vs. Norton On Ali Title Card
description: Jimmy Young of Philadelphia will take on Ken Norton March 24 as part of a closedcircuit television doubleheader featuring the heavyweight title bout between Muhammed Ali, the champion and Chuck Wepner. Young replaces Oscar Bonavena, who withdrew.

title: COURT REVERSES MATTHEW VERDICT
description: An appeals court in Brooklyn yesterday struck down the 1973 conviction of Dr. Thomas W. Matthew on charges that he had illegally diverted $200,000 in Medicaid funds from his Interfaith Hospital in Queens to other black selfhelp programs he was developing.

title: Less Than Half in Poll Believe an Energy Lag
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)A year after the end of the Arab oil embargo, fewer than half the Americans polled in a special Gallup survey believe there is an energy shortage.

title: Spanish Monument Bombed
description: MADRID, March 3 (UPI)A bomb blast today damaged a, Civil War monument erected by the Franco regime on the outskirts of Madrid, Europa Press Agency said.

title: THAIS TO ASK U.S FOR SPEEDIER EXIT
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 3The new civilian minority Government announced plans today to set an 18month deadline for the withdrawal of United States forces from Thailand.

title: A SOLDIER IS KILLED IN LEBANESE AMBUSH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3One soldier was killed and 29 were wounded when their truck was ambushed in the strifetorn southern port of Saida today, according to a military communique issued here.

title: Debt Issue Will Be Concern's First in 21 Years
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday plans to borrow $600million by issuing debentures and notes.

title: Byrne Called Ready to End Drive A gainst Inquiry Unit
description: TRENTON, March 3Governor Byrne and the Democratic legislative majorities were reported this evening prepared to abandon efforts to abolish the State Commissior of Investigation.

title: Shelton Assesses Effects of Plant Blast
description: SHELTON, Conn., March 3The people of this mill town took stock of their position today following the blast and fires that destroyed a multimillion dollar rubber factory, wiping out 800 jobs. They found little reason for hope.

title: Goldwater Says Cambodia Will Fall Soon, and Should
description: LINWOOD, N. J., March 3 (AP)Senator Barry Goldwater said tonight that Cambodia is going down the tubes, and he doubted that additional American aid could prevent the Communistled insurgents from taking over the Government.

title: Liberal Coalition Plans to Lobby For Human
description: WASHINGTON, March 3A score of liberal activist groups representing factory workers, teachers, farmers, environmentalists, mayors, churchmen and home builders announced a new coalition today to lobby for domestic and human concerns in the Federal budget.

title: Energy Plan in Sight
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The House Ways and Means Committee has been acquitting itself well in its new incarnation without Wilbur Mills and with an infusion of new blood. First it came through speedily with a S21.3billion antirecession tax cut weighted heavily to low and middleincome persons. Now the committee under Chairman Al Ullman of Oregon has produced the outlines of an effective energy program that obviously has given President Ford second thoughts about his

title: Theodore C. Miller, 48, Dies; Associate Dean at Paterson
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 3  Dr. Theodore C. Miller, associate dean of humanities at William Paterson College in Wayne, died yesterday after long illness at the Neurological Institute of Presbyterian Hospital in New York. He was 48 years old.

title: GERMAN RADICALS FLOWN TO MIDEAST
description: BERLIN, March 3The West German Government flew five imprisoned radicals to the Middle East today in capitulation to the demands of kidnappers who have been holding a Berlin political leader as a hostage here since Thursday.

title: Art Stolen From Car
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March (UPI)The police sought thief today who took $50,000 worth of art, including works by Picasso, from the parked car of Beverly Finn, 35 years old, a soprano with the San Francisco Opera Company.

title: ELY M. AARON
description: Ely M. Aaron, a Chicago lawyer since 1919, and chairman of that city's Commission on Human Relations from 1960 to 1966, died yesterday at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: Fifth Victim Dies in Coast Shooting
description: SMITH RIVER, Calif., March 3 (AP)A fifth person died today following a shootlog yesterday in which a gunman armed with a highpowered rifle opened fire from a balcony at a motel here.

title: MURDER DEFENSE TIED TO DRUG USE
description: PATERSON, Marci 3Juan Colon, on trial here for murder, testified today that he had been under the influence of heroin during an attempted robbery that resulted in two of his accomplices allegedly beating 79  year  old Roman Catholic priest to death.

title: A Mao Associate Assails Bourgeois
description: HONG KONG, March 3China's leading polemicist, Yao Wenyuan, has warned in a major political pronouncement that new bourgeois elements and upstarts are threatening to undermine the socialist system and seize power.

title: Medical School Plight

title: Daily News Is Shut 2d Day by Strike; Layoffs Planned
description: The Daily News shut down operations for the second day after newspaper deliverers, protesting new work schedules, defied a preliminary injunction last night and refused to report for work.

title: Young Criminals
description: The need for rethinking some of the wellintentioned laws that distinguish between juvenile offenders and adult criminals is indicated by the escalating figures of murder, rape and armed robberies committed by teenagers throughout the country.

title: KISSINGER IS COOL ON EFFORT SOUGHT IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Secretary of State Kissinger was reported today to be unenthusiastic about suggestions from members of a Congressional factfinding mission just back from Indochina that he make a new major diplomatic effort to settle the conflicts in Cambodia and South Vietnam.

title: Mystery of Valentine Day Triple Goes According to Form at Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., March 3Boat race? said David Brodsky, responding to a question today in the jockey room at Bowie Race Course. I'm not sure I understand what you mean by boat race.

title: U.D.C. Bill Stalled
description: Governor Carey's request for $110million to allow the Urban Development Corporation to pay its bill stalled in the Legislature yesterday, with legislative leaders describing the amount as excessive. Details, Page 21.

title: New Direction
description: Despite the praise and enhanced stature that he won for reversing United States policy toward mainland China, former President Nixon could never quite bring himself to revise the Government's similarly anachronistic stance toward Fidel Castro's Cuba. Now, with a President unburdened by emotional attachments to the policy an earlier decade, the Administration is, in Secretary State Kissinger's words, prepared to move in a new direction toward Cuba.

title: Oil Product Prices Begin to Slip At Retail Level Across Europe
description: PARIS, March 3 European consumers are starting to pay less for gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products reflecting the growing world surplus of oil and the increase in the value of their currencies against the dollar.

title: On Academic Quotas
description: The recession is not the only threat to long overdue justice for women in academic employment. Professional opponents, cashing in on their moral prestige as Establishment intellectuals, have sought to convince the public, the Congress and the President that faculty affirmative action is unworkable and unjust and that its implementation must be rescinded.

title: Justices Bar Review on Denial of Damages for Victims of Jackson State Shootings in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Victims of the 1970 police shootings on the Jackson State College campus in Mississippi failed today to persuade the Supreme Court to review lower court decisions denying them damages from the officers involved.

title: Market Place
description: Judging from the remarks of spokesmen for the Securities and Exchange Commission, the agency does a superior job in answering most of some 10,000 complaints the agency says it receives from the public each year.

title: Police Question Witnesses In Slaying of Policeman
description: CAMDEN, March 3 (UPI)The police were questioning witnesses today to establish a motive in the shotgun death yesterday of an offduty Lawnside police officer. The Camden police said that patrolman James Morris, 45 years old, was round sprawled on Federal street in Camden at about 0 P.M with a gunshot wound n the chest.

description: March 4, 1975 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. on the Cyprus question.

description: Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that Albert Podell, the controversial former lobbyist for Common Cause, had been intemperate in discussing his tactics, but that Mr. Podell's activities themselves, hid not violated the law.

title: LUNCH PLAN SLASH MAY HIT 6 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)The Ford Administration wants to cut Federal school lunch subsidies for children from middleincome homes, and Agriculture Department experts say that up to six million children could be involved.

title: Record Industry Is Taking a Hard Look At How Representative Grammys Are
description: As the dust settles from the 1974 Grammy Awards  presented on a nationwide telecast Saturday night in a ceremony originating at the Uris Theater on Broadway, many recurrent complaints are welling up once again from record executives over how representative the awards really are.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
SARAH P. LEVENTHAL
description: Sarah Polter Leventhal, former president of the Globe Book Company, and widow of Murray J. Leventhal, its founder who also was chairman and former mathematics chairman at James Madison High School in Brooklyn died Sunday in Coney Island Hospital. She was 83 years old.

title: Cuomo Urges a Ban on All Gifts From Lobbyists to Legislators
description: ALBANY, March 3secreta Mario ry of State Mario M. Cuomo recommended today that lobbyists be prohibited from giving Legislators and members of executive departments anything of value, even as much as a cocktail or a dinner.

title: Jersey City Firemen Start Phone Drive to Save Jobs
description: JERSEY CITY, March 3At 10 o'clock this morning, Thomas Carney, an offduty fireman who was one of the 65 men marked for dismissal, made the first of the day's 900 calls to Jersey City residents selected at random from the city's telephone directory.

title: An Abandoned Lion Taken to S.I. Zoo
description: An adolescent African lion who had charmed the children of a Staten Island neighhood since he had been abandoned by his owners and left chained to a backyard shed last week was tranquilized and carted off to the Staten Island Zoo last night after an alarmed adult called the mike.

title: Lehman's Five Wins CUNY Title
description: Lehman College fought off a determined secondhalf effort to beat City College, 5451, and capture its second straight City University of New York basketball title last night. A crowd of 800 watched the final at Queens College.

title: N.B.A. Still Seeks New Head Man
description: The National Basketball Association's 18 owners made a trip here yesterday for a special meeting to vote on a new commissioner. They didn't. The fourman selection committee didn't present them with a name to vote on, despite indications they had narrowed the field to one man.

title: COURT REVERSES MATIIIEW VERDICT
description: An appeals court in Brooklyn yesterday struck down the 1973 conviction of Dr. Thomas W. Matthew on charges that he had illegally diverted $200,000 in Medicaid funds from his Interfaith Hospital in Queens to other black selfhelp programs he was developing.

title: Tito, Preparing For the Succession, Tightens His Reins
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3  President Tito has begun a political campaign against suspected adversaries at home and abroad.

title: BRONX FIRE KILLS 2 ELDERLY WOMEN
description: Two elderly women died last night in a threealarm Bronx apartmenthouse fire that authorities said had been set by a 4yearold boy.

title: Lockheed Layoffs Rising
description: BURBANK, Calif., March 3 (Reuters)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has cut 1,000 workers from its two aircraft plants in Southern California since Jan. 1, and another 1,000 will be dropped by July, a company spokesman said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, March 3 (UPI) So eager were the leaders of the town of Cherkassy in the Ukraine to have a good soccer team that they imported a complete club, billeted the players in a hotel, paid them generous wages and fed them caviar, said Pravda, the Soviet press agency, today. But it all fell apart when the team celebrated a victory by fighting and smashing furniture in a restaurant, finally ending up in jail.

title: Critic's Notebook: Or How to See Movies
description: The question most purictually tossed at a movie critic (it starts after a month at the post) is whether you're tired of movies, or if you've ceased to enjoy them. The answer from this corner is that the appetite has only increased. But you need to keep widening your movie experience in order to stay fresh, especially through seeing revivals of many styles and periodswhile you're saturated in the idioms ca contemporary film.

title: SOME EXG.I.'S CALLED VICTIMS OF JOB BIAS
description: The city's Human Rights Commissioner, Eleanor Holmes Norton, said yesterday that Vietnam veterans with less than honorable discharges were being discriminated against in job opportunities, and she urged an ungraded discharge system for all veterans.

title: Bridge
description: An event that was once part of every tournament program but is now on the endangered species list ended the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional at the New York Hilton Hotel here Sunday.

title: and the Succession
description: The Ford Administration, not surprisingly, sees no reason for revision although President Ford has politely affirmed that perhaps Congress ought to take another look at the question of Presidential succession. The constitutional amendments subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee last week held public hearings do just that. Unfortunately, most of the testimony revealed considerable complacency about the status quo.

title: Beleaguered Rock Island To Get Employe Loans
description: The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad, contending that it faced bankruptcy unless it obtained immediate financial aid, reached agreement yesterday with officials of 17 unions representing company employes providing for an interestfree loan to the company in the form of voluntary 10 per cent pay cuts to be repaid at a later date.

title: CAREY ASKS U. S. FOR DISASTER AID
description: Governor Carey asked the Federal Government yesterday to extend disasterassistance loans to businesses hurt by the loss of telephone service as a result of last Thursday's fire in a lower Manhattan switching center of the New York Telephone Company.

title: Brooklyn Youth Wins Science Talent Search
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Paul A. Zeitz, a 16yearold Brooklyn youth who is first in a class of 700 at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan was awarded the first prize of a $10,000 college scholarship in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, tonight for work in advanced theoretical mathematics.

Fed's Retiring Foreign Money Head Hopeful of Dollar
description: Charles A. Coombs held his final news conference yesterday as head of foreign currency operations of the Federal Reserve System. Although the dollar had been so weak that a Swiss franc that cost 37 cents in November cost nearly 42 cents yesterday, Mr. Coombs sounded optimistic.

title: Birth Control Devices: What Studies Show About Side Effects
description: Birth Pill Linked to Strokes, IUD Cited in 11 Deaths, Pill Said to Cause Liver Tumors, Doctor Fears Birth Pill May Increase Cancer Risk, F.D.A. Seizes Unsafe IUD, Senators Question Pill's Safety.

title: Miss Stap Wins In Tennis Upset
description: BOSTON, March 3 (AP)Unseeded Sue Stap of Deerfield, Ill., toppled Kerry Melville of Australia, 62, 63, in the opening round of the $75,000 national women's indoor tennis championships at Boston University tonight.

title: No Word in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, March 3State and Defense Department officials said today they had reno indication thus far that India was interested in purchasing American arms. These officials said, however, they would not be surprised at such a move.

title: In Dancing Spirits, Jarrett Improvises On the Keyboard
description: Keith Jarrett plays the piano as though he were dancimg with it. He is seated when he starts, but his first few notes lift him from the piano stool, his body weaving, his knees buckling as he threatens to disappear under the keyboard only to pull himself up to his full height, descend briefly to the stool and rise again, leaning into the piano in a half crouch. When he is producing soaring, romantic lines in this fashion, he seems a cross between Maurice Rocco and Chopin.

description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Shooting Suspect Freed In a WrongIdentity Case
description: Charges of attempted murder and robbery against a 19yearold Brooklyn youth were dropped yesterday because two police officers had persisted in their belief that he had been mistakenly identified and arrested as an accomplice in the crime.

title: Woman Gives Birth In Courthouse Here
description: A woman gave birth in the women's rest room on the second floor of the Criminal Courts Building yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After five days of hearings on the proposed $1.95billion capital budget for 197576, the City Council's Finance Committee decided yesterday to recommend that construction projects totaling $35.3million be scrapped and the money reallocated for other projects.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3 (AP)President Tito said today that thirdworld countries must stand together to resist threats to their independence and he appealed to oilproducing countries to help the poor nations:

title: Basic Questions
description: Only Utopians believe that it is possible to create political institutions that will guarantee personal integrity among those in power or always produce a just result. But in any society there are useful traditions that deserve to be sustained and unhealthy practices to be discouraged. There are institutions that can be improved in timely fashion or allowed to decay beyond the point of recovery.

title: Bid to Get $ 1 1 0Million for U D O Stalls
description: ALBANY, March 3Governor Carey's request for $110million to allow the Urban Development Corporation to pay its bills stalled in the Legislature today. The leaders were in apparent agreement that $110million was more state money than the U.D.C needed to stay alive right now, but in a series of meetings throughout the day they could not agree on how much was enoueh.

title: Cuba Acknowledges Kissinger Remarks On Improved Ties
description: MEXICO CITY, March 3 (AP) The official Cuban agency, Prensa Latina, today acknowledged remarks by Secretary of State Kissinger that there was no virtue in perpetual antagonism between the United states and Cuba.

title: People and Business
description: Castle & Cooke, Inc., of Honolulu is scheduled to have a change in command on April 1. Donald J. Kirchhoff, 49, president and chief operating officer of the company since June,. 1973 is to succeed Malcolm MacNaughton as chief executive officer. Mr. MacNaughton, who joined the company in 1942, will become 65 on Sunday. He will continue as board chairman.

title: Brooklyn Building to Be Made Into Vertical Industrial Park
description: A fivestory factory building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklynvacant since the Detecto Scale Company left in 1971will be remodeled into a vertical industrial park. It will be the first such venture in the country to be financed with a Federal grant.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES REX IN CHICAGO
description: Buying by holders of short positions to even out their accounts and take profits brought a strong rally in grain and soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The upswing came after sharply lower prices early in the sessiona continuation of several weeks of sliding prices.

title: Public Session Slated For Holocaust Parley
description: There will be a free public session of the conference, titled The Holocaust  A Generation After, tomorrow at 8 P.M., at the Carnegie Endowment, 345 East 46th Street.

title: Sonia Modell Shaplen Dies; Union Health Center Aide
description: Sonia Modell Shaplen, who recently retired as administrative assistant at the Union Health Center of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union here, died Wednesday in Miami. She was 85 years old and lived here at 321 West 24th Street.

title: SCRANTON TEACHERS REJECT RAISE OFFER
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 3 (AP)Striking teachers shouted down today what was described as a final offer at ending their, weekold walkout that has closed the city's 32 public schools.

title: Envoy to Hungary Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)President Ford today nominated Eugene V. McAu liffe, a career diplomat, to be Ambassador to Hungary. Mr. McAuluiffe, 56 years old, is now deputy chief of mission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels.

description: HOUSTON, March 3 (UPI)Defense attorneys for David Owen Brooks, unable to secure an instructed verdict of not guilty or a mistrial on charges that he killed one of 27 youths during three years of torturemurders, rested their case today without calling any witnesses.

description: Lieut. Diana Carol Lindsay and Lieut. Kenneth Gerard Richard, both of the Air Force, were married yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Williston Park, L. I., by the Rev. Henry R. Kupsh.

title: Article 2  No Title
Widows and Company Differ on Warning on Chemical
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The widows of five of 25 workers who died of lung cancer and the president of the chemical company where they worked clashed today before a Senate subcommittee in their descriptions of what efforts the company had taken to protect the workers. The women accused the Rohm ana Haas corn pang of Philadelphia of fail ing to give their husbands timely warning that a chemical they were working with was suspected as a cause of cancer.

description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)The Ford Administration wants to cut Federal school lunch subsidies for children from middleincome homes, and Agriculture Department experts say that up to six million children could be involved.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, has told the agency's employes he believes that none of them will face prosecution for any illegal activities, a C.I.A. spokesman said tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3A score of liberal activist groups representing factory workers, teachers, farmers, environmentalists, mayors, churchmen and home builders announced new coalition today to lobby for domestic and human concerns in the Federal budget.

title: Laurence L. Winship, 83, Dead; Retired Editor of Boston Globe
description: BOSTON, March 3 (AP)  Laurence L. Winship, retired editor of The Boston Globe, died today at Marlboro Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: BOEING EARNINGS HIGHEST SINCE
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday it had the highest quarterly and annual earnings since 1968 for the periods ended last December.

description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)The Justice Department filed suit today to force the International Harvester Company to sell its holdings in Steiger Tractor, Inc., on the ground that it was in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Capsules Contaminated
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 3 (UPI)The California Department of Health warned today that approximately 37 million capsules of lecithin, a food supplement, may be contaminated with hexane. The department said that the capsules had been distributed to California retailers in the last six months. It is not known how hexane affects the human body.

title: Nader Opens Federal Regulators
description: WASHINGTON, March 3A monthly forum for Government regulators, the usually unfamous but nonetheless important officials sometimes overlooked in Washington, was opened today by Ralph Nader and his public citizen organization.

title: OilMoney Power
description: For more than a year, the major industrial nations of the world have been living with what West German central banker Otmar Emminger once termed a financial time bomb. Their steadily mounting oilpayments debts to the petroleumexporting countries, it was feared, would reach a critical mass that might set off a chain reaction of debt moratoria, bankruptcies, devaluations, deflation and trade restrictions, blowing up the world's economic and monetary systems.

title: About the Mets
description: Manager Yogi Berra has decided not to hold any practice games in camp this week before the Mets 28game exhibition season opens Saturday. Two or three intrasquad scrimmages have been played in the past to give the hitters and pitchers some live targets, but this time they will spend the week working on fundamentals. Dr. Peter LaMotte, now the Mets surgeon emeritus while building a hospital in Hilton Head, S. C., says there is a chance George Stone may pitch despite his strained shoulder. Don't give up on him, the doctor advised. He has no pain now, but he's not throwing really, just lobbing the ball. Dave Kingman using an aluminum bat in practicesame size and weight as the wooden one, but it doesn't break or sting. Not even when he uppercuts the ball out of sight. The Mets, not burying the past, are offering their annual film again. It runs 27 minutes and is available free to organizations in the New York area. It's titled Comeback, which is what they hope will be the sequel.

title: Byrne Runs 4:16.3 To Win N. J. Mile
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 3Kevin Byrne of Bergen Catholic added another Stellar performance to his track career as he won the onemile run in 4 minutes 16.3 seconds at the sixth annual New Jersey state allgroup interscholastic track and field championships tonight at Jadwin Gym.

title: A.J.C. PLAN TO AID PATIENTS IN HOMES
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 3The women's division of the American Jewish Congress initiated today a nationwide program to link nursing home padents with the outside community through volunteer ombudsmen.

title: Roosevelt Struck, Races Go On for OTB
