Sunshine traces its roots to the outstanding drama special of the same name that was carried many months ago on the rival CBS network (which gives some indication of how competitive patterns are being disrupted). The Bob Crane Show is, technically speaking, an original.

title: Political Purpose Seen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 6 Palestinian guerrilla leaders have indicated that the commando attack in Tel Aviv last night was politically designed to serve notice on Secretary of State Kissinger that there can be no Middle East settlement without the Palestinians.

title: Orange Juice Does the Kind Really Matter?
KILLER ENTERS PLEA TO SECOND MURDER
description: Robert F. Garrow Sr., a convicted murderer, pleaded guilty in Syracuse to strangling a high school girl there in 1973 and will plead guilty to two more 1973 killings under an agreement providing for the dropping of all other charges against him, according to his lawyers.

title: About New York
description: Celebrities come and go like the buildings in New York, but a few of them stay on forever. Anita Loos, who is 4 feet 11 inches tall and usually wears a 300watt smile, does not advertise her age, but as a child in California in the eighteennineties she acted in her father's stock company, and dreamed, she says, of coming to New York.

title: E.C.A.C. Hockey In Semifinal Play
description: BOSTON, March 6  The Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament moves into its semifinal round tomorrow night at the Boston Garden and the E.C.A.C.'s top four teams will be in adtion. Harvard, with a 223 wonlost record, meets Cornell (1772) in one game and Boston University (2341) faces Vermont (2311) in the other.

title: Delay in Congress Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Congress is unlikely to move for at least a year on two separate Administration proposals for a fiveyear delay in stricter auto pollution standards, Senate sources say.

title: Evers Ordered Evicted From Senate Chamber
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 6 (UPI)Mayor Charles Evers of Fayette was evicted from the Mississippi Senate today after an unsuccessful effort to speak to the lawmakers about legislative reapportionment.

title: KISSINGER ASSAILS TEL AVIV VIOLENCE
description: CARDIFF, Wales, March 6Secretary of State Kissinger expressed concern tonight that the attack in Tel Aviv yesterday could endanger his forthcoming Middle East diplomatic efforts. But he pledged to persevere because, he said, the alternative to a negotiated settlement was more travail and tragedy, not only for the peoples concerned, but ultimately for the world.

title: The Pop Life
description: Richard Nader's latest rock n roll revival spectacular, scheduled for Madison Square Garden next Friday night, has a reasonably lavish assortment of names to attract the nostalgia fans  Jerry Lee Lewis, Lesley Gore, Bo Diddley and the Drifters are only the bestknown on the big bill.

title: Bank of America Offers Credit to Soviet
description: Because ExportImport Bank loans to the Soviet Union have been restricted, the Bank of America has offered to form a banking syndicate to lend $500million to the Russians to finance imports from the United States.

title: For Cardiff Freemen: A Night of the Baths
description: CARDIFF, Wales, March 6 Britain's Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, and the deputy speaker of the House of Commons, George Thomas, were named freemen of Cardiff today at a ceremony attended by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Subway and Bus Riding Dip Reported
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday that ridership on its subway and bus lines was down by 200,000 passengers a day in January, compared with the same month a year ago.

title: CORRECTION
Wood, Field and Stream: Quail Hunt in Mud and Rain
description: KINGSTREE, S. C.Rain threatened, but I had come a long way in quest of South Carolina's wild quail, and to back out in the final stage of the game was unthinkable.

title: SWISS LEGISLATORS BAR ABORTION SHIFT
description: GENEVA, March 7An attempt by the Swiss Cabinet, to find a compromise on the abortion issue, which sharply divides the nation, suffered a sharp setback today in the lower house of Parliament.

title: R. J. REYNOLDS FILES FOR STOCK OFFERING
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed secondary offering next month of 2.1 million shares of common stock.

title: Seizure of Foreign Vessels By U.S. Lobstermen Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Complaining that the State Department is protecting the rights of foreign fishermen, a Massachusetts Representative turned today to an obscure constitutional procedure and asked that United States lobstermen be allowed to seize foreign vessels on the high seas.

title: ROBERT E. TOWERS
EASTERN AIRLINES SEEKS FARE CUTS
description: MIAMI, March 6Eastern Airlines proposed today a 35 per cent air fare reduction on 12 of its routes, including all flights between Miami and New York.

title: STEFANO LaROSA
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (AP)Stefano LaRosa, founder and chairman of V. LaRosa & Sons, Inc., Warminster, Pa., died here today. He was 83 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtney In Lead By Shot
Burns Defends His Bid to F.B.I. on Leak
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today defended his decision to ask for an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on whether any employe of the board had leaked inforImation on bank interest rates to a magazine.

title: Columbia Recognizes Cuba
description: HAVANA, March 6 (Reuters) Cuba and Colombia today resumed diplomatic relations. Colombia is the ninth member of the Orangization of American States to renew ties with Cuba.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball Pairings
description: EAST REGIONAL

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 4%
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $845million, up 3 per cent from the yearearlier $817million. Total retail store sales were about $10.52billion, up 4 per cent from last year's $10.11billion.

title: Bank of America Offers Credit to Soviet
description: Because ExportImport Bank loans to the Soviet. Union have been restricted, the Bank of America has offered to form a banking syndicate to lend $500million to the Russians to finance imports froth the United States.

title: Brazilian Opposition Asks An Accounting on Prisoners
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 6Brazil's only legal opposition party has intensified its human rights campaign with a formal summons to the Minister of Justice to appear before Congress to render accounts on the treatment of political prisoners.

title: Advertising
description: Since the fastest growing segment of the Canadian whisky business is the bottledintheUnited States segment, it's not surprising that the Seagram Distillers Company has come up with an entry.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT LOSS OF CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6The United States Embassy believes that the best that can be hoped for here is little more than a negotiated surrender in which the only subjects open for discussion would be details, humaneness and orderliness of the Communistled insurgents' takeover.

title: West Germany's Bank Rate Reduced From 5% to 5%
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 6 Reuters)west Germany announced today a halfpoint cut in its bank rate, from 5 per cent to 5 per cent. The new rate, effective tomorrow, was announced by the central bank (Bundesbank) after a meeting of its central council here. The Lombard rate, which commercial banks pay for central bank credits, against securities, was also cut effective tomorrow from 7 per cent to 6 per cent.

title: Article 4  No Title
Bar Group Names Panel To Study Service to Elderly
description: TRENTON, March 6, APThe New Jersey State Bar Association announced today the formation of a special committee on legal services to the elderly.

title: FIREMEN REPORT BACKING ON JOBS
description: JERSEY CITY, March 6Jersey City firemen said today that they had received favorable public reaction to the telephone campaign to stop the city from dismissing 65 fire fighters next month for economy reasons.

title: The Washington Star Struggles To Survive Circulation Battle
description: WASHINGTON, March 1One day last week there appeared in The Washington Star an advertisement headed Employes Open Letter to Residents of the Washington Metro Area.

title: Iraq and Iran Sign Accord To Settle Border Conflicts
description: ALGIERS, March 6Leaders of Iran and Iraq, the major military antagonists of the Persian Gulf area, announced here today that they had agreed to settle their border dispute and end subversive infiltrations from either side.

title: Ring Continues With Siegfried at Met Met Plans
description: Opera's magnificent marathon continued Wednesday night at the Metropolitan with Siegfried, the third work in Wagner's Ring, and long before the evening ran out a weariness of voice and spirit had taken its toll. For this proved to be a Siegfried without a Siefried, unless you will settle for Jess Thomas, who certainly looks every inch the blond Nordic hero but whose once impressive tenor voice has taken on a strenuous wobble that he attempts to counteract by barking.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
MISS CORKLE DANCES IN REMEMBRANCES
description: Remembrances of things past and present is the subject of Robert Joffrey's romantic gloss of movement to Wagner's Wesendonck Songs. It contents itself with floating on the surface of the music and flows by in an almost undifferentiated stream of friendly but not incisive movement. The piece made its first appearance of the season with Francesca Corkle and Gregory Huffman as the lead couple on Wednesday evening at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: FORD BACKS SIMON ON CHALLENGING HOUSE ON TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Ford said tonight that the tax cut bill passed by the House of Representatives, giving substantial tax relief to low and middleincome taxpayers, was weighted too heavily in favor of those people and not enough in favor of those Who might spend the money more readily.[Question 12. Page 16].

title: Bomb Damages Paris Office Of West German Publishers
description: PARIS, March 6 (UPI)A bomb destroyed the Paris office of the Axel Springer publishing company of West Germany tonight and a group sympathetic to the BaaderMeinhof anarchist group claimed responsibility for the attack, the police said.

title: Holy Cross Also Gains, Beating Providence
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 6Boston College and Holy Cross, a pair of longtime rivals from Massachusetts, will meet Saturday afternoon in the final of the Eastern College Athletic ConferenceNew England basketball tournament for the right to play Furman in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. March 15.

title: Crime Figure Is Accused in LunchWagon Racket
description: Philip Rastelli, reputed head of the Joseph Bonanno crime ramily, was arraigned yesterday on Federal charges of operating an extortion and protection racket involving mobile lunch wagons.

title: Two Music Dates Off
Egyptians Reassert Hopes
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 6Egyptian officials waiting for the arrival here tomorrow of Secretary of State Kissinger today reasserted Egypt's desire to reach a secondstage military disengagement agreement with Israel through American mediation, in spite of the Palestinian attack on Tel Aviv.

title: Article 3  No Title
Bridge:
description: Some of the saddest bridge stories concern declarers who play for safety, only to find that they have gone down in a contract that any beginner would have made by routine means.

title: Thai Government, 8 Days Old, Falls in Legislative Policy Vote
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 6The eightdayold coalition Government of Premier Seni Pramoj was defeated in a confidence vote in the National Assembly today.

title: Tough Break for the A.M.A.
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6When Bobby Lee Bonds was a small boy he wanted to Then I got my first.report card, he says, and realized I wasn't doctor material. In his family, sport was the obvious alternative. His father had boxed professionally. Bobby V., the first son, played football with the Kansas City Chiefs. Sister Rosie went to the 1964 Olympics with the American record in the hurdles. Bobby Lee ran 100 yards in 9.5 seconds for Riverside Polytechnic High in California, did 25 feet 3 inches to win the state championship in the long jump, played tailback in football and was the best baseball player. But the real athlete of the family, he insists, was my second oldest brother, David. He was a lefthander who could do anything, baseball, football, basketball, run on the track team. Then he broke his collarbone here and couldn't use his left arm much. The only one who didn't play anything was mother. She had polio most of her life.

title: Settlement of a Medicaid Overpayment To Nursing Home Is Criticized by State
description: TRENTON, March 6The State Attorney General's office here was asked today to investigate a 1973 settlement for $368,787 of an overpayment of $483,316 in Medicaid funds to a Wayne Township nursing home.

title: Eakins, '86, Leads Roll of 101 Names
description: For Louise Nevelson, it had the right atmosphere, a concentration of energy. James Rosenquist enjoyed its traditionalism, the feel of something to rebound from. Marisol found it a place to meet other students. And Theresa Pollak a painter and professor emeritus of the School of the Arts of Virginia Commonwealth University, remembers its spirit of life, filled with warmth and purpose.

title: Iciness Tests Man's Mettle
description: The quality of a word, an idea, a fear, a judgment, a clich such as that New York is a cold city, rests on a correct (or adequate) but physically unexamined sense of the word.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: RIGHTS ADVOCATED FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: CHICAGO, March 6Resolutions advocating equal rights for women and for homosexuals were passed today by the governing board of the National Council of Churches meeting here.

title: Roosevelt Bets Dip At OTB in Nassau
description: In the first two nights of headtohead competition with neighboring Roosevelt Raceway, Nassau Downs OTB's handle on harness racing has dropped significantly.

title: State's Public TV Agency Expects Grant for Studio
description: TRENTON, March 6  The New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority disclosed today that it would receive a Federal grant of nearly $600,000 to enable it to build a new studio in Newark by July, 1976.

title: Michael Lewis, the Actor, Sinclair's Son, Dies at 44
description: Michael Lewis, the actor, son of the author Sinclair Lewis and the late journalist Dorothy Thompson, died last night in Overlook Hospital in Summit, N. J. Mr. Lewis was 44 years old and lived here.

title: Eakins '86, Leads Roll of 101 Names
description: For Louise Nevelson, it had the right atmosphere, a concentration of energy. James Rosenquist enjoyed its traditionalism, the feel of something to rebound from. Marisol found it a place to meet other students. And Theresa Pollak a painter and professor emeritus of the School of the Arts of Virginia Commonwealth University, remembers its spirit of life, filled with warmth and purpose.

title: PASADENA VOTERS BACK BUSING FOES
description: PASADENA, March 6  Voters here have rejected an attempt to recall three conservative, antibusing school board members and have elected a fourth busing opponent to a seat on the fivemember board.

title: Laver Gives Aussies 10 Lead
description: HARTFORD, March 6Playing in his first World Cup tennis match for the United States, Dick Stockton carried. Rod Laver of Australia to the last possible point tonight before bowing, 57, 64, 76, in a tiebreaker. Australia took a 10 lead in the fourofseven match series at Hartford Civic Arena, where six more matches are scheduled the next three days.

title: Hero of India's Opposition
description: NEW DELHI, March 6He sat atop a carnationcovered car today, smiling and waving. A youth held a black umbrella over his head to shield him from the sun. As the car moved through the heart of New Delhi, the old man mopped his brow, drank water from a cup and finally wept as tens of thousands shrieked:: Loknaik Jaya Prakash zindabad! Long live Jaya Prakash, the people's hero!

title: UNION CRITICIZES HEAD OF COMPANY
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America accused Lawrence S. Phillips, president of the PhillipsVan Heusen Corporation, yesterday of hypocrisy because, it said, he was guilty of unfair labor practices while being identified with liberal and humanitarian causes.

title: 67 ILLEGAL ALIENS FOUND AT 2 PLANTS
description: TRENTON, March 6 (AP)The state announced today that 67 illegal aliens had been discovered working at two plants of the Heidenberg Corporation in Closter. The Department of Labor and Industry said they had been found during a joint stateFederal examination.

title: Louisville Routs Dayton
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 6 (AP)  Junior Bridgeman scored 17 points tonight to lead Louisville to an 8367 victory over Dayton.

title: Islanders Play Kings To 22 Tie
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 6A goal by Jude Drouin with 2 minutes 21 seconds to play enabled the New York Islanders to salvage a 22 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight and gave them an important point in the National Hockey League standing. It also began a sevenday, fivegame stretch that will severely affect their playoff chances in the Patrick Division.

title: Sirica Fears Effect On Rights of Appeal If Tapes Are, Played
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) United States District Judge John J. Sirica said today that he feared that the appeal rights of the four men convicted in the Watergate coverup trial might be jeopardized if he permitted television and radio networks to broadcast the White House Watergate tapes.

title: World Skiers Stymied Again
description: JACKSON HOLE Wyo., March 6An overnight snowstorm that produced as much as 18 inches blanketed the Grand Teton range today and forced cancellation for the second straight day of training runs for the World Series of Skiing. The scores of international racers representing 15 nations, who arrived in this scenic moun tain country on Tuesday to start tuning up for the competition, have yet to get in a moment of preparation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: THE OLD WAY There's a lot of oldtune nostalgia spread around town as nightspot entertainment, some of it thick and coy. The approach and delivery of four young singers in a new cabaret show titled New American Vanities is neither.

title: Hunter and Paramount Buy TV Rights to a New Hailey
description: The rights to The Moneychangers, a novel by Arthur Hailey to be published this month, have been purchased by Ross Hunter Productions in associations with Paramount Television.

title: House Panel Approves Rise In Price Support for Crops
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)The House Agriculture Committee approved today an emergency increase in 1975 price supports for milk wheat, corn and other major crops, despite warnings that the bill faced a Presidential veto.

title: STATE FUD URGED FOR MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, March 6A revamping of medicalmalpractice insurance to reduce the soaring premium rates paid by physicians and hospitals was proposed today by the chairmen of two Assembly committees.

title: Man Slain by Sharpshooter
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6 (AP) A sheriff's sharpshooter shot and killed an Altadena man today who barricaded himself inside his home for nearly 13 hours with his three children, the authorities said.

title: Migrant Worker Denies Clubbing Assemblyman
description: WOODBURY, March 6Marcos Portalatin, 39  year  old straw boss of the migrant labor, crew at a Gloucester County vegetable farm, denied on the witness stand today that he clubbed Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, breaking his arm, last summer.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market rose yesterday in slow trading.

title: Exxon USA Cancels Rise In Heavy Fuel Oil Price
description: Exxon USA, the chief domestic affiliate of the Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday that it had rescinded, retroactive to March 1, its price increase on heavy fuel oil of 60 cents a barrel.

title: Israel Complains in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6Israel in a letter to the Security Council today denounced the attack in Tel Aviv as another abominable atrocity by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: City Agency Defies Medical Examiner on Transplant
description: The city's hospital system said yesterday that it would defy the Medical Examiner's office and remove the kidneys from a gunshot victim for transplant to waiting cases as soon as the victim's heart had stoppedinstead of leaving the entire body intact for a murder investigation.

title: Stop That Pendulum
description: The new educational conservatism gaining a foothold in many of the nation's school systems is increasingly being hailed as a return to higher scholastic standards. Unfortunately, however, conservatism in the classroom is not necessarily synonymous with better academic achievements and improved moral values.

title: Agriculture Agency Ends Curbs On Farm Commodities Exports
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced the removal today of export curbs on major farm commodities imposed last fall to help conserve dwindling United States supplies of grain and soybeans.

title: The Grapefruit of Wrath
description: LA BELLE, Fla.See, I've worked with these people, so many years, so I know what's in the field. I know what they do, n I know how they treat 'em, cause I've been there, if I hadn't, I wouldn't know. You don't know by sitting home what's going on. This Teamster man he's not for nothing. Cause I've been to these meetings when I was in the Farm Workers.

title: AGENCY REVISES BEEF STANDARDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Agriculture Department rejected the objections of consumers and announced today that it was putting into effect virtually unchanged its revised beef grading standards.

title: Archibald Basket Wins It for Kings
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 6( UPI)  Nate Archibald banked in a 30foot jump shot at the final buzzer tonight giving the Kansas CityOmaha Kings a 111110 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: About the Yankees . . .
description: Mel Stottlemyre pitched batting practice for the first time and reported no pain in his shoulder. I had thrown on the side for about 15 minutes, the righthander said, and I felt a little better than I expected to. I asked Whitey [Ford] if I could throw to a couple batters. . . . Jim [Catfish] Hunter's outfield style isn't quite as smooth as his pitching style. While shagging flies, he ran back after one with his back to the infield, then suddenly lost sight of the ball. He ducked his head and covered it with his glove as the ball landed harmlessly about 20 feet behind him. . . . Opening game lineup against Texas: White lb, Whitfield cf, Johnson If, Blomberg rf, Oliver 3b, Chambliss dh, Dempsey c, Mason ss, Alomar 2b. . . . Gene McElwain, the rookie from the Bronx, was surprised that he was selected to pitch in the first game. I was hoping to get one outing this spring, but I didn't expect it this soon, the lefthander said.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's broadcast news conference last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: N.C.A.A. Choices Irk Independents
description: The N.C.A.A. made some enemies yesterday among the nation's top independent basketball teams as it named the field for its national championship tournament.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: Antioch President Faces Ouster Vote
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 6  Antioch College's Board of Trustees meets this weekend for what has been termed a showdown vote over whether to dismiss the college's president, James P. Dixon Jr.

title: People and Business
description: A group of Japanese business executives, touring the United States in an attempt to learn more about its economy, stopped in Atlanta yesterday and proposed a closer relationship between businesses in Georgia and Japan for mutual benefit and profit.

title: Israelis Report Capturing Ship Used by Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, March 6The Israeli Navy has captured on the high seas the ship used last night by eight Palestinian guerrillas who seized a shorefront hotel and held its guests and employes hostage, an Israeli military spokesman announced tonight.

title: W. R. Grace's Profits and Revenues for 4th Quarter and 74 Rose to Records
2d Trial of 2 for Conspiring To Kill Strangler a Mistrial
description: DEDHAM, Mass., March 6 (AP)The second trial of two Whalpole state prison inmates charged with, conspiring to murder Albert H. DeSalvo has ended in a mistrial. Mr. DeSalvo confessed to being the socalled Boston strangler.

title: Cambodia's Reserves Are Called Unfit
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6Cambodian Government troops, thinly spread and hardpressed by the dryseason offensive of the insurgents, are being reinforced mostly by inexperienced soldiers, according to two colonels in the field.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., March 6 (UPI)Presidents of the Southeastern Conference, concerned about unruly crowds at basketball games, recommended today that severe penalties be drawn up to deal with any raucous demonstrations. In a statement adopted unanimously, the heads of the 10 S.E.C. schools asked their athletic directors to propose such penalties for consideration at a May meeting with conference basketball coaches.

title: At Long Last Love' Evokes Past Films
description: "At Long Last Love," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is Peter Bogdanovich's audacious attempt to make a stylish, nineteen-thirties Hollywood musical comedy with a superb score by Cole Porter but with performers who don't dance much and whose singing abilities might be best hidden in a very large choir.It's a movie compounded of nerve and a lot of cinematic intelligence, which is no substitute for fun. "At Long Last Love" is almost entirely devoid of the kind of wit, vigor and staggering self-assurance with which real musical comedy performers  people like Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Ethel Merman, Clifton Webb, Nanette Fabray, Charlotte Greenwood, Jack Buchanancould turn a leaky rowboat of a show into the Ile de France."At Long Last Love" never quite sinks, but then it never leaves the pier. It may be some measure of my own feelings toward it that, at the end, I was exhausted. I'd been wanting it to work and had been straining to enjoy the good things that came along.In the forefront of the good things are the Cole Porter songs, more than a dozen (most of them complete with their verses), some so beautifully integrated into the story that no seams show. I also liked the intentional vacuousness of Mr. Bogdanovich's screenplay, which is about what used to be called a madcap heiress who loves a playboy millionaire, who loves a wisecracking Broadway star who, in turn, loves a charming Italian rou. There's also a comic valet and a no-nonsense ladies maid.Then, too, there are some great art deco sets representing posh New York hotel suites, an elegant country club and a Long Island mansion with a foyer bigger than the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles. They are the frankly fake artifacts out of our Great Depression movies, settings made for Fred and Ginger and Eric Blore.But there are no Fred and Ginger to inhabit them. Instead there is, most prominently, Cybill Shepherd as the madcap heiress, and casting Cybil Shepherd in a musical comedy is like entering a horse in a cat show. She's beautiful and lithe and has great lines but she's the wrong species. She's too big. She'd look terrific on a tennis court or playing golf but she's too literal to seem anything except gross in these fairy-tale surroundings.When she attempts to sing, she also attempts to "act" the lyrics, and there is no sense of fantasy. The bluntness and naivet that made her so appealing and so right in "Daisy Miller" are simply abrasive here.The other performers have an easier time, especially the indestructibly funny Madeline Kahn, who plays the Broadway star, and Eileen Brennan, who plays the ladies maid, a role that manages to evoke performances by both Patsy Kelly and Helen Broderick. Duilio Del Prete, as the Italian rou, is a macho Erik Rhodes who signs passably, and John Hillerman is nicely stuffy as the valet who puts great store on social form.The problem that Mr. Bogdanovich set himself in "At Long Last Love"and which he never solvesis how to top these evocations of the past for our current pleasure. Because the past is always right, it may be that "At Long Last Love" would have seemed as vapid as it does even if it were an immensely clever film, which it isn't.The film's most pleasant surprise is Burt Reynolds as the playboy millionaire, a performance that doesn't invite comparisons with any except earlier ones by Mr. Reynolds. He sings reasonably well. He dances. He plays the comedy lightly and earnestly, with low-key good humor of the kind that everyone else (except Miss Kahn) lacks.Best of all is the Cole Porter score and it's to the director's credit that we can at least understand all the lyrics. But this joy is not unalloyed: You keep remembering how they sound when done by Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald or Ethel Merman.

title: Traffic Ticket Quotas For State Police Ended
description: TRENTON, March 6 (AP) Attorney General William F. Hyland has ended a controversial practice that allegedly based promotions for state troopers on the number of traffic tickets they issued.

title: The Question in Capital: Recession or Depression?
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Depression. It is a word to send shivers down the spine of anyone over 50 years old. It evokes dark images of bread lines and bankruptcies, dust bowls and suicides. It is also a word being used by responsible public figuresgenerally liberals  for the first time since the nineteen thirties to describe the state of the nation's economy.

title: FORD BACKS SIMON ON CHALLENGING HOUSE ON TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Ford said tonight that the tax cut bill passed by the House of Representatives, giving substantial tax relief to low and middleincome taxpayers, was weighted too heavily in favor of those people and not enough in favor of those who might spend the money more readily. [Question 12, Page 16].

title: Policeman Dies From Shot
description: SHREWSBURY, Mass., March 6 (AP)A Shrewsbury policeman was wounded fatally last night when he apparently stopped a man for questioning in a motel parking lot here. The victim, James Lonchiadis, 28 years old, died early this morning at Memorial Hospital in Worcester from a bullet ?? in the chest.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS VOTE SOFTENED REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Republican National Committee softened even further today an already cautious reform program, then approved it with almost no dissent.

title: City Is Negotiating For Loan to Meet March 14 Payroll
description: The city unsuccessfully negotiated for 10 hours yesterday with a banking syndicate for the sale of $537million in bondanticipation notes to meet a payroll and two loans due March 14. The talks are to resume to day at 8:30 A.M.

title: Fund Diversion Laid to 4 Phillips Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)Four officers and former officers of the Phillips Petroleum Company diverted $2.8million to illegal contributions to political campaigns and to Swiss bank accounts, the Securities and Exchange Commission alleged today.

title: Hesburgh Urges Extension Of the Voting Rights Act
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The obliteration of black rights that followed reconstruction a century ago could recur unless Congress extends the Voting Rights Act, a former chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today.

title: Laughing Gas Kills Youth
description: KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., March 6 (AP)The son of a dentist died Tuesday night from the inhalation of nitrous oxide, more commonly known as laughing gas, the Montgomery County coroner, John Hoffa, ruled today. The victim, Steven Berman, 16 years old, was found by his parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harry Berman, lying on the floor of Dr. Berman's office, which is attached to their home.

title: In Albany, PowerHungry or Just Hungry?
description: ALBANY, March 6  The new Democratic leadership of the Assembly has ordered an end to the great litter of peanut shells, discarded jujube bags, hamburger scraps and occasional gnawed Tbones that have been as basic a part of the chamber's debating tradition as Robert's Rules of Order.

title: Attica Defense Tries to Discredit a Key Witness
description: BUFFALO, March 6Defense lawyers at the Attica murder trial here brought out today some discrepancies between what a correction officer told the court yesterday and what he told state investigators two days afer the 1971 prison rebellion was put down.

title: Oil Shipment Suspended
description: QUITO, Ecuador, March 6 (Reuters)Ecuador is suspending crude oil shipments, which average 149,500 barrels daily, for three to four weeks following landslide damage to the TransEcuador pipeline early this week, Ecuadorean Natural Resources Ministry sources said today.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Valerie Louthan, the redhaired Irish designer who heads her own knitting mill in Scotland, is busily bringing luxurious old cashmere sweaters into the modern era. Her latest wrinkle: styling them as softly as blouses.

title: 50 in Bangladesh Ferry Die
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 6 (Reuters)At least 50 people were drowned or killed by sharks when a ferry boat capsized near Saridwip Island, off Bangladesh, officials said today. The ferry was carrying 190 passengers Monday when it overturned after striking rocks, the official added.

title: LIBRARY TO MOVE CENTRAL OFFICE
description: The New York Public Library plans to occupy the entire sixstory building it owns across Fifth Avenue from the Main Library after the Arnold Constable department store moves out next month.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Several letters of reprimand, one abusive, the others patient, but all pointing out that I was not an authority on Thai gastronomy, followed a report on Bangkok Cuisine, a Thai restaurant, which appeared in this column last Jan. 3. Among other things, I didn't know that lemon grass is an herb used in flavoring. The letter writers were unanimous in extolling the authenticity of the cooking at this restaurant, to which I gave a favorable comment on the basis of I don't know much about Thai cuisine but I know what I like. I liked it.

title: Skate Lead Retained By Volkov
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 6 (AP)Sergi Volkov of the Soviet Union held the lead going into the final men's event, the freeskating, hoping to win another gold medal for his country in the world figureskating championships.

title: Rare Recordings Donated
N. C. State Is Victor, 9185; N. Carolina, Clemson Gain
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 6 (AP)  David Thompson's 38 points, including four free throws in the last 15 seconds, sealed a 9185 victory for North Carolina State over Vixginia tonight to climax an exciting first round of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

title: Books of The Times
description: With pleasant wars in short supply in recent years, novelists and reporters have been taking a second or third look at the battles and leaders of World War II. Vietnam gave war a dirty name, and Korea is not remembered nostalgically. The present pattern was set by the late Cornelius Ryan with his story of DDayinterviews with hundreds of eyewitnesses on both sides and continued by him in the story of the abortive airborne invasion of the Netherlands, A Bridge Too Far. In between came the journalistic account of the neardestruction of the City of Light, Is Paris Burning? Dan Kurzman now attempts a similar detailed story in The Race for Rome, which was captured a few days before the Normandy invasion.

title: Private Briefings Given by Kissinger Made Public by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The State Department, responding to a request under the Freedom of Information Act, formally made public today transcripts of background briefings given to reporters by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: OUTLAYS ARE CUT BY U.S. INDUSTRY
description: The nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers slashed capital appropriations by 24 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974, The Conference Board reported yesterday. The appropriations, or authorizations for capital improvements, amounted to $12.45billion in the quarter, seasonally adjusted, down from a record of $16.4billion in the third quarter.

title: 3Month Money Supply Steady
description: The nation's money supply, an increasingly debated topic on Capitol Hill, showed a modest gain in the week ended Feb. 26 but no change in the latest three months.

title: Malpractice Suit Dismissed As Court Allows Fallibility
description: MADISON, Wis., March 6 (UPI)Doctors are a class of fallible men and can make mistakes without being negligent, the Wisconsin Supreme Court said today in ordering dismissal of a malpractice suit against three Green Bay area doctors.

title: Japanese Company Import Iran Liquified Natural Gas
description: TOKYO, March 6 (Reuters)A consortium of 16 Jananese concerns including the Tohoku Electric Power Company and NisshoIwai Company, Ltd., will shortly organize a joint company to import liquefied natural gas from Iran on a longterm basis, a consortium spokesman announced today.

title: Inmates Accused in Slaying
description: RAWLINS, Wyo., March 6 (AP)  Charges of firstdegree murder were filed late last night against two inmates at the state penitentiary in the beating and stabbing death of a prison guard. The charges were filed against Jose Flores, 27 years old, and Charels Lopez, 28. The guard, Leville Ventling, 43, was dead on ar??val at a hospital last night

title: Art Students League Gathers the Fruits of Its Gifted to Mark Full Century
description: Current legend has it that a young conceptual artist, one of the new breed who majored in video at a newfangled art school, paid a visit to the Art Students League and was puzzled by an unrecognizable aroma in the lobby. Gee, what's that great smell? he asked. Oil paint and turpentine, he was told.

title: Africa Envoys Protest The Davis Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)  Ambassadors and other diplomatic representatives of 33 African nations went to the State Department today to protest the nominaion of Nathaniel Davis as Under Secretary of State for African Affairs.

title: 4 AT PRISON AGENCY ACCUSED OF BRIBERY
description: Two inmates and two officers of a prison halfway house operated here by the Federal Bureau of Prisons were arrested yesterday on bribery charges allegedly involving members of organized crime.

title: Bill in Albany Would Scrutinize Motives Of Some Who Seek Help From Legislators
description: Legislation is being drafted in Albany, with strong bipartisan support, that would set up a neutral body to investigate the credentials and motives of any person who asks a lawmaker to intervene in a matter that could involve profit or any other conflict of interest.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: IRISH LEAGUE CUP Quarterfinal Replay

title: SEARS SALES DIP 0.1% IN 5 WEEKS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest merchandising concern said yesterday that sales for the fiveweek period to March 1 fell to $1.08billion, or 0.1 per cent below the level in the corresponding period of 1974.

title: House Unit Passes $12Billion Subsidy For HomeBuyers
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) A $12billion emergency subsidy designed to lower mortgage interest rates and revive the depressed housing market was approved today by the House Subcommittee on Housing. The vote was 124, divided strictly along party lines, with the Democrats in the majority.

title: 1962 REPORT CITED ON NURSING HOMES
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was questioned yesterday about a hitherto undisclosed 1962 report on the nursinghome industry, that found no improvement in the overall operation of the industry after the 1960 Kaplan report.

title: 18 COUNTRIES SEEK AGREEMENT ON OIL
description: PARIS, March 6  Eighteen major oil consumer nations met here today to consider two American proposals for insuring development of alternative energy supplies.

title: U.S. URGED TO AID PRIVATE COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education urged today that the Federal Government embark on a multibilliondollar program of subsidizing the tuition of students in private colleges and universities.

title: 4 Utility Heads and 2 on P. U. C. Oppose NaturalGas Excise Tax
description: NEWARK, March 6  Two members of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners and the chief executives of New Jersey's four utility companies said today they would urge the state's Congressional delegation to oppose President Ford's plan for an excise tax on natural gas.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS CONGRESS IT MUST AID CAMBODIA NOW
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Ford, warning that time is running out, appealed to Congress tonight to provide additional military assistance to Cambodia. He said the aid was necessary to assure the survival of the Cambodian Government and to permit a negotiated settlement of the war.

title: Miss Evert Advances at Boston Net
description: BOSTON March 6 (UPI)Chris Evert and Evonne Goolagong won opening matches in the Virginia Slims of Boston tennis tournament, tonight and will be paired in tomorrow's semifinals.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1975

title: Concert
description: The Schubert MiniFestival at Lincoln Center moved to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, presumably to feature non orchestral works performed by the Chamber Music Society, which is associated with the New York Philharmonic in presenting the Festival.

title: Notes on People
description: Otto Kerner, former Governor of Illinois and Federal judge, was freed yesterday after he had served seven months of a threeyear sentence for bribery and tax offenses.

title: 21 of 23 Reactors Pass an Inspection Of Cooling Systems
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)All but two of the nation's 23 nuclear power reactors have passed a Governmentordered test for cracks in their cooling pipes and most already are back in operation, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: 7 Republicans Sue on Loss of State Jobs
description: ALBANY, March 6 Seven Republicans have taken a patronage dispute to State Supreme Court here, suing the Carey administration for abolishing their jobs with the Workmen's Compensation Board, but financing the same jobs a few days later in proposing the initial Carey state budget.

title: 1962 REPORT CITED ON NURSING HOMES
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was questioned yesterday about a hitherto undisclosed 1962 report on the nursinghome industry, that found no improvement in the overall operation of the industry after the 1960 Kaplan report.

title: About Real Estate
description: At first, said Philip Pilevsky over a cup of coffee at a diner in Whitestone, Queens, the banks were reluctant to lend to him and his partner. That has changed. In the last five years they have built about 200 small stores in the city at an estimated construction cost of $25million.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS EXAIDE TO AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, March 6A Federal grand jury here today indicted J. Walter Jones Jr., a former close personal and political associate of Spiro T. Agnew, along with the Singer Company of New York and three other persons, in connection with an alleged illegal $10,000 contribution by Singer to the NixonAgnew reelection campaign in 1972.

title: Rapp Admits Transit Authority Misconduct Charges
description: Robert H. Rapp, who had worked his way up from patrolman in the Transit Authority to chief of its police force, conceded yesterday that he had encouraged his men to falsify arrest statistics.

title: Witness Tells of Injections
description: A former stablehand for John L. Cotter testified yesterday that he had seen the trainer use needles and syringes to inject horses on three or four occasions in the Belmont Park barn area.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, March 7

title: FREDERICK H. MOLD
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., March 6 (AP)Frederick H. Mold, director of the Fairbanks Museum of Natural History since 1948, died today at a hospital in White River Junction. He was 53 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: A majority of United States corporations expect their profits to climb in 1975 despite the recession, economists at McGrawHill Publications said yesterday.

title: Rostropovich Conducts a Capital Concert
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Lots of nonconductors are getting into conducting these days, from David Oistrakh to Yehudi Menuhin to Daniel Barenboim to Dietrich FischerDieskau to Placido Domingo to Sherrill Milnes. Some of them have stuckMr. Barenboim in particular. But there remains a certain residue of cynicism about such career expansions, with a strong whiff of selfindulgent dilettantism hanging in the air.

title: CORRECTION
Reforming the Budget...
description: As New York City stumbles from crisis to deeper crisis in frantic efforts to avert collapse of the world's largest municipal budget, it is appallingthough scarcely startlingto be informed that: No one, including the agency Commissioner, and least of all the interested public, can work through the maze of lines [in the city's antiquated lineitem budget control system] to find out what the city is really doing and spending.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 3 From the WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of footstuff and industrial materials fell to 196 from 199 last week.

title: Gurney Jurors Questioned
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 6 (AP) Opening arguments are not expected to begin until next week in the briberyconspiracy trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, as jury selection dragged through its ninth day today.

title: JOHN E. M'KAY
description: John Edwards McKay, who was product director of the baby products division of Johnson & Johnson, surgical goods manufacturer, when he retired in 1965, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 57 years old.

title: FORD INTRODUCES LOWERPRICED CAR
description: DETROIT, March 6  The Ford Motor Company today introduced a new model called the Custom 500 and said its its sticker price of $4,288 will make it the lowestpriced standardsized car in the country.

title: 6 Accused of Payroll Padding in Newark
description: NEWARK, March 6Six persons were indicted here today by an Essex County grand jury on charges of defrauding the Newark school system of $30,000 in a teacher payrollpadding scheme.

title: Israelis Report Capturing Ship Used by Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, March 6The Israeli Navy has captured on the high seas the ship used last night by eight Palestinian guerrillas who seized a shorefront hotel and held its guests and employes hostage, an Israeli military spokesman announced tonight.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT OS OF CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6The United States Embassy believes that the best that can be hoped for here is little more than a negotiated surrender in which the only subjects open for discussion would be details, humaneness and orderliness of the Communistled insurgents' takeover:

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1975

title: Private Briefings Given by Kissinger Made Public by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The State Department, responding to a request under the Freedom of Information Act, formally made public today transcripts of background briefings given to reporters by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: GEORGE R. MARTIN, EXCY ANAMID AIDE
description: George R. Martin, who retired in 1962 as chairman of the executive committee of the American Cyanamid Company, died Sunday at his home here. He was 77 years old and lived also in New Milford, Conn.

title: Mideast Provocation
description: Two faces of today's ArabIsraeli confrontation present themselves in stark contrast. One is the dossier of diplomatic formulas now being carried to the Mideast in Secretary of State Kissinger's briefcae, formulas designed to help Israel and Egypt pull themselves away from the threats of war that have hung between them for two decades and more.

title: Dan Wagoner's Dances Original and Rewarding
description: Dan Wagoner is a choreographer who is attracting increasing attention, and his company, Dan Wagoner and Dancers, got off to a good start Wednesday night at Pace University's Schimmel Center. The group will perform there again tonight and tomorrow night.

title: Leon Goldman, 71, Surgeon Was an Early User of Laser
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP)  Dr. Leon Goldman, a prominent surgeon and medical educator, died here Tuesday. He was 71 years old.

title: A Black Opposes Black Mayor In Gary, Ind., Race as Antiwhite
description: GARY, Ind.Racial politics is common enough in America these days, but in the Democratic mayoral primary here there is a new twist. The two main candidates are black, and they are arguing about treatment of the city's white minority.

title: The Pitfalls of Presidential Politics
description: Running for President is a hard and chancy business in this huge country, full of varied interests and attitudes that one man can rarely satisfy. Gerald Ford and Henry Jackson are finding that out and Nelson Rockefeller, who got the point in 1960, 1964 and 1968, is being taught it all over again just in case he'd forgotten.

title: Court Urged to Reprimand Former S.E.C. Chairman
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 6G. Bradford Cook, a former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, should be reprimanded but not disbarred, a special hearing officer, John Kuns, recommended to the Nebraska Supreme court today.

title: Few in Italy Note The 500th Birthday Of Michelangelo
description: ROME, March 6The 500th anniversary of the birth of Michelangelo passed with little, notice in much of Italy today except in the little hill town of Caprese, where the Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect and poet was born.

title: McDonnell Douglas Expected to Lay Off 1,000 at Coast Plant
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 8 (UPI)The layoff of 1,000 workers is expected tomorrow at the Douglas Aircraft division assembly plant of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation here, union sources said today.

title: Taizo Ishizaka Is Dead at 88; Industrialist Headed Expo '70
description: TOKYO, March 6 (UPI) Taizo Ishizaka, Japanese industrialist who was chairman of Expo '70 in Osaka, died yesterday of cerebral thrombosis. He was 88 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 7, 1975

title: Bankruptcy Filings Climbed By 33% in Last 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)Bankruptcy filings in the last six months rose 33 per cent from the yearearlier level, Rowland F. Kirks, director of the United States Courts, said today.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Electric Company has received a $37.7million Army contract for endurance testing of turbine engines.

title: Bilingual Canada Debate Is Focused on Moncton
description: MONCTON, New Brunswick Tucked away in a private office a couple of blocks from Moncton City Hall is a heavy bronze plaque, prepared for a dedication ceremony three years ago.

title: Article 5  No Title
F.A.A. REVISES RULE ON PLANE LANDINGS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)The Federal Aviation Administration formally re vised the nation's flight regulations today in an effort to prevent premature descents such as the one that occurred when a Trans World Airlines jetliner crashed in Virginia last Dec. 1, killing 92persons.

title: 21 of 23 Reactors Pass an Inspection Of Cooling Systems
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)All but two of the nation's 23 nuclear power reactors have passed a Governmentordered test for cracks in their cooling pipes and most already are back in operation, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: Index of Wholesale Prices Declines 3d Month in Row
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 The Government's wholesale price index declined for the third consecutive month in February, providing further evidence of the abating of inflation at a time of deepening recession, the Labor Department reported today.

title: . . . Power to the Council
description: The Mayor's now dominant role in the budgetary process would be further curtailed in the proposed charter revision by removing him from participation in Board of Estimate action on the budget. That would eliminate his power to veto any reduction or deletion in the budget made by the Council and Board of Estimate. Soie authority to override a mayoral veto would be vested in the Council, a power it now shares with the Estimate Board.

title: Curbs on Arab Investors Who Use Boycotts Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Leaders of Jewish groups urged Congress today to bar any substantial investment in the United States from Arab countries until they end boycotts of Jews and companies that do business with Israel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mayor Peter M. Mocco of North Bergen, who was acquitted Wednesday of conspiracy and conflict of interest, was indicted by a Hudson County grand jury yesterday on charges of aiding and abetting the unlawful obtaining money, and neglect of duty. The indictments, handed up Jersey City in the final day of the jury's term, specifically charge Mr. Mocco, two town hall employes and the widow of a town employe with conspiring to allow the widow collect $4,484.64 in salary after her husband had died.

title: Life Expectancy Up in India
Market Place
description: The New York Stock Exchange took the unusual step yesterday of suspending shares of a listed company on the ground that the company no longer met minimum exchange standards as to market value and earnings.

title: Mississippi River Oil Spill
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., March 6 (AP)Thousands of barrels of crude oil continued to spill into the Mississippi River today hours after two of four barges slammed into a bridge pier here, killing one man and injuring three others, the Coast Guard said. Officials said the oil spill had been spotted as far as 40 miles downstream from Vicksburg and there were accumulations along the shoreline. The authorities identified the dead crewman as Bill Williams, 51 years old, of Greenville.

title: Art Students League Gathers the Fruits of Its Gifted to Mark Full Century
description: Current legend has it that a young conceptual artist, one of the new breed who majored in video at a newfangled art school, paid a visit to the Art Students League and was puzzled by an unrecognizable aroma in the lobby. Gee, what's that great smell? he asked. Oil paint and turpentine, he was told.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS CONGRESS IT MUST AID CAMBODIA NOW
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Ford, warning that time is running out, appealed to Congress tonight to provide additional military assistance to Cambodia. He said the aid was necessary to assure the survival of the Cambodian Government and to permit a negotiated settlement of the war.

title: OSCAR PERLMUTTER
description: Prof. Oscar W. Perlmutter, academic vice president and dean of faculty at St. John's University, Collegeville, Minn., died Wednesday in a Rochester, Minn., hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in St. Joseph, Minn.

title: Turnaround Is Found in Rising Prices
description: For longer than he likes to remember, Robert G. Rhett, a purchasing executive at the Kennecott Copper Corporation, has been paying everincreasing prices for the wide range of materials and manufactured products he buys for his company.

title: Big Board Will Sell 40% of Its Shares In Depository Trust
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would sell in May almost 40 per cent of the stock of the Depository Trust Company, an exchange subsidiary.

title: Bankers See No Early Solution To U.D.C. Financial Problems
description: Senior banking officials disclosed privately here yesterday that they saw little hope for a quick solution to help resolve the massive financial difficulties of the Urban Development Corporation.

title: MOTION FOR A DELAY IN AVIS CASE DENIED
description: Federal Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld yesterday denied a motion by the Justice Department to delay a financing and divestiture plan involving Avis, Inc., which had been submitted by the company's courtappointed trustee, Richard Joyce Smith.

title: John Dunlop Is Confirmed As New Labor Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) The Senate today confirmed the nomination of John T. Dunlop as Labor Secretary, succeeding Peter J. Brennan. Mr. Dunlop's nomination was approved by voice vote and without dissent or debate. The 60yearold former Harvard University dean was brought into the Administration as Director of the Cost of Living Council in 1973.

title: People in Sports
description: As a companion piece to the heavyweight title fight between Muhammad Ali and Chuck Wepner, Video Techniques, Inc., has got together with Madison Square Garden and scheduled a bout between Jerry Quarry and Ken Norton for the night of March 24 in the Garden's main arena.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: 3d Phone Company Blaze In 8 Days Held Suspicious
description: The third fire in eight days at a major New York Telephone Company installation in the city yesterday was declared suspicious by the Fire Department.

title: OIL STATES OFFER TO DISCUSS PRICES
description: ALGIERS, March 6The oilexporting countries offered today to negotiate with industrial nations on the stabilization of oil prices. But they stressed that the agenda of a conference could not be limited to discussion of prices.

title: St. Peter's and Seton Hall Fall in Playoffs
description: St. John's and Rutgers will meet tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden in a battle for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Ford Dubious on Price Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 President Ford said tonight that he had many reservations about the call made at the meeting of leaders of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for linking oil prices to the prices of the manufactured goods they import.

title: China Said to Negotiate Cotton Deal Cancellation
Article 2  No Title
PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Psychotherapists who work with children frequently get the sinking feeling that they're too latethey should have been talking to the parents years earlier.

title: People in Sports
description: Ben Crenshaw, who is followed around the pro golf tour by hordes of admiring young women known as Ben's Wrens and Ben's Bunnies, had had news for his fans yesterday. The 23yearold bachelor announced at Orlando, Fla., where he is playing in the Florida Citrus open, that he has become engaged.

title: Ft. Lee Builders' Trial to Begin Monday
description: TRENTON. March 7Jury selection will begin Monday in Federal Court here for the trial on bribery charges of seven individuals and two corporations involved in an abortive attempt to develop a multimilliondollar highrise commercial project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

title: In Memorian
description: GITTERAbraham, March 8th, 1959 in loving everlasting memory of dear husband and father.

title: Women Are Not to '75 as Women Were to '30
description: As the recession deepens, we are beginning to read and hear around us the shibboleths and unexamined truths that destroyed the momentum of the first wave of 20thcentury feminism.

title: Most Rates to Rise On Telephone Calls For Long Distances
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it would increase telephone rates for about twothirds of outofstate longdistance calls and reduce the rates for onethird, effective Sunday.

title: Life of Phnom Penh Slowly Grinds Down
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 7Primary schools are open only every other day now, and then only for a few hours. In Government offices, piles of paper mount steadily higher on the desks as the pace of work declines.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, March 7, 1975

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 8, 1975

title: Calzadillas Still Haunted by Kidnapping
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., March 7One year after their 9yearold son, John, was kidnapped and then released unharmed for a $50,000 ransom, Michael and Juanita Calzadilla say they are still haunted by the experience.

title: Rockefeller Unit Said to Check Report Of C.I.A. Link to Kennedy Assassination
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Rockefeller commission on the Central Intelligence Agency, is looking into allegations that the C.I.A. was somehow involved in the assassination of President Kennedy in 1963, according to informed sources close to its investigation.

title: Nordiques Beat Toros
description: TORONTO, March 7 (UPI)  Rene Leclerc scored a pair of goals and J. C. Tremblay and Rejean Houle added one each to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 41 victory over the Toronto Toros tonight. The victory snapped a threegame Quebec losing streak and gave the Nordiques a 10point margin in the World Hockey Association's Canadian Division.

title: INVENTOR'S DEATH IS LAID TO DARVON
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 7Results of an autopsy performed on the body of Berel Weinstein, a 28yearold inventor and industrialist who died Feb. 21 in his Fort Lee apartment, attributed the cause of death to a fatal dose of Darvon, a prescription painkiller, Bergen County officials said today.

title: MARTIN RAPHAEL, A LABOR LAWYER
description: Martin Raphael, a lawyer specializing in labor and civilrights cases, died Wednesday in Boulevard Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. He was 70 years old arid lived at 3958 44th Street, Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ETHEL S. BEER
description: Ethel S. Beer, founder of the former Brightside Day Nursery of the Lower East Side, died yesterday at her home, 41 Fifth Avenue. Her age was 77.

title: Blades Win in Overtime
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 7 (AP)Reggie Thomas of Baltimore, scored a tiebreaking goal at 2:48 of suddendeath overtime tonight to give the Blades a 54 World Hockey Association victory over the Indianpolis Racers.

title: Nudity Ban Aimed at Cape Cod Shore
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The National Park Service, professing concern about preserving a fragile world of dune and wave, beach plum and seashell, has come up with a novel solution: It is proposing to ban nudity within the boundaries of the Cape Cod National Seashore.

title: Court Upholds Ban On Entry of Women Into Jaycee Groups
description: A Federal appeals court ruled here yesterday that the United States Jaycees could maintain a policy of barring women from membership because it was a private organization.

title: A Long, Long Trail A winding
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThe air of relative confidence pervading Washington and Cairo as Secretary Kissinger's latest round of Middle East negotiations starts was obviously based on more than wishful thinking. But whether this modest hope has been irrevocably shattered by the latest guerrilla raid on Israel remains to be seen. One might assess the underlying situation accordingly:

title: Soviet Said to Expand Air and Naval Activities in Persian Gulf Area
description: The Soviet Union is steadily expanding its naval and air activity and base and port facilities in the strategically important Persian GulfIndian Ocean area according to intelligence sources in Washington and London.

title: Bryant, Wallace Honored Here
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant, the highly successful coach of the University of Alabama, and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama were honored guests last night at the 41st awards dinner of the Touchdown Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt. Bryant was presented the club's 1975 award for his contribution to football. Governor Wallace was given a lifetime gold membership pass to the club. Phil Iselin, president of the New York Jets, received an award from the Pop Warner Little Scholars football association, and Russell Sta??l, a Curtis High School senior, won the club's scholarship award. Stahl, a National Merit Student as well as an athlete, hopes to study law. He has been accepted by two Ivy League schoolsCornell and Penn.

title: ARTHUR SACHS, 95, EXBROKER, DEAD
description: Arthur Sachs, a retired American investment banker, art collector and philanthropist, died Thursday in Cannes, France, where he lived. His age was 95.

title: Chrysler U.K. Gets Order For Avengers From Iran
description: LONDON, March 7 (UPI)Chrysler United Kingdom, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation of Detroit, said today it had won a further order from Iran for 10,000 Avenger automobiles in knockeddown form in the face of stiff competition.

title: Where to Go From Art of 1950's
description: Grace Hartigan's paintings in the nineteenfifties came on as big strong and bouncy. Dense but not raucous in color, they were outstanding for the equilibrium that reigned between scale and idea, gesture and intention. They were the work of a real painter, of someone who felt in terms of the loaded brush and not of the loop or the line. The tumult in the work came from necessity and not from any received idea of what abstract expressionism should be.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 8, 1975

title: Better Job Insurance
description: Governor Carey's proposed liberalization of unemployment insurance would restore New York State to its proper place in the front rank of enlightened social concern for those jobless through no fault of their own.

title: Ford Urges O.O.P. Enroll All Who Care About U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Ford appealed tonight for a broadened Republican party embracing all who care about this great country, implicitly rejecting conservative demands for greater ideological purity.

title: EXXON WILL IDLE UP TO 8 TANKERS
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., March 7The Exxon Corporation is taking out of service up to eight of its 28,000 to 38,000ton oil tankers and laying them up here for six to 12 months, an Exxon spokesman said Thursday.

title: With Subsidized Adoption, the Opportunity for a Permanent Home
description: ALBANY At 3 months of age, suffering from malnutrition, Floyd was taken from his home and made a ward of the county. For the next 10 years, he lived in an institution lonely, destructive, handicapped by an I.Q. of 57.

title: Art:Age of Revolution in Detroit
description: DETROIT  The period that extends from the coronation of Louis XVI as King of France in 1774 to the July Revolution of 1830 was one of the most momentous in the history of the modem world, not only for France but also for the entire course of Western civilization. It was the period of revolution and counterrevolution, of Napoleonic glory and bourgeois ascendancy. It was the period in which the institutions and the culture of bourgeois democracy were given their first definitive form.

title: People and Business
description: Frustrated and disappointed by the failure of Congress to end Federal regulation of natural gas prices, Rush Moody Jr., a 44yearold Democrat and lawyer, is leaving the Federal Power Commission after three years and four months.

title: Ballet: Jeu de Cartes
description: John Cranko's Jeu de Cartes, now just about 10 years old, has proved not only among the most popular of Cranko's ballets, but also the most durable choreographic version of Stravinsky's score. Thursday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the Joffrey Ballet gave the first New York performance, and it seems, from its firstnight reception, that it could well be a popular hit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Lose, but White Wins a Chance at First
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 7I'm still alive, Roy White said with relief and a big grin today after playing first base in a game for the first time since his Little League days. White, however, may be more than alivehe may well be the Yankees' first baseman this year.

title: CONTINENTAL OIL REVERSES STAND
description: LONDON, March 7The Continental Oil Company, one of the American oil companies operating in the North Sea, withdrew tonight the cautious welcome it gave to the British Government's proposal for a 45 per cent tax on oil revenues from the North Sea.

title: Brooklyn Grocer Shot
description: A 36yearold Brooklyn grocer, Emile Menard, was shot and critically wounded yesterday during a holdup attempt inhis store at 377 Kingston Avenue. Four youths fled emptyhanded.

title: Francine Larrimore, Actress On Broadway Stage, 77, Dies
description: Francine Larrimore, a noted actress of the first half of the century, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home, 135 East 54th Street. She was 77 years old.

title: Israelis Find 5 More Bodies in ArabRaided Hotel
description: TEL AVIV, March 7 (Reuters) The bodies of five more people were discovered today in the rubble of the Tel Aviv hotel that was attacked Wednesday night by Arab guerrillas, the police reported.

title: 5 Democrats in Senate to Seek Oil Depletion and Tax Cut Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Five Democratic Senators announced today that they would attempt to force a Senate vote on including repeal of the controversial oil depletion allowance in the antirecession taxcut bill.

title: Illinois Bell Seeks Rise
description: CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI)The Illinois Bell Telephone Company today proposed to raise local coinbox telephone calls from 10 to 20 cents as part of its plan to provide a $178million, or 14 per cent, annual rate increase.

title: Police Sales Bring Buyer Convictions With the Bargains
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 7 (AP)A judge here has ruled that a number of people convicted after the police enticed them into buying purportedly stolen merchandise must he allowed to keep the merchandise if they pay the wholesale price.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HORIZONS New Yorkers have many artisttic outlets this weekend, from shells to stainedglass windows to Japanese woodblock printing. The public is invited tomorrow at 2 P.M. to the monthly meeting of the New York Shell Club, a 26yearold group with 325 members from a wide variety of professions, dedicated to the collection and study of shells as a hobby. The speaker is S. Peter Dince, a visitor from England and author of The Collector's Encyclopedia of Shells (priced in this country at $19.95). The place: Room 319, through the main entrance to the elevator, in the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street.

title: OPEC to Restudy Prices if Dollar Sags
description: ALGIERS, March 7The oilexporting countries have reportedly agreed that further deterioration of the United States dollar in foreign exchange markets would prompt an emergency meeting of their oil ministers to adjust oil prices upward or set new methods of payment.

title: Books of The Times
description: Wars, disease, treaties pocked by duplicity and decimation of the buffalo by whites drove the Sioux to reservations, shriveled their population and disemboweled their corporate body, wrote Federal Judge Warren K. Urbom the other day in a capsule of Sioux history, in which he added:

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW SHARP DROP
description: Wheat futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade dropped sharply yesterday following reports that the European Economic Community had granted export licenses for 128,500 tons of soft red wheat.

title: THURSDAY NIGHT
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Islanders, St. Laurent (10) (Unassisted) 8.05. 2, Los Angeles, Murdoch (11) (St. Marseille) 16:13. PenaltiesHart (4:29); Kannegiesser (5:54); Lewis (8:20); Hart (9:48); Carr (9:48); Hutchinson (12:03).

title: Discount Rate Cut To 61% From 6 To Spur Economy
description: The Federal Reserve Bank signaled a further easing in credit conditions yesterday by reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to commercial banks.

title: Interstate Highway Backed for West Side
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame announced agreement yesterday on building a sixlane Interstate System highway from the Battery to 72d Street to replace the old West Side Highway.

title: Souzay Celebrates Centenary of Ravel In a Song Program
description: The centenary of Ravel's birth is being wellobserved here by pianists, the New York City Ballet, Queens College, the Performers Committee for 20thCentury Music and other groups, but Gerard Souzay's recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night was a major celebration by a singer. The French baritone's program was representative of the composer's vocal music, ranging from one of the earliest songs, Sainte (1896), to his final work, Don Quichotte  Dulcine (1932).

title: Miss Colburn First In Title Skiing
description: KILLINGTON, Vt., March 7 (UPI)Karen Colburn of Bangor, Me., and Robbie Huntoon of Brandon, Vt., won their mogul competitions today in the opening events of the United States national amateur freestyle championships.

title: Johnson to Lay Off 1,680 in New Jersey: Others to Cut Back
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7 (UPI)Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical conglomerate, has announced that it will lay off 1,680 workers at its North Brunswick and Bridgewater, N.J., facilities for two weeks.

title: Texaco Delay Opposed in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 7Westchester County political leaders joined today in bipartisan opposition to a ruling by Ogden R. Reid, the State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, delaying the start of construction of Texaco's new office complex in Purchase.

title: Byrne Signs Bill Allowing Life Terms for Drug Sellers
description: TRENTON, March 7 (AP)Governor Byrne signed legislation today to permit judges to impose life terms on narcotics dealers.

title: Saigon Loses Highlands Road As Communists Blow Bridges
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7  By blowing up bridges and seizing one base camp in the last four days. North Vietnamese troops have succeeded in cutting the vital road that leads from Pleiku, the principal Governmentheld town in the Central Highlands, to the coast.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday for the second straight day as volume continued moderately higher.

title: Met Injuries, Deals In First Test Today
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7One month from the start of the regular season, baseball opened its exhibition program in Florida today with five games. But for the New York Mets and most of the other teams training in the sun, it was still the eve of battle, the final day of preparation before heading into 28 practice games and 162 that count.

title: SISTER MARY ANGELICA
description: Sister Mary Angelica Bresnahan, a former administrator and faculty member of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, the Bronx, died Thursday at the Convent of Mary the Queen, Yonkers. Her age was 89.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 8, 1975

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Yunich Says He Will Appear Before 2 Assembly Panels
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that he would appear as a witness here next Friday before two Assembly committees that are conducting hearings on the state's five transportation authorities.

title: Defense Is Granted Delay In Migrant Assault Trial
description: WOODBURY, March 7Over vigorous defense objections, Judge R. Edward Klaisz Jr. of Gloucester County Court delayed the assault trial of a migrantcrew chief today to permit the state to bring two rebuttal witnesses here from Puerto Rico.

title: Trial of Jersey Builders to Open Monday
description: TRENTON, March 7Jury selection will begin Monday in Federal Court here for the trial on bribery charges of seven individuals and two corporations involved in an abortive attempt to develop a multimilliondollar highrise commercial project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

title: King Named Coach
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 7 (AP)  Bob King, athletic director at Indiana State University since last spring, was named basketball coach today, succeeding Gordon Stauffer who resigned las night. King, 51 years old, who will retain the job of athletic director, compiled a 17589 wonlost record in 10 years as basketball coach at the University of New Mexico.

title: Cox, Fairlie Gain
description: LONDON, March 7 (UPI)Mark Cox of Britain routed topseeded Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 62, 62, today to gain a spot opposite Brian Fairlie of New Zealand in tomorrow's final of the $60,000 Rothman's international indoor tennis tournament.

title: Shipping in Crisis as Tanker Use Plunges
description: LONDON, March 7Steadily falling oil consumption and an unusually mild winter in Europe have created the worst crisis in international shipping and shipbuilding since World War II.

title: Life of Phnom Penh Slowly Grinds Down
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 7Primary schools are open only every other day now and then only for a few hours. In Government offices, piles of paper mount steadily higher on the desks as the pace of work declines.

title: Rail Freight Total Off
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.2 billion tonmiles, 11.4 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 457,714 cars, 13.0 per cent below last year.

title: Defense in Attica Trial Moves to Subpoena Rockefeller as Witness
description: BUFFALO, March 7Defense lawyers in the Attica murder trial moved today to subpoena Vice President Rockefeller as a witness.

title: TV Pressure Groups: Accent on the News
description: Although television's orientation has always been toward general audiences, pressures are increasing upon stations in this area for more particularized news coverage. Growing out of the recognition that citizens have certain rights in the electronic media since the stations exist by Government license the pressures are being brought by groups that feel discriminated against, or victimized by, the massaudience criteria under which the television industry operates.

title: Notes on People
