description: FARMINGDALEThere is still a substantial linkage in terms of NassauSuffolk residents to the welfare of the New York City labor market, an official of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics said last week.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Knicks will continue their struggle to gain a National Basketball Association playoff berth when they meet the Phoenix Suns Tuesday and the Portland Trail Blazers Thursday at Madison Square Garden. Both games will start at 7:30 P.M. The New York Nets also play twice this week in the Nassau Coliseum, meeting Virginia this afternoon at 2:30 and Denver Friday night at 8 o'clock.

title: Art of Mannerism on View
description: PRINCETONIn addition to a display of its handsome permanent collection, Princeton University's Art Museum is offering through Thursday a small, but significant exhibition devoted to the art of mannerism.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Amax, Inc., a diversified natural resources company formerly known as American Metal Climax, Inc., has leased about 110,000 square feet in a new building in Greenwich, Conn., for its executive offices.

title: Obscenity Statute Drafted By Priest
description: TRENTONIn an effort to bring New Jersey into line with the Federal Obscenity Law, the Legislature is considering a new statute for the state.

title: Beware the Apartment Fireplace
description: When we moved to Manhattan, our top priority was finding an apartment with a working fireplace. Decisions on location, lighteven on whether it should be a coop or a rentaltook a back seat to finding a hearth. We were therefore delighted when we stumbled upon an affordable coop on Gramercy Park with not one but three fireplaces.

title: BUS START
description: BOSTON. Cassie McDonough's mother, Ellen, got the news first unofficially by phone, then two days later officially in the mail. Cassie, who is 11, barely remembers the details. He remembers walking home from school one afternoon last spring and finding his mother fretting in a way he had never seen. He didn't speak much with her he merely watched her as she telephoned her friends, pacing about the small kitchen and almost pulling the phone out of the wall. That night, his father also began what Cassie calls fretting, the same way his mother had that afternoon. They told him not to listen and sent him to his room. You'll find out soon enough if the letter comes, they said. The letter came. It was the official announcement that Clarence Charles McDonough 3d, of the South Boston district, had been selected as one of a group of students to be transferred from their neighborhood school to another school three miles away.

title: Elderly Seek Financial Relief
description: BAY SHORELess than a dollar a day for food. No money for medication. No means of transportation.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Byrne on Income Tax and Other Matters
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Governor Byrne by staff reportters, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: You Can't Let a Bloody American Beat You
description: All right lads, three minutes to race time, the Oxford team captain, Andy Etchells, called out. Waiting at the starting line for the other runners from Oxford and Cambridge, I paced about nervously. Though I had arrived at Oxford with the attitude that I would run only to keep in shape, it was not long before I had come to regard my performances in meets as important.

title: $20MILLION LEFT FROM CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Political candidates and their contributing committees had more than $20million left over at the end of last year.

title: Daring German to Drive Mostly on U.S. Tracks
description: Hans Stuck says he got the fuel infection very early, which is not surprising for a son of Hans Stuck Sr.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, March 10

title: Travel Notes: Year Of the Package Tour
description: ACCORDING to the seers and savants of the travel industry, 1975 will be the year of the package tour. What with inflation and recession, the reasoning goes, Americans will no longer jump blithely into the family car and drive off without definite plan or itinerary. Instead, those fortunate enough to be able to afford a trip, whether long or short, far or near, will want to know ahead of time what the total cost will be. So, says conventional wisdom, they are likely to look for a costinclusive package tour. The tour packagers, of course, are responding. Below is a small sampling of some of their more unusual offerings:

title: City Council Committees List Hearings for Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week:

title: Recapturing the Ballerina's Art on Disk
description: Records have a special significance for balletomanes. Without them, they have only their uncertain recollections, a few photographs of dancers perhaps, or maybe a critic's description. Musicthe sole element capable of surviving beyond the original theatrical occasion short of filming or videotapingis the surest means of recapturing that past into which every dance performance immediately vanishes.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Two pianos tinkle with syncopation. It is jazz but it is not jazz. It is remotely heard music, heard from another room along a corridor. It is music caught in a warp of placeWeimar Germanyand timefour decades ago. The curtain rises. Blank, blackcurtained stage. with sharp crosslighting. Two parallel lines of dancers, like the chorus in an oldfashioned musical. Simple costumessome of these people are rich, some are poor. The rich are in evening dressthe men wear elegant opera cloaks and top hats. The workers are in dull colors. A newsboy enters and tries to sell papers.

title: Recession's Special Victims: Newly Hired Blacks, Women
description: The acronym LIFO sounds as if it could be man's first effort to name a new breakfast cereal, but it unfortunately has much more importance than that.

title: . . . People of Hope
description: In times of economic hardship, Americans character istically respond in two ways. Politically, their perspective shifts. Radical causes of the left and the right win adherents they ordinarily cannot attract. Demagogues with dark dreams and simple answers gain a hearing they do not deserve. The last depression brought Adolph Hitler to power in Germany and led to a terrible war. Americans, spawning several less fearsome demagogues of their own, pondered Sinclair Lewis's novel, It Can't Happen Here.

title: Edison Boy Is a Computer Expert at 15
description: EDISON  A 15yearold boy who taught himself computer science, and has written a manual on the subject, led a recent threeday seminar on the subject at Kean College. The boy, David Touretzky of Edison, introduced the participants to a computer language known as BASIC.

title: The Fall of Rome goes on and on
description: ROME. It's no news to anybody that Italy is in a state of crisis. The question now is, rather, is the crisis terminal? With fair reason, a lot of people fear that it may be; and it needs no great imagination to suggest what form the obituary notices might take.

title: Diagramless, 18 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Rima Kopelman To Marry May 25
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morris Haber of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Haber's daughter, Rima Gail Kopelman, to Roger G. Rosenstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Soloman N. Rosenstein of Hillsdale, N.J.

title: LETTERS
description: Fair Trade

title: So Far, the Imported Kind Has Not Worked Well
description: Africa's center of ideological gravity moved sharply to the left last year. The new governments emerging in Portugal's African territories and the new regime in Ethiopia have all promised socialist courses of development. Yet in the fifteen years that most black African countries have been independent, the continent has proved stony ground for imported socialism, and the indigenous variety has taken root with success in only one country, Tanzania.

title: The Zany Lifeline Of the Caribbean
description: SCHEDULED depart Martinique 9:30 A.M. Leeward Islands Air Transport flight to St. Lucia. Arrive airport 8 o'clock, superearly. LIAT clerk takes ticket, checks baggage, directs me to go through immigration and customs at 9:20. Going through customs at 9:15 when LIAT clerk interrupts. Shouts. Hubbub. Your plane, says immigration officer. It is leaving.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In three caste in its current term, the United States Supreme Court was celled on to measure the balance between the privacy of the individual and the constitutionally guaranteed freedom of the press. In its considerations, the high court chose ?? restrict itself to the narrower issue in each case; the effect of its caution has been to leave unadvanced the argument about what private matters are of rightful public interest and to what extent damage suits constitute censorship of the press after the fact.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONAlthough Governor Byrne and the Senate's Democratic majority were stymied last week in their drive to abolish the State Commission of Investigationthey contend that corruption inquiries can be handled better by the state's Attorney Generala special anticorruption unit was quietly established within the Attorney General's office.

title: Arthritis Condition Forces Mrs. Ford To Curtail Activity
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) Betty Ford has had a flareup of a chronic arthritic condition and will have to curtail her activities temporarily, but has not been hospitalized, the White House said today.

title: Ann Wilson Fiancee of H.R. Wilson Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Wilson 3d of Ridgefield, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Marie Wilson, to Henry Randolph Wilson Jr. of Hartford, son of Comdr. Henry R. Wilson, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Wilson of Ridgefield, The families are not related.

title: A Gallup Poll Finds 8 Out of 10 Oppose More Aid for Indochina
description: Nearly eight of every 10 American adults oppose the Ford Admonistration's proposal to provide South Vietnam and Cambodia an additional $522million in military aid, according to a recent Gallup poll.

title: Plan for Playoff Seats Disclosed by Rangers
description: A limited number of mezzanine tickets for New York Rangers playoff games at Madison Square Garden will be made available for public sale through a postcard selection system, the same method used last year.

title: Peas and Beans Are Easy to Grow
description: Proteinrich peas and beans are among the easiest crops to grow in a home garden.

title: Queen Attends Wedding of Her Cousin
description: CHESTER, England, March 8 (AP)Queen Elizabeth II headed the guest list today when her cousin, the fifth Earl of Lichfield, married Lady Leonora, daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Westminster, in Chester Cathedral.

title: SURPLUS OF WHEAT TIED TO WEATHER
description: CHICAGO, March 8Grair dealers here foresee the possibil ity of accumulating sizable reserves of wheat during the coming crop year beginning July 1.

title: Teachers Act to Save Jobs
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 8 (AP)Faculty members at Berkshire Community College are offering to forgo $700 in fees each if they can save the jobs of four fellow teachers who face dismissal if the state freezes the college's budget. About $20,000 in fees has been pledged.

title: Ten Years of Classic Jazz
description: MADISONBack in 1965, Dick Neeld, an executive with the Prudential Insurance Company in Newark made new year's resolution. He resolved to get some satisfaction out of life that his job alone did not provide, even though he had been in the insurance business for 15 years.

title: Cordero Scores in Rooseben
description: Step Nicely did exactly that in the Roseben Handic??p at Aqueduct yesterday. The Hobeau Farm's 5yearold raced to a 1length triumph over the Lady JoBelle Stable's Monetary Principle, who had a nose over Piamem in the sevenfurlong sprint.

title: A Few Basics for the WellTooled Gardener
description: Newcomers to vegetable gardening must equip themselves with adequate tools for the jobs of planting, cultivating and maintaining their crops. But which, among the formidable array of weapons and gadgets offered by the local hardware, are indispensable?

title: Bahrain Says Continued U.S. Use of Naval Station Depends on Support for Arab Cause in Mideast
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, March 8The Foreign Minister of Bahrain has questioned the future of the American presence here, saying continued use of naval facilities would depend on the United States attitude toward the Arab cause in the Middle East.

title: How to Find Instruction For Tennis in New York
description: New York is one of the most expensive cities in which to play indoor tennis, but on the other hand it has many places where one may learn to play at moderate prices.

title: Patrice B. Rinaldo, Student, Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Rinaldo Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patrice Bianca Rinaldo, to Steven Dennis Cassedy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Cassedy Jr. of Great Neck, L.I.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Unemployment is surely a personal disaster when a worker loses his job, cannot find a new one despite perhaps a desperate search and must suffer a drastic drop in income. It is even a greater disaster if that worker has a family to support.

title: Voting Age Is Lowered In Italy to 18 From 21
description: ROME, March 8 (AP) Italy has lowered the voting age from 21 to 18, adding three million eligible voters to the country's electorate of 37 million.

title: The World
description: The authoritarian system that Generalissimo Francisco Franco established in Spain 35 years ago is now under such strain that experienced analysts question whether it can withstand the pressure.

title: INVESTING
description: Last summer, the money market was the place to be. for highgrade commercial paper was yielding 12 per cent or more. At the beginning of winter, the stock market was the place to be, for stock prices were about to climb 31 per cent. Now, investment bankers suggest, the corporate bond market is the place to put your money.

title: Measuring Efficiency Is No Easy Task
description: In the course of compiling productivity statistics, Mayor Beame's inthefield productivitymeasuring teams often employed somewhat odd measuring means, encountered unexpected roadblocks and were occasionally stymied.

title: Stripping a Veto
description: For the country as a whole, tough stripmine controls are absolutely essential if Americans are to make sensible use of the one source of energy that we have in abundance. Large majorities in both houses of Congress agree. They share the view that the huge beds of lowsulphur coal in the West must not be thrown open for exploitation without firm assurance that the land will be genuinely restored and that no mining will be allowed where scarcity of water or sharpness of slope make such restoration impossible.

title: The 15th Britannica
description: The new, 15th edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica is not a neutral reference work. It has a theme, a pedagogical purpose beyond the dissemination of information. That theme is to point towards larger unities among human activities and groupings generally as well as greater cohesion among the intellectual disciplines.

title: ART VIEW
description: One of the dividends of the current situation in the visual artsa situation characterized, above all, by an ideological openness and pluralism inimical to the notion of a single permissible period styleis the increased visibility of styles likely, in a more heated doctrinal atmosphere than ours, to be consigned to the sidelines. We are, at the moment; no longer as susceptible as we once were to the belief that history sanctions oneand only oneapproach to art at any given moment of history. We are more conscious than we used to be of the great diversity of purpose to found in the art that has enduredeven in the art produced in the heyday of modernismand we are less bound by theories that enforce a false consistency on our artistic experience. How long the situation will continue, no one can say, but for now, at least, it has brought us a certain relaxation in ideological intensity.

title: Inflation Overcomes National Pastime, $5 to $4
description: Baseball fans hold on to your caps. Box seat tickets have bounced to $5.00 from $4.00 for Yankee gamesto $4.50 for Mets games. And that perennial corporate favorite, the season ticket, has soared to $300 from $250 in 1974.

title: Elegant Evergreens To Trim Home Grounds
description: There are many kinds of evergreens to plant around a home. For me, the elegant ones are choice. These are the trees and shrubs that have special beauty of form which they keep during their lifetime or attain with age.

title: REAGAN REJECTS FORD PLEA TO G.O.P. TO BROADEN BASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California took a firm stand today against President Ford, Vice President Rockefeller and others who called this week for a Republican party broad enough to include moderates and liberals as well as conservatives.

title: Grocers Seek Wine Permits
description: NEWARK  After more than a decade of setbacks, New Jersey food merchants, from the smallest to the largest, have banded together in an effort to bring beer and wine to more shelves.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Like actors, stage lighting can speak well or poorly. It speaks very well for the Royal Shakespeare's shortened version of King Lear (two and onehalf hours, with, most important, Goneril and Regan shorn of their husbands), which will continue in repertory at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this month. The production, cut and staged by Buzz Goodbody, was originally intended for school audiences at Stratford in England. At the Academy it has simply been dropped onto what is known as the Lepercq Space on the second floor, and a space is simply that: enough room for actors to move about in, whether they are performing before the threesided bleachers on which the audience sits or actually circling and around them.

title: LOCK 'EM UP AND OTHER THOUGHTS ON CRIME
description: As much as anything, our futile efforts to curb or even understand the dramatic and continuing rise in crime have been frustrated by our optimistic and unrealistic assumptions about human nature. Considering that our society is in the grip of a decadeold crime wave despite a decadelong period of prosperity, it is strange that we should persist in the view that we can find and alleviate the causes of crime, that serious criminals can be rehabilitated, that the police can somehow be made to catch more criminals faster, and that prosecutors and judges have the wisdom to tailor sentences to fit the needs of the individual offender.

title: An Inappropriate Policy
description: At his news conference, President Ford said it would be inappropriate for him to comment on almost everything he was asked about, except the necessity for the Democrats in Congress to send more military aid to the Lon Nol regime in Cambodia. Just why it was inappropriate for the man who pardoned Richard Nixon to say whether Mr. Nixon could again become a Republican party leader was among many things Mr. Ford left unclear.

title: Chile Buys Citroen Holding
description: SANTIAGO, Chile March 8 (UPI)The Chilean Government today purchased 49 per cent of the shares held by the French automobile company Citron, in an assembly plant in Arica in the north of Chile. The Government previously had a 51 per cent bolding in the company's installations here.

title: Miss Maynard Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Douglas Maynard of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Boothbay Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Plackett Maynard. to Charles D. Brisk, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Brisk of Englewood, N.J., and North Windham, Me.

title: Concert: Rare Works
description: The concert presented by the New York Philharmonic in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night may well have justified the Whole week of concerts that made up the MiniFestival Around Schubert.

title: Federal Law Official Will Argue Before Court on Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Department of Justice has asked the Supreme Court for an opportunity to take part in oral argument on the issue of the constitutionality of capital punishment, partly, but not entirely, in favor of reinstating the death penalty.

title: TEXTBOOKS STIR FUROR IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, March 8New textbooks on social and natural sciences have been distributed to Mexican public schools, touching off angry charges from the National Parents Union that children are being indoctrinated in MarxistLeninist ideology and abnormal sexual views.

title: HARVARD WILL PUSH IMMUNOLOGY STUDY
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 (AP)Biochemical researchers at Harvard University say they will continue experiments into an immunology theory to see if they can duplicate earlier results.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: A String Quartet From TokyoIt Had to Happen
description: Japanese musicians have joined the American musical establishment more and more over the past 15 years. Conductors Seiji Ozawa, music director of the Boston Symphony, and Kazuyoshi Akiyama of the American Symphony are only the most visible of the group. The majority are string players trained in the rigorous Toho SchoolJapan's analogue to Juilliard. They come to the United States for study in summer festivals and conservatories and eventually find work in the nation's major orchestras.

title: Researcher Finds Many Problems in Night Work
description: EAST LANSING, Mich. March 8 (UPI)Night workers have more problems to contend with than just the revulsion to roast beef and mashed potatoes when their stomachs say it's time for toast and coffee.

title: The Roving LifeIn a Student Circus
description: AT sunrise the crew clambers out of their tractortrailer. Some collect the remnants of yesterday's show flattened popcorn boxes, halfeaten cotton candy and squashed paper cups. The animal trainers head for a nearby field where the horses and llamas have been staked for the night. A halfhour later the trucks of Circus Kirk, filled with laughing young people, are on the road, for this is no ordinary group of traveling circus folk: the clowns, barkers and fireeaters, who double as concessionaires, riggers and cooks, are all high school and college students whose childhood dream has been to work under the Big Top.

title: Engagements
description: BornesEpstein

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mark Spitz, angered by his poor handling and treatment in Hollywood: My TV appearances were flops, my milk commercial was unbelievably bad... and in my commercials for Schick razors, I rated lower in credibility than Howard Cosell.

title: Bulldog Best at Rockland
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., March 8 A red brindle and white bulldog that has been sweeping aside all competition this year added a bestinshow trophy to the Westfield collection today, when she was named best of 1,546 dogs at the Rockland County Kennel Club's 29th fixture.

title: Molloy Captures City Meet
description: The Public Schools Athletic League won eight of the 12 events, but a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association member went home with the team trophy yesterday at the 19th annual Mayor's AllCity Scholastic indoor track championships.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: CRAFT IS NEAR SITE FOR SUN APPROACH
description: Engineers in West Germany and California are completing preparations for two key events in the unmanned exproration of the solar system next weekend.

title: Play to Be Performed With Black and White Interpretations
description: GREAT NECKAn unusual exercise in bridging cultural gaps between races will be initiated tonight when Writers in Residence begins presenting the same oneact play with two different casts and directorsone white and one black.

title: Thomas Jefferson's Grand Paradox
description: The University of Virginia, built from 1817 to 1827, is probably the single most beautiful and effective architectural group of its kind in the country, or in the history of American building. And since it is a work so distinctly from the heart and mind of Thomas Jefferson, the great statesman and humanist whose art and politics shared a common philosophy and culture, it would be hard to pick a better way to observe the Bicentennial than to experience his academical village at first hand. It is doubtful if any of the approximately 3,000 Bicentennial exhibitions and events gathering steam in their penultimate year of preparation can compete with a trip to the source to touch base with the beginnings of the new nation.

title: Letters
description: Can't cut the mustard

title: Susan Peters, M. R. McGown To Be Married
description: Mr and Mrs. Theodore J. Peters of East Williston, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Virginia Peters, to Michael Roe McGown, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank of Long Island, the Melville, LI., subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: Greater Productivity Cited By Beame Administration
description: The Beame administration said yesterday that two thirds of its productivity measures were on or above target and that the city would realize $80million in economies and $130million in revenues in the current and next fiscal years because of the measures instituted.

title: Rutgers Lends a Hand to High School on Douglass Campus
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThose Rutgers University students who think of high school only in the past tense apparently do not know about Gibbons School, an alternate secondary institution that is situated on the university's Douglass College campus.

title: Births
description: Cohen

title: Sam Pian, 78, a Manager Of Barney Ross, Tony Zale
description: Sam Pian, who was comanager with Art Winch of Tony Zale and Barney Ross when they won world boxing championships in the nineteenthirties and forties, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in a Chicago hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Kissinger Has Nothing to Offer Assad, and Assad Has Nothing for Him
description: BEIRUT  While Secretary of State Kissinger flies between Egypt and Israel, trying to sell those two buyers on his secondstage peace plan in the Sinai, he is barely knocking on the door of another potential customer.

title: Rights of Natural Father Ruled Valid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8  Eightyearold Lisa R. had a mother who was an alcoholic and died of heroin abuse. She had a legal father, and he, too, died of drug addiction. Her real father, Victor R., whose name appears on her birth certificate, is alive. But Lisa has had to five with foster parents rather than with him.

title: OVERBILING LAID TO NURSING HOMES
description: A state commission study estimated yesterday that the New York nursinghome industry had overbilled taxpayers by more than $400million under Medicaid.

title: CAMBODIANS OUST KEY COMMANDERS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 8The Cambodian command has dismissed the commanding generals of two key units and replaced them with younger men in an apparently Americaninspired effort to inject new life into the faltering defenses of this capital.

title: HEALTH LAG FOUND FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8The World Health Organization, in a report on South Africa's policy of racial segregation, says it has found evidence among black South Africans of massive prevalence of preventable disease and premature deaths due mainly to nutritional deficiencies and infections.

title: Music: Entremont Ravel
description: The 100th anniversary of the birth of Maurice Ravel fell on Friday, and it was observed at Avery Fisher Hall with a recital of Ravel's piano music played by Philippe Entremont, the French virtuoso. He is president of and teaches at the Ravel Academy at St. JeandeLuz, which is in session annually in September.

title: Banker Fiance Of Nell D. Wall
description: Nell Duncan Wall, a research assistant with Morgan Stanley & Co, and John F. Otto Jr., an associate in the investment banking division of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, will be married in May.

title: 2 Torah Cases Are Stolen At New Rochelle Synagogue
description: Two Torah cases, one made of silver and one of gold, were stolen Friday night or early Saturday morning from a New Rochele synagogue, Young Israel of Westchester.

title: Richard Petty: A Cool, Careful Superstar
description: The community of Level Cross lies on the edge of the North Carolina PiedMont, a crossroads on U.S. Highway 220, 12 miles south of Greensboro, five miles north of a little river town called Randleman, There isn't much in Level Cross4neat, comfortable, middleclass houses, a trailer park, a couple of churches, a nice brick community center \with a lighted baseball field out back, the new volunteer fire department building across the roadbut it may be the bestknown crossroads community in the South. The reason is Level Cross only industry, No. 1 tourist attraction and leading family. All bear the name Petty.

title: Miss Shaver, John D. Knight Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bennett H. Shaver of Akron, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter. Meredith Joan Shaver, to John David Knight, son of Dr. and Mrs. Elmo L. Knight of Tonawanda. N.Y.

title: Bennett Eyes Title Of Conteh
description: LONDON, March 8 (AP)Lonnie Bennett, the Music Man from Los Angeles, is tuning up for his crack at John Conteh's world lightheavyweight boxing championship here Tuesday.

title: Early, artful Nabokov
description: Middleaged American readers have become familiar with Nabokov's writing in an unusual way. That is, they tuned in on him in the late forties and early fifties, when he was at the peak of his powers, producing Speak, Memory, Pnin, and most of all Lolita He had the effect of a new writer, though he had been an established Russian novelist for more than 20 years. Since then his American admirers have been treated to the rather uncanny experience of following Nabokov's later career while at the same time discovering his early works as these were successively translated into English by Dmitri Nabokov in collaboration with his father. This process has now reached some sort of climax with the publication a few months ago of Nabokov's latest novel Look at the Harlequins! and the republication in this collection of one of his earliest tales, A Matter of Chance, now first appearing in English 51 years after was published in the Riga Segodnya on June 22, 1924. It is like listening at the same time to both ends of an unknown piece of music whose middle is strangely familiar.

title: Boston U. Takes Hockey Title
description: BOSTON, March 8 The score read Boston University 7, Harvard 3, and it meant that the Terriers were the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey champions and thus the favorites for next week's National Collegiate title in St. Louis. But more importantly, it meant that B.U. was unequivocally the champion of Boston.

title: Mr. Samuel Lumen's planet
description: By Harvey Swados. 348 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.

title: Lobbying Groups Press Congress for Funds to Pay for Lapsed Medical Insurance for Jobless
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The swelling number of unemployed, who have lost medical insurance benefits as well as salaries, has set conservative and liberal lobbying groups marching up Capitol Hill to seek funds to pay the premiums for the lapsed policies.

title: Music in Review
description: Pierre Feit, the Frenchborn oboist known through a number of import recordings, and the Slovenian String Trio, formed by the broadcasting network in Ljubljana, Yugoslavia, made their New York debuts at Town Hall last Sunday. Their chamber program, including first performances here of a newly discovered Divertissement attributed to Haydn, and a clever set of Concert Improvisations for Pierre Feit and his Music Makers written for them last year by No Petric, was framed by the two milestone works in the limited repertory for oboe and strings: Benjamin Britten's Fantasy Quartet (1932) and the great F Major Quartet of Mozart (K.370).

title: Music Notes: An Orchestra Saved Until the Next Crisis
description: Orchestral crises are almost as common as government scandals these days. Within recent memory the Dallas, Denver and San Diego symphonies suspended operations temporarily, and the ensembles of New Jersey and Kansas City were among those cutting back their seasons. The latest orchestra to find itself teetering on the financial high wire is the Miami Philharmonicalthough the Miami story appears to be heading toward a happy ending.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Leslie Gray Mitchell Is Married
description: Leslie Gray Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Mitchell Jr. of Ogden Dunes, Ind., and Cape May, N. J., was married yesterday to Thomas Booth Britton, son of Mrs. Horace Ely Britton of Somers, N. Y., and the late Mr. Britton.

title: Nobody's Mad at Jerry
description: WASHINGTON, Mar. 8Funny thing about. President Ford: Almost everybody is grumbling these days about something he has done or hasn't done, but nobody's really sore at him. The opposition around here to Rockefeller, Kissinger, and Simon is savage and personal, but unlike Nixon, who was blamed for everything, Ford somehow manages to avoid personal blame for anything.

title: Economy and Crime Rate Slow Phasing Out of Old Bergen Jail
description: HACKENSACK  Sheriff Joseph F. Job is trying to phase out the inmate population of the 65yearold Bergen County Jail, but he is running into the same problems that plague many lawenforcement agencies today the faltering economy and the increasing crime rate.

title: Glenn Hardin, 64, Winner In 1936 Olympic Hurdles
description: BATON ROUGE La., March 8 (AP)Glenn (Slats) Hardin, a 1936 Olympic goldmedal winner, died Thursday night in a hospital here, after having suffered a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 64 years old.

title: Janet Dixon Sets June 7 Bridal With Walter Clark Teagle 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Galloway Dixon Jr. of Rockville, Md., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Janet Dixon, to Walter Clark Teagle 3d, son of Mrs. Page Wright Smith of Mill Neck, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Teagle 2d.

title: Edible Roots From a Flower
description: Jerusalem artichokes are coming back into favor. This native North American perennial (Helianthus tuberosa) is a relative of the sunflower. The Indians cultivated the plant for its edible potatolike tubers long before this country was discovered. They called it sun root. Champlain reported seeing the plants growing on Cape Cod in 1605 and they are believed to have been introduced in Europe in 1616. The plants still grow wild in areas.

title: World Bank to Expand Aid For Poorest in Rural Areas
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The World Bank, a major source of aid for agriculture in developing countries, announced today that it planned to double its investment to $1billion a year by 1979 to help the poorest people in rural areas.

title: Hall Retires, Era Ends For State's High Court
description: TRENTONThe State Supreme Court will mark the passing of an era this week with the retirement of Justice Frederick W. Hall.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Study at High Schools Growing Shorter
description: METUCHEN  Is high school too long?Increasing numbers of New Jersey secondary school students believe that it is, and so they are shortening their high school careers by meant of accelerated schedules and, consequently, early graduation.

title: Hard Times For Nobility In Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 8 (AP)Ethiopia's miltary revolution has created a new classthe fallen aristocrats.

title: Dual Dating
description: As noted in the accompanying report on ordering the 1975 cupronickel Uncirculated sets, six of the 12 coins in each setthe quarter, halfdollar and dollar from both the Philadelphia and Denver mintswill have the special Bicentennial designs and 17761976 dating. Philadelphia and Denver are also producing these cupronickel Bicentennial coins in great quantities and stockpiling them for massive nationwide release (at face value) later this year or early next year.

title: A Fitting Abode For a Towering Poet
description: A SMALL signpost on the Galway road just north of Gort marks the turnoff to Thoor Ballylee, the tower home of William Butler Yeats. Warned that the sign is easy to miss, I watch the roadside carefully, and sure enough it appears, as understated as everything else in this gentle green corner of Ireland. I turn right into the narrow lane and remember to hug the left side of the road, for that's where Irish cows, donkeys and children expect to find me should one or all of them suddenly pop out of a small gap in the thick shrubbery.

title: Why They Did What They Did
description: In the last year and a half, 17 American companies and 15 highranking business executives have pleaded gull ty to Federal charges of making illegal political contributions. Included have been such corporate giants as American Airlines, Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Gulf Oil.

title: TV VIEW
description: At what point does a detailed warning become a primer in the very subject it is supposedly warning against? The question dates back to the invention of the printing press and the development of mass journalism, but it has been given new and legitimate urgency with the graphic immediacy of television. Consider for instance, any documentary on drug abuse. The intention, of course, is to discourage addiction, but the inevitable shots of snorting, puffing and injecting furnish, no matter how unintentionally, the audience with a how to manual.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There is a United States Senator in Henry Kane's LUST OF POWER (Atheneum, $8.95), and the author leaves no doubt about his prototype. He is young, handsome, immensely wealthy, is from a Northeastern state, has immense charisma and is an honesttoGod liberal. How many will that fit? Right! Fortunately it is all makebelieve, for this Senator also has some unpleasant sides to him that include kinky sex and an ability to be utterly ruthless, not to say dishonest, when his own interests are concerned.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
Chess Diagram in Error
description: The diagram accompanying the chess column on page 38 of today's Arts and Leisure section is in error. It should show a white queen on White's Q1 square.

title: Nobody's Going to Typecast Diana Rigg
description: In this age of narrow specialization, what are we to make of an actress whose roles have ranged from James Bond's wife to King Lear's daughter, from TV crimefighter to Lady Macbeth, from slinky sex objects to several varieties of nun? The actress is Diana Rigg, who this week demonstrates her versatility anew when she arrives on Broadway in Moliere's The Misanthrope, costarring with Alec McCowen in a muchlauded production by the National of Great Britain.

title: No Fun Nohow!
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.There are certain advantages (though not many) in having lived through more decades than one wants to be reminded of. One of them is now being enjoyed by people in their fifties and above. It is the knowledge that another depression would be no fun.

title: Two Roads to the bicentennial Diverge in Westchester
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., March 8Pound Ridge has nearly completed its plans for the bicentennial, and Fred Zwick, the Supervisor of this northern Westchester community, is getting excited.

title: Dutch Girl Wins World Skate Title
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 8 (AP)  Fivetime Dutch champion, Dianne deLeeuw outclassing her competition from the outset, employed a daring routine and captured the women's gold medal last night at the world figure skating championships.

title: Nancy Seward Plans Nuptials
description: Dr. Ralph E. Seward, who practices medicine in Peoria, Ill., and Dorothy Mitchell Seward of Peoria have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Clare Seward, to Steven E. Sicher, son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Sicher of New York.

title: Draft Lottery Is Set For Men Born in 1956
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)The seventh annual draft lottery will be held Wednesday for two million young men born in 1956, to assign them numbers for a sequence of callup should it be necessary to resume the draft.

title: What Makes Streisand Queen of the Box Office?
description: It is to belabor the obvious to say that the movie stars of the last decade have been men. In fact, the list of the top boxoffice draws published annually by Variety would have been exclusively male but for one familiar female intruder, the kook from Brooklyn who altered her name but not her nose, the girl who belted and bullied her way onto the list and contrived to stay there. In 1968 Barbra Streisand won an Oscar for her performance in her first film. Funny Girl. On Wednesday, Funny Ladythe second installment in the life of Fanny Brice, a musical comedy performer who wasn't a fraction as famous a star as her interpreterwill open. For seven years, Streisand has been the only woman in movies who, in the language of megacorporate moneytalk, was bankable. Why?

title: I Feel Very Unrespected
description: MESA, Ariz., March 6In the Oakland A's batting cage, Reggie Jackson swung and bounced a weak grounder toward second base. Behind him, Billy North and Joe Rudi were awaiting their turns to hit. North leaned his head toward Jackson, talking softly but loud enough for those nearby to hear, especially Jackson himself.

title: Black Dean in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 8 (Reuters)An eminent African theologian, the Rev. Desmond Tutu, has been elected Anglican Dean of Johanresburg, the first black to hold this high church post.

title: Director of Space Agency Is Injured in Auto Crash
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 8 (UPI)The new director of the Kneedy Space Center and his daughter were injured and a truck driver was killed in a traffic accident today at the space center.

title: Grenada Leader Accused In 1974 Police Shooting
description: ST. GEORGp'S, Grenada, March 8 (UPI)A commision investigating allegations of police brutality criticized Prime Minister Eric Gairy on Friday and recommended the dismissal of three officials and a reorganization of the police department.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Marie M. Eslinger Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Eslinger of Plandome, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Margaret Eslinger, to Robert B. G. Horowitz, a student at the University of Miami Law School. He is the son of Robert S. Horowitz of Pompano Beach, F la., and Mrs. Kenneth Gerard of Adelaide, Australia.

title: Reavis Breaks Record in Jump
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 8New Rochelle's Rudy Reavis, the national scholastic high jump recordholder, won his specialty with a leap of 6 feet 11 inches and broke the New York State record in the triple jump last night in the Section 1 indoor track and field championships in the West Point fieldhouse.

title: Taft Five Conquers Lafayette. To Take P.S.A.L. Title Again
description: Taft was patient and disciplined yesterday as Lafayette got deeper in foul trouble and the Blue Devils took advantage for a 7470 victory and their second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League baskeball championship at St. John's University gym in Jamaica, Queens.

title: 3 Cases Make the Point
description: DURHAM, N. C.There is growing concern in North Carolina that next month, when national attention will probably be given to a criminal trial in the little tobaccomarketing town of Washington, N. C., the state's already battered image of racial moderation may be shattered.

title: 3 IN BRAZIL PERCH IN TREE TO SAVE IT
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 8Three Brazilian students occupied an 80yearold acacia tree in the southern city of Porto Alegre last week. They were beaten up and jailed, but they succeeded in saving it from destruction, in defiance of the authorities, and are national heroes.

title: What's Doing in TOKYO
description: SAKURA  April is the time for cherry blossoms (sakura) in Japan. a season of subtle loveliness. Viewing the blossoms is at once in art, a pastime and a national sport. Each year experts solemnly predict precisely the daysometimes the hourwhen the blossoms will be at their height. For ordinary mortals, knowing the week should be enough. The best guess this year is that the blossoms will be out in Tokyo during the first week in April and that the trees will hit full bloom around April 10. A favorite way to enjoy the sight is to take a jug of warm sake (rice wine) and go to the Aoyama Cemetery, which is full of cherry trees, and sit under the blossoms in the moonlight drinking sake. Other places for splendid viewing are Ueno Park, where there will be a festival April 6 and 7; Shinjuku Gyoen Garden, where the blossoms are double and in midApril the Prime Minister holds bis annual cherry blossom viewing party; Yasukuni Shrine to Japan's war dead, which will hold a festival April 115; and, in the center of the city, the East Garden of the Imperial Palace and the grounds around the palace moat. All are free except for a 50yen (17 cents) admission charge at Shinjuku Gyoen.

title: Terrie Eaton Egert Engaged To John F. Wood Jr., Bank Aide
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Egert Jr. of Rocky River, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terrie Eaton Egert, to John Frederick Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of Darien, Conn.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: CHILDREN

title: Federal Study Charges Little Concern By Utilities With Reactor Reliability
description: WASHINGTON, March 8A Federal study has concluded that the utilities that own most American nuclear reactorswhich have recently been generating only about 55 per cent of their power capacityare not sufficiently concerned about the safety and performance of their reactors.

title: Building Alaska Oil Field Means Mastering Bleak, Icy Land
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, March 8When Buck Rice ran away from his Louisiana home as a boy, he had no idea how far he would get. Now he can go only a few more yards to remain on the North American mainland.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities

title: Devika Crowell Bride Of David L. Hubbard
description: Devika Crowell, daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. Arthur R. Crowell of Brooklyn, and David L. Hubbard, son of Mrs. Florence Hubbard and David Hubbard, both of Baltimore, were married here yesterday morning in the Park Avenue. United Methodist Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philip A. Clarke. He was assisted by the bride's father, minister of the Union United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.

title: SCHOOL UNIT ASKS FOR PAYOFF DATA
description: The City Board of Education has asked the State Commission of Investigation to provide it with information about alleged kickbacks or illegal gifts to board employes by a payrollprocessing company that until recently did business with the school system.

title: Groucho's 1950's Quiz Show Is a Hit All Over Again
description: You Bet Your Life, the TV quiz show that starred Groucho Marx back in the 1950's, is currently enjoying a second life. Whether because of nostalgia, the enduring appeal of Groucho or the gloomy news of the day, the show'has become a late evening hit on independent stations in 18 cities across the country, including WNEW here, where it is seen weeknights at 11 P.M.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Horsemen's Scholarship Winner Chooses University of Georgia
description: The Professional Horsemen's Association broke precedent this year and awarded its annual scholarship to 17yearold Gayle Gottfried of Somers, N. Y. Miss Gottfried will receive a $500 grant from the organization and will enter the University of Georgia as a preveterinary student in the fall semester.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Endpaper
description: If I have anything to say about it, the pronoun whom will be dropped from the English language except in one context. And I do have something to say about it in what follows.

title: David Gee to Marry Kim Faith Albertson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Albertson of Locust Valley, L. I., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kim Faith Albertson, to David Stephen Gee, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Gee of Greenville, Del., and Buck Hill Falls.

title: 25 Bubonic Cases in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola March 8 (AP)  Twentyfive cases of bubonic plague have been reported in southeastern Angola, about 250 miles north of the border with SouthWest Africa, the Angolan public health service said today.

title: Eyesquinting
description: ACROSS

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayCoach House Stables. Kenilworth Road, Rye, N. Y. Regular, maiden, novice, limit and junior working hunters; ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Workshop to Air Metric Measures
description: TRENTON  Mastering Metric Measure in Schools Today and Tomorrow will be the theme of a oneday workshop for teachers and educators at Rider College tomorrow.

title: Miss Chawluk Fiancee of Robert Drumm
description: Marianne Ellen Chawluk and Robert Elmer Drumm of New York, Woodrow Wilson fellows and doctoral candidates at Columbia University, plan to be married in August.

title: Richman Five Captures Girls' Crown in P. S. A. L.
description: While most of the attention was being focused on the Public School Athletic League's boys' basketball championship playoffs yesterday at St. John's University in Queens, two of the top girls' teams in the cityJulia Richman High and Flushing Highwere battling across town for the P.S.A.L.'s girls' title at Francis Lewis High School.

title: Changes in the Law On CableTV Urged
description: WASHINGTON The Federal Communications Commission was warned last week that its authority and policy in the field of cable television were being threatened in New Jersey.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Though the weather outside may be frightful, the planting season will soon be delightful. Meanwhile, there are many outdoor things to be done before seed goes into the ground. Essentially the cleanup process is clearing the lawn of winter debris and tidying up around shrub and flower borders. The ground is too wet to work in colder, low regions but where the soil is sandy and the sun warm, digging can begin.

title: Kansas Big 8 Swim Victor
description: STILLWATER, Okla., March 8 (AP)Despite a strong bid by Iowa State, Kansas won the Big Eight swimming championship tonight for the eighth consecutive time.

title: Saw Mill's 1,038Entry Dog Show Relies on Efforts of 13 Couples
description: Saw Mill is a show that enjoys the distinction of being the only fixture of the 656 allbreed events staged under the aegis of the American Kennel Club with no groups or best in show. Today it is holding its 35th show at the Westchester County Center in White Plains. As usual, it has set a limit of 1,000 dogs, and as usual, it has met the quota. All the entries that are in the mail pouch with No. 1,000 are accepted, so today there are 1,038 representing 100 breeds.

title: C.Y. Crockett to Wed Sarah Bacon
description: Robert Bacon of Woods Hole, Mass., and Katharine Jay Bacon of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Livingston Bacon, to Christopher Yates Crockett, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Crockett of Ipswich, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth Marine Terminal Now a Pacesetter in Port Activity
description: ELIZABETH  The Elizabeth Marine Terminal, which claims to be the largest containership port in the world, was an exceptionally busy place last year.

title: The Region
description: The insolvent Urban Development Corporation was given a $90million infusion of public money last week to keep it alive a while longer. But after that money runs out, the U.D.C. will need substantial financing, and as of now major commercial banks have not said they will provide it.

title: WIN Has Lost
description: Whip Inflation Now (WIN), a catchphrase heavily promoted by President Ford and the butt of many jokes, was quietly discarded yesterday by the Citizens' Action Committee, an antiinflation group. Details are on Page 40.

title: BYRDIE GREEN SINGS BLUES IN JAZZ SERIES
description: The blues were the announced contribution of Byrdie Green to Jazz: The Personal Dimension, the series at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening. And Miss Green, a lean and sinuous woman, had an honorable list of blue and bluesassociated songs on her program.

title: Syrian, Supporting Palestinians, Offers to Form Joint Commands
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 8 (AP)President Hafez alAssad offered today to unify Syria's political and military commands with those of the Palestinian guerrilla movement as a means to consolidate the Palestinian struggle.

title: Careers May End, but Fortunes Linger
description: The top executives of the Minnesota. Mining and Manufacturing Company, virtually all of them career men, have become wealthy on their salaries and stock options. Even those executives who have been forced to resign by the political funding scandal that swept the company carry with them lavish retirement benefits and millions of dollars worth of 3M stock.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Children

title: Marshals to Go to All Telephone Fires
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan announced yesterday that fire marshals and a mobile photographic unit would be immediately dispatched to any fires in buildings of the New York Telephone Company.

title: 2 CANCER EXPERTS SPLIT ON PROGRAM
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 (AP)Dr. James D. Watson, the Nobel Prizewinning biologist, says the national cancer program is a sham that may be contributing little to treating cancer, but the head of the National Cancer Institute strongly disagrees.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 9, 1975

title: The singular krill
description: In a hungry world where, in the past year, thousands of people have died of starvation and millions more are suffering from chronic malnutrition, the krill, a small Antarctic crustacean, noteworthy heretofore as the major item in the diet of the great baleen, or toothless, whales, is now being considered a possible addition to the menus of mankind. Over the past 40 years, whalers have reduced the whale population of the Antarctic by 90 per cent, and scientists speculate that the krill, on which the whales feed, could be enjoying a corresponding population boom. Russian scientists currently estimate the Antarctic's krill stock at anything from 800 million to 5 billion metric tons (the conservative American estimate puts the totals at 500 million to a billion tons, with the liberal guess at 3 billion to 4 billion). An Australian scientist has calculated that an annual catch of 70 million tons of krill could provide 20 grams of animal protein daily for a billion people, roughly onequarter of the human race.

title: GRACE WIEDER HEARD IN RECITAL ON PIANO
description: Grace Wieder, a pianist who has played here before, offered a program at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon consisting of a Bach Prelude and Fugue in B minor, Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 333), Brahm's Four Ballades (Op. 10), a group of pieces by Satie and Chopin's Scherzo in C sharp minor.

title: Trevino 2 Shots In Lead
Ben Jonson reluctant bricklayer
description: By C. Walter Hodges. Illustrated. 168 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $7.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: Book Ends
description: Fat Cat. Little did you know as you lay asleep in your beds that a biography of a cat almost made the Best Seller List. We're exaggerating but the book was reported by several stores, especially in the New York area. and the publisher says that over 85,000 copies have been sold. The work in question is entitled Morris: An Intimate Biography by Mary Daniels and it purports in a style archer than a tom's back) to recount the life and thoughts of the marmalade feline who is featured in television cat food commercials. Morris's finicky act made him a superstar, cat division, before the book's appearance, and evidently won him a lot of fans. Credit the late Jacqueline Susann with being the brains behind Morris. Miss Susann, who wrote a fairly popular book of her own about her poodle, was in Chicago on one of her tireless publicity swings and was interviewed by Mrs. Daniels, a reporter for The Chicago Tribune. Mrs. Daniels, it developed had written an article about Morris, winch.gave Miss Susann the idea for a book. She immediately called Sherry Arden, Morrow vice president and publicity director, and announced. You should do a book about Morris. Morris who? replied Mrs. Arden. Miss Susann explained; Mrs. Arden in turn explained who Morris was to her boss. Everybody agreed was a cute idea for a gift book, and a sales manager gave his blessing: That's merchandise. Mrs. Daniels then wrote, if that is the word, the book and it sold beyond all expectations.

title: The golden gospel of Reverend Ike
description: At precisely 3 o'clock on a recent Sunday afternoon, in the new time of America's economic and spiritual discomfort, Dr. Frederick J. Eikerenkoetter 2d, Th.B., Ph.D., D.Sc.L., founderminister of the United Church, Science of Living Institute, Inc., walked calmly down the aisles among the 5,000 New Yorkers gathered in the carefully restored Moorish splendor of a former Loews movie cathedral in Washington Heights, and told them to forget the 20thcentury blues currently afflicting the nation.

title: Byrne Now Expects to Get State Income Tax Passed
description: After nearly a year of repeated and often humiliating legislative defeats, Governor Byrne is now relatively confident that the overwhelming Democratic majorities in both houses of the New Jersey Legislature will approve a state income tax next month and thus resolve the state's worst fiscal crisis in recent memory.

title: Kissinger Rebuff Reported To Cambodia Talk in 1974
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia March 8Ambassador John Gunther Dean was rebuffed last year when he proposed to Secretary of State Kissinger that an attempt be made to establish contact with a key Cambodian insurgent leader to feel out the possibility of peace negotiations, according to sources in the United States Embassy here.

title: Stockton Defeats Newcombe, But Aussies Forge 32 Lead
description: HARTFORD, March 8Australia, mainly on the strong back or John Newcombe, moved today within one step of capturing her fifth Aetna World Cup in six years.

title: Chronicle on Tocks To Oppose Project
description: BELVIDERE A chronicle of the history and culture of the Tocks Island area, from its roots in the Ice Age to the present, is being prepared by a special staff established by the FourCounty Task Force on Tocks Island.

title: YALE TAKES STAND ON FREE SPEECH
description: The trustees of Yale University yesterday formally adopted a policy calling for suspension or expulsion for wilfull and persistent disruption of free speech at the university.

title: A setting for adventure
description: There are two schools of thought about how to design playgrounds these days. In England and Scandinavia children, in effect, create their own playgrounds. Open spaces are set aside for them to use in almost any way they want. Adults provide inexpensive, offbeat materials for the children to play withused tires, oil drums, fencing, wooden ladders, chains and stock lumber. In America designers create playgrounds for the children. Landscape architect M. Paul Friedberg uses ideas from both schools of thought in the two prototypes shown here: He takes the same materials found in English and Scandinavian playgrounds and uses them in the structures he designs for children to play on.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Clemson, Holy Cross, Massachusetts and St. John's accepted bids yesterday to play in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden starting next Saturday. They join Princeton, Oregon, Southern Illinois, South Carolina and Oral Roberts. Seven berths remain open in the 16team basketball tournament. The remaining teams are expected to be announced today.

title: Manila's Endless War
description: COTABATO, the Philippines Two years after Moslem insurgents made their first coordinated attacks on Government outposts in the southern Philippines, the martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos finds itself mired in a nasty guerrilla struggle in which the chances of either a negotiated settlement or a military solution seem slight.

title: RIGHTS VIOLATORS FACING U.S. ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)The Justice Department is cracking down selectively on states, counties and even cities that have violated the Voting Rights Act by failing to submit laws for Federal approval.

title: Movies Show How Neighborhoods Can Improve
description: The blockbuster movies filmed in New York everyone hears about: Robert Redford shooting in an East Side townhouse; Marlon Brando mumbling his way through Little Italy.

title: Meeting At Potsdam
description: By Charles L. Mee Jr. Illustrated. 370 pp. New York: M. Evans & Co. $10.95.

title: TV Notes: Series Failure Rate Is Soaring
description: Healthy as the networks are (profits are up and viewing levels rise every year), they have lately become curiously inept at developing successful new shows. Not that it was ever easy to bring in a winner; new TV shows have always had a high mortality rate, normally around 60 per cent. But a year ago, it went up to 90 per cent, when Kojak and Police Story were all that emerged from a field of 20, and this season has been nearly, as bad.

title: The life and death of a Colombian hero
description: On February 15, 1966, the Colombian army reported the death of an unusual guerrilla during an ambush on one of its patrols. He was Camilo Torres, a former priest armed with a Colt .38. During his seven years of public life, the had been spiritual adviser and sociology instructor to the students of the National University, held a seat in the Land Reform Commission, helped to father Colombia's Community Action movement, started a rural agricultural school. Somehow in the course of these activities he came to despair of effective reform and turned to guerrilla warfare as the only solution to Colombia's problems.

title: Michael Bittel Fianc of Majorie Adams
description: Mr. and Mrs, Daniel Putnam Adams of New York and Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Putnam Adams, to Michael Allen Bittel, son of Mr, and Mrs. William Allen Bittel of Englewood, N. J. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Hobbyists Are HellBent For Leather
description: According to Genesis, the first garments worn by Adam and Eve were made of leather. John the Baptist is mentioned in Scripture as wearing a leather belt. Paleolithic cave drawings have been found which depict men processing leather and some 3,500 years ago wealthy Egyptians considered leather a semi  precious material (leather sandals, bags, and cushions from this period have been found in Egyptian tombs). The Greeks and the Romans recognized the value of leather for armor and shields, and Roman soldiers took to wearing leather pants, a custom which they adopted from the Teutons.

title: The Law of the Taj Mahal and ether Tips for Travelers
description: OVER the last 10 years, my wife and I have covered some 200,000 miles and visited 32 countries, doing research and writing. Inevitably, we have developed a kind of philosophy of foreign travel, a way of looking at the experience: We seek places and people that will stimulate us, stir up our minds, change our way of seeing ourselves and the world.

title: Flowers to Grow Where It's Shady
description: A garden may have many degrees of shade, varying from light shade under highheaded and lightly foliaged deciduous trees to partshade along foundations and fences to the darkest conditions under the low spreading branches of evergreens. To grow colorful flowers in these areas, the amount of light at different times of day and through the seasons is important as the sun travels a new route.

title: Focusing on EnergyUnclearly
description: WASHINGTONIn a town where Scrabble with agecny names often becomes a Governmental game for concealing problems, a new bureaucratic conglomerate has emerged with a broad, still nebulous mandate for solving the nation's energy problems.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE price index declined for the third month in a row, the first time this has happened since 1967. Factory orders fell for the fifth conseutive month in January, by 2 per cent, compared with a 9.3 per cent drop in December . . . Manufacturers' inventories in January rose by the smallest amount since August, 1973 . . . Business failures for week ended Feb. 27 rose to 270 from 221.

title: 4 Persons Killed Upstate In Crash of a Small Plane
description: FULTON, N. Y., March 8 (AP) A small plane crashed shortly after takeoff from the nearby Oswego County Airport today, killing all four persons aboard, the airport manager said.

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI March 8Like the common egret, which once was threatened with extinction but now is outnumbered in Florida only by the English sparrow and the Yankee tourist, the major league catcher seems to be making a comeback. Not long ago he was an endangered species like the whooping crane, apparently destined to follow the passenger pigeon into oblivion, and not because he was good to eat. Modern youth was just getting too smart to cumber himself with armor and sweat out his summers in a kneesprung squat doing the thinking for a lot of pitchers, some of them lefthanded.

title: Djerassi Snaps Meet Mark In I.C. 4A Weight Throw
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 8  In the back of Boris Dov Djerassi's mind, away from dreamy thoughts about the hammer throw, there is always the dark thought: What would have happened if he had gone to the Munich Olympics as a member of Israel's track and field team?

title: About the Mets . . .
description: In the second game of the series, Bob Gibson will pitch for St. Louis today, opposing Jon Matlack for the first three innings. For Gibson, now 39 years old, the game will mark the opening of his final season in baseball. . . The Yomiuri Giants of Tokyo and the Chuniuchi Dragons of Nagoya, who won their opening games Friday against the Los Angeles Dodgers and Chicago White Sox, respectively, will count in the Grapefruit League standings during their twoweek visits from Japan. However, the standings themselves do not count for anything in particular.

title: Thousands Mark '5 March in Selma, Ala
description: SELMA, Ala., March 8 (AP) Thousands of black civil rights marchers, remembering a notsopeaceful day 10 years ago, walked solemnly across the Alabama River bridge here today in what the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called a continuing great struggle for liberation.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have a beautiful white marble fireplace mantel in my house which is covered with green paint. What would be a safe way of stripping this paint off? Dr. A.B., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Patricia Gabel Nuptials on Aug. 2
description: Patricia Gabel and Arthur P. Anderson, seniors at the Albany, Law School of Union College, plan to be married Aug. 2. Announcement of their engagement has been made by her parents. Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gabel Jr. of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Miss Gabel's fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Anderson of Williston Park, L.I.

title: More Early Birds, Higher Refunds on Taxes
description: More people are filing their income tax returns early this year than last year. In fact, early returns are up 50 per cent or more in the New York metropolitan area and statewide; nationwide there has been almost 9 per cent increase and processing has kept pace, according to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Caro of Thanks

It was the largest sum ever paid at auction for an individual 20th  century photographic image. Yet Stieglitz himselt despised a moneyminded approach to photography. He once told an astonished visitor to his gallery, I am not a salesman, nor are the pictures here for salethough in certain circumstances certain pictures may be acquired.

To the east of the highway, looking toward New York, industrial parks dominate; to the west, where each street rises dramatically above the other, staid, old houses are the rule. And it is the industrial area, built on the Hackensack Meadowlands, that has made possible both prosperity and total residential living for the 7,000 bluecollar workers who reside in the borough.

title: Learning to love, learning to work
description: He's a mere child, you're a typical teenager, we're sort of middleaged, she's really getting on, and he's practically dead. How ironic that technological America can accept so vaguely calibrated a continuum to tick off the ages of man. The way we dress now expresses the way we gloss over society's compartmentalization by age and generation. Lately, the young, in rebellion against tailormade conformity, broke out into a revolution of dress, if not ultimately one in fact, and now, like most revolutions, it has become a model for antirevolutionary imitation. A grandmother in St. Petersburg strolls under the palms in a size 16 duplicate of the doublek??it pants suit her daughter inlaw wears while carpooling her jerseyclad children to school in Mamaroneck yet their life expectations are as different as chalk and cheese. Now, less than five years after Kent State, coliege students (boys or girls) dip into their mother's bureau for her Yves Saint Laurent shirt, silk scarf or bulky cardigan. Even at the height of what may be described as the Mannerist Sixties, when inspired originality was the universal cry, the withit people from Harvard Square to HaightAshbury ended up looking like so many interchangeable characters in an allAmerican ethnohistoricotheatrical motley. The laws of costume have a certain leveling inevitability.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Rabbit's tale. Once upon a time there was a sawdust velveteencovered Rabbit who lived in a Boy's nursery, shared his owner's life and of course his bed. Though time faded the toy's features, the Boy came to love him as if he were a real rabbit. Then the Boy caught scarlet fever and the Rabbit was doomed for destruction. Providentially a loving flower fairy turned him into a rent rabbit, free to hop for eternity through a universe filled with other real rabbits. An English lady, Margery Williams, wrote 4,000 wellchosen words about him. Illustrated with 7 nostalgic drawings by William Nicholson, these were quietly published as The Velveteen Rabbit in England in 1922, four years later in the United States. Very quietlyfor, with a few exceptions, children's reviewers ignored the book. Sales were modest  a few thousand copies a year  but Doubleday kept it in print. Then about 1967, when Love had become a Big Thing, college students, hippies, Protestant clergymen and Catholic nuns began to dis cover the tale as a parable they could take to their hearts. Since then more than 400,000 copies have been bought in hardcover. Now, in good time for Easter, Avon is publishing it in a format identical with Doubleday's except that the covers are soft  at $1.50 a treasure for Rabbit lovers regardless of age.

title: The Joyous Life On a Blessed Isle
description: I WENT to the Canary Islands rather casually last summer, taking a small house for a month on the island of Tenerife simply because the ad promised clean air, sun, trade winds and peace. The rental price was $125 a month and included the services of a maid six days a week. My knowledge of the islands was slight hut all of it seemed reassuring. Horace had said that the Canary Islands were set apart from the world by Jupiter for a pious people when the Golden Age began to be tarnished with brass. Shakespeare spoke often of the bloodwarming Canary sack to which Falstaff was addicted. I knew the Canaries were called the Blessed Islands, the Fortunate Islands, that someone had said Zeus sent dead heroes there. And there was that maid.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The art of moving picture criticism has virtually stood still since 1915 when Vachel Lindsay published his seminal volume, The Art of The Moving Picture, a collection of essays that were sometimes deadwrong (as when he suggested that moving picture theaters would put corner saloons out of business) but that more often set the standards by which all succeeding movie criticism and movie critics would be judged. In the 60 years since The Aft of The Moving Picture came out, nothing has happened. It's been Dullsville. There've been no breakthoughts in movie criticism comparable to the ones we've witnessed in the technology of moviemaking, to say nothing of medicine, manners, physics, arithmetic, space and spelling.

description: The ordering period for the 12  coin 1975 cupro  nickel Uncirculated sets, also called Mint sets, officially began last Mopday, March 3, and the Mint has announced that it will end April 30. Collectors should not confuse this information with the Mint's late January announcement of a long extension of the ordering period for the silver threecoin Bicentennial proof and uncirculated sets. Those silver coin sets are completely separate from every other Mint offering; nothing comparable to them has ever before been offered to the public  in fact, they were created by special Congressional action so that the extension of the ordering period until July 4, 1976, and the elimination of the traditional fiveset ordering limit are applicable only to those special 40 per cent silver threecoin Bicentennial sets.

March 8 (AP)A freshman, Phil Ford, scored nine of his gamehigh 24 points in the last seven minutes to direct North Carolina to a 7066 victory over the defending champion, North Carolina State, in the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight.

title: In the Eastern Mediterranean, Washington Is Villain and Savior
description: ATHENSSeveral weeks ago, London outraged the Greek Cypriotes by allowing about 10,000 Turkish Cypriote refugees to move from a British base in Cyprus to Turkey. The Greeks staged several demonstrations against British installations, but soon lost interest in that pursuit and turned their attention to the United States Embassy and Cultural Center, which they nearly set afire.

title: Bill to Seek to Exempt Elderly From FuelCost Rent Increases
description: Two City Council leaders announced yesterday that they would move, at a public hearing tomorrow, to exempt the elderly from fuelcost rent increases proposed by Mayor Beame for many rentcontrolled apartments here.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: For the past six months one of the more astounding phenomena to emerge from popland has been a successful stream of thoroughly conventional romantic ditties. Timeworn variations on the pleasures and pangs that occur whenever Cupid shoots his arrows, three of these hitsWalking in the Rain by Neil Sedaka, Having My Baby by Paul Anka, and My Melody of Love by Bobby Vintonfind a pop superstar of yesteryear centerstage once again. These warblers are all in their mid30's; none has had a hit record in years. Yet suddenly and unexpectedly they are once again topping the popmusic popularity charts.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The Arab boycott of Jewishallied businesses has had predictable ramifications on the national business and political scene. It has also altered the course of the Sterndent Corporation, a mediumsize dentaleqquipment manufacturer in. Mount Vernon, N. Y., and its chief executive. Martin H. Dubilier, the chairman, is a 48yearold professional manager, of the Harvard Business School breed, who thought he had at last found his place as a leader and shaper of corporate destiny.

title: A Research Laggard Joins Exxon Club
description: The Esso Research Laboratory, which has made Baton Rouge, La., the cradle of the synthetic rubber industry according to its proud parent, has finally changed its name.

title: F.D.U. Star Finds Modern Dance an Asset in Sports
description: Twice a week Mike Battle, a Fairleigh Dickinson football and track star, is simply one of the girls.

title: TOO MANY MEN FOR BONN'S ARMY
description: BONN, March 4West Germany has so many youths to draw from for its armed forces that it is proposing to give conscientious objectors a chance to chose alternative civilia?? service without having to prove the sincerity of their beliefs.

title: Israeli Dove Dubious of Kissinger Tactics
description: JERUSALEM, March 8The prevalent view among Israelis discussing Secretary of State Kissinger's return to the Middle Eastmost conversations seem to settle on that subject no matter where they startis that Mr. Kissinger will put pressure on Israeli leaders to give up too much in return for too little.

title: Airline Seeks Cut in Fares
description: KEY WEST, Fla., March 8 (UPI)Air Sunshine has asked the Florida Public Service Commission for permision to halve its rates for senior citizens and the handicapped and to reduce night fares, it was announced today. The Key Westbased commuter airline, which flies to Marathon, Fla., and Miami and Tampa, said the lowered fares would aid the economy of the Keys, which is undergoing tremendous shock because of unemployment which now exceeds [that of] all of Florida.

title: Coltsfoot
description: At a quick glance it looks like a dandelion blossom, perhaps flattened a bit or skimped by the chill of early March. But it isn't a dandelion and it hasn't been shrunken by the weather. It is coltsfoot, one of the earliest of all our wildflowers, and it is in bloom now on sheltered banks that catch full sunlight.

title: Jurors Get Charge Dropped
description: PHOENIX Ariz., March 8A Maricopa County Superio?? Court judge has dismissed contempt of court charges against four women jurors who had been accused of discussing a trial over lunch. I feel that the point has been made to these ladies and to all jurors, Judge Charles Hardy said after dismissing the charges yesterday. On Feb. 27, Judge Hardy had sentenced the jurors to two days in jail each, after receiving a report of their discussion of the case that they had been hearing. On Feb. 28, he set aside the jail sentences pending yesterday's hearing.

title: Is It a Depression Or Just a Bad Recession
