description: Is the United States economy sinking into a bottomless pit? Or is the current recession just another business cycle, alike in kind to its postwar predecessors  if worse in degree?

title: Colorado Takes N.C.A.A. Skiing
description: DURANGO, Colo., March 8, (AP)Didrik Muller Ellefsen of the University of Colorado retained the National Collegiate ski jumping title today. His victory clinched the championship for the Buffaloes, their fourth straight.

title: Joseph Bech, Statesman, Dead; A Founder of Common Market
description: LUXEMBOURG, March 9 (AP) Joseph Bech, former Premier and Foreign Minister and a signer of the 1957 Treaty of Rome, which set up the European Common Market, died here yesterday at the age of 88.

title: Drake's California Voyage Reenacted
description: SAN FRANCISCO March 9  After a sixmonth journey from Plymouth, England, a 102footlong reproduction of Sir Francis Drake's ship, the Golden Hind, anchored off San Francisco Harbor today, after having been almost torn apart in a storm off the California coast.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT RYE, N Y.

title: Senate Study Calls U. S. Drug Agents Lax in Checking Alleged Link of Vesco to Heroin
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 Federal narcotics agents failed to investigate properly evidence that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, was behind a scheme to smuggle $300,000 worth of heroin into the United States from France, a Senate inquiry concluded.

title: About New York
description: About 3,000 Russian Jews have settled in New York in the last two years, and many of them, according to the editor of Novoye Russkoye Slovo, the Russian paper here, are unhappy.

title: FLORIDA CHECK SET ON CONDOMINIUMS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.. March 9Disturbed by repoits that some Florida condominium developers have engaged in unethical and illegal sales practices, a number of local builders have formed a policing association that they hope will spread statewide through the troubled industry.

title: Odermatt Registers a ProSki Double
description: ASPEN, Colo., March 9Josef Odermatt achieved a difficult feat today, completing a double in the $30,000 world professional skiracing championships at Aspen Highland.

title: Barry Paces Rally As Warriors Win
description: BOSTON, March 9 (UPI)Rick Barry scored 11 points in the final 5 minutes 30 seconds today as the Golden State Warriors rallied from a 16point deficit to score a 102101 victory over the Boston Celtics in a nationally televised National Basketball Association game.

title: Fused Unions
description: When the campaign to unionize massproduction industries was in high gear nearly four decades ago, the old C.I.O. formed an organizing committee in textiles, an industry with low wages and wretched working conditions.

title: Fears and Frustrations of the Greek Plotters Depicted
description: ATHENS, March 9 The Greek officers accused of plotting against the Government were fearful and frustrated men, worried about their country and their careers, confused by new values and ideas, ready to use violence to get their way.

title: Lieutenant, Musical With Something Worth Singing
description: The massacre at My Lai was one of the saddest, indeed one of the most horrendous, episodes in American history, not only for what happened but also for the implications of those happenings. It is not, one would have imagined, a very viable subject for a Broadway musical. Yet The Lieutenant, which opened at the Lyceum Theater yesterday, has a passion and vitality not often found in musicals these days. It is also, and this may be even rarer, a musical with something to say worth saying, or, if you prefer, something to sing about worth singing.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: A musical variety program antitled Andre Watts Makes Music will be presented at Avery Fisher Hall on April 9 for the benefit of the New York Public Library's Music Division at Lincoln Center. Tickets, from $10 to $50, are now on sale.

title: DEBUT IN PURITANI BY ARLENE RANDAZZO
description: Beverly Sills and Patricia Brooks are hard acts to follow, so Arlene Randazzo was at something of a comparative disadvantage Saturday night, when she succeeded these first ladies of the City Opera as the heroine of Bellini's I Puritani. Nonetneless, the soprano gave a generally satisfying performance in her first Elvira with the company, and one may logically expect even better things in the future as she settles more securely into her characterization.

title: Seton Hall Is Victor In Track
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 9When it happened, Coach John Moon couldn't believe it his three Seton Hall quartermilers were running against themselves in a section of the 440yard dash final.

title: City U. OutofCity Hiring Held Biased Against Jews
description: Quiet efforts by the City University to diversify its faculty by hiring fewer New Yorkers have raised the concern of the American Jewish Congress, a City Council member and others who are disturbed by the policy's effects on New Yorktrained academicians, particularly Jews.

title: Bridge
description: The semifinal stage of the New York and Long Island Grand National team championship began at the New York Hilton Hotel here yesterday with three of the four topranked teams still in contention. The topseeded team of Michael Becker, Gene Neiger, Tom Smith and Steve Altman were opposed in one semifinal by the fourthseeded quintet of Dorothy and Alan Truscott, Ronald Blau, Martin Ginsberg and Andy Gabrilovich.

title: Aides Say Robert Kennedy Told of C.I.A. Castro Plot
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Two former key aides to the late Robert F. Kennedy say that he told them in 1967 that agents of the Central Intelligence Agency had contracted with the Mafia in an aborted plot to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba before the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.

title: Suspect Is Charged In a Brooklyn Fire That Injured Four
description: A 28yearold Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with arson and attempted murder for allegedly starting a fire Saturday night in a twostory frame dwelling in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn in which four persons were critically injured.

title: Enchanted Evening for Joshua Logan
description: As director, coauthor and producer, Joshua Logan has had a creative hand in 29 Broadway plays and musicals (including Mister Roberts, South Pacific and Picnic) and 10 films (including Camelot and Paint Your Wagon). One of his least heralded contributions to the American theater is Minnehaha, a silly, crazy comedy song that he wrote for the 1930 Triangle Club show when he was an undergraduate at Princeton University.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 9 (AP)Irina Moiseeva and Andrei Minenkov, in a consistently expressive display of free dancing, captured the third gold medal for the Soviet Union last night at the world figure skating championships by winning the dance.

title: Costa Rican Link
description: MEXICO CITY, March 9 (UPI) Jose Figueres, former President of Costa Rica, said in a televised interview broadcast today that he worked for the C.I.A. in 20,000 ways since it was founded. He said he believed other LatinAmerican Presidents had also done so but did not mention any names.

title: Johns Hopkins Triumphs
description: BUFFALO, March 9 (UPI) Johns Hopkins University won the team championship of the 25th annual North Atlantic intercollegiate fencing competition yesterday, beating Penn State, 5554.

title: KISSINGER TAKES CAIRO PROPOSALS TO THE ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, March 9Secretary of State Kissinger brought Egypt's ideas on achieving a new Sinai agreement to Israel's leaders tonight. But Mr. Kissinger apparently failed during a stopover in Damascus, Syria, to persuade President. Hafez alAssad to drop his opposition to EgyptianIsraeli negotiations.

title: FUNDS TO PROTECT NIXON HOME REFUSED
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 9 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has rejected a request for $117,000 by the city of San Clemente for Federal safe streets assistance to protect the home of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Gisbert Takes Final
description: SHREVEPORT, La., March 9 (UPI)Secondseeded Juan Gisbert of Spain downed Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 63, 57, 61, in the final of the Shreveport Independent Players Association tennis tournament today.

title: Reds in Portugal Accused in Fatal Clash
description: LISBON, March 9The Popular Democratic party, Portugal's major centrist force, accused the Communists today of having encouraged and participated in an attack Friday night that resulted in one and possibly two deaths and injuries to 26 people.

title: MRS. A. W. WALLANDER
description: Berniece Boyd Wallender, wife of Arthur W. Wallander, Police Commissioner from 1945 to 1949 and later Director of Civil Defense, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue. Surviving, besides her husband, are a son, Arthur W. Wallander Jr.; two daughters, Rosalind Renouard and Barbara Spencer; a sister, Ruth McFaddin, and five grandchildren.

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI, March 9  When Wes and Rick Ferrell were the battery for the Red Sox they got on like brothers except for one game against Detroit. Wes wanted to throw his changeup curve and kept shaking off Rick's signs until Rick, exasperated, walked out front of the batter and said: Throw any damn thing you please. You can't fool me no way.

title: The Dilemma of the Republicans
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 For any minority party, the pressing question is always, How do we assemble a majority? It has vexed the Republicans since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt, occasionally producing bitter battles between the conservative purists and the basebroadeners (Taft vs. Eisenhower in 1952, Goldwater vs. Rockefeller in 1964).

title: Kay Weinstock Becomes Bride
description: Kay Frances Weinstock, assistant to the art director of Simon & Schuster, Inc., was married yesterday afternoon to Allen Carl Sabinson, administrator for NBC's audience services department.

title: Personal Finance: Municipal Bonds
description: The recent default by New York State's Urban Development Corporation on payment of $100million worth of bondanticipation notes has focused attention on the entire category of municipal bonds.

title: HUMPHREY GRIM ON CAMBODIA AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he had been shown official telegrams that give little or no encouragement to any solution in Cambodia on the basis of further military assistance from the United States.

title: Meanwhile, at RollsRoyce, Luxury Prevails
description: LONDON, March 9Just as General Motors and other automobile companies around the world are trying to make cars that cost less and are cheaper to run, RollsRoyce has introduced the most expensive vehicle in its history.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for Week follows:

title: Carey Plan Called Peril to 35c Fare
description: The Carey administration is proposing an aid program for mass transit that State Transportation Department officials say will probably be too small to hold the line on subway, bus and rail fares after Jan. 1, 1976.

title: Smothering a Fire Code
description: Only by the greatest good fortune were no lives lost in the devastating series of New York Telephone Company fires and the recent blaze in the World Trade Center. Property damage and interruption of the city's vital life processes were bad enough, but both fires point up the critical need for the newly revised fire code.

title: Virdon and Weaver in Spotlight as Yankees Down Orioles
Ellen Rodman, Buyer, Wed to Russell White
description: Ellen Joy Rodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Rodman, was married yesterday afternoon to Russell White, son of. Mr. and Mrs. William G. White., Both families live in New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Black Studies Feud Erupts at Harvard
description: Longsimmering dissension at Harvard University over the state of its sixyearold AfroAmerican Studies Department erupted into the open yesterday.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Originals are rare in fashion, as in any other creative field. Jonathan Hitchcock is an original. He works in an obscure loft on Sixth Avenue that is off off Seventh Avenue and he turns out clothes that can be upsetting to women who only buy things they can toss in the washing machine.

title: Motorcycle Classic Won By Romero
description: DAYTONA, Fla., March (AP)Gene Romero won the Daytona Classic, one of the world's biggest motorcycle races, today, but acknowledged that the star of the show was an 18yearold unknown from Venezuela.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 10. 1975

title: LARRY ALPERT DIES; ACTOR, COMEDIAN
description: Larry Alpert, comedian and actor, died of a heart attack yesterday in Ellenville, N. Y. He was 56 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Toy Spaniel Is Upstaged By TV Star
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 9The English toy spaniel is the rarest of the toy breeds in the United States. But for the judging yesterday at the Saw Mill River Kennel Club's 35th show at the Westchester County Center it drew one of the biggest crowds, with spectators five deep at ringside.

title: Semiconductor Group Is Still Profitable
description: Even though the current recession is the worst the multimilliondollar semiconductor industry has witnessed, most companies in this field are making money, though far less than they have made in good years.

title: Stardust Mel Is Victor at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March (AP)Stardust Mel, the favorite, won the 38th running of the $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap today, but had to survive a steward's inquiry after a torrid duel through the stretch with a long shot, Out of the East.

title: 2d Business Group In U.S. Offers Plan To Aid Pan Am Air
description: A second American business group Is pushing a plan allegedly designed to overcome Pan American World Airways' severe economic difficulties and to short circuit a tentative agreement whereby the Iranian Government would effect the financial rescue.

title: In Ontario, They Come and Go Talking of Michelangelo
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, March 9  How does one celebrate the 500th anniversary of the birth of an immortal like Michelangelo?

title: FED SEES LIMITS TO RATES DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Although the Federal Reserve Board reduced its discount rate last week and apparently lowered slightly once again its target for the key Federal funds market interest rate, its high officials are warning that there is a limit to how much the central bank can and should force down shortterm interest rates.

title: BRENDEL PIANIST, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Alfred Brendel, who yesterday afternoon gave the first of three Carnegie Hall recitals devoted to Schubert, Beethoven and Mozart, has been one of the world's more successful artists for some years. The Austrian pianist's lightfingered accuracy, his lucidity of thought and his grasp of musical structure all combine to make his performancesparticularly his recorded performancesconsistently impressive.

title: Sketches of Candidates for Election as Regent
description: Deputy Borough President of the Bronx since 1972 . . . product of New York City public school system . . . 33 years old . . . lawyer . . . Doctor of Jurisprudence degree from Yale Law School . . . . Former president of South Bronx Community Housing Corporation and deputy director and counsel, Bronx Model Cities program . . Member of Cardinal Cooke's Health and Hospitals Task Force . . . Vice Chairman of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund and member of board of ASPIRA . . . Member of commission for juvenile justice standards of American Bar Association and Institute for Judicial Administration.

title: AID FOR UTILITIES IS WEIGHED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 9We are all slaves of Wall Street, Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, said halfseriously to public utility regulators from four other states.

title: Cleaver, Reportedly Seeks Return to U.S. From Paris
description: Eldridge Cleaver, downandout in Paris, wants to come home to California where people have the room to, be human, Newsweek magazine reported yesterday.

title: Carey Plan Called Peril to 35c Fare
description: The Carey administration is proposing an aid program for mass transit that State Transportation Department officials say will probably be too small to hold the line on subway, bus and rail fares after Jan. 1, 1976.

title: MiniFestival Schubert Is a Cameo
description: The fiveconcert MiniFestival Around Schubert presented by the New York Philharmonic in association with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center ended Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Ravel's Valses nobles et sentimentales and Schubert's Symphony No. 9 were performed by the orchestra and Jorge Bolet played a group of piano solos by Vorisek, Schubert and Liszt.

title: Bonn Opposition Wins a State Election
description: BONN, March 9West Germany's Christian Demhcratic Union continued to make inroads against Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats, today with a victory in a state election in RhinelandPalatinate.

title: C.I.A. Reportedly Sold Airline To Front at Less Than Value
description: MIAMI, March 9, (AP)The Central Intelligence Agency sold a Miamibased air cargo company, with equity of $4.2million, for $2.1 million to an aviation executive who had fronted for the agency's ownership of the company, The Miami Herald reported in its Monday editions.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, March 10

title: Plan for Queens Track Dropped
description: The 15month study to determine whether to put a race track and football stadium on a platform atop the Sunnyside railroad yards in Queens had its expected conclusion yesterday: No. At least, no, if the city wants to save about a billion dollars.

title: Egypt and Israel
description: Peace is not at hand between Israel and Egypt, but an agreement to reduce the danger of war between these two longtime belligerents is clearly within reach.

title: Flyers Beat Wings, 85, Increase Lead
Cut in Discount Rate Is a Link In Declining Worldwide Trend
description: When the Federal Reserve Board reduced the discount rate late Friday, it was one more sign of a declining pattern of interest rates around the world, The recession, which has affected most countries, plays a key role in bringing lower borrowing costs because the demand for money has slowed. The pattern is not precise on a nationtonation basis, but the trend is unmistakable.

title: Labor Leaders Appear to Ignore Meany's Disengagement From Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, March 9George Meany's trumpeted disengagement of the A.F.L.C.I.O. from Democratic politics appears now to have been an essentially personal statement, and perhaps not a wholehearted statement at that. The first to ignore him, in any case, have been union presidents within the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, and notably some old Meany allies from the building trades. They are leaning openly toward endorsement of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976the same Senator Jackson whom Mr. Meany has been calling a doublecrosser on trade legislation.

title: RUSSELL PRESENTS HIS EPISODIC JAZZ
description: George Russell, a jazz composer who teaches at the New England Conservatory of Music, assembled an orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night that included three precussionists, three keyboard instruments (acoustic piano, electric piano, organ), two basses (acoustic and electric), a dozen wind instruments and two simulitaneously functioning conductors. They performed two long compositions by Mr. RussellLiving Time (50 minutes) and Electronic Sonata for Souls Loved by Nature (1 hour, 5 minutes)as part of the New York Jazz Repertory Company's series of concerts.

title: Layoffs Reflected In Bar's Business
description: CLIFTON  Unemployment statistics convert quickly into reality at Gus's Tavern here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Advertising
description: One effect the recession is having on the supermarket industry is that more and more of the packagedgoods manufacturers are insisting on accountability from the chains for trade deals.

title: Savings Banks Asked to Place 66% of Mortgages Within State
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein proposed yesterday that the state's savings banks he required to put twothirds of future mortgage loans into properties within the state, compared with the present 52.5 per cent, or be taxed more heavily on outofstate income.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The special telephone numbers established by state agencies to receive consumer complaints and provide information for the elderly have prompted an active response since they were installed a month ago.

title: Oil Pipeline Work Starts; 10,000 on Job in Alaska
description: SHEEP CREEK CAMP, Alaska, March 9The Alaskan oil pipeline has been begun.

title: IRAQIS REPORTED ATTACKING KURDS
description: PARIS, March 9Iraq has launched an offensive against the rebellious Kurds, according to reports from official Middle East sources received here.

title: Resort Business Booming Despite Economic Slump
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Maybe it's whistling past the graveyard, but in these days of deep recession millions of Americans have been indulging themselves at the nation's winter playgrounds as if there were no tomorrow.

title: Chile's Agriculture Makes a Fast Cornebac
description: TALCA, ChileOn either side of the PanAmerican Highway as it stretches south from Santiago the farmland is being worked with an intensity unseen in recent years.

title: Books of The Times
description: Through the flower is the autobiographymanifesto of a woman artist, anda don't know I guess it may prove inspirational to certain women, and even. certain men. As an autobiography, it traces the development of the author from youth to maturityfrom Judy Gerowitz, the bright, troubled child who felt herself destined to be different, to Judy Chicago, a widely recognized West Coast artist and sculptor, and a leader of the womanartist's liberation movement. It tells how she was raised in Chicago by her liberal parents: how she admired her father and wanted to be like him. (Once, when she was taking a bath with him, she pointed to his penis and said, When I grow up, I'm going to have one of those.  To which her father replied, Yes, if you're a good girl, you'll have one of, those. If you're a bad girl you'll have a lot of them. Thinking about this story, I realized that it was not that I wanted to be a boy, but rather, that I wanted to be a person like my father. It was if long time before I was to realize that one's sex was supposed to determine one's personality, interests, and options.

title: Sadat Sets Briefing
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 9President Sadat is to meet with Egypt's leading politicians and journalists tomorrow to brief them on his talks with Secretarn of State Kissinger.

title: Regents Candidates Face Legislators
description: The members of the Educadon and Higher Education Committees of both houses of the State Legislature will meet together today in an unusual public session in Albany to question the six candidates who were nominated last week to fill the three vacancies on the 15member Board of Regents, the state's highest education policymaking body.

title: FRANCE IS SEEKING WIDE AFRICA BLOC
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, March 9  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing said, last night that he looked forward to the emergence of a new grouping of African countriesincluding former French, Belgian and Portuguese colonieswithin a year or two.

title: 4 Men and Woman Rob 2 Bars In Brooklyn, Terrorizing Patrons
description: Four men and a woman were being sought by Brooklyn detectives yesterday after the holdups of two bars on Nostrand Avenue within 24 hours in which one man was shot and critically wounded, two women were sexually attacked and more than $2,000 in cash and jewelry were stolen.

title: ANTIOCH SETTLES DISPUTE ON HEAD
description: The trustees of Antioch College reached a compromise here yesterday and ended a twoyear controversy over the tenure of Dr. James P. Dixon Jr. as president of the innovative but financially troubled school.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Enactment of the Internetional Trade Act of 1974 in the closing hours of the 93d Congress last Dec. 20 settled, officially at least, one major issue: the basic trade policy of the United States for the next five years.

title: The Meaning of Grief
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. When someone suffers a severe personal loss, they experience grief. All the purposes attached to the lost relationship seem to have become unrealizable. The bereaved are at first numbed and unbelieving, then despairing angry, guilty, sleepless, as they restlessly seek release from their distress.

title: Slump in Industrial Nations Worsening
description: PARIS, March 9 Economic activity in the major industrialized countries is falling more sharply than experts thought likely four months ago, with an absolute decline now being projected for this year, a meeting of economic officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development concluded late last week.

title: China Calls on U.S. to End Support of Lon Nol at Once
description: PEKING, March 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  An article in Jenmin Jih Pao today called on the United States to end its support of Marshal Lon Nol's regime in Cambodia at once.

title: Jersey's Economic Illness Called Chronic by Analysts
description: New Jersey is taking a much worse beating in the recession than the rest of the country, and economists fear that when everyone else recovers, the state will still be on the ropes.

title: 6 DEMOCRATS HERE CRITICAL OF C.I.A.
description: Six Democratic Representatives attracted an audience of 800 on the East Side yesterday for a town meeting on the controversy over the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: KISSINGER TAKES CAIRO PROPOSALS TO THE ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, March 9 Secretary of State Kissinger brought Egypt's ideas on achieving a new Sinai agreement to Israel's leaders tonight. But Mr. Kissinger apparently failed during a stopover in Damascus, Syria, to persuade President Hafez alAssad to drop his opposition to EgyptianIsraeli negotiations.

title: VIETNAMESE REDS PRESS OFFENSIVE IN HIGHLANDS AREA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 10North Vietnamese troops today launched attacks around Ban Me Thuot, a placid Central Highlands provincial capital, assaulting its two airfields, an ammunition dump and other positions, the Saigon command said.

title: RUMORS OF FLIGHT BELIED BY LON NOL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 9Cambodia's President, Marshal Lon Nol, in an apparent effort to kill spreading rumors that he had fled the country, invited seven foreign newsmen to his villa early this morning to watch him walk in his garden.

title: Police Unable to Tie Explosives To Puerto Rican Nationalists
description: Detectives investigating the discovery of 75 pounds of high explosives Saturday night on the Lower East Side said last night that they had been unable to link the cache to the radical group of Puerto Rican nationalists that claimed responsibility for recent bombing in Manhattan.

title: Foyt, 40, 500Mile Winner
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 9 Johnny Rutherford said it best before the raindelayed start of the California 500 today.

title: Recession Leads to New Cadre of Cabbies
description: Classified ads like the one above appear daily in the papers because many drivers make a big decision after a few months: they have had enough of holdups (or fear), of the fierce competition during the very long hours, and of too many passengers who trick them out of tips or fares or both.

title: State Police Get New Radar System to Catch Speeders
description: FISHKILL, N. Y., March 9State Trooper Brian N. Rovnak sat in his unmarked patrol car on the edge of Interstate 84, just east of the Hudson River Bridge, this weekend, and watched the cars speeding by.

title: SchoolConstruction Costs Outpace Other Contracts'
description: The cost of building public schools in New York City has shot up in recent years at an even sharper pace than building costs in general.

title: Massachusetts Fire Kills 4
description: RANDOLPH, Mass., March 9 (AP)Four young men and women ranging in age from 17 to 24 years old were killed today when fire swept through a small house situated off a dirt road. The victims were identified as Joan Woods, 17; Susan Collins, 18; Anthony De Paolo, 22, and George Brown Jr., 24, all of Randolph.

title: What's With Boston?
description: BOSTON  Strolling down State Street toward the waterfront the other evening, I was accosted by a man in Colonial dress, out of breath, obviously distressed.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge has told the United States Government not to pay the Bon Vivant Company for the storage of 510,000 cans of soup suspected of botulism taint because the company applied too late for reimbursement. The ruling by Judge Lawrence A. Whipple will be filed today in United States District Court in Newark. The action denied Bon Vivant the right to submit a $52,000 storage bill to the Government.

title: Laver Beats Ashe, Aussies Take Cup
description: HARTFORD, March 9 With Rod Laver continuing his amazing mastery over Arthur Ashe today, Australia was able to continue its notsoamazing dominance over the United States in tennis by taking its fifth Aetna World Cup in six years, 4 matches to 3. Laver demolished Ashe, 62, 76, for his 19th victory in 21 meetings.

title: College, School Results
IRAQIS REPORTED ATTACKING KURDS
description: PARIS, March 9Iraq has launched an offensive against the rebellious Kurds, according to reports from official Middle East sources received here.

title: Aides Say Robert Kennedy Told of C.I.A. Castro Plot
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Two former key aides to the late Robert F. Kennedy say that he told them in 1967 that agents of the Central Intelligence Agency had contracted with the Mafia in an aborted plot to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba before the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.

title: ALFRED DRISCOLL OF JERSEY IS DEAD
description: HADDONFIELD, N.J., March 9 (AP)Former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll died here today of a heart attack at his home. He was 72 years old.

title: Trevino Wins Golf By Stroke
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 9  Hale Irwin and Ben Crenshaw gave it a good try, but few golfers can spot Lee Trevino three strokes and beat him in a closing round.

title: Nothing But Shame
description: WASHINGTON, March 9For the last dozen years, through assassinations and endless wars and Watergate, some of us have been telling the skeptics that there is an American system worth preserving. In the end, we said, democracy will work. The men of violence, the totalitarians, the anarchists are all wrong. Reject their evil counsel, have faith.

title: Resort Business Booming Despite Economic Slump
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Maybe it's whistling past the graveyard, but in these days of deep recession millions of Americans have been indulging themselves at the nation's whiter playgrounds as if there were no tomorrow.

title: Lynne Hochheiser Wed to Alfred Groff
description: Lynne Susan Hochheiser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Hochheiser of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Alfred Clyde Groff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald N. Groff of Pine City, N.Y.

title: DUNNINGER DIES; MAGICIAN WAS 82
description: Joseph Dunninger, who mystified millions as a magician and mindreader for more than half a century, died yesterday of Parkinson's disease at his home in Cliffside Park, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: F.T.C. Criticizes Warning On Cigarettes as Use Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Americans smoked more cigarettes than ever before last year, a record 602.2 billion, and the Federal Trade Commission suggests that the warning language on cigarette packages is not a strong enough deterrent.

title: Drake's California Voyage Reenacted
description: SAN FRANCISCO March 9  After a sixmonth journey from Plymouth, England, a 102footlong reproduction of Sir Francis Drake's ship, the Golden Hind, anchored off San Francisco Harbor today, after having been almost torn apart in a storm off the California coast.

title: Patients Battle to Save Condemned L.I. Infirmary
description: YAPHANK, L. I.  Aloise Voska, who is 104 years old, struggled to find words. Then, in a startlingly strong voice, she said: I want to stay here. This is my home.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We have known for years that one of the most popular and talked about recipes ever to appear in The New York Times was printed in the July 28, 1966 issue. The headline stated Ann Seranne's Recipe for a Perfect Roast Put It in the Oven and Relax.

title: Screen: Israeli Comedy:'Daughters, Daughters!' Falls Short of Style
description: "Daughters, Daughters!" is an Israeli comedy that becomes bleak when it means to be bittersweet and sentimental when it means to be robust. I suspect the reason it keeps falling short is that its central character is a man whose self-absorption is more cruel than comic.Sabbetay Alfandari (Shai K. Ophir) is a rich, middle-aged businessman, a tyrant around the house, a man obsessed by the fact that he has eight daughters and no sons. He's terrible to his wife, to his daughters, to his young mistress. In a last desperate effort to get a male heir he resorts to magic and succeeds in making both his wife and his mistress even more miserable."Daughters, Daughters!," the official Israeli entry at the 1974 Cannes Film Festival, treats its male chauvinist pig too seriously to allow us laughs at his expense. We are, instead, appalled, mostly because Mr. Ophir is an actor of such heaviness that he never seems to be kidding, nor does his plight seem especially important in the context of the real-life Israel we see around him.Like "the House on Chelouche Street," which was also directed by Menahem Golan, "Daughters, Daughters!" is a film that fails to find a distinctive tragic comic style. What charm it has depends entirely on the performances, particularly on that of Zaharira Harifal, a big, handsome, expansive actress who transforms the wife into a woman of real comic pathos."Daughters, Daughters!" opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: Islanders Toppled by Seals, 42
description: OAKLAND, March 9A golden opportunity slipped away from the New York Islanders tonight when they lost to the California Golden Seals, 42, in what might have been the last game they would play here. Tomorrow the National Hockey League may decide to move the Seals' franchise to Denver next year.

title: George Stevens, Film Director, Dies
description: LANCASTER, Calif., March 9 (AP)  George Stevens, director of A Place in the Sun, Shane, Giant and other popular movies, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, at a hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: Ogilvy Yields International Posts
description: David Ogilvy, the 63yearold advertising great, has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather International, which he founded, but he remains a board member and creative head.

title: HAROLD S. GRAHAM
description: Harold S. Graham, chairman of the board of John H. Graham & Co., Inc., of Oradell, N. J., hardware manufacturers representatives, died Saturday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: ISRAELI AIDE HINTS AT EASED STANCE
description: JERUSALEM, March 9  A senior Israeli official connected with the talks with Secretary of State Kissinger suggested today that Israel's frequently reiterated insistence on an Egyptian declaration of nonBelligerence was an objective that might not be realized in the present round of talks and indicated that Israel would settle for something less.

title: Moscow Charges Chinese Seek Undercover Deal With Chiang
description: MOSCOW, March 9A Soviet commentator said today that Peking hoped to make an undercover deal with the Nationalists under which Chiang Kaishek would become the provincial chief of Taiwan for life.

title: William Hrabrick, 55, Dies; Headed Equipment Concern
description: William J. Hrabrick, president of Creative Marketers, a foodrelated equipment concern, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 300 East 40th Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Canadiens Top Rangers Easily
description: Making the puck dance, as Montreal teams have done for half a century, the Canadiens completely dominated the Rangers yesterday in a 53 victory.

title: New Books
description: Jayne Mansfield and the American Fifties by Martha, Saxton (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95).

title: Miss Moore Beaten
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 9Birgitta Warbach of Syracuse, a former Finnish star, won the fifth women's singles event in the Festival of Tournaments at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today by beating Ann Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn., 62, 62, in the final.

title: Cambodian War Seen in Its Final Phase As Rebels Slowly Strangle Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 9After five years of a war in which the Communistled forces have methodically tried to capture Phnom Penh by slow strangulation, this surrounded capital is finally beginning to gasp for breath.

title: British Communist Resigns
description: LONDON, March 9 (Reuters) John Gollan, the 63yearofd general secretary of the British Communist party, announced his resignation today. He has led Britain's Communists, who claim a membership of 30,000, since 1956. He will be succeeded by Gordan McLennan.

title: JAMES P. PATTERSON
description: James P. Patterson, who was vice president of Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and its successor concern, American Oil Company, died yesterday in the Morristown (N. J.) Rehabilitation Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Madison, N. J.

title: Kissinger Off to Ankara For Cyprus Talks Today
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 9 Secretary of State Kissinger announced today that he would interrupt his EgyptianIsraeli diplomacy tomorrow to fly from Israel to Ankara for unexpected talks with key Turkish leaders on the Cyprus situation.

title: Events Today
description: THE ROCKY HORROR SHOW, cabaret theater, written by Richard O'Brien; direefed by Jim Sherman; starring Tim Curry; at the Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, 7.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1975
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Jerusalem yesterday and presented Egypt's latest proposals on a new Sinai agreement to Israel's leaders, but he apparently failed during a stopover in Damascus to persuade President Hafez alAssad of Syria to drop his opposition to EgyptianIsraeli negotiations. While in Jerusalem, Mr. Kissinger expects to receive Israeli proposals that he can bring hack to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: $100Million Rise Seen In City's Building Bids
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that, on the basis of current projections, the city would award about $100million more in construction contracts over the current fiscal year than it did the year before.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHANGING SCENE The section of East Greenwich Village that was once a thriving Slavic neighborhood of shops, offices and residences is rather curiously bypassed in all the talk and print about modern inroads con the Village that was. More picturesque sections of the downtown area get more attention. Tonight at 6:30, Yuri Kapralov, the East Village artist and author, will present a free program spotlighting his home neighborhood at the Tompkins Square Regional Branch Library, 331 East 10th Street (between Avenues A and B).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Klein Bride Of David Langsam
description: Sandra M. Klein, senior psychiatric social work supervisor at the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center, was married yesterday morning to David E. Langsam, an assistant treasurer in the international department of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Rabbi Shael Siegel performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Mrs. Grasso Is Frustrated in Filling Jobs
description: HARTFORD, March 9 The climate in the country has changed, said Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut, reflecting on the frustrations she has felt and the political pressures she has endured in filling the top positions in her government.

title: MUSIC BY WOMEN GIVEN IN FESTIVAL
description: A concert of women's music closed the first weekend of the International Women's Arts Festival yesterday afternoon at International House at 500 Riverside Drive, and proved a long (over three, hours) but most rewarding, affair.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The blue jean has come a long way since Levi Strauss made the original for a miner during the California Gold Rush. It's been bleached, recycled, embroidered, painted, elevated to high fashion and accepted the world over as uniform attire for teenagers.

title: Medical Students Elect
description: CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) A woman medical student from Case Western Reserve Medical School in Cleveland was elected president of the American Medical Students Association at its convention this weekend in Chicago. Laurie Cappa, 33 years old, a thirdyear student, is the first woman to head the 50,000 member association, an independent student group with chapters at 110 medical schools.

title: Promises on Food
description: The Ford Administration's commitment to make increased food aid available to meet this year's severe crop shortages had two stages. The firstpledged in Januarywas to allot enough money to the program to make a meaningful amount of aid available; the second was to do the actual work necessary to get the food to the countries in need.

title: MODEL LAW GRANT AIMS AT CORRUPTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)  The Justice Department announced today that it has granted the American Bar Association $328,000 to develop a model law to reduce corruption in Government purchasing.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplamentary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Purchasing Managers Increase Pace of Inventory Liquidation
description: Inventory liquidation of materials and supplies remains a major objective of purchasing managers, according to the February report of the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc. released over the weekend. Fully 51 per cent of the managers surveyed said they were liquidating stocks, compared with 45 per cent a month earlier.

title: JOHN GOLDMARK, 69, LED MANNES COLLEGE
description: John Goldmark, president of the Mannes College of Music since 1972, died Saturday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 171 East 74th Street and in Taos N. M.

title: In Memoriam
description: CANTORNaomi Freedman. How Intolerably sad that you died before we understood we were sisters. Your daughter Aviva.

title: Rockefeller Supporters Fear Backlash From NursingHome and U.D.C. Crises
description: New York Republican supporters of Vice President Rockefeller are privately concerned that the nursinghome scandal and the Urban Development Corporation fiscal crisis could haunt Mr. Rockefeller's national political career.

title: Treasurable Elly Ameling
description: Elly Ameling's recital at Hunter College on Saturday night was almost perfect from start to finish. Few singers today can begin to rival her command of the song literature or the ease and spontaneity with which she penetrates the essence of both words and music.

title: An Art From Japan Becomes an American Hobby
description: The patients were carried gently, even lovingly, into the clinicin cardboard boxes, shopping bags and arms. They were dwarf trees or bonsai, and their sometimes proud and often worried owners were bringing them for consultation to a sunny upstairs room of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden administration building. There they would be examined by Frank M. Okamura, a specialist in the horticultural art that was transplanted here from Japan by American G.I.'s.

title: NEW DISPUTE STIRS ROME COMMUNISTS
description: ROME, March 9The Italian Communist party is embroiled in a dispute over how much the architect of its present power, Palmiro Togliatti, knew about the terror during Stalin's rule in the Soviet Union.

title: HILTON HOTELS IN BID FOR ITS OWN STOCK
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation announced over the weekend that it would make a cash tender offer to its shareholders for 1 million common shares at $25 each. The offer will be mailed tomorrow and is set to expire on March 31.

title: SCHLESINGER WARNS ON ARMS CUTBACKS
description: Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has said that the United States can expect a very serious setback in the years ahead if the present trend in military cutbacks continues.

title: TWO U.S. WARSHIPS SAIL INTO BLACK SEA
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 9 (AP)Two United States warships crossed the Turkish straits today and sailed into the Black Sea on a showtheflag mission in international waters disputed by the Soviet Union, port sources said.

title: VIETNAMESE REDS PRESS OFFENSIVE IN HIGHLANDS AREA
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, Monday, March 10  North Vietnamese troops launched ground attacks early today against the usually placid central Highlands provincial capital of Ban Me Thuot, assaulting its two airfields, an ammunition dump and other positions, the Saigon command said.

title: Hanoi's Military Choices: Press Local Battles, or Open a Large Offensive
description: The North Vietnamese are regarded by United States intelligence analysts as holding the strategic and tactical initiafive throughout the Southeast Asian theater of war. But the analysts believe that Hanoi's high command has not yet chosen from among several inviting military options open in Cambodia and South Vietnam.

title: Klammer Gains Cup Downhill Victory
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 9  Streaking down the 10,400foot high Rendezvoius Mountain at an average speed of more than a mile a minute, Franz Klaminer of Austria the king of the downhillers, scored an impresive World Cup triumph today.

title: Solid and Businesslike
description: George Stevens strove for and achieved a remarkably high average of artistic and technical successes. Along with the films of such directors as the late John Ford, William Wyler, Frank Capra and Fred Zinnemann, his work epitomized Hollywood in its golden days.

title: Roberta Kramer, Teacher, Marries
description: Roberta Diane Kramer, a teacher in the city's school system, and Dr. Michael Sigall, an assistant professor of political science at Wagner College, Grymes Hill, S.I., were married yesterday evening at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: Mets Halt Card Bid, Win, 54
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9Spring training? Lou Brock reflected today with a touch of weariness. It feels like the Fourth of July already.

title: The 200 Years
description: The American bicentennial celebration, officially designated by Congress to begin this month, remains adrift in an uncertainty of purpose. There could be no better time for Americans to search their hearts and minds, to look back to their country's beginnings and to assess both the triumphs and the failures of what is, in the long view of history, still only a brief and vulnerable experiment.

title: Medical Professor Treats Mrs. Ford For Neck Ailment
description: WASHINGTON March 9 (UPI)  Betty Ford suffering from a severe flareup of a chronic osteoarthritic condition, was treated at the White House today by a rheumatology specialist.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1975

title: Oil Pipeline Work Starts; 10,000 on Job in Alaska
description: SHEEP CREEK CAMP, Alaska, March 9The Alaskan oil pipeline has been begun.

title: Jersey's Economic Illness Called Chronic by Analysts
description: New Jersey is taking a much worse beating in the recession than the rest of the country, and economists fear that when everyone else recovers, the state will still be on the ropes.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output Off
description: CARACAS, March 9 (UPI)Venezuelan oil production has fallen to its lowest level since 1958 and has dropped 18.7 per cent in one year, mines ministry spokesmen reported today. Production this week averaged 2,642,558 barrels per day, down 608,850 barrels from the level for the same period last year, the spokesman said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Members of the New York City Housing Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have voted by 783 to 243 to work five days without pay in the next 16 months to save the jobs of 45 officers who had received layoff notices from the city for budgetary reasons. The free work will enable the Housing Authority budget to be reduced as requested by Mayor Beame. The result of the vote was announced yesterday by Joseph L. Balzano, president of the union, at its headquarters, 299 Broadway, where the mail ballots were counted.

title: C.I.A. Involvement Is Alleged in Plots To Kill 3 Dictators
description: Time magazine reported yesterday that it had been told by credible sources that the Central Intelligence Agency had been involved in assassination plots against the Caribbean leaders Fidel Castro, Rafael L. Trujillo and Francois Duvalier.

title: North Carolina State Snubs N.I.T.
description: Happiness turned to disappointment within a few hours yesterday for the N.I.T. Selection Committee.

title: G.A.O. Says F.A.A. Ignores Safety Recommendations
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)The Federal Aviation Administration has ignored many recommendations by a Government air safety board, delayed action on others and lost the files on some, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Inmate at Yardville Flees, Apparently Over a Fence
description: BORDENTOWN, March 10 (UPI)An inmate at the Yardville Correctional Institution escaped today, apparently by climbing over a fence, prison authorities said.

title: BANK AIDE ADMITS TAKING $392,000
description: A 26yearold bank employe who was authorized to issue mortgage loans of up to $100,000 at one of New Jersey's largest banks conceded yesterday in United States District Court in Newark that he had embezzled $392,000 to pay gambling debts.

title: Chess Title Play in Peril
description: AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 10 (Reuters) Only a miracle can save the world chess championship match between Bobby Fischer, the titleholder, and Anatoly Karpov, the Soviet challenger, Max Euwe, president of the Internatinal Chess Federation, said today.

title: $54MILLION NOTES FOR HOUSING SOLD
description: The New Jersey Housing Finance Agency, one of three New Jersey agencies whose financial obligations are guaranteed by a legislative moral pledge, sold $54million worth of notes yesterday at higher rates of interest than it had hoped to get.

title: Ronan Cool to Financing Transit Running at a Loss
description: JERSEY CITY, March 10Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said today he had little confidence in the ability and the desirability of the bistate agency's financing any further mass  transit projects that promised to produce operating decifits.

title: Bribery Defendant In Fort Lee Case To Testify for State
description: TRENTON, March 10A defendant charged with complicity in a $1.6million bribery attempt to win approval for construction of a $250million commercial plaza in Fort Lee agreed here today to testify for the state against his business associates, who are named in the indictment as coconspirators.

title: 2 Escaped Mental Patients Sought in Bergen Breakin
description: PARAMUS, March 10 (AP)Bergen County authorities were searching today for two teenagers who escaped from a county mental hospital and terrorized a widow and her daughter here yesterday.

title: Ideology Dispute Shakes Black Journal
description: The Black Scholar, which has provided a forum for the growing ideological debate among blacks over MarxismLeninism and nationalism, has become enmeshed in the conflict.

title: Critics of N.I.T. Under Attack
description: Lou Carnesecca, St. John's basketball coach, leveled an uncharacteristically strong attack yesterday against players and coaches who have referred to the National Invitation Tournament as a loser's tournament and minor leagues.

title: Mrs. Ford Feeling Better
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Betty Ford, troubled by recurring arthritis that has caused neck and back pains, had to pass up two ceremonial appearances today but was reported feeling much better after weekend treatment by her doctor. Sheila Rabb Weidenfeld, press secretary to the President's wife, said that Mrs. Ford had been spending much of her time in bed the last few days but now was getting around bit.

title: New 1975 Highs/Lows
BOND PRICES DROP DESPITE FED'S CUT
description: The cloud of New York State's Urban Development Corporation hung over a moribund and nervous taxexempt market yesterday, while prices in the corporate and Govern

title: EXCELLENT SINGING BY AUGUST ANA CHOIR
description: Considering the difficulties professional groups encounter, the excellence of so many American college choruses is a continuing source of wonder. At Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night, the point was made again by the superb 70voice Augustana Choir from the Lutheranrelated Augustana College in Rock Island, Ill., which has about 2,300 students. Meticulously trained and conducted by Donald E. Morrison, the young musicians gave a difficult, unaccompanied, largely 20thcentury program, entirely from memory and virtually without flaw.

title: White U.S. Employe Is Ruled the Victim Of Employment Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)A white Federal employe has been awarded back pay and a delayed promotion after a finding that he suffered job discimination at the hands of top Labor Deprtment officials for equal employment opportunity.

title: Italians Dominant In Slalom
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 10  Italy came up with a surprise today in the World Series of skiing, but another siege of snow squalls caused the postponement of the World Cup women's downhill race.

title: Puerto Rican Deftla In a Precinct Cell Is Ruled a Suicide
description: The death of a Puerto Rican musician in a police cell last Decemberwhich touched off violence by a radical groupwas a suicide by hanging, a Manhattan grand jury found yesterday.

title: 200,000 at Work in Federal Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Cities around the nation are making steady but uneven progress implementing the $1billion public service employment program signed into law Dec. 31, 1974.

title: Waldman Conducts Concert Benefiting Jerusalem Hospital
description: The annual benefit concert at Carnegie Hall for Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem took place Sunday night, and by and large it was a pleasantly lowpressure affair. If neither the conductor, Frederic Waldman, nor the soloists, Arnold Steinhardt and Yehuda Hanani, tried to overpower the audience with sheer flash and brilliance, they still gave enjoyable accounts of themselves.

title: KATE SEREDY, WROTE BOOKS FOR CHILDREN
description: Kate Seredy, author and illustrator of popular children's books, died Friday in Middletown, N.Y. She was 78 years old and lived in Montgomery, N.Y.

title: Cavanagh Attends to Details While Beame Decides Policy
description: James A. Cavanagh he has become Jim to a lot more people than he really knows over the last yearis the man who says yes or no in Abe Beame's City Hall.

title: Bridge:
description: One of two quartets of young experts will eventually represent New York City in the zonal final of the grand national team championship, with a chance of international honors for 1976 beckoning on the horizon.

title: Migrant Chief Is Not Guilty of Assault
description: WOODBURY, March 10After deliberating less than two hours, a Gloucester County jury today found a migrant crew chief not guilty of breaking the arm of an Assemblyman and smashing his car.

title: White U:S. Employe Is Ruled the Victim Of Employment Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)A white Federal employe has been awarded back pay and a delayed promotion after a finding that he suffered job discrimination at the hands of top Labor Department officials for equal employment opportunity.

title: Ford Said to Rule Out Talk to Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)White House officials acknowledged today that an invitation for President Ford to address a group of conservative California Republicans had been declined, even though Mr. Ford plans to be in nearby Palm Springs at the time.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TREASURE COUNTER Private collections devoted to the antiquities and art of Iran are rarely sold on the market. An exception is the Lester Wolfe Collection of Persian and Near Eastern pottery and metalwork, scheduled for auction Friday afternoon at the Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, and on public view daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: SADAT ASSESSES KISSINGER'S TASK
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 10President Anwar elSadat told Egyptian officials and newspaper editors today that there was a serious chance10 to 20 per centthat Secretary of State Kissinger might fail in his current mission to the Middle East.

title: Phils Top Mets, 73; Yankees 43 Victor,
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10Tug McGraw, in the baby blue uniform of the Philadelphia Phillies, was reunited with the New York Mets today, shook hands with everybody in sight, signed autographs like a politician and announced: We're probably going to get Dick Allen in the next couple of days and we'll win the pennant.

title: H.E.W. to Give Priorities To Education Broadcasting
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that educational radio and television would be given special priorities in receiving H. E. W. grants.

title: Senators Weigh Public Hearings on Assassinations
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will make a thorough investigation of allegations about the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement in political assassinations and the inquiry could end up in public hearings, committee sources said today.

title: Exxon U.S.A. Sets Agreement
description: Exxon U.S.A. the domestic subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, a subsidiary of the Peoples Gas Company of Chicago that could lead to the sale of 20 per cent of Exxon's share of anticipated production of Prudhoe Bay gas. Exxon estimated that its reserves of pipeline quality gas in the Prudhoe Bay reservoir at 8.7 trillion cubic feet.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: Fourth Division Hartlepool 0, Exeter City 3.

title: A NEW PLANS BODY URGED FOR STATE
description: NEWARK, March 10The Governor's Commission to Evaluate the Capital Needs of New Jersey today heard a proposal to establish a planning and budget body within the Governor's office to devise and implement capital projects for the state.

title: RIGHTS AMENDMENT DEFEATED IN INDIANA
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 10 (UPI)The Indiana Senate defeated late today, 27 to 21, the proposed ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: DR. HUGH HUBBARD, A CHINA MISSIONARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The Rev. Dr. Hugh Wells Hubbard, China missionary, ornithologist and stamp authority, died here yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: I have just been doing a job of detection on the world's most famous writer of detective fiction. I have gathered quite a bit of incriminating evidence to prove that Georges Simenon no longer writes good mysteries. Like the Paris he describes in Maigret and the Loner, Mr. Simenon has changed. His books are no longer authentic, but designed for the tourist who is attracted by a famous name. Perhaps, like Parisians, the author is bored with pleasing strangers.

title: Market Place
description: It is, of course, obvious by now that the place for an investor during the 1974 bear market was on the sidelinespreferably in such socalled cash items as certificates of deposit and Treasury hills.

title: Secret Bid Related On Cambodia Talks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 10 The State Department was reported today to have turned down a proposal by the American Embassy in Phnom Penh to try to make diplomatic contacts with local Cambodian Communists last spring because such an effort might have interfered with a secret attempt to start negotiations with the former Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Blast Victim Dies in Paris
description: PARIS, March 10 (AP)  A 20yearold French airman home on leave died today of wounds suffered in a bomb explosion at the Gare de l'Est train station. Six others received minor injuries last night from the bomb hidden in a baggage locker.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's issue, The New York Times did not report on riots in Milan and the subsequent murder of the lay religious reformer Erlembald. These events took place in 1075, the year given in the dateline undo the nameplate on Page 1 ?? late editions. The Times regrets both incidents.

title: MAN GREEN DIES; AD MAN, AUTHOR
description: Alan Green, author of several books and an advertising executive in the book publishing field until his recent retirement, died yesterday in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital He was 68 years old and lived at 68 Greens Farms Road, Westport, Conn.

title: Nation's Retail Sales Rose A Scant 0.5% in February
description: The nation's retail sales in February rose onehalf of 1 per cent over January, failing to match January's 2.4 per cent advance, the Commerce Department announced in Washington yesterday.

title: Opera: A Thin and Pallid Falstaff Returns to Met
description: Falstaff, in Franco Zeffirelli's generally admired production, returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night after an absence of two seasons, this time with Cornell MacNeil as Verdi's overblown windbag. In his first Metropolitan appearance in the role, Mr. MacNeil gave what may justly be called a thin portrayal of a fat part. Although his account of the purely vocal dimensions of Falstaff was always adequate, and often richly pleasing, Mr. MacNeil did not come close to getting his arms around the character.

title: VIETNAM REDS PUT TROOPS AND TANKS IN HIGHLAND CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 11Government soldiers and North Vietnamese troops were fighting housetohouse for the second day today in the embattled provincial capital of Ban Me Thuot, the Saigon command reported.

title: House Rebuffs Ford On Billion Fund Cut
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The House rejected today President Ford's request to cut $1.2billion more from Federal programs, and angered Republican leaders said that the projected $52billion budget deficit could rise to $80billion.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 11, 1975

title: U.S. Dollar Climbs In Europe Trading; Gold Prices Decline
description: BRUSSELS, March 10 (UPI)The dollar began the week on an upward trend, on most European money markets today, having recovered from record lows at the end of last week.

title: Stage: A Flashy Rocky Horror Show
Harold Maynard, Who Devised TimeMotion Standards, Dead
description: PITTSBURGH, March 10Harold B. Maynard, an expert in management engineering and timeandmotion studies, died today. He was 72 years old and lived in Naples, Fla., and previously in Fox Chapel, a Pittsburg suburb.

title: City Ballet Plans 14 Works for Ravel Fete
description: Fourteen ballets to the music of Maurice Ravel, including 13 premieres will be presented in the last half of May at the New York State Theater during the New York City Ballet's Ravel Festival.

title: CNA Financial Narrows Its Deficit
HOUSE PANEL TRIMS FOREIGN AID FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The House Appropriations Committee today voted $3.5billion for all foreign aid programs, down $2.5billion from the initial Administration request and down $1.3billion from the Congressional authorization bill approved last January.

title: KURDISH SETBACK IN IRAQ REPORTED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10Iraqi armor and infantry units have reportedly pushed Kurdish rebels out of several militarily important mountain areas in the north since the Government offensive began there on Friday.

title: ARMY IN REBUTTAL ON BLACKS' RATIO
description: The Army rejected yesterday civilian assertions that its combat units are becoming predominantly black.

title: The Wrong Issue
description: President Ford's increasingly threatening remarks about the future of Cambodia are only serving to make a bad situation worse. If he persists in describing one Congressional vote authorizing $222 million in ammunition as the acid test of United States reliability to an ally (sic), then the genuine allies the President is presumably concerned about may regrettably come to believe it.

title: Theater: Shark at Riverside Church
description: T. J. Camp 3d's new play Shark, now running at Theater of the Riverside Church, is set in a caddy yard of a country club. The club not seen, but we hear reports of members' activities over a loudspeaker  is exclusive and elegant. In direct contrast, the yard and its practice putting green are seedy.

title: The Times Names Jenkins An Assistant News Editor
description: The appointment of Evan Jenkins as an assistant news editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor. Mr. Jenkins, who is 39 years old, had been an assistant national editor.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 10 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today it would auction off the contracts of 59 players of the World Football League champion, the Birmingham Americans. The auction is designed to recover more than $200,000 in back taxes.

title: Canadian Merrill Seeks Properties Of Drilling Plans
description: Canadian Merrill, Ltd., announced yesterday in Calgary, Alberta, that it had invited all participants in the Provident Drilling Fund Programs of 1967 to 1973 to sell for cash their oil and gas properties. These programs were sponsored and are managed by Canadian Merrill's wholly owned subsidiary, Provident Resources, Ltd.

title: 2 Reports Find Little Merit in Using Vitamin C to Treat Colds
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Two reports published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association conclude that Vitamin C shows little merit in treatment of the common cold.

title: Implant Patient Discharged
description: CAPE TOWN, March 10 (Reuters)Ivan Taylor, 58 years old, who last November became the first man to have a second heart implanted, was discharged from Groote Schuur Hospital over the weekend.

title: The Craft of Calligraphy Has Its Charms
description: The Girl Scouts who stopped in at the Museum of American Folk Art the other day originally planned just to eat their lunch there. But they lingered, magnifying glasses in hand, to view with absorption the Spencerian flourishes and rhythmic italic script decorating the walls of the 53d Street museum.

title: Millersville Five Wins in Upset
description: KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP)  Millersville State, of Pennsylvania, pulled the first upset in the opening round of the 38th annual National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament today with an 8281 victory over Ferris State, of Michigan, seeded 14th.

title: Japan Extends HighSpeed Rail Line to Her Southern Island
description: TOKYO, March 10at 5:40 A.M. today, Takahiro Inoue, a 10yearold schoolboy, cut a ribbon at Tokyo Station to send a sleek blueandwhite electric train on its way to Hakata, 668 miles away on Japan's southwestern island of Kyushu.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, who was forced out of office in December in the wake of a corruption and influence scandal, has been assessed $140,300 in additional personal taxes for the last three years.

title: Arab Concern Building Fleet of Big Tankers
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 21 Abdul Rahman Sultan, one of the world's newest oiltanker tycoons, smiled under his Arab headdress and jauntily waved his cigar.

title: The Task of Digging Out the Riches of the Adams Papers Is Handed on by the Editor
description: BOSTON, March 10Lyman Henry Butterfield is a miner. He mines for buried words, robust eloquent words full of wit and learning and pathos, in a small dark cavern three floors above the raucous streets of old Boston.

title: Gleb Derujinsky, Sculptor, Dies; Carved Busts of Two Roosevelts
description: Gleb M. Derujinsky, a sculptor whose work included busts of Presidents, religious art, classical compositions and statues on contemporary themes, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived here.

title: Thai Setback
description: The defeat after eight days of Thailand's first government installed by parliamentary process since World War II now appears likely to bring to power the conservative groups that backed the military dictatorship ousted by student riots only seventeen months ago.

title: BILL IS PROPOSED ON TRANSPLANTS
description: A Brooklyn State Senator yesterday proposed legislation that would prevent a Medical Examiner from delaying organ transplants from homicide and accident victims until autopsies had been performed. According to transplant specialists, the bill, if enacted, could double the number of kidney transplants performed in the city.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Landlord and tenant leaders denouncedfor sharply different reasonsa proposal by Mayor Beame to permit owners hurt by higher fuel costs to obtain rent increases in many of the city's 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments.

title: SST's to J.F.K.?
description: The advocates of supersonic aviation are nothing if not persistent. Four years ago, the House and Senate after wide public controversy voted down any further expenditure for an Americanbuilt supersonic transport.

title: Japan Doubles Oil Purchases From China
description: TOKYO, March 10  In a move that has more powerful political than economic impact, a Japanese importer has signed a contract that will raise oil purchases from China this year to twice the 1974 level.

title: Capt. Spencer Johnson, 74, Navy Medic at Port Here
description: Capt, Spencer Johnson, a Navy physician who was medical director of the Port of New York early in World War It and chief of urology, at St. Albans Naval Hospital, Queens, after the war, died last Thursday in Charleston, S. C., where he had retired in 1962. His age was 74.

title: Jersey Sells Notes
description: The New Jersey Housing Finance Agency, whose financial obligations are guaranfeed by a legislative moral pledge, sold $54  million worth of shortterm notes at higher rates of interest than it had hoped to get. Officials cited a temporary loss of confidence in legislative moral pledges. Page 39.

title: Penn Central Yards' Sale Is Approved by U.S. Court
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia authorized the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday to sell two large, virtually unused freight yards on the Hudson River in Manhattan to a builder who plans huge residential and industrial developments for the sites.

title: E. ROBINSON SQUIBB
description: E. Robinson Squibb, who retired in 1944 as a classics teacher at Milton (Mass.) Academy, died Sunday at his home in Alstead. N. H. He was 87 years old.

title: Lachman, Deploring Partisanship, Drops Regents Bid
description: ALBANY, March 10Criticizing polarization on the State Board of Regents and partisanship that has seeped Into the selection process, Seymour P. Lachman, former president of the New York City Board of Education, withdrew today as a candidate for the Regents.

title: Kissinger Meets Israelis And Then Flies to Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 10  Secretary of State Kissinger covered all aspects of a possible new EgyptianIsraeli agreement in meetings this morning with wary Israeli leaders. He then flew to Ankara to urge Turkey to take steps to reopen the Cyprus negotiations.

title: Carey's Choice to Direct Women's Unit Is Assailed
description: ALBANY, March 10  Governor Carey's reported choice to direct the women's unit in his office has stirred complaints from women concerned that the candidate might not have strong enough credentials in the feminist movement, administration officials reported today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Fluor Corporation said yesterday it had been selected to build plants in South Africa to convert coal into major fuels and chemicals. A spokesman for Fluor said the contract was worth more than $1billion and was the largest ever received by the company.

title: SENATE VOTE SET ON STRIP MINE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Ten weeks after President Ford's veto of strip mine control legislation, the Senate prepared today to pass an almost identical bill, with the possibility of changes that would make it stronger.

title: Voices Turn Into Faces As a Result of Phone Fire
description: The Second Avenue Delicatessen, at 10th Street, lost its phone service in the great telephone fire three blocks away.

title: Independent TV News Films Face Dim Prospects
description: The Rockefeller Foundation, which underwrites the Television vision Laboratory at WNET to encourage experimentation by young video producers, held an informal conference yesterday with representatives of the television industry. The conference was held to explore the broadcast prospects for news documentaries produced by independent videotape groups.

title: ExInmate Testifies 2 Beat Attica Guard
description: BUFFALO, March 10In testimony at the Attica murder trial, which is entering its third week, a witness today for the first time identified both the defendants as the men he saw beat Correction Officer William Quinn at the outset of the 1971 prison rebellion.

title: ExGov. Hall's Case Goes to Jury Soon As Defense Rests
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 10 (AP)The defense rested today in the briberyextorsion trial of former Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma and W. W. Taylor, a Dallas financier.

title: Cavanagh Attends to Details While Beame Decides Policy
description: James A. Cavanagh  he has become Jim to a lot more people than he really knows over the last yearis the man who says yes or no in Abe Beame's City Hall.

title: Colts Name Aide
description: BALTIMORE, March 19 (AP)The Baltimore Colts named George Boutselis today as its special teams coach for the 1975 National League season. Boutselis was the defensive backfield coach for the Charlotte, N.C., Hornets of the World Football League last season.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 11, 1975

title: COMMON MARKET OPENS DUBLIN TALK
description: DUBLIN, March 10  The heads of government of the Common Market countries today sought an agreement on meeting Britain's demands for easier terms in the community to increase the chances of her continued membership.

title: S. Africa Glum on Davis Cup
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 10 (AP)There is virtually no hope for a Davis Cup tennis series between South Africa and Mexico, Justice Bien Franklin, president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union, said today.

title: U.S.Amendment: What It Will Do
description: Is the Equal Rights Amendment to be the Tonkin Gulf Resolution of the American social structure? former Senator Sam J. Ervin asked three years ago, voicing his opposition to the resolution, then before the Congress, which would put an end to sex discrimination in terms of governmental action.

title: Charles T. Ayres, 71, Dies; A Retired ABC Executive
description: Charles T. Ayres, who retired in 1968 as a vice president and general sales executive of ABCTV, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: 200,000 at Work in Federal Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Cities around the nation are Making steady but uneven progress implementing the $1billion public service employment program signed into law Dec. 31, 1974.

title: People in Sports
description: Autograph hunters who approach John Newcombe lately are of a universal mind about his coming heavyweight title tennis match with Jimmy Connors. I don't understand where this feeling comes from, said Newcombe. They all say, I don't want you to beat him, I want you to kill him. I feel sorry for the guy. I live parttime in the United States, but I'm an Australian playing an American. Is it because he doesn't want to represent his country?

title: BRIBE DEFENDANT TO AID JERSEY CASE
description: TRENTON, March 10A defendant charged with complicity in a $1.6million bribery at tempt to win approval for construction of a $250million commercial plaza in Fort Lee agreed here today to testify for the state against his business associates, who are named in the indictment as coconspirators.

title: FUND MAY BE KEPT FOR ALCOHOLISM
description: ALBANY, March 10State budget officials said today that five of the 11 new state alchoholism treatment centers scheduled to be phased out last Friday may not be closed after all, and that none of the 71 employes got their expected dismissal notices today.

title: Cordero: 4 More Winners
description: Angel Cordero continued his amazing riding yesterday by winning four races at Aqueduct. However, the star jockey failed to win the one race that the greater part of the crowd of 16,465 wanted him to win.

title: Siega of Cosmos Hurts Knee; Lost for Tourney
description: Jorge Siega, the star forward of the New York Cosmos, has strained ligaments inside his left knee and ruptured tendons on the outside of the same knee, the team physician, Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, said yesterday.

title: ALEXANDER FRIEDMAN
description: Dr. Alexander Friedman, former chief surgeon at Beth David Hospital and a staff surgeon at Trafalgar and University Height Hospitals, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: SCOTT, IN A BREAK WITH FORD, URGES LON NOL'S OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today that the United States should use pressure to bring about a Cambodian transition government that could negotiate a truce and safe treatment of refugees.

title: People and Business
description: Yes, America is in a depression, George Meany, A.F.L.C.I.O. president, declared yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BigBomber Vitamins
