description: WASHINGTONAt the Pentagon, the major general fondles a model of the bomber, lowers his voice in hushed reverence, and confides: It flies like a dream. On Capitol Hill, a Congressman on the Armed Services Committee, observing that the plane is being sold as a boon to the economy, declares: It's a flying cork barrel.

title: Bronx School Boycott Follows Hepatitis Case
description: Parents of 1,700 children at Public School 91 in the Bronx boycotted classes yesterday and kept their children out of school in protest over the City Health Department's refusal to inoculate all the students after one child contracted hepatitis last week.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After deliberating less than two hours, a Gloucester County jury, in Woodbury, N.J., found a migrant crew chief not guilty of breaking the arm of an Assemblyman and smashing his car.

title: BILL IS PROPOSED ON TRANSPLANTS
description: A Brooklyn State Senator yesterday proposed legislation that would prevent a Medical Examiner from delaying organ transplants from homicide and accident victims until autopsies had been performed. According to transplant specialists, the bill, if enacted, could double the number of kidney transplants performed in the city.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: I.B.M. and Farms Help Dutchess Keep jobless Rate Manageable
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.Six men and women stood in line at the. New York State Employment Service office here the other day, applying for unemployment benefits for the first time.

title: Saudis Seen as Cushioning Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The latest cut in Saudi Arabia's oil production, to the very low level of 6.5 million barrels a day in February, was interpreted by Government analysts today as evidence that the Saudis have made themselves a shock absorber for the 13nation cartel of oil exporters.

title: Jefferson HayesDavis, 90, South's Leader's Grandson
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 10 (UPI)Jefferson HayesDavis, last surviving grandson of Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy, died Saturday at the age of 90.

title: South Africa to Release Ailing Communist Figure
description: CAPE TOWN, March 10Bram Fischer, former leader of the underground South African Communist party, will be released from custody for one month, the Government announced today.

title: Some Phone Users To Get New Numbers
description: When service is restored, new telephone numbers will he assigned to 1,800 residences and 80 businesses that have been without phones as a result of the 16hour fire on Feb. 27 that damaged the New York Telephone Company switching center at Second Avenue and 13th Street.

title: Kissinger Meets Israelis And Then Flies to Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 10  Secretary of State Kissinger covered all aspects of a possible new EgyptianIsraeli agreement in meetings this morning with wary Israeli leaders. He then flew to Ankara to urge Turkey to take steps to reopen the Cyprus negotiations.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 11, 1975

title: Stocks Show Gain Aided by Late Rally
description: Fueled by a late advance, stock prices finished higher yesterday in active trading after a sluggish start.

title: Two Youths on Trial In Murder of Judge Scored as Snipers
description: ELIZABETH, March 10Two youths on trial here for the murder Nov. 4 of Wanaque Magistrate Joseph J. Cresente were portrayed today by the prosecution as cowardly snipers who plotted to shoot the judge in the back for personal reasons as he conducted night court.

title: Not Every Pink Gull Is Rare Ross's Gull
description: The National Audubon Society and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service are warning that many reports of sightings of rare Ross's gulls that they are receiving are only interesting mistakes.

title: COMPROMISE SOUGHT ON ENERGY PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)White House and Congressional staffs are seeking a compromise between President Ford and Democratic leaders on energy policy, the energy administrator, Frank G. Zarb, said today, but the crucial question of timing remains unresolved.

title: 3 Utilities Here Seek Rise In Rate to Hunt Gas in Gulf
description: The three metropolitan gas utilities are seeking permission to invest in a search for new gas supplies in the Gulf of Mexico with $23million to be derived from a pro jected rate increase

title: Secret Bid Related On Cambodia Talks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 10 The State Department was reported today to have turned down a proposal by the American Embassy in Phnom Penh to try to make diplomatic contacts with local Cambodian Communists last spring because such an effort might have interfered with a secret attempt to start negotiations with the former Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Hope for the Campuses
description: The private colleges and universities of the United States are, individually and collectively, in extreme danger. A practical fiscal package to rescue them has just been proposed by the new Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education. Specifically, the council asks the Federal and state governments to share equally in providing any student who enrolls in a private institution with an annual subsidy in the amount of half of the average public subsidy enjoyed by students attending the state or municipal colleges. At present levels, this would amount to a $750 Federalstate contribution toward a student's tuition payment.

title: UPTURN FORECAST IN PAPER BUSINESS
description: The paper industry should see a turn for the better within the next two months, Alexander Calder Jr., chairman of the American Paper Institute, said yesterday.

title: CAMBODIANS SEEK TO BRACE MORALE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 11The Government sought yesterday to keep the morale of its army and people from deteriorating further as insurgent forces again shelled the capital and its airport and continued their ground attacks elsewhere.

title: Iraq Shifting Policy By JUAN de ONIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10  The agreement between Iraq and Iran to negotiate an end to their border problems is being viewed by experts as part of a political move by Iraq to establish normal relations with her Persian Gulf neighbors. It was noted that the agreement with Iran was followed by an announcement from Saudi Arabia that an invitation to visit Iraq had been accepted by Prince Fand Ibn Abdel Aziz, King Faisal's halfbrother and Deputy Premier.

title: STEEL OUTPUT RISES 2.3% IN LATEST WEEK
description: Steel production last week rose 2.3 per cent and reached its highest level since the week ended Nov. 2, 1974, according to figures released yesterday by, the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: 2 City Policemen Indicted in a Holdup
description: Two police officers were accused yesterday of stealing $2,000 and shooting an employe in a West Side grocery store where, the police said, marljuana was being sold under the counter.

title: CITY STUDIES UNIT SET UP AT STEVENS
description: Stevens Institute of Technology and the City of Hoboken announced yesterday the formation of a Center for Municipal Studies and Services, to be directed by Richard J. Sullivan, New Jersey's former Commissioner of Environmental Protection.

title: New U. S. Program Fails to Ease Rice Scarcity for Cambodians
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 10Despite American predictions last week that the critical shortage of rice here could be eased by a new American aid program, the average Cambodian is receiving less of this staple than ever before.

title: SCOTT, IN A BREAK WITH FORD, URGES LON NOL'S OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today that the United States should use pressure to bring about a Cambodian transition government that could negotiate a truce and safe treatment of refugees.

title: ARTHUR HUMMEL SR., HISTORIAN, 91, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Arthur W. Hummel Sr., historian and the father of Arthur Hummel Jr., Ambassador to Ethiopia, died today of a heart attack on the way to the Montgomery County (Md.) General Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: Economic Mission Foresees Money Rate Cuts in Japan
description: Leaders of a 25member Japanese economic mission to the United States said yesterday that they expected official action soon to ease Japan's tight money rates, similar to moves last week in this country.

title: Luis Amado Blanco, 72, Dies; Cuba's Envoy to the Vatican
description: ROME, March 10Dr. Luis Amado Blanco, Cuban Ambassador to the Vatican, died yesterday of pulmonary congestion. He was 72 years old and had held his diplomatic post here since 1962

title: Police Picket Roads to Pleasantville for Pay Raises
description: Offduty police officers held a oneday picketing demonstration on roads leading into Pleasantville yesterday in support of their demand for a $1,000ayear pay increase.

title: Bucks Beat Kings On Jabbar's Spree
description: MILWAUKEE, March 10 (AP)Kareen AbdulJabbar, held to 2 points in the third quarter, put in 13 in the final period to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 10396 National Basketball Association victory Monday, over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings tonight.

title: Ronan Is Cool to Helping Transit Running at a Loss
description: JERSEY CITY, March 10Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said today he had little confidence in the ability anti the desirability of the Instate agency's financing any further masstransit projects that promised to produce operating deficits.

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO CURB HEARING AID ADS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission initiated formal legal action today against six major hearingaid manufacturers over what the commission said was misleading advertising.

title: Article 1  No Title
Yankee Box Score
description: Yankee Box Score

title: RevenueSharing Fight
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 A heated debate is expected in Congress when it confronts the subject of renewing Federal general revenue sharing, a program eagerly endorsed by President Ford and a bipartisan group of mayors, governors and county officials. The Ford Administration and lobbying groups here representing thousands of state and local officials throughout the country are intent on seeking renewal of revenue sharing this year, although the $30.2billion program does not expire until the end of 1976.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The state Equal Rights Amendment raises a major question: Is it necessary in view of the campaign for a Federal E.R.A.? A hearing today advances the controversy one step closer to a referendum in the fall.

title: EAST GERMAN SPIES FORMALLY CHARGED
description: BONN, March 10Gnter Guillaume, whose arrest as an East German agent led to the fall of Chancellor Willy Brandt last year, was formally charged with high treason and breach of official secrets today.

title: Mayors of Southern Towns With Black Majorities Expand Their Influence in Politics, Race and Economics
description: GRAMBLING, La., March 8The word heard most often here this weekend was savable.

title: Oil Depletion Compromise Is Hinted in Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Marc. 10The possibility of a compromise on the issue of repealing tie oil depletion allowance appeared briefly today in the Senate Finance Committee.

title: 3 Utilities Here Seek Rise In Rate to Hunt Gas in Gulf
description: The three metropolitan gas utilities are seeking permission to invest in a search for new gas supplies in the Gulf of Mexico with $23million to be derived from a projected rate increase.

title: Burse, Black Yank, Is Oxford Star
description: OXFORD, England, March 10Ray Burse was eating lunch at St. John's College of Oxford University about a year ago when a friend tame up and told him the St. John's intramural rugby team was short a man for a game. Do you want to play? Burse was asked.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL BAN ON ABORTION URGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Two Republican Senators called today for a constitutional amendment banning abortion and possibly prohibiting some birth control methods.

title: PRICES ARE FIRM IN GRAIN TRADING
description: Prices of wheat and corn closed firm yesterday after a late rally eliminated earlier declines. But soybeans continued to weaken all day, closing off 10 cents a bushel, and soybean oil was down the daily limit of a cent a pound.

title: Music: Vivian Taylor's Richly Expressive Pianism
description: There aren't many pianists who can play Rachmaninoff idiomatically and then turn around and play Webern equally Well. Although there are definite connections between the postRomantic composers and the 20thcentury Viennese school, most musicians either fail to see them or do not make them clear. However, Vivian Taylor, the young pianist who appeared Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, proved a glowing exception. She not only performed the two types of music in masterly fashion but also pointed up their common background with her richly expressive playing.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top teams, with points figured on a 201816141210087654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records and total points.

title: The Question Of Death
description: Is it true that the American people support capital punishment? And even if they do, is that sufficient reason for the courts to refrain horn ruling it unconstitutional?

title: STRACH AN CLEARED IN WATERGATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)United States District Judge John J. Sirica dismissed charges today in the Watergate coverup case against Gordon C. Strachan, once the principal aide to H. R. Haldeman, the former Whit House chief of staff.

title: Schoolboys Jump 71 For Record
One Year Later, the Great Energy Crisis in the Berkshires Is One of Price, Not of Supply
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass  The panic of the Great Energy Crisis of last winter is gone from this industrial city in the rustic Berkshire hills, but its effects linger on in sharply higher costs for fuel and electricity.

title: RAILWAY SCORES REFUSAL OF LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)The president of the deficitridden Chicago Rock Island & Pacific Railroad, a former Government official himself, charged today that the United States Railway Association's denial of a loan to the line was the most mishandled Government action he had ever seen.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Veterans Civic League of New Jersey filed a suit yesterday in United States District Court here challenging the Newark residency requirement for city employes. Represented by John Cervase, an attorney, the veterans league and nine members asserted that they were discriminated against because the residency law exempts policemen, firemen, teachers and administrators.

title: Power Plant on S.I. Is Facing Rejection, P.S.C. Chief Says
description: ALBANY, March 10Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Public Service Commission, announced today that he had tentatively concluded that an application by the Power Authority of the State of New York to build a 700megawatt, fossilfired generating plant at Arthur Kill on Staten Island does not meet the requirements.

title: Court Overturns Ruling on Busing For Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10The State Court of Appeals dealt a serious blow today to a 12yearold effort to achieve mandatory desegregation of the Los Angeles city schools.

title: GATT Weighs Aid for Poor Nations
description: GENEVA, March 10World trade negotiators today took up the problem of ways to expand the earnings of the developing countries by opening foreign markets to their traditional exhorts.

title: John Hopkins Dies at 58; Red Cross Official Here
description: John E. Hopkins, assistant manager of the American Red Cross in Greater New York, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home. He was 58 years old and lived at 17123 45th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Civic Teamwork
description: Hope of solving New York City's staggering economic problems rests to a considerable degree in unionized civil service workers' willingness to improve performance quality and productivity to bring down payroll costs.

title: Burger's Plan to Bar Incompetent Lawyers Is Gaining Support
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 10Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's campaign to bar incompetent lawyers from practicing in Federal courts appeared today to be winning growing, if not overwhelming, support from some of the most experienced and successful trial lawyers in the nation.

title: Where the Arts Play a Key Role in Therapy
description: Past the theater district, West 51st Street turns drab, the empty Y.W.C.A. building on the corner of Eighth Avenue giving the street a desolate air until, farther west, it teems with neighborhood street life. Few passersby could be aware of a small enclave of hope and regeneration overlooking that dim block.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Speedy Head Boat Fishing
description: MURRELS INLET, S, C.,If you are accustomed to the typical head boat of New England, New York State or New Jerseymost of which are limited to a speed of 15 knots or lessyou will be in for a surprise if you go forth on Capt. Everette Ayers's 85foot New Inlet Princess out of Capt: Dick's Marina at Murrels Inlet, S. C., for she will cruise at nearly 30 knots.

title: Thompson, Webster, Meyers Rated Top N.B.A. Draft Prizes
description: The agents and lawyers have moved into the open. Name players have begun thinking about bonus money and for the next few weeks the pro scout will be piling up air miles racing between postseason tournaments. It's the annual ritual for getting ready for the May 8 National Basketball Association college draft. The top prizes among the seniors are considered to be David Thompson of North Carolina State, Marvin Web. ster of Morgan State and Dave Meyers of the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: BERNARD DUNAU, 54, LABOR LAWYER, DIES
description: ST. LOUIS, March 10 (AP)Bernard Dunau, a Washington lawyer, died today, apparently of a heart attack, soon after arguing a case on behalf of the United Brotherhood of Teamsters before the Federal Circuit Court M Appeals. He was 54 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Iran Seeks Quick Closing of Pan Am Deal
description: The head of Iran Air said yesterday that his country was aiming at the quickest possible consummation of the transaction whereby Pan American World Airways' deep financial woes would be relieved by huge loans and investments from Iran.

title: Buckley, Cool to a FordRockefeller '76 Ticket, Voices Admiration for Reagan
description: Senator James L. Buckley reserved judgment yesterday on whether he would support a FordRockefeller national ticket next year, contending that he had mixed feelings on Administration policy so far.

title: UNIFIED EXCHANGE IN STOCKS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)A Securities and Exchange Commission advisory panel has recommended the establishment of a single national stock exchange subject to public control.

title: Rangers, Islanders Near Drama's Peak
description: The script goes like this (Hollywood's or the National Hockey League's, take your pick): Two New York teams, one nearly 50 years old (call them the Rangers) and the other barely 3 (call them the Islanders), are put in the same division as the season begins. Everbody laughs. Eyebrows are raised as the babyfaced Islanders battle into contention for a playoff berth. Faces turn red when the babyfaced Islanders begin closing in on the hoaryhaired Rangers.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's issue, The New York Times did not report on riots in Milan and the subsequent murder of the lay religious reformer Erlembald. These events took place in 1075, the year given in the dateline under the nameplate on Page 1 in late editions. The Times regrets both incidents.

title: Garage Sale No Dud
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (UPI)Ron Martorana paid $1 for a World War II memento at a garage sale, then discovered it was a live 81millimeter mortar shell. The police said yesterday that Mr. Martora took the shell to them and they turned it over to the Army's bomb disposal unit.

title: Multinationals' Value
description: In Conduct of the Corporation Wilbert E. Moore observes that in some economic situations nothing fails like success. His aphorism seems particularly appropriate to the position multinational corporations find themselves in these days. Despiteor perhaps as a result oftheir economic success, they have become a focal point of criticism that is based on misconceptions, myths, and misinformation.

title: Ford Praises Mrs. Hills As Oath Is Administered
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Carla Anderson Hills became the first woman Cabinet member in 20 years today when she was sworn in as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: A WHIFF OF THE 50'S IN ENTWISTLE BAND
description: John Entwistle, the Who's bass player, occupies a position in that band roughly analogous to George Harrison's former role in the Beatles. Mr. Harrison was the lead guitarist, but he was still the withdrawn member, chipping in an occasional song but otherwise remaining mostly in the background.

title: COAST TRIAL OPENS ON GIFTS TO NIXON
description: SAN DIEGO, March 10C. Arnholt Smith, the once powerful financier, who says he is the victim of vindictive bureaucrats because of his longtime close friendship with Richard M. Nixon, went on trial today in Federal District Court on charges of making illegal Republican campaign contributions.

title: Sydney Paralyzed by Rain
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 10 (UPI)  Sydney was paralyzed today when the heaviest rainfall in 32 years flooded roads, homes, shops and railway lines. The Weather Bureau record more than five inches of rain in a 90minute downpour at dawn. Thousands of commuters were stranded and streets in the Wooloomooloo suburb filled with water at least three feet deep.

title: SIGMUND BAER
description: Sigmund Baer, retired president of David L. Wilkoff Company, Inc., steel importers and exporters here, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old and lived at 6919 Juno Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Grand Jury Summons Officials Of Company in Shelton Explosion
description: SHELTON, Conn., March 10A Federal grand jury began issuing subpoenas today in an investigation of the bomb blasts that destroyed a multimilliondollar rubberproducts factory here March 1.

title: Blades Topple Oilers
description: BALTIMORE, March 10 (AP) The lastplace Baltimore Blades surprised Edmonton's Oilers with two powerplay goals in a 10second span that led to a 63 victory in the World Hockey Association tonight.

title: AMEX AND OTC CONTINUE CLIMB
Israelis Cautious
description: JERUSALEM, March 10The Mr. Kissinger's efforts and row to hear a report from Premier Yitzhak Rabin on the opening talks of Mr. Kissinger's current round of mediation.

title: VIETNAM REDS PUT TROOPS AND TANKS IN HIGHLAND CITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 11  Government soldiers and North Vietnamese troops were reported to be fighting in sections of the embattled province capital of Ban Me Thuot today for the second day, but the Saigon command said the situation had stabilized somewhat.

title: RULING REVERSED ON NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, March 10  The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court today overruled a lowercourt decision that had barred the State Health Department from proceeding with hearings on 62 nursing homes said to have uncorrectible safety code violations.

title: Turnpike Deaths Down
description: BOSTON, March 10 (UPI)In 1974, the first full year a 55  mile  an  hour speed limit was in effect on the Massachusetts Turnpike, there were 48 per cent fewer fatalities, John T. Driscoll, the Turnpike Authority chairman, said today.

title: Screen: Sight-Gag Satire:'Wrong Damn Film,' at Screening Room
description: "The Wrong Damn Film" opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room and the management should be scolded. Over the last year and a half the theater has built up a solid reputation as as a showcase for difficult but deserving films of quality that more commercial theaters would not touch.The only reason I can imagine that any commercial theater might not touch "The Wrong Damn Film" is that it's terrible. It's a witless political satire padded out with the kind of weak sight gags that most film makers forget by the time they reach the age of eightwhen it's no longer seems funny to make a man dive backward out of a swimming pool by reversing the motion of the film through the projector."The Wrong Damn Movie" was produced, directed, written and edited by Carson Davidson. He's also distributing it himself. It looks like a vanity project.

title: KURDISH SETBACK IN IRAQ REPORTED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10Iraqi armor and infantry units have reportedly pushed Kurdish rebels out of several militarily important mountain areas in the north since the Government offensive began there on Friday.

title: Veterinarian Charged In Track Doping Case
description: CHICAGO, March 10 (AP)Dr. Walter D. Wilkey, a veterinarian from Oak Park, Ill., was charged by the state racing board today with more than 100 violations of Illinois thoroughbred racing regulations on the drugging of horses.

title: Stander Arrested
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, March 10 (AP)  A heavyweight boxer, Ron Stander, was free on bond today after he was charged with breaking and entering an adult bookstore.

title: ADELIA BIRD ELLIS
description: Mrs. Adelia Bird McGowan, who as Adelia Bird Ellis was director of the New York Dress Institute in the nineteenforties and later director of publicity at Forstmann Woolens, Inc., died Sunday at bar winter home in Tucson, Ariz. She was 70 years old and lived on Whitcomb Hill Road in Cornwall Bridge, Conn.

title: HEALTH DEPARTMENT CITES BANKERS CLUB
Hunt in Lawsuit, Seeking 90Million From Oil Concerns
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oilman, filed a lawsuit here yesterday seeking at least $90million in damages from major oil companies for allegedly putting him out of business in the world crude oil trade, United Press International reports.

title: A.M.C. Lifts Daily Output Of Pacer Model by 32%
description: DETROIT, March 10The American Motors Corporation announced today it would increase production of its new Pacer model by 32 per cent to 700 units a day because of stronger than expected demand.

title: Social Distinctions
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has been a busy place these past few years, what with overthrowing governments, reading Bella Abzug's mail and engineering the deaths of inconvenient foreign leaders. One wonders what the small talk must have been like after hours.

title: Lachman, Deploring Partisan Politics, Drops Regents Bid
description: ALBANY, March 10Criticizing polanization on the State Board, of Regents and partisanship that has seeped into the selection process, Seymour P. Lachman, former president of the New York City Board of Education, withdrew today as a candidate for the Regents.

title: Presidential Rule Is Reported Imposed in Maldives
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 10 (AP)President Ibrahim Nasir of the Maldive Islands has reportedly ousted Premier Ahmed Zaki and imposed presidential rule.

title: Stock Tables Revised
description: Starting today, the year's highs and lows in the stack tables apply only to the year 1975 rather than 1974 75, as previously. Quotations for both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange are affected.

title: STATE PRESS GROUP ANNOUNCES AWARDS
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 10 (AP)The New York State Publishers Association announced today the winners of its annual awards for distinguished excellence in reporting, editorial writing, community service and stategovernment coverage. The New York Times was cited for community service for the series of articles by Murray Schumarh exposing neglect of mental patients in the state.

title: Cincinnati Adds Team
description: CINCINNATI, March 10 (UPI)Arkansas State has been added to the University of Cincinnati's 1975 football schedule to replace Tampa, which has dropped football. The game will be Oct. 18.

title: CAMBODIANS SEEK TO BRACE MORALE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 10The Government sought today to keep the morale of its army and people from deteriorating further as insurgent forces again shelled the capital and its airport and continued their ground attacks elsewhere.

title: Yesterday's Exhibition Baseball Games
description: Batteries  Richard, Siebert (4), De los Santos (7) and May; Barr, Bomback (5), Wright (8) and Blackwell. Winning pitcherRichard. Losing pitcherBarr.

title: Study Finds Nursing Homes Got License to Steal
description: A new study made public yesterday by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein placed major responsibility for nursinghome abuses on a former State Health Commissioner and two of his aides and called their Medicaid payment formula. a license to steal.

title: N.J., Connecticut: What They Did
description: Both New Jersey and Connecticut have approved the pending Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution, but have acted differently regarding their own state documents.

title: RCA NOTES LAYOFF OF 10,000 WORKERS
description: The RCA Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had laid off a total of some 10,000 men and women in [its] worldwide work force mostly in consumer, component and solid  state activities  and a series of plant shutdowns ranging from five days to four weeks during December and January.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: House Rebuffs Ford On Billion Fund Cut
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The House rejected today President Ford's request to cut $1.2billion more from Federal programs, and angered Republican leaders said that the projected $52billion budget deficit could rise to $80billion.

title: Chess:
description: No matter how alluring a tactical or strategical operation is, it must always be evaluated in terms of the time it takes to carry it out. Thus, a pinning operation may well succeed in its limited objective of producing double pawns in the enemy camp or even winning a pawn and still turn out a failure when the opponent is able to use the time to develop an attack.

title: Braves Also Thinking About Absent Slugger
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10  The Atlanta Braves visited the Yankees today, but the guest list didn't include Henry Aaron or Dick Allen. Aaron was with the Milwaukee Brewers in Sun City, Ariz., and Allen presumably was with his horses in Perkasie, Pa.

title: Rail Yards' Sale Set
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia yesterday authorized the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company to sell two large, virtually unused freight yards on the Hudson River in Manhattan to a builder who plans residential and industrial developments. The buyer is Trump Enterprises. Page 39.

title: Advertising
description: Three more Doyle Dane Bernbach alumni have set up a new ad agency.

title: Indian Activist Charged In South Dakota Murder
description: RAPID CITY, S. D. March 10 (UPI)An American Indian movement leader Russell Means, was formally charged today with murder in the shooting death of a Kyle, S.D. man.

title: The A's: Green and Gold and God
description: MESA, Ariz., March 6In the obsession of Charles O. Finley for green and gold, the owner's color scheme goes beyond the Oakland A's uniforms. Their wooden lockers here in the clubhouse cavern under Rendezvous Park are painted green and gold. And in the manager's office, the desk is green with gold drawers. Alvin Dark was sitting there, in a green chair, when Wes Stock, the pitching coach, stopped by with a suggestion that would slightly alter the workout schedule. It's all right with me, Dark agreed, as long as the hitters get plenty of battng practice. Now that the threetime World Series champions no longer employ Jim (Catfish) Hunter, their manager realizes that the hitters must produce more runs this season if the A's are to win their fifth consecutive American League West title. And that's where the color scheme continues. Much of the pitching staff is green except for the golden arms of Ken Holtzman, Vida Blue and Rollie Fingers; the new second baseman, Phil Garner, is green but the other hitters are solid gold, so much so that Alvin Dark's primary cerebral concern is where to insert Billy Williams, the designated hitter ransomed from the Chicago Cubs, in the batting order.

title: BOTH SIDES SCORE BEAME RENT PLAN
description: Landlord and tenant leaders yesterday denounced, for sharply different reasons, a proposal by Mayor Beame to permit owners hurt by sharply higher fuel costs to obtain rent increases in many of the city's 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
CUOMO REJECTS MOST LOBBYISTS
description: ALBANY, March 10  Secretary of State Mario M. Guomo has rejected all but four of the 284 registration forms submitted by lobbyists and said today that he would enforce the lobbying statute strictly to show its deficiencies and get a better law.

title: The Mideast Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The critical question now facing Henry Kissinger in his talks with Israel and Egypt is what safeguards can be devised to make any new interim agreement believable and practical.

title: 2 More Suspicious Fires Hit Telephone Company
description: Two more suspicious fires damaged New York Telephone Company equipment in Manhattan yesterdayraising to six the number of mysterious fires that have struck telephone facilities in the city in two weeks.

title: Streisand as Fanny Brice (Continued)
description: "Funny Lady," wherein Ray Stark, the producer, and Barbra Streisand, his star, continue the Fanny Brice story they began in "Funny Girl," looks like a somewhat aged mirror-image of the first film. Everything that happens to Fanny, including the crises that prompt her to burst into song, as well as the new songs she bursts into, are calculated to repeat the responses evoked by "Funny Girl." If you have a good thing going for you, you obviously don't junk it.In "Funny Lady" Fanny is a little older and a big Broadway star of the depressed nineteen-thirties, but her private life is a mess. Stardom is a hollow thing for poor Fanny. Her luck in men is still terrible. No sooner has she been dumped for the umpteenth time by Nick Arnstein, again played by Omar Sharif, than she becomes involved with and marries pint-sized song writer-producer Billy Rose, played by tall, athletic James Caan in the casting non sequitur of the decade.Billy, like Nick, bristles at being referred to as "Mr. Brice." He also wears garish pajamas, a habit that, when combined with his own ambition for fame, makes their marriage an impossibility. It isn't long before Fanny is singing the blues again. And again and again.As long as Miss Streisand as Fanny is singing the blues, or singing anything else, "Funny Lady" is superb entertainment, but the minute she stops the movie turns into a concrete souffl. It's heavy and tasteless. Also, in attempting to be understanding to all its real-life characters (or to their memories), the movie is so bland that it makes little sense. Moments meant to be dramatic are embarrassingly bad.The score includes a lot of fine old standards written by the late Mr. Rose ("Me and My Shadow," "More Than You Know," "Paper Moon") and a bunch of new songs by John Kander and Fred Ebb. Mr. Kander and Mr. Ebb are talented composers (they did "Cabaret" among other things) but I had the feeling that they wrote their score for "Funny Lady" with a gun at their heads, being told to come up with song-by-song equivalents to the great "Funny Girl" numbers by Jule Styne and Bob Merrill.To match "Don't Rain on My Parade" from "Funny Girl," they have written "Let's Hear It for Me." For "Who Are You Now?" they've written "How Lucky Can You Get?" Herbert Ross, who staged the musical numbers in "Funny Girl" and directed everything in "Funny Lady," even repeats staging tricks from the first film, including a helicopter sequence. There's nothing intrinsically wrong with this, I suppose, but it makes "Funny Lady" predictable and it works against the star in unintended ways.When Miss Streisand takes over a good song or tears into a revue sketch, there should be the sense of discovery we always get with unique performers. Our awareness of the calculation that went into this film diminishes even its good moments.Miss Streisand looks sensational most of the time and is so forceful that even a good strong actor like Mr. Caan seems sort of feeble.Nostalgia note: James Wong Howe, the great old Hollywood cameraman who did such films as "The Thin Man," "Yankee Doodle Dandy," "Sweet Smell of Success" and "The Rose Tattoo," was the cinematographer for "Funny Lady," which is as full of microscopically loving close-ups as a nature film about the life of a queen bee.

title: Lon Nol Shuffles Cabinet And Ousts Chief of Forces
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 11President Lon Nol removed the commander of Cambodia's armed forces today and asked the Premier to form a new Cabinet.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS COMPROMISE PLAN ON CAMBODIAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 11A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee, in a surprise vote of 4 to 3, approved a Ford Administration compromise today to provide $125million in additional military aid to Cambodia.

title: SCHUMACH OF TIMES WILL BE HONORED
description: Murray Schumach, a reporter for The New York Times, and Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, the new State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, will be honored by the New York State Hospitals Medical Alumni Association at its 30th anniversary dinner on April 25 in the Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street.

title: VENEZUELA MOVES TO NATIONALIZE OIL
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 The Venezuelan Government moved closer to a takeover of its most important industry today when President Carols Andrs Perz sent Congress a bill outlining plans to nationalize foreign oil companies operating here.

title: Waterside Design Builds Reputation
description: The use of a square, rather than oblong, brown brick is becoming increasingly common in New York City housing construction. So is the chamfered, or cut off, corner. And so is the use of a tower that widens rather than narrows toward the top.

title: Playoff Tickets
description: A limited number of tickets for New York Knick playoff games at Madison Square Garden will be made available for public sale through a postcard, selection system, the same method used last season.

title: Steelmaking Embraced by Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar  Sheik Isa of Bahrein has a pack of Salukis, the Sultan of Oman has an ormolumounted grand piano, and Sheik Zayed of Abu Dhabi has a supertanker.

title: J. JEFFREY ROCHE, WAGNER AIDE, 59
description: J. Jeffrey Roche, a former newspaper reporter and City Hall press aide, died Monday of a heart attack on the street near his home. He was 59 years old and lived at 4 East 95th Street.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 12, 1975

title: Lack of Phones Hampers Work Of Service Organizations Here
description: Charitable and other nonprotit organizations with a variety of clients, from troubled children to the elderly, have, like many commercial establishments, found their work severely hampered by a lack of telephone service since the Feb. 27 fire in an East Side switchling center.

title: Like Huxley's Savage, Redfords Flee a Plastic World
description: Robert and Lola Redford, if they chose, could be doyens of the international jet set. Instead, the couple wear Hopi Indian wedding rings, eat no beef and look to the mountains of Utah for refuge from what they feel is a world gone slightly mad.

title: Wider Price Data On Stocks Backed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission urged yesterday all stock exchanges to provide outsiders with stockprice quotations now available exclusively to member brokerage houses.

title: Bay of Pigs Survivor Wants Flag Returned
description: MIAMI, March 11 (UPI)The 1,000member Bay of Pigs Association, composed of survivors of the unsuccessful military invasion of Cuba 14 years ago, will ask the Kennedy library to return its battle flag in protest over a bill introduced by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to end the United States Embargo on trade with Cuba.

title: GULF OIL ACCUSED BY S.E.C. OF HIDING $10MILLION FUND
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Gulf Oil Corporation today with falsifying its reports to hide the existence of a $10million secret fund that was used to make illegal political contributions between 1960 and 1974.

title: Moslems in Lebanon Seek Greater Voice in the Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11 Lebanon's Moslem leaders are pressing for a reorganization of the army command to obtain an equal share with Christian politicians in the making of military decisions.

title: Wings Register 42 Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 11The New York Islanders had counted on being in a position to tie the New York Rangers tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. But they never counted on the Detroit Red Wings and their goalie, Jim Rutherford, who defeated them, 42, tonight before 12,675 disappointed fans.

title: OUTLOOK FOR CITRUS TERMED IMPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)The Agriculture Department reported today that the current United States citrus fruit crop not only was still expected to establish a new record but probably would be better than forecasters thought last month.

title: JOHN S. HEJINIAN
description: John S. Hejinian, who retired in 1968 as a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Monday at his home in Palm Springs, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived also in Westhampton Beach, L. I.

title: Marichal, Dodgers End Their Rivalry
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 11 (AP)Juan Marichal, for years a top rival of the Los Angels Dodgers and the second leading winner among active pitchers, has signed with the National League team and will report to the Dodgers' spring training camp.

title: REV. DR. HOWARD CLARK
description: The Rev. Dr. Howard C. Clark, executive vice president of the Episcopal Church Building Fund, a national organization with headquarters in Broomall, Pa., died yesterday in Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital of complications following a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 56 years old and lived in Wayne, Pa.

title: Soviet Atom Blast Detected
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)Seismic signals indicating an underground nuclear explosion in the Soviet Union were received today, the Energy Research and Development Administration announced. The signals were recorded and originated from the Semipalatanisk nuclear test area. It was the second explosion detected this year.

title: WILLIAM M'CORNICK, ECONOMIST, 64, DIES
description: William Sylvester McCornick, retired as an economist of the Library of Congress in 1969, after 20 years of service, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 50 East 89th Street. He was 64 years old and lived also in Brooklin, Me.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME THREE AS REGENTS
description: ALBANY, March 11Three Regents were chosen tonight by a tired and grumbling Legislature at a session boycotted by Republican Senators and denounced as a rump meeting by Assembly Republicans.

title: U.S. Aide on Latin Tour
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 11 (Reuters)William D. Rogers, United States Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, left here today for Chile after a oneday visit to Argentina and Uruguay at the start of a sevennation LatinAmerican tour.

title: Ban Me Thuot Before the Shells Fell: Sleepy, Charming Highlands Town
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11Before 3 o'clock yesterday morning, sleepy Ban Me Thuot was probably one of the most charming towns in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam.

title: City Aides Assail Beef Grading
description: City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor C. Guggenheimer said yesterday that she and her colleagues were extremely displeased by the decision of the United States Department of Agriculture to adopt, virtually unchanged, the beef grading standards it proposed last fall.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Opera: A Thin and Pallid Falstaff Returns to Met
description: Falstaff, in Franco Zeffirelli's generally admired production, returned to the Metropolitan Opera Monday night after an absence of two seasons, this time with Cornell MacNeil as Verdi's overblown windbag. In his first Metropolitan appearance in the role, Mr. MacNeil gave what may justly be called a thin portrayal of a fat part. Although his account of the purely vocal dimensions of Falstaff was always adequate, and often richly pleasing, Mr. MacNeil did not come close to getting his arms around the character.

title: Open Interest
description: Tueseday, March 11, 1975

title: IMMEDIATE ACTION ON ENERGY ASKED
description: The United States cannot postpone action to conserve energy without jeopardizing national security or further damaging the balance of payments, Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton asserted yesterday.

title: Net Stars Forced Out By Injury
description: LANDOVER Md., March 11 (UPI)Marty Riessen defaulted an openinground match to Eddie Dibbs in a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today because of an injured arm. Stan Smith also won by default when his opponent, Tom Gorman, bowed out because of influenza.

title: SHOP TALK
description: One might think that status and recession don't marry too well and one might well be wrong. The recession is here but it hasn't driven away status it's merely reversed it. It's no longer how much one has paid for something, it's how little.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 28 reported incorrectly that state records showed the Rose Manor Convalescent Home in Waterbury, Conn., had spent an average of 32 cents a day per patient for food. The correct figure on the state records is $1.71 per patient per day.

title: THOMAS WASMUTH RETAIL EXECUTIVE
description: Thomas C. Wasmuth, a leading executive of retailing companies owned by Federated Department Stores, Inc., died yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 60 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: WINE TALK
description: Not too long ago, mention was made here of a French wine course that could be taken through the mails. Now we learn there is a German one, too. Only for this one, you have to go to Germany.

title: Swiss Women 1, 2 In Cup Downhill
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., March 11  The delayed, snowplagued World Series of Skiing had a sunny finish today.

title: Butz Opposes Bill Raising Farm Supports That Democrats Back
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Democratic leaders in the House backed today a farm bill that would increase price supports, but Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said he would strongly recommend that President Ford veto such legislation if it were passed.

title: Fossil of Giant Winged Reptile Is Found
description: The largest known creature ever to have flown, an extinct winged reptile with an estimated wingspan of 51 feetthe length of an IRT subway carhas been discovered by fossil hunters in Texas.

title: Nuclear Iran?...
description: The differences that are delaying a $7billion deal with Iran for sale of six to eight giant American nuclearpower reactors boil down to one simple question: Does Iran want nucleargenerated electric power for the 1980's to replace its depleting oil reserves or does it also want to make nuclear weapons?

title: Possible Transmission of Deadly Virus in Transplants Poses Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON, March 11When a 55yearold man died in New York a few years ago, his eyes were donated for cornea transplantation.

title: Bankruptcy Writ Filed By Jimmy's Restaurant
description: Jimmy's, the restaurant, nightclub, cabaret and, lately, home of lost political causes, has filed for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws, listing assets of $560,000 and liabilities of $579,500.

title: Students at Clinton In 2Hour Walkout Over Rule Changes
description: Several hundred of the 4,400 students at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx staged a twohour walkout yesterday morning in a protest against the school's new regulations governing tardiness and lunchhour freedom.

title: Rights Group Threatens to Picket N.I.T.
description: A threat to picket the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden because no allblack colleges have been invited was labeled unfair and unjust yesterday by the chairman of the selection committee, Pete Carlesimo.

title: Caldwell B. Esselstyn, 72, Dies; Medical Counsel to State, U.S.
description: Dr. Caldwell Blakeman Esselstyn, who had been active until recently as medical consultant to the health maintenance organization services of the Department of. Health, Education and Welfare, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Clayerack, N. Y. He was 72 years old.

title: SCHOOL DECISION ON COAST SCORED
description: LOS ANGELES, March 11If the decision of the appeals court is confirmed it will destroy 30 years or progress in equal rights as far as education is concerned.

title: Article 5  No Title
EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company stated yesterday it planned to make a public offering of 2 million common shares and 500,00 shares of a new series, $50 par preferred stock. Proceeds will be used to retire shortterm debt incurred in conection with its construction program. The offering to be managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., and Goldman Sachs & Co., will be made around April 10.

title: AbdulJabbar Accuses Referee of Ineptitude
description: MILWAUKEE, March 11 (UPI)I'm tired of that rule. Tonight I'm going to speak out. I'll get the American Civil Liberties Union to defend my rights of free speech in court.

title: Twins Sink Astros for 4th in Row
description: COCOA, Fla., March 11 (UPI)Larry Hisle's tworun double in the sixth inning gave Minnesota a 54 exhibition game victory over the Houston Astros today as the twins remained unbeaten in four games.

title: Basketball Ratings FINAL COACHES' POLL
description: (Points on 10987etc. basis; firstplace votes and wonlost records In parentheses).

title: Congress Confirms Israeli Aid Request; Cuts Are Expected
description: WASHINGTON, March 11A key unit of the House Armed Services Committee issued a report today disclosing officially that Israel had asked for $1.8billion in new arms aid and indicating that Congress was disposed to cut that request.

title: PROFIT AT PENNEY AND KRESGE DOWN
Red Smith
description: MIAMI, March 11Jeff Burroughs was just turning 19 when he played in his first exhibition game as a rookie with the Washington Senators. (That's the old Washington Senators, now resident in Arlington, Tex., who are not to be confused with the old, old Washington Senators, who live and love and have their being in Bloomington, Minn. Officially, the new Washington Senators are still a gleam in Bowie Kuhn's eye, but there are some who suspect they are already playing in the American League as the Baltimore Orioles.) In that first game, Burroughs hit a home run, warming the managerial cockles of Ted Williams, who had been suggesting that the young man might become the first .400 hitter since Ted Williams. The next morning in West Palm Beach, Burroughs's name came up at breakfast with Paul Richards, then general manager of the Atlanta Braves.

title: Europe Parliament Elects
description: STRASBOURG, France, March 11 (Reuters)  The French socialist, Georges Spenale, was elected president of the Common Market's European Parliament today.

title: Yankees Set Back Mets, 40
Policeman Is Dismissed By City as a Malingerer
description: A 31yearold motorcycle policeman who had been on sick leave for nearly five years was dismissed yesterday in what department officials described as a campaign to rid the force of malingerers and incompetents.

title: Recall of Color TV Is Widened; F. D.A. Cites Radiation Peril
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)In an expansion of the largest recall of television sets in history, the Food and Drug Administration said today that an additional 5,000 or more color sets might be leaking dangerous levels of radiation.

title: TV: ForgetMeNot Lane Is Compelling Drama
description: Fortuitously timed for public television's first national fundraising and awareness week (which really lumbers on for 11 days), WNET's Theater in America series is presenting a marvelous rendition of ForgetMeNot Lane, the Peter Nichols play that was first produced in London in 1971.

title: ATTICA WITNESS ON STAND 6 HOURS
description: BUFFALO, March 11William Zimmer, a 25yearold prosecution witness in the Attica murder trial, spent some six hours on the stand today as defense lawyers sought to impeach his testimony.

title: S.E.C. FINDS NO ABUSE IN U.S. NOTE OFFERING
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission has determined that there was no evidence of any misuse of in (side information in connection with a Treasury offering of securities last December.

title: MANSFIELD'S RIDER ON MINE BILL LOSES
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Ths Senate defeated today an amendment to the proposed Federal strip mine control law that would have curtailed surfacemined coal development on the Western Great Plains, where many ranchers oppose it.

title: The Big Question in South Korea: Can Park Survive?
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe political mood in South Korea today is one of expectancy. Everyone thinks something is going to happen, but no one is quite sure just when, just what or just how, and all this narrows down to the fundamental question: Can the President survive?

title: Watergate Is Rekindled As Trial Lawyers Meet
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 11The fierce legal debate over Watergate, presumably stilled by the resignation of President Nixon and the results of the coverup trial, was renewed in full force today in this lush tropical resort.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The stock market finished slightly lower yesterday in heavy trading as late profit taking erased most of the gains shown earlier in the session.

title: Jersey School Vote
description: Voters in a majority of 464 school districts in New Jersey were reported defeating their local school budgets, according to incomplete returns last night. Page 43.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS COMPROMISE PLAN ON CAMBODIAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 11A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee, in a surprise vote of 4 to 3, approved a Ford Administration compromise today to provide $125million in additional military aid to Cambodia.

title: Disarming New York
description: A steady flow of illegal handguns, largely from the South, has saturated the city with dangerous firearms. The concentration of an estimated two million guns means that every fourth New Yorker (counting men, women and children of all ages) is potentially armed with an illegal weapon. During one recent weekend, eleven persons were killed and 21 injured by illegal gunfire.

title: Rangers and Islanders Beaten
description: BOSTON, March 11Not that they played better, but the New York Rangers deserved a better fate than the 63 defeat by the Boston Bruins tonight. Three goals in the last four finutes and a crucial penalty sent New York to its fourth loss in the last five games.

title: Voice for Consumers
description: For those who believe Ralph Nader invented consumer advocacy, it may come as something of a shock to learn that the National Consumers League, an organization with an effective and often militant record as champion of consumer interests, is now celebrating its 75th anniversary.

title: Gulf and Veba of Germany To Cooperate on Energy
description: PITTSBURGH, March 11 (UPI)The Gulf Oil Corporation and Veba, A.G., of West Germany said today, they intended to establish broad cooperative arrangements in the international energy field and were discussing related spheres of possible future cooperation.

title: ...Kurds Betrayed?
description: The surprise agreement signed last week by the Shah of Iran and by Saddam Hussein, deputy chairman of Iraq's Baathist regime, willif it is fully carried outchange previous calculations regarding forces at work in the Middle East. It seems to strengthen the unity of the oilproducing nations by apparently ending the long, bitter Iran  Iraq dispute. This development certainly boosts the prestige of President Boumediene of Algeria, who brought the two sides together at the recent OPEC meeting in Algiers. But it does more than that.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 28 reported incorrectly that state records showed the Rose Manor Convalescent Home in Waterbury, Conn., had spent an average of 32 cents a day per patient for food. The correct figure on the state records is $1.71 per patient per day.

title: Seaver, Hunter To Pitch Tonight
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 11  Jim (Catfish) Hunter says Tom Seaver is still the No. 1 pitcher in New York, and today a couple of thieves tagged Seaver as the No. 1 target at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

title: Article 7  No Title
Bridge:
description: New York enthusiasts will have a rare opportunity to see some of the world's greatest players in action in two months' time, when the legendary Italian Blue Team, or a close facsimile thereof, will play an exhibition match here.

title: Cordego Aboard 3 Winners
description: Angel Cordero brought home another triple at Aqueduct yesterday and found a new route to the winner's circle as he made it 40 victories in 97 tries. In the sixth race, a claim of foul involving two other horses enabled Cordero's mount, Bo Hatch, to move up from second place to first H. Hour had finished a nose ahead of Bo Hatch in the 1 1/8mile event, but was disqualified and placed third for bothering Clarion Sky, who finished third.

title: Portugal's Stormy Time
description: The year that has passed in Portugal since the ousting of the authoritarian Government of Premier Marcello Caetano, the successor of Antnio de Oliveira Salazar, has been a turbulent one.

title: Article 3  No Title
Democrats Pick 3 as Regents; Republicans Boycott the Vote
description: ALBANY, March 11  Three Regents were chosen tonight by a tired and grumbling Legislature at a session boycotted by Republican Senators and denounced as a rump meeting by Assembly Republicans.

title: Brearley Administrator Named to Head School
description: Evelyn Janover Halpert, a member of the faculty of the Brearley School for 17 years, will become its head at the end of the current school year, replacing Jean Fair Mitchell.

title: Jersey Reports an Accord On PATHLine Extension
description: TRENTON, March 11The Byrne administration and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were reported today to have reached general agreement of the PATH Rapid Transit System from Newark to Plainfield.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's mutual savings banks reported yesterday that their deposits increased $675million in February yields on alternative investments continued to decline.

title: Some Hog the Phones In East Side Fire Area
description: Martin Kellner keeps an eye out for hands clutching long lists of phone numbers that warn him of a slowmoving line, and Carlyle Kelly deeps an ear cocked for the telltale jingle of a handful of dimes.

title: Recital: Vishnevskaya in Grand Style
description: Galina Vishnevskaya and her husband, Mstislav Rostropovich, have become political figures as well as musical ones, thanks to their insistence on standing up against what they consider repressive aspects of Soviet society. But the soprano's Carnegie Hall recital last night, in which she was, as in the past, accompanied by her husband at the piano, needed no propping up by political controversy to seize and hold attention.

title: World Church Unit Backs Rhodesian Black Leader
description: GENEVA, March 11  The World Council of Churches called today for a fair and public trial of the Rev. Niabaningi Sithole, the black Rhodesian nationalist leader who is accused of plotting the assassination of rivals in the nationalist movement.

title: Monster Hunt Score: 3 Hunters, No Monster
description: LAKE OWASSA, March 11 (AP)  The great monster hunt wound up today in a search for the hunters instead of the hunted.

title: Newark Policeman Slays AxWielder Who Struck Officer
description: Wielding an ax with a threefoot handle, a 43yearold man ran into Newark's busiest intersection during the noon hour yesterday and slashed a police officer across the back before being shot and killed by another officer.

title: Smoking in Pregnancy Is Linked To Fetus Breathing Movements
description: LONDON, March 11 (Reuters) Cigarettes smoked by a pregnant woman substantially reduce movements of her unborn child that help it to breathe properly at birth, a study says.

title: Rule, President of ABC, Inc., Wins RadioTV Gold Medal
description: Elton H. Rule, president of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., received the Gold Medal of the International Radio and Television Society last night at ceremonies held at the Americana Hotel. Mr. Rule was was cited for his dedication to the betterment of broadcasting, the progress of his cornpany and enrichment of the public interest.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: A new label and placard category, chilled, will appear in the meat departments of New York City food stores in the next few weeks. It designates a system for processing, packaging and distributing foodstuffs, and since the companiesthatuse it think it has marketing value, it will likely appear in other parts of the metropolitan area, too.

title: CYPRUS PROGRESS SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: JERUSALEM, March 11Secretary of State Kissinger said today in Ankara, Turkey, that after extensive talks with Turkish leaders, he believed progress had been made toward finding a solution to the Cyprus crisis.

title: People and Business
description: Jeffrey M. Bucher, a governor of he Federal Reserve Board, believes that the time has come to create a single new agency responsible for all Federal banking regulation.

title: CORN AND WHEAT SCORE ADVANCES
description: A sudden flood of export orders for grain and soybeans, traced to Soviet bloc countries, caused traders to bid prices up to the daily permissible limits on Midwestern exchanges yesterday.

title: Finland: Neutrality Is More Than Stillsitzen
description: VIENNAUnder the Presidency of Dr. Urho Kekkonenhis first term began March 1, 1956 and he is now in his fourth termthe neutrality of Finland has taken on new dimensions.

title: Books of The Times
description: I never really understood the appeal of Judy Garland when she was alive, or what was behind the socalled Garland Cult that surfaced around 1950 and grew and grew until the actresssinger died of an overdose of sleeping pills in Tune, 1969. But after reading Judy Garland: A Biography, by Anne Edwards, British novelist and screen writer, I think I understand a little. You take the young woman who sang of flying Over the Rainbow in the movie adaptation of L. Frank Baum's The Wizard of Oz (and thereby apparently caught the imagination of all the and and frustrated people who ever, dreamed of escaping what they saw as their own deadend destinies). You add years to her life. and a history of broken marriages, drug abuse, nervous breakdowns and failed suicides. You put her on a stage with a spotlight and a microphone. And you are moved. That she makes any sound at all let alone performs like a beaten prizefighter coming off the canvas to win in the final roundis moving. It isn't necessarily art, or even a matter of taste. But it's moving. And since it happened so many times in Judy Garland's life, her story is moving. Undeniably so.

title: Advertising
description: Over at the Union Underwear Company the folks have named April 6 Super Spectacular Sunday. They've got a reason.

title: Kurds, Lacking Iran's Aid, Shift to Guerrilla Tactics
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11  A Kurdish rebel spokesman said today that warfare from fixed positions was being abandoned in favor of guerrilla tactics in the new military confrontation with Iraqi forces.

title: Danny Kaye, Master of Wit, Is Also Master of Chinese Cooking
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.There were eight guests at table. Danny Kaye was at the stove with volcanolike, billowing smoke ascending from one of his three professional woks, as he stirred a dish of cubed beef with onions, Chinesestyle.

title: Plan for Utilities to Join Gas Hunt Is Abandoned
description: A projected deal for the three metropolitanarea gas utilities to invest in a hunt for new gas supplies in the Gulf of Mexico was suddenly withdrawn by Texaco, Inc., and the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation yesterday just as a state hearing was to start.

title: A School Where Young Offenders May Be Salvaged
description: Most of the 20 teenage boys at the Phoenix School have been street criminals, the kind of assaultive youngsters who have aroused fear and loathing in a victimized public.

title: To Be Obscurely Hanged
description: TEHERAN, Iran  Nothing, Voltaire tells us, is more annoying than to be obscurely hanged; and it is this fate, symbolically speaking, that has just overtaken the rebellious Kurds of Iraq for the umpteenth time in their incredibly ancient history.

title: PROPONENTS YIELD ON DEATH PENALTY
description: TRENTON, March 11Opponents of reinstating the death penalty in New Jersey won a major victory here today when they succeeded in removing a death penalty provision from legislation being drafted to implement the state's first penal code.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MEMORIES Mention Glenn Miller and sweet, swinging sounds come back from the era of the big bands. Today at 4 P.M., the public is invited free to relive the Miller career through a lecture, illustrated slides and recording excerpts presented by a close associate of the late band leader, George T. Simon. The place is the Mercantile Library, at 17 East 47th Street, a 151yearold membership library and reading room that is a rewarding place to visit on its own. Seating for the lecture is limited; call first (7556710).

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Cornell Poloists Triumph by 159
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 11 The University of California at Davis overpowered Harvard, 218, and Cornell defeated Virginia, 159, tonight in the first round of the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: People in Sports
description: Reggie Jackson was upset by the rain that washed out the Oakland A's practice at Mesa, Ariz., yesterday. While he and his teammates were fretting in the locker room, more upsetting news came. Thieves broke into Jackson's apartment and stole $13,000 worth of goods, including the star outfielder's three World Series rings.

title: BUILDING ACTIVITY DOWN FOR MONTH
description: Contracts for new construction fell sharply in January, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday. January contracts dropped 13 per cent to $5.1billion compared with January, 1974, to their lowest level in the last four years.

title: Conteh Stops Bennett In 5th to Retain Crown
description: LONDON, March 11John Conteh won a battle of left jabs from Lonnie Bennett tonight to retain the World Boxing Council's version of the lightheavyweight championship.

title: Food Costs Here Rise Again
description: A 1.3 per cent rise in the prices of meatsas three weeks of beef specials ended in many supermarkets and the stores offered most meat cuts at previous price levels brought about a 1.1 per cent increase in the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week.

title: Article 1  No Title
Issue and Debate
description: The New York City school system, acting under the compulsion of a consent decree issued by a Federal court, is in the final stages or developing a bilingual education program for the tens of thousands of Puerto Rican students Who are foundering because they cannot function in English.

title: Icebreaker Batters Free in Antarctica And Heads for U.S.
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 11 (AP)The 309foot icebreaker Glacier headed home today after battering her way out of a South Pole icepack where she had been trapped for nine days.

title: LINCOLN SQ. AREA: ZONING STILL ISSUE
description: A running controversy over zoning in the Lincoln Square area was bounced back to the City Planning Commission yesterday when the developers of a proposed highrise building on Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets abruptly withdrew their application for hardship consideration from the Board of Standards and Appeals.

title: Laver, Miss Navratilova Cited As Proof of LeftHander's Edge
description: The talk in tennis yesterday was about lefthanders, how unpredictable they were and how tough it was to play against them. Rod Laver and Martina Navratilova were the prime examples. The Aussie, in the twilight of his career, wove his southpaw spell over the Americans in the World Cup and the young Czechoslovak, just beginning to bloom, bewildered Evonne Goolagong in the finil of the United States indoor championship.

title: House Raises Committees' Funds by 79%
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Ths House voted without dissent today to give 10 of its committees $10million in operating funds this year, a 79 per cent increase over 1974.

title: House Drops Bid to Defeat Ford Veto
description: WASHINGTON, March 11President Ford won a victory of sorts in the House today when the Democratic leadership abandoned the idea of overriding his veto of the 90day oil tariff delay, and the House voted 364 to 57 to send the bill back to the Ways and Means Committee.

title: BYRNE SIGNS BILLS TO HELP ECONOMY
description: TRENTON, March 11 Governor Byrne signed into law today two bills designed to pump more investment money into New Jersey's ailing economy and to help financially hardpressed industries pay for state or federally required pollution control equipment and other machinery.

title: Article 4  No Title
Gas Hunt Plan Is Off
description: A projected deal for the three metropolitan gas utilities to invest in a hunt for new gas supplies in the Gulf of Mexico was suddenly withdrawn yesterday. Page 43.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS MORTGAGE SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters)The House Banking Committee approved today a $12billion mortgage subsidy bill that is designed to create 400,000 new housing units.

title: Music: Zumbro's Feat
description: Nicholas Zumbro, a robustlooking and robustsounding pianist who teaches at the University of Hawaii in Honolulu gave a bracing recital Monday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Women Clash in Albany on EqualRights Proposal
description: ALBANY, March 11 Citing such sources as King Solomon and Sarah Grimke, the early abolitionist and suffragette, dozens of women heatedly debated from morning to night the proposed equal rights amendment to the State Constitution that is expected to be put to the voters this year in a referendum.

title: A Compromise With City Ends P.S. 91 HepatitisIssue Boycott
description: A oneday parents boycott of Public School 91 in the University Heights section of the Bronx over the Department of Health's refusal to inoculate all the pupils against hepatitis ended yesterday after the department agreed to send a nurse to check the entire kindergarten class.

title: McCrory Sets More Closings
description: The McCrory Corporation, which last week announced that it would close most of its 17 S. Klein department stores by April 30, also is closing about 160 of its variety stores, laying off about 1,800 employes and shutting five warehouses in a major program to cut costs.

title: Stage: Williams's Kingdom of Earth in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Of all Tennessee Williams's plays, Kingdom of Earth has had one of the roughest passages. It was originally given in 1968 on Broadway, directed by Jos Quintero, under the mysterious title of The Seven Descents of Myrtle. A couple of years later it was filmed by Sidney Lumet as the Last of the Mobile HotShots. Now the McCarter Theater is staging a slightly shortened and revised version of the play under its original title, Kingdom of Earth.

title: Brown U. Resolves Dispute On Student Access to Data
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, March 11Brown University has announced that it will release students' special distinction records along with the rest of the academic files, thus ending a legal battle between the administration and the Brown student governement and Brown chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 12, 1975

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, March 11 (UPI)The Illinois Liquor Control Commission revoked today the licenses of liquor concessions operating at Chicago Stadium, White Sox Park and two Illinois race tracksMaywood Park and Cahokia Downs. The concessions are owned by Sportsytems Corporation, parent company of Eniprise, which was convicted in California in 1973 of conspiring to aid racketeering. Chairman Michael Berz of the state commission said the licenses were revoked on grounds the company had not been sufficiently rehabilitated since the conviction.

title: Two Smaller Agencies Go Out of Business
description: Two small ad agenciesJack Byrne Advertising and Katz, Jacobs & Douglaswent out of business last Friday. Is that a sign of the times?

title: Knicks Subdue Suns, 10398; Monroe Stars
Policeman Slays AxWielder Who Slashed Officer in Newark
description: Wielding an ax with a threefoot handle, a 43yearold man ran into Newark's busiest intersection during the noon hour yesterday and slashed a police officer across the back before being shot and killed by another officer.

title: Guerrilla Raid in Israel Deters Austrian Actors
description: TEL AVIV, March 11About half the cast of a Vienna theater troupe, scheduled to open here next week, has balked at coming to Israel, apparently as a result of the deaths of seven persons here last week when Arab guerrillas took over their seaside hotel.

title: State's Judges Urge Unifying Trial Courts in SingleTier System
description: ALBANY, March 11Members of the Council of Judicial Associations, which represents all of the 1,000 judges, justices and magistrates across the state, called today for consolidation of all trial courts in the state into a unified singletier trial court system.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Vow Loyalty to the Party And the President
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Following thirdparty talk by conservatives, a broad array of Republican leaders has joined in a statement pledging loyalty to the party and President Ford, Congressional sources reported today.

title: Kurds Claim Casualties
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 11Kurdish rebels in Iraq have shot down an Iraqi fighter bomber and killed at least 50 Iraqi soldiers in the last two days, proKurdish informants said here today. But they added that Iraqi Government forces had pressed their fiveday drive deeper into rebel territory.

title: New 1975 Highs/Lows
N. H. L. Gets Denver Club Next Season
description: The National Hockey League will expand to Denver next season, but may disband the California Golden Seals, who never quite had a home in Oakland.

title: Civil Rights Panel Urges U.S. to Cut Off Segregated Schools' Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Commission on Civil Rights urged the Federal Government today to withdravi Federal funds from public school districts that fail to desegregate their schools voluntarily.

title: Ford and Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, March 10President Ford, who bas tried to build a reputation for candor and forthrightness, appears to be facing his first major credibility problem since he assumed office seven months ago. The problem has arisen because members of his Administration have been giving in private a more pessimistic assessment of the situation in Cambodia than Mr. Ford's public assessment.

title: STRINGENT BUDGET OFFERED CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN, March 11Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti submitted a stringent 1975 budget of $31.3million today that holds the line on property taxes but calls for laying off 130 city employes and effecting other economies.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 12, 1975

title: Triple Pays $14,943 at Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 11The highest triple ever paid was registered tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, when the combination of 1082 returned $14,943 for a $3 wager. The highest previous payoff was $14,391 at Yonkers Raccmay on June 23, 1973.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward A. Hanna, Utica's flamboyant and controversial Mayor, called on Mayor Beame yesterday and afterWard confirmed a report that he would announce his intention today to seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, RepublicanConservative.

title: Has Greenspan Won Mind of the President?
description: Alan Greenspan cited two main objectives when he left his lucrative consulting practice in New York City last fall to take over as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. The conservative, 48yearold business economist wanted to have a strong voice in determining Administration economic policy, particularly in the tax and spending areas.

title: BOLIVIANS DENOUNCE U.S. BIRTHCURB PLAN
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 11 (AP)  The Roman Catholic Church charged today that the United States Agency for International Development was conducting modern genocide in Bolivia through birthcontrol programs.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON PATH PROPOSAL
description: TRENTON, March 11The Byrne administration and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were reported today to have reached general agreement on the financing of the controversial extension of the PATH Rapid Transit System from Newark to Plainfield.

title: NEWS DELIVERERS HOLD A 'SLOWDOWN
description: Distribution of today's first edition of The Daily News was delayed slightly last night by what a spokesman for the newspaper described as a rulebook slowdown by some deliverers.

title: Patient Rights Contested at a Hospital in Monmouth
description: FREEHOLD, March 11 (AP) A suit by a hospital and a countersuit by a woman who contends she was held prisoner at the hospital because of a bill presents a test case that could spell out the rights patients are entitled to from hospitals.

title: Hanoi Rebuts U.S. Charge On Escalation of Fighting
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 11 (Agence FrancePresse)North Vietnam today rejected as cynical calumnies charges by the United States State Department that Hanoi had stepped up fighting in South Vietnam in violation of the Paris peace agreement.

title: Town Hall's Future Is Linked to Success Of Drive for Funds
