description: LISBON, Friday, March 14Portugal's new Military Revolutionary Council decreed early today the nationalization of alIniost all banks in the country after a leftist victory over moderate and conservative forces two days ago.

title: Ridl Returning to N.I.T., This Time as a Coach
description: Most college basketball fans know that New York University and Notre Dame started Madison Square Garden's double  header programs in 1934. But how many fans can recall the parties of the second part on that occasion?

title: Suspect in '69 Bombings Pleads Not Guilty After Fugitive Years
description: Patricia E. Swinton, a fugitive for more than five years, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of participating in a plot to bomb buildings here in 1969 during a period of protest against the war in Vietnam.

title: CAMBRIDGE WEIGHS MOVES ON LIBRARY
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 (AP)  The City of Cambridge is working quietly with officials of Harvard and the John F. Kennedy Library Corporation to see if at least part of the proposed Kennedy Library complex can be saved for the city and the university.

title: U.S. JURY TRACES MISS HEARST CLUE
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 13A Federal grand jury is investigating reports that the fugitive Patricia Hearst may have spent some time in eastern Pennsylvania, a United States Attorney said today.

title: Cordero Wins Only Twice, But Delights Show Bettors
description: At the Race Tracks

title: TV: When Reliance on Imports Has Its Rewards
description: One result of public TV's current Festival '75 marathon, designed as a national fundraising campaign, is to underline the system's heavy reliance on imported programing. It seems that when all else fails in putting together a, respectable schedule, the first, and perhaps only, impulse is to grab a foreign production, preferably British. The policy has its apparent and real dangers but, simply in terms of quality material, it also has its rewards.

title: Whalers Tie Roadrunners
description: HARTFORD, March 13 (AP) Wayne Carleton's 31st goal of the season with 2:49 to play in the game gave the New England Whalers a 55 tie with the Phoenix Roadrunners tonight in the W.H.A.

title: Dr. Thomas J. Galvin, 74, ExSurgeon and Teacher
description: Dr. Thomas J. Galvin, a former surgeon here and for many years an assistant professor at the New York University Medical School, died yesterday at the East Orange, N.J., Veterans Hospital after a short illness.

title: TRADING IN DOLLAR IS UNEASY ABROAD
description: LONDON, March 13 (Reuters) The dollar consolidated some of its opening gains today in nervous trading on the European money markets.

title: Clandestinity
description: WASHINGTONA recent spate of news stories and articles have bemoaned the practical end of the Central Intelligence Agency's covert activities because an amendment to the foreign aid bill requires reporting any such operations to committees of the House and Senate.

title: RESERVE TO PRESS MONEY EXPANSION
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur F. Burns, said today the board would continue its policy of moderate monetary expansion to avoid further inflation.

title: Problems of Job Bill Are Cited, But Ford Aide Is Silent on Veto
description: WASHINGTON, March 13A White House spokesman recited today, a list of problems with a $5.9billion public service jobs bill passed yesterday by the House of Representatives, but declined to say whether President Ford would veto the measure.

title: HUMPHREY LOSES $200,000 TAX BID
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Internal Revenue Service has disallowed nearly $200,000 worth of incometax deductions claimed by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for the gift of his VicePresidential papers to the Minnesota Historical Society.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 3.8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 199.8 from 196 last week.

title: Reserve Report
description: Seasonally Adjusted

title: The Program
description: PENNSYLVANIA BALLET, Presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music at its Opera House.

title: Drake Upsets U.S.C.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 13 (AP)Larry Haralson led Drake to an 8070 upset of Southern California tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association commissioners invitation basketball tournament.

title: City Sells $375Million in Notes at 8%, Vowing Special Repayment Guarantees
description: The city sold $375million in shortterm revenueanticipation notes yesterday at a very high 8 per cent interest rate, but not before pledging to the banking community that both the City Corporation Counsel, Bernard Richland, and the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, would guarantee in writing that the city was not exceeding its borrowing authority.

title: Rules Asked for Uniforms
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)The Federal Aviation Administration proposed today setting flammability standards for uniforms worn by airline flight crews. The agency said that tests had showed that uniforms of crews on commercial airlines in the United States often provided inadequate protection when the attendants were called on to play roles in emergency fire situations.

title: The Aid Disgrace
description: The increasing difficulty in obtaining Congressional appropriations for foreign aidwith fiscal 1975 funds finally voted by the House yesterday in the ninth month of the yearis leading other wealthy nations to bypass the United States in getting vital projects under way.

title: Freight Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.9 billion tonmiles, 13 per cent below the yearearlier week. Carloadings in the same period totaled 447,651 cars, 14.6 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 23.7 per cent below last year.

title: The Question of Death
description: The Supreme Court Is about to take up the question of the death penalty again, since it failed to settle the matter with its 1972 ruling (in the socalled Furman case) that capital punishment was too arbitrarily and capriciously imposed to be constitutional.

title: North Vietnamese Capture Almost All of Highland City
Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.James Marshall, 159 pounds, Las Vegas, knocked out Jos Martin Flores, 160, San Diego, 3 rounds.

title: BRITISH COMPANY PLANS IRAN DEAL
description: Guest, Keen & Nettlefolds, Ltd., a British corporation in the steel products business, announced yesterday that it was taking an equity position in a venture with the Industrial Credit Bank of Iran, a Governmentowned institution, and the Teheran Motor Company for establishment of an automotive parts business in Iran.

title: RetailStore Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Commerce Department reported today that departmentstore sales last week totaled an estimated $901million, almost unchanged from the yearearlier $897million. Total retailstore sales were about $10.9billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $10.2billion.

title: HUMPHREY LOSES $200,000 TAX BID
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Internal Revenue Service has disallowed nearly $200.000 worth of incometax deductions claimed by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for the gift of his VicePresidential papers to the Minnesota Historical Society.

title: INTERNES' DISPUTE STILL UNRESOLVED
description: Federal mediators planned to continue their efforts today to avert a strike threatened for Monday by more than 3,000 internes and resident doctors at 11 major hospitals in the city.

title: Bulgari, the Jeweler, Kidnapped on Rome Street
description: ROME, March 13Giovanni Bulgari, coowner of an internationally known jewelers company that has a branch in New York, was kidnapped by gangsters in Rome tonight and is believed to be held for ransom.

title: Physician Testifies Fatal Blows Struck Attica Guard on the Left Side of the Head
description: BUFFALO, March 13A physician who examined and treated William Quinn just after the Attica correction officer was taken to the hospital in 1971 pinpointed the guard's fatal skull injuries today and said they had appeared to have been caused by a blunt instrument.

title: Bridge:
description: HONOLULU, March 13The vanguard of some 4,000 enthusiasts arrived here today, ready for the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, which will be played at the Hilton Hawaiian Village here during. the next 10 days.

title: Architecture Drawings at the Modern
description: Architectural Studies and Projects, which opens today in the Penthouse of the Museum of Modern Art, deals with the most peripheral, yet perhaps the most luxurious, aspect of architecture: the making of purely visionary drawings, schemes that have no connection with reality.

title: DYNAMICS CORP. LIFTS NET 71.3%
Books of The Times
description: Before reading George V. Higgins's fourth novel, A City on a Hill, I thought I was going to be able to report that Mr. Higgins had shifted gearsthat instead of producing another of his highly entertaining, although formally somewhat limited, slices of Boston lowlife, such as were The Friends of Eddie Coyle, The Digger's Game and Cogan's Trade, he had struck off in a new direction, put to wont a different facet of his experiences as a lawyer in the Massachusetts Attorney General's office and entered the arena of the political novel. So at least one would conclude from the title of Mr. Higgins's new booktaken from a 1630 sermon by the newly appointed Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, John Winthrop, that went in part: For we must consider that we shall be as a city upon a hillthe eyes of all people are upon us. So one would conclude from the characters, who are politicians, and the setting, which ranges from Nantucket, Mass., to Washington.

title: Lloyd Frankenberg, A Poet, Anthologist And Critic, 67, Dies
description: Lloyd Frankenberg, a poet critic and anthologist, died Wednesday at his home, 61 Perry Street. He was 67 years old.

title: A Delay In Giants' Move?
description: NEWARK, March 13Construction delays at the New Jersey Sports Complex are expected to prevent the New York Giants from moving into a 76,500Seat football stadium there before 1977.

title: Missing Americans: Hanoi Drops a Hint
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 In an exchange of letters between North Vietnam's Foreign Minister and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Hanoi has indicated publicly for the first time that it has information about Americans listed as missing in action in Southeast Asia.

title: In Memoriam
description: GALBIS,Carmen Dearest Carmen, ten years today, and either Mamy from Heaven, or Tia Elsa and I, from this valley of tears will never forget you. And keep loving you more every day.

title: Home of School Board Aide Bombed
description: The Canarsie home of a Senior Board of Education official, who is involved in a zoning plan that could send more black pupils into the heavily white Brooklyn community was firebombed early yesterday.

title: To Know Storm Losses, Nome Must Wait for a Thaw
description: NOME, Alaska, March 12 Four months ago a storm whipped in off the Bering Sea here and sent the needle on Hazel Renshaw's barometer clear down to the second R in Temperature. For 14 hours that unnamed hurricane, with winds up to 73 knots, tore at Nome's flimsy homes, tilled streets and basements with salt water and tossed rocks and huge chunks of sea ice around as if they were paper litter.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Because of a shortage of staff members, the New York City Buildings Department is averaging 1.5 inspections of elevators a year, while the code requires four a yeara building has a private maintenance company, in which case only two are prescribed.

title: Saul Epstein, Manufacturer And Philanthropist, 69, Dies
description: Saul L. Epstein, president and a founder of Interstate Container Corporation here, a manufacturer of corrugated containers, died Wednesday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived at 980 Fifth Avenue.

title: A.&P. Will Close 1,250 Stores Within Year to Improve Profits
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Campany, which operates the nation's largest chain of supermarkets, announced yesterday that it planned to close about 1,250 of its 3,500 stores within the next 12 months. It will also close supporting facilities such as warehouses and distribution points.

title: People and Business
description: Sheik Abdullah Tariki, one of the original and most vociferous advocates of nationalization of Westernowned oil operations by the petroleum producing nations, now indicates that the statetakeover process has gone far enough.

title: Westmoreland Says U.S. Ought to Bomb And Mine the North
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)  Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the former American commander in Vietnam, said today that it was too bad that President Ford did not have the authority to mine Haiphong Harbor in North Vietnam and use B52 bombers to hot Communist supply lines in Indochina.

title: The Dance: Pennsylvania Ballet Here
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet, so obviously destined to become one of this country's major ballet companies, returned to the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night for a run through Sunday afternoon.

title: Notes on People
description: About 100 demonstrators, mostly Arab students, disrupted a speech by President Ephraim Satzir of Israel Wednesday at the University of Michigan.

title: Transit Police Unit Agrees To Hold Revote on Job Bid
description: The executive committee of the transit police union voted 44 to 13 yesterday to conduct a second, balloting of the force's rank and file on whether they would work five extra tours of duty to save the jobs of 80 junior officers.

title: Girl's Elevator Death Prompts Inquiry
description: Two city agencies began a joint investigation yesterday into the death of a 6yearold girl who was killed Wednesday in an elevator that caused the death of another child two years ago.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Two weeks ago, a controversial series of regulations banning sex discrimination that could revolutionize the future of athletic programs in the nation's schools were sent to the White House for approval.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed legislation yesterday intended primarily to prohibit discrimination against women in obtaining credit. The measure, sponsored by the State Senate Preskient, Frank J. Dodd, Democrat of Essex County, bars discrimination in credit practices on the basis of race, religion, marital status or sex.

title: Racial Clash in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 13 (UPI)  About 85 students, some armed with bats, chains, scissors or knives, were arrested today after a clash between white and black pupils at Valley High School. The authorities said that the trouble started when about 50 white students gathered in a parking lot adjacent to the school grounds a few minutes before buses loaded with black students arrived from West Las Vegas. Dr. Cliff Lawrence, deputy superintendent of schools, said he had no reports of any serious injuries.

title: AID FOR CAMBODIA IS SET BACK ANEW IN CONGRESS VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The effort to rush military assistance to Cambodia received a double setback in Congress today when the House Foreign Affairs Committee rejected a compromise and Senate Democrats voted overwhelmingly against any additional aid.

title: Kurdish Truce Broken
description: Kurdish rebels and the Iraqi Government agreed on a ceasefire, but fighting is continuing, Kurdish sources reported. Details on Page 3.

title: ROCKEFELLER AIDE ASSAILS PEYSER
description: One of Vice President Rockefeller's closest advisers has sharply rebuked Representative Peter Peyser of Westchester County, a potential Republican challenger of Senator James L. Buckleyquestioning Mr. Peyser's integrity and even fitness to hold public office.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON THEIR TOES A free daylong program of dance events and exhibitions called Invitation to the Dance takes place today on the lobby floor of the Y.W. C.A. headquarters building, 30 Third Avenue at Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, cosponsored by the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Women Golfers Quit Tour Event
description: HOUSTON, March 13 (AP) Members of the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tour voted overwhelmingly tonight not to play in the scheduled $100,000 L.P.G.A. tournament, saying its sponsor had failed to put up the prize money.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Decoy Show to Cite Weiler
description: One of the attractions at the 1975 United States National Decoy Show at the American Legion Hall, Babylon, L.I., from noon on March 22 through March 23, will be a display in tribute to the late Milton C. Weiler of Garden City, L.I.

title: Minnesota, Mich. Tech Gain Final
description: ST. LOUIS, March 13 For the third consecutive year it will be an allWest final in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament as Minnesota defeated Harvard, 64, and Michigan Tech crushed Boston University, 95, tonight.

title: Money Supply Up Again; Treasury Borrows Billion
description: The money supply increased for the second week in a row; business loans shrank once again, and the United States Treasury, pressed for cash, had to borrow more than $1billion to tide it over until corporate income taxes begin to flow in.

title: UConn Poloists Beaten by 2515
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 13 The University of California at Davis, playing in the tournament for the first time, defeated the University of Connecticut, the titleholder the last three years, 2515, tonight in a semifinal of the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Proxmire On Love
description: Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin has discovered that the National Science Foundation is spending $83,000 a year out of the Federal Treasury to find out why people fall in love, and he wants it stopped. Not the love but the spending. Biggest boondoggle of the year, he says. I don't want the answer.

title: Era Vanishes With Monmouth Hotel
description: SPRING LAKE, March 13A giant steel wrecker's pendulum bashed away today at the remnants of the seaside hostelry known to generations of vacationers as the Monmouth Hotel.

title: GOLDMAN CHARGED WITH DEFRAUDING CITY OF $500,000
description: Irving Goldman, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissoner and head of the Shubert realestate and theater interests, has been indicted on felony charges accusing him of defrauding the New York City Transit Authority of more than $500,000 and stealing $225,000 from a vending machine company.

title: Limited SST Use Called No Danger By Head of E.P.A.
description: There would be no peril to the environment of New York or Washington if one or two supersonic transport planes a day landed at either city, according to Russel E. Train, Federal. Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: Nets Pin Defeat On Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 13 (UPI)Larry Kenon and Julius Erving took turns blitzing San Antonio for a combined 57 points tonight and the New York Nets went on to a 10894 victory over the Spurs in the American Basketball Association.

title: LOUIS S. STAMM
description: Louis S. Stamm, president and chairman of the board of Credit Exchange Inc., a creditchecking and collecting agency serving apparel manufacturers, died Wednesday in Bal Harbor, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 70 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Beame Forges an Accord On City's Capital Budget
description: In a grinding fourandahalfhour meeting at Gracie Mansion that ended at 2:30 A.M. yesterday, Mayor Beame convinced Board of Estimate members and City Council leaders to compromise and agree on a $1.95billion capital budget.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: F.B.I. Tells Agents Not to Trust Book on Luciano
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Bureau of Investigation has advised its heads of organized units throughout the country to discount information about the Mafia contained in The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano, a new book on the late Mafia boss.

title: RUBELLA VACCINE CALLED EFFECTIVE
description: The widespread use of rubella vaccine, licensed in this country in 1969, appears to have broken the epidemic cycle of this disease, which in its last peak 11 years ago caused severe birth defects in more than 20,000 American children, an expert on rubella said here yesterday.

title: Labor Lobbying Group Assails State at Hearing
description: NEWARK, March 13The New Jersey Alliance for Action, a newly formed lobbying group for organized labor and the construction industry in the state, told Governor Byrne's Capital Needs Commission today that for all practical purposes, the state is broke.

title: Study on Merger Of Exchanges Set
description: The New York Stock Exchange, responding to a growing clamor for costcutting, named a fiveman industry committee yesterday to study the feasibility of a merger between the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

title: Kissinger Gets New Ideas From Sadat for Israelis
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 13Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight that he had received new ideas from President Anwar elSadat that should elicit responses from Israel and advance the negotiations for an EgyptianIsraeli disengagement in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Cambodian Refugees Just Want Peace and a Return Home
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 13Early on the morning of Jan. 1, soon after the Communistlid insurgents' offensive of the 1975 dry season began, their troops rolled through the village of Khleang Sbek, 15 miles northwest of Phnom Penh.

title: Money Tree
description: The guilty plea of Maurice H. Stans, chief fundraiser for former President Nixon's campaigns, brings to a conclusion yet another of the series of Watergaterelated criminal prosecutions involving wellknown political figures.

title: Kissinger Gets New Ideas From Sadat for Israelis
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 13Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight that he had received new ideas from President Anwar elSadat that should elicit responses from Israel and advance the negotiations for an EgyptianIsraeli disengagement in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: British Group Says Wilson Has Failed on Inflation
description: LONDON, March 13One of Britain's most respected economic research organizations charged today that the Government of Prime Minister Wilson had failed in its struggle to contain inflation.

title: Article 1  No Title
Ulster Terrorists Kill 2, Wound 14 in Attack on Bar
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 13 (AP)Terrorists burst into a crowded Roman Catholicowned bar in Belfast's northern suburbs tonight, sprayed it with gunfire and hurled a bomb that killed at least two persons and wounded 14, the British Army said.

title: North Vietnamese Capture Almost All of Highland City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 14North Vietnamese troops have captured almost the entire city of Ban Me Thuot, and Government reinforcements are gathering north of town for an eventual effort to retake it, Western and Vietnamese informants said last night.

title: Miss Fonda Gets Telegram
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13Jane Fonda and Tom Hayden, who have been active in protests against United States involvement in Southeast Asia, said today that they had received a telegram from Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the titular head of the Cambodian insurgent movement, advising the United States to terminate military aid to the Lori Nol Government quickly or face isolation from the rebel forces that are expected to overthrow the present regime.

title: C.I.A. Link to Hughes Reported Disclosed by Burglary on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13 Safecrackers who looted Howard Hughes's Romaine Street headquarters here last year got documents that disclosed relations between the Central IntelIigence Agency and Mr. Hughes's Summa Corporation, according to sources connected with the investigation.

title: Nazis Picketed in Boston
description: BOSTON, March 13 (AP)More than 30 residents of South Boston, a center of resistance to courtordered school busing, picketed in front of the American Nazi party's office today to demonstrate opposition to the party's presence in their neighborhood.

title: Indian Trial Judge Removes Himself From New Cases
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., March 13 (UPI)United States District Judge Fred Nichol, who last fall dismissed Wounded Knee charges against Dennis Banks and Russell Means, removed himself today from presiding over any additional trials involving charges stemming from the 1973 occupation of the Pine Ridge Reservation village.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Six city inspectors were arraigned in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on charges they had received bribes over a twoyear period in connection with the building of two bank branches in the borough. District Attorney Mario Merola said four of the defendants were with the Buildings Department and two were with the city's Highway Department. The four employed by the Buildings Department were identified as Raymond G. Coffey, 146 Deepdale Avenue, Little Neck, Queens; Frank C. Biondi, of Yonkers; Albert Tedeschi, 2881 LaSalle Avenue, the Bronx, and Philip Mailson, 192 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx. Thewo employed by the Highway Department are Robert J. Hagerty of New Paltz, N.Y., and Daniel Russo, 21449 43d Avenue, Bayside, Queens.

title: Senate Inquiry Scans Charges Against Health Plans on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations began today two days of hearings into alleged profiteering and substandard services in Medicaidfinanced prepaid health plans of Southern California.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kinesiology Class Will Come to Order
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 13Walter Alston said Mike Marshall was still up at Michigan State teaching kinesiology and working or his doctorate in physiological psychology but had sent word that he was joining the Dodgers Sunday and would expect to pitch Monday. For the world's least defatigable relief pitcher, spring training is a stern regimen consisting of unzipping his windbreaker. He is then ready to work in 106 games during the championship season, two during the pennant playoff and five during the World Series, onethird of the Dodgers' scheduled games, onehalf of their playoff games, and all their World Series games. At least, that satisfied him last year; he may demand more action this season. 1 had heard about how often he wanted to pitch and how often he could pitch, Alston said, and didn't have to add that he was content to wait and see for himself. In 1973 Marshall had set a major league record by appearing in 92 games, but that was for the Montreal Expos, who finished fourth in a sixteam division. Could any mortal carry such a load for a team racing cheekandjowl with Cincinnati's formidable Reds? Alston's selfdeprecating grin said: Did I find out? Did I ever!

title: IraqKurdish Fighting Said to Continue Despite 2Week Truce Asked by Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 13Kurdish rebels and the Iraqi Government have agreed on a ceasefire which was to begin this morning, but fighting is continuing on Mount Handran and elsewhere, Kurdish sources reported here today.

title: STOCK PRICES UP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market ended higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Racers Defeat Toros
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 13 (AP)Bob Whitlock and Bucky Buchanan each scored two goals tonight, with Buchanan's second breaking a 44 tie and lifting the Indianapolis Racers to a 54 World Hockey Association victory over the Toronto Toros.

title: Piercing OPEC's Cellophane Wrapper
description: The Arabs tried to do us a big favor in October, 1973, but unfortunately we didn't appreciate it. When they imposed the boycott, they finally alerted us to the unalterable fact that we were dependent on them hook, line and sinker. That was the moment when we should have forcefully rallied to the protection and defense of our future stability. That was the moment for us to begin massive conservation and development programs and not to wait eagerly for a lifting of the oil embargo.

title: $64,000 QUESTION WILL RETURN TO TV
description: The $64,000 Question, one of the most successful bigmoney giveaway shows of the late nineteenfifties, will be rerevived on television and syndicated in the fall of 1976, with three of the stations owned by CBSTV as the nucleus for countrywide coverage.

title: MOVE TO KILL S.C.I. SEEMS TO BE OVER
description: TRENTON, March 13The budget watchers and the critics on the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee appeared today to hive all but abandoned their effort to abolish the State Commission of Investigation, which has been under recent criticism.

title: W. F. MEISTER, AIDE OF HISTORY MUSEUM
description: Walter F. Meister, former assistant director and controller of the American Museum of Natural History, died yesterday at his apartment in the New York Athletic Club. He was 73 years old.

title: F.D.A. HEAD ASSAILS PACEMAKER RULES
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, said today that the regulation by his agency of cardiac pacemakers was less than it should be.

title: S.E.C.'s COMPLAINTS RESTRICTED TO U.S.
description: NEWARK March 13 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that Americans who commit stock fraud in foreign countries cannot be sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission if the public in the United States is not hurt by the wrongdoing.

title: School Board Member Remains Oldest in State
description: GLOUCESTER CITY, March 13John A. Lynch, who joined the school board here in 1935 and has been its president since 1953, will remain the oldest school board member in the state.

title: North Vietnamese Capture Almost Allot Highland City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 14North Vietnamese troops have captured almost the entire city of Ban Me Thuot, and Government reinforcements are gathering north of town for an eventual effort to retake it, Western and Vietnamese informants said last night.

title: Shell Hits Munitions Dump At Phnom Penh's Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 13Insurgent gunners scored a direct hit on an ammunition dump at this capital's airport today, forcing a temporary suspension of the American airlift from Thailand arid South Vietnam that is supplying Phnom Penh.

title: Penn State, Baylor Cash In
description: DALLAS, March 13 (UPI)Baylor and Penn State will split a record $1million for their 1975 Cotton Bowl game.

title: 2 London Dailies Raise Price
description: LONDON, March 13 (AP)Two of Britain's eight national daily newspapers, The Daily Telegraph and The Daily Mail, will raise their prices Monday because of higher costs.

title: A Bus Driver Really Rides Passengers
description: There's a good show in town these days and it only costs 35 cents.

title: $2,000 HomeCost Credit Is Added to TaxCut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate Finance Committee added a new provision to the antirecession tax cut bill today that would have the effect of cutting as much as $2,000 from the purchase price of A house bought between April 1 and the end of this year.

title: The Pop Life
description: Ever since the astonishing success of Tapestry (13million copies sold so far), Carole King's records have been something of a letdown, perhaps inevitably so. She seemed to be working in much the same idiom as Tapestry, dealing in the same themes with the same sort of music, only paler than before.

title: Effort in Turkey to Form Cabinet Fails
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 13 (Reuters)The latest efforts by Premier Sadi Irmak to form a government failed today.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: From the bus window going down Second Avenue the other day it seemed to me that every second address was a restaurant. Back home, I set about estimating the number of restaurants in Manhattan by checking the Yellow Pages and came up with the figure 6,900. Possibly I misplaced a decimal and it is 69,000. But it sure isn't 690.

title: Consumerism, Limited
description: The long fight to establish an independent agency to defend the interests of consumers in proceedings before Federal regulatory bodies and courts has moved an important step closer to victory in the Senate. The 11to1 vote by which the consumer advocate bill was approved in committee this week measurably reduces the danger that it can be killed by filibuster, the fate that befell it on the Senate floor last year.

title: GURNEY WITNESS TRACES FUND ROLE
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 13 (UPI) The first witness in the briberyconspiracy trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney testified today that he had been a willing participant in a political fundraising scheme for the Florida Republican.

title: Susan Ford's Prom Is Set For White House May 31
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)Susan Ford has obtained her parents' permission to hold her high school senior prom at the White House.

title: In San Francisco They Love TeenAger With a Snake
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13Tammy Van Upp and her mother, Arden, live here in an immense 28room mansion on Pacific Heights with five green frogs, two large gecko lizards that look like stuffed animals covered in corduroy, and a 6foot python named Gideon who doesn't look like anything but a mean old snake.

title: HAMILTON'S SALE PLANNED BY I.T.T.
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the Oppenheimer Management Corporation and the directors of the Hamilton Funds announced yesterday that I.T.T. and Oppenheimer had reached a preliminary agreement providing for the sale by I.T.T. to Oppenheimer of the Hamilton Management Corporation.

title: Abel Urges Labor To Move Together To Revive Economy
description: I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said last night that the country's economy was worsening at a frightening speed, but that the condition is manmade and could be undone by man.

title: Strip Mine Bill Opposed
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 13 (UPI)  A coal strip mine control bill that was approved yesterday by the United States Senate would reduce national coal production by up to 100 million tons a year and shatter hopes of achieving energy selfsufficiency, Ben Lusk, president of the West Virginia Surface mine and Reclamation Association, said today.

title: As Inflation Slows in Italy, Forecasts Become Brighter
description: ROME, March 13Italian leaders and experts are publicly debating these days whether this nation is still the sick man of Europe or is well on the road toward economic recovery.

title: In a Changing Society, Manners Change, Too
description: New York, a city that never was in the same league with the Old South or the court of Louis XIV when it came to the niceties of etiquette, is undergoing, along with other places, changes in what passes for courtesy.

title: House Panel Backs Bill On Naval Oil Production
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The House Interior Committee approved today a bill that would authorize fullscale oil production from naval petroleum reserves Nos. 1, 2 and 3 and also transfer jurisdiction over the reserves to the Interior Department.

title: People in Sports
description: Forget about that deal that might have put Dick Allen back in a Philadelphia uniform. Paul Owens, the director of player personnel of the National League Club, and Eddie Robinson, the executive vice president of the Atlanta Braves, who own Allen's contract said the negotiations had been dropped. The Braves wanted Greg Luzinski, an outfielder in exchange for Allen, one of baseball's highest paid stars. Owens thought they were asking too much for only a probable.

title: TAPED BRIBE DEALS PLAYED FOR JURY
description: NEWARK, March 13Listening to a series of dramatic tae recordings, jurors in Federal court here today heard Mayor Burt Ross of Fort Lee accept $100,000, reportedly the first part of a halfmilliondollar bribe, from two men who were unaware that the transaction was being recorded.

title: E.E.C. Planning to Buy Sugar on World Market
description: BRUSSELS, March 13 (AP)The European Economic Community's commission announced today that it had authorized the purchase of 66,300 metric tons of sugar on the world market.

title: $2,000 HomeCost Credit is Add to TaxCut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate Financ Committee added a new provision to the antirecession tax cut bill today that maid have the effect of cutting as much as $2,000 from the purchase price of house bought between April 1 and the end of this year.

title: DOW DECLINES 0.71 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking continued to weaken stock prices yesterday for the third consecutive session as volume decreased.

title: Advertising
description: Advertising revenues of television stations will continue to grow this year but at a steadily declining rate, according to a research report by Goldman, Sachs & Co., the investment banking firm.

title: Bus Passengers Get Real Riding On West Side
description: There's a good show in town these days and it only costs 35 cents.

title: Los Angeles Official Balks At $1Million Swiss Claim
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13 (UPI)The city should refuse to pay a Swiss bank's claim for $1million that was swindled in an allegedly Mafiabacked scheme using stolen municipal treasury checks, the city attorney says.

title: Siamese Twins, Joined At the Skull, Separated
description: PARIS, March 13 (Reuters)French doctors have performed what is said to be the world's first successful operation to separate Siamese twins joined at the skull.

title: Court Tells H.E.W to Enforce School Integration in 16 States
description: WASHINGTON, March 14A Federal district judge ordered the Government today to move quickly to enforce school desegregation requirements in 125 school districts in 16 Southern and Border states.

title: Two Sentenced in Bribe
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 (AP)The chairman of the Dracut Board of Selectmen and a former selectman have been sentenced to one year in jail for accepting a bribe. Dexter Dutney, 62 years old, the chairman, and Leo Grondine, 60, were sentenced yesterday in Middlesex Superior Court by Judge Paul Rutledge.

title: Gasoline Prices Here Show Slight Decline
description: The average retail price of gasoline in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area dropped slightly in January, but producers are continuing to sell gasoline in this area at the secondhighest prices on the nation's mainland, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Flames Defeat Rangers, 1 to 0
description: ATLANTA, March 14After cutting down the pursuit of the New York Islanders last Tuesday, the Rangers continued to show no mercy for their Nassau County rivals tonight by losing 10, to the Atlanta Flames. The victory put Atlanta within 4 points of the thirdplace Islanders and a playoff spot in the Patrick Division.

title: North Vietnamese Troops Step Up Attacks to Isolate Tay Ninh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 15North Vietnamese tanks and troops attacked outposts southeast of the key city of Tay Ninh today, stepping up the drive to isolate the province capital, 65 miles northwest of Saigon, the South Vietnamese command said today.

title: Bridge:
description: HONOLULU, March 14 New York experts began the defense of their titles here tonight at the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships.

title: F.T.C. Curbs Philippines Flights For Cures by Psychic Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)A Federal Trade Commission today ordered three West Coast travel agencies to stop promoting tours to the Philippines for miraculous cures through socalled psychic surgery.

title: Market Place
description: Last summer when interest rates were high the First National City Bank brought out a novel issue of floatingrate notes.

title: School Paddling Inquiry Leads to Suspension of 2
description: The principal and acting assistant principal of a Bronx elementary school were suspended yesterday as a result of a Board of Education report charging that the school had covered up acts of corporal punishment against pupils and was the scene of other irregularities.

title: Iowa Puts 4 in Finals, Nears First N.C.A.A. Mat Title
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 14Led by Dan Holm, Iowa, the Big Ten champion, virtually clinched its first N.C.A.A. wrestling championship tonight at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: British Trade Gap Increases Slightly, But Hope Prevails
description: LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) Britain announced today an international trade deficit for February of $657.8  million, slightly wider than the month before but continuing an encouraging trend.

title: A Disturbing Case of Happiness
description: We spent a few minutes the other day in the courtroom of the Society of Suitable Writers, an organization which licenses literary people, as well as authors and hacks, to ply their craft throughout the United States, and which also, on occasion, disciplines members found to be in violation of the society's code.

title: Riches Lie Remote and Untouched In the Central African Republic
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, March 9Choruses of women in brocade or silverlame evening gowns sang Home on the Range and a newer song, Great Marshal Bokassa. Mothers Love You.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS $29.2BILLION CUT IN 1975 TAX BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Senate Finance Committee finished work today on antirecession legislation that would reduce the taxes of individuals and corporations by $29.2billion this year and by smaller amounts in future years. Of the total tax cut for 1975, $21.2billion would go to individuals.

title: Sports Critic Reportedly Being Sought For Questioning About the Hearst Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Jack Scott, a writer and radical critic of the nation's organized sports system, reportedly is being sought for questioning about the whereabouts of Patricia Hearst.

title: Report on Human Fetal Studies Finds Work Saved Thousands
description: BETHESDA, Md., March 14Research involving the human fetus has helped save thousands of lives that would have been lost had such research been banned decades ago, according to a study made public today.

title: DISEASED BIRDS SOUGHT ON L. I.
description: BABYLON, L.I., March 14About 40 agents and veterinarians from the United States Department of Agriculture are tracking down birds in this area that are suspected of carrying a rare and fatal virus disorder called Newcastle disease, which affects both birds and poultry. The disease was detected a couple of weeks ago in a parrot at a Bay Shore aviary.

title: People and Business
description: The Federal Reserve Board, long the target of criticism from outside the banking system, is again getting its lumps, this time from within the banking fraternity itself, in the annual report of the First Pennsylvania Corporation.

title: Cambodians Unable to Penetrate Area Near Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Saturday, March 15Five columns of Government troops pushing from different directions toward the important Cambodian town of Tuol Leap failed to make substantial progress yesterday. The area is essential to the security of Phnom Penh's airport.

title: HEAD OF AMTRAK ASSAILS HEARINGS
description: The president of Amtrak, Paul H, Reistrup, charged yesterday that what he termed publicityseeking hearings by the Interstate Commerce Commission into rail passenger service had created a false impression of conditions on Amtrak trains and caused a substantial decline in ridership.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nassau County may lay off about 450 municipal employes if the Board of Supervisors gives the 12,500 members of the Civil Service Employes Association more than the 4 per cent increase recommended by the County Executive, according to an informant in the Executive's office.

title: Sports Critic Reportedly Being Sought For Questioning About the Hearst Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Jack Scott, a writer and radical critic of the nation's organized sports system, reportedly is being sought for questioning about the whereabouts of Patricia Hearst.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, March 14 (AP)Players on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour who canceled a $100,000 tournament this weekend because the sponsors, the Gulf Coast Golf News, failed to provide the purse, got a consolation prize today. A proamateur tournament that will include 66 of the L.P.G.A. members who paid their way to Houston, has been scheduled for Sunday. The announcement of the proam event was made by Rosemary Kercheval, the president of Women's Golf Charities, Inc.

title: Investigation Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Donald C. Alexander, the Conlmissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that he was investigating allegations, Mrs. Suarez that she ha been employed by the Service in 1972 to spy on political figures.

title: REVLON SETS A DEAL FOR COBURN OPTICAL
description: Revlon, Inc.. and Coburn Optical Industries, Inc., announced jointly yesterday an agreement in principle for the acquisition of Coburn by Revlon.

title: New Falls Student Found Safe; 2 Men Accused of Kidnapping
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 14 (UPI)A Purdue Uni??ersity woman student from New Jersey who vanished mys??riously nearly a month ago ??as found safe in Minnesota ?? Thursday. A college assistant professor and a student, both from Minnesota, were held on kidnap charges.

title: Jersey Democrats' Dinner, Here Is Showcase for 1976 Hopefuls
description: One veteran New Jersey Democrat looked around the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night and said, This is the first time I've seen dancing at a political dinner.

title: TALKS SET FOR TODAY IN INTERNES' DISPUTE
description: Negotiators for the League of Voluntary Hospitals and the Committee of Interns and Residents are scheduled to meet at 2 P.M. today at the Biltmore Hotel in an effort to resolve their differences and avert a strike threatened for Monday.

title: RALLY IN LISBON HAILS TAKEOVER OF BANK SYSTEM
description: LISBON, March 14  Thousands of Portuguese gathered in the rain here tonight to cheer a Government decision to nationalize the banking system, and Premier Vasco dos Santos Gonalves said that it was the first firm, irreversible step to place the economy at the service of the people.

title: Court Tells H. E. W. to Enforce School Integration in 16 States
description: WASHINGTON, March 14A Federal district judge ordered the Government today to move quickly to enforce school desegregation requirements in 125 school districts in 16 Southern and Border states.

title: DOW STOCK INDEX CLIMBS BY 10.49
description: The stock market posted a sharp advance yesterday on encouraging developments for the market.

title: Frazier Sinks Rockets4th Straight
description: HOUSTON, March 14The Knicks have finally, climbed even with the Cleveland Cavaliers in their battle for a wildcard playoff spot in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division. They did it by defeating the Houston Rockets tonight 10394, before 9,471 fans, the largest Rocket crowd of the season.

title: PAY REDUCED 10% BY REA EXPRESS
description: REA Express, Inc., a major private delivery service, is cutting the paychecks of 11,000 employetis by 10 per cent as part of a bankruptcy reorganization plan, The Associated Press reported that the company said yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
General Mills Reports a 6.9% Profit Rise
ISRAEL INDICATES A COOL REACTION TO EGYPT'S IDEAS
description: JERUSALEM, March 14An Israeli official said today that Egypt's latest ideas for a new Sinai agreement fell short of what was needed for an accord but added that he expected Israel to give Secretary of State Kissinger concrete views of her own to keep the negotiations going.

title: A.T.&T. and Others Sign New Agreement On Communications
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and several other communications common carriers have signed and filed with the Federal Communications Commission an agreement under which Bell System companies would provide communications facilities to the other carriers.

title: President Again Asks Congress To Act on Economy and Energy
description: WASHINGTON, March 14President Ford, continuing to prod Congress to move faster on economic and energy legislation, said today that he and the American people now wait for the Congress to catch up with us.

title: California Poll Finds Public Has Mixed Feelings on Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 (UPI)  The California Poll reported today that it had found mixed emotions toward former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 15, 1975

title: T.W.A. MECHANICS ACCEPT CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)  Trans World Airlines mechanics and ramp servicemen have approved a new contract raising their salary more than $1 an hour and giving them $21.7million in back pay, the International. Association of Machinists said today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Susan Hayward Dies

title: Egyptians Weigh Commissions With Israelis to Meet in Sinai
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 14Egypt is considering the possibility of EgyptianIsraeli military commissions to meet in the United Nations buffer zone on the Sinai front, and has, discussed this possibility with Secretary of State Kissinger, Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy said tonight.

title: June Primary
description: New York Republicans apparently have learned nothing from their colossal miscalculation last year when they switched the state's primary election date from June to September, hopeful that their Democratic foes would tear each other apart In a prolonged primary campaign that would enable Gov. Malcolm Wilson and his G.O.P. legislative majority to retain control in Albany.

title: Coffee DeclineFewer Drinkers, Fewer Cups
description: The idea that a cup of coffee can be a warm, stimulating experience is stimulating fewer people to indulge in it these days. More Americans, particularly young Americans, are downing cold drinks, on the run, and when they do want coffee, research has found, they want it instantly and without caffeine.

title: Sally R. Denby Married to R. L. Hoffman
description: Sally Reed Denby, an assistant teacher at the Princeton (N. 3.) Day School, and Robert Lawrence Hoffman, mathematics teacher and athletic coach there, were married yesterday afternoon in New Hope, Pa. The Rev. Lawrence Seyler performed an Episcopal ceremony and Judge Isaac Garb of the Bucks County Court of Common Pleas performed a civil ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Metering of Water Is Urged to Avert Tapping of Hudson
description: Unless water meters are installed soon in New York City, the Hudson River will have to be developed as a water source to meet the needs of southeastern New York State, according to a report submitted to Governor Carey and leaders of the State Legislature.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Wagner's Siegfried, 1; Puccini's Manon Lescaul, 8.

title: The Perils of Caffeine
description: Classic symptoms of anxiety  headache, jitteriness, upset stomach, difficulty sleeping  may be due to drinking too many cups of coffee, according to reports in American and British medical journals.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Namath still has not signed with the New York Jets and may become a free agent on May 1, but the Jets will be sure of having an experienced passer in the lineup next season. Al Woodall, Namath's backur as signalcaller for five years, yesterday came to terms for last season and for 1975. He played the 1974 season without a contract.

title: Jeweler's Kidnapping Stirs Indignation in Rome
description: ROME, March 14The black metal shutters pulled down over Bulgari Jewelers' elegant storefront at the close of business yesterday remained lowered today.

title: Canada Begins a Debate on Immigration
description: OTTAWA, March 14  The Government called several dozen influential citizens together here today to begin what it hopes will be a comprehensive national debate on Canada's immigration policy.

title: GLADSTONE DIARY: SEXUAL PROBLEMS
description: LONDON, March 14William Ewart Gladstone, the Victorian Prime Minister, is portrayed in newly published diaries today as a man who not only enjoyed his rescue work among prostitutes but also derived pleasure from beating himself with a whip.

title: Exotic Bet Is Opposed By Drivers
description: Horse racing's exoticbet controversy took a new twist yesterday when New York harness drivers objected to a request by Roosevelt Raceway and the Offtrack Betting Corporation for doubleexacta wagering.

title: Laos Halts Saigon Flights
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 14 (Reuters)The Laotian airline today idefinitely suspended its twiceweekly flights between here and Saigon.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, March 15

title: Antiques: Styles in Dolls
description: Not all of the 300 dolls crowding the shelves and the cases of Grace Dyar's booth at the Coliseum Antiques and Flower Show were the playthings of children. Crche figures and costume dolls are two types in this dealer's wideranging selection that were probably admired from afar and rarely fondled.

title: It's True, Carey Is All Blarney
description: ALBANY, March 14  Everything about the Irish is a myth, Governor Carey was saying the other night here, talking to a Hibernian Hall full of politicians poised over plates of corned beef and cabbage and pitchers of cold Harp beer.

title: Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo Is Dead; Indonesian Independence Leader
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14 (AP)Dr. All Sastroamidjojo, an early Indonesian nationalist and one of the leaders of the republic during its first two decades, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: The Biggest Deal of All
description: TEHERAN, IranIt is perhaps unprecedented that the commercial relationship between two countries should change so swiftly and so stunningly as that between the United Slates and Iran. Only a few years ago this rapidly developing country, whose eyes reflect neon lights even while its feet remain mired in mud, was on the list of lands desiring American generosity.

title: Notes on People
description: Although Valery Panov and Galina Ragozina, the ballet dancers, could not be there to accept their award, the surprise presence of Aleksandr A. Galich, the dissident Russian poet and screenwriter, turned the award dinner of the Social Democrats, U.S.A. into a special celebration Thursday.

title: RAIL CROUP BARS ROCK ISLAND AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)  The United States Railway Association late tonight refused to reverse its decision denying the Rock Island Railroad a $30million loan the 122 year old railroad said was essential to stay in business.

title: Stage: New Drama at the Long Wharf
description: NEW HAVENThe Long Wharf Theater has long established for itself the reputation of being one of the country's best resident theaters, and it also has the reputation of being unsually hospitable to modern British drama. It does, however, present an occasional world premiere, and at present it is offering Richard Venture's You're Too Tall, But Come Back in Two Weeks.

title: New Commuter Cars Make Debut for M.T.A. in Bronx
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is introducing its latest type of airconditioned metropolitan commuter cars today at seven Bronx stations on the Penn Central's Harlem Line.

title: Snowfall Here Fails to Live Up to Ominous Predictions
description: After months of feinting, winter hurled a haymaker snowstorm at New York yesterdaybut missed.

title: Tim the Lucky
description: Just about everything is wrong with health care these days.

title: Leone Offers Fiscal Plan To Spur State's Economy
description: NEWARK, March 14State Treasurer Richard C. Leone said today that New Jersey should begin borrowing $300million a year to meet its future capital needs, and he suggested creating a five  year public works program totaling nearly $1.5billion.

title: ISRAEL INDICATES A COOL REACTION TO EGYPT'S IDEAS
description: JERUSALEM, March 14An Israeli official said today that Egypt's latest ideas for a new Sinai agreement fell short of what was needed for an accord but added that he expected Israel to give Secretary of State Kissinger concrete views of her own to keep the negotiations going.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Citing Poor TV News Coverage, Byrne Will Challenge Licenses
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, March 14 (AP)Governor Byrne said today that he planned to oppose license renewals for New York and Philadelphia television stations on the ground that they shortchange New Jersey on news and publicaffairs coverage.

title: S.E.M. Ensemble Offers Vocal Spark In Kitchen Concert
description: The S.E.M. Ensemble of Buffaloits director, Petr Kotik, once explained that the name doesn't really mean anything at allopened a series of four avantgarde concerts Thursday night at the Kitchen, 59 Wooster Street, with a program of music by Julius Eastman, an ensemble member.

title: Saudis End Link to Dollar; Oil Price Rise May Result
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14 (UPI)Saudi Arabia cut today the ties of her monetary unit, the riyal, to the United States dollar and raised Its value by 2.3 per cent in relation to the American currency. The move could mean higher oil prices.

title: Several Hundred Texans Are at War With Army Over Land at Fort Hood
description: GATESVILLE, Tex., March 14Deep down, the squabble that began in these central Texas chalk hills last week is simple: The United. States Army wants to annex 60,000 acres adjacent to Fort Hood for additional tank training grounds. The rancherowners of the lane want to stay put. Congress will have to decide who wins.

title: Subway and Bus Service Faces Cuts as Riders Fall
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the. Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that service on some subway and bus routes would be reduced starting about April 1 because of a very marked loss of ridership.

title: Scrap Industry Thriving in Recession
description: The scrap steel and iron industry, the leading recycler in the age of obsolescence, is one of the few industries that has thrived in the recession.

title: State Aide Tells of Suspicions On Finances of Nursing Homes
description: ROCHESTER, March 14Financial arrangements proposed for some nursing homes in this area and in the New York metropolitan area were so complicated that they aroused his suspicions, a research analyst for the State Health Department testified today.

title: Mao's Failure to Receive Visitors Is Laid to a Cold
description: PEKING, March 14 (Reuters) Prime Minister Forbes Burnham of Guyana said today that Chinese officials had told him he could not see Chairman Mao Tsetung because the 81yearold Chinese leader was suffering from a cold.

title: Denver's Surge in 4th Period Is Decisive
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 14Dave DeBusschere, who knows all about the pressure of a championship season, put it this way before tonight's New York Nets Denver Nuggets basketball game.

title: ExGov. Hall Guilty In Oklahoma Deal
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 14 A Federal jury convicted former Gov. David Hall on four counts of bribery and extortion late today. W. W. Taylor, a Dallas mortgage broker, was also convicted.

title: DEUCE COUPE GETS TUNEUP BY JOFFREY
description: When Twyla Tharp's Deuce Coupe muscled its fliply arrogant and elegant way into the City Center Joffrey Ballet's repertory two years ago, it became an overnight sensation.

title: New Drive in Vietnam
description: North Vietnamese tanks and troops attacked outposts near the key city of Tay Ninh, the South Vietnamese command said, stepping up a drive to isolate the provincial capital 65 miles northwest of Saigon. Details on Page 2.

title: Susan Hayward Dies at 55; OscarWinning Movie Star
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14 (AP)Susan Hayward, the redhaired actress who won a 1958 Academy Award for her role in I Want to Live, died today at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 55 years old.

title: Patricia Hearst Clue Stirs Village in Poconos
description: SOUTH CANAAN, Pa., March 14A raw wind out of the north sliced up the long hill behind the little house, swirling the snow against the base of the barn and jingling the rusting chains of an old swing in the yard.

title: Plot to Bilk a Corporation Charged in Fort Lee Case
description: NEWARK, March 14An alleged realestate scheme by which millions of dollars of corporate funds were siphoned off by officers of the nowbankrupt Investors Funding Corporation to cover bad company debts and such personal expenses as a Manhattan town house was outlined in Federal District court here today by United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RISE CONTINUING IN AUTO LAYOFFS
description: DETROIT, March 14  Although the United States auto ndustry maintains that its longrange outlook is becoming brighter, layoffs will climb lightly next week to 223,340 workers from 214,620 this week.

title: Charges May Upset Plan For Grossi to Quit Post
description: A reputed gentleman's agreement between Governor Byrne and Anthony J. Grossi, the embattled president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, under which Mr. Grossi reluctantly agreed to serve no more than one year in office, now threatens to be undone by corruption charges made against Mr. Grossi.

title: Aid Disgrace (cont'd)
description: When Representative Otto E. Passman of Louisiana finally got around to shaping a $3.5billion foreign aid appropriation for this fading fiscal year, his philosophy reflected the conviction that foreign assistance is largely the extension overseas of the narrowest vision of American selfinterest.

title: China's Pay Inequity Seems Under Review
description: HONG KONG, March 14Fragmentary evidence suggests that a major reassessment of the Chinese wage structure is under way and that officials and managerial personnel may be facing reductions as they did during the Cultural Revolution, when Chairman Mao Tsetung himself was said to have taken an exemplary 20 per cent cut.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPINNERS What's your preferenceBritish dancing in Manhattan or African dancing in Queens?

title: Broncos Raid W.F.L.
description: DENVER, March 14 (AP)The Denver Broncos of the National Football League signed today Jack Dolbin, a wide receiver who caught 54 passes for the Chicago Fire of the World Football League last season.

title: Industrial Output Is Down For Filth Month in a Row
description: In a reflection of the deepening recession, the nation's industrial production declined in February for the fifth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported from Washington yesterday.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS $29.2BILLION CUT IN 1975 TAX BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Senate Finance Committee finished work today on antirecession legislation that would reduce the taxes of individuals and corporations by $29.2billion this year and by smaller amounts in future years. Of the total tax cut for 1975, $21.2billion would go to individuals.

title: Striking Doctors
description: Monday morning has been set as deadline for a strike of unionized interns and residents in some of the city's largest voluntary hospitals. The doctors are objecting to work schedules that run to 100 hours a week, sometimes with uninterrupted duty stretches of 35 to 50 hours.

title: Proposed Districts
description: The following is a list of proposed Nassau County legislative districts, with the names of some of the major communities:

title: SHOP TALK
description: The knitted hangings of Mary Walker Phillips are a far cry from the ski sweater your Aunt Susie may have made you for Christmas. Her work emphatically contradicts the usual concept of knitting as a practical pastime rather than an artisan's craft.

title: Indiana Heads a Field of 32 in N.C.A.A.
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14There are enough new aspects to the 37th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament that starts tomorrow and enough controversy to presage one of the most interesting championships since the first title playoff in 1939.

title: Subway and Bus Service Faces Cuts as Riders Fall
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that service on some subway and bus routes would be reduced starting about April 1 because of a very marked loss of ridership.

title: ORVIS AIDES ASSERT GUILT IN CONSPIRACY
description: Two partners in the defunct stock brokerage firm of Orvis Brothers & Co. pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to overstate the firms net capital and other securities violations, United Press International report.

title: New Jersey Briefs.
description: The Atlantic City Commissioners slashed $885,000 from their proposed budgets in a move they said would reduce a 50cent propertytax rise to a dime. The economy measures were accompanied by layoffs for about two dozen city employes and early retirement for 10 others. Several commissioners expressed hope that the laidoff workers, including a dozen special policemen, would be rehired shortly with Federal funds. The savings include a $85,000 cut in city charities. Mayor Joseph F. Bradway Jr. halved the city's $125,000 contribution to the Atlantic City Medical Center and eliminated grants of $10,000 for a drugtreatment program and $8,300 for Atlantic Human Resources, which aids the needy and minorities.

title: Court Rules F. P. C. Exceeded Authority
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ruled that the Federal Power Commission illegally exceeded its authority in exempting sales of natural gas from normal Federal regulation for six months during the 197374 winter energy crisis.

title: Morton to Shift on Outer Continental Shelf Search
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Under intense pressure from Congress and the Coastal States Governors, Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton disclosed today that he was prepared to make radical changes in the 20yearold system for oil and gas exploration and development by private industry on the Outer Continental Shelf.

title: KEEVE M. SIEGEL, 52, ENGINEER, PHYSICIST
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Keeve M. Siegel, mathematician, engineer and physicist, died at the George Washington University Hospital here today after being stricken with a stroke yesterday while testifying before the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy. He was 52 years old.

title: In Rio, the Message Is Down With Machismo
description: RIO DE JANEIROPerhaps nowhere in the world is the density of feminine charm as high as in Rio's resort suburb of Copacabana. Rain or shine, workdays or weekends, there's a yearround parade of bronzed, lanky, highly attractive women, garnished with minuscule bikinis or tangas, that Brazilian invention most Americans know as The String.

title: ALFRED HAIGHT, 63, WAS LEVITT DEPUTY
description: Alfred W. Haight, first deputy controller of the State of New York, died last evening in a motel room in Buffalo. He was 63 years old and lived do Albany.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: LOS ANGELESFrankie Duarte, 119 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Jorge Altamirano, 121, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: HAVEN GILLESPIE, 87, COMPOSER, LYRICIST
description: Haven Gillespie, a composer and lyricist who wrote That Lucky Old Sun and some 900 other songs, died yesterday of cancer in Las Vegas, Nev., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: Miss Wenzel Takes Slalom
description: SUN VALLEY. Idaho, March 14Hanni Wenzel, the 20yearold skier who became a citizen of Liechtenstein only last year, continued today to keep that little European principality in skiing prominence.

title: Concert: Daphnis With Less Thrill
description: Maurice Ravel, the centennial of whose birth is being celebrated this year, is one of the oddest cases among composers of renown. A cool, meticulous and extraordinarily reticent man, he produced not only works that reflect that aspect of his temperament, such as the Sonatine and Le Tombeau de Couperin, but also other pieces that on the surface at least seem to be as feverish and ecstatic as anything by Scriabin.

title: Metering of Water Is Urged to Avert Tapping of Hudson
description: Unless water meters are installed soon in New York City, the Hudson River will have to be developed as a water source to meet the needs of southeastern New York State, according to a report submitted to Governor Carey and leaders of the State Legislature.

title: Cambodians Unable to Penetrate Area Near Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Saturday, March 15Five columns of Government troops pushing from different directions toward the important Cambodian town of Tuol Leap failed to make substantial progress yesterday. The area is essential to the security of Phnom Penh's airport.

title: Bit of Spain in Morocco Sure Old Tie Is Firm
description: CEUTAWe may be remote from Spain, said a publisher in this tiny enclave in northern Morocco, but we are not abandoned.

title: DON ALVARO IS SUNG BY THEYARD AT MET
description: The Metropolitan Opera is lucky to have a cadre of dependable, versatile young American singers who can take over when the visiting superstars depart. Among the busier tenors in the group is Harry Theyard, who sang his first Don Alvaro in Verdi's La Forza del Destino on Thursday night.

title: Snowfall Here Fails to Live Up to Ominous Predictions
description: After months of feinting, winter hurled a haymaker snowstorm at New York yesterdaybut missed.

title: Cordero Held to 2 Winners
description: At the Race Tracks

title: Toy Dog Given a Voice to Cheer Ill Children
description: NEWARK, March 14A toy dog found his voice at St. James Hospital today and is using it to help youngsters get over the trauma of being confined.

title: Lisbon's Real Coup
description: The new bid for power in Portugal by the Communistbacked military radicals strikes a blow at the oncehopeful prospects for political democracy. Elections for a constitutent assembly to draft a new constitution are still scheduled for April 12, and the official campaign is still slated to open next week, but both developments hav been substantially emptied of their meaning.

title: Book's of The Times
description: The trouble with history as autobiography is that it requires as much interest in the historiansubject as in the events he is narratingor, usually, even more. The nineteensixties are still too near to be viewed any way but darkly, flawed or at least distorted by the ragtag remnants of those passions and disillusionments that swept us all into the decade's dancing. So to read about those years we have to care about the person who is telling us, especially if he is really telling us about himself and his associates with history as ornament or afterthought.

title: FT. LEE CASE JURY TOLD OF A BILKING
description: NEWARK, March 14An alleged realestate scheme by which millions of dollars of corporate funds were siphoned off by officers of the nowbankrupt Investors Funding Corporation to cover had company debts and such personal ex??enses as a Manhattan town house was outlined in Federal District court here today by United States Attorney Jona??han L. Goldstein.

title: Blue Eagle Memories
description: The WIN button in all its red and white glory turned out to be a loser and it is being scrapped by those wellintentioned citizens who displayed it. Years from now button collectors will be hard put to remember that it stood for Whip Inflation Now. If only a button  slogan could substitute for a program.

title: BeckFitzGibbon Advance
description: SCARSDALE, March 14 John Beck of Mt. Kisco and Herb FitzGibbon of New York, the defending team, entered the third round of the 41st annual men's doubles platform tennis championship today at the Fox Meadow Club. Beck and FitzGibbon defeated Bill Schwartz and Steve Shane of Scarsdale, 62, 63.

title: It's True, Carey Is All Blarney
description: ALBANY, March 14  Everything about the Irish is a myth, Governor Carey was saying the other night here, talking to a Hibernian Hall full of politicians poised over plates of corned beef and cabbage and pitchers of cold Harp beer.

title: Norwegian Leads in Skiing
description: BAD MITTENDORF, Austria, March 14 (AP)  Fritjof Prirdz of Norway led the world ski flying championships after today's series of two jumps although Rainer Schmidt of East Germany had the longest leap of the day. Prydz's longest jump, 462 feet, was worth 173.5 points. Schmidt's best was 51.5 feet, but he was penalized for a poor landing and received 172 points.

title: 11 Die in Argentine Crash
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 14 (AP)The police, said that at least 11 persons were killed and 5 seriously injured today in a truckbus collision in bad weather 120 miles north of here.

title: Marden Art at the Guggenheim
description: The American painter Brice Marden, though not yet 40 years old (he was born in 1938), is already something a chef d' cole. The art journals follow his work with close attention. Younger painters, scarcely out of school, take his work as a model the way their counterparts once took Willem de Kooning's and Jasper Johns's and Frank Stella's. More than a few undisguised imitations of his style can be found in the current Whitney Biennial, and Mr. Marden's own work was represented in the museum of Modern Art's recent exhibition of Eight Contempoary Artists. He has exhibited in France, Italy and Germany, with similar effect, and a catalogue raisonn of his output to date is now being compiled. Not bad for an artist who had his first New York show in 1966.

title: Between Races With the Big A's Angel
description: Sports of The Times

title: Plans to Picket N.I.T. Here Canceled
Danger at Work
description: At least twenty deaths have been attributed to longtime exposure to vinyl chloride, a chemical widely used in the plastics industry.

title: LEO ADDE
description: MIAMI, March 14 (AP)Leo Adde, urban affairs reporter for The Miami Herald and formerly a newsman in Washington, died yesterday of cancer. He was 48 years old.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered sharp advances yesterday in much heavier trading.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

description: NEWARK, March 14A toy dog found its voice at St. James Hospital today and is using it to help youngsters get over the trauma of being confined.

title: PROTEST IN NAIROBI DISPERSED BY POLICE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 14 The police today dispersed with tear gas students who have been protesting the murder of Josiah Mwangi Kariuki, a popular politician known throughout Kenya as J.M.

description: Eleven years ago Ann and John Patrick Hagen bought 5.4 acres of land in Lacey Township on the Jersey shore, determined to fulfill their dream of combining rural and suburban life.

title: Cranking Up Oil Producers' AidGiving Machine
description: LONDONThe World Bank estimates that the increased cost of the current volume of oil imports for the nonoilproducing developing countries is $10 billion. This is equivalent to 15 per cent of their total import bill. For India, it is roughly the same as twothirds of her entire foreignexchange reserves and over 25 per cent of her total exports. Coming together with the rise in food prices and the slowdown in demand for exports because of the recession, the rise in oil prices has sent the third world reeling.

title: A Nassau Map Is Outlined For 15Seat Legislature
description: MINEOLA, LI., March 14Plans were outlined today for establishing a 15member Nassau County Legislature drawn from districts with equal populations.

Galich, the dissident Russian poet and screenwriter, turned the award dinner of the Social Democrats, U.S.A. into a special celebration Thursday.

title: ExGov. Hall Guilty In Oklahoma Deal
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 14 A Federal jury convicted former Gov. David Hall on four counts of bribery and extortion late today. W. W. Taylor, a Dallas mortgage broker, was also convicted.

title: GRAND JURY HERE FACES CHALLENGE
description: A lawyer representing 13 witnesses has challenged the constitutionality of a grand jury that is investigating the theft of $70million worth of heroin and cocaine from police custody on the ground that women were exempt from serving when the panel was formed more than two years ago.

description: LANDOVER, Md., March 14 (AP)Mark Cox upset firstseeded John Alexander tonight and joined Stan Smith in the Semifinals of a World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: ARAFAT STATEMENT CALLED A MISQUOTE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14 A denial has been issued here of a statement attributed by the editor of Saturday Review, Norman Cousins, to Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, about President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Business Briefs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 14 (AP)The Ford Motor Company agreed today to pay the Automatic Radio Manufacturing Company of Melrose, Mass., $6million in an outofcourt settlement on a 12yearold antitrust suit filed against Ford.

description: Governor Carey's task force on housing is expected to recommend repeal of the controversial vacancy  decontrol rent law, as well as to urge the enactment of legislation permitting New York City to adopt new rent laws of its own.

description: PASADENA, Calif., March 14 (UPI)Scientists struggled today to communicate with the Mariner 10 space mission, limping on perfect course for its record third sweep of the planet Mercury this Sunday but with its antenna painting the wrong way.

At this time of year a large number of hams move into retail channels for the Easter period, and as the inventories dwindle, they must be replaced by hog purchases.

title: Jumpers Sparkle At Meet
Dodgers Pin 87 Defeat On Yankees

The Yanks had taken a 54 lead in the last of the fifth on Alex Johnson's threerun homer. But the Dodgers came right back in the sixth. Singles by Joe Ferguson, Ron Cey and Willie Crawford scored one run. Steve Yeager's double sent another across and Auerbach's single past third base scored two more.
