description: Susan Hayward Dies

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 40 agents from the United States Agriculture Department are tracking down birds on Long Island that are suspected of carrying Newcastle disease, a fatal virus disorder that affects birds and poultry. The department has destroyed more than 500 birds, for which it paid owners and aviary operators $200 to $500 each. The Government has imposed a quarantine at nearly 100 homes and shops in New York State and Pennsylvania Where birdswere transported from an aviary in Bay Shore, L.I., where the disease was first spotted in a parrot.

description: The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that because of cable faults it was delaying until midnight next Friday the restoration of service it had planned for midnight tomorrow to 173,000 telephones in Manhattan that have been without service since a fire on Feb. 27.

description: The New York City Opera's new production of Strauss's Salome, visually gaudy and aurally muted, had a new protagonist Thursday night in Eileen Schauler. The soprano, always handsome, had reportedly slimmed down even further for the part. Certainly she looked beautiful, and the notorious Dance of the Seven Veils went smoothly, granted that this version is not very strenuous or orgiastic.

description: BUFFALO, March 14A lawyer representing Nelson A. Rockefeller argued here today that the Vice President should not be compelled to testify in a trial of two men charged with murdering an Attica prison guard because all Mr. Rockefeller knows of the 1971 inToident is hearsay that would be inadmissable as testimony.

description: TOKYO, March 14 (Reuters) The Sony corporation, noting that its inventories were returning to a normal level, said today it would suspend producthin curtailment starting in May. Sony has been curtailing production of color television sets and some other products by giving 8,000 of its 12,000 workers extra holidays at reduced pay, during the first four months of the year.

description: GENEVA, March 14Developing countries are to submit by May 16 lists of special concessions they hope to get at the world trade talks for their exports of tropical products to the industrialized nations.

description: ST. LOUIS, March 14Discharges by the Reserve Mining Company into Lake Superior constitute a potential threat to the public health, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit rulled here today.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS BAN ON BEERFLYING
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP)IThe White House has issued an order to end the practice of Secret Service agents of flying beer from the West to the capital, Administration sources said today.

title: LARUE SENTENCED TO 6MOTH TERM
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Frederick C. LaRue, once a power in the Nixon White House and the 1972 Nixon campaign and then a key prosecution witness at the Watergate coverup trial, was sentenced by Judge John J. Sirica today to six months in prison for his admitted role in the coverup.

title: STORM WASHES OUT PICKETING BY POLICE
description: PLEASANTVILLE March 14 (AP)  Rain and high winds washed out picket lines manned by offduty policemen alongside roadways here today as negotiations continued to resolve the officers' wage disnute.

title: LARUE SENTENCED TO 6MONTH TERM
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Frederick C. LaRue, once a power in the Nixon White House and the 1972 Nixon campaign and then a key prosecution witness at the Watergate coverup trial, was sentenced by Judge John J. Sirica today to six months in prison for his admitted role in the coverup.

title: Film: A New Neil Simon:'Prisoner of Second Avenue' Opens
description: If Neil Simon's adaptation of his 1971 Broadway hit, "The Prisoner of Second Avenue," which arrived at the Sutton yesterday, is less than an overpowering study of a married couple driven to distraction by the irritations and indignities of local middle-class living, it still scores valid points, both serious and funny. This time, the largely farcical kind of Manhattan madnesses Mr. Simon observed in his 1970 film, "The Out-of-Towners," have the impact of reality that has been humanely dulled by injections of relevant comedy.Comparisons are odious, but it should be noted that the play hasn't been changed appreciably in its transition to the screen. And, if Melvin Frank's direction is polished but not innovative, he is ably aided by a cast headed by Jack Lemmon and Anne Bancroft, who project forcefully natural characterization that are as realistic as the authentic Second Avenue and other New York sites caught by the color cameras.As in the original, New York is hardly a wonderful town for Mr. Simon's principals. Mr. Lemmon is frustrated and anxiety-ridden because of the faulty air-conditioning and inconsiderate neighbors in his high-rise apartment house, among other things. And, his fraying nerves aren't helped much when he is dismissed by his faltering firm. As a jobless ad executive, he cannot be blamed for railing at an unemployment office clerk. And he shouldn't be criticized for banging on fragile walls, cursing the neighbors, who douse him with water in retaliation, and developing neuroses inflamed by enforced idleness and visits to a non-committal psychiatrist.If Anne Bancroft, as his truly loving helpmate who resolutely gets a job to support them, becomes tense and confused to the point of paranoia, she, too, can't be faulted for her rising fears when she loses that job and must decide whether to accept financial help from her husband's concerned, if questioning, relatives.Mr. Lemmon, no stranger to Mr. Simon's work ("The Odd Couple," "The Out-of-Towners"), and Miss Bancroft are simply an unromanticized, believable team as recognizable in their comic and serious give-and-take as many of New York's scrambling millions. And they get sturdy, pointed support from Gene Saks, as Mr. Lemmon's well-to-do, plain-speaking but doting older brother and Elizabeth Wilson and Florence Stanley, as his careful-sisters, among others.They aren't involved in Greek tragedy or in common-place television situation comedy. Mr. Simon is serious about a theme that isn't earth-shaking and he understandably cloaks its gravity with genuine chuckles that pop up mostly as radio news bulletins such as the flash that a Polish freighter has just run into the Statue of Liberty. And, with a cast whose members appreciate what they're saying and doing, the gnawing problems of "Second Avenue" become a pleasure.

title: Art: Painted Melodramas From the Victorian Age
description: The Royal Academy (18371901) Revisited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is not what its title might, suggest: a thoughtout survey of English academic painting. It consists of 69 paintings that have been acquired for the collections of Forbes magazine since 1969. Most of them come from the London art market, where the taste for Victorian painting has been growing steadily over the last 20 years.

title: Out of Academic Ghettoes, Into the Mainstream
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y.A surprising majority of college students and faculty agree that only a small minority of the students get much of anything out of the courses they have come to take, but most of them don't complain because they can't think of anything letter for a person 18 to 22 years old to do.

title: CHAMBERS BROTHERS AND KOKOMO APPEAR
description: The Chambers Brothers, who opened Thursday at the Bottom Line and who will be there through tomorrow, are the name act on the club's bill. But the opening act, Kokomo, was more interesting.

title: Lykes Youngstown To Lay Off 1,200 At Plant in Ohio
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 14 (Reuters)  The Lykes Youngstown Corporation said today 1,200 employes would be laid off effective tomorrow at its Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company subsidiary.

Day School, and Robert, Lawrence Hoffman, mathematics teacher and athletic coach there, were married yesterday afternoon in New Hope, Pa. The Rev. Lawrence Seyler performed an Episcopal ceremony and Judge Isaac Garb of the Bucks County Court of Common Pleas performed a civil, ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Summer Season Cat By Jersey Symphony
description: NEWARK, March 14 (AP) New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's summer season has been canceled because of labor problems.

title: New Drive in Vietnam

title: Arabs Building Bahrain Complex to Repair Tankers

title: Coin Selector Devised To Verify Authenticity
description: WASHINGTON, March 14An electromagnetic method of checking the authenticity and denominations of coins was patented this week by Guy L. Fougere, a vice president of Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, Mass. The coin selector is covered by Patent 3,870,137. As assignee of this and other related patents, Mars Money Systems, Inc., of Folcroft, Pa., is manufacturing its coin changer trademarked Mars Electronic, which is used in vending and ticket machines in this country and Europe.

title: Irate Leftists Attack Echeverria At Mexico's National University
description: MEXICO CITY, March 14Angry antiGovernment disturbances greeted President Luis Echeverra Alvarez when he visited the National University here today. He was the first Mexican President to enter the campus in more than eight years.

title: Brown U. Students Rally for a Voice In Budget Planning
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 14Despite snow and rain, more than 2,000 Brown University students rallied on campus today to protest the school's budget  making systems and proposed cuts in financial aid, teaching faculty and student services.

title: Industrial Output Is Down For Fifth Month in a Row
description: In a reflection of the deepening recession, the nation's industrial production declined in February for the fifth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported from Washington yesterday.

title: Mets Rained Out
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 (AP)Joe Torre, a third baseman with the New York Mets was on crutches today with a sprained right ankle. The injury will keep him out of action at least 10 days.

title: U.S. Concerned at Lisbon's Swing Left
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Ford Administration expressed concern today over the leftward swing in Portugal.

title: Rights Proposed to Protect Patients in Nursing Homes
description: The American Jewish Congress called yesterday for the enactment of a bill of rights for patients in nursing homes that would, it said, strip away the prisonlike atmosphere of these institutions.

title: RALLY IN LISBON HAILS TAKEOVER OF BANK SYSTEM

title: Doctor Jazz Delayed

The musical about the birth of jazz in the Storyville section of New Orleans, opens at the Winter Garden under the sponsorship of Cyma Rubin. Bobby Van and Lola Falana head the cast.

title: Council Unit Scored for HospitalAffiliate Inquiry
description: The City Council's Committee on Health was charged yesterday with being grossly disruptive for starting an investigation into the affiliation agreements under which voluntary hospitals are paid for providing medical services to the municipal hospitals.

title: E.B.C.'s Monty Python Surprise Hit on Public TV
description: Monty Python's Flying Circus, a series of irreverent comedy and satire produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation, has become the surprise hit of the year in public television in the United States.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Layoffs
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 14 (UPI)The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation will shut down a second potline and lay off an additional 80 men at its Mead Primary Aluminum Plant here because of declining demand for aluminum products.

title: ACCORD EXPECTED ON MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, March 14A $150million state malpractice insurance fund, which New York doctors and nonmunicipal hospitals would have to join, would be set up under a plan on which the Carey administration and key legislators are close to final agreement.

title: South Side Five Babylon Victors
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. March 14 Undefeated South Side of Rockville Centre defeated Malverne, 8974, today at Nassau Coliseum for the Nassau County public high school basketball championship.

title: Horse Owners in Suburbs Running Into Opposition
description: Eleven years ago Ann and Rohn Patrick Hagen bought 5.4 acres of land in Lacey Township on the Jersey shore, determined to fulfill their dream of combining rural and suburban life.

title: Strawberry Trucks Halted
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14 (AP)The Federal Food and Drug Administration says it is holding up strawberry trucks at the Mexican border until a thorough search is made for residue of the chemical azodrin, a pesticide that is not allowed on edible products in the United States.

title: Miamian Says I.R.S. Recruited Her to Spy
description: MIAMI, March 14A Miami woman said today that she was recruited by the Internal Revenue Service in 1972 to take part in a widespread operation to gather information on the sex life and drinking habits of 30 prominent South Floridians, among them a state attorney involved in the Watergate investigation.

title: Ford Presses a New Plan For Cambodian Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (Reuters)President Ford tried today to work out a new plan for giving military aid to Cambodia in the face of warnings from Congressmen that approval for such assistance was virtually hopeless.

title: Kodak Furloughing 500
description: ROCHESTER, March 14 (UPI) The Eastman Kodak Company said today it was laying off 500 workers for one week, beginning Monday, in its apparatus division, which employs 11,500. The purpose of the furlough is to trim inventories.

title: PLEASANT PROGRAM BY A BERKSHIRE TRIO
description: The Berkshire Chamber Ensemble, a trio consisting of two musicians who work and teach in Western Massachusetts and one Dutch guitarist, gave a pleasantly understated concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The entire right half of me was cold. Right toes, right leg, right torso, right arm, right hand, right fingers, right ear, right scalp all frigid.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Few Americans are satisfied with the way in which the economy is now operating. Unemployment is increasing and prices are rising. Inflation in the United States has become a source of instability in the world at large. No reliabele mechanism in the modern economy relates needs to available manpower, plant and materials. In consequence we have shortages of housing, medical care, municipal services, transportation, energy, and numerous other requirements of pressing importance.

title: 8 Tennis Masters To Play in Sweden
description: The Commerical Union Masters tennis tournament, limited to the eight season leaders will be played in Stockholm, Sweden, Dec, 17.

title: The World
description: An attempted coup, attributed to a small group of moderates and conservatives in the armed forces, has been used by Portugal's left wing military leaders to firmly move that country toward dictatorship by the military. There is now less likelihood than ever that the democratic promise of a year ago will be met.

title: ReInventing the WindmillAnd Selling It
description: What's the latest in energy for the homenuclear, solar, atomic, gasified coal?

title: English Coach Looking Homeward
description: Like most coaches in the North American Soccer League, Bill Foulkes of the Chicago Sting counts a lot on foreign aid. That's why he is in England right now, looking for ways and means to strengthen his club.

title: The Letters of Sean O'Casey
description: He described himself in the titles of several of his books as a green crow and a flying wasp, but the image of Sean O'Casey that's fixed in my mind is of a more ungainly sort of winged creature: a crane or stork, a great flapping, squawking, long necked, nearsighted bird with Adam's apple bobbing in rage or indignation. O'Casey, pretended toand sometimes possessedthe homely uncorrupted sagacity of the crow of our animal tales, and regarded himself as called on to administer stinging wasplike rebukes to social and artistic complacency. Yet as this ponderous volume of his correspondence demonstrates, he was often simpleminded rather than innocently wise, and querulous, even meanspirited, instead of intellectually valorous.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: Douglass Duiham, the, chief security officer of the American Indian Movement during the trial of the leaders of the Wounded Knee takeover, was a paid informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Durham was the chief aide and confidante of Dennis J. Banks, one of the two defendants and a coleader of the movement. Last week Mr. Durham disclosed he had been reporting to the F.B.I. since 1973. The charges against Mr. Banks and Russell Means were dismissed. Federal District Court Judge Frederick J. Nichol said, It's hard for me to believe that the F.B.I. which I have revered for so long has stooped So low.

title: Is It a Play? An Opera? No, It's a Wilson
description: When Robert Wilson's A Letter for Queen Victoria opens at the ANTA Theater next Saturday, audiences will be witness to a work that is likely to mesmerize some, confound some, and send some hastening to the nearest exit. Billed as an opera,

title: STAGE VIEW
description: In Dickens's novel Our Mutual Friend, Bella Wilfer, a young woman of ordinary character and aspiration, declares about her coming marriage, I want to be something so much worthier than the doll in the doll's house. Although it is unlikely that Ibsen took this image for the title of his play directly from Dickens, it is noteworthy that two such different artists employed the same metaphor to describe the destiny that society expected of the married woman in the 19th century. One need not be biased to believe that this coincidence of expression was not an isolated accident, but was rather an indication of how prevalent the notion had become that something was very much. amiss in the Victorian household. Indeed, it is hard to think of any novelist or dramatist of the time who did not depict and analyze the use and abuse of female energy, showing it either being coerced into romantic disaster or being subjected to the deadening attrition of the mores of a middleclass parlor. Male writers who would never have endorsed feminist proposals nevertheless, as artists, had enough intellectual conscience to agree with George Eliot that the need for a female epos was both pressing and dangerous.

title: Old Ironsides Reopened
description: BOSTON, March 15 (AP)The world's oldest commissioned warship, Old Ironsides, reopened to visitors under new flags and rigging yesterday in time for the nation's Bicentennial celebrations. Long one of Boston's most popular attractions, the ship, U.S.S. Constitution, has been in drydock for overhaul for two years.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE

It had a narrow escape from, extinction at the hands of the lame duck session of Congress late last year, and now the new Congress is bearing down on it again.

title: Headliners
description: A penniless refugee when he fled his hometown, Smyrna, during the 1922 GreekTurkish War, by the time he died last week Aristotle Onassis had become one of the world's richest and most famous men. From Turkey he had gone to Argentina where he got a job as a telephone operator. But it was not long before he was able to buy two old ships that were to become the basis of the world's largest privatelyowned shipping fleet. Later he acquired his own airline, Olympic Airways, and in a celebrated financial tussle with Prince Rainier of Monaco bought, and lost, the bank at Monte Carlo. His wealth brought him friendship with such disparate personages as Sir Winston Churchill, Greta. Garbo, Gina Lollobrigida, Maria Callas and the Kennedy family. His first wife was Athina Livanos, daughter of a rival Greek shipping magnate. Then in 1968, he and Jacqueline Kennedy, widow of the President, were married. In January, 1973, his only son, Alexander, was killed in a crash of the family plane. He was reported profoundly depressed at this loss. His own health began to fail, and in February he was flown to Paris for gall bladder surgery. Since then his condition had steadily deteriorated.

title: Robinson Wins First

Last year Minnesota defeated Michigan Tech, 42, for the title, and the Huskies were out for revenge tonight. In the consolation game for third place, Boston University downed Harvard, 105.

title: Kitchen help
description: It has been labeled, and not without justice, the 20thcentury French Revolution. It is the equivalent of an electric blender, electric mixer, meat grinder, food sieve, potato ricer and chef's knife rolled into one. Its invention, in the minds of serious cooks, ranks with that of the printing press, cotton gin, steamboat, paper clips, Kleenex, wastebaskets, contour sheets and disposable diapers. It has, in many minds, ??endered the electric blender a hope??ess antique, and we are willing at any time to relegate our old faithful ??o the Smithsonian.

title: The methadone habit
description: In 1971, the Government started a crash program to expand the national capacity to treat heroin addiction. Included in the package was a huge increase in the use of methadone, itself a powerful narcotic drug, and for the first time since 1920 the United States seemed ready to accept the validity of administering one drug to treat another. By early 1973, 73,000 addicts were in methadone programs. After that the census rose slowly, leveling off at about 80,000, a figure which, according to Government estimates, represents a little less than 20 per cent of the addict population. Another 45,000 are in treatment other than with methadone, 85,000 are in jail and 250,000 are on the street.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 (AP)Closing California state offices for Good Friday worship has been ruled unconstitutional by the state Court of Appeals.

title: The Government Has Moved Sharply Left
description: LISBONWhat kind of revolution does Portugal want and who shall lead it? These questions were posed from the day last April when 50 years of dictatorship toppled a few hours although the euphoria of newfound freedom tended to obscure them. The flowers a happy people strewed about as festive symbols of a free Portugal soon faded, to be replaced by the conflict of fundamentally opposed interestsand groups. As for O Povo, the People so constantly invoked as the beall and endall of the revolution, they are not a little bewildered.

title: A List of Village Candidates
Letting Go of Lon Nol
description: Twenty years of bipartisan support for American intervention in Indochina appears to be coming to an end. Congress seems certain to deny President Ford's request for $222million in emergency aid to forestall the collapse of the Government in Cambodia, and it may also reject additional help for South Vietnam this year.

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 15  Chris Dundee was talking into one of the telephones on his desk. So he can't fight. That's okay, I got somebody else. Chris is almost always on, the telephone, and if somebody can't fight on one of his cards he always has somebody else at hand who can. Miami Beach has a denser population of fist fighters than New York or Chicago or San Francisco or many other towns where the Sweet Science used to prosper because this is where the work is.

title: Philadelphia Transit Strike Halts Buses and Subways
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP)About 5,500 transit workers walked off their jobs today, halting much of the bus and subway commuter service in Philadelphia and four surrounding counties.

title: Ellice Chase Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gardner Chase of Fishkill, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter L. Ellice Chase to Dr. Robert Claringhold Young, son of Dr. and Mrs. Claude R. Young of Binghamton. N.Y.

title: Islanders Triumph Over Bruins, 3 to 1
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 15The New York Islanders sat on a onegoal lead for two periods and then added an emptynet goal tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 31, for 2 muchneeded points in their bid for a Stanley Cup playoff berth. The victory broke a n Islander string of three losses and put the club 6 points ahead of the Atlanta Flames in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League.

title: John Wain's life of
description: When a man is tired of London, he is tired of life, for there is in London all that life can afford. Those words are also true of the great Londoner who said them, Dr. Johnson. Among the many achievements of John Wain's vividly humane life of Johnson is that it does justice to the range and depth of this just and merciful man. His dignity, his unexpected gentleness; his literary triumphs as a poet, critic, dictionarymaker, editor, essayist, and as a oneman university uniting the nest of faculties; his courage in the face of sickness, melancholia and even madness: all of these are alive in Mr. Wain's firm and delicate pages. It is a noble story nobly told.

title: Paperbacks
description: AN AMERICAN DILEMMA, by Gunnar Myrdal, with the assistance of Richard Steiner and Arnold Rose. (Pantheon, 2 vols., $11.90.) The classic study of American democracy's greatest failure. its treatment of the Negro, originally published ih 1942 and updated in 1962, is available once more in paperback.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The New York Life Insurance Company has begun construction of a $10million data processing center on a 139acre tract off Interstate 78 in Clinton Township, N. J.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Aspecialist, we Renaissance men all agree, is a person who knows more and more about less, and less. And in music, as in most other fields, the specialist has long since taken command. Although we pay occasional grudging homage to the protean musician such as Leonard Bernstein, who refuses to spread himself thick, so to speak, over a small area, we have in fact become intimidated by the authority of the narrow expert. Any prodigal display of general culture or manifold talent immediately comes under suspicion of dilettantism. That this should be true in music is especially odd since versatility is almost always an indication of an inborn gift that specialized study can only help expose and refine.

title: The Boswell Caper
description: In our day the 18thcentury biographer James Boswell appears to have become inextricably entangled in the career of a suave American collector named Ralph Heyward Isham. It was in the 1930's that I first heard Colonel Isham describe his acquisition of Boswell's archives from Malahide Castle near Dublin, and, like others in the audience, I was enthralled. Later, as wore and more discoveries were revealed, the amazing sequence of events became widely publicized. There have been numerous retellingsby Frederick Pottle, Richard Altick and others.

title: Puerto Rico: The Inn Way
description: AS our 747 rolled to a halt at the San Juan Airport, we exchanged one of those wordless glances that pass between husbands and wives. What have we got ourselves into? it said. With acute urban pallor and a vacation budget shellshocked by inflation, we weren't heading for luxury hotels or glittering gambling casinos. On the contrary, we were going to spend our three weeks in the paradoxes (family inns) of Puerto Rico, whose extravagant fullcolor brochure had promised just what we needed sun, rest, salt water and reasonably priced accommodations.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Paleontology, Medicine
description: Among the extinct winged reptiles popularly called pterodactyls are the largest creatures known ever to have flown, and paleontologists working in Texas have found the remains of the largest yet. It is an animal with an estimated wingspan of 51 feet, twice as large as that of the largest previously known specimen.

title: Presentation Is Set on Newark Parks
description: NEWARK  Newark's Great Parks will be the subject of a colorslide presentation at a meeting next Sunday of the Friends of Branch Brook Park. The meeting will be held at the Newark Museum at 3 P.M., and a contribution of $1.50 will be solicited.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Furniture from Scandinavia that's built to last: from preschool right up to college and longer.

title: Of Cabbages and wings, Corned Beef and the Irish
description: Along with Irish stew, soda bread, Irish coffee and green beer, culinary thoughts for St. Patrick's Day turn inevitably to corned beef and cabbage.

title: U.S. Investigating Alleged '73 Oil Import Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Federal Government is conducting an extensive investigation into the rapid rise of oil prices during the Arab oil embargo, a United States Customs Service spokesman said tonight.

title: MANHATTAN SCHOOL GIVES SPIRITED COSI
description: The Manhattan School of Music gave four performances of Mozart's Cosi fan tutte this weekend with no fewer than three different casts. The six singers, Friday night were of varying quality perhaps, but they and the production itself dealt respectably with what is a notoriously difficult opera, even for professionals.

title: Tracey Green Plans April 12 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Green of Princeton, N. J., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracey Pratt Green, to Wade Harrison Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Judson H. Whitney of Keene Valley, N. Y.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Montclair: A Shop for Crafts
description: MONTCLAIR  Five taltented women of divers international origin, but sharing a common interest in seeing made by hand reassert itself in a machinedominated marketplace, have established an outlet here at which artisans not only can sell their crafts but also teach how they make them.

title: New Shops Planned Downtown
description: Some of the owners of cleared sites in the Wall Street area who have shelved plans to build office towers are now thinking of erecting retail stores.

title: Sallie Burguieres To. Be Wed May 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Berchman Burguieres of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sallie Louise Burguieres, to Philip John Dietz Jr., an engineer with Mechanics Research, Inc., of McLean, Va. He is the son of Mrs. Dietz of Baltimore and the late Mr. Dietz.

title: Irish Put Out Kansas; Indiana Victor, 7853
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 15  Indiana University's skilled perfectionists in basketball defense got away with a mediocre offensive performance today. But they easily beat TexasEl Paso, 7853, to remain undefeated and become the first team to win an openinground game in the 37th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: Vanguard 1, Silent, to Orbit The Earth for Centuries
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 15 (UPI)The Air Force said today that Vanguard I, the nation's oldest satellite, would orbit the earth indefinitely despite a breakdown in equipment relaying information.

title: FORD SAID TO VIEW NEW CAMBODIA AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Ford Administration is considering asking Congress for at least $421million in new military aid for Cambodia as soon as there is a settlement of efforts to give Cambodia $222million in immediate emergency help.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 16, 1975

title: PRESIDENT WEIGHS ACCORD TO LIMIT FEDERAL SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Ford Administration is considering an offer of major concessions on the President's economic program in return for a commitment of Congressional restraint on spending.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission has decided to propose changes in its rules of practice that could strengthen its ability to bring major antitrust cases such as Exxon Et AI, the pending complaint against eight big oil companies.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Lee Trevino, after winning the Citrus open, talks about his problem: I don't jog and I play bad do my jogging and I win. That means I've got to keep on jogging and I hate it.

title: Syria Is Said to Balk At Kissinger's Plea For a Sinai Accord
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 15, Secretary of State Kissinger made another apparently fruitless, effort today in Syria to persuade President Hafez alAssad to at least go along with the quest for a new EgyptianIsraeli agreement in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: HIBACHI

title: ChichenItaza: Museum Piece In the Yucatan
description: With thousands of registered archeological sites within its boundaries, the Yucatan Peninsula, on Mexico's Caribbean coast, is a mammoth, green, openair museum, and one of its most impressive exhibits is ChichenItza, pictured here. Dating from A.D. 455, the sixsquaremile expanse of ToltecMayan ruins lies 75 miles east of Merida, the Yucatan capital, on an arrowstraight highway that leads to the sea. ChichenItza has come in for an unexpected measure of popularity in recent months because of its proximity to Cancun, Mexico's newest resort on the Caribbean.Vacationers can swim in the sea in the morning, take the twoaridonehalfhour drive to ChichenItza to climb. ruins like El Castillo, left, and the Caracol Observatory, below, in the afternoon and be back at the beach before sunset.

title: TRUE LABEL ORDERED IN RADIO AND TV SETS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the makers of radio and television sets to tell consumers in plain English what the cabinets are made of.

title: The Fabulous FableBetter Said Than Read
description: Aesop, some scholars argue, was a fable himself. Whether that's true or not, the moralistic stories that this supposed Phrygian slave set down are still real for us today, and no subsequent practitioners of the fabulistic formTolstoi, Thurber, and even Leonardo Da Vincisurpassed him in the art. We can read all of these fables, of course, but somehow they sound more immediate when passed on by word of mouth in the way fables were originally meant to be communicated. Numerous records are available today that provide us with just this special listening experience, and they cover virtually all the important authors who wrote pithy tales conveying brief, instructive morsels of wisdom.

title: Free Lessons Key to Her Billiard Success
description: When a billiard parlor in Madison, Wis., offered free pocket billiards for women on Mondays and Thursdays, Melissa Rice thought it was an offer she couldn't refuse.

title: Big Fishing Season Seen
description: TRENTONAbout 250 rivers, streams and lakes in New Jersey are being stocked with more than 600,000 freshwater fish this year in anticipation of an increased demand for fishing licenses and a growing popularity of the sport.

title: The Nation
description: The Watergate investigations into corporate campaign contributions have set off other inquiries that are beginning to show how much money has been dispensed for how long to candidates of both parties. It has gone on for years millions of dollars is involved, and the illegal donations have come from some of the corporate pillars of the business community.

title: Kansas State Conquers Penn, Syracuse Is Overtime Winner
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 15 The basketball season is over for both Philadelphia representatives in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Shirley MacLaine to China and back
description: As Sbirley MacLaine tells it, by 1970 the bloom was definitely off the rose. Hollywood was in tatters, the sound stages either empty or echoing to the jejune plots of television's miniature movies. The men who produced the situation comedies and game shows lived as though they were the leads in a madefortelevision movie about Hollywood in its glory years. And they wanted MacLaine to do a series, because their researchers gave her high marks on humanitarianism not to mention a high vulnerability quotient. She wanted to portray womanhood, vibrant and involved; they wanted to make money. When she suggested that the heroine needn't be tied to a boyfriend and a boss, the producer was aghast. This female liberation thing, he moaned, You know, it's real threat to television.

title: Toll on Parkway To Be Rolled Back
description: VALLEY STREAMGovernor Carey signed a bill last week that rolled back the highly controversial increase in the toll on the Southern State Parkway from 25 to 10 cents.

title: Pupils Try Life in the Woods
description: PRINCETON  A new dimension has been added to the fifthgrade curriculum at the Littlebrook School here: backpacking.

title: New Jobs for Old Factory
description: What Federal and city officials describe as the nation's first vertical industrial park is being developed under sponsorship of an antipoverty program in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section.

title: Aid to Indochina
description: Regarding the military future of South Vietnam, and United States responsibilities in that scarred land, there Is no room for ideological certitudeneither for the familiar disaster threats of the Administration nor the Congressional Democrats' sweeping rejection of further military aid to Indochina this year.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices moved in a narrow range last week and finished higher in continued heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 3.37 points at 773.47. Among the stronger issues were some of the glamour and special situation stocks as well as some of the lowpriced ones.

title: Reagan Bid to Aid Sandman Criticized
description: TRENTON  Ronald Reagan's offer to help former Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. pay off his 1973 gubernatorial campaign debts is threatening to aggravate the political division and financial turmoil that have plagued the state's Republican party.

title: Center for Children Assailed
description: TRENTON  A sharplyworded legislative report issued here last week charges that the construction of a state diagnostic center for children was a story of wasted money, idle staff and children with critical problems being denied desperately needed services.

title: Calendar of Events
Aqueduct Jockeys
Naples Explosion Brings Police Hunt For Leftist Plotters
description: ROME, March 15  The explosion of a homemade bomb in a Naples apartment last Tuesday, killing a student, has set off nationwide police action against a suspected ultraleftist conspiracy.

title: Hillside Housing for Westchester
description: WRITE PLAINS Most suburban zoning rules make It too costly to build housing on steep slopes. Butproving that recession can be the mother of invention  White Plains has authorzed an imaginative way to develop such a site.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: What can't be described must be experienced.

title: Hat Concern Aide and Worker Murdered in Loft Near N.Y.U.
description: An official and an employe of a hat company at 725 Broadway, in the Washington Square area, were found slain yesterday afternoon, in a conference room.

title: The March Buds
description: Buds fatten on the elms, beading their twigs against the sky, and in the lowlands the red maples begin to shrug off the scales that have protected their crimson florets from the winter's cold. In the dooryard the lilacs are in such big bud they make you wonder how much longer they can contain their swollen packet of leaves and stem and blossoms, all purple tinged for May delivery and celebration.

title: Notables in Paris on UNESCO Issue
description: PARIS, March 15About 100 men and women from the worlds of education, science and culture gathered here today from all over the globe for an encounter for the universality of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Stage: A Song of Venice
description: Not being one of those indestrugtible theatrical vehicles like The Front Page or The Boy Friend that can withstand almost any onslaught of ineptitude and still retain the strength to captivate an audience, the 10yearold musical Do I Hear a Waltz? provides a worthy challenge to its cast.

title: Francis BaconI Wanted to Paint the Scream
description: LONDON Once, gambling at Monte Carlo, where he lived for a time, the English painter Francis Bacon had a winning streak. He was spending days and nights at the roulette tables and It got to the almost mystical point where he believed he heard the croupier call out the winning number before the ball fell into the socket. One afternoon he won nearly $4,000. He rented a villa, stocked it with food, wine and friends, and had a marvelous 10 days. Nowadays he is less lucky as a gambler, but his fame as a painter in part makes up for it. On Wednesday the Metropolitan Museum of Art opens a threemonth show of his workpaintings mostly done since his exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris in 1971, Ba con, however, remains intensely interested in chance; not only in what makes for a gambling win or fame, but in the fortune that smiles (or grins a deathhead grin) when his oil paints and his obsessions are embroiled upon a canvas.

title: Mother and Son in an Auto Plunge to Their Death From S.I. Ferryboat
description: As dozens of passengers watched, a car containing the wife and son of a Staten Island surgeon crashed through the retaining barriers of a ferryboat moored to a slip in St. George, S.I. yesterday afternoon and plunged both to their death in the murky waters off the terminal.

title: JUDGE WITHDRAWS FROM RESERVE CASE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 15 (AP)  A Federal judge has passed the main responsibility for solving the, Reserve Mining Company pollution case to state officials and the oreprocessing company.

title: Boston College Victor; North Carolina Scores
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C. March 15 (AP)  Wil Morrison scored 14 of his 20 points in the last half to lead Boston College to an 8276 victory over Furman in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional basketball tournament tonight.

title: T. R. Tomai to Wed Miss McCarthy
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. McCarthy of Louisville, Ky., of the engagement of their daughter, Maude McCarthy, to Timothy R. Tomai, son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Tomai Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J.

title: How the Movies Chased the Blues Away In the Last Depression
description: Three days after 1929's Black TuesdayOctober 29, when The New York Times stock index tumbled nearly 40 pointsGloria Swanson's first talking picture, The Trespasser, premiered at Manhattan's Rialto Theater. It was the story of a Chicago stenographer's attempt to break into North Shore high society, and of her disillusionment when she accomplished the breakthrough, only to discover that wealth, once achieved, couldn't bring happiness. When the curtain came down there wasn't a damp eye in the house.

title: JAMES J. HURLEY
description: James J. Hurley, who retired as an assistant corporation counsel in 1962, died yesterday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived ??.

title: Princetonians Tightening Belt
description: PRINCETON  Anxiety over inflation, recession and sky  rocketing tuition is growing for students at Princeton University.

title: G.O.P.: Ford Says It Is His, But It Isn't Yet
description: There was a script for the 1972 Republican National Convention. Fifty or more pages of dialogue and cues9:03: Spontaneous Resolution From Pennsylvania Delegationwere prepared each day by the White House and delivered to the convention's permanent chairman, House Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford.

title: Taxes, Zoning Dominate Local Races
description: MINEOLA  Rhetoric on zoning laws, tax rates and oneparty rule has risen to its annual highest pitch with candidates running for village offices in Tuesday's election. Although both incumbents and challengers agree on the principle of home rule, rival candidates disagree on whose hands arc most capable of holding the reins of government.

title: HALL TO APPEAL VERDICT OF GUILTY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 15 Former. Gov. David hall said today he would appeal his conviction yesterday in Federal Court.

title: Soviet Gently but Clearly Cautions Japan Against Moving Toward Closer Ties With China
description: MOECOW, March 15The Soviet Union has begun to warn Japan, gently but unmistakably, that it is uneasy about the prospect of closer relations between Japan and China.

title: Behind the marble,
description: WASHINGTON. It was Saturday, and the United States Supreme Court, like the rest of Washington's public buildings, looked lonely and deserted. But inside, five of the Justices were hard at work. A sixth had interrupted his routine to visit with a friend from out of town. The fire in the Justice's chambers crackled warmly as the two men talked. The visitor ventured the opinion that the Court's biggest case of that year would be a capitalpunishment decision and asked if the Justice had made up his mind yet. The Justice alan't answer. The visitor, suacienty aware that he had asked an improper question, started to apologize. But his voice caught in his throat at the sight of his old friend. The Justice was slumped ashenfaced in his chair, eyes closed; his words seemed almost a whisper. My God, all those lives.

title: Portugal's Regime Nationalizes Insurance Companies
description: LISBON, March 15Within the last two days, Portugal's new High Council of the Revolution has seized the great bulk of the country's financial power.

title: Kentucky Ousts Marquette by 7654
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 15 (AP)Kentucky, sparked by Jimmy Dan Connor and Kevin Grevey, rallied at the outset of the second half toand trounced Marquette, 7654, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideas't Regional basketball tournament game.

title: Amy M. Rhodes, D. M. Rosenthal To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rhodes of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Margaret Rhodes, to Daniel Michael Rosenthal. A June wedding is planned.

title: LongRange Plans to Feed World Are Moving Ahead
description: In the four months since the World Food Conference ended in Rome amid criticism of its failure to provide immediate famine relief, several of the meetings longrange proposals for preventing famines have been moving toward realization at a promising pace, according to experts on the world food situation.

title: Muzak's Global Music
description: Like it or not, that ubiquitous sound called Muzak, heard in banks, offices, elevators and elsewhere across the nation, is not only a big business but also a growing presence. Every day an estimated 60 million people work, eat and travel to the Muzak beat.

title: Yale Loses Final In U.S. Polo, 1512
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 15 The University of California at Davis, playing in the tournament for the first time, defeated Yale, 1512, to win the national intercollegiate indoor championship tonight at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Maryland, Cincinnati Win
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., March 15 (AP)  Fourthranked Maryland, paced by the shooting of John Lucas and Brad Davis, a freshman, beat Creighton, 8379, tonight to join Cincinnati in the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regionals at Las Cruces, N.M.

title: Rogers Duo Gains in Platform Tennis
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 15Scott Rogers and John Brownlow from Cleveland, seeded sixth, gained the semifinal round of the 41st annual men's national platform tennis doubles championship at the Fox Meadow Club today. They upset the defending champions and topseeded team of Herb FitzGibbon of New York City and John Beck of Mount Kisco. 46. 108. 62. 62.

title: CAREY PROPOSES STRONGER AGENCY TO HELP CONSUMER
description: ALBANY, March 15Governor Carey submitted his consumer program to the Legislature today, proposing a stronger government agency to specialize in the field, greater authority for, consumers to instigate lawsuits and a variety of protective measures covering such matters as credit cards, traffic tickets and apples.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Lincroft Inn, 700 New man Springs Road (one mile west of Exit 109, Garder State Parkway), Lincroft (201) 7418170.

title: Moses Malone, ManChild
description: In the shell of insecurity created by his sudden fame, Moses Malone often hid under his bed when college recruiters knocked on the door of the shabby wooden row home in Petersburg, Va., where the 6foot11inch manchild lived with his mother. And even now, as he approaches the completion of his spectacular rookie season with the Utah Stars, the child in him still has a tendency to retreat into that shell, usually from newsmen. When he realized last week that a newsman had phoned him, his tone of voice changed abruptly.

title: Repression in Iran
description: In October, 1972, the Shah of Iran celebrated the 2,500th year of Persian monarchy which, despite twenty national dynastic changes, has constantly endeavored to remain absolute.

title: In 1974, the Birth Rate Moved Up
description: The first Government statistics on population trends in 1974 provide bad news for advocates of zero population growth. The curve of births suddenly moved upward last year, while the curve of deaths moved equally suddenly downward. This year saw the lowest death rate in the nation's history.

title: Richard Stone Weds Gail Kressmann
description: Gail Griffis Kressmann was married yesterday morning to Richard Howard Stone, an architect in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., The bride is project manager for the Village Improvement Society, Inc., of Salisbury, Conn.

title: Orchestra Day Set At Montclair State
description: MONTCLAIRThe Montclair State College Music Department will serve as host for High School Orchestra Day on Friday. A total of 400 students from 10 New Jersey high schools will participate.

title: Clean Sweep at C. I. A.?
description: WASHINGTONThe main hope for the survival of an effective Central Intelligence Agency in the, United States now lies in a clean sweep of its present leadership and the creation of a powerful new joint committee of the Congress to oversee its future activities.

title: The Region
description: The telephone company arsonists are still loose and at work, despite the attention they are getting from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the New York City Police Department and the utility's considerable security force. Three more phone company fires were set last week, not serious but each emphasizing the potential in the unusual situation. And three shots were fired through a window of a phone company office building in Queens, vandalism that police said might have been prompted by the extensive publicity the fires had received. There have now been seven fires in two weeks, five of them officially described as suspicious.

title: Where the Buffalo Graze...
description: WOODSTOWN  I don't know, Howard Harris was saying. I just like to see them around, grazing in my pastures. They're a sort of weakness, I guess.

title: Carol Brock Bride Of Jerome Kenney
description: Carol Brock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harlan Brock of St. Louis, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jerome Paul Kenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Kenney of Newton, Mass.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: As more and more photographers do their own processing and printing, an increasing number have learned that photographic images need not always be straight prints or enlargements which faithfully reproduce the picture created in the original negative. Images can be easily altered or dramatized to improve or change the composition, or to create an effect that is entirely different than that of straight print. These alterations or changes can be achieved by a number of different darkroom and printing procedures, any of which can be mastered by those photographers who are already familiar with basic printing techniques.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Secondround action in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden will take place in doubleheaders at 7 P.M. Tuesday and Thursday. The semifinals will start at 2 P.M. Saturday, the final at 1 P.M. Sunday following the thirdplace game.

title: Art: Slow in Summit Is a Tribute to American Indian
description: SUMMITFritz Scholder, an artist who has developed a striking and very personal manner of portraying the American Indian, is being honored by a brilliantlycolored exhibition at the Summit Art Center.

title: UTEP Triumphs In College Track
description: DETROIT, March 15The United States athletes wontoday, but not by much. This was the most conspicuous note on the concluding day of the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships at Cobo Arena.

title: The World/ Continued
description: TEHERANThe 13 member states of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries took in a total of $110.2billion in oil revenues last year, according to unofficial estimates made by the Banque de Bruxelles. About $61billion of that amount was what the economists call surplus, invested in foreign enterprises or socked away in the form of gold, foreign real estate holdings and the like.

title: EARLINE BALLARD IN TURANDOT DEBUT
description: The title role of Puccini's Turandot is such a throatbreaker that it's a wonder any soprano wants to sing it, much less make, a debut in it. The thinking is probably that if the risks are great, a triumph is that much greater.

title: Federal Consumer Agency Is Given a Good Chance
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Like the hardy perennial it is, legislation to establish a consumer protection agency has again sprouted on Capitol Hill. This year, admirers and critics aeree, it may even bloom.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Rusk on Assassination: Never Considered Idea
description: ATHENS, Ga., March 15 (AP)The Administrations of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson never tinkered with the idea of political assassinations, says Dean Rusk, Secretary of State under both men.

title: School Budgets: Vote Assayed
description: HACKENSACKA confusing pattern of rejection emerged last week as more than 60 per cent of the state's 547 school districts saw their budget requests for the 197576 fiscal year turned down. Budgets were defeated in both affluent and financially pressed communities.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Imported whiteonwhite sheer tablecloth irregulars ... at 53%67% less and a bonus of six matching napkins.

title: Letters: A Villa in France, Heigh Ho
description: To the Editor:

title: He spoke for John to Abbie and Meir and Joe
description: A scene from the 1960's: knots of blacks along rubblestrewn streets in Harlem or Brownsville or East New York are surging around John V. Lindsay  the symbol. writes Barry Gottehrer, of what every mayor should be, his sleeves rolled up, his collar unbuttoned, tireless, tough, courageous and caring.

title: Mets' Pitching Suffers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15  In some circles, the Chicago White Sox might be considered losers. They play in the same division with the Oakland A's, threetime world champions. They lost Dick Allen when the 32yearold slugger quit and went home last September. They lost six of their first nine games this spring and even lost two in one day when they split their squad.

title: CHARLES HATTON, 69, A RACING COLUMNIST
description: Charles Hatton, a columnist for The Daily Racing Form for 40 years, died Friday at his home, 5 Marwood Road North, Port Washington, L.I. He was 69 years old and had been in semiretirement.

title: Welfare Aid at a Record; 3 Programs Help 498,611
description: TRENTONAs the recession and unemployment tighten their grip on New Jersey, increasing numbers of people are turning to welfare assistance and food stamps as a means of providing their basic needs.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I recently purchased a humidifier which has fabric inserts. These have become caked with white mineral deposits and my furnace man says I have to buy new ones. Since the deposits build up in a few months, this becomes quite expensive. Is there any way I can remove the deposits?J. K., Millbrook, N.Y.

title: . . . a Speedy Tax Cut
description: Even with the need for action so pressing, the Senate Finance Committee could not resist the temptation last week to start Christmas treeing the tax bill passed by the House. One of the baubles was Senator Long's 5 per cent tax credit to home buyers, up to a maximum saving of $2,000 on a housewhich, as the White House says, would mainly benefit those who buy houses costing $100,000 to $200,000. Other proposed goodies included repeal of the 10 per cent excise tax on trucks, trailers and buses. These and other issuessuch as the stripping by the Senate of repeal of the oil and gas depletion allowance from the House billwill have to be ironed in conference with the House.

title: Kialoa Leads 811Mile Sail
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 15Kialoa II, skippered by Jim Kilroy of Los Angeles, appears to be setting an incredible pace in the eighth biennial MiamiMontego Bay yacht race.

title: Alcatraz: At Last, Peace on The Rock

They are on Alcatraz in San Francisco Bay, island home of the infamous maximumsecurity Federal prison now open to the public but empty of the likes of Machine Gun Kelly, Al Capone, Robert F. Stroud (the Birdman of Alcatraz) and Roy Gardner (last of the great train robbers).

title: JaiAlai for Connecticut

Then a fronton was opened in the MGMGrand Hotel in Las Vegas and in its first year of operation attracted about 2,000 spectators a night. Now the game is moving closer to New York. In the summer of 1976 frontons are scheduled to be opened in three Connecticut cities: Bridgeport, Hartford and Milford.

title: Easy When You Know How

In the meantime my avocado strangled itself while worms destroyed the cabbage cropand my enthusiasm for gardening. Had I learned to grow things before plunging in, I might have been spared the disappointments. Today's youngsters should have no problem acquiring knowhow for any hobby, with tons of hobby books to tell them everything they need to know.

title: English National Opera Holds to High Standard
description: LONDONLike Vienna and New York, London is a twoopera city. The Royal Opera at Covent Garden is the big international house, usually working with star casts and and conductors. At the Coliseum is the more provincial English National Opera, formerly the Sadlers Wells, which presents everything in English translation and uses Britisn or Commonwealth singers. The English National Opera Company is to the Royal Opera what the New York City Opera Company is to the Metropolitan.

title: Dog Strike Supported

description: TRENTONThe reputation and performance of the judiciary in New Jersey are declining, and drastic steps must be taken to improve the court system, a special study committee of the State Bar Association has concluded.

title: Everything for Sale, Including American Arms

title: Zoar: A Living Tribute To a Utopian Society
description: THE placid treelined streets with their bright picket fences and solid old frame houses and log outbuildirgs set off by grassy yards and meadows give the village of Zoar, Ohio, a remarkably peaceful, welcoming, aspect. The occasional cars moving along Main Street do little to disturb the pastoral scene, and the vistas of vinecovered porches, flower gardens and brick walks are a delight. But none of it is too perfectthere is real, believable life hereso it may take a while for the visitor to realize that he has stepped back a century.

title: Spinola Is Granted Asylum by Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 Brazil granted asylum today to the former Portuguese President, Gen. Antnio de Spinola, who fled Lisbon last week after what the Government described as an attempted reactionary military coup.

title: Craft Fair Opens Here on Thursday
description: The broad spectrum of the craft world will be on colorful display at the New York Coliseum from Thursday to Sunday, when the Third Annual International Craft Show and Fair, sponsored by New York State Craftsmen, Inc., will bring together individual craftspeople and representatives of craft suppliers, galleries, museums, shops, and publishers from all over the country. About 100 exhibitors, divided equally between suppliers and those offering finished crafts, will offer their wares to the public. Attendance is expect ed to top 17,000, and hours are noon to 9 P.M. Admission is $3 for adults, $2 for children under 12.

The chief item of business was the official formation of the National Brotherhood of Skiers. The first president of the group is Ray Mott of Washington, D.C.

title: The Opera: Siegfried
description: Yesterday's performance of Siegfried, the third opera in the Ring cycle being given by the Metropolitan Opera on alternate Saturday afternoons, was one the company could be proud of. It is perhaps the most difficult part of the Wagner tetralogy to bring off well because of its long, long succession of duologues between male singers. If this particular performance was not flawless, it held attention steadily.

description: Assemblyman Armando Montano of the Bronx said during a visit to Rikers Island Friday that he had found crowding and explosive tension at the Men's House of Detention, but prison authorities immediately accused him of acting irresponsibly.

title: But not soon
description: Solar power has suddenly become respectable. Only a few years ago it was treated in the United States as a subject for ecofreaks, too futuristic to deserve more than a polite smile; now thousands of people in universities, industries and Government are investigating such schemes as covering large sections of the Southwest desert with heat collectors, building strings of enormous windmills on the Great Plains or offshore, and generating electricity in space at orbiting power stations whose size would be measured in square miles. Some are even tempted to predict that one day all the world's energy needs will be supplied by the plentiful light and heat of the sun, so that the only plumes of smoke in the sky will come from wood fires on the hearth, and energy will no longer be a cause for international conflict or domestic debate.

title: New & Novel
description: W. H. Canaway's novels of the outdoors are exotic ventures into natural history. I remember particularly The Hunter and the Horns, which featured a party of sheiks, armed with machine guns hunting the nearly extinct ibex from RollsRoyces. This one adheres to another uncommon specimen of fauna: Conus gloria rnaristhe shell of a rare sea snail. A roundtheworld sailor named John Devon collects a live member of the species when he falls overboard from his Fiberglas raft and is washed up on a Micronesian atoll, snail in hand. Devon, a semipro poet, develops a mystical affinity for the mollusk, which he reinstates in a rock pool on the island.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Looking at the repertory of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, it sometimes seems as if it had been put together with little rhyme and less reason. An unusual Balanchine here, a trio of Massines there, a couple of Jooss works stacked up against a corner, a few Ashtons, an old Cranko down in the cellar, a triptych of wellkept Robbins, a modern group of assorted Arpinos, a couple of Joffreys and a pair of Tharpswhat is this repertory? The answer, when you know it, is simple. It is a very personal choice of ballets, and the man doing the choosing the man who founded the company and still directs it Robert Joffrey.

title: Love and death in southern France
description: The difficultyone of the difficultiesin reviewing this new novel by Nicholas Delbanco (his seventh) is its brilliance. The surface shines and sparkles so intensely that the reader is bedazzled and perhaps reluctant to probe beneath. Even Captain Ahab might have hesitated to strike through a mask so filigreed and jewellike. It's not just the learning, the witty allusions, the intricate transitions and patterned motifs, the wordgames and bilingual puns, the shimmering montages; it's also the unusual subjectmatter: the passionate and moving love affair between a bachelor plunging toward sixty and a married woman creeping placidly on fifty.

title: Drama on Englewood Planned

Special emphasis will be placed on the black community.

title: Do we play games to escape?
description: Before the 1972 Reykjavik world championship match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky  more notable for Fischer's performance away from the chess board than fur the actual games  chess had been a game firmly entrenched in the world of esoterica. Not that there weren't a sufficient number of patzers hulking over boards stenciled on park benches or, like me, amateurishly tinkering with plastic pieces and folding cardboard boards as an occasional pastime, but interest in chess on the serious tournament level was, among the general public, almost nil. Fischer's anticsreminiscent of Muhammad Ali's weigh  in pranks before a few of his fights, although apparently less calculatedwere the catalyst in making chess front page news. But at the same time that Fischer's behavior created mass public interest in playing and watching chess, it once again focused attention on the bizarre behavior that has been characteristic of many chess masters throughout the history of the game. And although chess fanaticism diminished among the general public after Fischer's withdrawal into seclusion, interest in the not uncommon eccentricity of many chess masters is apparently still intense.

description: While a passed pawn may be an advantage ample enough to, decide a game, more often than not it cannot be rammed through by main force. When the defender is on his toes, the passed pawn will be blockaded and the winning method, if there is one, will require circuitous maneuvering.

title: The Preening of the Presidentfor Television
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. At the Presidential press conference scheduled for to morrow evening on the Notre Dame campus in South Bend, Ind., TV viewers will discover Gerald Ford seated at the head of a rectangular conference table chatting in a relaxed and informal manner with about a dozen reporters seated along each side of the table. Behind them, re porters will occupy chairs placed in parallel rows facing the President. At least, as of this writing, that's the novel plan of Robert Mead, the 40Yearold former producer for CBS News who for the past seven months has had the job of making President Ford look good on television.

title: Ballet: A Substitution
description: The second program of the Pennsylvania Ballet on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, during the company's brief visit, should have been entirely different from the first night. However, an injury to a dancer prevented the presentation of Benjamin Harkervy's Recital for ?? and Eight Dancers, and a repeat of Hans Van Manen's moodily reflective Adagio Hammerklavier was substituted.

title: Naming a New Cadillac
description: DETROIT  What's in a name? A lot of work, frustration and bruised feelings for many people at the General Motors Cadillac division.

title: A changing women's world
description: Hidden From History is an overview of the history of women in England from the beginnings of the modern era to the 1930's. It has, I think, a dual purpose: It shows how the upheavals of the agricultural and industrial revolutions, of Puritanism and the French Revolution, of World War I and the coming of massmarket consumption affected the lives of women from different social classes. But it also shows that women have responded to these changes in a variety of waysas millenarian prophetesses, bread rioters, writers of tracts; workers on strikeand that these roles and beliefs have shaped the contemporary movement for women's social equality. Sheila Rowbotham sees her book not as an exhaustive work, but as a kind of pamphlet, or perhaps a bundle of pamphletsthe initial exploration of an unmapped field. As such, it succeeds.

title: Carlton KaDell, Announcer For Radio Shows. 70. Dies
description: CHICAGO, March 15 (UPI)Carlton KaDell, a radio personality in Hollywood and Chicago for nearly 40 years, had a heart attack on the air last evening and died in a hospital.
