title: State Bar Association Defends Nadjari's Undercover Methods
description: The leadership of the State Bar Association has defended the controversial undercover methods employed by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor., in his perjury case against Judge Paul P. Rao of the United States Customs Court, his son, Paul Jr., and a lawyer, Salvatore Nigrone.

title: Huge Mall Is Planned in Ocean County
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP  Despite some apprehension over a pending applcation for a required zoning change, a combine of Ocean County professional and businessmen has disclosed plans to build what would be one of the largest enclosed shopping malls in the state. A $35  million project, it would border on the Garden State Parkway at its intersection with Route 37.

title: Aristotle Onassis Is Dead Of Pneumonia in France
description: PARIS, March 15Aristotle Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate, died today at the American Hospital in nearby NeuillysurSeine.

title: Iowa State Keeps Gymnastics Crown
description: AMES, Iowa, March 15 (UPI)  Iowa State won its seventh consecutive Big Eight gymnastics championship today, beating Nebraska by almost 10 points and qualifying for the National Collegiate meet next month in Indiana. It is also the defending N.C.A.A. champion.

title: Letters To the Editor.
description: In Colder Print

title: Article 3  No Title
LIBERALS SEARCH FOR 1976 AGENDA
description: CHICAGO, March 13You can tell the whole story in two short sentences, said Allard K. Lowenstein, Where is our candidate, and what's our program?

title: TV VIEW
description: After all the reviews have been written, all the voluminous reports filed, all the Government hearings concluded, there is nothing quite like simply sitting down to watch an interrupted three hours of average primetime television. There it is, the chain of weekly series representing an awesome investment of time, money, research, sweat and dreams of lifetime annuities. As the products are smoothly fed into millions of homes across the country, excuses and apologies are beside the point. The cats are out of the electronic bag.

title: The President's Open, Sometimes Revolving, Door.
description: WASHINGTONWhen William E. Simon recently attacked the tax cut bill sponsored by the House Ways and Means Committee, saying it would be ineffective because it did not do enough for people of means, there were many in Washington who thought the controversial Secretary of the Treasury was once again speaking out of turn. White House aides had been saying for days that although the House bill was not all that the President wanted, it was basically acceptable.

title: Scott Terms Critics Of Kissinger Jackals
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)  Senate Republican Leader Hugh Scott today described critics of Secretary of State Kissinger as yaping jackals interested in journalistic prizes or selfglorification.

title: 5 Villages In Suffolk Have Races
description: BABYLON  Gilbert C. Hanse, Mayor of the Village of Babylon, says that his bid for a third term is proving to be my toughest political race yet.

title: The Presidential Nomination, in Both Parties, Is Up for Grabs
description: This is the second in an occasional series of reports on one man's pursuit of the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Nicklaus In a Tie
description: MIAMI, March 15Forrest Fezler was disappointed today. He wanted to be in second place so he could chase Jack Nicklaus, but Nieklaus crossed him up with a bogey. And so they finished the third day of the DoralEastern open golf tournament tied at 208 strokes, eight under oar for 54 holes on the Doral Country Club's blue course.

title: Interest in Home Baking On the Rise
description: I first started baking bread at home when we moved to northern Vermont about 10 years ago, after reading about how the early settlers in this area used to spend every Saturday baking. At the time I was not particularly aware of the extra nutrition this would give my family, nor of the savings possible with a large family (even in those preinflation days). However, in some way, reading about the old Vermont attitude toward baking seemed to put my mind in harmony with the idea of Saturday baking. I remember speaking to my 84yearold neighbor, Bertha Flanders, who told me, Back around the turn of the century Saturday was baking day. Well, I tell you, we baked for the whole week. Pies, johnny cake, biscuits, breadthey all waited their turn in the oven. And that's before gas and electric. I shouldn't say, but that was enough to keep a body busy; and there was dinner and besides.

title: Highlights & Index to Listings
description: MUSICALS, MUSICALSThere are lots of big movie musicals suddenly upon us. Ken Russell's Tommy, based on The Who's rock opera of the same title, opens Wednesday. At Long Last Love, Peter Bogdanovich's effort to recapture a 1930's musical with a score by Cole Porter, and Herbert Ross's Funny 1.4dy, with Barbra Streisand extenuating the story of Fanny Brice, have just opened to generally good reviews. Coming up are Stardust, which follows a rock group's rise to fame and fortune, starring Britain's major recording artist David Essex, and Robert Altman's Nashville, which dramatizes the countrymusic scene, Also on view hereabouts are documentaries dealing with the lives of musical figures: Janis, about the late rock singer, and Arthur RubinsteinLove of Life, about the octogenarian pianist.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: For those who see New York City in extremis, the Museun of the City of New York offers hope. It has just opened an exhibition called How Grim Was My City that definitely does not celebrate the good old days. Using photographs of the same areas in the 19th century and today, supplemented with descriptive and factual data and some evocative artifacts. it not only suggests that things may have been much worse in the past, but frequently were. Its message is meant to cheer the doomsayers, and in the words of the exhibition's director, Albert K. Baragwanath, restore perspective about the past and the present and the urban apocalypse.

title: Dance: Steady Work
description: Good choreographers do not succeed every time around. Gus Solomons Jr. is certainly one of the most interesting creative minds to come out of the Merce Cunningham mold. Yet on Friday night at the Richardson Dance Gallery, Mr. Solomons's new group piece, Steady Work, appeared done in by its own intelligence.

title: Night Flight, New York to London: A Sense of Unreality
description: THERE is a special quality about a night flight. The day is stood on end, time is out of jointand the sense of unreality that pervades any lengthy jet voyage is increased a dozenfold. Travelers to Europe get to know the feeling; two out of three fly at night during peak season. Some passengers prefer it; early morning arrival makes possible a full first day. Certainly the crew likes night flights, since sleeping passengers make fewer demands.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Any writer of mystery stories or novels in almost any category, indeedis in an immediate bind when writing about women of the sisterhood. A nun is inviolate in more ways than one. It is part of folklore that a nun has to be innocent, pure in thought and deed, commonsensical, resourceful, witty, unworldly yet immensely practical, a combination of doctor, nurse and confessor with milkwhite skin and Guido Reni eyes.

title: Democratic Leader Seeks Added Black Role
description: MINEOLA  Mrs. Hazel Dukes, who last week was one of three women from the state elected to the Democratic National Committee, is a vigorous proponent of a larger political role for, blacks.

title: McCloskey Warns Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. said today that South Vietnam would fall to Communist control within three years if the United States continued to reduce its economic and military aid.

title: Builders Allying In Quest For Funds
description: NEWARKLeaders of New Jersey's construction industry, which is experiencing a 40 per cent rate of unemployment, have joined in calling for a constitutional convention, if necessary, to generate billions or dollars in capital building funds.

title: Space Hall of Fame Delayed
description: SANTE FE, N.M., March 15Gov. Jerry Apodaca is holding up construction on the $10million International Space Hall of Fame in Alomogordo until he is convinced that it is not going to he the biggest white elephant in the countrya monument with no people. Members of the State Board of Finance were told by the Goyernor this week that he needs more detailed information on the hall's operating budget, sources of funds, expected attendance projections and artifacts commitments.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board will decide shortly whether the nation's airlines may experiment with a new kind of service  perhaps nonservice is a better description  that's already been nicknamed The Brown Baa Special.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: Arizona and Drake Advance to Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 15 (AP)Arizona survived a 34point effort by John Garrett to advance to the championship game of the National Commissioners Invitation Tournament with a 10296 victory over Purdue tonight.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT ENDS VISIT HERE
description: President Ephraim Katzir o?? Israel spent a weekend in the city With the largest Jewish constituency outside of his country, at Sabbath service in two of New York's most prominent Orthodox houses o?? worship.

title: Thoeni Wins Cup Slalom at Sun Valley
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 15An aggressive, allout plunge in the second run of today's slalom event by Gustavo Thoeni, the 24yearold Alpine star from the high Stelvio Pass region of Italy, made World Cup officials sharpen their pencils and resort to mathematics today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The table accompanying last week's article on the 3M Company understated the company's assets. As of Dec. 31, 1974, they were $2,841,346,000.

title: Book Ends
description: Disputed. Thirtyfive years after its founding at Antioch College amidst the alarums of a distant war, The Antioch Review is bogged down in another nasty little war between its former editor and college officials. The latest issue of the literary magazine (the last issue appeared in November; 1973) is being held up at the printers, awaiting binding, in the thrall of an unpaid $3,000 bill. The college says it will pay the bill but only if an offending editorial by the deposed editor, Lawrence Grauman, is kept out. Mr. Graumairs contract was terminated, and he was subsequently summarily dismissed, last summer after he had incensed college officials by (1) taking a blind ad in The New York Review offering the financially strapped magazine for adoption and (2) sending out a letter to its subscribers in June of last year predicting the magazine's probable demise. Later, Mr. Grauman refused to sign a memorandum of understanding with the college promising not to make any derogatory remarks about the college or any references to the dispute in the issue. Claiming that such an agreement constituted prior restraint, Mr. Grauman wrote a rambling editorial with blank spaces where references to the dispute would have appeared. The editorial, he said, was intended to demonstrate 'what censorship would be like if I had knuckled under. College officials then sought an injunction against the publication of the magazine (by Mr. Grauman, that is), and Mr. Grauman has filed a blizzard of countersuits. The upshot is that any hope of a settlement that would free the delayed issue seems increasingly remote. A college official has said that it will not pay the $3,000 printer's bill for the thoughts of a cashiered editor and called the editorial petulant and selfserving.

title: Article 19  No Title
description: Directional Furniture Showrooms. New York: 979 Third Ave. D& D Bldg.

title: The AllOver Tan: A Modest Pursuit
description: I DON'T want to join a nudist colony. I don't want to go to Denmark where, I'm told, lots of people lie on the beach naked. I don't want to sunbathe topless with the Beautiful People on the beaches along the COte d'Azur. What I covet are private beaches where I can disrobe in seclusion. And I know how to find them.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES RULES FOR WATER
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed the first national quality standards for drinking water.

title: Money Is Not the Only Reason For Calvin Hill's W. F. L. Jump
description: Calvin hill, who must be included in any list of the top five running backs in pro football, is one of those players rooting hard for the World Football League to pull itself together and get on with the show in 1975. The reasons for Hill, a sensitive, deep thinker, transcend mere money, according to the 28yearold Yale alumnus, who is scheduled to move from the Dallas Cowboys to the Honoulu Hawaiians of the W.F.L. this year.

title: Some Upbeat News From Italy
description: With all the bad news from Rome these daysstrikes, economic distress, art theftsItalophiles are ready to grasp at any straw of good news. Thus, the euphoria over this item: The Leaning Tower of Pisa, which over the centuries has been threatening to fall down, has slowed its rate of tilt, all by itself, thus arresting a continuously increasing inclination rate. The 800yearold tower increased its tilt by only ninehundredths of an inch last year compared to eighteenhundredths of an inch in 1973, according to Giovanni Tavaglini, chief of a government commission studying the structure, which leans 17 feet from the perpendicular. The commission is reviewing projects to save the tower.

title: L. S. Roberts Fiance of Diana Weinstock
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max B. Weinstock of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Robin Weinstock, to Lawrence S. Roberts, an accountant with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Roberts, also of Westbury.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held this week by City Council committees:

title: HeartLung Center Plans Benefit Sale
description: ELIZABETHThe 23d annual Antique Show and Sale for the benefits of Deborah HeartLung Center in Browns Mills will be held Tuesday through Thursday at the Masonic Temple, 668 North Broad Street.

title: The Region/Continued
description: New Yorkers are used to intermittent guerrilla warfare with Ma Bell, but they were not prepared for the Great Phone Fire of 1975, which cut off 170,000 telephones in 12 exchangesan AL, three GR's, three OR'S, a CA, an SP, an LE, a YU and one 260. With the Great Phone Fire there came a Great Silence in a 300block area below 23rd Street, including the Village, the Bowery and the Lower Esst Side.

title: LETTERS
description: Unemployment

title: Showdown Approaches on the Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTONThe showdown will come this week on farm legislation that Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, equates with a poker hand. The stakes are high for farmers, for the banks and industries that serve them and for the consumers whom the farmers serve.

title: Suzanne E. Mahlburg Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton W. Mahlburg of Rockford, Ill., have announced the engagsment of their daughter, Suzanne Elizabeth Mahlburg, to Robert Woodbury Kay, son of Prof. and Mrs. Marshall Kay of Leonia. N. J.

description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

description: Private and city hospitals made preparations for emergency measures to maintain pa tient care as Federal mediators met yesterday with both sides in an effort to avert a strike threatened for 7 tomorrow morning by 3,000 intemes and resident physicians.

title: Jeanne Pettit Engaged to Gail A. Ferris
description: Mrs. Georgette Winchester Pettit of Summit, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jeanne Pettit, to Gail August Ferris, a senior at Yale University where he is captain of the lightweight crew.

title: Ellen Wessler, Thomas Harris Set June Bridal
description: Ellen Paula Wessler and Thomas Randolph Harris, who are in their first year at the New York University School of Law, plan to be married in June in. Princeton, N.J., where Mr. Harris is president of the Haskins Press, commercial printers.

title: Steven A. Stier Fiance Of Francine Heineman
description: Mrs. Frank Heineman of Elmhurst, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Francine Heineman, to Dr. Steven Allen Stier of Branford, Conn., son of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Stier of Bloomfield. N.J.

title: Computerized Help for the Farmers
description: Sixty New Jersey farmers, dairymen and nurserymen have found a new solution to their incometax and yearround bookkeeping woes.

title: New Orleans Handicap to Lord Rebeau
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 15 (AP)C. H. Marquez let the sprinters go to the front, then brought Paul Cresci's Lord Rebeau along the rail today to win the $100,000guaranteed New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds. His margin was 4 lengths.

title: ART VIEW
description: DETROIT. An age that has witnessed the virtual collapse of vanguard ideology, that has lived to see the Myth and the mystique of the artist's resistance to society succeeded by a period of dtente and accommodations will naturally be moved to make some wholesale revisions of the past. No longer will the martyrdom of the avantgarde command the same exclusive prestige. No longer will an art upholding official standards be so automatically rejected. As contemporary taste grows more expansive and eclectic, historical research is less inhibited in acknowledging the quality and accomplishment of, artists who do not conform to simpleminded scenarios of revolt. Artists who once served and served brilliantly, the interests of established power are granted new esthetic visibility are granted, indeed, an esthetic existence independent of their social role.

title: Democracy survives
description: Things happen very fast in an Allen Drury novel; they just take a long time. It is now 18 or so fictional months, give or take, an eon, since the Senate caught old Bob Leffingwell trying to fudge his college flirtation with. Communism and refused to confirm him as Secretary of State. Naughty Bob. That was in Advise and Consent. the Pulitzer Prize novel of 1960, which also sold a lot of copies and doubtless helped in its little way to set the rhetorical terms for the great QuemoyMatsu debates of that year. So one cannot blame Drury for trying again, although by the time he has finished The Promise of Joy, the sixth and last novel in the series, even the hardiest consumer of majestic bombast will be thankful that he has turned off the wind machine.

title: MRS. ONASSIS FLIES FROM HERE TO PARIS
description: Jacqueline Onassis left New York for Paris last night on Air France flight 070. She had spent most of the day in her Fifth Avenue apartment after announcement of the death of her husband.

title: THE ALIMONY BLUES
description: It isn't hard to understand why divorced husbands sing the blues over alimony. The money alone would be reason enough, but there's more to it than that. Rightly or wrongly, a man may figure that it's his wife's parting shot at him and that she, by God, wants it to hurt. It's an emotional punch that carries all the resentment and guilt pent up during the months or years when the marriage was turning sour.

title: Play Is Where Life Lives, Where the Game Is the Game
description: Shakespeare was wrong. To play or not to play: that is the real question. Anyone with a sense of humor can see that life is a joke, not a tragedy. It is also a riddle, and like all riddles has an obvious answer: play, not suicide.

title: Airline Pilots Call 11 World Airports Critically Deficient
description: VIENNA, March 15 (AP)The International Airline Pilots Association has listed 11 international airports, including those at Los Angeles and Anchorage as critically deficient.

title: Arguello Retains Title on Knockout
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 15 (AP)The World Boxing Association's featherweight champion, Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua, scored an eighthround technical knockout over Leonel Hernandez of Venezuela tonight.

title: POP MUSIC FOUND TO RENEW ITSELF
description: Rufus, a rhythmandblues band that played two shows last night at the Felt Forum and will be there again twice tonight, represents a classic instance of pop music's ability to renew itself.

title: Officials Optimistic On Use of Sludge
description: TOMS RIVERAfter more than two years of an experiment designed to ascertain whether sewage sludge can be used safely as a fertilizer, the Ocean County Sewerage Authority has noticed the first adverse effects.

title: Spending the Oil Money: A Problem, but the Better One to Have
description: LONDONNigeria's military Government seems to have reached a crossroads in its attempt to translate newfound oil riches into the social and economic programs its leaders want and its people badly need.

title: Marriage Planned By Claudia Cortese
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Cortese of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Cortese, to Stephen V. Desiderio, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent C. Desiderio of Media. Pa.

title: In Cold Print: Safe Publishing
description: Every successful publisher finds original material with big sales potential, right? Wrong. Or at least not right as far as it applies to the successful scholarly reprint publisher, who is ever on the qui vive for unoriginal material which will have a notsobig sale.

title: Why Outside Paint Peels
description: Although most people are quick to blame the paint last used when an outside paint job starts to prematurely crack or peel, nine times out of ten it is not the paint that is at faultthe problem is most often caused by poor preparation of the old surface (painting over a dirty, dusty or glossy finish), or by a moisture condition (moisture working its way in behind the paint film).

title: Leonard Maltin, Critic, Marries Alice Tlusty
description: Alice Paula Tlusty, who is on the staff of the Psychological Corporation, a division of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, publishers, was married last evening to Leonard Maltin, writer and film critic. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Gawron a Bride at Yale
description: Dwight Hall at Yale University was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Rose Gawron, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Gawron of Pittsburgh, to Paul Andrew Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnson of Valley Stream, L. I., and New Haven.

title: A Dream Sets Sail In 1976
description: Frank Braynard wouldn't know a Mako from a Snark or a Swan from a Salty Goose. But he is the moving force behind one of the biggest boating projects ever Operation Sail '76 Braynard lives and breathes the ships of yesterdaythe early ocean liners steeped in rococo elegance, the giant sailing ships with towering 18story steel masts.

title: CHICAGO ELECTION HELD A FORMALITY
description: CHICAGO, March 15  Or April 1, Chicago's voters are expected to assure that Richard J. Daley will continue to occupy the Mayor's office on the fifth floor of City Hall for four more years.

title: OTTO FEGER
description: Otto Feger, retired consultant to Omma Properties, Inc., a real estate company here, died Wednesday. He was 56 years old and lived in St. Thomas, V. I.

title: 20 Admit Gifts From Concern Doing School Business
description: Three employees at Board of Education headquarters have conceded that they accepted giftsdescribed in a confidential board report as being of substantial valuefrom a company that did business with the school system.

title: Bicentennial Barge on Fiscal Shoals
description: ALBANYA sight out of America's past, a canal barge, would bob through Long Island Sound, up the Hudson River, eventually ride the shallow waters of the Erie Canal west to Buffalo. Its cargo would be exhibitions showing how New Yorkers lived during the Revolution, its crew would include performers to personalize that life. At each of 20 or so stops, it would be the focus for a Bicentennial festival.

title: Suffolk Is Offered 18,000 Acres
description: RIVERHEADHurt by the downswing in construction, realestate developers in oncebooming Suffolk County have offered to sell 18,000 acres of open space for the county's $60million farmland  preservation program. Suffolk officials say that while they are a little surprised they are delighted by the amount of space offered.

title: NO BAN ON WOMEN BY TRIAL LAWYERS
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 15The American College of Trial Lawyers inducted 77 lawyers as fellows of the college at its closing session here this week. All of them were men. The borrowed British nomenclature, it developed, was non accidentalall the preceding 2,516 fellows admitted to membership in the select society were also men.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 16, 1975

title: The Thompsons: A Dancing Couple
description: WALDWICKWhen Basil Thompson, ballet master of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, and his wife, Alaine Haubert, a dancer with the company, first moved to this Bergen County community three years ago, they were something of a curiosity to their neighbors.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Bad movies by ambitious notalents are easy to write about, either with pious indignation and outrage or with venom of the sort that always sells more papers than affection ever did. The most difficult films to criticize are the ambitious movies that fail in parts, that are neither bad nor good, neither smash hits nor dismal flops, in spite of the intelligence and talents of the people involved. It's especially tough if you think you can see evidence of the talent and intelligence throughout the particular film.

title: Food News
description: LIVINGSTONThe bread is a long French loaf, and the sliced layers of meat are a mixed assortment of Italian (prosciutto, cappacola, prosciuttini) and kosher (hot pastrami, corned beef, salami) delicacies. The result? A sixfootlong submarine that can feed 30 hearty eaters, or 50 nibblers.

title: Burial on Skorpios
description: ATHENS, March 15Aristotle Onassis will be buried on his private island of Skorpios next to his son, Alexander, family friends said today.

title: Mill Basin Landfill Is Stopped
description: In response to community pressures, the city has canceled a threeyear lease with a private developer who was illegally placing landfill on 30 acres of undeveloped property and wetlands to construct a golf  driving range in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn.

title: Ailing Mrs. Court Bows To Miss Evert 63, 62
description: HOUSTON, March 15(UPI)  Chris Evert wore down an injured Margaret Court, 63, 62 to win the final of a Virginia Slims tennis tournament and the $15,000 first prize today.

title: They stumbled blindly into marriage
description: This precise, affecting and gently clairvoyant first novel (by an accomplished writer of short stories) has formed a rather peculiar triad in my mind: with Rona Jaffe's Family Secrets and Ingmar Bergman's Scenes From a Marriage! Alice Adams's book is warmer, surer of what it is doing, and more closely focused on its people than Rona Jaffe's; it does not have the extreme closeup quality, the stifling, riveting intensity, of Bergman's film. In accomplishment too it falls somewhere in between Bergman's discomfiting genius and Jaffe's flawed but intriguing venture beyond the autobiographical. But what all three have in commonafter a period of interminable, sweating subjectivityis a tone of perspective and reconciliation that comes of seeing human lives and relationships across time. I wonder whether this is a tendency, a reaction or swing towards the classical temper; certainly it's a swing back towards regarding the social and interpersonal as a rich field for artistic exploration. After our long immersion in the individual psyche and its obsessions, we are rediscovering the pleasures of the omniscient point of view: the pleasures, differently, of Austen and of James.

title: What Hope For Healthy Dividends?
description: Since the beginning of the year, investors have faced some major surprises in the form of dividend reductions by several of America's bedrock corporations.

title: WEST SIDE SLAYINGS ARE LINKED TO DRUGS
description: Two men found shot to death in an apartment at 315 West 76th Street on Friday were identified by the police yesterday as Colombian immigrants believed to be involved in narcotics trafficking.

title: DR. ALDEN EMERY, CHEMIST, 73, DIES
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., March 15Dr. Alden H. Emery, executive secretary of the American Chemical Society from 1947 to 1966, died last night at Suburban Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Bright Prospects For Control of Dutch Elm Disease
description: In experimental efforts to control Dutch elm disease (DED), which the elm bark beetle carries, scientists learned that beetles can be lured to a sticky death on oversized flypaper traps baited with a chemically made copy of their own attractant (pheroMane). In other localities, valuable elms are being injected or fed fungicides to make them immune to infection by the disease fungus. These are two of the promising techniques now being developed to preserve the remaining elms in the Northeastern states and to decrease the impact of DED in western cities.

title: Make Way for The Chic of Araby
description: From the Middle East comes the news that the oil potentates are now planning to recycle their petrodollars by buying into America's cultural treasures. One sheik has offered to purchase the Alamo from the state of Texas because his son expressed a liking for it, and persistent rumors are heard concerning other Middle Eastern moguls replacing the Rockefellers as the mainstays of our hardpressed cultural institutions. These New Rockefellers, it has been learned from usually reliable sources, have attached certain conditions to their philanthropy:

title: Letters
description: Oil slick

title: Frederick Brockway Gleason 3d Weds Ann Powell Lackey Here
description: Ann Powell Lackey and Frederick Brockway Gleason 3d of New York were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church. The Rev. Frederick Hill performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev.. Russell Dewart, a cousin of the bridegroom's mother.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONGovernor Byrne had a ready reply last week to mounting criticism that he has been doling out political patronage at a time when many public employes face the grim prospect of being laid off. One of his appointees, he said, had saved New Jersey the cost of a junket to Europe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A.H.S.A. Expands Base For Board of Directors
description: The American Horse Shows Association has amended its constitution to provide for more active participation of its members. Starting this year, the chairmen of the 12 regional zone committees automatically will become members of the board of directors. This will broaden the powers of the individual members, said Richard E. McDevitt, who was elected president of the A.H.S.A. two months ago. The regional committees are elected by the members, so the chairmen will carry their policies, ideas and desires to the board meetings.

title: Expansion By Rutgers In Camden Is Assailed
description: CAMDENA local community group that is fighting expansion plans of Rutgers University has asked a Federal agency to cut off Government funding for school construction projects and order reparations of $1.5million for neighborhood development.

title: ART VIEW
description: The center of the stage in the Metropolitan Museum's small but choice exhibition, Bronze Sculptures from Asia, is shared by. two deities, Vishnu, one of the three supreme gods of Hinduism; and Parvati, the consort of another, Shiva. At heights of about 30 inches, looking as if they had been made for each other (actually, both are from Madras but separated. by about 50 years in the 10th century), they are the largest figuresin the gallery. They look monumental in a company that included a number of other bronzes only two, three or four inches high among the 23 that glow under individual spotlights the darkened room.

title: For State Lotteries, Business Is Booming
description: CHICAGO, March 15In this period of economic hard times, state lotteries are booming.

title: Encounter: In Paris, a Haunted Memory of a Gilded Age
description: HIS was the only table in the restaurant with a vacant chair, and I begged permission in French. Please, he said in English. You honor me.

title: BRIDGE
description: Inspection of the McKenney rankings for 1974, which give the masterpoint totals of the most successful tournament players, suggests that the center of bridge gravity in North America continues to move West and South.

title: Long Island Club. Sets Collie Show
description: The Collie Club of Long Island will stage its 21st annual specialty at the Riverhead Armory on Saturday.

title: What's Doing in DUBLIN
description: ST. PATRICK'S DAY  Dubliners don't celebrate St. Patrick's Day with quite the same abandon that New Yorkers do, but tomorrow the Irish capital will offer: a parade through the center of the city, an openair concert on St. Stephen's Green, ballad singing and Irish jig contests in various pubs, horse racing in Phoenix Park and the annual Irish Kennel Club Show at the Royal Dublin Society Grounds in the city's Ballsbridge area. Dubliners have not forgotten the day! Ireland's National Feast Day, in fact, will be marked by a weeklong festival throughout the country from today through next Sunday, with parades scheduled in all the major towns and cities.

title: 4Town Fund Drive Tops Goal by $9,000
description: RIDGEWOODThe recently completed annual fundraising campaign of the United Way of Ridgewood, Glen Rock, HoHoKus and Midland Park, Inc., exceeded its $200,000 goal by approximately $9,000.

title: Phnom Penh Lifeline: The Supply Lift From Thailand
description: U TAPHAO, Thailand, March 15Thirtyyear old Chris Rice was flying for Eastern Airlines until he was laid off a year ago. Today he is one of about 601 highly paid United States Air Force veterans operating a vital airlift to sustain the Phnom Penh Government in its present state of seige.

title: Beame Would Give Office of the Aging Full Cabinet Status
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed upgrading the Mayor's Office of the Aging to a fullfledged city agency to make the city eligible for more Federal and state aid.

title: Fiscal Woes Force Cutback, in Contrast to the Federal Drive to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Many states are being forced to adopt economic policies that are the opposite of and could undermine proposed action by the Federal Government to restore the economy.

description: We have 383 inmates at the facilityminus six at this point.Warden Louis J. Gengler, after the latest escape from the Federal Detention Headquarters on West Street. [57:7.]

title: With Some Fascination, Speculates on His Successor
description: Clearly, the Egyptian side wants its Arab allies to believe that it is standing firm in demanding territorial concessions from Israel without making any of its own.

title: Vincent Sheean Dies
description: Vincent Sheean, reporter and author, died in Italy. He was 75 years old. His bestknown book was Personal History (1935). Page 32.

title: Lovejoy Award for Reston
description: WATERVILLE, Maine, March. 16 (UPI)James Reston, columnist for The New York Times, will receive the annual Lovejoy Award tomorrow night at Colby College. The award, honoring journalistic achievement, is named for Elijah Lovejoy, an 1825 Colby graduate,. who was killed while defending his press in 1837.

title: Alabama Legislature Summoned In Dispute Over Electricity Rates
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 16A hastily called special session of the Alabama Legislature will convene Tuesday to consider sweeping oranges in electric power rate regulation that would, according to the Alabama Power Company, bankrupt it if put into effect.

title: Connors Rallies to Win Final
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 16 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors, down a set for the second straight day, rallied again and won the local Independent players Association tennis tournament with a 36, 63, 60 victory over Jan Kodes.

title: Robber Hangs Himself In a Brooklyn Jail Cell
description: A Brooklyn man who was sentenced last Friday to a term of up to 12 years in prison on a robbery charge hanged himself with his belt yesterday in a cell of the Queens House of Detention in Kew Gardens.

title: F.B.I. Says Aim Is to Find Miss Hearst, Not Scott
description: Charles Bates, the Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in charge of the Patricia Hearst kidnapping case, said yesterday that the thrust of the investigation was still to find the fugitive newspaper heiress and two radical companions.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16Two Middle East pipelines have fallen victim of the changes now going on in the supply and demand of crude oil.

title: Reigned for 30 Years
description: You are a tradition; no, more than a tradition, you are an event in the life of America. This was John B. Connally's toast to Perle Mesta at one of her last Washington parties, given in 1972. Allowing for the usual Texas hyperbole, the salutation was not far off the mark, for Mrs. Mesta was a reigning Washington hostess for almost 30 years. Her lavish entertainments, which invariably included political figures, were notable for their gaiety and informaility.

title: Protestants and Catholics Get a Common Catechism
description: An extensive statement of agreedupon beliefs, the first document of its kind written jointly by Roman Catholics and Protestants since the 16thcentury Reformation, will become available here this spring.

title: 6 Bank Robbery Suspects Flee From U.S. Jail Here
description: Six men awaiting trial on bankrobbery charges escaped from the Federal Detention Headquarters here yesterday afternoon by cutting through three wiremesh screens, breaking through a skylight, then climbing down a makeshift ladder fashioned from bedsheets.

title: CABINET IN LISBON IS REPORTED OUT AS LEFTISTS GAIN

description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 16  The Rev. Sean Healy, an African missionary from Ireland, captured the 16th annual Earth Day marathon today at Roosevelt Raceway in 2 hours 27 minutes 1.4 seconds.

title: About the Yankees ...

Both teams will donate all their proceeds to the project that was the dream of the late Pirate star. . . . The Yankees produced a pair of fiverun rallies against Pittsburgh yesterday. Otto Velez singled in two runs in the second inning with one of histhree hits and Alex Johnson knocked in two with a homer in the eighth.

title: Troops Seem Surrounded In Town Near Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 16The Cambodian Government troops who were reported yesterday to have seized the key town of Tuol Leap were apparently surrounded today and perhaps cut off in the town by the same troops they had driven off.

description: Associated Press

title: Carey Hints There Is Give in His Budget
description: ALBANY, March 16Will Governor Carey be an easy touch in the state budget negotiations with the Legislature as they enter the twoweek homestretch toward an April 1 deadline for passage? This question is being asked increasingly here because of certain early hints that it only takes a bit of protest on the budget to bring a quickly yielding response from the Governor. Politician's are citing the Governor's actions in recent weeks in retreating in small ways from his initial budget proposal by restoring some money for state nursing schools, for treatment centers for alcoholics and for firemen's training assistants after relatively predictable flurries of protest.

title: Sonics Thwart Knicks, 9794
description: SEATTLE, March 16Even though they came within a point twice in the closing moments after trailing by 11 with 5 minutes to play, the New York Knicks lost to the Seattle SuperSonics, 9794, today, with both teams fighting for playoff positions.

title: Article 4  No Title
Fleet Velvet Coast Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 16 (AP)Fleet Velvet scored a mild surprise in winning the $55,700 San Felipe Handicap, at Santa Anita today and: threw some confusion into the 3yearold set with the Santa Anita Derby two weeks away.

title: Davis Cup Showdown Nears for S. Africa
description: Further disruptions of the Davis Cup competition over South Africa's participation may force an immediate showdown on the question, W. Harcourt Woods, the chairman of the Davis Cup Committee of Management, said yesterday.

title: Unifying the Courts
description: At the turn of the century, Roscoe Pound, one of the great theoreticians of the law, noted that the court system is archaic in three respects: multiplicity of courts, preservation of concurrent jurisdictions, waste of judicial manpower.

title: Mariner, Ending Mission, Gets Good Mercury Photos
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 16 (UPI)Mariner 10 made an unprecedented third planetary flyby today in its final mission, soaring probably less than 100 miles from the surface of Mercury, scientists said.

title: Sihanouk Forecasts Return
description: PARIS, March 17 (Reuters)The former Cambodian head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has forecast that his governmpntinexile in Peking will be installed in Phnom Penh by December, or perhaps sooner. In an interview with the magarine Le Point, Price Sihanout said that if he came to power, Cambodil would be nonaligned. But he added, China will remain our best friend.

title: Trail Paths In Rail Beds Are Urged
description: A Presidential advisory committee has urged the conversion of thousands of miles of abandoned railroad tracks into inexpensive hiking, biking and skiing trails as this nation's onetime opportunity to provide recreation and environmental benefits?

title: Texas Utility in Accord With Soviet on Coal Use
description: DALLAS, March 16 (AP)A private utility company will team with the Soviet Union in using the latest technology for developing deep deposits of lignite coal in East Texas, the Dallas Morning News reported today.

title: Kissinger in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, March 16Talks between Israeli leaders and Secretary of State Kissinger resumed here tonight after the Cabinet had empowered,the Israeli negotiating team to continue efforts to reach a new Sinai agreement with Egypt.

title: State Frees Sherwin, ExState Secretary
description: COLLINGSWOOD, March 16 (AP)Paul J. Sherwin, a former New Jersey Secretary of State, was released from prison today. What can I say?, he asked. I'm happy to be home. He was attending a party in his honor at the home of a friend. Two hundred people showed up.

title: Internes Affirm Deadline For Hospital Strike Today
description: Internes and resident physicians last night reaffirmed their determination to strike 23 local hospitals at 7 A.M. today, but early this morning they were considering a management proposal to avert the walkout.

title: FIRE KILLS EIGHT IN JERSEY FAMILY
description: CAMDEN, March 16  Eight members of a family that had just celebrated a birthday with a surprise party  the father, mother and six of their 10 children  were killed early today in a fire that wrecked their threestory row home here.

title: Violent Crime by Young People: No Easy Answer
description: Why is it happening? Why are an increasing number of youths committing brutal, violent and often senseless crimes?

description: Deborah Louise Conin, a general analyst in the intelsat management affairs department of the Communications Satellite Corporation in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Gilman of Washington, an assistant United States attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Almost a year ago we received a letter from a reader named Elaine Lapidus concerning rossel borscht. It is available, she informed us, only during the Passover season and in light of that we reprint her letter describing what seems to be one of New York's bestkept culinary secrets.

title: CHARGES EXPECTED IN SLASHER DEATHS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 16Los Angeles Police Chief Edward Davis said today that chargesas yet unspecifiedwill be filed Monday against a 31yearold man in connection with a recent wave of killing called the slasher murders.

title: Pivotal Time in Southern Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 13The logic of geography and economics has driven the whites and blacks of southern Africa together in an uneasy and unstable coalition. It could lead to real progress in solving the region's racial problems, but it could as easily fail. Increasingly the nations of the region have become closely intertwined. Increasingly, whiteruled South Africa has become the key to progress.

Cassebeer, Apothecaries and Chemists, now at 1021 Madison Avenue at 75th Street, since 1843, died Saturday night in Nyack (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and attracted thousands yearly to his gardens on Lake DeForest. N. Y.

Like the islands in Nantucket Sound, these dunes are particularly cherished because they are an uncommon and relatively unspoiled natural area near a crowded metropolitan centerin this instance, the city of Chicago and its suburbs.

description: TORONTO, March 16 (UPI) Gil Perreault and Rick Martin each scored three goals and Rick Dudley added a pair to lead the Buffalo Sabres to an 113 defeat of the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

17 JAZZMEN SAMPLE ROLLCALL OF GREATS
description: The National Jazz Ensemble covered an impressive range of history at the New School on Saturday evening in a concert by a 17piece ensemble conducted by Chuck Israels. The program drew on the work of Bix Beiderbecke, Jelly Roll Morton, Duke Ellington, Lee Konitz, Gil Evans, Horace Silver and Wayne Shorter and capped its historical perspective with a performance by Roy Eldridge, the veteran trumpeter, that crackled and flared with characteristic flashes of musical lightning.

title: Girl Scout Cookies In Ohio Tested for Contamination

title: CHANGES FAVORED IN MARIJUANA LAW
description: The state's 21 county Prosecutors have recommended that the penalties for smoking or giving out a few marijuana cigarettes be modified and that Prosecutors be given wider discretion to distinguish between offenders who distribute small amounts among friends and those who buy and sell for profit.

title: Nantucket Sound...
description: Rich in history and in physical beauty, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket are two of America's bestloved islands. Situated in Nantucket Sound... thin easy traveling distance of densely populated New York and southern New England, these still pastoral islands afford a test of the nation's capacity to reconcile intensive use and open space.

title: Christine Alexion Married to Roger Lee
description: Christine Maria Alexion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Alexion of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Roger Arras Lee, son of Jean Arras Lee and the late E. Melvin Lee. The Rev. Dr. Daniel K. Poling performed the ceremony in the Fort Washington Collegiate Church.

description: In a search for new sources of materials for special programing, the commercial television networks are turning en masse to books, both fiction and nonfiction.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a spurious, threatening letter in 1969 to a black Baptist minister to compel him to'cease his civil rights work in Mississippi and return to the North, newly released bureau documents show.

description: The Law of the Sea Conference which reconvenes in Geneva today offers the last chance that the international community can anticipate to organize for orderly use and exploitation, for the benefit of all mankind, of the more than twothirds of this planet that is covered by water.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is one of the peculiarities of modern life and language that our dissatisfactions seem so very sophisticated while our gratifications tend to have a naive, artless sound. Goodness shows up badly and cynics have all the best lines. Few people had a more thoroughly documented low opinion of man than Freud and it gave his books a tragic sense of life that held literary intellectuals in thrall for half a century.

title: Miami Beach, Nearing Age 60, Is Facing an Uncertain Future
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 15When the late John Collins started developing this subtropical strip of oceanfront back in,the early nineteenhundreds, he dreamed of creating another Atlantic City.

description: ALBANY, March 16At the start of what is supposed to be the final week of negotiations on the new state budget, the Republican majority in the Senate and the leader of the Democraticcontrolled Assembly collided again today over the need for higher state taxes.

title: About New York
description: What I've seen of it I've adored, Rosarie Dunne was saying. She was talking about New York, saying she had not seen much more of it than Flatbush Avenue, 34th Street, City Hall, Macy's and various drugstores, but that all this had pleased her, nonetheless. Miss Dunne is Irish, and today she will march in the St. Patrick's Day parade. Then she will see Fifth Avenue, Mo.

title: Australia Revises Policy in Approval Of Citicorp's Deal

title: SEEGER AND GUTHRIE SALUTE LEADBELLY
description: In the nineteenfifties, Huddie Ledbetter, more dramatically known as Leadbelly, was the darling of the folklorists. The current neglect of the singer who died in 1949 is as surprising as it is unjustified. Therefore, the Tribute to Leadbelly staged Saturday at Hunter College, is a step in the right direction.

description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: 100,000 March Early In South Boston Parade
description: BOSTON, March 16 (UPI) More than 100,000 persons today celebrated St. Patrick's Day early by watching 15,000 parade through South Boston. Nearly all wore the traditional green and some flourished antibusing buttons in their lapels.

title: COMPLAINT LODGED IN SAIGON SHOOTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (Reuters)  The widow of a French correspondent who was shot dead by the Saigon police has lodged a complaint of premeditated murder, informed sources said today.

C.I.A. Report Says Worsening World Grain Shortages Could Give U. S. Great Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16A research report of the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that world grain shortages, which are likely to increase in the near future, could give the United States a measure of power it had never had beforepossibly an economic and political dominance greater than that of the immediate postWorld War II years.

title: Flyers Win; Parent Gets 11th Shutout
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP)Bernie Parent, a doubtful starter in goal until game time, recorded his 11th shutout of the season for the Philadelphia Flyers today against the Los Angeles Kings, 3.0, in the National Hockey League.

title: Indiana: Still Undefeated, Still Favored
description: Between halves of the IndianaTexasEl Paso game in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, Adolph Rupp, the retired Kentucky coach, said, If we get 'em we'll handle 'em and beat 'em.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING FOUND DEAD IN CAR
description: William L. Ball, a 50yearold unemployed businessman facing trial for the murder of his former wife's best friend, was found dead yesterday morning in a car in the garage of the Westchester home where the slaying had taken place last May 27.

title: Women's Caucus Ends on Cheering Note
description: ALBANY, March 16With shouts of Bella for Senator and Krupsak for Governor, the convention of the New York State Women's Political Caucus came to a resounding close here this afternoon as the nearly 200 women rose to their feet and cheered their two beaming favorities, Representative Bella S. Abzug and Lieut. Gov. Mary Ann Krupsak.

title: CITY OPERA MANON HAS SENSITIVE GLOW
description: Despite a number or pivotal cast changes, a superior ensemble of fine young singing actors gave a sensitive glow to the City Opera's Manon Lescaut at the New York State Theater yesterday afternoon. In the litle role was Patricia Craig, who made her debut four years ago as another Puccini heroine, Mimi, in La Bohme; her Des Grieux was Gaetano Scano, the Italian tenor who first appeared here last September as Cava??adossi in Tosca.

title: Article 10  No Title
About the Nets . . .
description: Mike Gale, the Nets' reserve guard, still has the stitches in his right hand, which has kept him out of the last five games since he gashed himself between the second and third fingers colliding with Kentucky's Artis Gilmore. He said there was no pain, and he could've played yesterday if the Nets needed him but they didn't. . . . Wendell Ladner, out with a pulled hamstring in his Tight leg suffered in the same Kentucky game, was also ready for action but did not play. . . . The Max Kase Lodge of B'nai B'rith presented Coach Kevin Loughery with its coachoftheyear award at halftime and Julius Erving with its playeroftheyear award. . . . Tonight's game against the Indiana Pacers is the makeup of the Feb. 12 snowedout game. In celebration of St. Patrick's Day, the first 5,000 fans through the turnstiles will receive green derbies. Tickets for the Feb. 12 game will be honored.

title: 3 Inquiries Begun On Plunge of Car From S.I. Ferry
