description: Dr. Samuel Gelfan, who retired in 1973 as research professor of neurophysiology at New York Medical College, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Ossining, N. Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: CHOKOLOSKEE ISLAND, Fla., March 16The apparition materialized dead ahead as Doug House steered a snaky course north through the maze of mangrove islands, channels, bays, inlets and estuaries that make an unsolved jigsaw puzzle of Florida's Southwestern coastline, where the Gulf of Mexico meanders over oyster bars and through jungle deep into the Everglades. What's that? Doug said. A plane down? A note of excitement crept into his voice. Salvage? he said. One of his passengers had binoculars but couldn't hold them steady in the lurching boat. A freshening breeze had been kicking up seas for an hour, prompting the guide to take leave of the redfish down in Lostmans River and start the 25mile run home earlier than he would in calmer weather. Now the fishing party was crossing a wide and lumpy arm of the Gulf inside Pavilion Key, about 12 miles below Chokoloskee. Whatever the thing was on the water ahead, it was orange in color.

title: Neckties Designed to Tickle the Sense of Humor Discreetly
description: During a recent lunch hour, a neckwear aficianado passing Chipps, just west of Madison Avenule in 44th Street, was struck by a display of ties adorned with multicolored letters IITYWTMWYBMAD. He pronounced it to himself with greatdifficulty and even after identifying its Latin roots was unable to comprehend its meaning.

title: Bridges:
description: HONOLULU, March 16 New York experts captured both major titles last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here.

title: New Books
description: Cry Witch, by Naomi Hintze (Random House, $6.95), Romantic suspense story.

title: About the Mets...
description: The Mets' use of the designated hitter in some games with American League teams may foreshadow a softening of the National League's resistance to the 10th man: Yogi Berra's explanation: In the early exhibition games, our pitchers only work three innings and don't get to bat anyway. . . . Before yesterday's game the White Sox presented a contract to John W. Allyn, owner of the team, as hitting coach for the pitchers. Since the designatedhitter rule went into effect in the American League two years ago, Chicago pitchers have gone to bat only five times and made no hits. As their hitting coach, Allyn received a $2 contract in 1973, took a dllar cut in 1974, then won a raise phis a costofliving bonus to $2.75 this year because his pitchers suddenly have gone 33

title: Internes Affirm Deadline For Hospital Strike Today
description: Internes and resident physicians last night reaffirmed their determination to strike 23 local hospitals at 7 A.M. today as Federal mediators continued their roundtheclock efforts to avert the walkouts.

title: Beame Would Give Office of the Aging Full Cabinet Status
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed upgrading the Mayor's Office of the Aging to a fullfledged city agency to make the city eligible for more Federal and state aid.

title: Florida Women Golf CoVictors
description: HOUSTON, March 16 (AP) A pair of Floridians, Debbie Austin and, Sue Roberts, Bach shot fourunder par 69?? today to shake top honors in the hastily organized $35,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association pro amateur tournament at Sugar Creek Golf Club.

title: Advertising
description: Things might have been rather bleak elsewhere Friday morning, but in the ultramodern offices of Benton & Bowles all was sunshine, warmth and happiness when those good folks from Rocky Mount, N.C., delivered the word that the agency had just gotten the national advertising assignment from Hardee's Food Systems.

title: Massahusetts Bomb Threat
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., March 16 (AP)The home of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was evacuated and searched today after the Federal Bureau of Investigation received a terse telephoned bomb threat.

title: KURDISH FAMILIES FLEEING TO IRAN
description: HAJ OMRAN, Iraq, March 16  The freezing wind whipped at Aisha Mohammed Amin's cotton clothes as she squatted by the highway beside her belongings and her shivering children. We have no food, no bread, she said to a traveler. We left our village before the killing, and now we will die of the cold.

title: Drake Captures Tournament Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (UPI)Unheralded Drake upset 17thranked Arizona, 8376, and won the second annual National Commissioners invitation basketball tournament.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 17, 1975

title: SeaLaw Talks Resume Today in Geneva, With U.S. Hopeful
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The United Nations Conference on the Law of the Seas resumes tomorrow in Geneva, with American negotiators hopeful of agreeing on a draft treaty.

title: Politics to the People
description: WASHINGTON  Writing in 1796 Madame de Stal understood fully the revolution of her time. The aristocracy of election, when its proceedings are conducted with wisdom and integrity, cannot fail to select men distingulshed for their talents, whom it will place in the most eminent stations of society. If we puzzle today at this seemingly innocent statement by an illustrious intellect and experienced politician of the French Revolution, let us understand where she stood where our Constitution of 1789 stood, and where stand today.

title: ATTICA DEFENSE SPLITS ON FUNDS
description: A split in the ranks of the leading Attica brothers men facing murder and other charges growing out of the 1971 prison riotscame to light yesterday, with detectives investigating alleged misuse of checks intended for their joint defense.

title: Protestants and Catholics Get a Common Catechism
description: An extensive statement of agreedupon beliefs, the first document of its kind written jointly by Roman Catholics and Protestants since the 16thcentury Reformation, will become available here this spring.

title: Food Stamp Inefficiency
description: As deepening unemployment leads to broader participation, the food stamp program is bound to draw increasingly intense scrutiny. The most recent reports, indicating that 17.9 million Americans now sustain themselves with the help of food stamps, clearly indicate that the program is serving as one of the major cushions for the people most severely affected by the lagging economy.

title: SURGING AUDIENCE AT RUFUS CONCERT
description: Seats were just a formality Saturday at the Felt Forum, a tenuous base of operations for the audience (at least up front) to work with the group Rufus, in particular the singer Chaka Khan and the headliner, Al Green, in the most vocal way possible. It was that kind of concertsoul singers, noise, a surging audience full of righton rallying cries as Miss Khan, all bump, grind, strut and strongly elastic voice, commandeered the faithful to react to Rufus's high energy.

title: 100,000 to March Today In Honor of St. Patrick
description: The city's annual St. Patrick's Day parade is expected to attract 100,000 marchers today. The parade, which has never been canceled since it began in New York 213 years ago, is scheduled to be conducted in wet and windy weather.

title: Economists Challenge Validity Of Simon's TaxCut Strategy
description: As Congress has put together its package of tax cuts, controversy has developed over how to obtain the greatest stimulus to the economythat is, whether to give most of the benefits to taxpayers with lower income or higher income.

title: New Hampshire Is Lacking Enthusiasm, But Not Candidates, for 1976 Primary
description: CONCORD, N.H., March 13Someday they will hold a New Hampshire Presidential primary and no one's going to come, says Robert J. Keefe, director of Senator Henry M. Jackson's campaign for the Democratic nomination.

title: Residents Near Metropolitan Museum Sue to Obtain. HistoricDistrict Status
description: In a spirited attempt to block the building of a 25story studioapartment building on a block of turnofthecentury row houses and beauxarts mansions, residents of East 82d Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues have taken the Landmarks Preservation Commission to court to obtain historicdistrict designation for the street.

title: City Opera: At Last, an Idomeneo!
description: It probably goes too far to say that Idomeneo is an unknown opera, even in New York, where neither of the leading companies had, until last night, produced Mozart's masterpiece in the opera seria tradition. But even those few Mozarteans who know and love the work would not pretend to have much to go on in the way of actual performances.

title: Peter Wylie Weds Linda A. Margolis
description: The Cottage on the Park at Hampshire House was the setting here at noon yesterday for the marriage of Linda Ada Margolis to Dr. Peter Bradford Wylie. Rabbi A. Allan Bloch performed the ceremony.

title: Couple and 6 of Their 10 Children Die In Camden Fire After a Birthday Party
description: CAMDEN, March 16Eight members of a family that had just celebrated a birthday with a surprise partythe father, mother and six of their 10 childrenwere killed early today in a fire that wrecked their threestory row home here.

title: Cairo Wants Timetable
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 16Egypt expects a new Israeli withdrawal in Sinai to be carried out over a period of three to six months if Secretary of State Kissinger gets a new agr'eement, high Egyptian officials said today.

title: Babylon Wins L.L. Title
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 16Babylon beat previously undefeated South Side of Rockville Centre, 7262, tonight at Nassau Coliseum, and won the first Long Island scholastic basketball championship.

title: Hospital Dispute Issues
description: PARTICIPANTS The League of Voluntary Hospitals and The Committee of Internes and Residents, representing 3,000 internes and resident physicians employed by the league in 23 hospitals in the city. The doctors work in 12 nonsectarian voluntary hospitals, four Catholic volunteer hospitals and seven municipal hospitals that have affiliation contracts with the league.

title: Getting Down To the Basics
description: Her shops aren't chi chi, nor Is the merchandise they carry terribly expensive. But Vicki Cooper, who runs the Ulla stores in Westport, Conn.; Great Neck L.I., and on Madison Avenue with hes husband, Allyn Claman, decided her customers deserved a fashion show anyway.

title: Cays Top Jazz at Buzzer
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (AP)Jim Brewer tipped in the winning goal at the buztier tonight to give the Cleveland Cavaliers a 113111 victory over the New Orleans Jazz.

title: City Council Considering $124Million in New Taxes
description: While Mayor Beame anguishes about imposing new taxes to balance his expense budget for the next fiscal year, which he contends has an $883million deficit at this time, the City Council legislative hopper holds nuisance taxes that could bring an estimated $124.8million in new revenues to the city.

title: Stage: Wings, Based on Aristophanes
description: Ornithologists of the world unite, you have nothing to lose but your brains. Wings, which opened at the Eastside Playhouse last night, is based on Aristophanes's The Birds. There is nothing much wrong with Aristophanes's comediesindeed their fantasy is frequently brilliantbut because time has for the most part taken the sting out of their satire, they now seem singularly unfunny, childlike at best, childish at worst.

title: Blessings of Recession
description: In a Cleveland tavern, the man on the barstool to my right looked bleak; he had been out of a job for two months, had no prospects, and was feeling the pinch. But the man on the barstool beyond him, who was buying the beer, had a different story:

title: Issue and Debate
description: The attempt to get more minority workers into the construction trades in New York City recently moved from the controlled give and take of yearlong negotiations among the city, state and representatives of unions and contractors to an open and often acrimonious polarization.

title: Cairo Wants Timetable
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 16Egypt expects a new Israeli withdrawal in Sinai to be carried out over a period of three to six months if Secretary of State Kissinger gets a new agreement, high Egyptian officials said today.

title: Egyptian Office Damaged
description: A window of the Egyptian Government tourist office in Rockefeller Center was smashed with a brick early yesterday, the police reported. A caller to United Press International shortly before 4 A.M. attributed, the vandalism to a group calling itself SOIL, an acronysm for Save Our Israel. The caller described it as our answer. to [Henry] Kissinger's pressure on Israel to relinquish vital land. The police said that they knew of no witnesses to the incident and that no one was inside the Egyptian office, at 630 Fifth Avenue, when the vandaism occurred.

title: Democratic Contests Focus on Strauss
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Another series of guerrilla skirmishes in the protracted battle for control of the Democratic party is expected this week at a number of meetings in Washington.

title: NEED FOR TAX RISE IN STATE DEBATED BEFORE DEADLINE
description: ALBANY, March 16At the start of what is supposed to be the final week of negotiations on the new state budget, the Republican majority in the Senate and the leader of the Democraticcontrolled Assembly collided again today over the need for higher state taxes.

title: G.M.'s Record Financing Due This Week
description: The General Motors Corporation leads the parade of borrowers in the corporate bond market this week, while the United States Treasury will weigh in with two auctions totaling $3.45billion in securities. Scheduled for offering on Thursday is G.M.'s package of $600million in notes and debentures. It will rank as the biggest debt financing ever by an industrial company.

title: Fee Issue Leads Dean To End Lecture Tour
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., March 16 (AP)John Dean 3d, President Nixon's former counsel, said last night that he was ending his college lecture tour because his fees were becoming the issue and not what he had to say about Watergate.

title: Mentor of a Generation of News Reporters
description: Vincent Sheean, the American journalist whose reflective, personal style influenced a generation of newspaper reporters in the nineteenthirties and forties, died Saturday at his home in Arolo, Italy. He was 75 years old.

title: Legal Contest in Fort Lee Bribery Trial Pits Youth Against Experience at Bar
description: NEWARK, March 16The $1.6million Fort Lee bribery trial in Federal District Court here is pitting a team of youthful, aggressive prosecutors against a battery of wellknown criminal lawyers.

title: U.S. Urged to Strip Indians Of Special Sporting Rights
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16 (UPI)Delegates to the National Wildlife Federation's annual convention today called For a new national policy that would strip American Indians of special hunting, fishing and timber rights.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dover Township in Ocean County announced plans Saturday to recycle garbage and sewage in cooperation with a Washington company that will share its profits with the township. The company, the American Resource Recovery Corporation, will pay for the construction of a $1.8million recycling facility in Toms River and will give the township part of its profits from selling the products made from the recycled materials.

title: Key Headquarters Shifted From Pleiku
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 17  Steppedup rocket attacks against the important airport at Pleiku, the cutting of two vital highways in the area and a buildup of North Vietnamese forces were cited yesterday by knowledgeable Westerners in the transfer of a South Vietnamese corps headquarters from Pleiku to the coast.

title: Music: Spanish Passion
description: Alicia de Larrocha, that small but towering artist, long ago expanded beyond the narrow category of specialist in Spanish music, so that now few pianists of her caliber have so large and catholic a repertory. But, gladly as one grants that fact, no musician alive plays Spanish music with the conviction and taste of Miss de Larrocha.

title: BLACK PASTOR GOT F.B.I. THREAT IN '69
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a spurious, threatening letter in 1969 to a black Baptist minister to compel him to cease his civil rights work in Mississippi and return to the North, newly released bureau documents show.

title: 52 Are Killed in Crash Of an Argentine Plane
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 16 (AP)  At least 52 persons died today when a passenger plane operated by the Argentine Air Force crashed into a mountain peak near the Andean resort of San Carlos de Bariloche, authorities reported.

title: RICHARD DEKORTE A JERSEY OFFICIAL
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., March 16 (AP)  Richard W. DeKorte, considered by many persons as a future gubernatorial candidate in New Jersey, died of cancer at his home here today. He was 38 years old.

title: Mansfield, at 72, Reflects on Agony of Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, March 16As he celebrated today the 72d birthday of a life that has largely been shaped by Asia, Senator Mike Mansfield saw what he called the beginning of an end of an era of American involvement in the Asian mainland.

title: Oregon Ousts St. Peter's; Oral Roberts Advances
description: Arnold Dugger, who played only the second semester of his junior year at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, put in 35 productive minutes for Oral Roberts last night in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square. Garden. He also lifted the Titans to a 9795 victory over Memphis State with a jump shot from the foul line with 2 seconds left to play.

title: Article 12  No Title
Man Jumps to Death
description: A 32yearold Brooklyn man apparently jumped to his death from the ninth floor of the Hotel St. George at 51 Clark Street yesterday morning. The police identified the man as Larry Sourile of 1651 11th Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. He had checked into the hotel the night before.

title: Dr. Frederick Blachly, 94, Political Scientist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Frederick F. Blachly, a political scientist, who retired as a senior staff member of the Brookings Institution in 1945 died Thursday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 94 years old and lived in Adelphi. Md.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We have 383 inmates at the facilityminus six at this point.Warden Louis J. Gengler, after the latest escape from the Federal Detention Headquarters on West Street. [57:7.]

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A wiry, 28yearold shipping clerk resembling a man sought for close to 100 rapes in the South Bronx was arrested two hours after he allegedly raped a 40yearold mother after entering her upperfloor apartment at 500 Southern Boulevard through a bathroom window. The suspect, Jose Carabello of 669 Prospect Avenue, was seized at about 7:30 A.M. by two uniformed patrolmen in front of 964 Avenue St. John. Though he was charged only with yesterday morning's rape, the police said that Mr. Carabello fit the description of a suspect sought for dozens of recent sexual assaults in which the rapist gained access to his victims through nearly inaccessible windows.

title: Loughlin Tops Hayes For Crown
description: Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn defeated Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx, 6257, yesterday for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title at Fordham University in the Bronx.

title: The Classics, Lincoln Center and Papp
description: Joseph Papp, who is a pragmatist as well as an idealist, has always given himself enough room to change his mind  before, during and after the fact. He has scheduled plays and then dropped them; fired directors in the middle of a production: closed shows in previews; and, at least in retrospect, been critical of his own work. He has always been flexible enough to contradict himself. But two weeks ago he had what for him appears to be not so much a change of mind as a change of heart. He announced that beginning next season he was renouncing his policy of presenting new American plays atithe Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center and switching to revivals of classics with guest stars.

title: Jacob Kalich of Yiddish Stage, Molly Picon's Husband, 83, Dies
description: Jacob Kalish, who produced, directed, wrote and acted in Yiddish theater productions here and abroad, died yesterday of cancer at his home at Lake Mahopac, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: IRVIN A. EDELMAN
description: Irvin A. Edelman, a lawyer active in philanthropy, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital following a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Protecting Freedom
description: The struggle now going on in Washington to achieve some kind of control over national police and intelligence forces basically concerns the quality of freedom.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Kissinger,
description: JERUSALEM, March 16On the way to Aswan several nights ago, newsmen in the rear of Secretary of State Kissinger's plane were talking about the possibility of his resigning. Some believed he would quit by the end of the year and remove himself as a political issue in President Ford's campaign; others argued that he would stay at least through the rest of this term.

title: Mrs. Onassis Visits Bier; Family Arranging Burial
description: PARIS, March 16  Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis today visited the chapel of the American Hospital here, where the body of her husband Aristotle Onassis lay, as preparations were made for burial on his private Greek Island of Skorpios.

title: Ellyse Gordon Wed to Tiberio Schwartz
description: Ellyse Gordon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Gordon of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Tiberio Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elemer Schwartz of Barranquilla, Colombia.

title: Susan Hayward Is Buried Near Old Home in Georgia
description: CARROLLTON, Ga., March 16 (AP)Susan Hayward was buried today in the piny woods near this west Georgia city where she used to live, after a requiem mass was offered in the chapel she helped to found.

title: Article 9  No Title
3 AGENCIES STUDY OIL IMPORT PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Forty agents of the United States Customs Service and 140 investigators for the Federa Energy Administration are look ing into potential and alleged frauds in the supplying of of that may have cost consumers millions of dollars in the Iast 18 months, spokesmen for the two agencies said today.

title: Miss Bleiberg Married to R. A. Seperson.
description: Susanne Gisele Bleiberg, a sociology instructor at Dowling College in Oakdale, L. I., was married yesterday to Robert A. Seperson, a supervisor of sets for ABC television shows.

title: FOREIGNERS BEGIN BORROWING IN U.S.
description: Foreign borrowing in the United States is reviving, but so far it is still far from a boom.

title: Susan Walker Bride of R. J. Kowen
description: Susan Pomeroy Walker daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alexander Walker Jr. of Honolulu, was married Saturday to Richard James Kowen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Kowen of Pittsford, N.Y.

title: McDowell's Pirate Pitch Strong
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16At different times and in different places throughout his 14year career, Sam McDowell often has been the eye of the hurricane, both on and off the field. Today, however, McDowell was the calm in a scoring storm that engulfed the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: ISRAEL IS SEEKING IMMIGRANTS HERE
description: The head of a major Zionist organization yesterday called on American Jewish communities to list aliyah (immigration to Israel) as a major priority because of the recent sharp decline of immigrants to the Jewish state.

title: Is There a Jerboken in Hoboken's Future?
description: HOBOKEN  The jokes began to travel almost fits fast as the news that the Mayors of Jersey City and Hoboken were looking into the possibility of combinmg some of the towns' municipal services police, fire, public works and purchasing, among othersat a prelude perhaps to outright merger.

title: Spinola Declines Comment
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 16Former President Spinola, appearing tired but relaxed and closely guarded by Brazilian security agents, refused to make any declaration here today about the uprising that forced him into political exile.

title: So. Carolina, Princeton Gain NIT Quarterfinal
description: South Carolina's touch of New York and Princeton's defense put both basketball teams into the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tournament yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. They meet Thursday

title: Women's Rights, and Wrongs
description: PITTSBURGHA recent rash of pop sociology articles in the national media has attempted to link a rise in the female crime rate with the growth of the women's rights movement. The spurious reasoning behind this charge seems to be that granting women equal rights encourages them to commit the same crimes as men.

title: Turkish Student Sees America Through L.I. Filter
description: WANTAGH, L.I.Always, there is the question. Whether Kursat Onder, a Turkish exchange student, is making a speech, visiting a home or walking through the halls of the high school he is attending here, there is the question: What do you think of America?

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1975

title: Texas Utility Buys Soviet Coal Method
description: DALLAS, March 17Soviet technology for developing underground gasification of liginite coal has been purchased for use in Texas by a threecompany power system, it was announced here today. The cost, of the technology was put at less than $2million.

title: G.O.P. Paper Downgrades Prospects for Third Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)The latest issue of First Monday, the monthly newsletter published by the Republican National Committee, devotes four of its 16 pages to downgrading the prospects for a successful third party move in 1976.

title: Transportation Authority Strike Snarls the Philadelphia Area
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP)Traffic slowed to a crawl on crowded highways and city streets, and harried commuters jammed mass transit alternatives today as the twodayold strike against the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority entered its first working day.

title: TOURO SETS DATE FOR LAW SCHOOL
description: With fresh financial backing and a new name, Touro Law School will open next fall, Eugene V. Rostow, the school's director of planning, said yesterday.

title: Wildlife Leader Reelected
description: PITTSBURGH, March 17 (AP) Walter L. Mims of Birmingham, Ala., has been reelected president of the National Wildlife Foundation, the largest conservationist group in the country, with 3.5 million members.

title: 21 HOSPITALS HERE HIT BY A WALKOUT OF HOUSE DOCTORS
description: In the country's first major work stoppage by doctors, 21 of the city's 91 voluntary and municipal hospitals were struck yesterday by a union of 3,000 internes and resident physicians seeking a reduction in long hours.

title: U.S. WITHDRAWAL SOUGHT BY THAIS
Shadow Over Kenya
description: In eleven years of independent life, the Republic of Kenya, under the leadership of President Jomo Kenyatta, has enjoyed a reputation for relative stability and economic progress in a part, of the world not noted for either achievement. This image was badly scarred in 1969 by the murder of Tom Mboya, one of Kenya's outstanding younger leaders. Mr. Mboya had predicted that there, would be an attempt on his life by rivals within the Government party.

title: Books of The Times
description: Andrew Beyer is not the usual sort of horseplayer. He came to his profession with a philosophical vengeance. In 1965, with two weeks to go before graduation from Harvard, he ran into an irreconcilable conflict. My final examination in Chaucer was scheduled on the same day that Kauai King would be trying to win the Triple Crown at Belmont Park. I knew nothing about the Canterbury Tales but I know something about Amberoid in the  Belmont Stakes. So I went to the track. Although I blew a $12,000 education, I did collect a $13 payoff on Amberoid, cutting my losses for the day to $11,987. And he has been at it ever since: first as a sports reporter or The Boston Globe and The Washington Post, then 3.5 horseracing columnist for The Washington Daily News and since 1972 The Washington StarNews, and now as the author of a book called Picking Winners: A Horseplayer's Guide.

title: Nolan Ryan in Form
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 17 (UPI)Nolan Ryan pitched three perfect innings in his first appearance of the spring and combined with Charlie Hudson, Dick Selma and Orlando Pena to restrict the Cleveland Indians to a pair of singles today as the California Angels posted a 53 exhibition victory. Ryan struck out three batters. He said a slightly strained calf muscle in his right leg had little effect on his performance.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: CARLYLE W. HALL

title: 7 Hurt in Phoenix Blast
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17 (AP)Seven persons were injured today when an explosion, apparently touched off by a natural gas leak, ripped through a factory on the city's West Side, firemen said.

title: Rock Island Line Files for Reorganization
description: CHICAGO, March 17The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad Company, unable to get an emergency loan from the Government, filed today for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act and said it would cease operations after March 31.

title: Onassis Legacy: A Complex Empire Under Pressure
description: PARIS, March 17  Aristotle Onassis had one of the most complex and extensive empires in modern business, but even before his death on Saturday, the web of shipping, air transport and real estate operations was under pressure from the world business slump.

title: JUNE 30 DATE URGED FOR EUROPE SUMMIT
description: GENEVA, March 17The Soviet Union wants the 35nation European Security Conference to complete its negotiations here in time to call a summit session in Helsinki on June 30 to adopt a declaration on EastWest dtente, Western diplomats said tonight.

title: Two Developers Accused by F.T.C. On Homesite Sales
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused two major land developers today of selling millions of dollars worth of virtually worthless and useless property under the guise of homesites.

title: The SleeplessNights Syndrome
description: News Analysis

title: Verso's Comic Gift Pervades Dances as a Puppet and Joker
description: Sunday afternoon and evening were busy for Edward Verso, who danced two major roles at the City Center 55th Street Theater. In the afternoon he was the hapless puppet of Petruchka as the Joffrey Company presented the ballet for the first time in repertory this season, and in the evening he was more happily cast as the joker in Jeu de Cartes.

title: German Spacecraft Rounds Sun in Record Approach
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)A German spacecraft named Helios survived a recordbreaking approach to the sun and made the first detailed measurements of the sun's surface, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: JOB CORPS TEACHER WINS POINT IN COURT
description: I NEWARK, March 17 (UPI)  A Job Corps teacher who was stabbed in the skull in 1966 by a trainee wielding a screwdriver won a fouryear court battle today to make the Government liable for brain injuries he sustained.

title: TV Hearings Attract Cameras for Brief Time
description: Channels 2, 4 and 7 all had camera crews at the hearing today. Channels 4 and 7 packed up their equipment and left shortly after Governor Cahill  the first and one of the most easily recognizable of today's witnessesfinished his presentation.

title: Garelik Is Named Chief of Transit Police
description: Sanford D. Garelik, former City Council President and former chief inspector of the city's police force, took over as chief of the Transit Authority Police Department yesterday and pledged to make safety on the Icity's subways his No. 1 priority.

title: City Spurs Columbus H.S. Integration
description: A new zoning plan for academic high schools in the Bronx, which will give more minority students the opportunity of attending the borough's most heavily white school, was announced yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: My Guy Has Trouble With Tall Guys
description: Sports of The Times

title: 2 Tenement Floors Burn
description: A twoalarm fire destroyed the top two floors of a fivestory tenement at 150 East 97th Street yesterday afternoon. Seven persons, including six firemen, were reported slightly injured in the fire, which slightly damaged the third floor and buildings on each side of the tenement. Firemen said that about 10 families were temporarily homeless because of the fire. Its cause was not determined.

title: SOUTH VIETNAM REPORTED YIELDING MOST OF CENTRAL HIGHLANDS AREA; MAIN EVACUATION ROUTES CUT OFF
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 18The Saigon Government has decided to abandon most of the Central Highlands of South Vietnam because the area has become militarily indefensible, wellplaced Western sources said today.

title: Newark Dismisses 348 More; Gibson Sees a $10.15 Tax Rate
description: The new layoffs, which are the first to touch the Police and Fire Departments, will bring to 781 the total number of city employes to be dismissed here since the Gibson administration began its effort to eliminate the anticipated budget gap.

title: Rockland Official Quits Over $36,75 Voucher
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. March 17 (UPI)  Rockland County's $25,000ayear Transportation Coordinator has resigned in a dispute over a $36.75 accident voucher.

title: Brooklyn Supreme Court Slowed by Aides' Sick Call
description: Operations at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn were sharply curtailed yesterday when 170 of its 182 uniformed court attendants called in sick in a oneday job action over several longstanding grievances.

title: ROSTROPOVICH EYES U.S. CONDUCTOR POST
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP)  Mstislav Rostropovich, currently on a concert tour of the United States, says he is considering a post as conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington.

title: Lifting Mark Set
description: MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters)Nikolai Kolesnikov of the Soviet Union set a world featherweight lifting record for the jerk today with a lift of 160.5 kilograms (354.1 pounds).

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP)Mary Bacon, who was quoted in a local newspaper as saying that race horses at the Fair Grounds were being drugged, convinced track stewards she has no knowledge of illegal drugging. As far as we are concerned, the matter is closed with Miss Bacon, said E. J. Champagne, one of the stewards, when asked if punitive action would be taken. Miss Bacon appeared before the stewards yesterday to amplify the charges attributed to her in The New Orleans TimesPicayune.

title: ExRangers Vs. Club They Left Behind
description: How would you like to see the leading scorers of the Los Angeles Kings and Minnesota North Stars plus the second highest scorers on the Pittsburgh Penguins, Atlanta Flames and Kings playing in the uniform of the New York Rangers?

title: U.S. WITHDRAWAL SOUGHT BY THAIS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 17  Premier Kukrit Pramoj said in a policy statement today that his coalition would seek the complete withdrawal of the 25,000 American troops and 350 aircraft from Thailand within a year.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Eeyore's is a new bookstore just for children. The small, greencarpeted shop at 230 West 82d Street (just east of Broadway), is lined with hundreds of the standard classics, as well as new works.

title: U.S. Ready to Talk
description: WASHINGTON, March 17A State Department spokesman said today that the United States was prepared to enter discussions on withdrawal of the American troops remaining in Thailand whenever the Bangkok Government desired.

title: Assemblyman Confirms He Gave Leak on Wilson to Carey Aides
description: ALBANY, March 17An upstate Democratic Assemblyman who received money from the Carey gubernatorial campaign has confirmed that he had told Carey officials during the campaign of some information derogatory to former Gov. Malcolm Wilson that he helped leak to newspapers.

title: South Africa Gold Output Off
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 17 (Reuters)South African gold production fell to 1.91 million ounces in February from 1.94 million ounces in January and 2.22 million ounces in February last year, the Chamber of Mines said today.

title: People and Business
description: Attempting to pour oil on roiled waters, Robert S. Ingersoll, Deputy Secretary of State, defended Investment in the United States by oilexporting nations.

title: LEGISLATORS' FUN SPOILED ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.For members of the California Senate and Assembly, possibly the most pampered state legislators in the nation, this is the winter of discontent, a time of rain and loss of privilege.

title: CORRECTION
description: Randolph A. Hearst, father of the missing Patricia Hearst, was erroneously identified in Sunday's Week in Review section as the publisher of The Sari Francisco Chronicle. Mr. Hearst is editor and publisher of The San Francisco Examiner.

title: Court to Weigh Ban on Drug Price Ads
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can effectively ban all advertising of prices of prescription drugs by threatening to revoke the license of any pharmacist who publishes such information.

title: PRICES FOR CORN AND SOYBEANS UP
description: Corn and soybean prices moved up sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly because of short positions bought heavily to even out positions ahead of the Government acreage estimates due after the close of trading.

title: ExAide in H.E.W Warns U.S. on Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Dr. Charles C. Edwards, who resigned in January as the nation's chief health official, foresees a potentially disastrous tug of war soon between Congress and the Administration over national health insurance.

title: Stocks Up; Dow Gains 13.06
description: The stock market registered a broad advance yesterday in heavier trading with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at its highest level in more than seven months.

title: SUPREME: COURT GIVES U.S. ATLANTIC SHELF OIL TITLE, DENYING 13. STATES' CLAIM
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Federal Government has exclusive rights to any oil and gas resources on the Atlantic Outer Continental Shelf beyond the threemile limit.

title: Notes on People
description: Protests greeted the announcement in the House of Commons yesterday that Alexander N. Shelepin, former chief of the Soviet secret police, the K.G.B., under Nikita S. Khrushchev, would be granted a visa to visit Britain next month. Mr. Shelepin, a member of the Politburo, was invited by Britain's Trades Union Congress as chairman of the AllUnion Council of Trade Unions.

title: SOUTH VIETNAM REPORTED YIELDING MOST OF CENTRAL HIGHLANDS AREA; MAIN EVACUATION ROUTES CUT OFF
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 18The Saigon Government has decided to abandon most of the Central Highlands of South Vietnam because the area has become militarily indefensible, wellplaced Western sources said today.

title: Article 4  No Title
Capital Appropriation Seen Spurred by Money Supply Rise
description: Continued growth of the country's money supply will be an important factor in the eventual increase in capital appropriations for expanding and improving manufacturing capacity, The Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Highland Provinces Back at Center Stage
description: With the word that they will be abandoned to North Vietnamese military pressure, the Central Highlands provinces of Kontum, Pleiku and Darlac once again are center state in South Vietnam's long and bloody drama.

title: Garelik Is Transit Police Chief; Declares Safety No. 1 Priority
description: Sanford D. Garelik, former City Council President and former chief inspector of the city's police force, took over as chief of the Transit Authority Police Department yesterday and pledged to make safety on the city's subways his No. 1 priority.

title: Line Carved Niche in Nation's History
description: CHICAGO, March 17At 10 A.M. on Sunday, Oct. 10, 1852, six yellow coaches pulled by a brightly painted locomotive dubbed the Rocket, with wood smoke billowing from its balloon stack, pulled out of Chicago station. Two hours later the train arrived in Joliet, Ill., completing the 40mile maiden trip of the new Rock Island Railroad.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In the last two months fewer than half of the Board of Estimate members and high city officials have made the symbolic gesture of contributing portions of their annual salaries to ease the city's financial crisis.

title: DOLLAR LINKAGE IS CUT BY KUWAIT
description: KUWAIT, March 17 (UPI)Kuwait severed today the link between her dinar and the dollar, becoming the third oilexporting state to link her currency instead to the International Monetary Fund's special drawing rights. The change is effective tomorrow morning.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 2 million common shares of Philip Morris, Inc., at 48 a share, was made late yesterday afternoon by underwriters headed by Lehpan Brothers; Goldman, Sachs & Co., and Kuhn, Loeb & Co. The company has said net proceeds from the offering initially would be applied to repayment lof shortterm debt.

title: Thirsty Metropolis
description: Blessed with a prolonged period of abundant rainfall, the residents of New York City have been consuming water for the past five or six years as if the supply were unlimited.

title: Mariner 10
description: We are all so blas these days that even nearmiracles are taken for granted and little noted. Consider the case of Mariner 10 , which rocketed from earth Nov. 3 1973, and has traveled almost a billion miles since then.

title: I.R.S. Leprechauns
description: The recent information explosion about the misuse of Federal agencies to dampen real or imagined domestic, political dissent now includes broad allegations of abuse of the records and powers of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Knicks' Next Test Is Lakers Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, March 17 Will the Knicks make the National Basketball Association playoffs? It's a question the team, its ownership and its fans have had to face seriously only once in the last 17 years, and as the Knicks arrived here last night for a game against the Lakers tomorrow, the pressures were mounting.

title: Bomb Tossed in Saigon Bus Injures Eight Americans
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 18 (UPI)A man on a motorcycle tossed bomb into a bus in Saigon today, wounding eight Americans, a United States spokesman said. None was believed seriously hurt.

title: At Last, an Idomeneo, Thanks to City Opera
description: It probably goes too far to say that Idomeneo is an unknown opera, even in New York, where neither of the leading companies had, until Sunday night, produced Mozart's masterpiece in the opera seria tradition. But

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: STATE THREATENS SUIT ON RAIL CUTS
description: TRENTON March 17 (UPI)The State of New Jersey threatened today to file suit against the reorganization of eight Northeast railroads if the Federal Government ignored its plea to save small freight lines that serve vital industries.

title: Funds Ask the Supreme Court to Bar Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 17A major segment of the mutual fund industry, with the strong support of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged the Supreme Court today to dismiss antitrust charges against it on the ground that Congress never intended Federal antitrust laws to apply to mutual fund sales charges.

title: Teachers Reject Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, March 17 (AP) The 2,600 members of Local 420 of the American Federation of Teachers voted overwhelmingly last night not to go on strike at midnight, as union officials had recommended.

title: Liberal Party Offers a Program To Rescue National Economy
description: The country's economic crisis was variously viewed last night as a dread recession, a depression and, finally, the brink of catastrophe at a Liberal party delegate convention held to review a ninepoint national program to rescue our economy.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Youngsters watchingor trying to watchthe St. Patrick's Day Parade here.

title: Data on Tires to Be Allotted
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)Government consumer and safety offices said today they would furnish automobile and tire hazard information to state and local consumer offices. The office of Virginia H. Knauer, special assistant to the President for consumer affairs, said the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration would send the recall information to about 289 state and local consumer offices throughout the nation.

title: FORD SEES PROOF OF DOMINO THEORY
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 17 President Ford said here today that events in Southeast Asia tended to validate the socalled domino theory and that the existence of a nonCommunist government in Cambodia was vital to American security.

title: DEVELOPER HEARD IN FORT LEE CASE
description: NEWARK, March 17A Bergen County realestate developer testified in Federal Court here today that a Belleville electrical contractor last year told him it would cost $3.5million to pay off Fort Lee officials who were blocking a giant commercial center that the developer hoped to build near the George Washington Bridge.

title: Ballet: A Too Brief Visit
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet ended its sadly short visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday. For the company to be called, as it is on the Brooklyn programs, a resident company of the Brooklyn Academy of Music seems to be taking the word resident etymologically all too lightly.

title: CAHILL, MEYNER FAULT TV NEWS
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 17Two former New Jersey Governors faulted television news coverage of the state as inadequate and said that lack of coverage made it more difficult for them to govern.

title: Notes on People
description: Protests greeted the announcement in the House of Commons yesterday that AIeksandr N. Shelepin, former chief of the Soviet secret police, the K.G.B., under Nikita S. Khrushchev, would be granted a visa to visit Britain next month. Mr. Shelepin, a member of the Politburo, was invited by Britain's Trades Union Congress as chairman of the AllUnion Council of Trade Unions.

description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Federal Government has exclusive rights to any oil and gas resources on the Atlantic Outer Continental Shelf beyond the threemile limit.

title: Giscard Shaping Reform Plans And French Find Idea Catching
description: Paris, March 17The specifics of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing's proclaimed goal of changing French society without upheaval are beginning to take shape.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State of New Jersey has created a new bureau to investigate corrupt public officials and has set up a special unit to take public officials to court to return graft money. Attorney General William F. Hyland established the agencies as part of a reorganization of the State Criminal Justice Division. He said the corruption control bureau would made up of four lawyers, eight state police detectives and seven special accountants to investigate crimes through public records.

title: Farmers Plan a Cut In '75 Corn Planting
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Farmers intend to plant 75.3 million acres of corn this spring for harvest in 1975, a decrease of 3.2 per cent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: MERLE ARMITAGE, 82, ART PUBLISHER, DIES
description: YUCCA VALLEY, March 17 (AP)Merle Armitage, author and former editorial and art director for Look magazine, died Saturday at HiDesert Memorial Hospital, apparently of a stroke. He was 82 years old.

title: NEWARK LAYS OFF AN ADDITIONAL 348
description: NEWARK, March 17Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that 348 city employes, including 112 policemen and 66 firemen, had been sent dismissal notices, and that the propertytax rate would rise from $8.60 to $10.15, the highest rate in the city's history, because of an anticipated $35million deficit in the next fiscal year's budget.

title: Racial Incidents in Pensacola Prompt Attempts by Klan to Get New Members
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., March 16 C. E. Carroll, who identified himself as Titan of Provinces 5 and 6 of the United Klans of America, stood in the middle of the little repair shop just west of the Pensacola city line and explained the organizing tenets of the Knights of the. Ku Klux Klan.

title: JURY IS CRITICAL OF CAMDEN POLICE
description: CAMDEN, March 17  A Camden County grand jury that investigated the Camden Police Department for eight months found a severe breakdown in its administration and functioning, according to a presentment made public today.

title: About the Mets
description: In the first cuts of spring training, five young players were sent crosstown to the minor league complex for reassignments. They were Ike Hampton, formerly a catcher and now an infielder; Benny Ayala and Bruce Boisclair, outfielders; Luis Rosado, a catcher and Jay Kleven, a catcher who had been invited to camp but was not on the varsity roster. That leaves 39 players on hand, and Manager Yogi Berra must drop 14 more in the next three weeks.... Marvin Miller, director of the Players Association, will meet the Mets today during his annual tour of training camps, after which the team plays the Boston Red Sox in a night game (Channel 9, New York, 7:30 o'clock). Jon Matlack and Rick Baldwin will pitch for the Mets.

title: South Africans Invited to Montreal
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 17 (Reuters)  South Africa has been invited to send a team to the preOlympic Games track and field meet in Montreal in July, officials announced here today.

title: Issues in Hospital Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSThe League of Voluntary Hospitals and The Committee of internes and Residents, representing 3,000 internes and resident physicians employed by the league in 23 hospitals in the city. The doctors work in 12 nonsectarian voluntary hospitals, four Roman Catholic volunteer hospitals and seven municipal hospitals that have affiliation contracts with the league.

title: Schools and the People
description: When registration for the third citywide community school board elections begins tomorrow, parents and others interested in the improvement of public education face the opportunity of proving that school decentralization can work.

title: N.I.T. to Consider Proposals on Blacks
description: Blacks will probably have a greater voice in the selection of teams for the National Invitation Tournament asa result of a meeting yesterday at Madison Square Garden between Peter Carlesimo of Fordham, the chairman of the tournament's selection committee, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson of PUSH, People United to Save Humanity.

title: Tunnel Work, Halted Dec. 7, Resumes
description: Seventy sandhogs and other construction workers, most of them out of work since last Dec. 7, gathered on a bleak hillside in Highbridge Park above the Harlem River Drive early yesterday morning, waiting for an elevator to drop them 670 feet into the ground to resume digging the city's Third Water Tunnel.

title: Paying Patients Blockaded By London Hospital Staff
description: LONDON, March 17 (AP)Workers in a London hospital blockaded the section used by paying private patients today, cutting them off from normal meals, cleaning, porter and telephone services.

title: SUN OIL CUTS PRICE FOR RESIDUAL FUEL
description: The Sun Oil Company said yesterday it had cut its prices for residual fuel by 2.1 to 4.8 per cent, effective immediately, for f.o.b. shipment's from Marcus Hook, Pa.

title: Smith's first Woman President Anticipates a Great Adventure
description: NORTHAMPTON, MassOne hundred years after it was foundedon the benefaction of a reclusive spinster and the prompting of her parsonSmith College will at last be run by a woman.

title: Surgery for McGraw
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (UPI)Tug McGraw, considered the key to the Philadelphia Phillies' pennant hopes this season, will undergo surgery here Wednesday for removal of a lump below his shoulder blade.

title: Hunter Blanks Pirates 6 Innings
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. March 17 (UPI)Jim Hunter and Pat Dobson pitched the New York Yankees to a 21 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight before a capacity crowd of 20,000 at Hiram Bithorn Stadium. The Pirates managed only five hits.

title: Ullman Would Tax Gasoline 37c More
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Representative Al Ullman of Oregon, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, introduced today a comprehensive energy bill that would gradually add 37 cents a gallon to the Federal gasoline tax by 1980, with cash rebates on the basis of nine gallons a week.

title: Henderson Drops Appeal
description: Skitch Henderson has dropped an appeal of his conviction for filing false income tax returns. The orchestra leader filed papers yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals in New York, asking to withdraw the appeal, which had been due for a hearing in the week of April 21. Mr. Henderson faces six months in prison and a $10,000 fine.

title: Bucks See No Need Now to Make Deal for Unhappy AbdulJabbar
description: About Pro Basketball

title: TRADE MAY EXPAND BY 3% IN THE WORLD
description: GENEVA, March 17World trade may expand by up, to 3 per cent in volume this year if economic activity recovers during the second six months, according to the experts of the international agency that oversees most of the world's commerce.

title: COURT DISMISSES JUDGE'S BIAS SUIT
description: An attempt by Judge Bruce McM. Wright to regain his former position on the city's Criminal Court bench was rejected yesterday by Judge Charles M. Metzner in Federal Districts Court here.

title: High Court Again Rejects Levy CourtMartial Plea
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPL)The Supreme Court refused today to reverse the courtmartial of former Army Capt. Howard B. Levy, who disobeyed orders to train medics for service in Vietnam.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: MR. FORD. Good afternoon. It's been a great and wonderful day here in South Bend. And I thank everybody for it and I'm looking forward to this news conference. Mr. Jack Caldwell.

title: METALS INDUSTRY HIT BY RECESSION
description: The effects of the growing recession are reaching into the metals industry almost daily, according to industry reports.

description: Seven landlords and managing agents, and 18 realestate corporations with which they were affiliated, were indicted yesterday on charges that they had falsely certified that they had corrected housing violations and thus were entitled to rent increases under the city's rentcontrol law.

description: MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters)The threeman American team scheduled to pilot a United States Apollo spacecraft to an orbital linkup with a Russian Soyuz in July arrived in Moscow today for 10 days of joint training with their Soviet colleagues. The Americans were led by Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford.

description: DALLAS, March 17 (AP)Martina Narvatilova of Czechoslavkia, seeded third, defeated unranked Marena Croschina of the. Soviet Union, 64, 75, tonight in the $75,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker women's tennis tournament.

description: PEKING, March 17 (Agence FrancePresse)Foreign Minister Ahmed Laraki of Morocco met Premier Chou Enlai in a Peking hospital today, on the third day of an official visit to China, the news agency Hainhua reported. The agency gave no details about the meeting.

title: PRICES MOVE UP ON AMEX AND OTC

But they, indicated that the fight against offshore drilling would continue until stringent environmental safeguards were imposed.

One policeman was wounded in the shootout at a small home in suburban San Antonio de Padua, 12 miles west of Buenos Aires.

Both Wendell Ladner, reserve forward, and Mike Gale, reserve guard, were ready to return to action last night. They were hurt at Kentucky 10 days ago. Gale had a gash between the fingers of his right (shooting) hand and Ladner pulled a hamstring muscle.

Nixon in return for the two pandas at the Washington zoo, died on Feb. 20. Milton died of hardware disease, which results from the swallowing of sharp objects, such as nails. His mate, Matilda, is apparently well in her enclosure at the Peking Zoo.

description: American school children have apparently slipped in their reading ability since the midnineteensixties, but they are still ahead of their contempo??ries of the nineteenfifties, the nineteenforties and earlier periods.

description: MEXICO CITY, March 17The Mexican Government has accused the United States Central Intellience Agency of having bee behind the stoning of President Luis Echeverra Alvarez by a band of youths at National University last Friday. Several officials, among them the President himself, have made such charges, but they have offered no evidence.

title: DEAN WITTER PROFIT AND REVENUES RISE
description: Dean Witter Organization, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $2.5million on revenues of $42.2million for its fiscal second quarter ended last Feb. 28.

description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 17 President Ford said here today that events in Southeast Asia tended to validate the socalled domino theory and that the existence of a nonCommunist government in Cam. bodia was vital to American security.
