description: The planned shutdown date of March 30 for the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroads was extended yesterday to April 12 by United States District Court Judge Frank J. McGarr in Chicago.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1975

title: REA Cuts 11.000 Employes' Pay 10%
description: REA Express, Inc., the nation's largest ground and air express service, has made another 10 per cent cut in the paychecks of 11,000 employes, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Murder Suspect Is Sued for Divorce
description: Claudius James Giesick Jr., charged with the New Orleans honeymoon murder of his heavily insured bride, has been sued for divorce by one of his three previous wives, according to United Press International.

title: AMEX STOCKS DIP; OTC IRREGULAR
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday while those in the overthecounter market finished mixed.

title: ROAD OUT OF HUE: LONG NIGHTMARE
description: HAI VAN PASS, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 22By the thousands, the people are abandoning Hue, the former capital of Vietnam, and the road south from the city is scene of human suffering.

title: Connors, Taylor, Kodes, Gerulaitis in Semifinals
description: Jimmy Connors who says that tennis is show biz as well as a sport, pleased a small unsympathetic crowd of 2,627 in the Felt Forum last night when he had to struggle a bit with John Teaver ofBritain to gain a 61. 75 victory. Connors will meet Jan Kodes of Czeaoslovakia tonight in the semifinals of the $25,000 Independent Players Association tournament. Kodes defeated Sandy Mayer of New York, 61, 62, to gain the berth. Play will begin at 7:30 PM.

title: Mets Fall; Kingman In Center
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 21Dave Kingman continued his springtime slugging today with ?? fifth home run. He also made a debut as a center fielder without flaw. But his efforts alone could not produce a victory as the Los Angeles Dodgers pounded three New York Mets' pitchers for 15 hits and a 135 triumph.

title: Hoosiers' Speed Seen Decisive in N.C.A.A.
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 21 Coach Bobby Knight of Indiana said today that there was a 5050 chance that Scott May would start against Kentucky in the Mideast Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament tomorrow.

title: Witter Raises Dividend
description: Dean Witter Organization, Inc., the holding company for the brokerage house of the same name, said yesterday it was raising its regular quarterly dividend on common stock to 12 cents a share from 10 cents a share. The dividend is payable May 1 to shareholders of record April 9.

title: WRIT IS SET ASIDE ON NURSING HOMES
description: A State Supreme Court judge yesterday pushed aside a legal obstacle that for two years had impeded the enforcement of the Federal Life Safety Code at the city's nursing homes.

title: Thompson Is Leader With 66133
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.. March 21 (AP)  Barney Thompson, a secondyear man on the pro golf tour, shot the best round of his brief careera sixunderpar 66and led Arnold Palmer by three strokes after the second round of the $150,000 Greater Jacksonville open today.

title: Army to Keep N.W. Ayer As Its Advertising Agency
description: DORADO, Puerto Rico, March 21With four of the country's leading advertising agencies competing for its recruitment account, the Department of the Army decided yesterday to stay with its current agency, N. W. Ayer ABH International. The heads of all four agencies got the news here at the Cerroman Beach Hotel, where they are attending the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: MANILA CITES GAINS IN ITS LAND REFORM
description: MANILA, March 22Information Secretary Francisco S. Tatad said yesterday the landreform program that is a keystone of the promised New Society was proceeding satisfactorily, having already aided 190,630 tenantsthreefourths of whom were tilling lots of 58 acres or more.

title: Coletti, an Italian Ace, Is Foiled In International Fencing Here
description: Giovanni Coletti, the Italian foil champion, failed yesterday to win a bout in the opening round of the Martini & Rossi international fencing competition.

title: Klammer, Race Victor, Ties for Ski Cup Lead
description: SANTA CRISTINA, Italy, March 21 (UPI)  Franz Klammer of Austria blazed into a threeway tie for the men's World Cup Ski championship today by winning the last downhill race of the season in course record time.

title: Iraq Planning $1.5Billion Oil Development
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 19 Iraq is planning to invest $1.5billion in exploration and development of its huge oil reserves, and production capacity will be raised gradually to a maximum of 4.40 million barrels a day by 1980.

title: Yankees Chide Martin For BeanBall Tactics
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, March 21The Yankees and the Texas Rangers met in a B game today, but it didn't even produce a grade B fight.

title: Newark Unions Try to Save City Jobs
description: NEWARK, March 21Leaders of the local municipal unions here said today that they had prepared several proposals that could save some of the jobs of the 348 city employes, including 112 policemen and 66 firemen, who have been sent dismissal notices in anticipation of a deficit in the 1976, budget scheduled for adoption next Thursday.

title: Big 3 Auto Makers To Open All Plants
description: DETROIT, March 21For the first time since last November, the Big Three auto makers will have all their plants operating next week.

title: The Mummy's Flight
description: In 1968 when American relations with Egypt were at a low point, the Central Intelligence Agency approached Howard Hughes with an expensive plan to obtain the Great Pyramid of Cheops.

title: Jerome Nathanson Dead at 68; Headed Ethical Culture Society
description: Jerome Nathanson, chairman of the board of leaders of the New York Society for Ethical Culture for 20 years until illness caused him to curb his activities last year, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 145 Central Park West. He was 68 years old.

title: PANAMA IS PLANNING PAYMENT TO JAVELIN
description: PANAMA CITY, March 21 (Reuters)  Panama will pay compensation to the Canadian Javelin Company, which discovered the Cerro Colorado Copper deposits in western Panama, the head of the Panamanian Government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, said today.

title: N.I.T. Conducts Its Semifinals Here Today
description: Upsets have been the history of this tournament, said Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's yesterday, looking back over the 38 years of the National Invitation Tournament. And so saying, he suppressed a shudder in anticipation of the Redmen's meeting against Providence this afternoon in the opener of a semifinal round basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: H. L. HUNT EMPLOYES CONVICTED OF FRAUD
description: DALLAS, March 21 (UPI)Two former employes of the late oil billionaire H.L. Hunt have been found guilty of defrauding a Hunt concern, HLH. Products Company, in 1968.

title: Phones Ringing Again
description: The sweet sounds of jangling telephones began to be heard once again yesterday evening in the 300block area in Manhattan that has been without telephone service for more than three weeks, as the New York Telephone Company raced to meet its 11:59 P.M. deadline for full restoration of service to the area. Page 49.

title: ITALY TO ABOLISH CURBS ON IMPORTS
description: ROME, March 21Italy today announced early abolition of controversial import curbs that were imposed at a low point of her financial crisis last may and eased credit restrictions.

title: HERMAN KROOSS, ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Herman E. Krooss, professor of economics and former chairman of the department of economics at the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University, died yesterday in the Allentown (Pa.) Sacred Heart Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Allentown.

title: Degomorrahization
description: The columns of this newspaper have carried countless articles concerning the decline of Times Square, once known as the crossroads of the world. The area itself is now at a crossroads. Is rejuvenation of Times Square finally beginning, or is the area to follow its present path which can leave us with only a history of what was the greatest tourist attraction in the world?

title: Prime Rate Cut to 7% By National City Bank
description: The First National City Bank lowered yesterday Its prime rate on corporate loans to 7 per cent from 7 per cent, effective Monday. In reducing its rate to this level, Citibank joined the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Chemical Bank, the two banks that led the way last Tuesday.

title: FREDERICK B. LYON OF FOREIGN SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Frederick B Lyon, a retired career minister in the Foreign Service, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: U.S. Preparing for Atlantic Oil Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)  The Interior Department said today it planned to take the first step next week toward opening up the Atlantic Ocean as a new frontier for offshore oil drilling.

title: PARTY IN AUSTRALIA ELECTS NEW LEADER
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 21Malcolm Fraser, a wealthy 44yearold landowner was elected leader of the Liberal party today in a victory that was seen as a shift to the right for Australia's major opposition party.

title: Celtics Set Back Braves. 109 to 101
description: BOSTON, March 21 (UPI) Jo Jo White's 26 points led a balanced attack tonight to offset Bob McAdoo's 49 points as the Boston Celtics defeated the Buffalo Braves, 109101, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Writer Says He Met With F.B.I., but Denies Seeing Miss Hearst
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 Jack Scott, the writer and radical sports figure who is being sought in connection with the Patricia Hearst kidnapping case, disclosed today that before his disappearance earlier this month he met twice with Federal agents.

title: Tully Hall Concert Canceled
description: Dennis Russell Davies, who was scheduled to conduct Lincoln Center's New and Newer Music concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, is ill, and the concert has been canceled. Ticket holders will be given refunds at the Tully Hall box office.

title: DurableGoods Orders Rose in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 21In one of the first signs of a possible upturn to the sliding economy, new orders for durable goods rose in February after a precipitous decline that began last September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Turnpike to Reroute Traffic
description: Traffic on parts of the New Jersey Turnpike will be rerouted this weekend because of continuing repairs on its mainline Passaic River Bridge, a spokesman said. From 7 A.M. to 3 P.M. today, all traffic southbound from the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel area will be directed to the turnpike's parallel western spur.

title: Head of U.D.C. Inquiry Panel Named
description: Sheldon H. Eisen, a former Federal attorney, was appointed as chief counsel to the special state commission investigating the Urban Development Corporation. The appointment of Mr. Eisen, a 46yearold lawyer who previously served as an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, was announced by Orville H. Schell, Jr., the chairman of the inquiry panel, which is known as a Moreland Act Commission.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A Painless Recession At Some Restaurants
description: They're feeling it at La Caravelle, the Four Seasons, Orsini's, Quo Vadis, and The 21 Club. But at Lutce, La Grenouille, La Cte Basque, La Goulue and The Sign of the Dove, they say it doesn't hurt at all.

title: Puerto Rico Pays Heavily For Mainland's Recession
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 21 Puerto Rico is importing a massive dose of the United States recession, and paying for it is forcing equally massive austerities on the people and Government of this sunny, productive but deeply troubled island commonwealth.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains Semifinals at Dallas Net
description: DALLAS, March 21 (UPI)Thirdseeded Martina Navratilova, the points leader on the Virginia Slims women's tennis circuit, powered her way into the semifinals of the Maureen Connolly Brinker event today.

title: C.A.B. OFFICIALS DIFFER ON INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 21In sworn testimony, the acting chairman and former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board gave sharply conflicting versions today of the reason the board dropped an investigation into alleged illegal campaign contributions by the nation's 35 regulated airlines.

title: Phillips in a Deal With Oil Shale Corp
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Oil Shale Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed a letter outlining the basis of negotiations for the sale of Phillip's California refining and marketing properties to Oil Shale. The negotiation will also include transfer of certain Phillips oil terminals and marketing properties in Washington, Oregon and western Nevada.

title: N.H.L.'s Worst Team Provides Capital Punishment for Its Fans
description: LANDOVER, Md. Soon, maybe not tonight, but soon, the Washington Capitals know they will smash still another record that marks them as the worst team in the history or the National Hockey League.

title: Accused Slayer Convicted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 21 (UPI)Donald Jones, 21 years old, of Pittsburgh, was found guilty yesterday of thirddegree murder in the Christmas night slaying of Robert Bedney, 31, of New York.

title: Art: John Walker Changes His Style
description: Exactly 10 years ago, when Clement Greenberg was on the jury of a prize exhibition in England, he responded at once to the quirky, ambiguous and nonimitative work of John Walker. Mr. Walker later visited the United States, as did many of his British contemporaries; and he was more successful than almost anyone else in maintaining what might be called a midAtlantic posture.

title: Britain Cuts Lending Rate to 10%
description: LONDON, March 21 (UPI)The Bank of England announced today that its minimum lending rate was being reduced by onequarter of a percentage point to 10 per cent, the sixth cut this year.

title: Army Keeps Ayer
description: The Department of the Army decided yesterday to stay with its current advertising, N. W. Ayer ABH International. Four of the country's leading agencies had been competing for the Army's recruitment account. Page 49.

title: Burma Says Communist Rebels Are Defeated and Chiefs Dead
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 21 (UPI)  Military authorities here said today they had suppressed a foreigninspired insurgency by Communists and that the leaders of the rebels had been killed.

title: PLUTONIUM FLOWN INTO J.F.K. AIRPORT
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has permitted two recent shipments of approximately 100 pounds of plutonium to be flown into New York City's John F. Kennedy Airport.

title: Stankiewicz's Sculpture, Strong and Bold
description: Twenty years ago, the sculpture of Richard Stankiewicz posed an interesting problem: Was it at right to laugh in the presence of a construction that was flawless in form but evidently conceived to gratity something beyond our appetite for flawless form? Mr. Stankiewicz was then a virtuoso constructivist of the openform school, but he differed from many other sculptors of this persuasion in bringing a sharp humor to his work. Using the scrap metal of the junkyards as his basic materials, he created an astonishing succession of welded sculpture that satisfied the stringent formal standards of constructivism while at the same time placing them at the service of an imagination completely at home in the word of observable human ??

title: NEW BOSTON PLAN SAID TO CUT BUSING
description: BOSTON, March 21Experts named by the Federal District Court here to draw up next fall's citywide school desegregation disclosed a draft plan today that they said would desegregate more classrooms with less busing than the interim plan, which has led to controversy and sporadic violence.

title: JORGE MOREL HEARD IN A GUITAR RECITAL
description: Jorge Morel has a technical facility that makes it possible for him to play anything and a repertory that leans toward the lighter side of music. The combination makes the Argentine guitarist a popular recitalist and deservedly so. He is a sophisticated artist when dealmg with arrangements of folk and musical comedy melodies, and one does not have to condescend to enjoy his taste and skill.

title: Carolyn L. Casale, Daniel Baris Wed
description: Carolyn Louise Casale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Francis Casale of Brooklyn, was married yesterday evening to Daniel Baris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ettore Buis of Eltingville, S. I. The Rev. Dominic Sclafani performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Power Line Towers Bombed
description: SAN BRUNO, Calif., March 21 (UPI)Three Pacific Gas & Electric Company power line towers in a San Francisco watershed area were bombed yesterday, but damage was minor and there was no interruption in service.

title: City Asks for Federal Aid To Get Cash in 30 Days
description: City officials appealed to the Federal Government at a meeting here yesterday for an infusion of what one of them called a massive amount of cash into the city's treasury.

title: C.I.A. Aide Quitting to Defend Agency
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The chief of Latin American operations for the Central Intelligence Agency is resigning effective May 9 to organize former United States intelligence officers in an effort to defend the organization against those who attack it.

title: Doctors Are Joining Services to Avoid Malpractice Insurance Costs
description: SAN DIEGO, March 21For 10 years Dr. Kenneth W. Karols, a 35yearold psychiatrist. worked 65 to 70 hours a week building up a private practice in Los Angeles that brought him an annual income upward of $40,000.

title: 2 Concerns Set Uruguayan Oil Deals
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 21 (Reuters)The Uruguayan Government has agreed to issue contracts to Exxon Corporation and the Chevron Oil Company to explore potential oilbearing offshore areas, but wants the companies to improve their submitted bids.

title: Suit Against Avis Dropped by S.E.C.
description: Avis, Inc., the carrental agency, disclosed here yesterday that the Securites and Exchange Commission had agreed to drop a yearold lawsuit in which the Government agency charged Avis with misrepresenting the source of its profits for the first quarter of 1973.

title: Marion Lawson, 94, Dies; British Suffragist Leader
description: MENTON, France, March 21 (Reuters)Marion Lawson, one of Britain's early suffragists, died at her home here on the French Riviera. She was 94 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1975

title: Congress Looks Beyond the Easter Recess
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Congressional leaders, caught between Easter recess plans, parliamentary rules and considerable opposition to Administration requests, today virtually wrote off any chance that congress would act on emergency military aid for South Vietnam and Cambodia before midApril.

title: A. WESTON SMITH JR., A FINANCIAL WRITER
description: A. Weston Smith Jr., a finan. cial columnist author, editor and public relations consultant, died Monday in Stamford, N.Y He was 74 years old.

title: Gerald L. Smith, Helped To Introduce New Drugs
description: Gerald L. Smith, a retired pharmaceutical executive, who helped introduce and popularize new drugs for medical use, died Thursday in the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived at Sands Point, L.I.

title: Cambodian Cabinet Shuffled Slightly; Rumors Grow on Lon Nol's Departure
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Saturday, March 22Premier Long Boret last night announced the formation of a new Government. The reshuffle largely involved familiar political faces.

title: YOUTH SENTENCED IN FIRE FATAL TO 6
description: The leader of a Brownsville youth gang was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 15 years to life in prisonfor six deaths that resulted from carrying out a kangaroo court decision to punish a 13 yearold gang member by burnling down his home.

title: A Growing Cloud of Fear Darkens Brooklyn Project
description: Two boysone 13 years old, the other 16were charged with murdering an 86yearold man in his Brooklyn apartment and robbing him of about $25.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Increase Farm Aid Despite Veto Threat
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)Challenging threats of a Presidential veto, the Senate Agriculture Committee today Bolstered a House  approved farm bill by voting increased supports for milk and cotton.

title: First Installation Is Near On Alaska Pipeline Route
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 21 (UPI)The first pipe installation along the transAlaska oil pipeline route will be made Tuesday, the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company announced, today.

title: FORD MAY SIGN STRIP MINE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 President Ford hinted tonight that he might be ready to sign into law the strip mine control bill that Congress has just passed a second time after a veto of a similar measure last December.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It's next to impossible these days to get a doctor to make a house call when a member of the family is ill. The situation is different, though, when your tropical fish is under the weather. Just phone the West 78th Street Aquarium and one of their experts will be over posthaste with his little black bag. The service is free, even if your guppies were purchased elsewhere.

title: 2 Held on Hashish Charges
description: MIAMI, March 21 (AP) United States Customs inspe?? tors confiscated 85 pounds ?? hashish today in Nassau, th?? Bahamas, and turned a Fo?? Lauderdale couple over to B??hamian authorities on dru?? charges, a spokesman said. Th?? spokesman said the hashis?? valued at $382,000, was foun?? in six falsebottom suitcase and a ladies cosmetics cas?? when Bill Turnhall, 23 year old and his wife, Donna Rae, ?? were being cleared by American officials for a return flight ?? Miami.

title: U.S. Officials Say They Lack Data on War
description: WASHINGTON, March 21High Administration officials say they have inadequate information about what is happening in Indochina and little control over events in Saigon.

title: A Private Tour of Offices for Carey's Staff
description: ALBANY, March 21Governors Levi P. Morton and Alonzo B. Cornell, commemorated in brownish 19thcentury oils, are at one end of the dim marble corridor. W. Averell Harriman and Franklin D. Rooseveltone of the four New York Governors who went on to become President, a young tour guide intones to tourists respectfully shuffling byare in sprightlier 20thcentury oils at the other end.

title: Meskill Nomination As Judge Approved By a Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today by a vote of 8 to 6 the controversial judicial nomination of former Gov, Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut, amid predictions of a floor fight.

title: JELLY ROLL THEME FOR JAZZ REPERTORY
description: The multimedia effects with which the New York Jazz Repertory Company has been expanding the historical aspects of some of its concerts recordings, film and slides in addition to live musicproved a perfect complement to the company's concert of Jelly Roll Morton's music at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening.

title: Athletic Director Quits
description: MILWAUKEE, March 21 (AP)  Thomas Rosandich, athletic director at the University of WisconsinMilwaukee since July, 1972, resigned today, effective Aug. 31. He is 42 years old.

title: Companies Defend the Monitoring Of Employes' Phone Conversations
description: Officials from some of the 177 companies in New Jersey that monitor employe converse titans testified yesterday before the Board of Public Utility Commissioners that the monitoring was done for training and performance checks and did not constitute an invasion of privacy.

title: SENATE IS READY TO PASS TAX CUT OF $30BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Senate headed toward final action on the tax bill today after adopting some additional amendments, including one that would remove all limitations on the deductions that working parents may take for childcare expenses.

title: PROGRAM ARCHIVE FOR TV PROPOSED
description: The need for Federal initiatives to index and preserve network television programs in archives as a visual transcript of our culture was asserted yesterday by George Stevens Jr., director of the American Film Institute, an organization devoted to the preservation of this country's film and television heritage.

title: Bayonne Cheers a Hometown Product
description: BAYONNE, March 21The telephone rang constantly at Churchill's Inn, the Good limes Cafe and at Johnny Di's Bar over the last few days until it seemed like half of this industrial town was headine for Cleveland to cheer Charles (Chuck) Wepner in his longshot bid to defeat Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion.

title: New Delhi Expands Guard on Officials In Wake of Threats
description: NEW DELHI, March 21The Indian Government has thrown a tight security ring around public figures because of apparent threats on the lives of at least two important officials.

title: Cordero to Face Hearing On Foul
description: Angel Cordero crossed the finish line first twice in his six races yesterday, but his horse in the second race, Fernie T., was disqualified from first and placed second. The Puerto Rican jockey, the star at the Aqueduct meeting, will thus make his third appearance before the stewards. who will consider the question of suspension.

title: U.S. STAND HINTED ON SALVAGING SUB
description: JERUSALEM, March 21The Ford Administration has made no final' decision on whether to continue trying to salvage the rest of a sunken Soviet submarine from the Pacific Ocean.

title: Yes for a Clean Fight
description: The heart of Presidential election campaign reform is provision of a public fund to cover the candidates' high cost of running. This new way of financing the crucial contests for the nation's highest office, beginning with next year, is linked to a question on line 8 on Forms 1040 and 1040A of every Federal Income Tax return. The question is: Do you wish to designate $1 of your taxes to this [Presidential Election Campaign] fund? A checkmark in the Yes box on that line authorizes the Internal Revenue Service to place one dollar of that return into the fundat no cost whatsoever to the taxpayer, either in actual payments or in the amount of refund.

title: Church Music: LowKeyed
description: Frank Spoto sings at St. James' Episcopal Church during Sunday services and at Temple EmanuEl on Fridays, Saturdays and weekdays. He also sings at funeral masses in Roman Catholic churches whenever he gets a chance.

title: Screen: Encore Lelouch
description: As a somewhat cynical French romantic in love with love and with movie cameras, Claude Lelouch first clicked here in 1966 with "A Man and a Woman." He scores with "And Now My Love," which arrived at the Fine Arts yesterday. This exploration of how an attractive young pair of Parisian strangers come to be smitten at first sight evolves as a tender dissection of the couple and of the two generations that preceded them. It makes the improbable fairy-tale ending realistic and persuasive."And Now My Love" is, in fact, more sweeping than its French title, "Tout Une Vie," implies in the succession of lives exposed to illustrate the family backgrounds of the hero and heroine, who are fated to meet only at the film's end. If the director was a mite self-indulgent with his camera in "A Man and a Woman," "The Crook," and "Love Is a Funny Thing," he has used it this time for constructive and illuminating effect.The past, he strongly indicates, impinges on the present. So, with speed, humor and appreciation of vintage movie making, we're introduced to the respective grandparents by way of pre-World War I silent but subtitled black-and-white footage, then to the couple-to-be's Jewish parents, who've met after being freed from Nazi concentration camps.Thus, the parallel inspections of preceding generations add substance to the film's contemporary personalities. Sarah, the daughter of the concentration-camp survivor, is as troubled as her doting father. When she falls in love as a teen-ager with the pop singer Gilbert Becaud, her opposite number, Simon, is being jailed for stealing some Becaud records.Their careers proceed along trying paths to maturity; she goes from bored dilettante to conscientious social awareness, and he from convict to work with porno and commercial films and, eventually, to recognition as a rising movie maker.But Mr. Lelouch is not just spinning a chronology. Included in his kaleidoscopic inspection are pertinent observations on the spinning social scene. And the implications of ideologies and the future being spelled out by scientists also serve to develop believable human beings.In their portrayals of the major characters over the years, a slim, blond, photogenic Marthe Keller and an intense Charles Denner project the anxieties, sorrows and joys of people making the best of changing worlds. Andr Dusssollier is natural and appealing as Simon, whose instincts remain decent despite a rough road to success. They are professionally supported by, among others, Mr. Becaud and Charles Grard as Mr. Dussollier's jailmate and friend.Mr. Lelouch, of course, gives amour its due in "And Now My Love," but this is not nearly so impressive as his perceptive, often touching portraits of three eras and their principals.

title: Attica Defense Loses on Rockefeller
description: BUFFALO, March 21State Supreme Court Justice Gilbert H. King today denied a defense motion to order the appearance of Vice President Rockefeller as a witness in the Attica murder trial.

title: Article 1  No Title
Puerto Rico Pays Heavily For Mainland's Recession
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 21Puerto Rico is importing a massive dose of the United States recession, and paying for it is forcing equally massive austerities on the people and Government of this sunny, productive but deeply troubled island commonwealth.

title: Douglass Dean Leaving
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. March 21 (AP)  Rutgers University's president, Edward J. Bloustein, announced today the resignation of the Douglass College dean, Margery S. Foster. Dr. Bloustein said Dr. Foster would leave on Sept. 1.

title: Rotterdam's Port Faltering
description: ROTTERDAM, the NetherlandsA year and a half of energy crisis and economic slump have taken their toll on this harddriving Dutch city, fiercely proud of its position as the world's largest port.

title: Hrebec, Solomon Gain Tennis Final on Upsets
description: MEMPHIS, March 22 (AP) Unseeded Jiri Hrebec of Czechoslovakia, still looking for his first tour victory, notched a 63. 62 upset of Mark Cox today to advance to the finals of the World Championship Tennis event.

title: Fort Lee Trial Witness Denies Bribe Plan for Zoning Changes
description: NEWARK, March 22Arthur J. Sutton, a key prosecution witness in the Fort Lee bribery trial here, acknowledged today that he had begun purchasing land for the controversial George Washington Plaza project long before all the property needed was zoned for commercial development. But he insisted that he had never planned to pay bribes to have the zoning changed.

title: Spring Meets the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Mar. 22  Spring came to Washington this week, right smack on time. It was soft and warm, nonpolitical and seasonally adjusted, providing generous rebates and noncontributory benefits for one and all alike. Ah, Spring!

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Let the Women Try Out for Men's Teams
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shad in the Swim for Dinner
description: Traditionally, shad has been one of the treasures of spring, anticipated as eagerly by some as the first crocus.

title: Singing the pathologies of our time
description: In an intensely personal, frank memoir of her friend Sylvia Plath, (The Barfly Ought to Sing, TriQuarterly 7, 1970) Anne Sexton claimed that suicides are a special people. We talked death, she said, and this was life for us. These two young, gifted and very attractive women spent hours exchanging details of their suicide attempts; and after Sylvia Plath's successful attempt some years later, Anne Sexton wrote a poem that belongs with the most terrible and yet the most intelligent and convincing work of what is loosely called the confessional mode. The poem is Wanting to Die. and it is included in Live or Die, Anne Sexton's third volume. Too long to be quoted here, it is probably the poet's central poem, the calm, dispassionate and sparelycrafted statement that makes the familiar charges of hysteria quite irrelevant:

title: Killings in the Mafia market
description: The Godfather Business, as Mario Puzo, majority stockholder, once called it, may be healthier these days than its subject matter. Known in most circles (but not by Dwight C. Smith, demythologizer) as the Mafia or Cosa Nostra, organized crime, what with internal convulsions and external pressure by law enforcement, is about as untroubled as Pan Am. By comparison, the literary Mafia industry, as evidenced most recently by publication of these volumes, is still making a killing. The hardbound advance for the Luciano book was reportedly $150,000it is also a Bookofthe Month Club main selectionand a paperback house at one point weighed in with an $800,000 bid for its rights, which is pretty good dough even at Carlo Gambino's level. In 1972, in a magazine article, Murray Kempton wrote hyperbolically that the big scores were being made not by belonging to but by exposing the Mafia. It is a hyperbole that works equally well this fiscal 1975.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Think Tank for Conservatives
description: WASHINGTONThere is a clear national need for a Republican conservative counterpart to Brookings, wrote former Presidential speechwriter Pat Buchanan to Richard M. Nixon in March, 1970, which can generate the ideas Republicans cari use, [and] which can serve as a repository of conservative and Republican intellectuals.

title: GIFTS TO COLLEGES STEADY FOR YEAR
description: Voluntary support for America's colleges and universities failed to increase last year for the second time in a decade as institutions, of higher education received an estimated total of $2.24billion in gifts, the same amount received in the previous year.

title: Cancun: Construction Boots in the Footsteps of Mayan Kings
description: THE magazine ad was simple and seductive: a trail of footprints on an otherwise pristine, incredibly white and wavelapped beach. This is Cancun, it said. Mayan kings wintered here 1,000 years ago. Now you may join the procession. Well, I tried. And if the Mayan kings wore construction boots, I think I found their line of march.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ANOTHER few weeks and we will be into the first of the American Bicentennial observances and we must confess to some disappointment. Not only is there no focal point, but major events seem likely to be left out of the picture. The ones we would like to see included are concerned with American business inasmuch as American civilization, perhaps more than any other, has flourished in a business environment and has reflected business values. The American businessman is the national stereotype.

title: Major Book on Holocaust Due
description: Negotiations are under way between Israel and an American company for the publication of The Diary of Adam Czerniakow, a document that a leading Jewish scholar in Brooklyn College termed of major importance in understanding the near destruction of European Jewry under the Nazis.

title: Abortion Argued Around the World
description: PARIS, March 22The issue of abortion has unloosed stormy debates in much of the world.Whether abortion is legalized, as it was several months ago in Roman Catholic France, or declared criminal and unconstitutional, as it was last month by West Germany's highest court, the laws are widely flouted.

title: John Kipp Jr. to Marry Susan Huggins
description: Mr. and Mrs. David E. Huggins of Naples, Fla., and Mouse Island, Me., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Huggins, to John P. Kipp Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kipp of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: Cordero Suspended For 7 Days
description: Viva la Vivi scored an impressive victory under Jorge Velasquez in the Correction Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, and Angel Cordero suffered an important setback. Viva la Vivi took the sixfurlong Correction by three lengths, to the general expectation of the 31,968 fans, who hacked her into $3.60 favoritism.

title: Thailand Will Bar Airlift to Cambodia Carrying Weapons
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22The new Thai government will no longer allow Thailand to be used as a base for the United States airlift of ammunition and other war matriel to Cambodia, senior officials said here today.

title: Kansas State Bows in East, 9587
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 22Rudy Hackett hit a lefthanded shot over his head at the buzzer, sending the game into overtime and unheralded Syracuse went on to defeat Kansas State 9587, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional basketball championship and a spot in next week's national semifinals.

title: Corrections
description: In an addendum to the Feb. 16 review of Frederick Manfred's Buckskin Man series by Madison Jones, Wallace Stevens was credited with the foreword to Conversations With Frederick Manfred. The writer was, in fact, Wallace Stegner.

title: U.S. Ship Arrives in Egypt
description: CAIRO, March 22 (AP)The United States Navy vessel Opportune arrived today in Port Said to replace a sister ship The Escape, in Suez Canal clearing operations, the United States Embassy said.

title: Proposed State Consumer Unit Is Called Insufficient by Activists
description: Governor Carey's proposal to set up a state Division of Consumer Affairs falls short of establishing the kind of strong, unified agency long sought by consumer forces in the state, according to several consumer activists.

title: Eric Ludwig Marries Jeannette Cawl, Nurse
description: Jeannette F. Cawl, a registered nurse at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Providence, R. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Eric C. Ludwig, son of Col. Verle E. Ludwig of the Marine Corps and Mrs. Ludwig of Twentynine Palms, Calif.

title: AndersonColumn Libel Case Due Trial
description: WASHINGTON, March 22A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that a prolonged and important case that had involved the right of newsmen to withhold the identity of their sources must go to trial.

title: TV VIEW
description: The quickest way to make executives of the American commercial networks wince is to mention the British Broadcasting Corporation. As imports from the BBC began to trickle into this country several years ago, the embarrassing question of the day became: Why can't the networks reach that solid level of quality, not only in dramatic shows but also in publicaffairs programing? The standard answers are depressingly familiar.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Leases for more than 200,000 square feet of office space at an aggregate rent of more than $65million have been signed at Olympic Tower, 645 Fifth Avenue at 51st Street.

title: Toll Cut on Bridge to Atlantic Beach
description: MINEOLA Tolls on the Atlantic Beach Bridge will be reduced effective July 1, according to Peter De Bible, chairman of the Nassau County Bridge Authority, which operates the span between the villages of Lawrence and Atlantic Beach.

title: Notes: 1,500 Cyclists To Rally in Amherst
description: THE little college town of Amherst, Mass., will be up to here in bicycles When the League of American Wheelmen holds its Great Eastern Rally (GEAR '75) there May 2326Memorial Day Weekend. The rally is open to all cyclists, and more than 1,500 riders are expected to pedal onto the Amherst campus of the University of Massachusetts to attend it. Last year's Great Eastern Rally, held in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., attracted about 900 cyclists, but the interest already shown in this year's GEAR, according to Roger Desrosier, a member of the Springfield (Mass.) Cyclonauts Bicycling Club, one of the cohosts for the event, promises a much greater turnout. We estimated that when nonbiking friends are included there will be 2,000 people on hand, he says.

title: HEARST INFORMANT LINKED TO WALTON
description: CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI)An informant described as a young athletic type who is reportedly linked to Bill Walton, a professional basketball player, was described today as cooperating with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the search for Patricia Hearst, the fugitive newspaper heiress.

title: It Is Mr. Ford's Move
description: The notion that Presidents have the right to withhold information from Congress on the ground that it might injure national security or embarrass confidential relationships has flowered in recent decades. Only in 1953 was the doctrine given the name executive privilege. Its use to bolster claims of secrecy reached a peak in the Nixon years, when the President tried to withhold crucial evidence from a Congressional committee considering his own impeachment.

title: Statements On Decision In Mideast
description: Following are the texts of statements issued in Jerusalem by Secretary of State Kissinger by the Israelis and in Washington by the White House on the suspension of Mr. Kissinger's Middle East peace mission:

title: oil Deliveries by City Up Sharply This Winter
description: Despite mild winter weather, the Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance has financed almost twice as much fuel oil for hardpressed apartment buildings this year as it did last.

title: Humanities Studies Focus on Economy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The state's Committee for the Humanities, which promotes public educational programs for outofschool adults, is focusing on several of the prevailing economic, educational and social crises in implementing its 1975 theme. The Idea of Equality in New Jersey: The Humanities Address Public Policy Issues.

title: A Quest for Guides
description: IN the spirit of the Bicentennial, the American Society of Travel Agents is pursuing a revolutionary idea: the creation of a nationwide corps of certified tour guides. The hope is that the guides will be ready to start work by the end of the year, and continue to operate after the Bicentennial.

title: For skaters And skiers
description: A lot has happened to hockey since the first recorded game 120 years agoindoor arenas, artificial ice, paperback books on the sport to name a few changes. Yet professional hockey is still the same fast physical sport. Athletes lose more teeth and acquire more stitches in hockey than in any other sport. Any game played on ice skates, with a stick that can propel a rubber disc over 100 miles an hour, has to be dangerous.

title: Coal Production Seen Up
description: HARRISBURG. Pa. (UPI)In this year of increased demand for coal, Pennsylvania could produce 100 million tonshighest in a quarter centuryaccording to the Keystone Bituminous Coal Association. The association says adequate transportation facilities and increased productivity are the keys to reaching the figure.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE DISENCHANTED, by Budd Schulberg. (Viking/ Compass, $3.95.) The last crackup of a Scott Fitzgeraldlike genius caught in Hollywood's toils occurs at Dartmouth, of all places: a good 1950 novel worth a 1975 read.

title: The Region
description: More than 2,000 doctors went on strike in New York City for four days, an extraordinary event in itself, and the central issue was their opposition to a medical tradition: the grueling way that doctors serve their apprenticeships.

title: Amy Koleman Is Wed
description: Amy Koleman, former curatorial coordinator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and Ralph Arno Gant, general counsel and secretary of the Continental Ore Corporation here, were married in Boston March 15 by Rabbi Roland B. Gittelsohn. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Koleman of Newton Centre, Mass., and Mrs. Max Gans of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Gans.

title: The Smartest Horseplayers
description: Through the magic of the electronic brain, New York's friendly bookmaker, Paul Screvane, has discovered that the horseplayers he services at Queens Boulevard and 70th Road in Forest Hills are smarter than those at 1501 Broadway in Manhattan or 3484 Boston Post Road in the Bronx or, in fact, any of the Offtrack betting Corporation's other shops around town. OTB's computer has established that the Forest Hills punters lose, on the average, only 20 cents out of every dollar bet, whereas the citywide average is 27 cents. This Is a story about a former offtrack bettor named Phil Bieber, and the reader may make his own judgment as to Phil's sagacity.

title: Article 8  No Title
The Offensive of The Administration
description: Mr. Ford himself, referred with approval to the domino theory first publicly enunciated by President Eisenhower in 1954, when France was the foreign presence in Indochina. Mr. Eisenhower, describing what would happen if one Southeast nation fell, said: You had a row of dominoes set up, and if you knocked over the first one and what would happen to the last one was the certainty that it would fall over very quickly.

title: Cuban Exiles Talk Less of Return, More of Future Here
description: MIAMIAfter the 1,200 Cuban exiles who survived the Bay of Pigs invasion were ransomed from Premier Fidel Castro's Jails in 1962, they reassembled here in the Orange Bowl before an emotional throng of 30,000 fellow refugees and presented their battle flag to President Kennedy.

title: New & Novel
description: Shella and Philip Gaynor are a young couple so full of high ideals that they are miserable. (The time is 1962, when idealism was a nonelective.) Philip doesn't want to be beholden to his rich, possessive mother, so he lets Sheila work his way through law school. That's good. But now he wants to sell out as corporation lawyer for a tobacco company. That's

title: Early Cartoonist Cited in Queens
description: How many of the millions of people who enjoy reading the funny papers could identify Richard F. Outcault? Only a few, most likely, even though countless bellylaughs can be credited to the man called The Father of the Comic Strip.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There are those who will never believe the Warren Report's conclusions about the assassination of President Kennedy, and it is true that there remain certain unexplained ambiguities. Which makes it fair game for novelists. Only a short time ago, in Norman Lewis's The Sicilian Specialist, the assassination was explained in terms of Mafia contract. Now comes THE TEARS OF AUTUMN by Charles McCarry (Saturday Review Press, $7.95) with a completely different hypothesis.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: LONDON, There has always been something of the grim Scottish chieftain about Nicol Williamson, even when he has played relatively unbloodthirsty parts. His Malvolio was only a little less baleful than his Coriolanus; and his Hamlet was less the sweet prince of theatrical tradition than an aging student revolutionary on furlough from the University of Wittenburg, stalking through the fleshpots of Elsinore as if deciding where to plant the first bomb. Which brings us, logically enough, to the Macbeth Williamson is now doing for the Royal Shakespeare Company here at the Aldwych Theater.

title: Oil Heir Gives Rain Forest Tract On Dominica to a Nature Group
description: A 950acre ecologically important tract of tropical rain forest on the Caribbean island of Dominica has been given to The Nature Conservancy by John D. Archbold, Standard Oil Company heir and sportsman.

title: P.L.O. Official in Syria Calls for an Arab Stand
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sunday, March 23 (Reuters)A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said early today that the failure of Mr. Kissinger's mission should inspire the Arabs with the logic of October  the 1973 war with Israel.

title: The False Art of the Propaganda Film
description: In most lands around the globe, propaganda is a monopoly of the state. In this country, however, the most notable examples of the craft, such as the three current films discussed below, come from the state's adversaries. When Shirley MacLeine takes a camera crew to China or Jane Fonda takes one to North Vietnam or when Peter Davis, who made the TV documentary, The Selling of the Pentagon, sets out to do a film about the war in Southeast Asia, nobody expects a testimonial to U.S. foreign policy. Yet works of propagandaworks whose primary design and overriding effect is the promotion of a case or cause, usually without the intention being made explicitoften send forth messages that their creators did not intend and in the process draw attention to the creators' set of mind and guiding impulses.

title: LETTERS
description: REIT's

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The smallest boy won the biggest prize for the thirdandfourth grade students in the Metropolitan Basketball Shootout at Madison Square Garden, yesterday. Kevin Good, 9 years old, of St. Sylvester School, Staten Island, scored 20 of a possible total of 30 points to capture a trophy and a $1,000 grant for his school awarded by Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: The Many Faces of Money
description: WASHINGTONQuiz. The following was said last week by a public figure:

title: Betsy Freund Married To Alfred L. Loomis 3d
description: Betsy Lee Freund, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer Berkowitz Jr. of New York and Remsenberg, L. I., and of S. E. Freund of St. Louis, was married here yesterday afternoon to Alfred Lee Loomis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loomis Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Bull Island, S. C.

title: Deborah A. Willard Affianced To Pester W. Coogan, a Lawyer
description: Deborah A. Willard, a lawyer with the Boston law firm of Foley, Hoag & Eliot, and Peter Weston Coogan, a partner in that firm, will be married in June.

title: Montarsolo Bows In Met Pasquale
description: Paolo Montarsolo, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday nght in the title role of Don Pasquale, is a veteran Italan bassobuffo who has sung successfully all over Europe and America. But he hasn't come to the Met too late. The voice, while hardly of striking beauty per se, is big and resonant enough to satisfy the basic musical demands, and more important, Mr. Montarsolo is a genuinely funny man

title: Few Losers (or Winners) in the WIN campaign
description: When the Administration's WIN campaign against inflation was quietly buried recentlya victim of rising unemploymentthe suspicion arose that a lot of button manufacturers and businesses were stuck with worthless inventory.

title: Byrne Asks $40Million for New Offices.
description: TRENTONThe Byrne Administration has proposed a $40million program calling for the construction of up to 500,000 square feet of new office space for state government agencies.

title: Project Enables Elderly To BabySit for Students
description: BRANCHBURG  Somerset County College is meeting the needs of both the elderly and student mothers by providing a babysiting service.

title: Lon Nol Is Said to Pack For Eventual Departure
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 22President Lon Nol, whose removal has been urged both here and in Washington as a step toward ending the war, has packed his belongings and obtained passports for himself and his family, reliable sources at the Presidential Palace reported today.

title: Willie Feliner Returns
description: WASHINGTON  William John Fellner, who has spent several decades sitting near the pinnacle of the economics profession, is worried. The 69yearold scholara former President of the American Economic Association and a former adviser of President Ford  thinks that he and his fellow economists have marched into a booby trap of their own design.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market finished lower last week as negative economic news depressed the list in continued heavy trading.

title: Engagements
description: BernsteinKamm

title: Congress Has Second Thoughts on the Power of Outside Money
description: WASHINGTONIt is important to keep in mind the fact that the benefits of foreign investment the United States have historically far outweighed any disadvantages, (but) I do not believe we can ignore any longer the dangers inherent in our traditional open door policy toward foreign investment.

title: Familiar Name Returns To Run Ox Ridge Show
description: David H. Wright is back at his old stand directing the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

title: GINGER BAKER BACK WITH GURVITZ ARMY
description: Ginger Baker was one of the first rock drummers of heroic proportions, first as a member of Cream eight years ago and later with Blind Faith. He has faded since then, working occasionally, and on Friday in his latest reincarnation, the Baker Gurvitz Army, he could not fill the Academy of Music on 14th Street.

title: Robin S. Veitch, Marsha Murphy Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Murphy Jr. of Columbus, Ga., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Lee Murphy, to Robin Scott Veitch of London, son of Anthony Scott Veitch of London and Sydney, Australia, and Enid Foster Veitch of London.

title: Hockey's Hall Of Fame
description: Hockey, like football and baseball, has many legendary Hall of Fame heroes, and Tim Moriarty sketches the lives of many of the most outstanding members. His biographies highlight the careers of such stars as Gordie Howe. Lester Patrick, Terry Sawchuk, Maurice Richard and others. Photographs, a list of all Hall of Famers and a history of hockey's hallowed hall will interest the fan.

title: State Office Plays Big Role in Capital
description: WASHINGTONThe Easter holiday is a time when thousands of tourists, mainly schoolchildren, invade the nation's capital, and those from New Jersey should not think that they are in Trenton by mistake when they pass 419 New Jersey Avenue, S.E.

title: Miss Carlin Bows On Harpsichord
description: Maryse Carlin, a young French harpsichordist who is currently studying here with. Sylvia Marlowe, appeared Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall in an attractive program of mostly Baroque music. Her recital was presented by arrangement with Jeunesses Musicales de France.

title: NoWork Gardens Need Planning
description: Dear Neighbors, When we planned our nowork garden eight years ago, little did we think we'd be sitting in the catbird seat this spring.

title: Taquin, Bouvier, Judged Best in Bronx K.C. Show
description: A Bouvier des Flandres, who has been on the most impressive winning streak ever recorded by the breed in America, won his third bestinshow award in as many nays at the Bronx County Kennel Club's 53d fixture last night at the Kingsbridge Armory.

title: Foreman's Trip Delayed
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 (AP)Passport and visa problems have delayed George Foreman the former world heavyweight boxing champion, by three days in his trip to South Africa. He was duc tomorrow, but now is not expected until Wednesday.

title: Hofstra Law Students Giving Free Aid in Tax Suits
description: HEMPSTEADTax assessments may be inevitable but they are not necessarily final, as students in Hofstra University's Law School Tax Clinic have discovered.

title: Problems at Ranger Games: The Other Side
description: Joe Siano, season subscriber to Ranger Seat 10, Row G, Section 437, Madison Square Garden, is displeased, according to this page last Sunday. He says the Garden beer lacks full body, the organ is uninspiring and, when the circus is in town, the joint stinks.

title: Ariz. State Routed in West, 8975
description: PORTLAND, Ore. March 22  Marques Johnson, a sophomore, tossed in 20 of his gamehigh 35 points in the first half today, leading U.C.L.A. to an 8975 victory over Arizona State in the West Regional playoffs. It gave the Bruins a berth in the National Collegiate basketball tournament's semifinal round for the ninth consecutive year.

title: College Fraud Units Assist Consumers
description: Two new consumer centers, one at Brooklyn College and the other at Queens College, are tackling the same goalpractical consumer assistance  but from different angles.

title: F.B.I. Reportedly Harassed Radicals After Spy Program Ended
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Federal Bureau of Investigation continued disruptive techniques and harassment against domestic political groups after its controversial counterintelligence program was terminated, according to two former senior F.B.I. officials.

title: A Police Denial
description: CHICAGO, March 23 (AP)James M. Rochford, the city Police Superintendant, flatly denied today that his department had kept intelligence; files on Mr. Carey.

title: Suffolk Pressing Physicians on Medicaid
description: HAUPPAUGE  Several physicians and dentists in Suffolk County's East End, where medical facilities are generally considered inadequate, have refused to treat Medicaid patients, according to a report prepared by the Suffolk County Executive.

title: 33 Books of My Lai Data Released by U.S. Army
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)The Army has released 20,000 pages in 33 bound books of the raw investigatory material used in the investigation at the My Lai killing in 1968.

title: The Nation
description: Each week it becomes clearer that the scope of the Senate Select Committee's inquiry into Federal intelligence operations will have to be more ambitious and sweeping than generally imagined.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Kentucky Ends Indiana String And Gains N.C.A.A. Semifinals
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 22 Kentucky's powerful team ended Indiana University's, 34game basketball victory streak, 9290, today and moved to the semifinals of the 37th National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: A 2.1Million Fund Expected to Ease Coast School Plight
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22, (AP)An account containing $2.1million found by the San Francisco Board of Education could end the public school financial crisis and salvage athletic and other extracurricular programs.

title: Communist Computer
description: The Control Data Corporation, in an effort to sell more computers to the Communist countries has purchased a computer made in East Germany. The machine, called the ES1040 is thought to be the first Eastern Bloc computer purchased by an American concern.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: CLEVELAND. It is 1944, more than a year after the battle of Stalingrad, and the Red Army is pushing across the Ukraine, forcing the Wehrmacht into full retreat, We are in a small Ukrainian town occupied by the Germans. A German commandant and his adjutant listen to the boom of approaching Russian artillery, a warning that full evacuation of all German troops is only hours away.

title: 18 More Are Shot to Death in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 22Eight more persons were killed today, apparently by rightwing terrorists, in the worse upsurge of political violence in Argentina since the beginning of the year.

title: STAMPS
description: Mariner 10 is a robot spacecraft that has flirted with Venus and stripped away many of the mysteries of Mercury, baring many hitherto unknown secrets about Earth's neighbors in the solar system.

title: ConRail Hearings Set Here
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission will conduct public hearings here tomorrow and Tuesday on the new Federal plan to restructure the Penn Central and five other bankrupt railroads into a slimmeddown Governmentaided system called ConRail. The hearings will start at 9:30 A.M. in Hearing Room No. 1, 24th floor, No. 2 World Trade Center. Testimony will be limited to 15 minutes for each person.

title: Search in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., March 22 (AP)The state police and officials of the state Radiation Control Agency were searching today for a potentially hazardous radioactive device reported missing from the Brown Paper Company in Berlin, N. H. The device, harmless while locked in its leadfilled steel box, contains Cesium 137 and is used in connection with grading and classifying paper, officials said. But they said that if the container was tampered with, the device might product a serious hazard from gamma radiation in the immediate vicinity.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayRiverhead K.C. allbreed, Armory, 1405 Old Country Road (Route 38), Riverhead, L. I.; 678 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: CHESS
description: After Bent Larsen had drawn the first game and then lost three in succession to the 23yearold Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson in their recent Stockholm match, his chances for escaping a stinging defeat in the series were just about nil. Nevertheless, the everbuoyant Dane threw everything he had into a gloriously speculative attack which led to his first win in the fifth encounter.

title: Hearing Set on Air Pollution
description: TRENTONIndustrial interests in the state are expected to voice strong opposition this week to the Byrne administration's latest campaign to clean up New Jersey's polluted air. A public hearing on the issue will De held here Tuesday morning.

title: Wildcats Say Title Is Theirs
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 22 Joe Hall, the man who succeeded Adolph Rupp as basketball coach at the University of Kentucky in 1972, described the ordeal against Indiana University today as a classic in college athletics. I was proud to be a part of it.

title: KISS ROCK QUARTET BRINGS EXCITEMENT
description: Kiss returned to New York  at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Streetconfirmed its status as a genuine headline group and played the same ordinary rock music as before. But for some reason the effect this quaret has on crowds is quite startling: the whole audience was standing on the seats for the last 45 minutes, an event even in these days of rock emotionalism.

title: Cultural Unit Formed
description: Mayor Beame announced the creation yesterday of a new advisory panel for cultural matters and said he would submit legislation to the City Council to establish an independent Cultural Affairs Agency. Page 38.

title: U.S. POLICY SHIFT ON OIL IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 Several highranking energy and defense officials have outlined an alternate strategy for directing United States interest in oil supplies away from the Persian Gulf and toward other parts of the world, chiefly Venezuela, Mexico, Nigeria, Indonesia and possibly Canada.

title: N.Y.A.C.'s Elite Eight Triumphs
Englewood Wins Title
description: LINCROFT, N. J., March 22Bill Willoughby, described as a professional prospect by American Basketball Association scouts, scored 27 points today and led Englewood to the New Jersey High School Group 2 basketball championship with a 7066 victory over Pleasantville at Brookdale College.

title: Petrel Offers a Taste of the Sea
description: For the past two months, ferryriding commuters to and from lower Manhattan have seen an imposing yawl lying directly behind the Battery Park Coast Guard Station, or they have seen all 70 feet of her glide by under sail.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: RESIGNATION THREAT BY WILSON REPORTED
description: LONDON, March 22 (UPI)Prime Minister Harold Wilson has threatened to resign unless seven leftwing Cabinet members change their stand and support the majority cabinet members change their stand and support the majority cabinet decision approving Britain's continued membership in the European economic community, a London newspaper said today in its early edition of tomorrow's paper.

title: PORTUGAL MAOISTS FIGHTING VOTE BAN
description: LISBON, March 22Portugal's best known Maoist, whose party has been forbidden to participate in elections scheduled for next month, has vowed to fight against the ban by mobilizing the masses.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: He is short, fairhaired and smiles a lot. He moves and talks briskly. The movement has an almost unexpected grace; the talk is fluent and very bright, and if in English, it is softly and charmingly accented. The clothes are informal, happy but quite often expensive. The manner is confidentabout a year ago in London he took a public swing at a critic who didn't like his work. The notices improved perceptibly. He is a 42yearold Dutchman, Hans van Manen, and is one of a handful of Europe's top choreographers.

title: Midwood Girl Gymnastics Victor
description: Nancy Ruben won the Public School Athletic League's allround individual girls' gymnastics championship yesterday with 31.20 points. Miss Ruben, a senior at Midwood High School in Brooklyn, set citywide records in the balance beam and floor exercise events.

title: Scranton Strike Ending
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 22 (AP)A fourjudge panel of the Lackawanna County Court today ordered both sides to accept a compromise twoyear contract that will reopen city schools after a fourweek teachers' strike. School Superintendent John F. Stephens said the district's 32 schools will open on Monday.

title: Judith Vandeveer Has Nuptials
description: Judith Vandeveer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington Vandeveer of Bernardsville, NJ., was married there yesterday morning to C. James McDermott 3d, son of Charles J. McDermott of Remsenburg, L.I., and the late Eugenie B. McDermott. The Rev. Scott Kirby performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain.

title: Memorial Services
description: SHAPIROLeo. Memorial service, March 24, 8:50 P.M., Kneses Israel Synagogue, Bklyn.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Four Late Scores Win for Wings
description: DETROIT, March 22Mistakes, says Emile Francis, the New York Rangers' coach, are what turn a good team into a losing team. Tonight against the Detroit Red Wings, who have little to lose this season, mistakes led to a fourgoal third period that turned the Rangers into 74 losers at Olympia Stadium.

title: NEWSMEN'S DINNER OPENED TO WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)Setting precedent, the wives of President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller were guests with their husbands at a Gridiron Club dinner tonight as the journalists group initiated the first woman member In its 90year history.

title: Susan Keyes Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George T. Keyes of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Katherine Keyes of Denver to F. Blake Lynch of Vail, Colo., son of Mrs. Joseph Lynch of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Lynch.

title: Suzette Howard Fiancee Of Thomas Nichols Oates
description: The engagement of Suzette de Marigny Howard to Thomas Nichols Oates has been announced by Reese Evans Howard of New York and Mrs. Alger Howard of Far Hills, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of William A. Oates, headmaster of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and the late Mrs. Oates.

title: Hearing to Consider a Damless Park in Tocks Region
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa.Thirteen years after Congress told the Army Corps of Engineers to dam the Delaware River at Tocks Island, construction has yet to begin and the corps is in the midst of another study on the controversial proposal.

title: CALIFORNIA ACTS ON AUTO EMISSION
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22Air pollution authorities in California are flouting the Federal Government's goslow policy on curbing autombile fumes.

title: 14to1 Shot Winner at Gulf stream
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22There were nine horses in today's $124,200 Gulfstream Park Handicap, but from start to finish, for a mile and a quarter, the heavily favored Proud and Bold and a 141 shot, Gold and Myrrh, had the race to themselves.

title: The Taming of the Phew
description: EARLY April in the mountains of West Virginia. Sunrise. A hardy band of highbooted lumbermen and coal miners tramp through underbrush and melting snow, armed with shorthandled hoes and gunny sacks. They seek the ramp, an edible plant with lanceshaped leaves, root bulb and a noisome reputation. Ramp has a mouthwateringly sweet flavor, with a hint of garlic; it also has an astounding pungent odor, something on the order of wild onion but magnified and intensified a thousandfold. Ramp eaters, particularly those who favor it raw, tend to stick together. They have to.

title: Virginia Josephine Jones to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Brinston Jones of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Josephine Jones, to Peter Starnes Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ebenezer Richardson 2d of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Transportation Chief Is Sought in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE  Four months after the Suffolk County Executive reluctantly agreed to the County Legislature's insistence that a Transportation Commissioner be appointed before any new transportation superagency was created, the search for a candidate for the position is still going on.

title: Candy Bar Makers Don't Want Weight on Wrapper
description: The makers of the shrinking candy bar, the symbol of inflation's impact on familiar products, want to mask what they have done.

title: Man Leaps Off Bridge Here
description: An unidentified man jumped off the Greenpoint Avenue Bridge into a branch of the East River yesterday but was rescued minutes later, authoritie said. A bridge tender, Dennis Halpern, said the man jumped at about 7 P.M. Mr. Halpern's partner, Rufus Malone, and two unidentified youths pulled the man out minutes later. The man was taken to a hospital but the police could not say which one.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: P. G. Wodehouse

title: Urban Crisis of the 1960's Is Over, Ford Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 Urban policy makers in the Ford Administration have concluded, despite vigorous objections from many local political leaders and experts on the condition of the cities, that the urban crisis of the nineteensixties is over.

title: Music Notes: How Much New Music Will $15,000 Buy?
description: It would be hard to overestimate the importance of recordings in propagating the music of contemporary composers. At the same time, it is no secret that the cost of producing a record can be prohibitive and that the prospect of a company's recouping such an investment is in some cases ??, record companies have occasionally issued worthwhile works as a matter of prestige and have been willing to absorb the loss, but they can't make a habit of this kind of expenditure, and some form of outside assistance is clearly needed.

title: Bonnie Siegel Engaged to David Covey
description: Bonnie Ellen Siegel and David Martin Covey plan to be married Aug. 9 at Temple BethEl in Great Neck, L. I. The announcement of their engagement has been made by Mrs. Philip Bialo of Great Neck, Miss Siegel's mother. Mr. Covey is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Covey, also of Great Neck. Miss Siegel also is a daughter of the late George Siegel, a New York furrier.

title: Encounter: In the Philippines, a Little Bahala Na Helps
description: BAHALA NA is a Filipino expression that rolls Che sera, sera and You can't fight city hall into a smooth ball of almost Impervious Asian fatalism. You say when a fungus destroys your rice crop, When martial law is declared, when you come back to a deserted parking lot after a late movie and find your new car has a deep scratch running from front bumper to taillight. I never really understood bahala na until a typhoon named Susang left me sitting for six long days in the lonely peasant village of Palanan.

title: Mary Shiland, C. E. Rounds Jr. Plan to Be Wed
description: Mary Alicia Shiland and Charles Elder Rounds Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Rounds of Nowell, Mass., plan to be married Aug. 16 in Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: Diary of a Soap Opera Wash Out
description: After having my plays produced by good, underfinanced theaters for some years, I decided it was time to make a living. I applied for and got a job writing a network television soap opera. What follows are excerpts from a diary I almost kept:

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Last month, writing in the Times Literary Supplement, Erich Leinsdorf got some things off his mind about The New Staging, which is as much a part of the contemporary opera scene as The New Criticism used to be in literary circles some years back. Leinsdorf decried the directors and producers who make a brilliant career on the back of defenseless Verdi or Mozart. If this goes on, he says, Ultimately the public will be alienated, and the opera house will become an experimental laboratory for a small set of kooks.

title: Elizabeth Bloomberg Engaged to David Sullivan
description: Elizabeth Bloomberg, a lawyer here with Cravath, Swathe & Moore, plans to be married May 25 to David Bahnsen Sullivan, who graduated a year ahead of her from the Boston University School of Law.

title: Street Crime Tied To Broken Homes
description: TRENTON  One of the state's leading lawenforcement officials says that street crime can be attributed largely to family disintegration, a condition that is beyond the control of the police.

title: Three Institutions Sparking Revival of Interest in Classic Small Boats
description: The old names are being heard again. Colon, Miller, Couch, Guerin, Rushton, Ruggles, Bow dish, as the skiffs and canoes they built come out of their long hibernation, for all across the country there is growing interest in these small boats that were the toys or the work boats of the late 19th Century.

title: JANET SOARES GROUP DANCES FOUR WORKS
description: Janet Soares has an eclectic eye and professional skill in shaping movement from diverse sources into her own dances. Her program of four works at the American Theater Laboratory Friday evening ranged from a pleasantly lush design to an intense dramatic vignette.

title: Navy Yard May Get Museum
description: After 173 years, the Brooklyn Navy Yard (formally the New York Naval Shipyard) should really be honored with its own museum, Trudy Mason feels, and she has determined to make this a part of the industrial development of the yard.

title: Ann Wysor Is Wed to Peter Moore
description: The marriage of Ann Leah Wysor to Peter Vincent Moore took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Wysor, parents of the bride, in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Steven Johnson, minister of the First Unitarian Church in Cleveland, performed the ceremony.

title: HEINZ MEDJIMOREC GIVES PIANO RECITAL
description: Heinz Medjimorec, an Austrian pianist who made his debut here in 1973, offered a decent but not very special recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program was presented by the Austrian Institute.

title: Annual Reports Acquire a New Look
description: This spring shareholders will find that their annual reports have a new look.

title: What's Doing in BARBADOS
description: FIRST GLIMPSE  British West Indian Airways and Pan American World Airways operate daily direct flights from New York to Barbados, and Eastern Air ??ines flies in daily from San Juan. Try to get a flight that arrives before 6 P.M., when the sun goes down. As your plane approaches Barbados, it will skirt the island's west and southcoast beaches and you will get a glimpse of seas so blue you'll catch your breath. The island, 21 miles long and 14 miles wide, is a former British colony that was granted independence in 1966 and has a population of 249,000, relatively large for the Caribbean. It stands outside the arc of islands called the Lesser Antilles, 100 miles to the west, which form a dividing line between the calm Caribbean and the Atlantic surge. Barbados gets the best of both worlds: on the western side an endless sandy shoreline and an azure sea, on the eastern side a rugged, breezy coastline with whitetopped rollers, good for experienced surfers but not so safe for a lazy swim. Barbados is a coral island, flat compared to the wild, volcanic terrain of the Antilles, but it does have 1,100foot Mount Hillaby, which is high enough for you to admire both coastlines from. Photographers should test their skill by shooting the sunset over the west coast waters. Daytime temperatures in Barbados are in the 75 to 85 degree range the year round, with a 10degree drop overnight.

title: DAVERN AND WILBER TEAM ON JAZZ BILL
description: For several years, the reputations of Kenny Devern and Bob Wilber as clarinetist and soprano saxophonist have been growing simultaneously but separately. Inevitably, their paths crossed, producing provocative duets that focused primarily on the differences in their use of the soprano saxophone  Mr. Davern playing the straight instrument, which looks like a fat, golden clarinet, and using a bigtoned, soaring attack that has its roots in Sidney Bechet; Mr. Wilber using the bent soprano that is a miniature saxophone in a style much like Johnny Hodges's use of the alto saxophone.

title: School for Disabled Opens in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn School for Special Children, an educational and vocational training center for the mentally handicapped, has moved into its new home at Bay 44th Street and Shore Parkway in Bensonhurst.

title: Susan P. Johnson Married in Boston
description: Susan Porter Johnson was married yesterday to Johnstone Rutherfurd, a greatgrandson of Levi Parsons Morton, Benjamin Harrison's Vice President. The Rev. Harris Collingwood performed the ceremony In the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: The Shah (III): The Oil King
description: TEHERAN, IranOne of the world's acknowledged experts on petroleum is Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, whose country is the second greatest supplier of liquid energy and who unquestionably makes the most effective selfdevelopment use of accruing profits. But the Shah sees a definite time limit to oil economies. He complains that the international community refuses to face facts.

title: Only in the West Can We Fulfill Our Art
description: To talk with the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, the soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, is to experience the Russian character at its most vociferous. The room becomes charged with good  natured excitability. When they speak (often simultaneously), their voices frequently rise in joy or anguishqualities one can also hear in their music. Indeed, it is perhaps their sheer intensity which has brought this musical couple both international acclaim for their art and the official disfavor of the Soviet Government for their beliefs.

title: Homicide Trends in the City
description: * To date investigation has no?? indicated motive

title: Quarry, Norton Bout Not Just Appetizer
