description: Ken Norton, the fourthranked heavyweight, and Jerry Quarry, ranked No. 5, meet at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night in a 12round bout that could be the turning point in their careers.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Math Whiz Converts dx Over nth Root of 1 Plus x to the 2x Into $10,000
description: For Paul Zeitz of Brooklyn, a 16yearold senior at Stuyvesant High School, winning the $10,000 scholarship this month in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search was only the latest, although the most profitable, in a series of firsts.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: A Former Mayor Is Fined
description: READING, Pa., March 22 (UPI)Thomas J. Monaghan, former state Cabinet officer and former Mayor of Lancaster, pleaded no contest yesterday to an income tax evasion charge and was placed on three years' probations and fined $5,000.

title: Photography Is Making Him a Millionaire
description: In 1969, when Lee Witkin decided to open an art gallery on East 60th Street which would be devoted exclusively to photography, friends warned him that no one had ever turned a photography gallery into a commercial success. Yet Witkin, who started his venture with $6,000 in the bank, reportedly has grossed more than a million dollars to date, and now operates the biggest and bestknown photography gallery in New Yorkif not the world. His gallery has established standards for photography galleries all over the

title: Related Reports In Indochina Crisis
description: The American airlift of food, fuel and ammunition into Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital's last supply line, was suspended Saturday after rockets fired by insurgents struck two of the airlift planes. Page 7.

title: A Fanfare of Fetes
description: AMONG the mysteries of America's Bicentennial celebration is its starting date. The best that the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration can come up with is March 1, 1975: The Administration was charged by Congress with keeping a master register of Bicentennial events for the period March 1, 1975, through Dec. 31, 1976. The fact is, however, that the Bicentennial celaxation wiil be basically a state and local affair and the festivities have barely begun. What follows is a listing of some major Bicentennial events scheduled through July 4 in four major East Coast cities.

title: Broadcast Notes: How Come So Many Reruns?
description: The television rerun has pushed ahead of the crocus as a herald of spring. It comes into flower approximately 26 weeks after Labor Dayor just about now. Not more than a dozen years ago, the rerun signaled summer. What caused that to change had nothing to do with equinoxes but rather with economics.

title: Home Runs Help Pirates Beat Tigers
description: LAKELAND, Fla.. March 22 (UPI)Manny Sanguillen hit a threerun home run and Willie Stargell hit a tworun clout today as Dock Ellis pitched seven scoreless innings in the Pittsburgh Pirates' 81 exhibition baseball victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford traveled out to the Midwest last week and, in the heartland of the old isolationism, attacked the Congressional opponents of his Indochina policy and what he called the new isolationism. The substantial majority in Congress that seems poised to end further aid to Cambodia and to begin ending aid to South Vietnam paid little attention to the isolationist charge. But it will be made again, and in time the larger debate will be joined, as it has been twice before in this century and as it was in the very germinal days of the republic.

title: Is Betrothed
description: Diana Towle and Jean Paul Jallifier plan to many April 5 in St. Joseph's Chapel in the Kent (Conn.) School, ?? which the future bride's father is headmaster.

title: Arab Nationalism Must Be Dealt With
description: JERUSALEMIsrael's repeated insistence that she will never negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization veils the real dilemma for Israel's policymakers. Publicly, Israel continues to maintain that negotiations over the future of the West Bank and Gaza can be held only with Jordan.

title: It's Time to Begin the Annual Lawn Care Ritual
description: The picture  book lawn rates high on the list of expensive landscape features. As the high cost of practically everything is putting a squeeze on pocketbooks, homeowners are looking for ways to cut back on garden expenses. Is the lawn one of them?

title: Rebellion A Tradition For Kurds
description: A fiercely independent people, Moslem but not Arab, the Kurds have been in intermittent revolt against all who have attempted to govern them for the last thousand years. Claiming a total strength of 14 million, their tribal lands stretch over five nations  Iraq, Iran, Syria, Turkey and the Soviet Union.

title: U.N. Is Expanding Its Program To Coordinate Disaster Relief
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22United Nations authorities have approved a 33miilion disaster relief program designed to coordinate assistance to countries stricken by floods, earthquakes, famines or other calamities.

title: COMMUNISTS TAKE 3 MORE KEY TOWNS AND PRESS ON HUE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 23  Rapidly advancing Communist forces yesterday captured two more district capitals and a provincial capital, increased pressure on the city of Hue, and appeared to be preparing an offensive against Saigon itself.

title: NO CLUES ARE FOUND IN JERSEY ABDUCTION
description: Police Chief Herman Bolte of Union City, N.J., said yesterday that hundreds of persons had been interviewed without substantial clues to the identity of the man who abducted an 11yearold girl and her 6yearold brother last Thursday.

title: Indochina Dj vu
description: Again, Vietnam. The Americansupported regime in Saigon has unexpectedly relinquished almost twothirds of the territory of South Vietnam, abandoning all but a few major enclaves where President Nguyen Thieu says he will continue to fight against the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong.

title: Jipcho Takes Mile, 2Mile In Record Pro Track Double
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 In a devastating double, Ben Jipcho ran away from the field to set an indoor professional record of 8 minutes 27 seconds for the 2mile run today and less than an hour later he tore around the Sports Arena track in 3:56.2 for the third fastest indoor mile ever.

title: Family Medicine Returning as Specialty
description: EAST MEADOW  Unlike most recent medical school graduates, Dr. Michael M. Mishkin wants to be a family physician.

title: Merzario the Fastest
description: SCARPERIA, Italy, March 22 (UPI)Italy's Arturo Merzario, in an Alfa Romeo 33 TT12, won the pole position today for tomorrow's Mugello 1,000kilometer race, the second in the world sports car championship series. Merzario had an average speed of 107.599 miles an hour. Jean  Pierre Jabouille of France, in an Alpine Renault Turbo, was 6 onehundreds of a second slower than the Italian.

title: Status of Ocean Parkway As Landmark in Dispute
description: A sharp controversy over designation of Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn as a New York City landmark has broken out, with five members of the City Planning Commission warning that the designation could jeopardize badly needed Federal funds to repave and otherwise rehabilitate the thoroughfare.

title: Dispirit of '76: A Bicentennial Divided Against Itself. . .
description: NINE years ago Lyndon Johnson and Congress brought forth the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission. It was, in a way, the perfect outfit for coordinating the 200th anniversary of the United States. Starting off with grandiose plans, its performance never got above the level of grubby politics, internal strife and external ridiculesome of the very qualities that beset any new nation and doubtless plagued the American colonists as well.

title: Tips for Success With Vegetables
description: Where, oh where do you find that ideal vegetable plot so cheerfully described in garden booksthat perfect, level, totally sunny rectangle with the loam soil? For most of us, that plot is but a dream, so we make do with what we have.

title: PERSONNEL POLICY OF CITY ASSAILED
description: The escalating costs of city services and their generally poor quality were attributed by the State Charter Revision Commission yesterday largely to what it termed a sluggish, overcentralized personnel system.

title: Byrne Forms a Panel to Advise on Abortion Laws
description: TRENTONGovernor Byrne has formed a panel of legal and medical specialists to advise him on the controversy surrounding the United States Supreme Court decision legalizing abortions in the first three months of pregnancy.

title: Governor Assails Report on City Pension Systems
description: Governor Carey yesterday assailed the State Pension Commission for its report last week that questioned the financial soundness of New York City's employe pension systems.

title: Futures Trading In Home Mortgages
description: For the first time in history the Government has become a prime mover for futures trading in a commoditynamely, home mortgages which are soon to start trading as futures on at least one major commodity exchange.

title: Fire Kills Brooklyn Woman
description: A 70yearold woman died early yesterday in a fire in a frame home in Brooklyn's By Ridge section. The victim, identified as Julia Ivors, was found by firemen in her thirdfloor attic apartment at 251 80th Street. She was pronounced dead of smoke inhalation. Four other persons were injured, two with broken ankles suffered jumping from a secondstory apartment and two with burns. The fire broke out on the second floor at 1:05 A.M.

title: Soviet Union and Arabs Are Quietly Competing for Influence in Somalia's Socialist System
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, March 12Although droughtravaged Somalia is one of the poorest nations in the world, her friendship is the object of a quiet but strong competition between the Russians and the Arab bloc.

title: U.S. Team Heads for Europe
description: The United States national team wil leave tonight for Poland to meet the Polish national and Olympic teams before going to Rome to take on the Italian national squad. The Americans have not had much preparation for the important although friendlymatches. Al Miller, the coach, is not optimistic, but he is not pessimistic either.

title: Schlesinger Disputes Theory on Indochina
description: PHILADELPHIA March 22 (UPI)In sharp contrast with remarks made by President Ford, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has said that the loss of Southeast Asia to the Communists would not significantly alter the world military balance.

title: Miss Newman Is Betrothed
description: Elizabeth Lani Newman, a lawyer with the Civil Service Commission in Washington, and John C. F. Tillson 4th, a systems analyst in the office of the Secretary of Defense, plan to be married in June.

title: Seattle's Skid Road Fears Encroaching Renovation
description: SEATTLEAs the two panhandlers, shoulders hunched against the wind, shuffled through the Skid Road section here on a recent gray aftersoon, their darting eyes fixed on a stranger emerging from a cab. The younger of the two, moving with a new quickness, planted himself in the man's path.

title: Good Dance Books For NonExperts
description: Here are three dance books for the general readera veritable glut on a once nonexistent market  and here are their authors in Real Life. Jack Anderson, who wrote Dance, is a poet. Charles Spencer, the head man of the team that collaborated on The World of Serge Diaghilev, is a British art critic. Joseph H. Mazo, who takes an inside look at the New York City Ballet in Dance is a Contact Sport, was trained as an actor/director and writes on dance and theater for Women's Wear Daily.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Connors and Gerulaitis Gain I.P.A. Net Final
description: Jimmy Connors and Jan Kodes played a great tennis match last night, and it took every weapon the American commanded to win and reach the final of the $25,000 Independent Players Association tournament at the Felt Forum.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to Richwood (population: about 4,000) in southeastern West Virginia for the season's earliest ramp festival, proceed to the grade school in the center of town on Valley Street near Commercial Avenue. The festival lasts from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., April 12. Platters cost $3.50 for adults, $2.50 for children. (No admission fee.) Richwood has three motels: the Watergate on Route 39 west ($14 single, $18 double), Mariwood Motel on Route 39 east ($11 to $14 single, $13 to $16 double), and Oakford Motor Inn on Route 39 in town ($7 single, $10 double). There are also two lowpriced hotels. Indian Rocks Campground on Route 20 at Craigsville, 14 miles away, is open at festival time.

title: The Gardener's Law of Parsimony
description: In these difficult times, it's becoming a growing challenge for gardeners to sustain last year's ways without last year's means. The solution may lie in reviving the Gardener's Law of Parsimony, which states, Invest the least necessary that will accomplish the most possible.

title: A Shrunken South Vietnam
description: The surrender of several provinces by the Saigon Government and the contested state of others has reduced the territory under its control by about twothirds. The Thieu regime has abandoned longcontested cities such as Kontum, Pleiku, Quang Tri and possibly Hue. But it retains the bulk of the population and the three largest cities, Saigon, Da Nang and Qui Nhon. The Saigon strategy was to retreat to defensible endives around the big cities and in the Mekong Delta. It was to those refuges that hundreds of thousands of uprooted Vietnamese were fleeing last week.

title: Residents of Laurelton Reclaiming the Streets
description: An openhouse campaign to keep Laurelton integrated has attracted 44 couples, most of them young and white, according to civic leaders of this southeast Queens community.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, March 24

title: Art At Rutgers, A Response to Environment
description: NEW BRUNSWICKLive begonias, a couple of tanks full of busily swimming brine shrimp and a 20footlong plaster cast of a muskrat's abandoned underground burrow are just a few of the attractions at the newest exhibition at the Rutgers University Art Gallery.

title: SAN JUAN REPORTS 17% JOBLESS RATE
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 22For 15 years, Angel Rivera worked as a skilled mechanic for a General Motors automobile dealer here. Then, last year, gasoline shortages and recession came to San Juan. The demand for new cars declined, and so did the need for Mr. Rivera's skills.

title: Rail Picture Is Called Bright
description: WASHINGTON If Federal plans materialize, railroad improvements in New Jersey in the next five to 10 years will be among the most spectacular in the nation.

title: Hunter Tries to Be One Of the Guys Succeeds
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22  The Yankee pitcher stood near the orangejuice dispenser, talking to another player. Suddenly, the clubhouse erupted in the mock sound of a fife siren. The pitcher looked down. His white shoelace was burning. The Mad Torch had struck again.

title: Study of Suffolk Air Base Is Planned
description: WESTHAMPTONSuffolk Airport, which has run up a $2.5million deficit since the county acquired it from the Federal Government five years ago, will be the subject of a comprehensive master Nan that will chart the future use of its interior facilities and its surrounding areas.

title: Not Just Compacts
description: Iris Lane often shows up wearing part of her collection of antique compacts around her neck. It so happens that some of the more than 250 compacts she has acquired can be considered jewelry pieces as well as carrying cases for powder.

title: Created in 1836 by Capt. Hazelton Seaman, the Barnegat Sneakbox Was Specifically Designed for the Market Gunners of that Era
description: Winters were long in the 1830's, Crops hard to coax from the sandy soil of southern New Jersey. Little wonder those who could turned to the vast bays to provide. Summers offered fish, crabs and clams. When cold sent these scurrying for cover, down from the far northern places came hordes of waterfowl. Succulent birds appeared on the baymen's dinner tables. And shooting for the market padded budgets when cash crops were hard to come by.

title: D'Amato Seeking to Persuade Commercial Banks to Release Mortgage Money
description: HEMPSTEAD  Declaring that some commercial banks within Nassau County are Dot making enough of their deposits available for home mortgages within their local communities, Alfonso D'Amato, Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, said last week that the municipalities should refrain from depositing public funds in these banks until they make a commitment to promote the healthy development of Long Island.

title: Rutgers Increases Camden Holdings
description: CAMDENDespite public statements by Rutgers University that it is no longer buying land here for its controversial expansion plans, the university has purchased another property, it was learned last week.

title: Celebration Slated for Symphony Hall
description: NEWARKA Celebration of the Performing Arts, a cultural event to be held at Symphony Hall on April 4, will feature something for everyone, including concert music, opera, ballet and gospel singing.

title: Speidel Names 2 Editors
description: IOWA CITY, March 22 (AP) David R. McMillen, 35 years old, news editor of The Iowa City Press Citizen since 1971, will he managing editor of the Chillicothe, Ohio, Gazette, it has been announced. The Press Citizen and the Gazette are part of the Speidel newspaper group of 13 papers in nine states. Mr. McMillen succeeds Donald R. Casey, who will be managing editor of The St. Cloud, Minn., Times, a paper ?? acquired by Speidel.

title: Nuclear Warheads Were Not Retrieved In Sub, Paper Says
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)The Central Intelligence Agency did not recover two nuclear torpedo warheads from a Soviet submarine that sank in the Pacific Ocean. The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: SAIGON SITUATION SEEN WORSENING
description: The military situation in the Saigon area is likely to deteriorate further, according to United States military sources, who emphasize that the delay in mounting counterattacks allows the Communists to reinforce columns advancing on the capital area while retaining the initiative.

title: FORD ASKS STUDY OF ASIAN POLICY
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)President Ford said in an interview today that developments in Southeast Asia were very disturbing and said the United States must reexamine its policy there.

title: List of Weights
description: Following are the minimum weights in pounds for 28 species of saltwater fish that will he judged by the State Department of Environmental Conservation:

title: Spies, Spies, Everywhere
description: CHICAGO, Mar. 22The newspapers here, as usual, are full of scandal but this time it's not graft, roughhouse politics, or gang warfare. It's spying. Like Washington agog over the C.I.A., Chicago is breathless at the news that the city's police have been infiltrating community groups, keeping politicians, newspapermen and even Father Hesburgh of Notre Dame under surveillance, and compiling dossiers on numerous citizensincluding State Senator Richard Newhouse, a black who ran against Mayor Richard J. Daley in the Democratic primary last month.

title: Land Added to Park
description: A 14acre section of waterfront on Norton Basin in Far Rockaway, Queens, will be added to. MichaelisBayswater Park. The vacant parcel was sought by community groups to supplement the park. The Board of Estimate voted last week to approve required changes in the city map to permit acquisition of the added land.

title: PICASSO PICASSOS ARE BEING INDEXED
description: PARIS, March 22A team of experts was at work this week at a secret location cataloguing Pablo Picasso's fabulous collection of his own works.

title: Ford Policies Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)  President Ford's economic policies would cost the United States $1.45trillion in output between 1975 and 1980, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress said today.

title: Beame to Reassure the Public On Fiscal Strength of the City
description: Mayor Beame held a day of conferences with his top fiscal advisers yesterday in preparation for the announcement at noon today of a program to restore public confidence in the city's fiscal position. The announcement will be broadcast live on WNYCAM.

title: The Latin Giants in Search of Stability
description: BUENOS AIRESThere will soon be events which will show quite clearly that the President fully exercises power, said Alfredo Gmez Merales, the Minister of Economy last month. Everything is going to be all right. Believe me.

title: Janet S. Grossman Planning Wedding
description: Janet S. Grossman, an account executive with WABCTV here, and Russell K. Schaehrer, an account executive in New York with The Los Angeles Times, plan to marry in May. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Max Grossman of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Meriden, Conn., mother of the future bride, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Schaehrer of Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Tomatoes to Grow, Indoors or Out
description: The high cost of food faces us all. And this summer many consumers will be growing Vegetables at home for the first time. Even those who have only a tiny roof garden or a miniscule city terrace can plant.

title: Substandard Care Is Found in the Majority of 105 Hospitals in Federal Spot Check
description: More than half of the hospitals surveyed in a nation wide Federal spot check last year were delivering substandard care because they had significant health and safety deficiencies, according to a Government report now in preparation.

title: BURGLARY IS LAID TO 2 I.R.S. AGENTS
description: MIAMI, March 22Two men who were working as paid informants for the Internal Revenue Service burglarized the office of a candidate for the House of Representatives in 1972, according to an announcement by Richard E. Gerstein, Dade County State Attorney.

title: Short of Money? Try a PartTime Shopping Center
description: Has the recession produced an increase in the number of parttime workers? Well, then, the obvious response is the parttime shopping center with parttime storekeepers.

title: A Former House Painter Works At Being Effective Congressman
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Representative Ed Beard rolled his eyes while looking out of his office window the other day at the laborers at work on the new Library of Congress annex across the street and told a visitor, There but for the grace . . .

title: KISSINGER HALTS EFFORTS TO REACH ACCORD ON SINAI; FINDS RIFT TOO WIDE NOW
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, March 23Secretary of State Kissinger announced late last night that he was suspending his current efforts to achieve a new EgyptianIsraeli agreement on the Sinai Peninsula because of irreconcilable differences between the two sides. He said he would return to Washington today.

title: BRIDGE
description: The connection between the SpanishAmerican War and this column might not seem obvious at first glance; but the link was provided by Ely Culbertson more than four decades ago when he named his tricksacrificing play the Merrimac Coup. Culbertson's coup was designed to cut the opponents' communications with a sacrificeas in the Spanish American War the collier Merrimac was sunk in Santiago Harbor in an unsuccessful attempt to block the channel. (Not to be confused with the ship involved in the wellknown sea confrontation in the Civil War between the Monitor and Merrimack.)

title: Shari K. Tanner Engaged to Jay Stack
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester J. Tanner of New York and Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shari Kathryn Tanner, to Jay Stack, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stack of Philadelphia.

title: S. F.
description: Once upon a time there was a science fiction writer named Cordwainer Smith. Of course, that wasn't his real name. His real name was Dr. Paul Myron Anthony Linebarger, and he was a professor of political science at Johns Hopkins University, and a Government consultant on psychological warfareall of which may help to explain why he invented a pseudonym when he published his first science fiction story in a pulp magazine in 1950. From the name he invented, however, it should be clear that Dr. Linebarger was not at all ashamed of hip S.F. moonlighting.

title: Jazz Pianist to Slow Pace
description: OXFORD  Keith Jarrett, who was named the best jazz pianist of 1974 in a poll conducted by Down Beat magazine, and whose threerecord set, Solo Concerts, was selected as the jazz record of the year, plans to spend a great deal more time in his house here than he has in the three years he has owned it.

title: A Fight for the Fans of Marcus Welby
description: My Fellow Fans: Eight weeks ago in this space I declared the 1975 sports year over. All live contests were to be canceled until further notice. As your newly selfappointed Supreme Commissioner of Sports, I felt it was crucial to soften the gas bag of our extravagant sports balloon. I am happy to report to you now that my announcement was premature.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 388.7 from 389 a week earlier. A year ago it was 401.6.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: For generations, the American mining industry was dominated by engineers who spent much of their time underground, examining firsthand the rich veins of ore that assured their companies of a steady income.

title: Design: The A.I.A. awards
description: Many architects are turning to renovations for their bread and butter these days (there isn't much housing construction going oncontracts in the New York metropolitan area are down 44 per cent). This trend was acknowledged recently by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects when it chose the 1975 award winners for residential design (to be formally announced tomorrow). Five out of the 10 citations went to renovations, all but one or which are modestbudget projects by lesswellknown architects, three of them firsttime winners. The other five citations were given to new, singlefamilyhome designs.

title: Freedom of Theater
description: By ruling that the First Amendment protects live stage performances and plays against censorship in advance of public showing, the United States Supreme Court has finally given to the theater a guarantee of freedom of expression comparable to that for books.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 23, 1975

title: The Stricken Ones
description: Why do they flee? From Pleiku and Kontum in the highlands, from the old imperial capital of Hu, from the coastal city of Danang, the refugees in South Vietnam struggle eastward and southward ahead of the oncoming Communist forces. The lucky ones by airlift, thousands more by motor convoys bumpertobumper on mountain roads, and still others, meager possessions on their backs, wearily trekking on foot, the refugees are on the move. The idea that safety can be found in Saigon and the Mekong Delta may be an illusion, but not since the partition of Vietnam have so many refugees taken flight from their homes.

title: Temple in Millburn Is 50 Years Old
description: MILLBURNIn celebration of its 50th anniversary, Congregation B'nai Israel has scheduled a series of varied communitywide events, highlighted by a weeklong Yiddish Festival of the Arts.

title: Food
description: It is in no sense an exaggeration to state that within the next few days Americans will be off on what could be called the annual hardcooked egg binge. It is the season when the nation's kettle runneth over, so to speak, with what they used to laughingly refer to in the American South as hardcooked chicken fruit. Now is the best of times, it would seem, to decide what to do with all those eggs once they have served their lawnrolling function. Truth of the matter is, hardcooked eggs can be transformed into numerous delectable luncheon dishes, including one called eggs Chimay in which the eggs are stuffed with mushrooms, covered with Mornay sauce and baked. A recipe for that dish (plus recipes for a complete menu) is included here.

title: Leader of Kurdish Revolt Says That Fighting in Iraq Is Ended
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 22Gen. Mustafa Barzani, the leader of the Iraqi Kurdish rehellion, said today that the fighting is over, that his revolt has no foreign support and that he is considering taking refuge in the United States.

title: Article 1  No Title
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Anne Metts Is Married Here To Andrew Leslie Smith Jr.
description: In the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Elizabeth Anne Metts, daughter of Edwin Anderson Metts Jr. of Wilmington, N. C., and the late Jane Miller Metts, became the bride of Andrew Leslie Smith Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Truro, Mass., and Buffalo. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew Mullins.

title: Dr. Beeckman Delatour, 85, Internist Here and in Paris
description: Dr. Beeckman J. Delatour, a former associate professor of medicine at New York Univerisity and clinical director of the American Hospital of Paris in the early nineteenfifties, died Friday at his home in South Wercester, N.Y. His age was 85.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Phil Niekro, Atlanta Braves' pitcher, who hopes Dick Allen decides to report: If he walked through the door right now, I wouldn't even see him. All I'd sae would be 50 homers and 100 runs batted in.

title: Discomforting fragments of an uncomfortable mind
description: This is a difficult and uncomfortable book. There is nothing beautiful about it. At least half the pieces collected here are interviews, one is a transcript of a tape recording in which a patient turns on Ms psychiatrist, two are refutations of Sartre's views on the importance of the transcript, one is a fragment of an incomplete study of Tintoretto, another is Sartre's speech before the International War Tribunal accusing the United States of genocide in Vietnam. And yet, if you have the time and energy to do battle with the fragmentariness, with some dense philosophical jargon and, perhaps, with a lot of views inimical to your own out of the French intellectual left, they do make a book. They are strenuously, touchingly, sometimes powerfully, part of the history of a mind struggling to become a Fart of the history it fears it can only analyze.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section last week said incorrectly that the Bates Manufacturing Company in New York was an offshoot of Burlington Mills. The Bates Company is a coal royalty, coal sales and textile concern listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It has never been connected with Burlington Mills or any other company.

title: 2 Fencing Competitors Cut From Separate Molds
description: An Italian fencer whose father  a twotime world saber champion  had him wielding a light sword as a 3yearold, and a black of JapaneseAmerican ancestry from New Jersey, who stumbled into the sport as a 15yearold, will be featured today as the Martini & Rossi international fencing tournament ends a threeday stand.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Unless otherwise noted, the critical judgments in this Guide reflect the published views of Times critics.

title: Kennedy High Victor
description: Kennedy High School of the Bronx scored 21 points and won the Kingsbridge Armory indoor relays yesterday. DeWitt Clinton and Columbus were second and third, respectively.

title: POLICE GIVING AID TO ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22After years of being duped and defrauded by employers, businessmen, lawyers and professional consultants, illegal aliens are finding some unexpected help for their problems in the local police.

title: Starvation Threatens Many Highlands Refugees
description: TUY HOA, South Vietnam, March 22 Tens of thousands of South Vietnamese refugees are stranded, without water or food, and many are facing starvation in the violent exodus from the Central Highlands.

title: Tennessee Tornado Hurts 17
description: JACKSON, Tenn., March 22 (UPI)At least 17 person were injured early today when a tornado slammed through a fatalities were reported.

title: The Collapse: Why So Sudden?
description: What had happened?The Government in Saigon has never been a source of accurate information about the war, and as a result there are unverifiable rumors that President Thieu's brief explanation for his decision is not the real one. He said that because American aid had been reduced, military strategy dictated the withdrawal.

title: SeaMonitoring Fleet Gets a New Boat
description: ATLANTIC CITYA 42footlong vessel equipped with sophisticated electronic gear was officially launched here last week as part of the state's program for monitoring the quality of coastal waters and shellfish beds.

title: Miss MacLeod Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ian M. MacLeod of Mountain Brook, Ala., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marcia MacLeod, to Thomas Michael Meiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Meiss of Smoke Rise, N.J. Miss MacLeod and her fianc, a Princeton graduate, plan to be married May 3.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayWestchester Sports Car Club Economy Run; start at Patterson's Chevron station, 1275 East Post Road (next to Toyota City), Mamaroneck, N.Y. Registration: 9:30 A.M.

title: Dayan in Japan
description: TOKYO., March 22 (AP) Moshe Dayan, the former Israeli defense minister, arrived in Tokyo tonight on a private visit to Japan.

title: Exhibit Traces the Saga of America
description: MONTCLAIRThe Montclair Art Museum's exhibition of the American Society Revealed Through Art is a show organized in the Bicentennial spirit.

title: Wedding on Coast For Lynn Wyner
description: Lynn Wyner, a real estate sales agent in Davis, Calif., was married there yesterday afternoon to David White, a student at the McGeorge School of Law of the University of the Pacific in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Fashion
description: Some of the prettiest summer dresses look like little girls' pinafores and sundresses. These childlike designs are meant for grownups (but not too old, please). Mary Janes and straw cartwheels complete the innocent look.

title: RESCUE CREWS FIND BODIES OF VICTIMS
description: TACOMA, Wash., March 22 (UPI)Rescue crews, threatened by snow avalanches, today found the bodies of 16 men killed in the crash of an Air Force C141 Starlift jet in the Olympic Mountains.

title: Easter, 1975: Denims and TShirts
description: Handpainted denims, appliqud jumpsuits and tiedyed Tshirts will be seen alongside more traditional spring ensembles in Long Island's versions of the Easter parade next Sunday if the brisk sales at the handful of children's boutiques are a sign of what is ahead.

title: Politics and Music By Chilean Group
description: A combination concert and political rally took place Friday night against considerable odds. Quilapayun, the Chilean ensemble now headquartered in Paris, had visa problems and only landed at Kennedy Airport at 8:50, 20 minutes past the scheduled starting time of their program at Hunter College. Nobody at the hall seemed to have any idea when the group would actually arrive, and while the audience was milling in the lobby, the organizers of the event were desperately struggling to put together an alternate roster of performers.

title: School Umpires Are Tested
description: To most spectators and amateur athletes, baseball has always been considered one of the least complicated sports. But, as some avid fans discovered recently, there is more to the game than meets the eye.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The United Fund of Greater New York and the Salvation Army have agreed to merge their annual appeals to raise funds within the business community here, Richard E. Booth, executive director of the United Fund, and Lieut. Col. Waiter C. French, commander of the Greater New York Division of the Salvation Army, announced here yesteday. The new arrangement, according to Mr. Booth and Colonel French, makes it possible for the Salvation Army to join both the Greater New York Fund and the American Red Cross here as current partners designating the United Fund as their exclusive fundraising vehicle. The seventh annual United Fund campaign begins May 1.

title: GOP. LOSING GRIP ON WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 22We've won a few seats and lost a few, a Westchester Republican leader said the other night as he glanced at still incomplete village election returns, but we're still a Republican county.

title: The Oil Powers Assemble a Tanker Fleet
description: LONDONIf this were the stock market, said a banker surveying the world shipping situation, you would call it a classic manipulation. By jacking up the price of oil, the Arabs cut the bottom out of the tanker market. Then they come in and buy up the ships at the depressed prices that they themselves created.

title: John R. Nichols, Sculptor, Weds Eliza Twichell, Student at Mills
description: Eliza Twichell and John Robert NiChols were married yesterday afternoon in the Swedenborgian Church of San Francisco by the Rev. Erwin Reddekopp.

title: CORRECTION
description: Last Sunday's Economic Scene stated incorrectly that the depletion allowance for oil and gas was higher than for all other minerals. Sulphur and uranium are on the same basis as oil and gas22 per cent for production anywhere in the world. Forty others have the same allowance, but only for domestic production.

title: Sing Out, Sweet Choristers!
description: Choral singingsinging as a member of an organized groupis a leisuretime activity that can be as spontaneous as singing around a campfire, or as polished an refined as a wellrehearsed performance of Bach's St. Matthew Passion. Dating back to earliest times, choral singing has in recent years experienced a decided rise in popularity.

title: A wildeyed son of a bitch with a glass in his hand
description: At least among themselves, Americans are famous for their sense of humor, but strikingly few humorists have pot it in writing successfully. Mark Twain, of course, and then...? In this century there are many contenders, but the big two seem to be Robert Benchley and James Thurber. Here, some 13 and a half years after Thurber's death, Burton Bernstein details the, life and the life's work of Benchley's major challenger.

title: Point of View
description: A reassessment, of New York City's approach to landmark preservation may be needed as a result of recent court decisions that negated the Landmark status of two buildings, Grand Central Terminal and the J. P. Morgan House. The two decisions cast serious doubt upon the legitimacy of the Landmarks Preservation Law and the way the Landmarks Preservation Commission has carried out its task.

title: ART VIEW
description: CHICAGO. Exactly 15 years ago, an exhibition called Claude Monet: Seasons and Moments, organized by the late William C. Seitz, opened at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. That exhibition marked a kind of climax in the exciting rediscovery of Monet that had taken place in the 1950'san act of recovery and revelation that reestablished this quintessential Impressionist painter as one of the greatest of the modern masters.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: A Princeton University chemistry researcher and his wife made frontpage news in May, 1961, by winning a court battle for the right to keep their three children out of public school so they could teach them more at home. The children all had I.Q.'s in the genius category.

title: ParkwayToll Cut Is Blocked by Court
description: MINEOLA A temporary injunction was granted last Thursday in State Supreme Court in Albany prohibiting the implementation of a law that would roll back the increased toll on the Southern State Parkway.

title: Warren Anderson, the Unknown Who Is Really No. 2 in Albany
description: Warren M. Anderson has been having a good year. When the Democratic landslide last November left the Binghamton Republican, the Majority Leader of the State Senate, as the head of the only branch of state government to remain in Republican hands, there were those who said he was just lucky. In December, when he put the incoming Democrats on the defensive by proposing a tax cut, there were those who conceded he was clever. But there are few in Albany who would describe the last three weeks in Senator Anderson's career as anything less than a personal triumph.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Impressions of the great at sleep:

title: Postal Rate Commissioner Paul Miltich Is a Case in Point
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Postal Reorganization Act of 1970 was passed, making the Post Office Department an independent agency now known as the United States Postal Service, Congress went to special pains to remove politics from the fixing of postal rates, a function that Congress itself had performed over the years. The act set up a Postal Rate Commission, separate from the postal service, to establish reasonable and equitable fees through a judicious process insulated from improper pressures of the market place.

title: HALDEMAN ADMITS ERROR OVER TAPES
description: H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, now believes that the Watergate tapes, which led to President Nixon's resignation last August, should have been destroyed, although he said he had originally advised against such attion.

title: Ecologies of the finite and the infinite
description: When Walt Whitman advised his countrymen in 1871 to book passage to India he was not dreaming of extending the American empire to Asia. though he was enough of a chauvinist to view the restless migration to the Pacific complacently. Before the Civil War, American mercantile interests, New Englanders prominent among them, had discovered the lucrative China trade. Thoreau had carried the BhagavadGita in his bag to Walden Pond, and Emerson's Transcendentalism had taken much from Hindu, Buddhist and other Oriental philosophies. For Whitman, as for Emerson and Thoreau, the allure of the East was that it was not tainted by the allegedly worn out forms and methods of Europe. The enterprising American artist might draw on new sources of inspiration, uncover newold versions of the self, acquire a new lingo of spiritual ecstasy and enlightenment.

title: Days Are Numbered For a White Elephant
description: The New York Cultural Center, nee the Huntington Hartford Gallery of Modern Art, was recently pronounced dead, following a lifelong illness, shortly before its 11th birthday. A group of friends unwilling to accept the pronouncement  and determined to apply artificial respiration  have been instructed to cease and desist during an extended wake preceding the official burial date of June 30, at which time there is just a chance that the body will be turned over to them for resurrection. In the meanwhile, the white marble building on Columbus Circle, which opened on March 20, 1964, will continue to house the remains while offered for sale at $6million.

title: Jeanne Schwarz Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schwarz of Elmont, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Schwarz, to Michael Sofia, son of Mrs. Philip Sofia of Bethpage, L. I., and the late Mr. Sofia. The future bride is a graduate of Adelphi University. Her fianc graduated from Fordham. A wedding in August is planned.

title: David Massee Jr. Weds Gail Lione
description: Mrs. Massee, until recently, was with the Philadelphia law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Her husband is a partner in the Atlanta law firm of Kilpatrick, Coty, Rogers, McClatchey & Regenstein.

title: Cars: The Cost of Rebates
description: DETROITThe price rebate program probably cost the domestic auto companies more than $150million in the last two months, executives and industry analysts estimate, but they believe it was worth it.

title: Prize Fish In Ocean To Be Cited Bt State
description: ALBANYThe State Department of Environmental Conservation has establishedfor the first time a record fish program to find the largest saltwater fish caught in New York waters and to reward the fishermen who catch them.

title: Morley Leader By Shot
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22 (AP)  Arnold Palmer blasted himself out of the lead with a triple bogey and Mike Morley emerged from obscurity as the pacesetter after today's third round of the $150,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

title: Much Less Reliance on Trade With U.S.
description: RIO DE JANEIROFor us, the Soviet Union is a window which we are opening, without closing traditional doors, a senior official of the Brazilian state oil monopoly declared a few days ago, predicting that Russia could become this countrys chief trading partner. We cannot remain dependent on the United States, a country that is putting customs obstacles before us.

title: Mean Misanthrope
description: There is an interesting, if perhaps ominous, stage effect at the very opening of the British National Theater's production of The Misanthrope. Alec McCowen, as Molire's intolerant Alceste, is seated utterly alone beneath a darkened chandelier, wrapped only in chamber music. Suddenly an offstage door slaps open and a babble of merriment is all too briefly heard. The sound is cut off, abruptly, one might say rudely, as the door slaps shut again. There is a party going on in the very next room, a party Alceste is certainly never going to join. Let it be shut out.

title: A massive novel of Peruvian realities
description: Few Latin American writers have attempted to create so ambitious and complicated a body of work as Mario Vargas Llosa. In one decade (his first novel was published in 1963) this 38yearold Peruvian has published three long novels, two short ones and a collection of short stories. Linked by common themes and structures, these six volumes can be seen as one workone of the largest narrative efforts in contemporary Latin American letters. With an ambition worthy of such masters of the 19thcentury novel as Balzac, Dickens and Galds. but with a technical skill that brings him closer to the heirs of Flaubert and Henry James, Marlo Vargas Llosa has begun a complete inventory of the political, social. economic and cultural reality of Peru. This inventory is necessarily controversial.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Muhammad AliChuck Wepner heavyweight title fight from Richfield, Ohio, will be shown on closedcircuit television tomorrow night at Madison Squar? Garden. It will be preceded by a live 12round fight between Ken Norton and Jerry Quarry heavyweight contenders from California. The Garden program begins at 8:30 with three sixround bouts and a four rounder A closedcircuit showing of the two fights will be presented in Asbury Park's Convention Hall the Trenton Civic Center and 15 theaters in New York, New Jersey and Long Island.

title: Marjorie Duckrey, President Of Girls Clubs of America, Dies
description: Marjorie Hunt Duckrey, national president of Girls Clubs of America and a consultant in education and social welfare, died Friday in Philadelphia. Her age was 60.

title: Redskins' Stadium Lease Challenged
description: In the Litigation League, another trial is to start tomorrow with the pro football establishment again the target of the court action. This case, to be tried in Federal court in Washington challenges the right of a National Football League team, the Redskins, to hold an exclusivetenant contract for a Governmentowned facility, the Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in the nation's capital.

title: Aiding Transplants
description: So many thousands of kidney transplants have been successfully performed in this country that the procedure itself is now essentially routine for any competent surgeon in this field. The key problem today is providing enough kidneys for the tens of thousands of Americans who are victims of kidney diseases and whose lives would be pleasanter, easier and potentially much longer if they could receive transplants. Kidney dialysiswhich cleanses the blood of poisons that sick kidneys cannot removeis essentially a palliative procedure that exacts a high physical and emotional price at best.

title: Art Notes: Last of the BigTime Internationals
description: Trendspotters! More than two years before it'll happen (in June, 1977, at Kassel, Germany), Documenta, the last of the trendsetting international art shows, is sending ripples through the art world. Working out the big show's concept, the 12member Documenta committee has decided that painting will play a major partthe kind of abstraction that is more or less geometrical and scrupulously plotted, as opposed to the more spontaneous compositions of, say, the Abstract Expressionists. The monochromatic canvases of the late Ad Reinhardt and the work of such current artists as Brice Marden, Robert Ryman and Robert Mangold are examples.

title: Friars, Princeton Reach N.I.T. Final
description: Providence, young and talented, and Princeton, clever and defensiveminded, are in the final of the National Invitation Tournament today at Madison Square Garden. The teams meet for the championship at 1 P.M.

title: Rockefeller Knew of U.D.C. Problems
description: Two years before the nearcollapse of the Urban Development Corporation, Nelson A. Rockefeller and Malcolm Wilson, then Governor and Lieutenant Governor, were aware of serious financial difficulties in the agency and made at least one major move to put U.D.C. on more solid fiscal ground.

title: Epilogue
description: The lecture circuit has worked out well for John W. Dean 3d, former counsel to President Nixon. Mr. Dean has just wound up six weeks of lectures to college students, and he is expected to gross about $100,000.

title: A tenth and second novel
description: The Big Nickel

title: Big Game From Small Boats No Impossible Dream
description: Ten years ago if someone suggested going for big game fish from an outboarddriven craft, they'd be laughed out of the harbor. It would, at best, have been a stunt, for the small open boats of that time just weren't designed for the sport.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Record Tarpon
description: When Gus Bell of Washington. Pa., went forth for tarpon off Key West, Fla., a short time ago it was his sixth year of fruitless angling for the species.

title: Including a ride on a large elephant named Rosebud
description: In a piece that appeared some years ago Perelman describes a book that sells so well prior to publication that a first edition is never published. One wishes him better, or worse, luck with the new collection.

title: Convicts React to Nixon's Pardon
description: NORFOLK, Mass., March 22President Ford pardoned Richard M. Nixon, but prisoners at the Massachusetts Correctional Institution here have not. Fourteen inmates billed as the Stars in Stripes have put together a stage production of The White House Transcripts dramatizing the former President's tape recorded conversations and starring a cast of inmates.

title: Uncompromising with the world
description: In debates over the viability of communalism, someone eventually mentions Hutterites, the German  speaking people who have lived communally longer than any other group in Western history. They have believed in community of goods as the true Christian practice from their first days in Moravia in 1533 through their migration to North America from Russia in 1847, on into the present.

title: No Glitter in Gold Except for Futures
description: Nearly 12 weeks after gold ownership again became legal for United States citizens, investor interestinitially predicted to be a flood remains a dribble.

title: Italy Reports on Emigration
description: ROME, March 22 (Reuters)More than 25 million Italians emigrated over the last 100 years, less than a third of whom returned to their own country, according to official figures released here today. Over 11 million went to North America5,668,947 of them to the United States.

title: The World
description: After two weeks of shuttle diplomacy, Secretary of State Kissinger announced in Jerusalem that he was suspending his current effort toward a new EgyptianIsraeli agreement in the Sinai and would return to Washington.

title: Wepner Ain't Important
description: CLEVELAND, March 22When he decided not to train, the world heavyweight champion sank into a soft couch in the flowery Marriott suite where his wife, Belinda, and their tour children were staying. Sixyearold Maryum, 4yearold twins Janillah and Reesheda and 2yearold Muhammad Ibn watched cartoons on the TV set as they munched on hamburgers and drank milk provided by room service. Their mother had gone down to the coffee shop for lunch and the world heavyweight champion was checking a list of ticket requests for his title defense against Chuck Wepner in the Coliseum on Monday night. Muhammad Ali appeared more concerned with his children and his ticket problems than with his condition or his opponent.

title: Dorothy Hoover Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Jackson Hoover Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Hoover, to Richard Scott Vezina Jr., a junior at the University of Bridgeport and son of Mr. and Mrs. Vezina of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Now that golfers in the Northeast have come out of hibernation and seen their shadows, the new season cannot be far behind. If you want to lower your handicap in 1975, this is the time to ask yourself a couple of leading questions:

title: PLUTONIUM SHIPPING BY AIR IS CRITICIZED
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond yesterday criticized the shipment of plutonium oxide flown into Kennedy International airport and into any other airport in the United States, contending that it is possibly the most lethal oxide known to man.

title: Cahill Assailed On $20,000 Job
description: TRENTON  Former Gov. William T. Cahill has been asked to resign as a member of the board of directors of the Prudential Life Insurance Company on the ground that the $20,000 he receives each year as a public member constitutes a possible conflict of interest.

title: Article 10  No Title
Bullets Top Cavaliers As Chenier Scores 26
description: LANDOVER, Mr., March 22 UPI)Phil Chenier scored 4 points in the final 27 seconds tonight to lift the Washington Bullets to a 10097 National tory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Through the Wallto the movies. Socialism's highest standard of living. Art of compromise, compromise of art.
description: EAST BERLIN. A letter from the editor: Would you be interested in writing 3,500 words for our Magazine on life in East Germany today?

title: Women Join Active Ranks Of Volunteer Firefighters
description: WEST WINDSORThere no longer are firemen In the Princeton Junction Volunteer Fire Company No. 1. There are only firefighters. And there's a reason for the distinction.

title: Spanish Guitarist Master of Rhythm
description: A guitarist new to this country but by no means new to his art made an impressive debut at Alice Tully Hall on Friday and celebrated his 40th birthday in doing so. His name is Antonio Membrado, he was born in Madrid on March 21, 1935, he began studying the lute when he was 10, took up the guitar at 13, was a Geneva Competition prizewinner in 1956, and obviously has done a lot of playing since then.

title: Women's Ski. Is Captured By Austrian
description: ORTISEI, Italy, March 22 (AP)  Monika Kaserer of Austria survived 10 runs in quick succession today and won the first: dual slalom on parallel courses of World Cup skiing competition.

title: Lake George War Breaks Out Between Residents and Army
description: ALBANYA small war of words has broken out between the Army Corps of Engineers and angry residents of Lake George over a recent declaration by the engineers that the lake is a navigable waterway of the United States.

title: Laver and Ramirez Advance
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 22 (AP)Australia's Rod Layer and Mexico's Raul Ramirez captured their W.C.T. Blue Group semifinals of the $60,000 Altamira event today.

title: Article 11  No Title
Russian Squeeze
description: Traditionally Communist party congresses are occasions for reinspiring the faithful, for emphasizing the positive, and for boasting about past achievements and planned future accomplishments. That is why the downbeat tone of Janos Kadar's report last week to the 11th Hungarian party congress was so unusual. His warning that our foreign trade balance has deteriorated, our national economy has suffered considerable losses, must have sent waves of apprehension through all Hungary.

title: The Nation
description: The Senate has completed action on a tax reduction bill, making it almost certain the Congress will meet President Ford's April 1 deadline for the legislation. He will not like some features of the bill he gets but is expected to sign it anyway.

title: D. M. Gorski Jr. Weds Ruth White Warfield
description: Ruth White Warfield and Dennis M. Gorski Jr., 1974 graduates of Rider College, were married at noon yesterday in the Presbyterian Church of Westfield, N. J. The Rev. Henry Ash Tilghman, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Richard L. Smith.

title: Geraldine E. Derby Is Married To Dr. Lathrop Ellicott Roberts
description: Geraldine Elynor Derby, a counselor at Mamaroneck (N.Y.) High School, was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Lathrop Ellicott Roberts of Stamford, Conn., a psychiatrist with the New York Hospital, Westchester Division.

title: Headliners
description: Sanford Garelik, who left New York City's Police Department for one term as City Council President and an unsuccessful attempt to be mayor, has been appointed chief inspector of New York City's Transit Police. His predecessor, Robert H. Rapp, was removed earlier this month after admitting he lied about payoffs to transit police and about the falsification of crime statistics within the department. A state grand jury is still investigating reports of largescale payoff systems within the department. Mr. Garelik's salary is $44,000.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger announced last night in Jerusalem that he was suspending his current efforts to achieve a new EgyptianIsraeli agreement on Sinai because of irreconcilable differences between the two sides. He said he would return to Washington today. The announcement followed a final series of meetings between Mr. Kissinger and Israeli leaders in which he failed to get from them a compromise to keep the talks going. Earlier, Egypt also refused to ease her position on crucial questions. [Page 1, Column 8.].

title: Body of Stowaway in Jet Recovered in Biscayne Bay
description: MIAMI, March 22 (UPI)A body believed to be that of a youth killed while stowing away in a wheel well of a New Yorkbound plane was found in Biscayne Bay today.

title: Brazil's Reforms Now Seem Uncertain
description: SAO PAULOBrazil's President, Ernesto Geisel is facing a major test of his policy of gradual liberalization over the issue of human rights.

title: Katharine Bowden, Opera Singer, Wed
description: Katharine M. Bowden, who has sung with the Boston Opera Company and the Providence Opera Company, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Gregory Shields in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Austin, Tex., where Dr. Shields is assistant professor of astronomy at the University of Texas.

title: 76 Sailing Race to Recall Spirit of '64
description: For Frank Osborn Braynard, an author and illustrator with a special fondness for the sea, imagination has seldom had an ebb tide.

title: Inmate in Dutchess Attempts Suicide; 3d Incident in Week
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 22 (AP) A prisoner failed to day in a suicide attemp at the Dutchess County Jail, where two other inmates hanged themselves Thursday and Friday.

title: Cards Triumph in Midwest, 9682
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., March 22  Thirdranked Louisville conquered Maryland's press and used the shooting of Phillip Bond to gain a 9682 victory today in the final of the National Collegiate midwest Regional basketball tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, March 24

title: The Peace That Never Came
description: Thus, in the two years since the Paris peace agreement and the ceasefire in South Vietnam, the fighting has gone on and the casualty lists grow, without American names. In Laos there is peace, under a Communistdominated coalition reflecting the military reality there when the accords were signed. Cambodia was supposed to be covered by a later agreement; that never happened.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Today I have come bearing an olive branch and a freedom fighter's gun. Do not let the olive branch fall from my hand. I repeat: Do not let the olive branch fall from my hand.YASIR ARAFAT, before the United Nations General Assembly, Nov. 13, 1974.

title: Garden Lectures Are Offered
description: HACKENSACKThe Bergen County Cooperative Extension Service has begun a comprehensive program to teach suburbanites how to succeed at backyard gardenine this siring and summer.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The Byrne administration is expected to push next month for final legislative approval of a bill that would drastically increase fines for public officials and corporations convicted of political corruption in New Jersey.

title: Police in Chicago Kept Dossiers On Civic Leaders and Newsmen
description: CHICAGO, March 22  Undercover agents of the Chicago Police Department infiltrated several community action organizations during the last several years, and the department's intelligence unit has kept dossiers on scores of Chicago civic leaders, politicians and journalists.

title: Words and pictures that do mix and don't
description: Children's books are duck soup, really. All you have to do is draw as well as Drer and write as well as Mr. E. B. White and get the text and the pictures to marry.

title: Asa Bushnell Dies in Princeton; Led College Athletic Association
description: Asa S. Bushnell, the former commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference. died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at the Nassau Club in Princeton.

title: 8 Health Bills, Including a Plan For Flu, Are Offered by Carey
description: ALBANY, March 22Governor Carey today offered an eightbill package stressing preventive health care, including a measure to establish and enforce nutritional standards in nursing homes and other healthcare facilities regulated by the state.

title: Rosemary A. Furse Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Ronald Furse of Old House, West Hoathly, Sussex, England, and Fishers Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Anne Furse, to Talbot Jones Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Reed Taylor of Brookville. L. L

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about todays television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: FinancialDisclosure Bill Nears a Vote
description: TRENTONThe sponsors of a proposal requiring every candidate and elected official in New Jersey, from Governor Byrne down to local school board members, to disclose significant sources of their financial support are hoping for a decisive vote on their measure when the Legislature reconvenes next month.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Bounce flasha technique whereby the light from a flash unit is reflected or bounced off a nearby wall, ceiling or other reflective surface, rather than being aimed directly at the subject is almost as old as photography itself. Eearly photographers used flash powder and had no reflector so the flash was nondirectional. It was not until flash bulbs came along that reflectors were added and flash lighting became directional.

title: Ming Cho Lee Is All Set
description: Sets by Ming Cho Lee. That credit has appeared in theater, opera and dance programs an astounding 130 times since 1962  often enough to give the impression that it refers to some kind of oriental conglomerate. Actually, Lee is a tiredlooking but smiling 45yearold family man whose East Side apartment is so cluttered with sketches and scale models of his work that at first glance visitors tend not to notice the double bed in the master bedroom.

title: As Inflation Slows, Some Prices Fall
description: Potatoes are cheaper, interest rates are falling, there are bargains in clothing and airline fares will be reduced again in a few weeks. Perhaps it's time to fall in love.

title: FILM VIEW
description: About halfway through a movie called Deranged, its hero, a slightly retarded country fellow named Ezra, picks up a piece of fried chicken, smears it daintily with peanut butter and takes a large healthy bite. The audience the other day at the 42d Street Lyric Theater laughed at and cheered this gesture, clearly appreciating the consistency in Ezra's bizarre behavior. Ezra, you see, is no ordinary eccentric. In addition to liking peanut butter on his fried chicken, he has missed his dead morn so much that he has brought her home from the cemetery and set her up in a bedroom so they can chat, Psychofashion, with Ezra doing both voices.

title: Letters: Be Patriotic, Leave Concord Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: SEDER WEDNESDAY BEGINS PASSOVER
description: To the traditional question asked at the Passover seder on WednesdayWhy is this night different from all other nights?has been added another: Will this year be different from all other years in bringing peace in the Middle East?

title: Lyons Beats 93 Rivals in Epee Event
description: Bruce Lyons, a 32yearold construction executive from Washington, surprised last night by capturing the Martini & Rossi international epee tournament at the Kerr York Athletic Club.

title: Hanoi Officials Indicate Surprise At Rapidity of Saigon's Pullback
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 22I suppose if the Saigon troops continue to pull back at this rate we shall be in Hue very soon, a North Vietnamese army officer said today.

title: My Favorite? The Rose I See
description: When asked for my favorite rose, the stock reply is The rose I am looking at, at the moment. Now I have been asked to name the roses I love best. The plural does not help much.

title: Fishing Fun: The Lure That Attracts Most Boatmen
description: If there were no fish to pursue and catch, the recreational boating industry in the United States would probably collapse.

title: Alternatives to Prison
description: WASHINGTONAt my sentencing in the Watergate case, my attorney, Ira Lowe, asked not for leniency but that I be sentenced to perform a carefully supervised term of public service as an alternative to imprisonment, to comport with the Hasidic command of a good deed for a bad.

title: Flyers Beat Stars, Win Division
description: PHILADELPHIA. March 22 (AP)Ross Lonsberry's two secondperiod goals helped Philadelphia to a 40 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight, making the Flyers the first National Hockey League team to clinch a division title this year.

title: Suzanne Lindberg to Be Bride Of George Flynn 2d in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eric Lindberg of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Christine Lindberg, to George Daniel Flynn 2d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Doyle Flynn of Barrington, R. I., and Pohogonot Farm, Edgartown, Mass. A wedding in October is planned.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Bernard Slade's Same Time, Next Year is a neatly functional sentimental comedy thoroughly conscientious about getting a laugh every 40 to 60 seconds, given to sudden, sobering silences just regularly enough to let you know that if the playwright is a hustler he's a perceptive hustler. I wouldn't keep you from it for a minute, though when you do go I hope you will pay strict attention not only to the respective charms of its two performers  Ellen Burstyn and Charles Grodin  but to the virtually demonic skill with which they keep justifying jokes they probably shouldn't have made.

title: Housing Is Voted For Fulton Park
description: Risley Dent Towers, a 243unit middleincome housing project in the Fulton Park urban renewal area in Brooklyn, received final approval from the city's Board of Estimate last week.

title: Transit Accord Reached By Philadelphia Strikers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (UPI)The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority and the Transport Workers Union approved a contract agreement today paving the way to an end of the weeklong transit strike.

title: Roth's Bridge Team Faces Aces In Vanderbilt Play Semifinals
description: HONOLULU, March 22Four of the country's topranked bridge teams began play here today in the semifinal of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship, the prestige event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Study Concludes That TV Promotes Stereotypes That Adversely Affect Children
description: SETAUKET, L.I.A Long Islandbased research group has found that television programs convey racial and sexual stereotypes that may negatively influence the behavior of children.

title: Harris in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, March 22, (AP)Fred Harris, the former Democratic Senator of Oklahoma announced today that he would he a candidate in the 1976 Democratic Presidential primary in Massachusetts.

title: Cairo Arrests Workers In CostofLiving Protest
description: CAIRO, March 22 (UPI)Interior Ministry sources said today that police have arrested 40 to 50 persons in connection with antiGovernment rioting at the Middle East's largest spinning and weaving plant in which one person was killed and several others injured.

title: Worst Race Horse Shortage Putting Pinch on $2 Bettor
description: The doors of a 14stall starting gate bang open at Aqueduct, and the horses spring forward. All four of them.

title: Drive Began to Save World's Biggest Plane
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)A save the Spruce Goose campaign is under way in Los Angeles.

title: Center in Newark Gets Arts Funding
description: NEWARK  The Newark Community Center of the Arts has received a $15,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. The grant will be used for expansion of the center's existing program.

title: Brokers' Fees Higher Since PriceFixing Suit
description: Manhattan real estate brokers have increased their commission rates almost universally in the 20 months since the Federal Government filed suit to halt the publication of suggested rate schedules by the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: Apartment Vegetables
description: Apartment gardeners, take heart! Vegetables can be raised indoors successfully.

title: Carolina Bill Bids Schools Give Class In Free Enterprise
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 22The North Carolina General Assembly enacted this week a bill requiring high schools to give instruction in the free enterprise system.

title: Teresa Treadway Married to T. S. Mabon
description: Teresa Lee Treadway and Thomas Starr Mabon were married yesterday at noon by the Rev. Lawrence Prast in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest here.

title: Redman and BMW Win At Sebring
description: SEBRING, Fla., Sunday, March 23A factoryteam BMW, with four drivers alternating in its cockpit, held off four Porsche Carreras and a Ferrari to win the 12 Hours of Sebring endurance race early todya.

title: LILLIAN D. TICK
description: Lillian Davidoff Tick, a fellow of Brandeis University and past president of its na tional women's committee. died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 3515 Henry Hudson Parkway, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: J. D. Adams Jr. to Wed Constance Carden in June
description: Constance Porter Carden, a staff attorney with the Legal Aid Society of New York, will be married in June to J. Dinsmore Adams Jr., a lawyer with the law firm of Webster Sheffield Fleischmann Hitchcock & Brookfield.

title: The Magic Shop  An Easter Fantasy
description: OLDWICK  For several weeks before Easter, hundreds of children from miles around come to this quiet preRevolutionary village to squeeze through a hole in a hollow tree and slide down a magic Bunny Hole. Once inside, they view six or seven tiny rooms filled with exquisite miniature furniture, fluffy stuffed rabbits and other fanciful animals inhabiting an enchanting world of makebelieve.

title: The Best of the Lilacs
description: Lilacs are one of the most popular spring  flowering shrubs. The clusters of blossoms are delightfully fragrant and the hardy bushes last many years with a minimum of care.

title: A Singer sampler
description: In our home there was always talk about spirits of the dead that possess the bodies of the living, souls reincarnated as animals, houses inhabited by hobgoblins, cellars haunted by de. mons. My father spoke of these things, first of all because he was interested in them, and second because in a big city children so easily go astray. They go everywhere, see everything, read profane books. It is necessary to remind them from time to time that there are still mysterious forces at work in the world.

title: Bonn Festival Marks Opening of Subway
description: BONN, March 22With a gala festival in front of its pink and white baroque town hall, West Germany's minicapital, Bonn, celebrated the opening of its longawaited subway today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: An extensive and varied collection of medals of the world came out of storage and onto the auction block last month, and the prices realized indicate that exonumia is still going strong and has not lost any ground to the gold rush of '75. The collection of approxi?? assembled over a 60year period by J. Henry Ripstra, who died in 1961. A former president of the American Numismatic Association, Mr. Ripstra was probably best known for his collection of Lincoln medals. The auction included his library of several hundred Lincoln books, but the outstanding item was a cast of an original life mask (illustrated at right) made in 1861 by Leonard Volk. It sold for $1,500.

title: Hawks Triumph
description: ATLANTA, March 22 (AP) Tom Henderson's driving basket with 10 seconds left and two free throws by Herm

title: ExSkipper Talks Of the Ideal Boat
description: Not long ago a sportsman friend of mine who is thinking of graduating to a larger boat, said to me, If you were planning to get back in the charter boat business what sort of craft would you pick?

title: Son to the Scott Kellmans
description: A son was born March 8 to Dr. and Mrs. Scott Keliman of Manhasset, L.I., in the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, where Dr. Kellman is a resident in internal medicine. His wife, the former Amy Beth Blumenstock, is a speech pathologist. Their child has been named Alan Samuel.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Both men and women will benefit from a Supreme Court decision that gives widowers Social Security rights that widows have had for 36 years.

title: Modern Hospital Boasts Everything but Patients
description: One of the nation's most modern and bestequipped nonhospital medicalcare facilities is idle and without patients in downtown Brooklyn while a group of doctors frantically seeks to find some medical use for it.

title: HUNGARY RETAINS ECONOMIC REFORM
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 22 Hungarian Communists ended their 11th party congress today, leaving the main lines of their liberal economic and cultural programs intact. The policies were implicitly endorsed by the visiting Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: 1975 TransAm Will Lack Glamour of Past, But Still May Turn Into an Exciting Series
description: There were many people who predicted that 1974 would be the last year for the TransAmerican Championship sanctioned by the Sports Car Club of America. But as in the About world of rock n roll music, old favorites never diethey are rediscovered. So, there will be a 1975 TransAm. It's doubtful, however, that it will be as glamorous as TransAm series of the past.

title: There's a schism in the world of the Grand Old Soap Opera.
description: Cathy Craig was a teenager who experimented with drugs and was cured of her incipient habit at Odyssey House. She went on to become a reporter for her hometown newspaper, the Llanview Banner, and wrote a nationally syndicated article telling nice people what to do when they get venereal disease. She turned some of her newspaper experiences into a bestselling book of short stories that won feminist praise. She has borne a child with out a husband but is enthusiastic about being a single parent rather than an unmarried mother. On a national television talk show, she looked meaningfully down at her bulging belly and asked the interviewer, Melba Tolliver, to call her Ms.

title: Food News
description: WEST ORANGEMarion Josephson began baking bread 20 years ago, more for her own amusement than anything else. Today, she is known as the bread lady. and she has a lucrative business operating out of her farmhouse kitchen at the top of First Mountain.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: WESTERN STATE UNIVERSITY

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayFairfield County Hunt Club, Long Lots Road, Westport, Conn. Regular and children's working hunters, short stirrup, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Psst! Wanna Buy Some Coors?
description: Beer lovers in the East have probably heard some good things about Coors, the famous Colorado brew that has won fanatical supporters in the West. Now, thanks to a Federal judge, some Coors is trickling into New Yorkthough perhaps not for long.

title: Harvey Swados
description: There is an eerie but appropriate congruence in the fact that Harvey Swados's last workthe novel called Celebration, completed just before his death in 1972 at the age of 52 and published this month by Simon and Schusteris, in effect, the chronicle of a liberal hero who, in the face of approaching death, is intent upon disclosing the difficult and often unappealing truths underlying the glossy image of his legendary accomplishments.

title: Dorina Finley Wed to John Szczepanski
description: The marriage of Dorina Mary Finley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Finley of Cherry Hill, N.J., formerly of Brooklyn, to John Szczepanski, son of Frank A. Szczepanski of Pennsauken, N.J., and the late Mrs. Szczepanski, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Felony Murder Here Rose Sharply in '74
description: A confidential police study has disclosed sharp increases here last year in murders involving strangers and those that occur during the commission of other crimes, known as felonymurders.

title: Connecticut Jails Are Filling Up Again After Court Ruling That Released 200
