The bearings will start at 9:30 A.M. in Hearing Room No. 1, 24th floor, No. 2 World Trade Center. Testimony will be limited to 15 minutes for each person.

title: Princeton Wins N.I.T.
description: Princeton defeated Providence College, 8069, yesterday to win the National Invitation Tournament basketball title at Madison Square Garden. Page 43.

title: War Operations Used to Restore Phone Lines to Manhattan Area 22 Days After Fire
description: To turn on virtually all the telephones again for a 300block area in Manhattan only 22 days after the worst American phoneservice disaster, the Bell System had to throw away the rulebook and carry out its most massive mobilization of talent and equipment ever.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, March 24

title: DR. ALEXANDER KELEN
description: Dr. Alexander Kelen, a heart specialist, died Saturday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: Michael, a Tiger Now, Blames Paul for Making Him an ExYank
Text of Mayor Beame's Fiscal Statement
description: I have called this press conference to announce a series of major steps designed to ease the city's borrowing and fiscal problems in the years ahead.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: A.A.U. BASKETBALL

title: Vietcong Seek Foreign Aid To Feed Highlands Millions
description: TOKYO, March 23 (UPI) The Vietcong today asked for foreign aid to feed more than a million people who have come under its rule as a result of victories this month in South Vietnam's Central Highlands.

title: COMMUNIST FORCE ALL BUT ENGULFS PROVINCE IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 24  North Vietnamese offensives virtually engulfed the key northern province of Thua Thien, pressed toward Saigon's eastern and western flanks and engaged Government troops near the Cambodian border, the military command said today.

title: N.E.A. Urges Teachers To Seek Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)  School teachers are being encouraged by the nation's largest teachers' organization to apply for food stamps.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ford, Studying Tax Bills, Consults Aides and Ullman
description: WASHINGTON, March 23President Ford met separatery today with his economic advisers and Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to discuss what should be done with the taxreduction bill that Congress plans to finish by midweek.

title: CAMBODIA AIRLIFT OFF INDEFINITELY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 23The American airlift of food, fuel and ammunition, the last supply link between Cambodia's capital and the outside world, has been suspended indefinitely until the military situation near the airport improves.

title: Greek Town Looks Beyond Oil Windfall
description: KAVALLA, Greece  Oil can be burned. mused Pavlos Kontomisopoulos, a local lawyer, but it can also burn you.

title: Baseball, Game of Youth, Attracts Elderly to Camps
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23Casey Stengel, the Mount Rushmore of the senior citizens' landscape, is absent from Florida's sporting scene these days for the first time in many years.

title: F.T.C. Plan on Food Ads Scored
description: DORADO, Puerto Rico, March 23The proposed trade regulation rule of the Federal Trade Commission that would require nutritional information in food advertisingone of the more controversial issues in advertising todaywas attacked at the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Toward Equal Rights
description: When Congress in 1939 decided that widowsbut not widowersof participants in the Social Security system would be entitled to collect benefits if they had dependent children, it was acting on traditional assumptions about work and family life. It assumed that the father would be the principal wage earner and that, if he died, society should financially enable his widow to stay home and care for her growing children. Conversely, if a mother died, the widowed father would make some other arrangement for the care of his children, rather than quit work himself.

title: Advertising
description: DORADO, Puerto Rico, March 23  While more Americans believe that advertising is esesntial now than they did a decade ago, their positive attitudes toward it in other areas have declined, according to a report released here yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Cavs Drop Rockets Out Of 2d Place
description: CLEVELAND, March 23 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers rallied for a 10195 victory today over Houston despite 30 points and 14 rebounds by the Rockets' forward, Rudy Tomjanovich.

title: Test of Election Board
description: Less than a year old, the new State Board of Elections is on the spot. The bipartisan, but nonetheless highly political, board has been asked to look into alleged irregularities in Governor Carey's campaign financing in what could be a test of just how stringently the state's new Watergateinspired campaign finance law will be enforced.

title: Saber Title Is Captured By Montano
description: Mario Aldo Montano of Italy won his third Martini & Rossi international saber title when he defeated Paul Apastol of the United States in an argumentfilled bout yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Humble Hotel Is Transformed Into PublicTV Center
description: An undistinguished 45yearold skyscraper, which has been going to seed since the end of World War II as a transient hotel at 58th Street and Ninth Avenue, is about to become one of the significant buildings in the cultural and communications life of Manhattan.

title: Personal Finance: Listing Deductions
description: There is no such person as an average taxpayer, just as there is no average family or average businessman. But averages are nevertheless important as a guide to the activities of the majority of the group under consideration.

title: This Is the End, Fahmy Says of Kissinger Role
description: ASWAN, Egypt, March 23Egypt firmly maintained today that Secretary of State Kissinger's stepbystep mediation in the ArabIsraeli conflict had collapsed and could not be renewed.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The Supreme court took the following actions today:

title: Levitt Says Advance Payments Asked by City Would Hurt State
description: ALBANY, March 24  State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that any acceleration in payments of state funds to New York City, as proposed yesterday by Mayor Beame, would result in increased interest costs to the state.

title: Worry on Debt and Dollar Stirs Cut in Bond Prices
description: Mounting concern about Federal deficit spending, the soaring volume of unsold new corporate debt issues and the value of the dollar combined again yesterday to slash prices of fixedinterest securities.

title: The Stage: Waterlilies
Counsel in NursingHome Inquiry
description: S. (for Seth) Andrew Schaffer yesterday made his public debut as chief counsel to the. Moreland Commission set up to investigate nursing homes, and did so in an aggressive, if not pugnacious, manner. The 33year old former assistant United States attorney sliced through the bland assertion of one witness that nursinghome care should be turned over to nonprofit institutions with sharp questions about whether that would cost more or less. It might cost more, the nonplussed witness conceded.

title: COLLEGE AID ISSUE FACES HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Supreme Court cleared the way today for a full reexamination of the question of state financial aid for private colleges and universities with religious sponsorship.

title: Opera: A New Lucia
description: If Lucia di Lammermoor is to succeed as a music drama as well as a vocal showpiece, the soprano must somehow suggest that she is young and tender enough to go mad when forced to marry the wrong tenor. Patricia Wise, performing the title role of Donizetti's opera for the first time with the New York City Opera on Sunday night, succeeded entirely in that respect.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The new Federal plan to restructure the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads into a slimmeddown ConRail system was assailed by Governor Carey at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing at the World Trade Center as contemptuous of New York's needs, and Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania called it snake oil in a new bottle and harmful to Northeast industrial states. Governor Carey said in his statement that the plan deprived New York City, Westchester and Long Island of competitive rail freight service; failed to provide needed highspeed passenger service in the New YorkAlbanyBuffalo corridor, and shifted freight traffic and jobs to other states. The Beame administration complained that the plan lopped off an important freight connection in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn,

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: E. Sutton of Manhattan and Jerome Hornblass, the Commissioner of the Addiction Services Agency, were shouted at and jeered on a Harlem street corner during a news conference they had called to promote two new registration vans for narcotics addicts desiring treatment.

title: Ruling by High Court On Zoning Is Recalled
description: The United States Supreme Court has ruled on only one zoning case in the last 45 years. In a decision last April 1, the court upheld the authority of Belle Terre, L.I., to bar six unrelated college students from sharing a rented onefamily house.

title: Music: Neutral Turbae
U.S. REQUESTS BIDS ON OFFSHORE TRACTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Interior Department took its first official step today to bring oil and gas development to the Atlantic Coast, inviting tract nominations off the midAtlantic.

title: Mayor of Allentown Wins Often In the Battle for Federal Funds
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.,  Who wants to build a school that may never be needed or a highway that goes nowhere?

title: Refugee Kurds Find Iran Alien Land
description: ZIVEH, IranThe sheep are fine and fat here in the western reaches of Iranian Azerbaijan land the stony hills are handsome in their coat of snow.

title: City's New Auction Rules Will Take Effect April 24
description: The final wording of amendments to regulations governing auction sales were announced yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. These code modifications require auctioneers or galleries to disclose to bidders any special interests other than commissions in the lots for sale.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1975

title: Cook Travel Agency Halts Promotion of South Africa
description: LONDON, March 24 (Reuters) Thomas Cook, the travel agency, said today that it had agreed to stop newspaper and magazine advertising for trips to South Africa.

title: Advertising
description: Advertising industry conventions, although tough on the liver, appear to be designed to refresh the participants both physically and intellectually.

title: Winner's Fall in 9th Ruled Knockdown
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, March 24Muhammad Ali registered a knockout over Chuck Wepner with only 19 seconds remaining in the 15th round of a brawling bout tonight and retained his world heavyweight title before 14,847 spectators in the Coliseum outside Cleveland.

title: People and Business
description: Price watchers were given some discouraging words last night in Des Moines, Iowa, by the United States Agriculture Department's chief economist.

title: Korvette Suburban Stores Plan Later Opening Time
description: Korvette Suburban Stores Plan Later Opening Time

title: Some Minority Students in Brooklyn Given Right to Cross Borough Lines
description: Some students from areas in north and central Brooklyn that have large minority populations will, for the first time next fall, be given the option of attending integrated high schools in Queens and Manhattan under a new zoning plan announced yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: Beame Criticized for Bypassing City's Congressmen on U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Senior members of the New York City Congressional delegation complained today that Mayor Beame had failed to make maximum use of the delegation's strength in his quest for fiscal relief from the Federal Government.

title: E.E.C. Seeks a Halt In Its Cheese War With United States
description: BRUSSELS, March 24 (UPI)The European Common market, called today for a halt in its cheese war with the United States.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The First Avenue Screening Room, a theater that won a New York Film Critics' citation for its presentations of new imported films, has been transformed into a house specializing in male homosexual movies.

title: FLIGHTS RESUMED INTO PHNOM PENH IN A U.S. GAMBLE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 25American officials, taking what they termed a calculated gamble. have ordered a resumption of the supply airlift into Phnom Penh's airport, the last remaining supply link between the Cambodian capital and the outside world, although the military situation around the airport appears to have deteriorated.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TRENTON, March 24Freehold Raceway's concessionaire, Sportservice, Inc., is under investigation by the State Attorney General's office. The inquiry is centering on a $300,000 loan Sportservice made to the track four years ago and other aspects of the harness track's relationship with the subsidiary of the Emprise Corporation of Buffalo. The State Racing Commission initiated the inquiry after learning that Emprise's 1972 Federal conviction on a felony charge had been upheld earlier this year by the Supreme Court. Emprise had been convicted of conspiracy for trying to conceal the transfer of stock it held in a Las Vegas gambling casino. As a result of the Supreme Court action, Emprise has been denied racing dates and/or liquor licenses at race tracks in Kentucky and Illinois.

title: Slater, Walker Unit Acquired for Cash By First Fortune
description: First Fortune Holdings, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore said yesterday that it had acquired the Slater, Walker Finance Corporation, Ltd., the banking and installment finance subsidiary of Slater, Walker SecuLondon.

title: Slower Mail Is Studied
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Postal Service said today that it had awarded more than $500,000 in contracts for outside companies to find out why the mail does not move faster. Test mailings will be made in addition to those already conducted by the service. In these the employes frequently know when certain pieces of mail are sent only to examine postal efficiency.

title: SHOUTS DISRUPT ADDICT PROGRAM
description: A news conference scheduled for a Harlem street corner to publicize a drugaddict referral program yesterday morning turned into a shouting match that had more to do with the accountability of public officials than the treatment of addicts.

title: More Calls Than Usual In Stricken Phone Area
description: In the first business day since telephone service was restored to most of the 104,000 customers whose phones were out for more than three weeks, some delays in getting dial tones were reported as calls from are area were up 65 per cent above normal yesterday morning and occasionally, up to 165 per cent above normal.

title: In Astoria, the Greek Community Dances to Its Very Own Drummer
description: The children watched the belly dancer writhe and wriggle while their parents clapped in time to the languid rhythms of bouzouka, drums and electric organ.

title: State NursingHome Unit In Rift With City Owners
description: The president of the state association of nursing homes testified yesterday that its New York City leaders had told him to keep your nose out of our business when he asked them to police alleged abuses in nursing homes.

title: SPACECRAFT GOES TO LAUNCHING PAD
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 24Twenty years ago it would have been all but unthinkable, except in science fiction. Another Saturn rocket moved to the launching pad here today, taking a slow, grinding step on the way to thrusting men into space.

title: SOVIET AND FRANCE ASK ISRAEL PULLOUT
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (AP)France and the Soviet Union said today that peace was possible in the Middle East only if Israeli troops withdrew from all Arab territory they occupied in 1967.

title: Rating by High Court On Zoning Is Recalled
description: The United States Supreme Court has ruled on only one zoning case in the last 45 years. In a decision last April 1, the Court upheld the authority of Belle Terre, L.I., to bar six unrelated college students from sharing a rented one family house.

title: 9992121: Bettors' Favorite Number
description: Fifteen minutes after yesterday's first race at Aqueduct, offtrack horseplayers by the thousands began dialing 9992121. Somewhere in the city, raspyvoiced bookies were picking up telephones in the back rooms of candy stores and grunting, Yeah? But not at 9992121. The voices that give race results for Fonawin belong to college seniors or graduates who speak distinctly enough to thrill an elocution teacher.

title: Market Basket Rise For February Held Lowest in 4 Months
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The annual retail cost of a food market basket rose $7 to a record of $1,830 in February, but the gain was the smallest in four months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: State Drug Law Constitutionality Is Under Fire in Court of Appeals
description: ALBANY, March 24  The constitutionality of the state's stringent drug law was tested for the first time today before the State Court of Appeals.

title: Embattled Mayor . . .
description: Mayor Beame needs and deserves the support of every New Yorker in his attempts to restore investor confidence in the city's battered credit. His weekend commitment to new economies and to reductions in the volume of municipal borrowing carries forward an austerity course that will demand sacrifices beyond any this metropolis has been asked to make since World War II.

title: 291MILLION CUT IS SET IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 24A bipartisan agreement to cut $297million from Governor Carey's budget proposal today paved the way for passage tomorrow of a $10.4billion budget for the fiscal year starting April 1.

title: Tests Indicate Aspirin Use for Colds Increases Hazard of Infecting Others
description: A team of researchers reported in Chicago yesterday that the use of aspirin to relieve symptoms of the common cold increased the amount of virus shed in nasal secretions for one week after onset of the infection.

title: Okker Early Victim
description: MONTE CARLO, March 24 (Reuters)Tom Okker was upset in the first round of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Gulf Nomination of Nun Surprises Activists
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, which has continually been taken to task by church groups for the social consequences of its corporate actions, has just nominated a Roman Catholic nun and Pittsburgh civic leader to its board of directors.

title: Twin Bill Proves Big Hit at Garden
description: In the eerie blackness of Madison Square Garden last night a woman began to dance when Muhammad Ali shuffled on the huge television screen above.

title: Henri Filion Fined, Suspended
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 24Henri Filion has been suspended from race driving for 10 days for failing to apply for his 1975 New York State harnessrace driving license and has been fined $500 for an infraction in the seventh race on Friday night's program at Roosevelt Raceway. The suspension was handed out by a state steward, Charles Plumb. The fine was by the presiding judge, Tom Cassidy.

title: A Quiet Times Reader Is News in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 24Many citizens on their way into Borough Hall here or driving by are inclined to do a double take. From a distance, they see what looks like a man reading a newspaper on a marble benchand yet the figure is sitting too still to be human.

title: Electric Rate Study Promised by Zarb
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Frank G. Zarb, Federal Energy Administrator, said today his agency would spend $1million to finance experiments in electricity conservation, including a redesigning of rate structures.

title: Rabbi Korff Asks $15,000 For Nixon's Attorney's Bills
description: CINCINNATI, March 24 (UPI)  Richard M. Nixon's chief money raiser, Rabbi Baruch N. Korff, appealed yesterday for $15,000 in donations so the former President can pay his attorneys' bills this week.

title: Chess
description: The minor piece plus two pawns is stronger than the rook, but the rook is stronger than the minor piece plus one pawn. How do we know that? By summarizing leading examples of these two confrontations as provided in 400 years of recorded chess.

title: American Enka to Shut Unit
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Marc?? 24 (UPI)The American Enk?? Division of Akzona, Inc., wi?? close its rayon filament pla?? at Enka, N. C., near Ashevill?? its oldest American mill, afte??46 years of operation. Abo?? 1,700 jobs will be lost.

title: Saxbe Wary on Relations Between U.S. and India
description: NEW DELHI, March 24Ambassador William B. Saxbe said today that a mature relationship between India and the United States was not possible so long as the Indians failed to appreciate the realities first.

title: 2 OIL COMPANIES CITE TAX DANGERS
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) warned yesterday that amendments to the Senate tax bill carried the threat of a devastating impact on United States international oil companies.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: THE GREATEST That selfstyled peerless parade of phantasmagoria, the bicentennial edition of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, opens its visit here this morning with a parade. The show's animals will be unloaded from the circus's 31car train at the Penn Central Yards, 12th Avenue between 35th and 36th Street, at 8:40 A.M. preparatory to marching to the Madison Square Garden entrance on 33d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Circus clowns will be on hand for the unloading and for the march, which begins at 9 A.M. The circus will he at the Garden for nine weeks.

title: Rhodesian Inquiry Opens in Detention Of a Black Leader
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 24 (Reuter)A specie court began a hearing today to determine whether the detention of the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, the Rhodesian nationalist leader, on charges of plotting to kill some of his political rivals and of continuing to support terrorism in Rhodesia was justified.

title: FASHION TALK
description: It has to be the longest continuous running fashion show in town. What other performance off Seventh Avenue turns up as regularly as the equinox, fall and spring, for a quarter of a century?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Five Wins Final
description: BATON ROUGE, March 24 (UPI)Capitol Insulation of Los Angeles downed the California Junior College AllStars, 10591, yesterday to win the national Amateur Athletic Union basketball championship.

title: 3 Die and Governor's Mansion is Damaged by Atlanta Tornado
description: ATLANTA, March 24Three persons were killed and the Georgia Governor's mansion was severely damaged this morning when a tornado skipped across Atlanta.

title: Somalia Expresses Regret
description: PARIS, March 24The French Government has received a note expressing regret from the Sonali leader, Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre, and has answered that it was Somalia's responsibility to see to it that the Ambassador would be freed unharmed.

title: Leafs Defeat Seals, 53, As Ellis and Sittler Star
description: TORONTO, March 24 (AP)Ron Ellis and Darryl Sittler scored two goals apiece tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the California Golden Seals, 53, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Contract Awards
description: Ateliers de Construction Electriques de Charleroi, the Belgian unit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has received from Iran a $67million order for 12 gasturbine power plants. The plants were ordered by the Iran Power Generation & Transmission Company.

title: 2 Top Orange Police, 16 Others Are Indicted in Corruption Case
description: NEWARK, March 24The two top police officers in Orange, eight other members of the city's police force and eight other men were indicted today by an Essex County grand jury on charges of corruption.

title: Hue Falling; Da Nang Cut Off
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 25With shells falling heavily on the former imperial capital of Hue and military units having nearly completed the evacuation from the city by sea, the fall of Hue was expected imminently.

title: French Envoy in Somalia Held by AntiParis Group
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Tuesday, March 25 (Reuters)Four armed men kidnapped the French Ambassador to Somalia over the weekend an took him to a suburban villa. Negotiations for his release have proceeded since then, with the building surrounded by Somali troops and policemen.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, March 14, 1973

title: Despite Fare Rise, Taxi Fleets Report New Losses Again
description: The city's taxi fleets have found the fare increase granted last fall inadequate and are preparing to seek a new increase, according to Taxi News, the industry's paper.

title: Father of 5 Slain At a Bronx Carnival As Hundreds Watch
description: A 29yearold taxicab mechanic, the father of five children, was shot and stabbed to death at a crowded street carnival in the South Bronx Sunday night by a halfdozen young thugs who escaped with his wallet and about $40, the police reported yesterday.

title: Louis Says Ali Meets Wrong Foe
description: RIDGEFIELD, Ohio, March 24 (AP)Joe Louis stole the early spotlight as fans gathered in the Midwest Coliseum tonight for Muhammad Ali's heavyweight title defense against Chuck Wenner.

title: Carnegie Mellon Drama Chief Is Chosen for C.C.N.Y. Post
description: The City College of New York has reportedly chosen Earle R. lister, the 40yearold chairman of the drama department at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, to head C.C.N.Y.'s performing arts center.

title: The Dilemma of the P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON  The Palestine Liberation Organization has been enormously successful on the international diplomatic front since it was sanctified by the Arab leaders at their summit conference in Rabat, Morocco, last fall. But the P.L.O.'s diplomatic triumphs are, paradoxically, contributing to its problems, and may in the end subvert the movement.

title: BEAME SAYS CITY WILL HAVE TO AN TAXES IN 197576
description: Mayor Beame warned members of the City Council in a briefing on his 197576 expense budget yesterday that there isn't a doubt in my mind that there is going to be a need for new taxes.

title: Stanley Young Is Dead at 69; Playwright, Poet Headed ANTA
description: Stanley Young, poet, playwright, publisher and literary reviewer, died Saturday of cancer at the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: PRICES PLUMMET ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped sharply in steppedup trading yesterday in reaction to the breakdown of Secretary of State Kissinger's effort for a Middle East settlement and to the crisis in Southeast Asia.

title: Lisbon Official Sees His Nation On Independent Socialist Path
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Capt. Joo Tomaz Rosa, a leading member of Portugal's ruling Armed Forces Movement, said today that his country would travel a socialist path, but would never become Communist or a dependency of the Soviet Union.

title: Ali, Wepner and Referee AgreeA Dirty Fight
description: Ali Wins in Round 15

title: Jersey's Zoning Laws Are Upset
description: TRENTON, March 24The New Jersey Supreme Court today struck down local zoning Ordinances that exclude poor persons or families with low or moderate incomes, ruling that every community in the state must share the housing needs of its surrounding region.

title: Books of The Times
description: Perhaps the finest book ever to be written about a city, Rome and a Villa is an implicit comparison between the farthest flaunting of the human spirit and the way we live now. A piling on of imperial and divine metaphors, Rome became the ultimate museum and garbage dump of the grand. It was a poem pressed into service as a city.

title: Conferees Reported Reaching Consensus on Some Aspects of Final Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The joint SenateHouse conference committee closed its doors to the press and the public today and began work in secret on the final version of the multibilliondollar tax bill.

title: Parc Vendome Utility Bill A Hint of Builders' Woes
description: An aide to the builderowner of the Parc Vendome started talks yesterday with Consolidated Edison officials after the utility threatened to cut off heat because of an overdue bill of $59,489 for the apartment complex on West 57th Street just east of Ninth Avenue.

title: Mideast Ties to S.D.R. Could Raise Oil Prices
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 24 The decision by the Persian Gulf oilexporting countries to free their currencies from fixed parities based on the United States dollar is seen here as a cushion against domestic inflation and could be a step toward higher oil prices.

title: Depression Is a Reality To Chicanos
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. Anyone with grass outside his adobe home in South Valley, near this city, is affluent by Chicano standards. It means he can afford to use water on his little plot of land.

title: Mr. Vorster's Detente
description: CAPE TOWNOne thing is obvious in South Africa's complex and changing political scene: Prime Minister John Vorster relishes his new role as a builder of dtente with black Africa.

title: Knicks' Mystique Keeps Fans Hoping on Playoff
description: The mystique the Knicks have created in eight seasons is difficult to overcome. They are struggling for the Eastern Conference wildcard playoff berth with 12 days and seven games left in the regular National Basketball Association season, but both the fans and players like the team's chances of making it.

title: In Astoria, the Greek Community Dances to Its Very Own Drummer
description: The children watched the belly dancer writhe and wriggle while their parents clapped in time to the languid rhythms of bouzouka, drums and electric organ.

title: Mixed Audience for Foreman in S. Africa
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 (Reuters)George Foreman said today he had received assurances from South Africa that a mixed audience of blacks and whites would see one of the four exhibition fights he gives in that racially segregated country next month. The other three bouts of the former heavyweight boxing champion are to be held in black neighborhoods before black audiences. Foreman is due to arrive in South Africa next Sunday.

title: Quarry Halted by Norton in 5th Here
description: Jerry Quarry didn't see his last fight. Squinting through bleeding eyes, unable to look at the man who was pounding him, he staggered helplessly last night as Ken Norton was awarded a fifthround knockout at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pro Basketball Scoring
description: Pro Basketball Scoring

title: Court Closes Book On a Lost Fortune
description: Chance M. Vought Jr., who squandered a fortune left to him by his father and lived in poverty for years, sold his right to a $900,000 trust for only $54,000 and died destitute.

title: Attica Prosecution Hammers at Recollections of Former Inmate on Beating
description: BUFFALO, March 24Under cross examination by the prosecution at the Attica murder trial here, the recollections of a former inmate changed on the witness stand today from hardedged and clear to murky and vague.

title: Trade Negotiators Turn to Agriculture
description: GENEVA, March 24  The world trade talks turned today to the sensitive issue of how to expand the international flow of farm products.

title: HEARST CASE BRINGS SEARCH IN MONTREAL
description: MONTREAL, March 24 (Reuters)Acting on a telephone tip, the police burst into the home of a former Canadian Prime Minister's granddaugther over the weekend looking for Patricia Hearst.

title: Market Place
description: It's an old Wall Street story. If you have a sticky issue, you price it right and offer the salesmen a good commission to sell it.

title: Concert: Blood, Sweat
description: In 1969 and 1970, Blood, Sweat and Tears was one of the most popular popmusic acts in the country. Founded in late 1967 by Al Kooper and Steve Katz it was one of the earliest bands to combine rock with jazz (in this instance the mostly prerehearsed, static brass sonorities of the big bands).

title: 2 AMERICANS AID WITH FALSTAFF
description: It took some Italian and German plus some French. English and Polish, but Warsaw has now seen its first performance of Verdi's Falstaff with the help of two Americans. The production turned out to be one of the biggest successes the Polish capital's opera house has had.

title: Sparkman Appraises His Job as Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 John J. Sparkman is 75 years old and has spent the last 29 of those years in the United States Senate, 24 of them as a member of the Foreign Relations Committee. Now, in what may well be his last term, the Alabama Democrat has become chairman of the cornmittee.

title: Status of Brooklyn High Schools
Scranton Teachers Return Under Imposed Contract
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 24 (AP)  Teachers returned to their classrooms today, ending the longest school strike in the city's history.

title: Marcos Has Invited Rebels on Mindanao To Talkson April 17
description: MANILA, March 24President Ferdinand de Marcos has invited all Moslem rebel leaders to a conference on April 17 in Zamboanga City, key capital in Moslem Mindanao.

title: TV Plea Bargaining
description: Just a year ago on the CBS News program, Sixty Minutes, reporter Mike Wallace discussed the ratings war between the networks and asked the question, How far do you go to attract an audience? Last Sunday, following payment of a reported $25,000 to the subject of an interview, Mr. Wallace provided an unwitting answer: Pretty far.

title: But Wasn't It a Bleedin' Shame?
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, March 24Chuck Wepner, a brave and inoffensive liquor salesman who cannot box and cannot punch, lurched, stumbled and floundered in pursuit of the heavyweight champion of the world tonight for 15 rounds, lacking only 19 seconds. Slugged stupid at that point for the first time in a hard, hard life, he was dragged to his stool all limp and bleeding, a sorely used old gentleman yet still in possession of the title he had brought into the ringthe heavyweight championship of New Jersey. At that instant the winner and still champion, Muhammad Ali, pitched to the floor in a back halfgainer and lay there supine while witnesses assembled here in the cornfields rent their haberdashery in response to what seemed a double knockout. This was the first Ohio performance by the ring's most gifted Thespian, and the crowd had no way of knowing that this is the master's way of covering up against an onrush of adorers.

title: Father of 5 Is Slain At a Bronx Carnival As Hundreds Watch
description: A 29yearold taxicab mechanic, the father of five children, was shot and stabbed to death at a crowded street carnival in the South Bronx Sunday night by a halfdozen young thugs who escaped with his wallet and about $40, the police reported yesterday.

title: Women Lawyers: Still Not Welcome
description: STANFORD, Calif., March 24At Yale Law School in the nineteenforties one professor held an annual ladies' day at which he'd call on all the women in his classthe only day all year he'd call on any of them. At Harvard Law, there were no women at all; on Wall Street the few women to be found were mostly tucked away in trusts and estates departments; in the courts, a woman lawyer was an oddity, her presence cause for snickering and staring.

title: DRUGS AID FIGHT ON LYMPH CANCER
description: SAN DIEGO, March 24 A Pennsylvania physician reported here today the development of a drug therapy that can significantly improve the survival chances of children suffering from cancers of the lymph system that ordinarily kill 70 to 85 per cent of their victims within five years.

title: People in Sports
description: Although Bill Russell, the former Boston Celtic star and now coach of the Seattle SuperSonics, has said he would prefer not to be inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame, he will be put in anyway. Bernard H. McMahon, president of the hall, said yesterday that the trustees have voted by a wide margin to give Russell recognition by installing a stained glass portrait of the athlete and leave it at that. They will omit him from the enshrinement ceremony April 28, at which time Robert Vandiver, former Indiana star, Joseph Brennan, former professional player, and Emil Liston, founder of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, will be inducted.

title: 297MILLION CUT IS SET IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 24A bipartisan agreement to cut $297million from Governor Carey's budget proposal today paved the way for passage tomorrow of a $10.4billion budget for the fiscal year starting April 1.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Soar at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Treasury bill yields soared on the regular weekly sale of 91day and 180day maturities yesterday.

title: DUTCHESS JAIL ASSAILED ANEW
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 24The deaths of two inmates in the Dutchess County Jail in a space of 18 hours last week has reopened a longstanding controversy over the antiquated institution and its hardline administrator, County Sheriff Lawrence M. Quinlan.

title: Confusion Over Cambodian Aid
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 24Unlike some of the credibility problems of the United States in Indochina in the past, the problem now is not a matter of differing interpretations of official statements but rather a case of contradictions and inconsistencies in the Americans' public stance here and in Washington. Here are some examples:

title: Canarsie Man, 70, Found Suffocated In a Friend's Room
description: An elderly man was found slain yesterday in the ransacked Brooklyn apartment he shared with a neighbor who had begun caring for him a few months ago when he became ill.

title: Da Nang Is Reported Cut Off
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 25Two more provincial capitals on South Viet Nam's central coast hal,e fallen to rapidly moving Communist forces, effectively cutting off the city of Da Nang by land on all sides.

title: Russian, Trip Barred, Fears Blindness
description: MOSCOW, March 24Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, said today that his wife expects to go blind within months but that Soviet authorities have refused to let her travel to Italy for critical eye treatment.

title: In Memoriam
description: BIKALESWalter, belovingly remembered. Nita and Family.

title: Preminger's 'Rosebud' Comes to Screen
description: Talent and Nerve continue to wrestle for Otto Preminger's soul. When Talent wins, Mr. Preminger makes good, tough commercial films"Such Good Friends," "The Man With the Golden Arm," and "Anatomy of a Murder." When Nerve triumphs he may come up with "Skidoo" or something like his latest, "Rosebud," a suspense melodrama of such ineptitude, lethargy and loose ends that only someone with his arm being twisted would take credit for it.Though there is some action in the film, and a lot of moving around, "Rosebud" consists principally of exposition, spoken by people with accents so thick that only Mr. Preminger might understand them, about a group of Arab terrorists who have kidnapped five rich girls and hold them for a ransom I'm not sure is ever defined.The exposition takes place in Paris, the south of France, Corsica and Israel, but which scenes are set where is one of the film's lesser mysteries. The people we hear most often are a tattered Central Intelligence Agency man (Peter O'Toole ), who masquerades as a Newsweek correspondent: a renegade Englishman (Richard Attenborough) who has turned Muslim and is planning his own holy war against Israel and Communist-leaning Arabs, and a nice, clean-cut Israeli intelligence officer (Cliff Gorman).Some of the other speakers include actors of the stature of Claude Dauphin, Peter Lawford and Raf Vallone, and one former Mayor, John V. Lindsay, whose discomfiture seems no greater or lesser than that of his colleagues.Mr. Lindsay plays a United States Senator, the father of one of the hijacked girls, a man whose manner of looking worried is to look elegant. Mr. Lindsay thus is reduced to displaying haberdashery, which, as those of us know who've seen him sing and dance in local Inner Circle shows, is a waste of one of the city's natural resources.The screenplay was written by Eric Lee Preminger, the director's son, with additional dialogue by Marjorie Kellogg, the author of "Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon." Their consistently idiotic work includes the following bit of dialogue about Rosebud, which is the name of the yacht on which the kidnapped girls disappear: "Rosebud," says someone, "that's a strange name for a yacht. What's it mean?" "I'm not sure," is the reply, "I think it has something to do with a movie."This "Rosebud," which opened yesterday at the Plaza and Paramount Theaters, is pure camp.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Scott Paper to Lift Outlays
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (UPI)The Scott Paper Company said today its domestic capital outlays this year, including environmental control projects at its mills, would exceed $200million, up from $147million last year. The largest expendtures for production expansion will be for the 262,000tonayear Sommerset pulp mill near Skopwhegan, Me.

title: Fort Lee Witness Accused Of Shielding His Relatives
description: NEWARK, March 24Defense lawyers in the Fort Lee bribery trial here today wound up their crossexamination of the chief prosecution witness, Arthur J. Sutton, with accusations that he had testified for the Government to protect his sister and brotherinlaw from indictment and that he had masked $270,000 in bribe money as a consulting fee.

title: Conductor Stabs Himself As Baton Breaks in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, March 24 (UPI)The Uruguayan conductor Jos Serebrier inadvertently stabbed himself through the hand with his baton yesterday when he became overpassionate while leading 180 members of a brass  percussion ensemble and chorus through a special Easter musical festival.

title: ARMY WILE TRAIN WOMEN ON RIFLES
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Army has decided that all women soldiers donning their new uniform after June 30 must become qualified with the M16 rifle.

title: Lobster Lobby Cavorts In Bid for 200Mile Limit
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Congress was lobbied today by a lobster.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24(UPI)The House Commerce Committee approved by voice vote and sent to the floor today a $1.18billion measure to fund Amtrak, the national rail passenger corporation, through Oct. 1, 1977.

title: Colonels Victors Over Stars, 9984
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 24 (UPI)  The Kentucky Colonels defeated the Utah Stars, 9984, tonight to keep alive their hopes of catching up with the New York Nets in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division.

title: More Aid Only Means More War
description: Refugees are streaming down the road from Hue to Da Nang, and an offensive directly against Saigon may be next. So the situation in South Vietnam may appear superficially as desperate as that of Cambodia, where the Lon Nol Government obviously is in its final days. But the plight of South Vietnam is fundamentally different; collapse is not yet at hand. Nor is American involvement the same in the, two countries.

title: Norton Stops Quarry
description: Ken Norton stopped Jerry Quarry in the fifth round last night at Madison Square Garden in a heavyweight bout that served as the closedcircuit TV preliminary to the Muhammad AliChuck Wepner title match in Richfield, Ohio. Details, Page 39.

Sutton, with accusations that he had testified for the Government to protect his sister and brotherinlaw from indictment and that he had masked $270,000 in bribe money as a consulting fee.

title: ... Indifferent Uncle
description: The message that the Ford Administration regards the crisis of the cities as over stands in strange contrast to the realities of mayors staring at growing puddles of red ink on their ledgers and of new recruits added weekly to the ranks of the unemployed.

title: FORD CALLBACKS OF WORKERS SET
description: DETROIT, March 24 The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would recall 1,125 workers, now on in definite layoff, before the end of this month and 5.150 more over the next two months.

title: Jesuit Scans Origin of Hitler Killings
description: ROME, March 24A Roman Catholic theologian may have helped to foster the Nazi massmurder ethics that led from forced euthanasia to the mass killing of Jews in Hitler's extermination camps, according to a Jesuit historian.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Quake Hits San Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, March 24 (Reuters)  An earthquake shook this capital for about 20 seconds early today, hut there were no reports of damage or casualties.

title: World Skate Mark Set
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (AP) Yuri Kondakov of the Soviet Union shaved nearly ninetenths of a second off Ard Schenk's 5.000meter world speedskating record at the Soviet championships Monday, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. Tass reported Kondakov was clocked in 7 minutes 8.92 seconds.

title: New Powers Urged for fob Rights Agency
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, without permanent chairman since John H. Powell Jr. resigned last week, has problems that are even more profound than its need for leadership, according to various sources here.

title: Admiral at a Hideout With Russian Daughter
description: ORANGE PARK, Fla., March 24 (UPI)The son of Adm. Jackson R. Tate, retired, said today that his father and the Russian daughter he never had seen before this week were getting to know each other in a secret hideout and were very happy.

title: REYNOLDS METALS TO TRIM OUTPUT
description: The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday cutbacks at various aluminum potLines that will drop its operations to twothirds of its annual rated domestic capacity of 975,000 tons. The cutbacks affect facilities with annual capacity of 124,000 tons.

title: Move for More Aid for U.D.C. Due Today
description: ALBANY, March 24 The Legislature is expected to take up tomorrow a bipartisan request for $20million more in state assistance for the Urban Development Corporationanother part of the attempt to piece together a plan with the banking community to revive the housing agency.

title: Rangers, Islanders Still Scrambling
description: Each member of the Philadelphia Flyers earned an extra $4,500 over the weekend as the 1974 Stanley Cup champions clinched the title in the Clarence Campbell Conference with a 40 victory over Minnesota. The Flyers are the top team in their division with an unbeatable 17point lead over the New York Rangers. But the competition remains heated in the Patrick Division, the only one in which playoff berths are still up for grabs. Scrambling for the final two spots are the secondplace Rangers, the thirdplace Islanders and the fourthplace Atlanta Flames. With six games remaining on the schedule for both New York teams, the Rangers would have to earn 7 points and the Islanders 9 to keep Atlanta in fourth place if the Flames win their remaining seven games. Victories are worth 2 points in the standings; ties are worth 1 point.

title: Monsignor to Leave Post
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., March 24 (AP)Msgr. Thomas F. Devine will step down as president of Our Lady of the Elms College to take a parish assignment Monsignor Devine said his new post and the date of transfer were indefinite. He has headed the Roman Catholic college for women since 1965.

title: Funds for Pension Unit Classic Case of Trading
description: ALBANY, March 24  The politically controversial Pension Study Commission was restored to the state budget today, but its chairman, Otto Kinzel, who fought hard to keep his job, is to be dropped.

title: Kashiwa Wins Pro Ski Race
description: BEAR VALLEY, Calif., March 24 (UPI)Hank Kashiwa of Steamboat, Colo., bolstered his No. 1 position on the pro skiing tour today by winning a giant slalom. Kashiwa earned $4,000 for defeating Henri Duvillard of France in the final of the parallelcourse meet.

title: Bridge:
description: HONOLULU, March 24A Mexican expert and four Californians won the Vanderbilt Cup here in the early hours of this morning to conclude the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Championships.

description: BUFFALO (UPI)The little man in the white hat is a familiar figure at Buffalo Sabre hockey games. He' s always in the same seat in the corner, studying and observing.

description: Certain of the minimum weights needed to qualify in New York State's recently inaugurated record fish recognition program leave at least one longtime angler feeling strangely inadequate.

title: Stottlemyre: No Progress
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 24Mel Stottlemyre made his first trip of 1975 with the Yankees today. He has to wonder, though, if there will be any more.

title: Luzinski's Hitting Helps Phils Vanquish Mets, 97
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 24 (UPI)Greg Luzinski homered, singled, walked and tripled to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 97 exhibitiongame victory today over the New York Mets.

title: SIMON MINIMIZES DOLLAR'S DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told Congress today that the dollar's overall international value had declined very little in the last two years of floating currency exchange rates and that he firmly opposed Government intervention in the markets to peg the dollar at a particuar rate or zone.

title: Blue Shield Files Request For a 37% Rate Increase
description: TRENTON, March 24Blue Shield of New Jersey filed a request with the State Department of Insurance today for an average increase of about 37 per cent in its medicalsurgical insurance premium rates.

title: Fine Fibers Called Lung Disease Risk
description: A study of the relationship between fiberglass and human cancer has found that those workers exposed to ultrafine fiber particles may be in greater danger of getting respiratory cancer than their fellow workers who are exposed to only the larger fibers.

title: Stocks Show Sharpest Loss in 4 Months
Large Crowd of Refugees Is Converging on Da Nang
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 25Refugees have been converging on Da Nang, South Vietnam's second. largest city, and enormous crowds fill the streets.

title: GetNEPA Movement
description: A batch of bills have been introduced in the House of Representatives which have the nominal air of putting people to work and the concealed promise of wrecking the National Environmental Policy Act. One, entitled the Emergency Public Works Acceleration Act of 1975, would allow the head of a Federal agency to reduce eliminate at his discretion any procedural requirement for such projects in his jurisdiction as highways, sewage treatment plants, airports or those dams and channels so dear to the heart of the Army Corps of Engineers. Foremost among those hampering procedural requirements is the environmental impact statement.

title: OPEC'S REVENUES MAY DROP IN '75
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reports in the latest issue of its World Financial Markets that revenues of the nations which are members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are likely, to fall to about $96billion in 1975 from an estimated $105billion in 1974.

title: CLARK, SCHULDMANN A FINE MUSICAL DUO
description: Not many young instrumentalists with the solo capabilities of Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann are willing to sublimate their virtuoso instincts in favor of a chamber music career. This cellistandpianist, husbandandwife team is a duo in every sense of the word, however, with artistic rapport and expressive unity at the core of the pair's sonata performances.

title: FORD ORDERS WIDE REVIEW OF U.S. POLICY ON MIDEAST; ISRAELIS FEAR A CUT IN AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Ford ordered today a total reexamination of United States policy toward the Middle East following the collapse of Secretary of State Kissinger's efforts to attain a new agreement between Egypt and Israel.

title: Counsel in NursingHome Inquiry
description: S. (for Seth) Andrew Schaffer yesterday made his public debut as chief counsel to the Moreland Commission set up to investigate nursing homes, and did so in an aggressive, if not pugnacious, manner. The 33yearold former assistant United States attorney sliced through the bland assertion of one witness that nursinghome care should be turned over to nonprofit institutions with sharp questions about whether that would cost more or less. It might cost more, the nonplussed witness conceded.

title: U.S. Hockey Team Loses
description: OREBRO, Sweden, March 24 (AP)The Swedish Olympic hockey team defeated the United States national team, 74, tonight in a rough exhibition game. Ron Wilson, Herb Boxer, Tom Ross and Richie Smith scored for the Americans.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne vetoed a bill designed to guarantee the civil rights of the state's mentally ill patients, stating that there are simply no funds to meet the fiscal demands of this bill. He put the cost to the state at $7.8million the first year and $19.3million the second.

title: Labor Relations in Europe
description: PARIS, March 24While the facade of Western Europe grows increasingly uniform, the economic health and, perhaps more important, the psychological health of its components are persistently diverse, What makes for such diversity?

title: Two Salvage Capers
description: Nobody has explained how the Government came up with the $350 million it cost to salvage half of an obsolete Russian submarine from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, and responsible people who understand our Government may dismiss the question as silly.

title: Two Top Police Officials And 16 in Orange Indicted
description: NEWARK, March 24The two top police officers in Orange, eight other members of the city's police force and eight other men were indicted today by an Essex County grand jury on charges of corruption.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)The Department of Transportation approved today a $7.3million grant for the bankrupt ErieLackawanna Railroad to meet the line's cash needs through June 30.

title: TALLY BROWN MIXES SINGING WITH ACTING
description: If Tally Brown, who has been singing on Sunday evenings at Reno Sweeney, were not so intent on appearing grotesque, one might think of her in terms of that exquisite singer of the nineteenthirties and forties, Mildred Bailey. But Miss Brown's exaggerated black eye makeup, her wild eruption of black hair and particularly the bright red minisurplice in which she wraps her short, globular body are distractions that suggest that she is not sure if she is a singer or a visual gimmick.

title: State NursingHome Unit In Rift With City Owners
description: The president of the state association of nursing homes testified yesterday that its New York City leaders had told him to keep your nose out of our business when he asked them to police alleged abuses in nursing homes.

title: SOVIET HELD AHEAD IN AMERICAN SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)A former highranking Federal Bureau of Investigation agent said today that the Soviet KGB does more spying on Americans than do American intelligence agencies.

title: HIGHER COST SEEN FOR ELECTRICITY
description: Electric costs are rising so rapidly in this country that by the end of the seventies, rates may be the highest in the world. according to a survey of electric costs for industrial and large commercial users in Europe, North America, Australia and South Africa.

title: Some People Wore Just Their Tattoos
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y.Spider Webb celebrated his birthday the other day and some of the party guests took their clothes off. There was no snickering. The nudityif one can call an entirely tattooed body nudewas done for art's sake. Ac a party, it was almost Victorian in its sedateness: The guests drank white wine and discussed tattooing as an art form. The host wore a proper blue suit, complete with shirt and tie.

title: Joyce's Dubliners' Evokes Old Dublin

description: The longmissing service revolver of Police Officer Joseph A. Piagentini, who was shot to death in East Harlem in 1971, has been found buried five feet deep in the mud flats of a farm in Pocahontas, Miss.

title: Ulster Postal Official Slain In Possible Error by I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 24 (UPI)Gunmen suspected to be from the Irish Republican Army shot and killed a senior postal official today while he was investigating a burglary at a rural post office in southern Armagh.

title: TV: ABC Huckleberry Finn Marred by Coyness
description: Unlike Tom Sawyer, Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn resists coy treatments. On at least one key level, as Leslie Fiedler, the critic, has observed, the Huck story constitutes not merely an adult but a subversive novel. It is a matter of Huck versus sivilization. Huck, living on the margins of society, is the only independent person in the community of Hannibal, Mo.

title: World Bank in Egypt Loan
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)The World Bank announced today a $37million loan to Egypt to help further modernize and improve the country's railroads. The loan is for 25 years, including four years of grace, and carries an 8 per cent annual interest rate.

title: Experts Expect Lower Road Speed to Remain and Curb Toli
description: DETROIT, March 24  Some safety experts predict that the lower speeds brought about by last year's energy crisis will continue and keep down the death toll on the highways.

title: Kyoto's Silk In Thrives on Tradition
description: KYOTO, JapanThe silk weavers here, like almost everyone else in this ancient capital of Japan, thrive on tradition.

title: Saigon Opposition Unit Asks Thieu to Resign
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24 (AP)An opposition group today urged President Nguyen Van Thieu to resign because of the deteriorating military situation in the country.

title: $563Million Maritime Sill For Fiscal Year '75 Signed
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)President Ford signed into law today a $563million appropriation bill for certain maritime programs for the 1975 fiscal year. The measure also provides for the establishment of a maritime administration office in the Great Lakes region.

title: Financial Programs' Settlement Of 2.5Million Cleared by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Securities and Exchange Commission accepted today a settlement offer of Financial Programs, Inc., a Denverbased mutualfund manager, to pay $2.5million to four of its six constituent funds for losses resulting from unsound investment policies of the managing company in 196970.

title: SOYBEAN RISE CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Prices on the Chicago Board of Trade closed mixed yesterday after rising sharply in early trading.

title: FLIGHTS RESUMED INTO PHNOM PENH IN A U.S. GAMBLE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 25American officials, taking what they termed a calculated gamble. have ordered a resumption of the supply airlift into Phnom Penh's airport, the last remaining supply link between the Cambodian capital and the outside world, although the military situation around the airport appears to have deteriorated.

title: 60% in Poll Give Ford Low Performance Rate
description: Sixty per cent of the American people continue to give President Ford a low rating on the job he Is doing, the Harris survey reported yesterday, according to the Associated Press. The percentage is the same as January's.

title: Hazardous Case Recovered
description: BERLIN, N.H., March 24 (AP) A 100pound case containing potentially hazardous radioactive material was recovered today at a local junkyard, the police said. Radioactive Cesium 137, missing since last Thursday, was contained in a lead case that was jacketed with steel.

title: CHEMICAL BANK EXPANDS DATA
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, in the final prospectus covering the sale last Friday of $100million of convertible debentures, added two and a half pages on possible loan losses and real estate investment trust loans that were not included in the preliminary statement registered late in February.

title: Large Crowd of Refugees Is Converging on Da Nang
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 25Refugees have been converging on Da Nang, South Vietnam's second largest city, and enormous crowds fill the streets.

title: EASING IN MONEY ASKED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)The House of Representatives joined the Senate in urging the Federal Reserve Board to fight the recession by casing monetary policy, but did not set any specific money supply goals.

title: Jersey's Zoning Laws Are Upset
description: TRENTON, March 24The New Jersey Supreme Court today struck down local zoning ordinances that exclude poor persons or families with low or moderate incomes, ruling that every community in the state must share the housing needs of its surrounding region.

title: Ohio Editor Resigns Over Letting Paper Print an Obscenity
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 24Charles Alexander resigned today as editor and publisher of The Dayton Journal Herald after he had allowed the paper to print an obscenity, an action his employers said was indefensible.

title: Rate Increase Protested
description: BROWNSVILLE, Ore. March 24 (AP)About half of Brownsville's 1,000 residents participated in a voluntary blackout to protest a 13 per cent utility rate increase requested by the Pacific Power and Light Company.

title: E.C.A.C. Playoffs Hurt League Plan
description: Syracuse and Rutgers decided last week not to join a proposed new intercollegiate basketball league, a decision that must strengthen the Eastern College Athletic Conference playoff system that was started so successfully this season. Penn State and Pittsburgh, the institutions most interested, may be forced to new league for a while. It would be difficult to convince any Syracuse player or fan that the E.C.A.C. playoffs are anything but wonderful. Without them, the Orange would probably not have reached the National Colle giate Athletic Association tourney and, of course, not be on the way to the semifinals at San Diego this week. Syracuse will play Kentucky Saturday.

title: Chicago Jury Hears Policemen On Infiltration of Civic Groups
description: CHICAGO, March 24Undercover agents of the Chicago Police Department began testifying this afternoon before a Cook County grand jury investigating the infiltration by the agents of several Chicago civic groups most of which were led by blacks.

title: SUBMARINE HITS A FISHING VESSEL
description: A United States submarine, on a training mission off Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was involved in a minor collision last night with a fishing boat, the Navy reported.

title: MT. LAUREL HOMES CARRY HIGH PRICES
description: MOUNT LAUREL, March 24 (UPI)Like scores of communities in New Jersey, the township of Mount Laurel, 10 miles north of Camden and Philadelphia, is an attractive place to live if you can afford to buy a home here.

title: YONKERS CENTER FACES SCRAPPING
description: YONKERS, March 24  A proposed multimilliondollar civic center designed by the architect I. M. Pei as the center piece of a rejuvenated downtown Yonkers was all but scrapped today by Mayor Angelo Martinelli.

title: Allied Stores Lifts Profit 2.9% in Quarter; Other Companies Report Results

title: Superdome Date Set
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP)Contractors and architects told the Louisiana Superdome Commission today that the $163million arena would be ready by Aug. 1, eight days before the New Orleans Saints first home exhibition game.

title: Tiger Burning Bright
description: An Ivy League team winning the National Invitation Tournament at the Garden? Princeton? Name your odds. The conventional wisdom for years has been that the basketball race is to the tallest, the best that scholarships can buy, and to the individual stars who score the most without necessarily playing as a team. The Tigers were stuck with guards instead of forwards and had to reinvent something called defense.

title: Jersey Canoe Sweep
description: PHOENICIA, N.Y., March 24New Jersey competitors swept all five classes of the Whitewater Downriver championships of the American Canoe Association's Atlantic Division on the Esopus Creek yesterday. Robert Alexander of East Brunswick won the kayak oneman competition in 29 minutes 42 seconds and Mary Hesselgrave of Fort Lee won the woman's event in 34:12.

title: Emergency Tax Action
description: The continued faltering of the economy makes it essential that the Ford Administration and Congress agree upon a prompt and substantial tax cut. With eight million men and women out of work, corporations in almost every sector suffering a decline in new orders, and major industries such as automobiles and housing in a severe slump, the economy requires emergency action.

title: The Military options for Hanoi
description: After seven days of virtually uninterrupted success, North Vietnam, in the view of United States military analysts, will have to choose between expanding, the offensive in the next five weeks into the ultimate battle for Saigon or waiting until next year.

title: SeizedCigarette Auction Attracts Three Bidders
description: TRENTON, March 24New Jersey's first auction of freshly confiscated cigarettes drew only three of the state's 144 eligible and duly notified distributors, and only two of the three decided to bid.

title: 9 POLICEMEN HURT IN AMSTERDAM RIOT
description: AMSTERDAM, March 24 (Reuters)About 3.000 demonstrators marched through the center of Amsterdam tonight after battles with the police earlier today in which nine policemen were injured and 47 people arrested.

title: 100Billion Budget Deficit Projected by Ford's Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Ford Administration officials said today that the potential budget deficit for the fiscal year 1976 had reached the $100billion level and was still growing under the tax reduction and spending proposals pending before Congress.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24Ford Administration officials said today that the potential budget deficit for the fiscal year 1976 had reached the $100billion level and was still growing under the tax reduction and spending proposals pending before Congress.

title: Sollas Wins British Title
description: LONDON, March 25 (Reuters)Vernon Sollas won the vacant British featherweight boxing title when he knocked out the former champion, Jimmy Revie, in the fourth round tonight.

title: Saudi Arabia at a Glance
description: GeographyAn eastwardsloping plateau covering most of the Arabian Peninsula Saudi Arabia, with 830,000 square miles of territory, most of it desert, is almost the size of Texas and Alaska combined. It is bounded on the north by Jordan, Iraq, Kuwait and two neutral zones; on the east by the Persian Gulf, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Oman; on the south by Yemen and Southern Yemen, and on the west by the Red Sea.

title: P.U.C. Plans Forums On Utility Rate Rises
description: NEWARK, March 25 (UPI) The Board of Public Utility commissioners announced today that it would hold townmeetingstyle forums around the state on consumer issues and outstanding requests for utility rate increases.

title: Her Cooking? It's All Simply
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.A lengthy note from our friendly, farranging correspondend, Feinschmecker, that gentleman of impeccable taste and appetite, informed us that the finest German cooking he's found in any home on the East Coast was that of Christa Drechsler of New Canaan.

title: Troy Proposes New Revenue Sources to Cut Deficit
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., chairman of the Finance Committee, yesterday suggested to Mayor Beame a number of proposals for new revenue that Mr. Troy said could cut a projected deficit in the 19756 expense budget.

title: Nobody Laughs at Chuck Wepner Now
description: CLEVELAND, March 25In the racial consciousness that he invariably creates, Muhammad Ali was asked last week if he considered Chuck Wepner as representing white America in their heavyweight title bout. The champion rolled his eves.

title: Advertising
description: Peter F. Fleischmann, chairman and president of The New Yorker, called it an alarming figure.

title: $151MILLION BID FOR ARGUS CORP.
description: MONTREAL, March 25The Power Corporation, Ltd., one of Canada's largest holding companies, sought today to take over one of its principal rivals in a transaction that has political and financial ramifications throughout the country.

title: U. S. IS SADDENED
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Administration officials said today that they expected no immediate change in Saudi Arabia's proAmerican policies as a result of the assassination of King Faisal, but they said they believed that his death had removed a major force of political moderation in the Middle East.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Homosexual Rights Measure Introduced by 24 in House
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  Twentyfour United States Representatives introduced a bill today to ban discrimination based on a person's sexual preferences.

title: 12 More ExOfficials of Equity Funding Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UPI)Samuel B. Lowell, former executive vice president of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison for his role in what has been described as the biggest corporate fraud in United States history.

title: Day of Slaying Marked As Prophet's Birthday
description: Yesterday, the 12th of Rabi I, the third month of the lunar year in the Islamic calendar, marks the birth of Mohammed, Prophet and founder of Islam.

title: About Education
description: Two years ago, after a long struggle that involved the signing of an unusual waiver of tenure, Phyllis Rackin was granted tenure at the University of Pennsylvania and filed suit seeking retroactive promotion to associate professor, back pay and $100,000 in damages.

title: Blacks Say Drive to Spur College Enrollment Ends
description: CHICAGO, March 25A major commitment to increase the number of blacks on the nation's college campuses, made during the civil rights era of the nineteensixties, appears to have ended.

title: Big Board to Halt Assessing Members To Rescue 2 Firms
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that after collecting some $35million from stockbrokers, it would shortly suspend assessments against members to defray the cost of rescuing two ailing brokerage housesGoodbody & Co. and duPont, Glore Forgan & Co.

title: Gypsy Bret Takes Pacing Series Final
description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 25 Gypsy Bret scored a 1length triumph tonight, beating Right Tic before 16,010 fans in the $25.000 final of the Hopeful Pacing Series at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Loves Sign Pat Bostrom
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 25 (UPI)The Indiana Loves, new entry in World Team Tennis, signed Pat Bostrom of Seattle today. She ranks sixth in the country.

title: MESSAGE BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Administration officials said today that they expected no immediate change in Saudi Arabia's proAmerican policies as a result of the assassination of King Faisal, but they said they believed that his death had removed a major force of political moderation in the Middle East.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Islands in Stream Will Be a Movie

title: Cooper Union to Drop Three Programs
description: Faced with a mounting deficit and unwilling to impose tuition, Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art is discontinuing its degree programs in three areas for which it is highly regardedphysics. mathematics and a special science program.

title: Shortages Hamper Defenders in Delta
description: CAN THO, South Vietnam, March 25The South Vietnamese Army, preparing to counter a major Communist thrust in the Mekong Delta, is without fuel for helicopters and short of ammunition for artillery and other weapons, and even of hand grenades.

title: Britain Doubles Fees For Private Treatment
description: LONDON, March 25 (AP) The Government doubled its charges for private treatment within the staterun National Health Service today. It was the second big increase in a year.

title: Sugar: A Slight Decline
description: An 11cent decline in the price of a 5pound bag of sugar, one of nine drops in the price of the sweetening in the last 14 weeks, marked price changes in New York City's retail food markets last week.

title: Willowbrook Hospital Gets a New Director
description: The State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene has appointed Harold C. Piepenbrink, a mental health administrator in Illinois, to be director of Staten Island's Willowbrook Development Center for the mentally retarded, despite objections from the president of the Benevolent Society for Retarded Children, an organization of parents of Willowbrook patients.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Jersey Mapping Local Housing Goals
description: TRENTON, March 25The Byrne administration was reported tonight preparing legislation that would establish housing goals for individual communities in New Jersey.

title: Press to Hear Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller will address the annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New Orleans on April 9, aides said today.

title: DEFENSE FINISHES IN FORT LEE CASE
description: NEWARK, March 25The defense in the Fort Lee bribery trial ended its case in Federal Court here today without producing a witness. The prosecution, headed by United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein, finished its case earlier in the day. After the lunch recess, several defense lawyers introduced documents in evidence then, one by one, announced to the court that they I had completed their cases.

title: Ukrainian Supreme Court Rejects Physician's Appeal
description: MOSCOW, March 25 (Reuters)The Ukrainian Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by Dr. Mikhail Shtern, a physician, against an eightyear labor camp sentence imposed in December on charges of bribery and swindling, Jewish sources said.

title: Fire Island Burning Low
description: Fire Island National Seashore, a long sand reef off the southern shore of Long Island, was established by Congress in 1964 for the purpose of preserving unspoiled areas of great natural beauty close to a large urban center. The concept was excellent and the Seashore is still an enormous asset to the metropolitan area, but the National Park Service has allowed Fire Island's beauty and its integrity to be eroded to the degree that only Congressional action can save it. The required action has been proposed in bills introduced by Senator Javits in the Senate and by Representatives Pike, Downey and Ambro. Their companion bills deserve prompt hearings.

title: Slayer Sentenced to Death Under New Delaware Law
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 25 (UPI)The first person convicted of firstdegree murder since Delaware reinstated the death penalty was sentenced in Wilmington Superior Court today to death by hanging.

title: A World Depression?
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., March 24Will there be a world depression? The distinguished economists from several countries who met here this past week end at the fifth biannual Claremont international monetary conference, answered the question forthrightly: the world is already in a depression.

title: Kissinger's Latest Dilemma
description: The outlook in the diddle East now is fairly grim, but recriminations about who's to blame can only make it worse. Naturally but unfortunately, Israel is blaming Egypt for the collapse of the Kissinger peace mission, Egypt is blaming Israel, both are blaming Mr. Kissinger for not reconciling the irreconcilable, and Washington is pretending publicly to be evenhanded but in private is blaming Israel.

title: FIRE RAISES ISSUE OF SAFE REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Early last Saturday afternoon, an electrician for the Tennessee Valley Authority named Larry Hargett held a lighted candle near some insulation to find out whether air was leaking into an area under the control room of T.V.A.'s two giant nuclear reactors.

title: First Seder Is Tonight; Parking Rules Eased
description: Passover, the weeklong commemoration of the Israelites' emigration from Egypt, begins this evening with the traditional Seder feast of matzoh, or unleavened bread, bitter herbs and wine.

title: Auto Sales Drop by 28.7%
description: DETROIT, March 25  Sales of new cars for the March 1120 period declined 28.7 per cent from the same period last year, thereby indicating that the price rebate programs had stolen sales from the usual spring upturn.

title: Preparing Greatest Show on Earth Is a Show in Itself
description: It is only 5 o'clock Monday, but the afternoon has nearly given way to night. A cold drizzle glazes the rough brick paving, blurs the street lamps and gives a sinister glint to the broken beer bottles scattered around the railroad yard on 12th Avenue and 35th Street. A silver train, bright with red, white and blue side paintings, lumbers in and chugs to a halt.

title: Annual Armed Forces Day
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  President Ford today designated the third Saturday of each May as Armed Forces Day.

title: Attica Defense Rests as Inmate Says He Saw Hill Hit No One
description: BUFFALO, March 25 The defense in the Attica murder trial rested today after introducing its sixth and strongest witness, a former inmate whose testimony challenged nearly every aspect of the prosecution's case against John Hill, one of two defendants being tried here for the murder of Correction Officer William E. Quinn.

title: French Set to Meet Terms for Release Of Envoy to Somalia
description: PARIS, March 25 (Reuters)The French Government has agreed to meet all the demands of guerrillas who kidnapped the French Ambassador to Somalia on Sunday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said here today.

title: Assassin, as Colorado Student, Once Faced Charges Over LSD
description: BOULDER, Colo., March 25 (UPI)The nephew who was accused of assassinating King Faisal of Saudia Arabia was remembered today as a fairly good student at the University of Colorado who was once arrested on drug charges.

title: Bulls Beat Rockets; Celtics Defeat Cavs
