description: CHICAGO, March 25 (UPI) Bob Love scored 13 of his 29 points in the third period tonight to lead a Chicago surge that enabled the Bulls to defeat the Houston Rockets, 11294, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Canada Oil Reserves Down
description: CALGARY, Alberta, March 24 (Reuters)The Canadian Petroleum Association said today that proven crude oil reserves declined to 7.1 billion barrels in 1974, compared with 7.6 billion at the end of 1973. Gas reserves, for the first time including Mackenzie River delta figures, rose to an estimated 56.7 trillion cubic feet, up 3.7 trillion cubic feet.

title: The Opera
description: Galina Vishnevskaya's appearances at the Metropolitan Opera are like a cornet's, sudden, infrequent, capable of lighting up the sky. On Monday night, the Soviet soprano sang the title role of Tosca, and by the excitement and conviction of her performance gave the lie to the statement that the Puccini work is a shabby little shocker.

title: Peanuts Bridges a Language Gap and Captivates the French
description: PARIS, March 25Zut et grands dieux!  Rats and good grief!

title: High School Offers Project on Migration
description: Sixteenyearold Diane Murphy perched nervously on a low bookcase in the library of Park East High School and watched the images from her classmates' family albums flickering on the screen before her. It was a dry run of a slide  and  sound documentary that traces, through the lives of relatives and friends, the immigration or migration of four ethnic groups to New York.

title: Ridgewood Taking Down Obstacles to Wheel Chairs
description: RIDGEWOOD, March 25 (AP)The business district here has been made virtually free of obstacles for people in wheel chairs.

title: Rock Island's Request Heard
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  The I.C.C. heard oral arguments today on a request by the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific for permission to impose a $30percarload surcharge for GO days to keep the financially ailing line running.

title: Gas Agreement Is Set
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday at Los Angeles that it has reached an agreement granting the Pacific Lighting Gas Development Company the right to negotiate for the purchase of 60 per cent of the gas produced from Atlantic Richfield's natural gas reserve in the main Prudhoe Bay field on Alaska's North Slope.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS OF TAX BILL VETO
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The White House, seeking to influence the final shape of a multibilliondollar fax bill now before Congress, said today that President Ford might veto the bill if it were passed with some of the provisions being contemplated by a joint SenateHouse conference.

title: Mamie Eisenhower, 78, Hospitalized in Georgia
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., March 25 (AP)President Eisenhower's widow, Mamie, was hospitalized at the Fort Gordon Medical Center today with internal bleeding, a spokesman said. Her condition was described as stable.

title: FrenchAlgerian Oil Pact
description: ALGIERS, March 25 (Reuters)Compagnie Franaise de Petroles and the Algerian stateowned oil company, Sonatrach, said today they had renewed their association agreement covering exploitation of the Sahara oil deposits of HassiMessaoud. A joint communiqu said the two companies signed an agreement here extending their association for the years 197680.

title: Assembly Unit Approves Bill on Mentally Retarded
description: ALBANY, March 25A proposal to strip the Department, of Mental Hygiene of the care for the mentally retarded received key Assembly committee approval today, with informed lawmakers predicting passage and referral to Governor Carey.

title: A Time For Silent Diplomacy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  United States influence among the Arabs is up against immense pressures, as indicated by the assassination of the proAmerican King Faisal of Saudi Arabia. Willynilly the collapse of Secretary Kissinger's stepbystep negotiations has produced dramatic new strains. King Faisal and Egypt's President Anwar elSadat had been placing virtually all their hopes in an American basket and the bottom of that basket just fell out.

title: Taxi Fleets Here Request a 7.5% Increase in Fares
description: The city's taxi fleet Industry asked the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday for a new 7.5 per cent rate increase and permission to pass a portion of gasolineprice increases along to passengers.

title: Proposal Would Allow Students to Try Cases
description: Qualified second and thirdyear law students supervised by members of the bar, would be permitted to try civil and criminal cases in Federal Court in Brooklyn starting Sept. 1 under a rule adopted yesterday by the court's 11 judges, who also laid down requirements for certifying such students as qualified.

title: Mayor's Plan to Cut Borrowing Cited
description: The chairman of Citicorp, whose subsidiary, the First National City Bank, was criticized Sunday by Mayor Beame, yesterday praised the Mayor's plan to reduce the city's shortterm borrowing sharply.

title: City Charges ConRail System May Harm Its Freight Service
description: The Beame administration has formally protested that the new Federal plan to reorganize bankrupt Northeast railroads Onto a future ConRail system may damage the city's already inadequate railfreight service.

title: Card of Thanks
description: DeNAPOLIPeter. The family of Peter DeNapoli wishes to thank his many friends for their kind expressions of sympathy.

title: ... Closing Net
description: The rapid deterioration of the South Vietnamese position along a broad front, and particularly in the enclave around Da Nang, makes it increasingly questionable that President Thieu's military gamble of abandoning the highland provinces will accomplish its goal of establishing more viable lines of defense.

title: PoliceMurder Witness Testifies He Was Tortured Alter Arrest
description: A prosecution witness in the retrial of five reputed members of the Black Liberation Army testified yesterday that he was tortured by the New Orleans city police shortly after he was arrested there in August, 1973.

title: FOREIGNERS GIVEN PLEDGE OF SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The Provisional Revolutionary Government was reported today to have broadcast guarantees for the safety of foreigners, including Americans, in territory the Communists now control in South Vietnam.

title: Ali's Next Payday, Against Bugner, May Be Too Expensive for Garden
description: Muhammad Ali is not quite ready for the big one, a boxing promoter said yesterday following the mismatch in which Ali earned $1,5million for stopping Chuck Wepner.

title: Panel Votes No on Calling Rockefeller
description: ALBANY, March 25A state commission that is investigating nursing homes voted today not to call Vice President Rockefeller to testify on any political influence he or any of his subordinates might have exercised in the industry when he was Governor.

title: Conferees Agree to Give Every Taxpayer a Rebate
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A joint SenateHouse conference committee agreed today to give all taxpayers a rebate on their 1974 taxes of at least $100 or the total amount of tax they paid, if less than $100.

title: TOMMY HOLMES
description: Tommy Holmes, a baseball writer who covered the Brooklyn Dodgers for more than 30 years, died yesterday at the State University Hospital of Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old and lived at 39 Kenilworth Place.

title: Interstate Police Force Urged To Combat Cigarette Smuggling
description: The president of a group of tax and lawenforcement officials from 13 states and the District of Columbia urged yesterday the establishment of an interstate police force to combat the cigarette smuggling operations of organized crime.

title: Kingman Swats No. 8 as Mets Romp
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 25Dave Kingman continued his spring home run spree today by hitting his eighth in 15 games and fourth in the last three. The 400foot smash over the leftcenter field fence came with two men on base in the first inning and powered the Mets to an 80 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: PANIC IS BELIEVED TO DOMINATE FLOW
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 The hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese streaming from their homes to the rapidly shrinking Governmentcontrolled areas appear to be fleeing in panic rather than for political reasons.

title: New Worry for Israel
description: JERUSALEM, March 25A senior Israeli official put down his newspaper this morning after reading the accounts from Washington of United States plans to reassess its whole Middle East policy.

title: Texasgulf Expansion
description: Texasgulf, Inc., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, Texasgulf Canada, Ltd., planned to proceed with construction of its Kidd Creek copper smelter, refinery and mine and mill expansion projects. The smelter and refinery are expected to be completed in 1978 at a cost of more than $200million. It will have a capacity of about 130,000 tons of copper a year.

title: Panel Urges Suspension Of WorkRelief Project
description: A task force appointed by Governor Carey has recommended the repeal of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's 1971 program requiring employable welfare recipients to pick up their checks every two weeks at state employment offices and to take available jobs or training.

title: Fears of a Coup Shrivel Most of Dollar Advance
description: PARIS, March 25The assassination of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia sent stocks and the dollar lower in the first nervous reaction on Europe's financial markets, while the price of gold rose. The dollar, which had been a dvancing before the Saudi news, managed to end the day slightly higher than yesterday. Most European securities markets closed lower.

title: Faisal, Rich and Powerful, Led Saudis Into 20th Century and to Arab Forefront
description: From his beginnings as the third son of an obscure raiderchieftain in the desert of central Arabia, Faisal ibn Abdel Aziz Al Saud rose to be one of the most powerful and richest men in the world.

title: Monticello Plans Richest State Race
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 25A harness, race that Leon Greenberg the president of the Monti??ello Raceway, predicted would be worth the attractive gross figure of $200,000 when he announced the project last summer, now looms an event that may be worth as much as $300,000. And if so, and there is no reason to believe to the contrary, it will be the richest horse race  harness or thoroughbredever run in the state.

title: WORLD FOOD BOARD ENDS ROME SESSION
description: ROME, March 25 (Reuters)The governing body of the World Food Program today ended a sevenday session that approved $129million in food aid and received additional pledges from donor countries to surpass its $440million target in 197576.

title: Talented Pitchers Angels' Top Asset
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 25  When Dick Williams took over as manager of the California Angels last July, with Bill Singer already injured and the team already in last place, the club made a whole hearted commitment to a youth movement and accepted the fact that would stay last in 1974.

title: Douglas Firm About Staying on Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court said today that the idea of resigning from the high court after his stroke had never entered my mind and that he knew of no circumstances that could induce him to step down now.

title: CONCORDE SERVICE TO START EARLY '76
description: LONDON, March 25 (Reuters) Britain and France formally agreed today to put the supersonic Concorde airliner into passenger service at the beginning of 1976.

title: HUE LOST, DA NANG MAY GO; U.S. ORDERS AN AID REVIEW AND BIG REFUGEE AIRLIFT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 26  The northern city of Hue, the cultural heart of South Vietnam, was abandoned by the Saigon Government's forces yesterday.

title: NEW HEARINGS SET ON GAS CUTBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The Federal Power Commission opened a new round of hearings today into natural gas curtailments by the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, including large cutbacks to New York and Pennsylvania utilities.

title: Fleischmann Offering New Acadien Whisky
description: All of you who remember fondly Longfellow's Evangeline  A Tale of Acadie' will be delighted to learn that Fleischmann Distilling is bringing out Acadien Frenchly Canadian Whisky. Made in Nova Scotia, it is being introduced appropriately in Louisiana.

title: NIXON CALLS DEATH AN IMMENSE LOSS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 25 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon characterized the death of King Faisal as an immense loss to this country, to the world and to the cause of ArabAmerican friendship.

title: Notes on People
description: Alexander P. Butterfield, who electrified the 1973 Senate Watergate committee hearings by disclosing the existence of the White House tapes, resigned yesterday as chief of the Federal Aviation Administration. President Ford accepted the resignation, effective March 31. with sincere regret.

title: Israel Is Excluded From Tariff Favor In Listing by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Although there was no connection with the breakdown of Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East peace mission, President Ford excluded Israel yesterday, at least temporarily, from proposed new United States tariff benefits to be extended to nearly all lessdeyeioped countries.

title: TRANSIT STRIKE ENDS FOR PHILADELPHIANS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (UPI)  The city's striking transit workers approved today a twoyear contract, ending an 11day walkout that halted bus, trolley and subway service for 400.000 commuters.

title: ETHEL CHASINS
description: Ethel Chasins, a pianist and teacher, died yesterday at her home here. She was 75 years old and lived at 173 West 78th Street.

title: Elizabeth Morgan Ely Is Married
description: Elizabeth Morgan Ely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Griswold Ely of Riverside, Conn., was married there at their home yesterday noon to Bruce Edward Zuckerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Zuckerman of Beverly Hills, Calif. Justice of the Peace Robert Mowbray performed the ceremony.

title: FORD BUDGET CUTS REJECTED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The House passed two compromise bills today that rejected most of the $21billion in budget rescissions that had been requested by President Ford.

title: STEIN URGES BAN ON HEALTH GROUP
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein called yesterday for the suspension of the Comprehensive Health Planning Council of Western New York and the resignation of two officers. He charged conflict of interest.

title: Instability in Mideast Oil States
description: PARISA sense of doom hangs over the developed worlda product of the guilt, boredom and satiety that have been the general lot of the West since 1945. Long before the outbreak of the ArabIsraeli war in October, 1973, and the subsequent Arab oil embargo there was no lack of vague forecasts of universal disaster.

title: Play's the Thing for Princeton Kids
description: Children performing an extemporaneous play as others watched during a recent workshop of the Creative Theater Unlimited. Housed in Princeton's Trinity Church on Mercer Street, the program is celebrating its sixth year of unconventional classes for people of all ages, from kindergarteners to adults. Aim of workshops is to stimulate creative flow of ideas among participants.

title: Ford Sending Army Chief To Vietnam for a Report
description: WASHINGTON March 25President Ford today directed Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, to fly to Saigon tomorrow to assess the military situation and recommend whether any further American assistance is needed by South Vietnam.

title: Lincoln Center to Gut Fisher Hall and Start Afresh
description: In an allout effort to correct the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, the auditorium will be gutted next year and a completely new installation built under the supervision of the acoustician Dr. Cyril M. Harris and the architect Philip Johnson.

title: Italian President Praises Faisal, His Recent Host
description: ROME, March 25President Giovanni Leone, the last Western head of state to visit Saudi Arabia before King Faisal's death, expressed his sorrow today about the tragic passing

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Almost every major department store and many specialty stores now sell all manner of telephonesBonnie and Clyde phones, antique phones and so onand telephoneanswering devices. Potential customers often want to know if there are legal restrictions on such installations and if any charges must be paid to the New York Telephone Company.

title: Top Hockey Scorers
More Women Are Answering Uncle Sam's Call
description: Rebecca Steck, who is barely 19 years old, is about to have a sixthgrade dream come true. Antoinette Loschi, 17, says it's what she's wanted to do since she was 13. And Wanda Gray, who has just turned 21, decided while in high school, and again during two years of college, that it was what she really wanted.

title: Electric Car Bill Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  Five Congressmen introduced today a bill for a $120million program to persuade Americans to do much of their driving in electric cars. The legislation would authorize $40million in each of the next three years for the Government to buy 10,000 electric cars and test and promote them throughout the nation.

title: Sap Is Running Well; It's Maple Syrup Time
description: GRAHAMSVILLE, N.Y.When the price of sugar escalated, Donna Denman wasn't particularly disturbed. She uses homemade maple syrup for her pies, cakes, custards and canning and from now until early next month she'll be busysometimes for 72 hours at a stretchboiling off and bottling a year's supply.

title: Elephant Boy, 65, Remembers 50 Years With Circus
description: For most of the year, Ray Moreau, wearing a flameproof suit and goggles, stands over vats of sodium at the Du Pont plant in Niagara Falls. But yesterday, when the circus opened at Madison Square Garden, Ray Moreau was Sabu the Elephant Boy. It is a role he has been playing for the last 50 years.

title: Plan by Kuwait to Develop Carolina Island Denounced
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., March 25  Conservationists and Charleston's Jewish community made a final attempt last night to stop or restrict the development of Kiawah Island, a primitive 10mile barrier strip purchased last year by the Sheikdom of Kuwait for $17.4million.

title: OIL MEN WARNED OF SPILL HAZARDS
description: I SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 The chairman of the Federal Council on Environmental Quality, Dr. Russell W. Peterson, cautioned the oil industry today against potentially disastrous complacency about unknown hazards of oil spills.

title: Pittsburgh Fire Kills 6
description: PITTSBURGH, March 25 (UPI) Seven persons, including five children and a woman eight months pregnant, were killed today when a threealarm fire raced in Knoxville district. The victims were identified as Mrs. Marlene Wood, 23, who was eight months pregnant; her children, Raymond, 4, and Marlena, 3; Mrs. Wood's younger brother, Doyle White Jr., 20; John Bailey, 11; and his younger brothers, Ralph, 7; and Robert, 10.

title: TaxRebate Table
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The following table shows rebates that would he paid to typical taxpayers, by income levels and according to dependent status, as agreed to today by a Congressional conference committee:

title: Stars Pin 11297 Loss On Pacers
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 25 (AP)The Utah Stars held the Indiana Pacers to 12 points in the second period and, behind Ron Boone's 28 points, went on to chalk up a 11297 American Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: Federated Sets Profit Record, Alone Among Big Retail Chains
description: Federated Department Stores, Inc., which operates Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus stores here, reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the quarter and fiscal year ended Feb. 1the oniy major merchandising chain to do so.

title: Two Oil Concerns Seeking Share in Petrofina Project
description: MONTREAL, March 25 (Reuters)Petrofina Canada, Ltd., said today Pacific Petroleums, Ltd., and Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, Ltd., were jointly seeking permission to acquire Candel Oil, Ltd.'s 6.9 per cent interest in the Athabasca oil project headed by Petrofina.

title: Iowa Crash Kills 3 in Family
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Marcb 25 (AP)A Massachusetts family of three died yesterday when its car and trailer went through a guard rail on a bridge on I80 here and plunged into the Des Moines River. The police identified the victims as Michael P. McMackin, 28 years old, his wife, Cathy E., 26, and their son, Michael, 2, all of South Lancaster, Mass.

title: After a Bitter Debate, M.P. Throws Money
description: LONDON, March 25 (UPI) Sharp words were not the only things flying in the House of Commons last night. After a particularly bitter debate an Opposition lawmaker threw a coin that accidentally hit the eye of a Government official.

title: Conferees Agree to Give Every Taxpayer a Rebate
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A joint SenateHouse conference committee agreed today to give all taxpayers a rebate on their 1974 taxes of at least $100 or the total amount of tax they paid, if less than $100.

title: Ford Appoints 3 Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  President Ford announced today the appointment of three special assistants for legislative affairs who will be handling liaison with the House. They are Douglas P. Bennett, 33 years old, Dr. Robert K. Wolthuis, 39, and Charles Leppert, 42.

title: News Summary and Index
description: King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was assassinated in Riyadh by a nephew who had a history of mental illness. His brother, Crown Prince Khalid, will succeed him on the throne. Another brother, Prince Fand, was named Crown Prince and is expected to be the real political power in the country. The assassination appeared to be an individual act, with no change in the military and security support for the monarchy. [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: MARK BLACKTON
description: Mark Blackton, president and founder of Blackton Fifth Avenue Stores here, in Florida and in Puerto Rico, died Sunday during a visit to Puerto Rico. He was 78 years old and lived at 353 West 56th Street.

title: NEW HEARST REPORT IS DENIED BY F.B.I.
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation office in San Francisco, heading the search for Patricia Hearst, said today that there was no basis for a Chicago Tribune report that fingerprints of the fugitive heiress and two other persons had been found in a motel in upstate New York.

title: HOUSTON BANK SHUT; LARGE LOSSES CITED
description: HOUSTON, March 25 (UPI) State and Federal bank examiners, who said they found subof the Franklin Bank here, closed it yesterday and appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver.

title: FOX AWARD GIVEN TO N.Y.U. STUDENT
description: There were days, splicing filmstrips in the editing Iabs at N.Y.U. that Drew Denbaurn dreamed he'd be discovered by a bigtime movie producer. Now, he has been.

title: Italian Prices Accelerate
description: ROME, March 25 (Reuters)Prices in Italy rose 1.5 per cent during February and 23.3 per cent over the 12 months up to the end of the month, the Central Statistics Institute said today. The general consumer price index (base 1970) was 165.5 in February, the institute said.

title: People in Sports
description: The United States Olympic Committee confirmed yesterday that Dean Smith of the University of North Carolina had been approved as coach of the 1976 Olympic basketball team. Smith, 43 years old and considered one of the game's foremost innovators, has led the Tar Heels to a postseason national tournament in each of the last nine years. This season his team, ranked ninth in the country, won the Atlantic Coast Conference title, but was ousted from the National Collegiate tournament by Syracuse last Thursday.

title: MOTIVE UNKNOWN
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia. March 25King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was assassinated here today.

title: 1,500 Forced From Homes By Rising Illinois River
description: ROCKORD, Ill., March 25 (UPI)High levels on the Rock and Pecatonica Rivers have forced more than 1,500 persons from their homes, the authorities reported today.

title: Railroads Granted 7% Rise on Freight
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Interstate Commerce Commission, reversing a stand taken less than two months ago, granted today a 7 per cent increase in freight rates to most of the nation's railroads.

title: THOUGHTFUL MUSIC BY RIBEIRO, VIOLINIST
description: When Gerardo Ribeiro made his New York debut in 1971, as a winner of the Concert Artists Guild Award, his playing was described as having more passion than finesse. Apparently the young Portuguese violinist has spent the intervening years well, because the fires are banked now, and it was a polished thoughtful artist who appeared at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night.

title: OilTrading Deal Set by Cuba, Mexico, Soviet and Venezuela
description: MEXICO CITY, March 25 (AP)Mexico, Cuba, the Soviet Union and Venezuela wall officially join forces in a triangular trading company for selling crude oil and petroleum products to countries without an oilproducing capacity.

title: P.B.A. Voids Accord With City; Rookies Again Facing Layoffs
3 HELD IN SLAYING AT BRONX CARNIVAL
description: Three youths were arrested last night in connection with the murder last Sunday of a 32yearold taxi driver, the father of five children, who was shot and stabbed to death at a street carnival in the South Bronx.

title: Music:
description: Charles Ives, never timid in his musical fantasizing, left at his death some sketches for a Universe Symphony, whose performance features he thought might include from 6 to 10 different orchestras placed on separate mountaintops, each moving in its own independent time orbit, and only meeting one another when their time cycles eclipsed.

title: Portugal Gets a New and More LeftWing Cabinet
description: LISBON, March 25  The fourth and most leftleaning Government of the 11month old Portuguese revolution was formed here today after centrist forces largely lost their battle to halt what they fear is movement to a militaryled Communist state.

title: Joint Operation Pleases Alaska Papers
description: ANCHORAGEIn 1966, Lawrence Fanning, a former Chicago newspaper editor and executive, journeyed here with his wife, Kay, in search of a newspaper to buy and develop into a firstrate experimental newsgathering organization.

title: SOVIET CLUE SPURS U.S. CANCER STUDY
description: The discovery of a Russian report linking chloroprene to cancer, plus the knowledge that the chemical, used to make synthetic rubber, is related to vinyl chloride, a known cancercausing agent, has prompted E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. to undertake a health study of the thousands of its employes who have ever worked with the substance.

title: Legislature Prepares to Approve a State Budget of $10.4Billion
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, March 26The legislature prepared early today to pass a $10.4billion state budget that entails no new state taxes for the time being but leaves the door open for a large tax increase later in the legislative session.

title: Delta Fighting Next in Vietnam
description: North Vietnam has reportedly extended its offensive into the Mekong delta, compounding the military problems faced by the Saigon high command.

title: Orantes Ousts Ashe, 62, 63; Borg Wins
description: MONTE CARLO, March 25 (AP)Arthur Ashe was toppled today by Manuel Orantes of Spain, 62, 63, in the second round of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis event.

title: Dow Ends Day Up 4.46 After Sharp Early Drop
description: The stock market managed to reverse an early sharp setback yesterday caused by the assassination of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and finished slightly higher in heavier trading.

title: Pilots Obtain Writ Barring Shipments Of Perilous Cargo
description: The Air Line Pilots Association yesterday obtained a court order temporarily barring airlines from carrying hazardous cargo, such as the two shipments of highly toxic plutonium nitrate that, according to Representative Fred Richmond of Brooklyn, were driven through the city's streets to Kennedy International Airport last fall.

title: 9 Newspaper Unions Agree On Unity in Bargaining
description: George E. McDonald, president of Mailers Union No. 6, said that the nine newspaper unions with contracts expiring Sunday night had agreed to support each other in connection with a common expiration date for new contracts, the economics of settlements and in opposing any retrogressions in current negotions.

title: Lincoln Center to Gut Fisher Hall and Start Afresh
description: In an allout effort to correct the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, the auditorium will he gutted next year and a completely new installation built under the supervision of the acoustician Dr. Cyril M. Harris and the architect. Philip Johnson.

title: In Memoriam
description: BIKALESWalter, lovingly remembered. Nita and Family

title: City and Utility Plan To Burn Garbage To Generate Power
description: Mayor Beanie and the Con solidated Edison Company announced yesterday the details of a ninemonth study to develop a system that would turn. at least part of the 33,000 tons garbage collected here each day into fuel.

title: Article 1  No Title
Preparing Greatest Show on Earth Is a Show in Itself
description: It is only 5 o'clock Monday, but the afternoon has nearly given way to night. A cold drizzle glazes the rough brick paving, blurs the street lamps and gives a sinister glint to the broken beer bottles scattered around the railroad yard on 12th Avenue and 35th Street. A silver train, bright with red, white and blue side paintings, lumbers in and chugs to a halt.

title: DEFENSE FINISHES IN FORT LEE CASE
description: NEWARK March 25 They defense in the Fort Lee bribery trial ended its case in Federal Court here today without producing a witness. The prosecution, headed by United States Attorney Jonathan L. Gold stein, finished its case earlier iin the day. After the lunch recess, several defense lawyers introduced documents in evidence then, one by one, announced to the court that they had completed their cases.

title: Air Strike End Foreseen
description: MIAMI, March 25 (AP)A strike that has shut down Texas International Airlines since Dec. 5 moved closer to being resolved today after agreement was reached on hacktowork arrangements for 1,200 ground workers. Yesterday's agreement on details such as vacations and scheduling is subject to the approval of Airline Employes Association members.

title: City in Cockpit of Turmoil
description: To Westerners and to the Vietnamese who lived there. Da Nang has long had a reputation as an unlovely city, politically discontented, socially frayed and physically overburdened by the demands of colonial conquest, commercial exploitation and finally by modern mechanized warfare.

title: MIRIAM PYLE
description: Miriam LeMon Pyle, who had been the organist and the choir director at the Arlington Street Presbyterian Church and the utheran Church of the Reformation, both in Brooklyn. died of pneumonia Sunday in Tucson, Ariz. She was 62 years Old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Municipal officials in Orange said they would not suspend two top police officials and eight other members of the police force who were indicted by an Essex County grind jury Monday on 82 counts of corruption. The charges included extortion, perjury, obstruction of justice and protecting gambling operations of crime figures.

title: City Proclaims Today in Honor Of Tennis Stars of Tomorrow
description: Today is Easter Bowl Day by city proclamation and from 9 A.M. to the end of the week the best junior players in the country will be on display at Tennis 59, the claycourt indoor center at York Avenue and 60th Street. The annual Easter Bowl championships have been a springboard for Jimmy Connors, Vitas Gerulaitis, Sandy Mayer, Harold Solomon, Brian Gottfried, Billy Martin, Dick Stockton and other American and foreign stars

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Several hundred unemployed construction workers broke through barricades and battled the police outside Roosevelt Hospital, where they were picketing in what a hospital spokesman described as a jurisdictional dispute with another union.

title: KURD ASKS U.N. AID, FEARS IRAQI ATTACK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25A representative of the Kurdistan Democratic party appealed for help to the United Nations today, charging the Iraqi Army planned a fullscale war against the Kurdish people within a few days.

title: BOSTON SCHOOL PLAN STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: BOSTON, March 25 (AP)A new plan to integrate Boston schools next fall was criticized today by lawyers for parents, teachers and government groups as vague and based on questionable statistics.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Are Mixed
description: Recovering some of their early losses, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed mixed yesterday in desultory but slightly steppedup trading.

title: Greeks Celebrate First PostJunta Independence Day
description: ATHENS, March 25For the first time in eight years, Greece celebrated her independence day today free from the shackles of military rule.

title: E. I. du Pont de Nemours Sets Sale of Antifreeze Business
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating for the sale of its antifreeze business to PPG Industries for an undisclosed sum of cash. Du Pont is the secondlargest seller of antifreeze, which it distributes under the Zerex trademark. The largest distributor is the Union Carbide Corporation, which markets its antifreeze under the Prestone trademark.

title: Bird AirThe Mysterious Airlift to Cambodia and How It Grew
description: Periodically a teletype machine in the Oakland offices of Bird & Sons, Inc., springs to life with a signal from the riverside construction compound outside Bangkok that is serving as office headquarters for the emergency American airlift to Cambodia.

title: SAUDI MONARCH BACKED POLICIES
description: CAIRO, March 25The assassination of King Faisal, so soon after the breakdown of Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East peace endeavors. is a personal shock to President Anwar el  Sadat, Arab and Western diplomats here said today.

title: Wallwork Gives Back $1,000 of Senate Pay
description: TRENTON, March 25State Senator James H. Wallwork made a dramatic appeal today for economy in state government by returningto the state $1,000 of his annual $10,000 legislative salary, and suggested that his colleagues do the same.

title: FOX AWARD GIVEN TO N.Y.U. STUDENT
description: There were days, splicing filmstrips in the editing labs at N.Y.U. that Drew Denbaum dreamed he'd be discovered by a bigtime movie producer. New, he has been.

title: Reassessment . . .
description: The assassin's bullet, the Mideast compromise that never came together and, half a world away, the army advancing over land contested for a generationthe international order in all its frailty confronts a stern and challenging time of testing.

title: N.B.A. Alters Schedule For the 197576 Season
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) The National Basketball Association adopted a revised schedule today for the 197576 season under the current 82game format.

title: Books of The Times
description: The headlines focus on nursinghome scandals in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. In California similar headlines tell about the licenses to steal obtained by organizers of socalled prepaid groups to provide medical care to the poor. But neither the headlines nor the news stories accompanying them can explain adequately how swindling aged paupers and the indigent sick has become the last decade's quick road to riches. For the explanation, the concerned citizen needs to read this book, a landmark contribution to the literature, helping us understand how Lyndon B. Johnson's dream of ending poverty has contributed so much to today's nightmares.

title: 9 Hurt, 47 Held After Riot Over Amsterdam Subway
description: AMSTERDAM, March 25 (Reuters)The police dispersed 1,500 young demonstrators late last night after fierce clashes in which nine policemen were injured and 47 people arrested.

title: U.S. Court House On Foley Sq. Cited As City Landmark
description: The United States Court House on Foley Square, an imposing neoclassical skyscraper erected 40 years ago as the final work of the architect Cass Gilbert, was designated a New York City landmark yesterday.

title: Indonesian Government To Back Ailing Pertamina
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25 (Reuters)Mining Minister Mohammad Sadli said today the Indonesian Government had taken over all financial problems of the Pertamina Oil Company, which controls the country's oil industry.

title: No PointShaving Found at Jacksonville
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 25 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found nothing to support a report of pointshaving in Jacksonville University basketball games during the 197374 season, United States Attorney John Briggs said today. Briggs added that the investigation, begun last May but brought to public attention two weeks ago, was closed. Dr. Robert Spiro, J. U. president, said, I hope this restores the good name of Jacksonville University. If I had known of anything of any substance, I would have reported it to the F.B.I. in the first place. We make every effort to run a clean program at J. U. The F.B.I. said they reviewed the situation extensively and I'm sure they did. The last thing we want is for any player to do something he shouldn't do.

title: People and Business
description: It is still too early to reach a definitive determination, on the basis of proxy statements, of who was the highestpaid corporate executive last year in the ranks of publicly owned companies. Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, who has headed the list in previous years, received $788,610 in salary and bonuses last year, according to the company's latest proxy statement.

title: BEAME DEDICATES YORKVILLE COOP
description: A new cooperative housing development in Yorkville emerged yesterday as an example of how Federal and city housing laws can make it difficult to rent or sell housing built with Government aid.

title: Antoinette K. Gordon Dies at 83; World Authority on Art of Tibet
description: Antoinette K. Gordon, an associate in the Department of Anthropology of the American Museum of Natural History and an authority on Tibetan religion and art, died Monday at her home, 1 Fifth Avenue She was 83 years old.

title: Islanders Play 33 Tie; Trail Rangers by Point
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 25Dave Fortier didn't even get into the game until the final period, but the Islanders' benchwarming defenseman was his team's saviour tonight. He scored his sixth goal of the season with 65 seconds remaining to give the Islanders a 33 tie with the Montreal Canadiens at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Ehrlichman Is Disbarred
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., March 25 (UPI)  The Washington State Supreme Court announced today the disbarment of John D. Ehrlichman, former aide to President Nixon, because of his, involvement in the Watergate scandal. The court's action was the result of an agreement under which Mr. Ehrlichman must wait at least three years before applying for reinstatement as an attorney. He was suspended from the practice of law on Aug. 9 following one of two Federal court convictions.

title: State Unemployment Rate Reaches 10.9%
description: TRENTON, March 25New Jersey's rate of unemployment reached nearly 11 per cent in February, with more than 380,000 members of the state's work force idle, the State Department of Labor and Industry reported today.

title: Du Pont Acid Price Rise
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., said yesterday it would raise its price for hydrofluoric acid by 11 cents a pound effective next Tuesday.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 100 School Aides Voted Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP)The Board of Education voted yesterday to dismiss almost 100 school employes in a dispute over the state's refusal to release about $12million in Federal funds earmarked for a program that serves 1,250 lowincome students with deficiences in reading and math.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor

title: Bridge:
description: The Vanderbilt Cup victory of Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City in Honolulu Sunday was a longdelayed and welldeserved reward for determination and effort, He gives as much time as he can spare from his duties as president of the Syntex Corporation to his favorite game, and has led strong teams in the Vanderbilt and the Spingold teams for many years. He has had several near misses, and finally succeeded.

title: Shortages Hamper Defenders in Delta
description: CAN THO, South Vietnam, March 25The South Vietnamese Army, preparing to counter a major Communist thrust in the Mekong Delta, is without fuel for helicopters and short of ammunition for artillery and other weapons, and even of hand grenades.

title: OSCAR RASBACH
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 25 (AP)Oscar Rasbach, a founding member of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died at his home yesterday at the age of 86.

title: OTB Office Robbed
description: A man wearing a ski mask hid himself in a office of the Offtrack Betting Corporation at 1612 East 16th Street, Brooklyn, and after it closed at 8 o'clock last night he forced the manager, Bernard Bikanowski, to open the safe at gunpoint. The robber fled with $13,000 after cutting the telephone wires.

title: FED ACTS TO HALT DEBT RATE RISES
description: The Federal Reserve plunged heavily into the credit market yesterday to buy huge amounts of direct and indirect Government obligations for its own account. In addition, the Fed negotiated repurchase agreements to pump cash into the money market over the end of the statement week for banks, which is today. Both moves were taken with the aim of halting the deterioration of prices of both Federal and corporate debt securities, particularly those maturities beyond 1980.

title: Ford Sending Army Chief To Vietnam for a Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 25President Ford today directed Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the Army Chief of Staff, to fly to Saigon tomorrow to assess the military situation and recommend whether any further American assistance is needed by South Vietnam.

title: Miss Wade Makes Some Tough Points
description: Virginia Wade's tennis style is aggressive and definitive. So are some of her volleys on the current state of the professional game, from the dangers of an overcrowded calendar to the crucial test awaiting World Team Tennis.

title: 2 Held in Pajama Theft
description: NEWARK, March 25 (UPI)Two men were indicted today on charges of conspiracy and hijacking 48 cartons of Chinese pajamas at Port Elizabeth, last year. The men, Salvatore Dicristina, 41 years old, of Lakewood, and Michael Dionico Munoz, 40, of Iselin, were charged with intercepting the cargo on Nov. 27, 1974.

title: Construction Workers Fight Police Outside Hospital
description: Several hundred unemployed construction workers broke through barricades and battled the police yesterday morning outside Roosevelt Hospital, where they were picketing in what a hospital spokesman described, as a jurisdictional dispute with another union.

title: Kissinger Fears Mideast Faces a July Flash Point
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Secretary of State Kissinger said today that, as a result of the breakdown in IsraeliEgyptian talks, President Anwar elSadat said he would agree to extend the United Nations peacekeeping force for only a few months instead of the usual six months' renewal.

title: U. S. Court Upholds Conviction of Parr, Louisiana Politician
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 25 (UPI)A Federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of George Parr, the Duke of Duval, who was sentenced to five years in prison for evading income taxes.

title: POLICE INVESTIGATE BLIND BOY'S DEATH
description: An 18yearold blind youth died Monday at Willowbrook Development Center for the Mentally Retarded, and it was later discovered that he was killed by an infection caused by a table knife lodged in his rectum.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  Interest rataes climbed for the first time in 14 auctions of home mortgage commitments, the Federal National Mortgage Association said today. Fannie Mae said the average interest rate was 8.84 per cent for Governmentbacked mortgages and 8.997 per cent for conventional. The agency auctioned $357.2million of fourmonth commitments.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BALKAN BONANZA The 75 young Rumanians who form the Ciprian Porumbescu Conservatory Choir and the Crown of the Carpathians Folk Dance Ensemble will make a public farewell to the Unites States today in a free concert at 12:30 P.M. at the Dag Hammarskjold Auditorium of the United Nations Building. Since March 4, the performers have been touring the country as the largest group of cultural exchange visitors to arrive here from their homeland. Their sponsors are Friendship Ambassadors, a nonprofit organization in New York that also sent a large delegation of young American musicians to Rumania last year.

title: TrickorTreat Critics Upset on 2d Thought
description: BOSTON, March 25 (AP)The Massachusetts House has decided that it is not opposed to Halloween after all.

title: Union Bank in Zurich Sues Control Data for Damages
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, March 25 (AP)The Union Bank of Switzerland said today it had filed suit against the Control Data Corporation of the United States in connection with the termination of a contract order for an integrated dataprocessing system.

title: Law Is Planned to Suggest Programs For Housing to Communities in State
description: TRENTON, March 25The Byrne adminisration was reported, tonight preparing legislation that would establish housing goals for individual communities in New Jersey.

title: WINE TALK
description: In all the recent furor over the problems of Bordeaux, little has been said or written about what is going on Burgundy. The fact is that the wine scene in France's other famous wine district is none too happy, either.

title: Miscues Downfall Of Yanks
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 25 The New York Yankees played before another sellout crowd today as they continued to intrigue Southern audiences with the notion that the old ogres might be rising again.

title: KISSINGER'S AURA DIMMER IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, March 25  The prestige of Secretary of State Kissinger is suffering some severe blows in the press in major European capitals, although officials are taking a calmer view in the hope that a Middle East settlement can still be salvaged.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DISCARD INSISTS ON ATOMIC ARMS
description: PARIS, March 25President Valry Giscard d'Estaing said today in a television speech that France must be able to guard her security with an independent military force equipped with nuclear arms.

title: Spinola Reported to Believe Coup Attempt Bared Reds' Tactics
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 Portugal's former President, Antonio de Spinola, has reportedly told friends here that the military uprising that failed in Lisbon on March 11 had the positive result of unmasking Communists tactics.

title: Schumann Cycles Sung by Warfield In an Anniversary
description: There was a moving simplicity about the program that William Warfield chose to celebrate the 25th anniversary of his New York concert debut on Monday night at Carnegie Hall: two song sycies by Schumann, the Liederkreis (Op. 39) and Dichterliebe, introduced by a pair of Purcell songs. The Schumann cycles are so comptementary in their romantic evocation of mood and manner that one wonders why they are not sung together more often.

title: NO POLICY SWITCH SEEN IN SAUDI OIL
description: The assassination of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia sent shock waves through Wall Street and the oil industry yesterday. But the initial apprehenision turned to relative confidence as many experts interpreted the smooth transfer of power to Crown Prince Khalid as an indication of stability for Saudi Arabia, the oilproducing states and the world economy.

title: SAUDI OUTLOOK CALLED A RIDDLE
description: WASHINGTON, March 25United States officials and unofficial students of Arab affairs said today that the death of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia would bring about no abrupt changes in nil prices or production and no sudden weakening of the 13nation oil cartel.

title: In Mekong Delta, a Fear, But People Don't Show It
description: CAN THO, South Vietnam, March 25The Americans in this Mekong delta capital are quietly shipping home their stereo sets, porcelain and art objects. The other morning, a South Vietnamese woman failed to show up at work in the local American commissary.

title: A LAIDOFF BOSS GETS JOBLESS PAY
description: TRENTON. March 25Gerald G. Spinello, a Kearny businessman, told the Appellate Division of the State Superior Court here today that he should not have to repay unemployment payments he received from the state when he laid himself off from his own business during the winter of 197273.

title: Justices Curb Challenges In CourtsMartial Cases
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Supreme Court further reduced the jurisdiction of the Federal courts today by limiting their authority to hear challenges to the constitutionality of military courtsmartial.

title: MOTIVE UNKNOWN
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 25King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was assassinated here today.

title: POLICE UNION ENDS ACCORD WITH CITY ON 5 PAYLESS DAYS
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that, because the city was seeking a change in work schedules that could cost the police officers an additional 18 days, the officers had withdrawn their agreement to work five free tours of duty in the next 15 months to save the jobs of 481 rookies.

title: Italy Plans to Lay Up Big Ocean Liners
description: ROME, March 25Fifteen ocean liners, representing most of Italy's government  subsidized passenger fleet, will cease service and be sold over the next two years, the Minister of the Merchant Marine told Parliament today.

title: ETHIOPIANS MARK MOSLEM HOLIDAY
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 25To the sounds of handclapping, ancient chants and the beating of animalskin drums, Ethiopian Moslems today began celebrations of the 1,435th anniversary of the birth of the Prophet Mohammed. It was the first time that the day was observed here as an official holiday.

title: 6 PLACED ON TRIAL IN FOILED ESCAPE
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., March 25After a threeyear delay, six men went on trial today, accused of participating in a San Quentin escape attempt in August, 1971, that resulted in six deaths.

title: MURIEL HUTCHISON, ACTRESS, 60, IS DEAD
description: Muriel Hutchison, a stage actress of the nineteenthirties and forties, died of cancer Monday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 414 Central Park West.

title: ...Oil Instability...
description: King Faisal was of world importance because the land he ruled lies over an ocean of oil so vast that Saudi Arabia was and is the largest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the cartel which has held a gun over the world economy for a year and a half.

title: Anderson Says Soviet Knew Submarine Story
description: Jack Anderson, the columnist, said yesterday that he had printed the story of the attempt by the Central Intelligence Agency to raise a Soviet submarine from the bottom of the Pacific because what was at stake was not national security but international etiquette, according to United Press International.

title: Radiologists Report CancerFight Gain
description: SAN DIEGO, March 25A means of destroying tumors by causing miniature atomic explosions within the cancer cells without much harm to normal tissue was described by two radiologists here today to the American Cancer Society's seminar for science writers.

title: Holdup Suspect Is Killed
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (UPI)One holdup suspect was shot and killed and another suspect and a policeman were wounded last night in a shootout in a north Philadelphia bar. The man killed was James Williams, 23 years old.

title: COMMISSION SEEKS VOTELAW CHANGES
description: TRENTON, March 24 (UPI) A complete overhaul of the election laws that strips several county and state officials of their powers was recommended today by a state commission. Former State Senator William E. Schluter of Pennington, a member of the Election Law Revision Commission, said if the reforms were enacted into law they would break the control that political bosses had over the voting process.

title: 10 PLAGUES DUMPED AT A PAN AM OFFICE
description: A militant Zionist youth group dumped plagues of blood, live frogs, live locusts, and live mice in the Pan American World Airways ticket office in the Pan Am Building yesterday in protest against Syrian treatment of Jews.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONT STE. ANNE, Quebec, March 25 (AP)Tim Caldwell of Putney, Vt., gave the United States its only gold medal of the North American crosscountry ski championships today, winning the 50kilometer (about 31 miles) event.

title: Sithole Drops Case Before Rhodesian Tribunal
description: SALISBURY Rhodesia, (AP) The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole withdrew his case today from a special tribunal studying his detention and said he preferred to return to prison.

title: Stamp Honors Hero
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25 (AP)The United States Postal Service issued a commemorative stamp today honoring Salem Poor, a black militiaman who was cited for bravery during the Battle of Bunker Hill. The stamp was one of a set citing four unheralded Revolutionary War heroesPoor, Sybil Ludington, Peter Francisco and Haym Solomon.

title: WILSON SETS MAY 1 FOR ULSTER VOTING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 25 (Reuters)Prime Minister Harold Wilson today set May 1 as the date for new elections in Northern Ireland and appealed to rival Protestants and Roman Catholics to settle their differences peacefully.

title: P.B.A. FlipFlop
description: In reneging on its commitmentmade by overwhelming membership voteto have unionized police officers work five extra tours of duty without pay, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has done more than condemn nearly 500 rookie cops to dismissal. It has dimmed hope that New York's pampered civil service unions had finally become aware of the desperateness of the city's financial plight.

title: 250 at Columbia Score A Contract With Iran
description: About 250 students from Columbia University and other metropolitan schools demonstrated on the campus to protest the university's ties with the Shah of Iran.

title: Road at Notch Is Barred
description: CONCORD, N. H., March 25 (AP)Federal District Court Judge Hugh Bownes granted a permanent injunction today against construction of a section of Interstate 93 north of Franconia Notch until a new environmental impact study was completed. Judge Bownes said the study for the sixmile stretch between Littleton and Waterford, Vt., must include the possible impact on Franconia Notch.

title: Rebels Keep Pressure on Phnom Penh Airport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, March 26Communist led insurgents continued their pressure northwest of the capital's airport yesterday, using the apparent momentum of their push Monday night that, according to reports, took them through the town of Tuol Leap.

title: Inimitable Marceau, Master of Mime
description: Over the years20 in the United States aloneMarcel Marceau has become recognized as a brand of theater, a conjuror or stage miracles, a miniature dramatist of profound silence. Last night at the City Center 55th Street, he returned to New York for a threeweek visit. The splendor of this white clown remains totally undimmedas fastidious in his artistry and as daring in his imagination as ever.

title: RABBI KLAPPHOLZ
description: Rabbi Kurt Klappholz of Congregation Tifereth, Brooklyn, died Thursday at Maimonides Medical Center after a lingering illness. His age was 61. His home was at 1495 Dahill Road, Brooklyn.

title: Seoul Reports Its Planes Drove Off Jets From North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 25 (UPI)  South Korean jet aircraft drove off 30 North Korean fighter planes that threatened South Korean airspace off the western coast today, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Rockefeller Is Less Sanguine for Year
description: David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that he expected strong earnings for the quarter ending this month. But, he added, given current trends in banking, earnings for the year will probably not continue at the high level of the first quarter.

title: Federal Officials Fear Dispute Over Strike Forces May Harm Fight on Organized Crime
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The entire Federal attack on organized crime could be crippled by a growing controversy over methods used by strike forces and by squabbling between the Internal Revenue Service and the Department of Justice, senior officials of both agencies privately report.

title: Market Place
description: The conventional wisdom on Wall Street until recently was that the stock market was the only game in town. The investor neither bought bonds nor put his money into savings accounts; he bought stocks so that that old devil, inflation, would not eat him up. And he got ahead, or so the theory went.

title: Mine Safety Head, Opposed by Union, Is Resigning Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Interior Department said today that James M. Day, a 44yearold former campaign aide of Richard M. Nixon and Barry Goldwater, has resigned effective July 1 as the chief Federal mine safety enforcement official.

title: Fighting Saints $2.68Million in Red
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., March 25 (AP)The Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association lost $1.26million during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1974, according to the club's annual report made public today. Coupled with a loss of $1.42million in fiscal 1973, the Saints have an accumulated deficit of $2.68million for their first two seasons.

title: POLICE UNION ENDS ACCORD WITH CITY ON 5 PAYLESS DAYS
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that, because the city was seeking a change in work schedules that could cost the police officers an additional 18 days, the officers had withdrawn their agreement to work five free tours of duty in the next 15 months to save the jobs of 481 rookies.

title: Brothers Who Share Saudi Power
description: Neither power nor publicity ever attracted the quiet, squarevisaged Crown Prince who was once described by a foreign diplomat as probably the nicest man in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. But yesterday, Khalid ibn Abdel Aziz Al Saud ceased to be even the reluctant Crown Prince he was, and instead fell heir to the Kingwith all its attendant publicitywhen an assassin's bullet ended the life of his older brother King Faisal.

title: NET PLUNGES 47.7% AT SEARS, ROEBUCK
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the world's largest retailer, reported yesterday that it had suffered its first profit declined in a decade in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 and its second consecutive quarterly decline in earnings.

title: Threat to Laotian Neutrality Seen if Lon Nol Is Defeated
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 25 (UPI)The rightwing Defense Minister, Prince Sisouk Na Champassak, said today the fall of neighboring Cambodia would seriously affect neutral Laos.

title: Brazil Bus Plunge Kills 26
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 (Reuters) Twentysix passengers on a suburban bus were feared to have died when the vehicle plunged into a muddy river and sank out of sight near here today. According to radio reports, only six of the 32 passengers were saved.

title: Star Roles Elude Actor's 2 Horses
description: For a few pulseraising calls, Hollywood's hottest actor had the hottest horses in yesterday's fourth and sixth races at Aqueduct.

title: LATIN LEADERS URGE U.S. TO YIELD CANAL
description: PANAMA, March 25The Presidents of Colombia, Costa Rica and Venezuela ended a meeting here today by calling on the United States to hand over the Panama Canal next year as a 200th birthday gesture.

title: Moslem World Feels Shock And Loss Over King's Death
description: The Moslem world reacted with shock yesterday to the news of the assassination of Ring Faisal of Saudi Arabia.

title: About New York
description: There are two enduring myths about cab drivers in New York. The first is that a cab driver is a lout, and the second is that he is a philosopher. The one about being a lout was spread by people from Cleveland and places like that after they had a bad time coming in from La Guardia, and the one about being a philosopher was spread by Hollywood and Dorothy Kilgallen. This myth was worse than the one about being a lout.

title: Senate C.I.A. Investigation to Look for Hughes Links to Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The investigation by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence into the attempt by the Central Intelligence Agency to salvage a Soviet submarine will lead the committee into the relationships between Howard R. Hughes and the Watergate case, former Watergate investigators say privately.

title: Pentagon Cost Overruns $8.5Billion for 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The Pentagon said today that in three months cost overruns have added $8.5billion to the cost of its 40 main weapons programs, raising the overall cost to almost $150billion.

title: Israeli Troops Are Placed On Alert Along Borders
description: TEL AVIV, March 25 (UPI)Israeli troops went on the alert on the Lebanese and Jordanian borders today against possible Arab guerrilla strikes during the Jewish holiday of Passover as well as possible violence in the aftermath of the assassination of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia.

title: Sweet and Syrupy
description: MAPLE SYRUP CAKE

title: A RETURN TO SINGING FOR SANDY STEWART
description: Corky Hale, who emerges occasionally from the worlds of commercial jingles and studio recordings to play piano, harp and flute or to sing in night spots, has placed herself in a supporting role in her appearance at Soerabaja, Lexington Avenue at 74th Street. She is serving as accompanist and backup voice for Sandy Stewart, who was a rising young singer a dozen years ago when she introduced My Coloring Book on the Perry Como television show and subsequently had a hit record with the song. Following a long period of retirement, she has returned to singing after the death of her husband, Moose Charlap, the composer.

title: Atlanta Tornado Damages
description: ATLANTA, March 25 (UPI)Civil Defense officials said today a preliminary survey had indicated that damage from tornado that slashed the northwest side of Atlanta would range from $20million to $30million and possibly higher. The twister touched down eight times yesterday, causing three deaths and leaving at least 170 persons injured, most with minor wounds. It left an eightmile path of destruction from public housing to the Governor's mansion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 22yearold man was sentenced to a minimum of 12 years in prison for the Oct. 6, 1974, rape of a nun at the Christ the. King Roman Catholic Church complex at 1345 Grand Concourse in the Bronx. The rapist, Samuel Kelly of 1020 Trinity Avenue, is a previously convicted felon. He will have to serve half the 25year maximum sentence imposed by Justice Isadore Dollinger before becoming eligible for parole. . . . A former vice president of R. L. Whitney Securities, Inc., pleaded guilty to embezzling more than $500,000 from the company. The man, Harvey Fenichel of North Woodmere, L. I., faces up to seven years in prison when he is sentenced by Justice Gerald P. Culkin on June 4. . . . A Manhattan lawyer, Stanley Milstein, pleaded guilty in Federal Court to conspiring to defraud the Immigration and Naturalization Service by arranging sham marriages between American citizens and aliens seeking to remain this country. Mr. Milstein, who has agreed to resign from the bar, faces up to 15 years in prison and a total of $25,000 in fines when he is sentenced on June 24.

title: Legislators, Recess Near, Get Carey's Transit Bills
description: ALBANY, March 25  A package of transportation bills mingling state aid to save New York City's fare with an increase in state control over transit, including the submission of local authorities' budgets to Albanywas dropped onto legislators' desks by Governor Carey today as they hurried to recess for the holidays.

title: Networks to Broadcast Kissinger News Parley
description: The three major television networks  CBS, NBC and ABC  will cover live the news conference at 11 A.M. today of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Railroads Granted 7% Rise on Freight
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Interstate Commerce Commission, reversing a stand taken less than two months. ago, granted today a 7 per cent increase in freight rates to most of the nation's railroads.

title: Westchester Theater Opens Amid Songs and High Spirits
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 25The Westchester Premier Theater, a flossy popmusic hall opened to a packed house here last night with a show headlined by Diana Ross, the former lead singer of the Supremes.

title: Kissinger Fears Mideast Faces a July Flash Point
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Secretary of State Kissinger said today that, as a result of the breakdown in IsraeliEgyptian talks, President Anwar elSadat said he would agree to extend the United Nations peacekeeping form for only a few months instead of the usual six months' renewal.

title: BAR UNITS SCORED ON MINIMUM FEES
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Lawyers have no more right than any other group to engage in pricefixing that violates the antitrust laws, an attorney for suburban home buyers forced to pay high legal fees told the Supreme Court today.

title: PAN AM SEEKING GROWTH PATTERN
description: Pan American World Airways has ended its period of contraction dictated by its financial emergency and hopes, by concentrating on maximum use of its 31 Boeing 747 jumbo jets, to resume its historic pattern of growth, officials conveyed yesterday in a detailed briefing on how the airline has been restructured.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: GRAIN FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: After being down most of the day, prices on the Chicago Board of Trade closed higher because of short covering and ??ght profit taking.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, March 25 (UPI)The Banque de Bruxelles, Belgium's second largest bank, announced today that it must dip into its reserves to cover $100million in foreignexchange irregularities uncovered last year.

title: Some Indonesians on Truce Unit Planning to Quit Vietnam Today
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 26With the fournation International Commission of Control and Supervision for the Vietnam ceasefire in growing disarray, part of Indonesia's delegation was planning to leave the country today, and there was a possibility that Indonesia would quit the commission.

title: Sudden Shirt in Thieu Strategy Is Called Key Factor in Debacle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25  Western military specialists here say that the key factor in what has become a rout of Saigon Government forces was the suddenness of President Nguyen Van Thieu's decision to shift from a strategy of defending territory to abandoning it.

title: Thousands Try to Board Ships Waiting Off Hue
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 25 (AP)  As dawn broke over the beaches near Hue today, an armada of South Vietnamese Navy and civilian vessels of all sizes stood 500 yards from shore.

title: Show of Life and Art in Days of Yore
description: How to live and how to die are perennial problems. But they press hardest in times of transition, when they have to be solved all over again without the cornforts of a stable society and the guidance of rules that seem to us immutable.

title: Urban Europeans Worry About the Quality of Life
description: PARIS, March 26  When Stockholm decided to cut down the old elms in front of the opera house to build a subway station a year or so ago, many people protested. The city government insisted, so people perched on branches all day and slept in protective circles around the trunks at night. The city relented.

title: Man, 74, Found Slain In Ransacked Room Of Queens Project
description: Stephen Singer, 74 years old, was stabbed and beaten to death late Tuesday night in his apartment in a lowincome project, at 438 Beach 40 Street, in the Edgemere section of Queens. The apartment had been ransacked.

title: Bridge:
description: The Spring Nationals in Honolulu last week were quite hot enough for most of the players, but a great deal of additionalperhaps unnecessaryheat was generated by the Affair Sheinwold.

title: Bill Bars Offshore Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Contending that the Federal Government is moving too hastily and blindly into an offshore leasing program, Representative Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced legislation today to halt new offshore oil drilling. The bill would prohibit new drilling until Congress acted to provide for the orderly development of the outer continental shelf. Mr. Dodd said the Government planned to lease 10 million acres off the Atlantic coast this year, almost as much as all offshore leases since 1953.

title: Premier Calls for Austerity
description: LISBON, March 26Premier Vasco dos Santos Gonalves today announced a program of total austerity as well as further moves toward socialism through the nationalization of basic industries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 1975

title: CHRYSLER OFFERS NEW SALES PLAN
description: DETROIT, March 26  The Chrysler Corporation is offering a sales incentive program to its dealers that some said would help the company remove some of its slowselling cars into dealer hands.

title: Committee of House Votes to Broaden S.E.C. Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Legislation giving the Securities and Exchange Commission broadened authority over the nation's stock exchanges, including their integration into a national market system, was approved today by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

title: How a Couple Beat the Tax
description: A husband and wife team of certified public accountants has hit upon a zany but apparently legal way to beat the Marriage Tax. They divorce at the end of one tax year and remarry at the start of the next.

title: States Step Up Scrutiny Of Insurance Companies
description: Many state insurance authorities, taking on a greater consumerprotection character and equipped with improved enforcement power, are making increasing findings of unfair practices by insurance companies in the settlement of claims.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 27, 1975

title: People and Business
description: The nation's largest home building company will get a new president later this year. Stuart S. Golding, 57, president of the U.S. Home Corporation of Clearwater, Fla., since June, 1973, has indicated that he will not seek reelection as president or as a director at the annual meeting June 24.

title: Kissinger Revives A Vietnam Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Secretary of State Kissinger, in an effort to break an impasse with Congress, today revived an Administration proposal for a threeyear phaseout of military and economic aid to South Vietnam.

title: ROBERT K. BLACK
description: Robert K. Black, for many years a rarebook dealer in Montclair, N.J., died Sunday at Cherith House in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: White House Gate Crasher Is Sentenced to 18 Months
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)  Marshall Fields, convicted of crashing a car into the White House gate, has been sentenced to 18 months in jail.

title: 2 Marines Killed
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., March 26 (UPI)Officials at the Parris Island Marine Corps recruit depot said an explosion at a grenade range on Gibb's Island yesterday killed Sgt. Tony R. Holloway of Lakeland, Fla., and Pvt. Stephen G. Rowson of Levittown, Pa.

title: Skiing in Vermont Just Like Winter
description: WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 26Temperatures dropped well below freezing early this morning and an allday snowstorm helped put Vermont ski conditions back on a wintertime basis today.

title: Sihanouk Reports Rejecting Phnom Penh Peace Appeal
description: PEKING, March 26 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the Cambodian insurgents, today rejected a reported new peace appeal by Premier Long Boret of the Phnom Penh Government.

title: Asylum Hint by Lon Nol
description: TOKYO, March 26 (UPI)President Lon Nol of Cambodia has sounded out Japan on the possibility of seeking asylum here, a Foreign Ministry official told Parliament today.

title: AMEX AND OTC SHOW PRICE GAIN
description: For the first time in seven consecutive sessions, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday in slightly increased trading. Prices in the overthecounter market also showed advances although volume dropped slightly.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, March 26, 1975

title: Big Apple Polishers Brighten City's Image
description: Back in the nineteentwenties, Damon Runyon popularized the term Big Apple as the ultimate description of New Yorkthe city that was the big time in all respects.

title: 51 in Angolan Liberation Group Are Reported Slain by Rivals
description: LISBON, Thursday, March 27 (Reuters)Fiftyone young recruits of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola have been machinegunned to death in the Angolan capital of Luanda by a rival group, the Portuguese Government news agency reported today.

title: 410% Rise in MalpracticeInsurance Rate Sought
description: TRENTON, March 26 (AP)The insurance company that has threatened to cancel medical malpractice policies at 29 New Jersey hospitals tomorrow asked for a 410 per cent rate increase for such insurance coverage.

title: Selling Cars: Hard Work Again
description: DETROIT, March 26Walter J. Gubelius came back to work as a salesman at the Pointe Dodge dealership when the Chrysler Corporation was offering rebates of $200 to $500.

title: Article 2  No Title
Reginald Dabney, 65, Led Blue Cross of Maryland
description: Reginald H. Dabney, who retired in 1973 after 27 years with Blue Cross of Maryland, Inc., 22 of those years as president, died Friday in a hospital in Baltimore. He was 85 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Rodriguez Rides Victors in Double
description: Frank (Pancho) Martin used a new jockey in the second race at Aqueduct yesterday, and the move turned out satisfactorily for both. The rider was Jose Rodriguez and the horse was Sigmund Sommer's Obverse, who won the sixfurlong sprint by 1 lengths at a payoff of $5.60.

title: SLOW EFFECT SEEN FROM TAX CREDIT
description: The stimulus to capital spending that House and Senate conferees included in the tax bill probably will not affect the economy significantly until the worst of the recession is over, businessmen and economists said yesterday. The House and Senate passed the bill last night.

title: TEAMSTER OFFICIAL GUILTY IN TAX CASE
description: BALTIMORE, March 26 (AP) William C. Moore, chief of the political arm of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, pleaded guilty today to a Federal tax evasion charge involving the alleged embezzlement of union funds. A Federal District Court judge, C. Stanley Blair, accepted the plea and sentenced Mr. Moore to two years imprisonment, suspending all but six months of the term. Judge Blair also placed Mr. Moore on three years probation after his release from jail.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, may be telephoned to Oxford 53311 until 11 P.M. In Regional officer 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through. Friday New Jersey (201) MArket 33900; Westchester Co. and Northern New York State Counties (914) WHite Plains 95300; Nassau Co. (516) 1470500; Suffolk Ca. (516) 6631800; Connecticut (203) 3487761.

title: Saigon Reports It Halted Plot to Overthrow Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 27 The South Vietnamese Government announced this morning that a number of persons had been arrested for plotting to overthrow President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: STEIN LOSES IN BID TO EXTEND PANEL
description: ALBANY, March 26The Assembly last night resoundly rejected a plea by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein that the temporary commission he heads be extended for another year so it could uncover other scandals similar to those that have been uncovered in the nursing home industry.

title: Saigon Accuses AP and UPI Of Breaking Press Rules
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, March 26The Saigon bureaus of The Associated Press and United Press International were accused by the Government today of flagrant violation of official rules on press disclosure of troop movements.

title: Saudis Bury Faisal and Hail King
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 26King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, the victim of an assassin, was buried today with Bedouin simplicity in a grave marked by a stone, and the people of the kingdom pledged fealty to their new ruler, King Khalid.

title: Man Visiting Grocer Shot In a Holdup in Brooklyn
description: A 26yearold Brooklyn man was shot and critically wounded last night in a holdup in a friend's grocery store in the BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Article 1  No Title
Unions and Physicians Setting Up Detection Systems for Occupational Diseases
description: A growing number of labor unions have allied with epide?? to set up scientific studies and surveillance sys ems to detect cancers and other diseases attributed to occu??ational hazards.

title: PUERIO RICO USES SHIPRATES LURE
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.This island commonwealth, where the container revolution in cargo handling began, is trying another shipping innovation: the use of low ocean freight rates to stimulate economic development.

title: Hope for a Speedy Tax Bill Passage Seen as Spur
description: Prospects of speedy passage for the taxcut bill sent the stock market sharply higher yesterday in continued active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 18.30 points to 766.19.

title: AbortionRelated Bill Killed
description: HARTFORD, March 26 (AP) A bill banning experiments on aborted human fetuses was narrowly killed today by the legislature's Public Health and Safety Committee.
