The measure was defeated by a vote of 8 to 7 after a committee member, Senator Lawrence DeNardis, Republican of Hamden, asked the panel to await the outcome of a national study on the matter. Backers say they may try to bring it to the floor of the state House.

title: CLINICS DETECTING HIGH CANCER RATE
description: SAN DIEGO, March 26  A national network of breast cancer detection clinics has uncovered two and a half times the expected number of malignancies in women screened during the clinics' early months.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES FOR AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, by a Note of 9 to 7 approved a bill today allowing President Ford to lift the Congressionally imposed ban on Military aid to Turkey.

title: Chess:
Tax Victory
description: In working out the final version of the tax bill, Congress has achieved a constructive compromise. The bill accomplishes the essential goal of providing a timely and sufficiently strong stimulus to the lagging national economy. The conferees eliminated most, though not all, of the unwise amendments added by the Senate while making a modest beginning on the monumental task of tax reform.

title: Later Hearing Start
description: ALBANY, March 26 (AP)Public Service Commission hearings will start at 1 P.M. instead of 10 A.M. to give working people a chance to testify in the late afternoon, Alfred Kahn, Commission chairman, said today.

title: Whalen Is Nominated As State Health Chief
description: ALBANY, March 26Governor Carey today announced the nomination of Dr. Robert P. Whalen as Commissioner of the State Health Department. Dr. Whalen has been the Acting Commissioner since the retirement of Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham in January.

title: At Busy Da Nang Piers, Boats for the Lucky Rich
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 26Tens of thousands of refugees jammed the piers today along the Han River, which runs through Da Nang.

title: On the Outs With Boxing's InFighters
description: In boxing, the best infighters aren't boxers. They're promoters. In a ring, they'd be disqualified for unsportsmanlike conduct. Muhammad Ali exaggerated the rabbitpunch Monday night in retaliation for Chuck Wepner's impersonation of an angry Easter bunny. But as infighters, All and Wepner would be stopped by a promoter's receptionist, or at least outpointed. Once upon a time the Madison Square Garden boxing promoter was the undisputed heavyweight champion. He had all the power because he had all the money. But now the Garden promoter is only a contender, merely one of four. In the other corner, Video Techniques, Inc.; in another corner, Top Rank, Inc.; in the fourth corner, somebody new willing to take a chance. When the bell rings, the rules are easy to remember because there is only one. No holds barred. Now that Ali's manager, Herbert Muhammad, is accepting bids for his fighter's next title defense, the bell has for the promoters.

title: Indonesian Minister Is Confident He Can Deal With Red Indochina
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 26Foreign Minister Adam Malik expressed confidence today that Indonesia and other nonCommunist countries in Southeast Asia would be able to cooperate with Communist regimes in Indochina.

title: $10.4Billion State Budge Is Voted Without Taxes
description: ALBANY, March 26Groggy legislators straggled out of the Capitol early today after passing a $10.4billion state budget, still facing demands for new taxes and new programs when they return from a threeweek holiday.

title: Live Classical Recitals Set For Midnight by WQXR
description: A new nonprofit foundation, the Haydn Foundation for the Cultural Arts, will sponsor a series of live classical music recitals to be carried Monday. through Friday at midnight on WQXR radio. The series of 50minute concerts is scheduled to begin April 14 and will run for a year.

title: COMPUTER IS TOOL USED BY THE POOR
description: Ruby Ware, at the age of 44, decided that she wanted a career in nursing. Furthermore, she has a limited income, lives in Brooklyn but works in Manhattan, and wants to study for a degree at night.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: Saigon Asks Aid From U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, March 26 (UPI)A United Nations spokesman said today that South Vietnam had asked for aid for her refugees. The request, the spokesman said, had gone to Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and was being studied.

title: Gains Are Recorded By Dollar in Europe; Price of Gold Is Up
description: BRUSSELS, March 26 (UPl)The dollar gained on European money markets for the fifth consecutive day today and jumped to its highest level in more than a month in Tokyo. The price of gold also rose.

title: Effects of New Tax Bill on Poor
PIANIST SAMPLES COPLAND'S MUSIC
description: The number of piano solos written by Aaron Copland is not large, but they are of a consistently high order. The earliest pieces, The Cat and the Mouse (1919) and Passacaglia (1922), are well made and are still attractive in their eclectic ways. The three largest works rank among the best in 20thcentury music literature: Piano Variations (1930), a landmark in the growth of Mr. Copland's style and American music; Piano Sonata (1941), a piece of enormous richness and emotional power, and Piano Fantasy (1957), a brilliantly developed kaleidoscope.

title: CITY COUNCIL LAGS ON FEE INCREASES
description: Mayor Beame's program to overcome what he has estimated as a $430million gap in the current expense budget may be set back by a shortage of more than $6million in anticipated revenue from license fee increases. the Budget Bureau said yesterday.

title: POOR HERE GIVEN SEDER PACKAGES
description: Free Passover food packages and transportation to synagogues helped thousands of elderly poor and physically handicapped Jews to observe the Passover seder last night, celebrating the freeing of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage.

title: Conferees' Tax Program
description: Rebate. A rebate of 1974 taxes of between $100 and $200 for most taxpayers. Those who paid less than $100 in tax will have the entire tax refunded.

title: Savings Banks' Assets Show Large Increase
description: The assets of the 118 savings banks in New York State increased $671million in February, the largest increase in nearly three years, their trade association reported yesterday.

title: COMMUNIST FORCE PRESSES DA NANG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 27With all roads out of Da Nang cut and Communist pressure increasing, Western officials there reported yesterday that the North Vietnamese had more than 35,000 men able to strike at the city.

title: Incident at Airport
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 27 (AP)  An American security man fired three pistol shots into the air last night at Da Nang airport to drive back panicky Vietnamese who broke through a barrier to try to board a refugee flight. The plane, a Boeing 727 let, carried 198 American and Vietnamese passengers to Saigon, one third of them children.

title: McGovern Visiting Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 (Reuters)Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, arrived here today for a fourday visit to Lebanon as part of a Middle Eastern tour. His next stop will be Damascus.

title: Judge Dismisses 2 of 3 Counts Against One in the Ft. Lee Case
description: NEWARK, March 26Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey today dismissed two of three bribery counts against Nathan L. Serota, one of six defendants in the Fort Lee bribery trial in United States District Court here.

title: SENATE APPROVES FARMPRICE AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate passed today an emergency farm bill to increase price supports and income protection for farmers at a threeyear cost estimated by the Department of Agriculture at more than $19.6billion.

title: Arthur Nugent, 84, Who Drew Funland Puzzle Page, Is Dead
description: Arthur W. Nugent, who wrote and drew the syndicated Funland puzzle page that appeared in newspaper comic supplements for more than 45 years, died Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, N.J. He was 84 years old and lived in Newark.

title: GOLF CLUB FACING RACEBIAS HEARING
description: PRINCETON, March 26The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights has announced it will bring charges next week against Springdale Golf Club that it discriminated last May on the basis of race and color when it denied membership to the Princeton High School basketball coach, Marvin Trotman.

title: BIG BANKS TO LEND U.D.C $140MILLION
description: ALBANY, March 26The 11 major New York City commer1cial banks tentatively agreed today to lend the Urban Development Corporation $140million to help finish its projects, Governor Carey announced here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: More than $100,000 has been pledged toward the $200,009 needed by April 7 to keep the Mannes College of Music from suspending operations at the end of the school year. The board of directors' decision to close the college unless funds could be found was made public last week. The pledges received thus far have resulted from a telephone and personal solicitation campaign by studnts, faculty members and others. A special telephone number (7379088) answered by students from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily will be open through April 6 to pledges.

title: Storm Course Snowed Out
description: SHELDON, Iowa, March 26 (AP)The National Weather Service canceled a training course for Severe Storm Spotters todaybecause of a sudden, unexpected March snowstorm.

title: E.P.A. PANEL TO AID MINNESOTA CLEANUP
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency ordered a panel established to monitor the Reserve Mining Company's efforts to stop polluting the air and water along Lake Superior.

title: Saigon's Forces Are in State of Shock After Decision to Quit Northern Area
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26The South Vietnamese Army is stunned and demoralized by the North Vietnamese offensive and the Government's decision to abandon most of the northern twothirds of the nation, according to Western military analysts, Vietnamese observers and army officers in the field.

title: AGENCY PUTS CURB ON DATA SEARCHES
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Federal Energy Administration has told its price enforcement agents to stop issuing socalled notices of probable violation as discovery devices for getting information in the early stages of an investigation.

title: PARKE HENRY LUTZ
description: Parke Henry Lutz, a retired vice president of the publishing house of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, Inc., here, died Sunday in Lititz, Pa. He was 78 years old and lived in Denver, Pa.

title: ELIZABETH YARNALL
description: Elizabeth Biddle Yarnall, who, with her late husband, D. Robert Yarnall, aided victims of both world wars through the American Friends Service Committee, died Tuesday in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 78 years old.

title: EXAIDE TO GURNEY TESTIFIES ON FUNDS
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 26 (AP) A man who says he kept custody of $100,000 in, cash political contributions to former Senator Edward J. Gurney testified today that he was told the money came primarily from Federal housing contractors in exchange for favors and services.

title: Nearly Blind Student Accepts $165,000, As Jury Is About to Award Her $900,000
description: Moments before a jury would have awarded her $900,000, a nearly blind 21yearold Brooklyn College sophomorefearful of becoming a burden to her familyaccepted a $165,000 settlement of a malpractice suit she had brought against a hospital and two doctors.

title: Market Place
description: Investment companies that have a fixed number of shares outstanding  the socalled closedend fundshave often complained that their shares usually sell at a discount from the value of their holdings.

title: Skepticism on Domino Theory
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Secretary of State Kissinger restated at his news conference today the classic domino theory, which links American security in one place to American security everywhere else.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: BOSTONAl Romano, 150 pounds, North Adams. Mass., outpointed Gerry Annson, 150, Brockton, Mass., 8 rounds.

title: PARTY SHIFTS DUE IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, March 26The two major political parties in Connecticut, one plumbing the depths of despair and the other. riding a crest of popularity and power, are planning extensive reorganization.

title: Beaunit Increases Prices On Most Fabrics 9 or 10%
description: The Beaunit Corporation announced yesterday it has increased prices of most of its fabrics 9 or 10 per cent, effective at once. A spokesman said the increase reflected improved demand and thus a shift toward tighter supplies.

title: FORD LEADS POLL ON '76 G.O.P. RACE
description: The latest Gallup Poll shows that President Ford, former, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, and Senator Barry Goldwa ter of Arizona are the top choices of Republican voters nationwide for their party's 1976 Presidential nomination.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three youths were arrested on homicide charges in the slaying last Sunday night of a father of five at a Bronx neighborhood carnival. The youths were said, to be members of a street gang know as the Spanish Mafia.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an item in the Consumer Notes column of The New York Times yesterday, the charges for telephone interface devices were incorrectly stated. The correct charges are: for a telephone interface, $25 installation charge and $5.80 per month; for a GTS device (used with telephone answering machines), $30 installation and $3.10 a month.

title: Mrs. King, Miss Evert Advance
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 Billie Jean King and Chris Evert headed a procession of the eight seeded players into the quarterfinal round of the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tennis tournament tonight at the Palestra.

title: PLEA IS CHANGED BY SAKS OFFICIAL
description: Barrie Sommerfield, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, yesterday changed his plea from not guilty to no contest on Federal charges that he conspired to fix prices of women's clothing in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Favored Boys Gain At Easter Bowl Net
description: All three topseeded players in the boys' division of the ninth annual Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis championships won their firstround matches yesterday at Tennis 59.

title: Field for Heritage Golf Is AllStar
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 26 (AP)All the game's top starsJack Nicklaus, Johnny Miller, Lee Trevino, Arnold Palmer and Gary Playerare gathered for the first time this year in the $200,000 Heritage golf classic.

title: PAUL ARMSTRONG JR.
description: Paul Armstrong Jr., postmaster of Levittown, L.I., since 1958, died Tuesday at the Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I., after a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 3 Low Lane, Levittown.

title: Saudis Bury Faisal and Hail King
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 26King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, the victim of an assassin, was buried today with Bedouin simplicity in a grave marked by a stone, and the people of the kingdom pledged fealty to their new ruler, King Khalid.

title: Private Eye 'Sheba'
description: "Sheba, Baby," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and 86th Street Twin 2 Theaters, is a moderately entertaining B picture in the mode of "Foxy Brown" and "Coffy," though somewhat less violent. It's about a beautiful black private eye named Sheba who goes home to Louisville in an attempt to save her father, a kindly money-lender, from the mob that wants to take over his business.Pam Grier, who also starred in "Foxy Brown" and "Coffy," plays Sheba in a most unusual way. Although she's no great shakes as an actress, she gives the impression of being as intelligent as she is beautiful.The film was shot mostly in and around Louisville under the direction of William Girdler, who also directed another Louisville-located black melodrama, "Abby." From what one can see at the sides of the frame and in the background, Louisville looks serene and prosperous.

title: Midtown Jeweler Robbed
description: The owner of a midtown jewelry store yesterday was robbed at gunpoint of $100,000 in jewelry and a goldbullion bar worth $20,000 as he was closing up shop to go home for Passover. The police said the gunmen entered the HRG Jewelry Company, 36 West 47th Street, shortly bfore 3 P.M. and forced the owner, Herschel Gancz to open the safe. The police said Mr. Gancz was not hurt.

title: Knicks Win, 12898
KISSINGER FEARS PERIL IN MIDEAST, LOOKS TO GENEVA
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Middle East was now in potentially grave danger and that the Geneva peace conference would probably have to be reconvened to seek a way of avoiding a war.

title: Canadian Court Upholds Abortion Curb
description: MONTREAL, March 26The Supreme Court of Canada, in a landmark decision regarded as a defeat for women's rights groups, today upheld the couninterpretation of the country's fiveyearold abortion law.

title: Kissinger Revives A Vietnam Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Secretary of State Kissinger, in an effort to break an impasse with Congress, today revived an Administration proposal for a threeyear phaseout of military and economic aid to South Vietnam.

title: Ford Alumni Meet: Fun, Contacts
description: The Greater New York Ford Alumni Club held its annual spring luncheon this week at the Yale Club.

title: On Cambodia's Route 4, a Waiting War
description: PHOM PENH, Cambodia, March 26  It was, again, a day of preparation out along Route 4.

title: JACKSON PROPOSES AN ARMSCURB STEP
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Senator Henry M. Jackson proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union agree not to modernize 700 of their strategic weapons as a step toward future reductions in their nuclear arsenals.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Drop Below 500,000
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The Labor Department said today that initial unemployment claims reported by the states had fallen below 500,000 for the first time in 16 weeks.

title: U.S. Companies Plan Rise Of 17% in Outlays Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, March 26United States companies plan a further increase of 17 per cent in plant and equipment spending abroad in 1975 to a record $29.6billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Article 3  No Title
A RELEASE OF ENVOY IN SOMALIA STALLED
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, March 26 (Reuters)An airliner stood by here tonight to fly the kidnapped French Ambassador to freedom, but there were lastminute problems in negotiating his release.

title: Willie Ritchie Dies at 84; ExLightweight Champion
description: BURLINGAME. Calif., March 26 (AP)Willie Ritchie, who was lightweight boxing champion of the world for more than two years before World War I, died Monday. He was 84 years old.,

title: F.C.C. Urged to Open Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Representative Timoty E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, urged the Federal Communications Commission today to conduct its meetings publicly. Commissioners have disclosed information from private meetings to parties who have business before the regulatory agency, Mr. Wirth said in a statement.

title: Time for a Sweeping Israeli Initiative
description: It is time for a sweeping Israeli Initiative aimed at a peace settlement. The United States will remain an indispensable participant in the effort. But instead of what is essentially an American policy groping to bring gradual peace to the parties, we now need a decisive effort by the party whose future existence and security are at stake, whose role in the Middle East has been the heart of the matter since 1948, and which finds itself on the defensive. For it is its destiny that is being shaped, and it has a vital interest both in remaining its own master and in reaching with its adversaries a settlement that cannot be seen as the result of an outside power's skill at exploiting temporary circumstances.

title: Rodgers, 27, Improving As Runner
description: The way Will Rodgers tells it, he had stopped running for almost two years, was smoking half a pack of cigarettes a day and was tooling around Boston on a 10speed bicycle.

title: Business Slips in Public's Eyes
description: Public attitudes towards business, which improved slightly in 1967, have plummeted ever since, a group of corporate advertising specialists heard yesterday.

title: Wilson Says He Saw Bergman Twice On Home but Didn't Do Him Favors
description: Former Governor Malcolm Wilson testified yesterday that he had met with Bernard Bergman twice last year, but did not grant the nursinghome promoter any favors.

title: Major Parties More Active In City's School Elections
description: Democratic and Republican clubs in white areas are intervening more openly and to a greater extent than in past elections to support local school board candidates who will resist forced integration of schools.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DHJ BOARD HITS BID BY TEXTILE CONCERN
description: The offer made last week, was contingent on DHJ completing arrangements with its institutional lenders and creditors for a longterm deferment of its obligations. At the request of DHJ, trading of the stock on the American Stook Exchange was suspended on Jan. 27.

title: Books of The Times
description: I cultivate my hysteria with joy and terror, Charles Baudelaire said 100 years ago and quite a few poets have followed his example. You might conclude, if you read snough biographies, that poetry is a dangerous business, rather like being a test pilot. Will I fly or crash? Icarus comes to mind as the first test pilot. Randall Jarrell, Theodore Roethke, Robert Lowell, Delmore Schwartz and John Berryman were among the last to cultivate their hysteria  in both senses of that word before a new generation of American poets began to change it to indulge.

title: Schoolboy AllStar Games Have Players on the Move
description: For some high school basketball players postseason allstar games are causing as much of a whirl as the charge of brigades of college recruiters. In the next two months some of the outstanding seniors in the metropolitan area will be playing in games from Monticello, N. Y., to long Beach, Califwith many stops in between.

title: NEW ATTACK SET ON NERVE DISEASE
description: BONN, March 26More than one hundred scientists meeting in Wurzburg, Germany, this week have mapped out a new approach to solving the riddle of multiple sclerosis, based on the hypothesis that the disease Is caused by a slowvirus infection.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Equal Rights Setback

title: 4 Yank Errors Help Mess Win, 52, and Even Series
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 26The Yankees and Mets, who will share Shea Stadium again this summer, shared little old Al Lang Field on Tampa Bay this afternoon and the Mets evened their Southern subway series at two games apiece with a 52 victory.

title: Expediency in Albany...
description: Politics prevailed over prudence this week as the New York Legislature finally adopted a scaleddown $10.4billion budget without voting any of the new taxes that Governor Carey has insisted are needed to insure a constitutionally mandated balance. The Governor had estimated that $800 million in additional revenues was needed to balance his initial $10.7billion proposal. The Legislature cut $300 million from the spending side, presumably reducing the gap to $500 million.

title: 100 Dump Truck Owners Take Protest to Trenton
description: TRENTON, March 26 (AP)The owners of about 100 dump trucks parked their vehicles outside the State House today ti dramatize their demand for an extension of the deadline for paying annual license fees.

title: Bought From Swiss Concern
description: In Ottawa yesterday Dr. Myron Laskin Jr., research curator of European art at the National Gallery, said the Bernini bust had been purchased in 1974 from Eugene V. Thaw, a New York dealer, for a price of less than $1million. He said Italian officials had made no Irepresentations to the museum about the work and that the museum was satisfied it had been properly obtained.

title: Amusement Park Urged For 100Acre Site on S.I.
description: Plans were announced yesterday for the construction of a $40million turnofthecentury amusement park in the Bloomfield area of Staten Island.

title: Security For Israel
description: The sudden, destabilizing events in the Middle East come at a poignant time for Jews: Passover, the holiday that for so many centuries symbolized the hope of return to the land of Israel. The embodiment of that cream, presentday Israel, seems more than ever at risk in a hostile world.

title: An Easy Burglary Led to the Disclosure of HughesC.I.A. Plan to Salvage Soviet Sub
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26When a burglar thrust a gun the back of a security guard at Howard R. Hughes's headquarters here last June 5, he set in motion a chain of events that breached one of the most tightly held secrets of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: To Head U.S. Units in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Lieut. Gen. George S. Blanchard was named today to become commander of the 180,000 United States Army troops in Europe. General Blanchard, 55 years old, will replace Gen. Michael S. Davison, who is retiring.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VILLAGE VOLUME Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Wednesday are music nights at Sweet Basil (2421785), a jazz restaurant at 88 Seventh Avenue South, a few doors north of Bleecker Street. People listen closely in this airy room, with a pinebrickplant dcor, at the tables (primarily vegetarian food from about $1.60 to $6.25) and the bar (with, among other drinks, beer at $1.25 and 90 cents, and Scotch at $1.50). Solo and in groups, there's a turnover and return of musicians including some name players. Bucky Pizzarelli, the guitarist, has been a recent favorite; Jack Wilkins, another guitarist, and Eddie Gomez, bassist, are due back tomorrow and Saturday.

title: Excerpts From the Kissinger News Conference
description: Following, as transcribed by The New York Times, are excerpts from Secretary of State Kissinger's news conference yesterday, in which he made an opening statement on the Middle East and answered questions on the situations there and in Indochina:

title: Woman Ensign Gets Medal
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)Ens. Deborah Burnette was awarded the Navy's medal for heroism today, the first Navy woman to to receive the secondhighest noncombat award The 23yearold officer from Cleveland, Tenn., received the honor for risking her life recently in pulling a child from the path of a speeding car.

title: SEAT FLAW FOUND ON 2 FORD MODELS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Front seat pivot pin brackets on 1968 and 1969 Ford Mustangs and Mercury Cougars may give way suddenly, causing seat backs to collapse and drivers to lose control of their cars, Federal safety experts said today.

title: Eucharist Congress Is Set
description: ROME, March 26 (Reuters)The 41st International Eucharist Congress will be held in Philadelphia in 1976, Pope Paul VI announced today.

title: Major Revisions Urged In Land Planning Here
description: Declaring that landuse planning in the city has become a nightmare for public agencies, private developers and local communities, the State Charter Revision Commission esterday proposed changes that would affect the entire established planning process.

title: Former Vietnam Queen Decides to Stay in Hue
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 26 (UPI)Vietnam's Queen Mother, with a regal wave of her hand, sent away the limousine that the Government sent to evacuate her from Hue before it was abandoned. She decided to stay and face the Communists rather than leave the place of her birth.

title: ROME ASKS RETURN OF BERNINI BUST.
description: ROME, March 26Italy is seeking to recover a marble bust of Pope Urban VIII, attributed to the celebrated baroque architect and sculptor Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini, now on display at the National Gallery in Ottawa, art officials here said today.

title: CITY COUNCIL LAGS ON FEE INCREASES
description: Mayor Beame's program to overcome what he has estimated as a $430million gap in the current expense budget may be set back by a shortage of more than $6million in anticipated revenue from license fee increases, the Budget Bureau said yesterday.

title: Gulfstream Faces Boycott
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26  For a time this morning it appeared that racing at Gulfstream Park would be halted by an informal horsemen's boycott and that Saturday's $125,000 added Florida Derby featuring unbeaten Foolish Pleasure might not take place.

title: Recession Delays Efforts to Reduce Errors in Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)A yearold effort by the Federal Government to force states to reduce welfare errors is being, delayed because of the nation's economic problems, Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Brooklyn man who allegedly earned $290,000 by advertising a weightreducing plan based on handwriting analysis was indicted in Newark on mailfraud charges.

title: Price Plunges for Sears Notes
description: Prices for two recent issues plunged in the resale market yesterday after the offerings were freed from syndicate restrictions. Meanwhile, a tone of caution prevailed in the fixedincome sector following the sharp Tuesday rally set off by large Federal Reserve purchases of Government coupon issues. In new offerings yesterday, buyer reception was mixed. Meanwhile, the huge prospective financings, especially to fulfill new money needs of the Treasury, kept dealers and underwriters in a wary state.

title: 103102 Victory Keeps Colonels' Hopes Alive
Wounded Man Refuses Help
description: MADISON, Wis., March 26 (UPI)Paul Rogers, a former convict, tried unsuccessfully to commit suicide last Friday by shooting himself in the head after a liquor store robbery. He is in critical condition and refuses to allow doctors to remove the bullet. The authorities said today they were powerless to force Mr. Rogers to accept treatment.

title: Rise of Vermin in Apartments Is Tied to Garbage Compaction
description: Apartment houses in residential areas of the city have begun to experience a problem with rats, mice and other vermin as a result of the conversion from incinerators to compactors for garbage disposal.

title: JUDGE IS REMOVED FROM COAST BENCH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (UPI)The California Supreme Court removed from office yesterday a judge who made an obscene gesture to one defendant and gave another a Bronx cheer.

title: Personal Finance: Facing Tax Audit
description: Why Me, Tom Krolik?

title: Syracuse E.C.A.C. Team of Year
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., March 26 (AP)Syracuse was chosen Eastern College Athletic Conference team of the year today in balloting conducted by a sevenman awards committee for the conference. The Syracuse cocaptain, Rudy Hackett, was named player of the year. Syracuse, with a 237 wonlost record, will play Kentucky in the National Collegiate tournament semifinals on Saturday in San Diego.

title: Howell Teachers Angry Over the Dismissal of 54
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, March 26Teachers reacted angrily here today to the dismissal of 54 teachers and said they were seriously considering a strike in September, when the dismissals take effect.

title: Gregory Testimony Cited
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Dick Gregory appeared before staff members of the Rockefeller commission today to present more evidence in support of his theory that President Kennedy was the victim of a Central Intelligence Agency assassination plot, a spokesman for the comedian said. A commission spokesman refused to comment on the statement.

title: HERBERT POSNER
description: Herbert Posner, who served from 1930 to his retirement last year as president of the Dr. Posner Shoe Company, founded by his father, the late Abraham Posner, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 262 Central Park West.

title: About the Mets and Yankees . . .
description: Catfish Hunter, the North Carolina financier, will make his fifth start for the Yankees today against Don Gullett of the Cincinnati Reds. It also will be his debut along the Gulf of Mexico sunspots since the Yankees signed him to a fiveyear contract for a $3.75million in assorted benefits.

title: Rights Amendment Seems Dead for '75 After New Setback
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 26 (UPI)  The South Carolina House voted today to table the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, effectively defeating it in that state and apparently destroying any chance it could become a part of the United States Constitution in 1975.

title: Builder Who Rose Fast Undaunted by the View
description: Four years ago, Christoper Boomis was an obscure New York builder, virtually unnoticed by his competitors or hardly anyone else. Raised in Wichita. Kan., he lived with his wife Zaida in a brownstone that he had renovated himself on 78th Street near First Avenue.

title: UNION'S $25,000 GIFT TO SAMUELS STUDIED
description: A $25,000 political contribution by a union to Howard J. Samuels's gubernatorial Dmueratic primary campaign last year is being investigated by the State Board of Elections. The union challenged yesterday a subpoena issued for its 197475 minutes and records. Mr. Samuels lost the primary to Representative Hugh L. Carey, who was elected Governor.

title: Gen. Bradley Has Surgery For Removal of Brain Clot
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (UPI)General of the Army Omar N. Bradley underwent successful surgery today to remove a blood clot from his brain that caused a stroke March 16,, U.C.L.A. Medical Center sources reported.

title: Next Phase
description: Despite deep disappointment over the failure of his latest mediation effort between Egypt and Israel, Secretary of State Kissinger at his news conference yesterday put the best face possible on the forthcoming Geneva Conference on the Middle East.

title: Simon Withdraws Film Held Insulting to Italians
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)  Several Representatives of Italian descent said today that the Treasury Department had agreed never again to show a United States savings bond promotion film which they called an insult to the entire ItaloAmerican community.

title: Kidnapping Victim Freed
description: DECATUR, Ill., March 26 (UPI)Mrs. John Luttrell, wife of the president of the First National Bank of Decatur, was kidnapped today and held briefly for ransom before being released unharmed. The police said a 40yearold suspect had been arrested and the money recovered. Neither the suspect's identity nor the amount of ransom money was disclosed.

title: Decline in Garbage Is Laid to Recession
description: For the first time in anyone's memoryand probably for the first time since the end of World War IIthe amount of trash and garbage being generated by New Yorkers is declining. Waste, like the people who produce it, has apparently become the victim of the recession.

title: Alexander Dobkin Is Dead at 67; Painter and Author Taught Here
description: Alexander Dobkin, an American painter and graphic artist. died last Friday, apparently of a heart attack, on the island of St. Martin in the West Indies. He had been on a Caribbean cruise when he was stricken.

title: Nuclear Agency Suspends ExportImport of Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has stopped issuing licenses to import and export nuclear reactors and several materials such as plutonium, pending a review of the commission's regulations and procedures in this area.

title: Dispute Halts Publication Of Daily Mirror in London
description: LONDON. March 26  Britains biggestselling daily, newspaper, The Daily Mirror, did not appear in London today as its publisher adopted a tough line on a staffing dispute.

title: People in Sports
description: Carol Stallworth, last year's president of the champion Birmingham Americans of the World Football League, is now tending bar in a downtown Birmingham establishment.

title: A Formidable Barrier
description: What is so forbidding about a flight of stairs? A lotto someone in a wheel chair.

title: Penn Central Riders Face Fare Increases
description: NEWARK, March 26 (AP)Commuters on Penn Central rail lines linking New Jersey with Penn Station in New York will pay an average increase of 25 per cent beginning tomorrow.

title: The Screen: Pranksters
description: The Merry Pranksters, which heads the new film program at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is a sad, wan, hungover souvenir of the midnineteensixtiesthat time when so many sons and daughters of America's wellheeled middleclass were dropping out and turning on that it seemed theoretically possible Marx's dreams would come true by default.

title: Exodus From Capital: Impending Recess Provides Focus for Skirmishes Between Ford and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The periodic exodus of elected officials from the capital is a rite as regular as springtime, and today the three airline clerks who work in room H101 on Capitol Hill were as harried as they always are when Congress prepares to go home. But this year's 10day Easter recesswhich awaited only the passage of the taxcut legislationis of more than usual interest.

title: Judicial Temperament
description: Whether or not the proceedings recently initiated by the State Court on the Judiciary against a State Supreme Court Justice for intemperate judicial conduct results in the judge's removal, the action was important for the future of judicial discipline in New York. It may be a signal that the disciplinary court is not entirely comatose on judicial behavior which, though not corrupt, tyrannizes litigants, lawyers and witnesses.

title: A.A.U. Sets Junior Track
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 26 (UPI)The Amateur Athletic Union announced today that the national junior men's track and field championships would be held at Knoxville, Term., June 13 and 14. The meet is for athletes 19 years and under. The competition for young women will be part of the national A.A.U. senior women's championships June 2428 at White Plains, N. Y., the A.A.U. said.

title: VETO IS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Congress approved today a $22.8billion taxreduction bill that would give a tax cut of at least $130 this year to nearly every taxpaying individual or family.

title: Notes on People
description: Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. quietly flew home from his European post, had a weekend visit with former President Nixon at his estate and has an appointment today with President Ford, it became known yesterday. General Haig, now the military commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and former White House chief of staff, played a key part in arranging the mechanics of Mr. Nixon's resignation. Sources close to the general said he flew unannounced last Friday from his headquarters near Brussels and on to California, spending the night at a San Clemente motel

title: CORRECTION
description: In an item in the Consumer Notes column of The New York Times yesterday, the charges for telephone interface devices were incorrectly stated. The correct charges are: for a telephone interface, $25 installation charge and $5.80 per month; for a GTS device (used with telephone answering machines), $30 installation and $3.10 a month

title: Bronx School Head Gets Reprimand
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker's trustee for Community School District 9 in the Bronx yesterday officially reprimanded the district superintendent, John S. Greene, for failure to exercise due diligence in connection with an inquiry requested by Mr. Anker into possble cheating on last spring's citywide reading tests.

title: A Wrestling Power Leans on the Riveras
description: So long as there is a Rivera boy with muscles and agility, Jackson Township appears likely to remain one of the prime powers in New Jersey schoolboy wrestling compelition. Actually, that's not to take anything away from Coach Bernie Reider, whose skill is reflected in the fact that Jackson, between 1972 and late last season, won 58 consecutive dual meets before losing. But it hasn't hurt to have a Rivera in action.

title: Marriage Tax Has Couples in a Rage and Even Divorcing
description: For years, single taxpayers were complaining that the Internal Revenue Service was a domesticminded despot who showered benefits on the marrieds and penalties on the singles. Married taxpayers had the good sense to keep still.

title: Experts See Rising Risk Of a War in Middle East
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's news conference observation yesterday that the longer the stalemate, the greater the danger of a Middle East war underscored United States military concern over the potential explosiveness of the situation now that the Israeli  Egyptian talks have broken down. In both Washington and at the Brussels headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization there are fears that accelerated improvement in Arab weaponry during a protracted stalemate might encourage those in Israel who see preemptive air strikes as a means of averting heavy civilian and military casualties in a general war.

title: PRISONERS REBEL AT DUTCHESS JAIL
description: Young inmates at the Dutchess County jail in Poughkeepsie overpowered a guard, seized their cellblock and went on a rampage yesterday morning while two state inspectors were at the jail investigating two inmate suicides there last week.

title: U.S., in Message to Lisbon, Says Move Left Is a Danger to NATO
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The United States has warned the military leadership in Portugal that the leftward turn there is inimical to American and Atlantic alliance interests.

title: Saigon Reports It Halted Plot to Overthrow Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 27The South Vietnamese Government announced this morning that a number of persons had been arrested for plotting to overthrow President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: A $35 Setter Blazed Championship Trail
description: Fortyone years ago Wilton Meyer had his first judging assignment. It was in Long Beach [Calif.], at the Harbor Cities Club, which I helped to organize, he recalled. I did the pointers and English springer. I'd been hunting since I was a boy and had shot over both breeds.

title: Advertising
description: William Bernbach, chief executive of Doyle Dane Bernbach, opened yesterday's annual meeting the way most agency executives would like toby announcing a new assignment. The Olin Corporation is returning to D.D.B. for corporate advertising.

title: Law Parley Finds Women Lagging in Rights
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., March 4Courts and legislatures have dramatically changed the legal status of women in recent years, bringing it far closer to that of men. But a substantial gap remains, with women around the country sometimes denied rights that men have, other times given different rights.

title: No Charge Filed Against Furlow
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., March 26 (AP)Michigan State University police say they are investigating a complaint against Terry Furlow, a basketball star, concerning an alleged assault.

title: Music: Focus on Japan
description: Lukas Foss and his Brooklyn Philharmonia got around to Japan on their adventuresome Meet the Moderns series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night.

title: Loving Hands Rebuild Wildcat, Heroic Fighter of World War II
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., March 26A 32yearold fighter plane used in the Pacific during World War II was displayed proudly at the Grumman Corporation plant today by 28 retired company employes who had worked voluntarily to restore it.

title: U.S. Revives Study of 4 Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Justice Department said today that it had reactivated an investigation of four major oil companies in California but that so far it had found no grounds on which to go to court.

title: VETO IS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Congress approved tonight a $22.8billion tax cut that would give at least $130 this year to nearly every taxpaying individual or family.

title: Police PaylessDays Pact Is Still Valid, C odd Insists
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that the plan approved by rankandfile officers to work five extra tours of duty without pay, to save the jobs of 500 rookies and recruits, remained in effect despite its repudiation Tuesday by the president of the police union.

title: Hickey Joins Army Staff
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 26 (AP)Bill Hickey, a former assistant coach at Notre Dame and Colorado State University, has joined the Army football staff,

title: JUDGE DISMISSES 2 FT. LEE COUNTS
description: NEWARK, March 26Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey today dismissed two of three bribery counts against Nathan L. Serota, one of six defendants in the Fort Lee bribery trial in United States District Court here.

title: ... Political Hatchet
description: Budgetary horsetrading between Republicans and Democrats at Albany has saved the State Permanent Commission on Public Employe Pension and Retirement Systems despite Governor Carey's effort to kill itat behest of the union leaders who contributed so lavishly to his campaign fund.

title: Market Summary
Carey's Olympic Budget Request Cut
description: ALBANY, March 26 (UPI)The State Legislature has slashed all but $158,000 from Governor Carey's executive budget request for $1.6million to prepare facilities at Lake Placid for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Chemical New York Corp. Sees A Strong Earnings Increase
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the holding company that owns Chemical Bank, expects to report a strong earnings increase for the first quarter, Donald C. Platten, chairman, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting.

title: MEMOREX REACHES A LAWSUIT ACCORD
description: The Memorex Corporation said yesterday a proposed settlement had been reached on various class action derivative and individual suits that alleged a violation of Federal securities laws in 1970 and 1971 by Memorex and others.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)President Ford will propose legislation soon after Congress returns from its Easter recess designed to help revitalize the nation's rail industry, a White House aide said today.

title: Flames Win, Move Closer To Islanders
description: ATLANTA, March 26 (UPI) Tim Ecclestone and Gerry Meehan scored thirdperiod goals tonight to give Atlanta a 53 victory over Detroit and move the Flames to within 5 points of the thirdplace New York Islanders in the National Hockey League's Patrick Division. The Flames have two games remaining with the Islanders in the battle for the final playoff position.

title: COMMUNIST FORCE PRESSES DA NANG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 27With all roads out of Da Nang cut and Communist pressure increasing, Western officials there reported yesterday that the North Vietnamese had more than 35,000 men able to strike at the city.

title: Legislators Wind Up Hectic Session With Bipartisan Aye on Long Recess
description: ALBANY, March 26The Assembly session of 16 straight hours warmed slowly, with a debate at 2 P.M. yesterday about walleyed pike and their predators. By 4 o'clock this morning the lawmakers themselves seemed a bit walleyed and even green around the gills as they slumped and fidgeted in their chairs and occasionally stood up, mouthing the chamber air, which was viscous with tobacco smoke, and speaking pieces of their minds.

title: Judge Lifts Freeze on Funds Collected at Republican Dinner
description: NEWARK, March 26Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman lifted today a freeze he had imposed on the Republican State Committee from spending funds It collected at a Jan. 29 dinner honoring Vice President Rockefeller.

title: Retail Milk Prices Rise To 44caQuart Average
description: The price of whole milk has risen to 45 and 50 cents a quart in some New York retail food stores and the average in the New York area is 44 cents, reflecting a small advance in the price to farmers under the Federal milk marketing order to $9.25 from $9.20 a hundredweight46.5 quarts.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 1975

title: C. Moreau Jansky Jr., 79, Pioneer in Radio Broadcast
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)C. Moreau Jansky Jr., a pioneer in radio broadcasting, died at his home here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Garden State Imperiled
description: CHERRY HILL. N. J., March 26A dispute involving union jurisdiction is threatening the continuance of racing at Garden State Park.

title: Title Swim In N.C.A.A. Set Today
description: CLEVELAND, March 26The 52d annual National Collegiate swimming championships will begin tomorrow with some of the world's fastest swimmers performing before an audience paying some of America's stiffest minimum prices for a sports event.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Equal Rights Setback

title: TV: Two Programs Exploit Subjects
description: Barring manmade or natural disasters, ecological and otherwise, show business may be the death of us all. Tonight's television specimens include programs using that is the precise wordthe Smithsonian Institution and the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Police PaylessDays Pact Is Still Valid, Codd Insists
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that the plan approved by rankandfile officers to work five extra tours of duty without pay, to save the jobs of 500 rookies and recruits, remained in effect despite its repudiation Tuesday by the president of the police union.

title: Amusement Park Urged For 100Acre Site on S.I.
description: Plans were announced yesterday for the construction of a $40million turnofthecentury amusement park in the Bloomfield area of Staten Island.

title: Tony Nominations Led by Wiz, Mack and Goodtime Charley
McAdoo Gets 34 Points As Braves Beat Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 26 (AP)Bob McAdoo pumped in 34 points tonight, including 12 in the last quarter, to lead the Buffalo Braves to a 9491 victory over Washington in the National Basketball Association. It was only the Bullet's fifth defeat in 37 home games.

title: Britain Set to Take Over Ailing Belfast Shipyard
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26The British Government announced today plans to save the Belfast shipyard of Harland & Wolff by taking it into public ownership and absorbing future loses of $145million.

title: A SUIT IS AVERTED ON PENNSY NOTES
description: The Getty Oil Company was disclosed yesterday to have won a $1.4million settlement from the investment house of Goldman, Sachs & Co. for selling Getty $2million of notes of the Penn Central Transportation Company only five months before the Pennsy went into bankruptcy.

title: 2 House Leaders Leave For Visit to China Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)Representative Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House and Representative John Rhodes, the Republican leader, will leave tomorrow for a 10day official visit to China, the Speaker's office announced today.

title: LEUKEMIA CLAIMS PEMBERTON GIRL, 9
description: PEMBERTON, March 26 (UPI) Debbie Bogardus, a 9yearold girl who lived here and who never made her long dreamed of trip to Disney World, died yesterday of Leukemia with her parents at her side.

title: Nixon Is Said to Halt Friends' Efforts for TV Appearance by Him
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 26Richard M. Nixon was reliably reported today to have called a halt, at least for the time being, to efforts by a group of friends to obtain bids around $250.000 for his appearance on television to discuss his years in the White House.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Oxford Lets Rhodes Scholar Do Homework in Basketball
description: OXFORD, England, March 26Tom McMillen, the 6foot10inch Rhodes scholar, will he able to play professional basketball in the United States next season. He is now studying whether he wants to.

title: Cocteau Repertory Does Max Frisch's Firebugs
description: Graham Greene's biting, but presumably jocular, accusation that during centuries of peace the Swiss succeeded only in inventing the cuckoo clock is little more than an amusing libel. The Swiss theater, for example, is among the more active in Europe, and two of the world's leading dramatists, Friederich Drrenmatt and Max Frisch, are Swiss.

title: Assassin's Fate and Motives Unknown
description: The accused slayer of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was depicted yesterday in conflicting termsas a killer bent on vengeance; as a mentally deranged drug user; as a radical and as a gentle, devout man who abhorred assassination.

title: Wayne Goes to London in 'Brannigan'
description: Brannigan happens to be, among other things, an Irish-oriented euphemism for a drunken brawl and the name John Wayne goes by in "Brannigan," which erupted like a donnybrook in local theaters yesterday. But there's little in "Brannigan" to dispel the nagging notion that after more than 200 largely Western adventures shot over 45 years, he is still the indestructible cow-poke despite a Chicago detective's badge and the contemporary London locale. The results are no more convincing than a standard shootout on a Hollywood set."Brannigan," it should be noted, generates a suspicion of self-parody since, it will be recalled, our hero also played a police lieutenant in last year's "McQ." But as a cop, he again is the rough, if tiring, hombre, who's quick with his gun and fists, hates bad guys as much as rustlers and relishes taking them on singly on gangs.This time he's the veteran dispatched to London to extradite a top racketeer for the Windy City's grand jury. As the fugitive mobster, John Vernon is blatantly obvious despite Savile Row clothes and the rich life in Mayfair. But he's surrounded by sordid types like James Booth, who kidnap him, and a double-dealing lawyer blandly played by Mel Ferrer. Of course, there's John Wayne simultaneously contending with a tenacious hit man, Daniel Pilon, imported to get him and Richard Attenborough, as Scotland Yard's smoothest sleuth, in pursuit of the rackets chief.If we're exposed to an improbable blitz of gun battles, bombings, car chases, a saloon slug fest and Judy Geeson, as Wayne's pretty, British detective aide, we're also guided on a colorful Cook's tour of such landmarks as the Garrick Club, Piccadilly, Tower Bridge and the Thames docksides. Unfortunately, Mr. Wayne's first film trip to London doesn't appear to have been necessary. He and his busy company only serve to make "Brannigan" a commonplace crime caper.

title: Builder Who Rose Fast Undaunted by the View
description: Four years ago, Christopher Boomis was an obscure New York builder, virtually unnoticed by his competitors or hardly anyone else. Raised in Wichita, Kan., he lived with his wife Zaida in a brownstone that he had renovated himself on 78th Street near First Avenue.

title: Tax Law Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The following table shows the tax reductions that would accrue to a family of four as a combined result of the rebate on 1974 taxes and the major provisions affecting 1975 taxes:

title: Highlights of the Tax Bill
description: Rebate. A rebate of 1974 taxes of between $100 and $200 for most taxpayers. Those who paid less than $100 in tax will have the entire tax refunded.

title: Retail Price of Whole Milk Increases
description: The price of whole milk has risen to 45 and 50 cents quart in some New York retail food stores and the average in the New York area is 44 cents, reflecting a small advance in the price to farmers under the Federal milk marketing order to $9.25 from $9.20 a hundredweight46.5 quarts.

title: City Faces Problems in Improving Its Cash Flow
description: Mayor Beame has asserted repeatedly that the city will pay its debts and meet its payrolls. He has said that he isn't worried at all about the city's financial future that he expects its borrowings and interest payments to decrease, and that he expects its cashflow position to improve in the next month. But the actions that he says would guarantee this happy state for the city remain under the control of others, and the Mayor is expressing hopes rather than certainties.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A lot of eggs go down the drain at the Chronis home in Fort Lee, N.J. Vladimir Chronis and his partner, Yiannis Nomikos, are only interested in the shells, on which they paint figures from Greek mythology, and there's a limit to the number of omelettes that can be whipped up by Mr. Chronis's wife, Tina.

title: I.R.S. CHIEF HEARD IN SPYING INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)The head of the Internal Revenue Service said today that the Justice Department had had overall control of an operation that reportedly included spying on the sex and drinking habits of prominent Miami residents.

title: DR. CHARLES HADLEY
description: Dr. Charles E. Hadley, who retired a year ago as a professor of biology at New Jersey State Teachers College in Montclair, died yesterday at his home in Crawfordsville, Ind. He was 82 years old.

title: Corn and Soybean Prices Up by Limits in Midwest
description: Nervous corn and soybean exporters bid up prices to their daily permissible limits in the final minutes of trading yesterday on the Midwest exchanges.

title: Israelis Issue Sinai Negotiation Maps
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Israeli diplomats have made public what they describe as maps of the Israeli and Egyptian negotiating positions in the Sinai talks that broke down on Saturday.

title: Saudis Stoic in Grief for Faisal
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, March 26The desert wind whistled through empty parking lots today at the headquarters of Aramco, the ArabianAmerican Oil Company. The bulldozers stayed silent and unused in the sandy building sites nearby. And Saudi riflemen turned travelers away from the United States Consulate General here, which had closed its doors.

title: Officer Is Burned Defusing A Pipe Bomb in Bushwick
description: A police officer was injured last night in Brooklyn when he defused what the police said was a pipe bomb that had been placed under the gasoline tank of an auto parked in the rear of the 83d Precinct station at Wilson and DeKalb Avenues, in the Bushwick section.

title: BLAST VICTIM WINS $750,000 VERDICT
description: A 36yearold Long Island man was awarded $750,000 yesterday for burns he suffered in a 1965 explosion of lacquer fumes at a Uniondale, L. I., bowling alley.

title: Henry's Two Faces
description: WASHINGTONHenry Kissinger is still pursuing his favorite tactic: saying one thing in public, and passing the word directly to the contrary in private.

title: American String Quartet Is Prized
description: Music competitions come in for a good deal of criticism, not all of it illfounded. They favor the coolly precise and competitive musician at the expense of the passionate risktaker. They overpublicize winners at the expense of runnersup. And so on. But competitions took at least one uncontroversial step in a musically valid direction when they began to give prizes for chambermusic groups as well as the usual solo instrumentalists.

title: Soviet Police Move Jews From Street After Service
description: MOSCOW, March 26 (UPI)Policemen moved Jews off the street outside Moscow's only synagogue tonight following a brief Passover service.

title: Ellingtonians Join Cab Calloway To Evoke Days of Cotton Club
description: Town Hall, a staid auditorium, is obviously a far cry from the legendary Cotton Club in Harlem 45 years ago when Duke Ellington and Cab Calloway were making their names there. But the enthusiasm of the 1,600 people who filled Town Hall on Tuesday evening for a program evoking the Cotton Club, the first of a series of New York Nights, created a jubilant atmosphere in which Mr. Calloway and the current Duke Ellington orchestra, assisted by Mama Lu Parks's recklessly acrobatic Lindy Hoppers, could work the magic of memory and association, even for those who had never been there.

title: FOE OF SPACE BASE KILLS WIFE, HIMSELF
description: MERRITT ISLAND, Fla., March 26 (UPI)Walter Starkey, who waged a celebrated and successful sevenyear battle against the Federal Government over land condemnation for expansion of the Kennedy Space Center, shot his divorced wife, Caroline, to death and then took his own life yesterday, the police said.

title: KISSINGER FEARS PERIL IN MIDEAST, LOOKS TO GENEVA
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Middle East was now in potentially grave danger and that the Geneva peace conference would probably have to be reconvened to seek a way of avoiding a war.

title: Crabiel Relies on Statute of Limitations
description: NEWARK, March 27J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, has wen an unusual appeal to have his trial on highway bidrigging charges split into two parts.

title: N.B.A. East WildCard Battle
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Chocolate, Chapeaux and Corsages Are Part of Easter's Preparations
description: In the candy shop on Broadway, the smell of roasting cashew nuts drifts out from the back room. In the front, women peer closely at the large glass jars containing miniature pastelcolored Easter eggs made of pure apple jelly; butterscotch drops; dark brown coffee royals with chocolate centers and assorted sugared slices of lime, lemon and orange. Unconsciously, the women smile and reach for their wallets.

title: Article 4  No Title
TV: Right to Believe
description: One of the more pertinent offerings for the Easter and Passover season will be shown Sunday on the ABC network, at the underwhelming hour of 1 in the afternoon. Called The Right to Believe, the program is part of the ABC News Directions series and. in an unusual arrangement, has been made with the cooperation of four separate religious groups: the United States Catholic Conference, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, the National Council of Churches and the Southern Baptist Convention.

title: THREESTATE DRIVE IS URGED ON DRUGS
description: TRENTON, March 27A tristate compact that would involve New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania in a coordinated drive to stop illicit drug traffic among the three states was proposed here today by a leading legislative figure from each state.

title: State Details 16 Ways Nursing Homes Bilked Taxpayers of Medicaid Millions
description: Sixteen ways for nursing homes to cheat on Medicaid payments were detailed yesterday by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy, which estimated that the devices had cost taxpayers at least $400 million is New York State alone.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, March 27, 1975

title: At Da Nang Airport, The Desperate Wait
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 27The deputy commander of the Saigon Government forces in the northern part of the country sat disconsolately at the airport here today, waiting with thousands of other South Vietnamese for American air transportation to the safety of the capital.

title: Illegal Medicaid Benefits In '75 Put at $600Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare will pay out more than $600million in 1975 for illegal Medicaid benefits, Senator William Proxmire said today.

title: Jack Storm, Pediatrician On Long Island, Dies at 47
description: Dr. Jack Storm, medical director of the Nassau County Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, died yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 47 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: People and Business
description: A 59yearold Boston banker, Ben Ames Williams Jr., yesterday was named chairman of the executive committee of the board of Arthur D. Little, Inc., the Cambridgebased consulting company. Mr. Williams, who is executive vice president of the First National Bank of Boston, succeeds James M. Gavin, 68, who continues as chairman of the board. John Magee, 48, continues as president and chief executive officer of the company, which held its annual meeting yesterday in Boston.

title: 20% TRUCKBUS CUT IN FUEL IS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)Federal energy planners have announced a new fiveyear plan to make trucks and buses use at least 20 per cent less fuel.

title: PROTESTERS SEIZE AN OFFICE AT U.N.
description: Eight young men and five women from an antiimperialist group called the Revolutionary Student Brigade, forced their way into office of the South Vietnamese mission to the United Nations yesterday afternoon and occupied the suite for two hours.

title: MORE LAYOFFS SET FOR CAR INDUSTRY
description: DETROIT, March 27Despite plans for production increases in the second quarter, the United States auto industry will enter April with over one third of its work force unemployed.

title: As Usual, Marks in Swim Set
description: CLEVELAND, March 27Cynics contend that a record is broken every time a swimmer sticks his little toe into a pool. That was almost true tonight as the 52d annual National Collegiate championships started in Cleveland State University's shiny new exhibition pool.

title: Pope Names Philadelphia As Site of 1976 Congress
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 28 (AP)  Philadelphia was designated today by Pope Paul VI as, the site of the Roman Catholic Church's 41st Internationall Eucharistic Congress next year.

title: Taiwan Is Issued Chinese Games Bid
description: China, which last week invited an American track and field team to compete there in May, yesterday issued an invitation to Taiwan to attend the Third Chinese National Games to be held in Peking in September. The New China News Agency reported that a cable had been sent to Taiwan's National Olympic chairman, Yang Seng, and other leading Nationalist sporting figures.

title: THREE ARE SEIZED IN OFFICE HOLDUPS
description: Three suspects in at least six holdups of Brooklyn doctors' offices since the first of the year were arrested yesterday moments after they had allegedly raped two young women during what the police said was their second waitingroom robbery within two hours.

title: Tight Security Is Planned For Integrated Twain High
description: School officials planning the integration of Coney Island's Mark Twain Junior High School have submitted a plan for extraordinary school  security measures, including ultrasonic detection devices and personal alarms for teachers, to assure the safety of the student body, which, under the integration plan, is to become predominantly white.

title: PuzzleSolving Builder
description: ALBANY, March 27Some of the worst political advice of recent months was offered by Richard Ravitch to his son, Joey, when the 13yearold was running for class president at the Dalton School and found himself facing a formidably charismatic opponent, Jamie Redford, the son of Robert Redford, the actor.

title: A.A.U. Acts on Woman Boxer
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27  Two Phoenix Amateur Athletic Union officials have been dismissed by the National A.A.U. boxing chairman, Roland C. Schwartz, for allowing a woman to box against men in the Arizona Golden Gloves competition March 7, 8 and 9.

title: 3STATE ATTACK URGED ON DRUGS
description: TRENTON, March 27A tristate compact that would involve New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania in a coordinated drive to stop illicit drug traffic among the three states was proposed here today by a leading legislative Figure from each state.

title: U.S. WILL GIVE AWAY SURPLUS PEANUT OIL
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Department of Agriculture announced today plans to donate the oil from $142million worth of peanuts to domestic and foreign food programs in a move to dispose of 338,000 tons, now in danger of spoiling, that was acquired under the pricesupport program.

title: May Stores Cites Lag
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest variety chain, and the May Department Stores Company, which operates 121 department and discount stores nationwide, reported lower quarterly earnings yesterday, following the downward pattern of profits shown by most of the major retailers.

title: Carey Names Joan Davidson of Kaplan Fund to Head State Council on Arts
description: Joan K. Davidson, former president of Westbeth, the controversial artists' housing project in Greenwich Village, was named chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts by Governor Carey yesterday, subject to confirmation by the Senate.

title: Railroad Executive Urges A Partial Nationalization
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The president of the highly profitable Norfolk & Western Railway, one of the chief competitors of the Penn Central Railroad, called today for the nationalization of part of the plant and facilities of the Penn Central and other bankrupt Northeastern lines.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Intelligence tests used to be something between the tester and the teacherparents got to know relatively little about what the testing showed or how it was done.

title: U.S URGED TO BUY NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has called on the Government to order four or eight floating nuclearpower plants now so that they could be available in 1980 for regions where energy will be running out.

title: Mrs.King Reaches Semifinal
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27 Billie Jean King was so happy at being back in the thick of a Virginia Slims tennis tourney tonight that she giggled her way through a 61, 60 rout of Wendy Overton to enter the semifinals of the $75,000 event at the Palestra. Then she called off a threatened boycott of the United States Open by the Women's Tennis Association.

title: MARTHA CHEAVENS
description: Martha Cheavens Schuck, who was a novelist, shortstory writer and poet under the name Martha Cheavens, died Wednesday in Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. She was 76 years old, lived in King of Prussia Pa:, and was the widow of Hugh J. Schuck, former foreign editor of The Daily News here.

title: State Is Urged to Protect Consumers From Utilities
description: TRENTON, March 27  A Michigan Public Utility Commissioner said today that customers of gas, electric and other utilities were captives of their suppliers and needed protection from monopolistic abuses and discriminatory practices.

title: JOHN CARTER DIES; BIBLIOGRAPHER, 69
description: LONDON, March 27John, Carter, a bibliographer and, antiquarian who had unmasked: Thomas J. Wise, one of the most respected bookman of the late 19th century, as a forger of first, editions of Victorian authors, died March 18 at the age of 69.

title: RADICAL FUGITIVE IS APPREHENDED
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)Susan Edith Saxe. a fugitive since a 1970 Boston holdup in which a policeman was slain, was arrested tonight in downtown Philadelphia, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: Eastern Joins National In End to Free Drinks
description: MIAMI, March 27 (UP)The liquor war between National and Eastern Airlines will apparently end in a quiet armistice April 14 with coach passengers paying for their drinks on flights to and from Miami

title: Newcombe, Rosewall Gain at Net
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 27 (AP)John Newcombe and Ken Rosewall struggled to threeset victories today and advanced to the semifinal round of the $35,000 Tennis South invitation tournament.

title: Conservatives in Unions Lose Faith in Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 27Organized labor, the backbone of the Peronist movement, is threatening to withdraw its support from the Argentine Government, which could further undermine President Isabel Martinez de Pern's weakening hold on power.

title: STEREO RADIO SENT BY WAY OF SATELLITE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  National Public Radio staged the first successful domestic satellite transmission of stereo radio programing today and held out hope of making it systemwide.

title: The Tide of History
description: I am not alarmed when I hear warnings that the tide of history is running against us. I do not believe it for a minute because I know where the tide of history really ison this campus, and thousands of others in this great country.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COOL BREEZE Sirocco (6839409), the Greek  Israeli nightclub at 29 East 29th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues), is a pleasant, atmospheric place, refurbished and reopened after a recent fire.

title: An Evenly Paced Race
description: LEBANON, Ohio, March 27 (AP)All eight pacers in the seventh race at Lebanon Raceway finished in the same order as their post position numbers last night. Track officials said odds against that happening were 53,760 to 1.

title: Information Chief Named
description: TRENTON, March 27 (AP)Robert Comstock today was appointed director of public information for New Jersey. He takes office April 7. Mr. Comstock, 47 years old of Wayne, is assistant editor of The Record in Hackensack. He succeeds Herbert Wolfe, who had resigned to become associate editor of The Trenton Times.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Collapsed Mideast Peace Talks Lamented in Passover Sermons
description: Rabbis in Passover sermons yesterday recalled the ancient Jews' difficulties with Egypt as they expressed concern over the breakdown in the Middle East peace negotiations and Galled on Secretary of State Kissinger to influence the. Arab states, and Egypt to engage in direct negotiations with Israel.

title: Mets Use New Ball, Win, 149
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27There were 29 hits in a game between the Mets and the Cardinals tonight, but it was difficult to tell if all the hitting was the result of a new, experimental baseball in use or the strong wind blowing to right field. The Mets outslugged the Cardinals and won. 149.

title: Dip in Oil Imports Brings A Record Trade Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A huge and probably temporary drop in oil imports moved the United States balance of trade from a deficit in January to a record surplus of $917million in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DUTCHESS SHERIFF ASKS JAIL BE SHUT
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 27Amid growing indication that the state plans to take steps to close the Dutchess County jail, the county sheriff, who has come under increasing criticism for the way he has run the jail, today urged that the facility be shut.

title: U.S. to Help Landlords Bypass Rent Limits on Many Units Here
Bomb Ring Broken Up At Illinois Grade School
description: CRESTWOOD, Ill., March 27 (AP)  The authorities have broken up a grade school bomb ring in which boys 12 to 14 years old made crude explosive pipe bombs and sold them to classmates for 35 cents each.

title: CLEMENCY PLAN WILL END MONDAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The final extension of President Ford's clemency program for draft evaders and war resisters will end at midnight Monday. Only a fraction of those eligible to participate have applied so far.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Off
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.8 billion tonmiles, 15.1 per cent below the corresponding week year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 442,200 cars, 17 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 24.4 per cent below last year.

title: Business Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH, March 27 (Reuters)A shareholder of the Gulf Oil Corporation filed suit today in Federal District Court here against Gulf's chairman, Bob R. Dorsey, and seven other former or present officers and directors seeking recovery of $10million allegedly spent illegally for political operations during the last 10 years.

title: Dutch Arrest 4 at Port
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 27, (Reuters)Four Dutch Nationals were arrested here today after the police seized 1,120 pounds of hashish that had been unloaded from a Turkish ship in this port, the police said. They said the four men were carrying the sacks to trucks.

title: People in Sports
description: Steve Blass, the pitching hero of the 1971 World Series whose two triumphs lifted the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Baltimore Orioles, may be at the end of his baseball career. Yesterday the Pirates asked waivers on the righthander for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: Academy May Put Data On Cancer in Lay Terms
Ethyl Reaches Pact To Buy Cooper Unit Of Burmah Oil Co.
description: The Ethyl Corporation reached an agreement in principle to purchase the Edwin Cooper division of the Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., for about $46million. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

title: Soviet Expected to Begin Manned Space Mission
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Knowledgeable observers in the United States think it likely that the Soviet Union will launch a twoman Soyuz spacecraft within the next several days for a mission of long duration.

title: Article 5  No Title
STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose again yesterday as volume also increased somewhat. In the overthecounter market prices also increased but volume fell slightly.

title: LOSS FOR FEBRUARY LISTED BY PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a February net loss of $25.6million for the airlin and its consolidated subsidiaries.

title: Film Said to Record Faisal's Assassination
description: CAIRO, March 27 (Reuters) The assassination of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was recorded on television news film that shows him bending forward to be kissed by the man who shot him, the Cairo newspaper Al Akhbar reported today.

title: U.S. to Help Landlords Bypass Rent Limits on Many Units Here
description: The Federal Government is prepared to aid landlords of nearly 100,000 apartmentsmost in New York City and New Jerseyby helping them seek higher rents if their buildings are financially jeopardized by local rent controls.

title: G.A.O. Finds Nixon Gift Data Lacking
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) Government auditors reported today that a number of gifts apparently received from foreign governments by President Nixon and his family were not officially recorded, while the gift records of President Johnson were found to be in order.

title: U.S. Says Arms Situation In Vietnam Is Not Critical
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Defense Department said today that despite Congressional reductions in military aid, South Vietnamese forces were not critically short of either ammunition or fuel.

title: Britons Told of Dangers In No Vote on Market
description: LONDON, March 27The Government told the British people today that if they voted ob withdraw from the Common Market in a referendum in June, they would face rising unemployment and inflation.

title: U.S. Says Arms Situation In Vietnam Is Not Critical
