description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Defense Department said today that despite Congressional reductions in military aid, South Vietnamese forces were not critically short of either ammunition or fuel.

title: DONALD S. LORD
description: Donald S. Lord, a vice president of the Public Service Electric & Gas Company in Newark, died Wednesday of a heart attack in West Orange, N.J., on his way home to Bernardsville, N. J. He was 60 years old.

title: Judge Accused of Soliciting Sex In Return for Favorable Ruling
description: RIVERHEAD, March 27 A Suffolk County Family Court judge, William M. Higgins, was indicted today on charges that he solicited sexual favors from a woman on the understanding that his decision in her case would be favorable if she consented.

title: Saigon's Weaknesses: Command Poor, Unrealistic
description: Operations in South Vietnam in the last 24 hours have underscored the weaknesses of Saigon's forces, including a tendency toward wishful thinking on the part of the high command, according to United States officers studying the rapidly deteriorating military situation.

title: Bad Times for Social Agencies
description: Private socialservice agencies are going under. But not only are the nation's disadvantaged people being cut off from needed support, so is the troubled middle class in cities.

title: New Shooting Erupts in Angolan Capital
description: LISBON, March 27 (Reuters)  Shooting was reported today in the Angolan capital of Luanda following earlier clashes between two rival liberation movements that left more than 50 dead.

title: Boat Sinks Off Coast
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., March 27 (UPI)  A charter fishing boat suddenly sank in choppy waters yesterday, going down in seconds, but the 33 persons aboard, some of whom fought for lifejackets, were saved by a harbor patrol boat that happened to be nearby. The 65foot Westerner was outside the Newport Harbor jetty, returning from a fishing trip, when she began to sink.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: State Unemployment Up By 21,800 for February
description: Unemployment in the state continued to worsen in February, with 21,800 more people counted out of work than in January and the percentage of the labor force without jobs rising from 9.3 to 9.6 per cent, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Governor's Old Law Firm Is Accused of Impropriety
description: TRENTON, March 27The State Attorney General is investigating a sworn statement that a former law partner of Governor Byrne's interviewed a Camden County public official for a top state position on the same day that the official was to vote on a multimilliondollar contract for a client of the Governor's former law firm, officials indicated here today.

title: Basque Bombings Reported
description: BILBAO, Spain, March 27 (AP)Police sources said that members of the Basque separatist movement exploded four bombs today, damaging 13 shops in Guernica and a television relay station at Legazpia, both in northern Spain. No casualties were reported.

title: FORD TO ESTABLISH CAMPAIGN AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Ford has decided to set up an independent campaign committee to raise money and seek commitments of Presidential convention delegates late this summer.

title: Jockey's First Start at Aqueduct Results in His First Triumph
description: Bobby Gilbert had his first opportunity to ride in New York yesterday and made the most of it at Aqueduct with the first victory of his fourrace career. Gilbert. 17 years old, lives at Elmont, L.I., close to Belmont Park, with his parents. His father is Bill Gilbert, who, as a jockey a generation ago, won 174 races.

title: Advertising
description: Twenty years ago U.S. News & World Report, with the help of Detroit, began to conduct and publish studies of the automotive market. The success of this effort led to combined studies of other markets in which the getting advertisers.

title: Sale Show Increase
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Bridge:
description: Cryptographers are in short supply in the bridge world. In the absence of Alfred Sheinwold of Los Angeles, who served with the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, the enthusiast who has to decode an esoteric auction is left to his own devices.

title: Ford Says Israel Lacked Flexibility in Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Ford said in an interview made public today that the chances for Middle East peace would have been enhanced if Israel had shown more flexibility in the recent negotiations for a new accord with Egypt.

title: Police Union Prepares Court Battle To Bar Enforcement of Free Duty
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday it was mounting a legal battle to prevent the Police Department from forcing officers to work five extra tours of duty without pay as they had agreed to do to save the jobs of almost 500 rookies and recruits.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 27 (UPI)The East African Safari auto rally, a fiveday endurance test across the continent's game plains, began today with 82 starters and amid the tightest security in the event's history. The added security followed a series of bombings in Nairobi in recent weeks and the murder of a prominent Kenyan politician. Leaving Nairobi, the drivers will proceed through elephant country en route to the Indian Ocean coast on the first stretch of the 5,000kilometer course, which rally officials described as the toughest in the world.

title: An Assemblyman Charges That Stein Threatened Him
description: ALBANY, March 27Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, a Queens Democrat, has filed an affidavit with the Assembly Ethics Committee charging that Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, who heads the temporary state, commission investigating nursinghome practices, had threatened him.

title: Prefontaine Is Boiling Over Amateur Rules
description: DENVER, March 27 (AP)To hell with love of country, says Steve Prefontaine, America's best amateur distance runner. I compete for myself.

title: Whose Commitment?
description: Secretary of State Kissinger has added his voice to those who would have us believe the domino theory that the collapse of South Vietnam would endanger American positions throughout the world. But Mr. Kissinger went further.

title: FORD FEELS HOUSE WOULD BACK VETO OF TAX MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Ford believes that the House of Representatives would sustain a veto of the $22.8billion taxcut bill passed last night by Congress, but it will be several days before he decides whether to sign or veto the measure, his spokesman said today.

title: Tea and Heavenly Aphorisms
description: BOULDER, Colo.To thousands of the nation's tea drinkers, Red Zinger, Mo's 24 and Sleepy Time are becoming names almost as well known as Lipton and Red Rose. They are among the 12 brands of herbal teas produced by Celestial Seasonings, a local enterprise that has blended hibiscus flowers, lemon grass, spiritualism and capitalism into a heady brew of success.

title: STATE AND UNION CUT NEGOTIATIONS
description: ALBANY, March 27Negotiators for the state and its employes adjourned contract talks today without setting any time for a further meeting, and the union distributed a flyer headed, We're prepared to shut down N.Y.S. government on April 1.

title: Mistrial Declared in Trial Of Little Ferry's Mayor
description: HACKENSACK, March 27 (AP)A mistrial was declared here today in the bribery trial of Little Ferry's Mayor, Malcolm W. Hill, and a former Councilman, Robert Simon.

title: NINE F.A.A. OFFICIALS ARE HURT IN CRASH
description: DU BOIS, Pa., March 27 (UPI) Eleven persons were injured, five seriously, today when a twinengine plane owned by the. Federal Aviation Administration crashed on takeoff from the Du BoisJefferson County Airport here.

title: The Pop Life
description: Patti Smith, the poet turned rock n roller, seems on the verge of the big timeor at least as big a time as poets turned rock n rollers can expect.

title: Ford Says Israel Lacked Flexibility in Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Ford said in an interview made public today that the chances for Middle East peace would have been enhanced if Israel had shown more flexibility in the recent negotiations for a new accord with Egypt.

title: Dip in Oil Imports Brings A Record Trade Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A huge and probably temporary drop in oil imports moved the United States balance of trade from a deficit in January to record surplus of $917million in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dollar Rises Again In Europe, Buoyed By Trade Figures
description: BRUSSELS, March 27 (UPI) A record United States trade surplus for February helped the dollar maintain its weeklong upward trend today on all European money markets. The price of gold opened higher but slipped in later trading to close down slightly for the day.

title: WARREN A. PINE
description: Warren A. Pine, who recently retired as a vice president of Pan American World Airways, in charge of development of intercontinental hotels, died March 20 in Miami. He was 66 years old and lived in Homestead. Fla.

title: Expiring Goose
description: Higher real estate taxes are a key element in the increased revenue Mayor Beame is counting on to help narrow the 197576 budget gap. But a report submitted to the City Council by the Mayor's Housing and Development Administrator, Roger Starr, shows that the ratio of uncollected taxes on privately operated apartment buildings in this city, has been climbing rapidly even under the old tax rates.

title: New Brunswick Begins a Dog Census, Seeking to Count All, Pets or Strays
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThis city of 44,000 has embarked upon what its officials hope will be the most comprehensive and accurate dog census undertaken since Capt. Henry Greenland, the first resident, settled here in 1680 with his family and pet canines of unrecorded breed and gender.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $985million, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier $950million. Total retail store sales were about $10.9billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $10.18billion.

title: Tour by Chinese Troupe Ended on Taiwan Issue
description: A monthlong United States tour by an ensemble of musicians and dancers from China that was to have begun tomorrow has been called off because the program included a song expressing determination to liberate Taiwan.

title: F.B.I. and a Utility Hit by Separate California Blasts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 Separate explosions last night damaged a building that houses the Berkeley office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and destroyed a Pacific Gas and Electric Company power substation in San Jose. There were no injuries.

title: Article 3  No Title
Philosophy Behind the Tax Bill
Rockefeller Calls on Sadat and Khalid
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 27  Vice President Rockefeller gave assurances today to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and King Khalid of Saudi Arabia that the United States was striving for a just, equitable and lasting peace in the Middle East.

title: Giants Stress Youth and a Past
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27For those who still find it difficult after 17 years to separate the words New York from the word Giants and replace them with San Francisco, a surprising amount of Polo Grounds aura remains attached to the Giant uniforms working out here.

title: 4.07 GAIN POSTED BY STOCK MARKET
description: Encouraging economic news enabled the stock market to post a modest gain yesterday in somewhat easier trading.

title: Security Funds Released
description: Mayor Beame yesterday released $2million in capital budget funds for expansion of the city's neighborhood security program. Under the Block Security Program established in 19473, the city underwrites a variety of measures that are prepared by neighborhood block and tenant associations and approved by local Police Department technical experts.

title: 8.600 Candy Bars Recalled By the F.D.A. as Rancid
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of 8,600 Peter Paul Mounds and Almond Joy candy bars that it believed were rancid.

title: Article 2  No Title
Morton, in a Cabinet Shift, Picked for Commerce Job
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The White House announced today that President Ford was shifting Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton to head the Commerce Department, and there were reliable but officially unconfirmed reports that Mr. Ford would name former Gov. Stanley K. Hathaway of Wyoming as the new Secretary of the Interior.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The North Vietnamese advanced southward along the central coastal plains of South Vietnam yesterday. Behind it virtually all the northern part of South Vietnam had been engulfed. Only the enclave of Da Nang, South Vietnam's second largest city, remained in Saigon Government hands, and the central coastal port of Qui Nhon, the country's third largest city, appeared threatened. At least eight South Vietnamese army regimentsa total of about 19,000 menhave reportedly fled, leaving equipment behind. The retreat, a Western military analyst said, was a rout beyond our wildest fears. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Prices of Soybean Futures Show Declines on Selling by Farmers
description: Prices of soybeans and most grains retreated before increased offerings by farmers, yesterday. The limit price advances of Wednesday encouraged the farmers to sell some supplies overnight.

title: 200 LEFT HOMELESS BY TEXAS TORNADO
description: LEFORS, Tex., March 27 (AP)  A threeyearold girl was killed and at least 200 persons were left homeless today when tornado touched down in this Panhandle oil town, striking again at a small community 60 miles from here.

title: TOP SEOUL RIVAL BIDS PARK RESIGN
description: SEOUL, March 27The leader of the major opposition party in South Korea challenged a new censorship law today by urging President Park Chung Hee to permit revision of the nation's Constitution and to resign.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Two kinds of dresses are in demand for summer, Bill Blass has found in his travels around the country to such places as Houston, Tulsa, St. Louis and Indianapolis. Both are for evening because except for New York, there's no street life anywherewomen just hop in their car. he says. For driving to the shopping center, there's no neea tor the expensive clothes he sellssweaters and pants do quite nicely, he agrees.

title: Sir Arthur Bliss, 83, Composer, Master of Queen's Musick, Dies
description: LONDON, March 27Sir Arthur Bliss, the composer, died at his home here today after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Ford Motor Cuts Capital Spending
description: DETROIT, March 27The Ford Motor Company cut its 197475 capital spending by a total of $268million, according to the company's annual report released today.

title: 2 Asian Envoys Quit Cambodia; Other Embassies May Be Closed
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia; March 27Two of Cambodia's Asian allies have quietly withdrawn their ambassadors from Phnom Penh and there were indications that others may soon follow.

title: A Brisk Rally Is Staged by Corporate Bond Market
description: A brisk rally rippled through the corporate bond market late yesterday, fueled by the release of critical weekly statistics by the Federal Reserve. The improvement was apparent particularly in the longterm industrial bond sector. Gains here ran as high as threequarters of a point on individual issues.

title: INDEX OF ECONOMY ROSE IN FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Government's often misleading index of leading indicators of the economy, which is about to be revamped drastically, turned upward in February, for the first time in six months, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: SUIT ACCUSES SIX IN A STOCK SCHEME
description: Two shareholders of the Two American Agronomics Corporation filed a class action suit today accusing six persons of manipulating the price of the stock from $1.50 a share to $18.37 in the final three months or 1974

title: Shoulder Pains Bonds, Adding to Yanks' Woes
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 27The longawaited millenium of the New York Yankees took another detour today when they made only one hit off the Cincinnati Reds, lost their fourth straight game and also lost Bobby Bonds with a shoulder injury.

title: Figure in I.R.S. Spying Seeks a Transfer
description: MIAMI, March 27The chief of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force here said today that he had requested a transfer to Washington, and at the same time assailed the press because of reports that Federal agents had used informers to learn about the sex lives and drinking habits of 30 prominent Florida residents.

title: Some Hope for Portugal?
description: Portugal has without doubt moved substantially further to the left with the increased representation of the Communists and their allies in the new provisional Government. Marxists not only occupy six of thirteen civilian Cabinet posts but hold portfolios critically important for Portugal's economic development: finance, economy, industry, transportation.

title: Sometimes the Price Is Exorbitant
description: In the time it took to go out to Ohio and watch Muhammad Ali posture and strut through 15 rounds, New York grew immeasurably poorer. Tuesday morning New York lost Tommy Holmes, the best baseball writer of his time, possible the best of all time, certainly one of the finest allround reporters and writers in sports. Tommy, who retired after the Herald Tribune folded, had a heart attack several years later. Last year high blood pressure put him in the hospital in the Soviet Union. Even without that experience, he might not have remembered that trip as the most enjoyable of all the trips he and his wife, Grace, made after retirement. He was not enamored of the airborne comforts on Aeroflot. They can teach a rooster to roller skate, he said of the Russians, but they can't run an airline. Recently Tommy had what he thought was a charley horse and it turned out to be a blood clot.

title: U.S. to Help Landlords Bypass Rent Limits on Many Units Here
description: The Federal Government is prepared to aid landlords of nearly 100,000 apartmentsmost in New York City and New Jerseyby helping them, seek higher rents if their buildings are financially jeopardized by local rent controls.

title: Music: A Choral Debut
description: The Philadelphia Singers, who gave their first New York concert on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, are cast in what may be called the Robert Shaw Chorale mold. The group's music director, Michael Korn, has put together a mixed chorus of 29 tightly disciplined, handpicked singers and a chamber orchestra. The repertory, according to the program notes, ranges from Back to Broadway.

title: COMMUNIST FORCE IS SURGING SOUTH; DA NANG HOLDS ON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 28The North Vietnamese advance surged southward yesterday along the central coastal plain of South Vietnam.

title: Rutgers Instructor Called Before Jury in S.L.A. Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (AP)  A Federal grand jury subpoena has been issued for Phillip K. Shinnick, a one time Olympic jumper and a friend of Jack Scott, a sports activist linked in news reports to the search for fugitive newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst, sources said today.

title: FED HEAVY BUYER IN BOND MARKET
description: The Federal Reserve bought in the week ended Wednesday more than $900million of United States Treasury notes and bondsthe strongest support, it has given the bond market in many years.

title: Pope Paul in Maundy Thursday Rite
description: ROME, March 27Pope Paul VI, performing the ageold Maundy Thursday rite, washed the feet of 12 boys from around the world tonight.

title: Morton, in a Cabinet Shift, Picked for Commerce Job
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The White House announced today that President Ford was shifting Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton to head the Commerce Department, and there were reliable but officially unconfirmed reports that Mr. Ford would name former Gov. Stanley K. Hathaway of Wyoming as the new Secretary of the Interior.

title: Fordham 9 Wins Season Debut, 115
description: Fordham opened its 1975 baseball season yesterday with an 115 victory over Holy Cross at Jack Coffey Field.

title: A YOUTH FARE CUT APPROVED BY C.A.B
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave its approval yesterday to the revival of a bargain youth fare to Europe.

title: Lagos Bars South Africans, So Press Meeting Is Shifted
description: GENEVA, March 27  The International Press Institute announced today that its 1975 assembly would be held in Zurich, not Lagos, because the Nigerian Government said it would bar South African journalists.

title: LAURENCE S. JONES
description: Laurence S. Jones, former owner of Gertner's restaurant on Fifth Avenue and former president of Frederick Braun, Inc., embroidery for children's apparel, died Tuesday at his home, 2 Sutton Place South. He was 59 years old.

title: Holiday Schedules Set
description: Major securities and cornmodities exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today in observance of the Good Friday holiday. Banks in New York will be open, but those in Connecticut and New Jersey will be closed.

title: Contract Awards
description: An agreement to establish a $180million chemical fertilizer manufacturing complex in Jordan was signed yesterday in Amman by representatives of the Jordanian Government, the Agrico Chemical Company, a subsidiary of the Williams Companies and the International Finance Corporation, a member of the World Bank Group. Agrico will own 25 per cent of the venture, known as the Jordan Fertilizer Industry Company. The contract will involve the largest single investment to date by a United States company in Jordan.

title: U.S. Army Chief in Saigon To Assess Military Situation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 28 (AP)  Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, the United States Army chief of staff, arrived today in Saigon to assess for President Ford the deteriorating military situation, including the loss of much of South Vietnam's territory to the North Vietnamese.

title: Yunich Criticizes Carey As M.T.A.Gets New Cars
description: David L. Yunich. chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, used the occasion of the delivery of four new subway cars, yesterday to criticize Governor Carey's attempt to assume considerable control over the M.T.A.

title: 14 Perish in Hotel Fire In Italian Alpine Town
description: SANTA MARIA MAGGIORE, Italy, March 27 (AP)  Fire swept through the Excelsior Hotel in this Alpine community near the Swiss border early today, killing at least 14 persons land injuring about 40, police and fire officials reported.

title: McDonnell Douglas to Idle 2,000 at Long Beach
description: LOS ANGELES, March 27 (UPI)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today a parts shortage would force it to lay off 2,000 workers at its Long Beach plant tomorrow.

title: City BeltTightening ...
description: As Mayor Beame prepares to enter his threeday budget retreat next Tuesday, it is clear that he will have to emerge with cuts in city spending and in plans for future city borrowing far beyond those in the tenpoint program he issued last weekend.

title: About Real Estate
description: There a is a large apartment house in Woodside, Queens, built only 14 years ago, that is marching relentlessly into insolvency.

title: PUBLIC TV RAISES $5MILLION PLEDGES
description: The Festival '75 fundraising campaign of public television stations across the United States brought in more than 200,000 new subscribers and more than $5million in contribution pledges, according to figures released by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Reader's Digest: Condensation of Its Sales Techniques and Forays Into New Ventures
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y.,A few years ago, President Nixon, on one of his infrequent visits to New York, was the overnight guest in northern Westchester of Hobart D. Lewis, then president of the Reader's Digest and now its chairman and editor in chief.

title: Gun Victim Weighs Surgery
description: MADISON, Wis., March 27 (UPI)Paul Rogers, 23 years old, the paroled Milwaukee man who refused to let doctors operate after he shot himself in an apparent suicide attempt last Friday, may undergo surgery after all. Jan Wheeler, legal counsel for the State Division of Corrections, said that Mr. Rogers had changed his mind after talking with his probation and parole officer, his doctor his father and Mr. Wheeler.

title: 4 LAWYERS FOCUS ATTACK ON SUTTON
description: NEWARK, March 27Arthur J. Sutton, the chief Government witness in the Fort Lee bribery trial in Federal Court here became the chief target of the defense lawyers today in their summations.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 28, 1975

title: Thieu Is Urged to Yield Powers to a New Regime
description: SAIGON, south Vietnam, March 27A group of opposition politicians meeting today with former Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky urged President Nguyen Van Thieu to turn over full powers to a new Government that would pursue new policies to save the nation.

title: OilDepletionAllowance Cut in Tax Bill Called Loss to Industry and Consumers
description: The petroleum industry and Wall Street energy analysts greeted the new tax bill with resignation yesterday and predicted that the American consumer would be the ultimate loser from its provisions for the elimination of the oildepletion allowance and changes in foreign tax regulations.

title: Members of Committee
description: The executive committee of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association currently consists of the following members:

title: SUSPENDED GUARD IS SHOT FROM A CAR
description: A correction officer under suspension and indictment for allegedly beating a prisoner was wounded by a shotgun blast from a passing car early yesterday on a Queens street.

title: An Elite Still Calls Tune on Met Board
description: Based on decisions now being made and others that will have to be made soon, the Metropolitan Opera will live or die, or perhaps gasp along for years on some notquiteterminal state. Those decisions are in the handsnominally, at leastof the Met's board of directors, a group of 51 members, most of them wealthy, many of them socially eminent, and some of them knowledgeable about the arts.

title: Reader's Digest: Condensation of Its Sales Techniques and Forays Into New Ventures
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y.,A few years ago, President Nixon, on one of his infrequent visits to New York, was the overnight guest in northern Westchester of Hobart D. Lewis, then president of the Reader's Digest and now its chairman and editor in chief.

title: Arab and Iranian Students Increasing at U.S. Colleges
description: STILLWATER, Okla.Once a month Ramadan Omeish and nine other Arab students at Oklahoma State University visit a farm on the outskirts of Stillwater and buy 10 sheep.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 28, 1975

title: European Talks, in Final Phase, Recess for Holiday
description: GENEVA, March 27  Negotiations on European security recessed for the Easter holiday today after the Soviet Union proposed that the final document be signed in four separate parts at a summit meeting in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Localities Seeking Tax Rises as U.S. Is Preparing Cuts
description: Soaring inflation, shrinking Federal aid and growing demands for public services are forcing many of the nation's city and suburban officials to seek increases in local taxes at a time when the Federal Government is deciding to cut taxes.

title: Arab and Iranian Students Increasing at U.S. Colleges
description: STILLWATER, Okla.Once a month Ramadan Omeish and nine other Arab students at Oklahoma State University visit a farm on the outskirts of Stillwater and buy 10 sheep.

title: U.S. Votes Against Program For ThirdWorld Industry
description: LIMA, Peru, March 27 (Reuters)The United States was the only country today to vote against a program to increase the third world's share of global industry to 25 per cent by the end of this century.

title: Chinese Aide Visits Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, March 27 (Reuters)  Deputy Premier Chen Yungkuei of China arrived here today for a nineday visit. Mr. Chen, one of the leading figures in China's agrarian development, will spend most of his visit touring farming areas.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Whether there's a campaign going on or whether it's only coincidence I don't know, but a lot of readers of this column seem to be getting wrought up over the question of frozen foods served in restaurants and want to know what my stand is. Somebody even telephoned from Chicago to enlist my support for legislation that would require restaurants to state, alongside each dish on the menu, whether or not any of ingredients had been frozen or otherwise preprepared.

title: Stage: Afternoon Tea
description: HARTFORD, March 27In the first place, Paul Weidner, the producing director of the Hartford Stage Company, deserves some kind of award for gallantry, enterprise and imagination for staging Harvey Peres interestingly interminable short play, Afternoon Tea.

title: Carey, With Budget Passed, Faces Reality
description: ALBANY, March 27  The Capital's weary relief at meeting the April 1 deadline with a new state budget has for the moment obscured the fact that the most grinding political and fiscal battles over taxes and more spending are still ahead, when the Legislature returns from its threeweek recess. The compromise that the legislative leaders worked out agreeing to pass a $10.4billion expenditure budget with the tacit understanding that new taxes would come lateraverted the chaos of payless paydays and allowed the two political parties to accommodate each other without relinquishing their basic positions.

title: CHARLES SUTHERLAND
description: Charles Moseley Sutherland. a retired art teacher, died last Saturday at his home in Bronxvile, N. Y. He was 74 years old.

title: Business Backs Most Tax Bill Provisions
description: Businessmen and their economic advisors endorsed most provisions of Congress's new tax bill yesterday, but few of those interviewed were notably enthusiastic.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, March 27, 1975

title: Localities Seeking Tax Rises as U.S. Is Preparing Cuts
description: Soaring inflation, shrinking Federal aid and growing demands for public services are forcing many of the nation's city and suburban officials to seek increases in local taxes at a time when the Federal Government is deciding to cut taxes.

title: A Fleeing Holdup Man Ends Chase by Suicide
description: An armed robber fleeing with about $80 from a Harlem clothing store fatally shot himself yesterday afternoon as two Transit Authority officers chased him along West 145th Street, the police reported.

title: How the Duty Charts Led To City Clash With Police
description: The confrontation between the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association involves a work schedule that the city originally fought to put into effect over the union's opposition, and that the union now insists on keeping.

title: FORD FEELS HOUSE WOULD BACK VETO OF TAX MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Ford believes that the House of Representatives would sustain a veto of the $22.8billion taxcut bill passed last night by Congress, but it will be several days before he decides whether to sign or veto the measure, his spokesman said today.

title: Howe Eclipses 2,000 Points
description: HOUSTON, March 27 (AP) Gordie Howe became the first player in major league history to reach 2,000 points with two goals and an assist tonight in the Houston Aeros' 80 World Hockey Association victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Pressures in Advertising Scored
description: Advertising and marketing people have their problems with regulation the world round. In the Netherlands, for example, all TV commercials for candy are required to show for their entire length a toothbrush at least onetenth the height of the screen

title: 6 Companies Plan to Halt Film Shipments to Iran
description: Six major movie companies plan to halt shipments of their films to Iran, starting Monday. The companiesWarner Pros., Paramount, 20th CenturyFox, United Artists, Universal and MetroGoldwynMayer  want Iran to increase admission prices. Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Export Association said the American companies receive a percentage of the admissions.

title: Localities Seek Increased Tax Levies
Market Place
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation is retiring an issue of cumulative convertible preferred stock. And if history is any measure, some holders of the stock will be disappointed.

title: College Results
Thailand Ready to Aid Cambodia Peace Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 27 (Reuters) Thailand is ready to offer her good offices to help restore peace in Cambodia, Foreign minister Chatichai Choonhavan said here today.

title: HOUSING INDUSTRY HAILS TAX CREDIT
description: LOS ANGELES, March 27Buy Now. $2,000 Government Tax Rebate.

title: Pravda Criticizes Kissinger's Mideast Approach
description: MOSCOW, March 27  The official party newspaper Pravda said today that the failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's mission to the Middle East has again reaffirmed the hopelessness of attempts at socalled partial solutions to the Middle East problem by means of quiet diplomacy.

title: Why Blacks Don't Vote
description: ATLANTAThe Voting Rights Act of 1965 is up for renewal this year, and it is essential that it be reenacted The law, one of the most important pieces a legislation in United States history, has contributed enormously to the transformation of the South. Not only has it enfranchised large numbers of black citizens and led to the election of hundreds of them to public office, it has also helped release the region's dynamic growth. Much more remains to be done.

title: Wood, Field & Strearn
description: BABYLON, L.I.A splendid black duck by John Sheeler of Mays Landing, N. J., won the bestinshow award for a working decoy carved by a professional at the National Decoy Show here last weekend.

title: Turkey Acts to Prevent Entry of Fleeing Kurds
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 27 (Reuters)  Turkey today proclaimed martial law along her 210mile border with Iraq, underscoring her determination to block entry of Kurdish rebels fleeing from the battlegrounds of northern Iraq.

title: 7 IN FAMILY KILLED BY BALTIMORE FIRE
description: BALTIMORE, March 27 (AP) At least seven members of a northeast Baltimore family died early this morning in a row house fire, officials said.

title: GERALD D. NELSON
description: Gerald D. Nelson, who retired in 1957 as director of laboratory services of RCA Laboratories, Inc., of Princeton, N. J., died Wednesday evening, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, in Putnam Hospital, Bennington, Vt. He was 82 years old and lived in Bennington.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division, First Department, yesterday denied a motion to quash the subpoenas of 13 persons who argued that a special grand jury was unconstitutionally impaneled because women were exempt from serving when the jury was formed more than two years ago. In a fourpage unanimous opinion, the Appellate Court ruled that a United States Supreme Court decision last January, which found that criminal trial juries must be drawn from panels reflecting female representation in the community, was not retroactive. The 13, subpoenaed by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, must now appear before the grand jury, which is investigating the theft of $70million in heroin and cocaine from the Police Department property clerk's office.

title: About New York
description: Henry Schroer had a hangover, his first in years, but manfully he stood, talked and smiled, anyway. Hey, what's the matteryou don't feel like working? he was saying. He was talking to a camel, who, being recalcitrant, would not do what Mr. Schroer wanted him to do. Mr. Schroer wanted him to Waltz.

title: STATE VOIDS BAN ON INCINERATOR
description: NEWARK, March 27The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners today told Jersey City it had overstepped its authority in closing down its incinerator and ordered the city to reopen the facility, which is on Route 40.

title: INDIAN RESERVATION IS SCENE OF KILLING
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., March 27 (UPI)The sisterinlaw of a slain American Indian Movement leader was killed yesterday as she sat in her car on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Attorney General's office agreed to do its homework over the weekend and issue an opinion early next week on whether the state had the authority to delay $5million in yearly registration fees for outofwork dirt haulers.

title: SUPERDOME STUDY FINDS FAVORTISM
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 27The management of the Louisiana Superdome  the world's largest covered stadium, now nearing completion here  has involved extensive political favoritism, public deception, and possible criminal violations by state officials and contractors, according to an investigative report released today.

title: I.C.C. Lets Rock Island File Surcharge Plans
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday that it would allow the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad to file freight rate surcharge plans of $30 per car and $15 per piggy back trailer for freight traffic originating or terminating on the Rock Island line.

title: Quake in Rockies
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 28 (AP)  An earthquake rocked the central Rocky Mountains tonight. There were no immediate reports of damage.

title: S.E.C. Lays Fraud To Hughes on Deal
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 .. The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Howard R. Hughes today of fraud and manipulation in connection with the billionaire's acquisition in 1969 of Air West, which serves 69 cities in the Western United States, Canada and Mexico.

title: . . . For State Response
description: Once the city has established the good faith of its own effort, the ball will pass to Governor Carey to act as cosponsor with the Mayor of a program for rounding out the needed support from the Federal Government, the state and the banks.

title: Books of The Times
description: Edgar Degas was certainly the greatest of the impressionists, partly because he was the one whose art depended least on specifically impressionist devices. And yet as soon as we make a statement like that about him, his alliances with impressionist theory and practice seem to flare up to deny ithis mastery of effects of light by means of broken color, his concentration on commonplace subjects new to serious painting, his ways of capturing his models in the fleeting unposed attitudes of daily life. But immediately the counterarguments to these rebuttals demand attention: effects of light, yes, but never the, natural light that was the sine qua non of pure impressionism. Concentration on everyday subjects, yes, but subjects observed with the probing eye of a psychologist rather than with the eyeasaprism that impressionism popularized. And no other artist of any century ever synthesized apparently unposed attitudes with a degree of analytical invention approaching Degas's.

title: COMMUNIST FORCE IS SURGING SOUTH; DA NANG HOLDS ON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 28The North Vietnamese advance surged southward yesterday along the central coastal plain of South Vietnam.

title: Nicklaus: 66 in the Wind
Nader Alleges Mail Was Monitored
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accused the United States Postal Service today of monitoring, and possibly opening, dozens of letters addressed to Public Citizen, an organization, headed by Mr. Nader, that engages in litigation with a variety of Federal agencies.

title: Freehold Tax Chief Loses ExtortionConviction Appeal
description: TRENTON, March 27 (UPI)The extortion conviction of the Freehold Tax Assessor, Alfred Parenteau, was upheld today by the Superior Court's Appellate Division.

title: Article 1  No Title
Soviet Starts Nuclear Plant
description: MOSCOW, March 27 (Reuters) Work has begun near Kalinin on the Volga River on what will be the Soviet Union's largest atomic power station, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: S.I.A. HEAD VIEWS COMPETITIVE FEES
description: The head of the Securities Industry Association yesterday disputed the widespread belief that price competition on brokerage fees would cut deeply into the profitability of stockbrokers. Brokers have been ordered by the Securities and Exchange Comission to negotiate fees with their customers beginning in May.

title: 6 Doctors Held in Carolina Drug Raids
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 27Six North Carolina physicians were arrested yesterday on charges of illegal distribution of amphetamine and barbiturate drugs.

title: Rule of Saudi Royal Family Is Firm Despite Vast Social Change
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 27  Armed guards tramped desert dust under the huge chandeliers of the 200room palace. Courtiers in gold  trimmed robes whispered urgently into walkietalkies. And when Vice President Rockefeller met Saudi Arabia's new King, he found three royal brothers on hand as well.

title: Cavaliers Beat Bulls, Gain in Bid
description: CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI) Dick Snyder scored 11 points to help the Cleveland Cavaliers outscore the Chicago Bulls 172 in a span of 4 minutes 22 seconds of the third quarter tonight to set up an 86.83 triumph in the National Basketball Association. It was the first time the Cavaliers have won on the Bulls' court.

title: 21,800 MORE ADDED TO STATE JOBLESS
description: Unemployment in the state continued to worsen in February, with 21,800 more people counted out of work than in January and the percentage of the labor force without jobs rising from 9.3 to 9.6 per cent, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: HUTTER WILLIAMS
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., March 27 (AP)Hutter Williams, news editor of The Daily Advance here, died Tuesday night at his home. He was 42 years old.

title: Tax Cut's Propulsion
description: Talk turned to action this month when Congress, in a rush for Easter recess, passed a massive tax cut in the waning hours of Wednesday night. The legislation, according to most analysts, should propel the country a giant step closer to the economic recovery that has eluded it for a long and difficult 16 months. By fall, they say, the economy should be on the way up again.

title: France's Reds Battling Socialists for Top Role
description: PARIS, March 27  The French Communist party is battling to establish a position of leadership over the Socialists among opposition leftists and. in the process, has become locked in a bitter struggle with the Government.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Aspirin Puzzles
description: It may seem puzzling that there are puzzles about aspirin, a relatively old drug so taken for granted that its 75th birthday slipped by unobserved and unhonored last year. It is probably the most frequently used pharmaceutical that exists; some estimates suggest that as many as 20 billion tablets will be ingested in this country this year. Most will be taken to relieve a headache or other pain, but others to reduce fever or combat inflammation.

title: College Placement Service for Blacks Needs $340,000 to Avoid Disbanding
description: An organization that has helped place more than 250,000 blacks in some of the nation's major colleges and universities is on the verge of bankruptcy.

title: 5 NATO Countries Voice Unease Over Lisbon Shift
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Administration officials expressed satisfaction today that five Atlantic alliance countries had voiced concern to Portugal this week about the leftward turn there and that more were expected to follow.

title: JOHN H. BEGLEY
description: John H. Begley, a vice president of RKO General, Inc., died Wednesday evening, apparently of A heart attack, at his home, 105 East 38th Street. He was 62 years old.

title: Ford Signs Aid Bill Totaling $3.7Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)President Ford today signed into law a $3.7billion appropriation for foreign aid for the 12 months ending this July but expressed considerable misgivings over deep Congressional cuts in his request.

title: Notes on People
description: The new president of the United Negro College Fund is Dr. Milton K. Curry Jr., 55 years old, president for the last 23 years of Bishop College in Dallas and a graduate of Morehouse College in Atlanta. Dr. Curry, elected at a board meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, succeeds Dr. Herman H. Long, president of Talladega College in Alabama. Morris B. Abram, New York lawyer and former president of Brandeis University, was reelected chairman.

title: STEVE BARRIE DEAD; CANCER PUBLICIST, 62
description: Steve Barrie, who had been director of special events for the American Cancer Society for almost 30 years, died after surgery at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 62 years old and lived at 4710 Skillman Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens.

title: World Trade Talks Reach a Deadlock Over Agriculture
description: GENEVA, March 27 The new round of world trade negotiations ran into its first major snag today when the initial session on agriculture was adjourned in deadlock.

title: Newark's Council Cuts Budget by $450,000
description: NEWARK, March 27  The City Council today presented an amended budget at a public hearing that trims nearly $450,000 from the budget presented earlier this month by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, and set a municipal property tax rate of $9.94 for each $100 of assessed valuation instead of the $10.24 a $100 proposed by the Gibson administration March 17.

title: Kissinger's Utopian Principles
description: WASHINGTON, March 27In defense of the Administration's embattled policy on both Southeast Asia and the Middle East, Secretary of State Kissinger suggested in his latest press conference several general principles to guide us through our present troubles:

title: House Vote Splits 27 State Democrats Along Conservative and Liberal Lines
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The 27 Democrats from New York State in the House of Representatives have split virtually down the middle in a vote that appears to have pitted the conservative members against the liberals.

title: State QuarterHorse Division Dissolved Without Ever Having Staged a Race
description: After producing nothing but annual reports and a brochure explaining quarterhorse racing for New Yorkers, the Quarter Horse Division of the State Racing aid Wagering Board has been dissolved  without ever staging a race.

title: N.H.L. Battle for Two Playoff Spots
description: RANGERSHome: March 30, Kansas City; April 6, Islanders. Away: March 29, Islanders; April 3, Philadelphia; 4, Atlanta.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Weekended March 21, 1975

title: Notes on People
description: The cancellation of an American tour by 60 Chinese performers was protested yesterday by a group that, in a telegram to Secretary of State Kissinger, called the action censorship and a retreat from the 1972 Shanghai communiqu signed by the United States and China. The tour was called off Thursday because the program included a song expressing determination to liberate Taiwan.

title: A Rockefeller Protege Moves Into the Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 27It was back in 1968, in the snows of a New Hampshire Presidential primary, that James M. Cannon decided, he says, to get out of the grandstand and go down on the playing field. The grandstand was his career as a journalist: the playing field has turned out to be the White House.

title: FINE PIANO RECITAL BY CLAUDE SAVARD
description: Hearing Claude Savard play a stimulating program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night, one regretted that the demand for pianists of his intelligence, sensitivity and skill is not greater than it is.

title: ROSE BRAUDE
description: Rose Stern Braude, who had been a teacher in public and parochial schools here for 45 years until her retirement 10 years ago, died of a heart ailment yesterday in French Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at the Brewster Hotel, 21 West 86th Street.

title: Pro Transactions
Love Computer Shows That Data Can Be Blind
description: When her nineyear marriage ended in separation last summer, Wendy Mott went to a computer dating service to see if it could supply her with the name of a compatible man.

title: Expo '74 Reports Deficit Covered by Money Pledges
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 28 (AP)Expo '74 will probaby suffer a $724,000 operating deficit, but no one will lose a red cent because they did business with us, directors Were told at their final meeting today.

title: TWO GET 199 YEARS FOR RACIAL SLAYING
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 28 (AP)Comparing the racial slaying of a white youth to the Nazi annihilation bf Jews in World War II, a circuit judge has sentenced two black men convicted of seconddegree murder to 199 years in prison.

title: Ice Cream Recipe Was Same  Results Weren't
description: For those who yearn for ice cream with the oldtime taste unencumbered by emulsifiers, stabilizers or other artificial ingredients, several ice cream makers have been placed on the market at prices ranging from $15 to $40. In a recent blind tasting, ice cream was made in five different machines with ingredients that yielded ice cream at a cost of about $1.20 a pint.

title: ROCK ISLAND GIVEN EXTENSION OF LIFE
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (UPI)United States District Court Judge Frank J. McGarr ordered the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad today to continue operations at least through May 15 and appointed a Chicago attorney, William M. Gibbons, as trustee for the bankrupt line.

title: Article 1  No Title
Vault Record Is Set at 186
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 28 (AP) Dave Roberts set a world record in the pole vault today by soaring 18 feet 61/2 inches in the Florida Relays at the University of Florida.

title: Plutonium Warning
description: A few pounds of plutonium suffice to make an atom bomb. Ingested Into a human body, even a minute amount of plutonium can be lethal for it is the most poisonous existing substance. These facts are well known.

title: E.E.C. MOVE ASKED ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: PARIS, March 28For the first time since the European Common Market was founded two decades ago, a national steel federation is calling for Community protection against imports.

title: Dollar At Month High In Trading in Tokyo
description: BRUSSELS, March 28 (UPI) The dollar hit a onemonth high in Tokyo today and traded mixed on the few European money markets that were open on the Good Friday holiday.

title: National's NoFrills Flights At 35% Saving Approved
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave National Airlines the goahead yesterday for a no frills service that will slash many fares 35 per cent for passengers willing to forgo meals and liquor, fly on weekdays, and buy tickets a week in advance.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times last Saturday that the Sri Chinmoy Center had set up a table at the Earth Day celebration at Battery Park. Actually, the followers of Sri Chinmoy, a meditation leader, were working at the table of another organization.

title: Ancient Penitential March
description: CIVITAVECCHIA, Italy, March 28More than 100 barefoot, whitehooded figures emerged from the Church of the Dead here tonight for a Good Friday penitential procession that dates back to medieval times.

title: ALL 6 CONVICTED IN FT. LEE BRIBERY
description: NEWARK, March 28All six men and two corporations standing trial in the Fort Lee bribery case were found guilty tonight by a jury in Federal court here. The jury returned the verdict shortly before midnight after deliberating for six hours and 40 minutes.

title: Mother Finds Baby Drowned in Bathtub; SleepIn Maid Held
description: A 66yearold livein maid who worked for an upper East Side couple for eight years was arrested yesterday in the slaying of the couple's 11monthold son, according to the police.

title: ETHEL S. TAYLOR
description: Ethel Stoddard Taylor, a writer and former actress, died Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 80 years old.

title: College Results
U.S.CITY DISPUTE BARS ROAD WORK
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Federal and city officials are involved in a dispute that is delaying Federal approval for six New York road projects totaling $25million.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Just inside Macy's, by the main Broadway door, a crowd of, women are daily acting as happy as children let loose in a candy store. The area houses The Face Factory, where hundreds of shades of lipstick, eye makeup, foundations, powders and makeup accessories are openly displayed.
