title: S. W. Schwartz to Wed Miss Horowitz May 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Horowitz of East Windsor, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Horowitz, to Steven William Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray A. Schwartz of Merrick, L.I.

title: The U.S. Influence Remains but It Is Shadowy Now
description: SAIGONPresident Nguyen Van Thieu is now commanding an army in retreat, a nation in disarray and a populace that seems panicky and frightened. In this bloodsoaked land, Mr. Thieu. is now facing the most critical hour of his career and, it appears, he is facing it increasingly alone.

title: Miss Donaghy Fiancee Of Robert V. Blake
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Thomas Donaghy of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Patricia Donaghy, to Robert Vincent Blake, who will graduate in June from the New York Medical College. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Blake of Ridgefield Park. N.J.

title: Haldeman Says Nixon Weighed Replacing Agnew
description: In his first term as President, Richard M. Nixon considered the possiblity of seeking Spiro T. Agnew's resignation as Vice President and appointing John B. Connally as his successor under the 25th Amendment, according to Mr. Nixon's former chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman.

title: Western Europe's Jews Feel Sense of Wariness
description: PARIS, March 27  After nearly three decades of respite from overt antiSemitism, the profound skepticism of the Jews of Europe is intensifying once again.

title: Marriage Planned By Wendy Parker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Parker Jr. of Plainfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Parker, to Mark William Knudsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leif L. Knudsen of Orinda, Calif.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Gates Brown of the Detroit Tigers doesn't appreciate being rated one of the most valuable pinchhitters in either league: I'm not paid like I'm valuable. I have to fight for a raise every year . . . and they don't give me a chance to make more. How can I make more if I only get to bat 99 times?

title: Summit Kill
description: By Clark Howard. 206 pp. New York: Pinnacle Books. Paper, $1.25.

title: Pordham's Crew Wins Ewald Cup
description: Fordham University's varsity eight made the official unveiling of its new old noathouse on the chilly waters of the Harlem a triumphant one this afternoon by defeating Iona College and Notre Dame in the Ewald Cup competition.

title: Miss Brody Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brody of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanne Adrienne Brody, to Glen Steven Rosengarten of Tarrytown. N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosengarten of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Miss Gad to Be Bride of Alan Fischman
description: Sherry Lynn Gad and Alan S. Fischman will be married June 22 in Peekskill, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Gad of Peekskill have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Fischman of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: State Terms Bid for Hospital in Lawrence Withdrawn, L.I. Jewish Presses Plan
description: The State Department of Health has Informed Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center that the hospital's proposal to build a new facility on a site straddling the Queens  Nassau boundary, which would replace its present facility in Far Rockaway, is considered withdrawn.

title: Has Martin Scorsese Gone Hollywood?
description: More than ever before, the movie studios are terrified to try anything new. They want to repeat past successes, and they have found a new generation of filmmakers willing to oblige them. During the sixties young directors dreamed of becoming the American Bergman or Fellini. Today's young filmmakers are more likely to emulate Peter Bogdanovich, the filmbuffturneddirector who has built his career on clever reproductions of the genre movies of the thirties and forties.

title: Further Court Tests Are Awaited on Issue of Access to MigrantLabor Camps
description: CAMDENThe issue of access to migrantlabor camps is before the state courts again, this time in trials growing out of incidents last summer on a fruit and vegetable farm near Swedesboro.

title: Albert and Rhodes Arrive In China for a 10Day Visit
description: PEKING, March 29, (Reuters) The Democratic and Republican leaders of the House of Representatives arrived here today on a 10day visit to China.

title: Hungary Leads in Swimming
description: LONDON, March 29 (AP)Andras Hargitay paced Hungary to a narrow halfway lead today in the 14nation swimming tournament at the Crystal Palace pool. Hargitay won the 400meter individual medley, the last event on the first day, in 4 minutes 32.39 seconds.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Like the variable and inclement spring weather, the nation's economy is continuing to show uncertain and very mixed trends at the moment and is emitting no conclusive evidence about its likely performance for the next several months.

title: Celia C. Riely Bride of M. W. Lewis
description: Celia Carrington Riely, daughter of Mrs. James Evans Riely of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mr. Riely, was married there yesterday afternoon to Michael Wyndham Lewis of Hong Kong. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's mother

title: NBC's Ford Coverage Delayed by Basketball
description: NBC television delayed its broadcast of President Ford's speech on his decision to sign the taxcut bill for more than 10 minutes last night while it finished televising the U.C.L.A.Louisville basketball game.

title: Carolyn Whigham Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Whigham of Newark have announced the engagement of their (laughter. Carolyn M. Whigham, to Malcolm N. Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Bennett of Los Angeles. The wedding is planned for Aug. 2.

title: Access: A Film to Aid the Retarded
description: TEANECK  They said they wanted me for a movie, Ted Erwin recalled. I said, Forget it, I'm retired. Then they said it was for retarded children, and I said, That's not a request, it's a command.

title: David Anderson to Wed Amanda Davis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hanford G. Davis of Brandon, Vt., and Willshoro Point, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Hale Davis, to David Stuart Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Anderson of Pittsford. Vt.

title: NEW MIDEAST STAND IS SEEN BY SENATOR
description: PARIS, March 29A strong and almost total bipartisan foreign policy with regard to the Mideast has developed in the last 10 days within the United States, according to Senator Hugh Scott, Republican leader in the Senate, and coleader with Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of an eightman Senatorial study tour of Western Europe.

title: Colonels Top Nets, 126 to 95
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29  In a game punctuated by a fight, the Kentucky Colonels routed the New York Nets, 12695, tonight at Freedom Hall and cut the Nets' lead over them in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division to a halfgame.

title: SONG PROGRAM GIVEN BY GERALD HAMILTON
description: Gerald Hamilton appears to be a man who has enjoyed singing for a long time. He gave two recitals here in the nineteensixties and Friday night, after an interval of nine years, came to Carnegie Recital Hall for his third. He brought with him a friendly audience of enthusiastic listeners, and the event was pleasantly informal.

title: Concert: The String Revival in Debut
description: A firstrate string ensemble made up of 20 of the better freelance players in New York made its debut in Wollman Auditorium at Columbia University on Tuesday night under the direction of Howard Shanet, chairman of Columbia's music department.

title: Boating Crime Shows 20% Rise in Metropolitan Area
description: Crime . . . it usually happens to somebody else. But if you are a boatman, the odds are growing that you would be a victim unless some simple, common sense precautions are taken. Theft of boats and equipment is a big problem and growing in the Metropolitan area, says Capt. B. Russell Henry, chief of the New Jersey Marine Police.

title: Town of Langtry, Tex., For Sale For $750,000
description: LANGTRY, Tex., March 29 This community of 37 inhabitants, where Judge Roy Bean frequently served as judge, prosecutor, defense attorney and jury while administering the law west of the Pecos, is for sale for $750,000.

title: It Has a Lot of Friends
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress adopted new farm legislation two years ago, Agriculture Secretary Earl Butz hailed it as a historic turning point in the philosophy of farm programs in the United States. By dumping the rigid price supports and planting controls that had characterized American agriculture for years, the new law was a major step toward moving the Government out of agriculture, said President Nixon.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Mr. Fixit for the $50Million Telephone Job
description: When Lee Oberst was a boy fixing radios as a hobby in the South Bronx he already knew he wanted to work in an electrical environment. He could have hardly imagined, however, that he would one day be earning over $80,000 a year and working up to 20 hours a day while directing several thousand people in the restoration of the silenced telephone system of a large part of the entire city.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: Weddings
description: OstuwChaliff

title: PATIENTS' RIGHTS DISCUSSED IN BOOK
description: Though 34 million Americans are admitted to hospitals annually and the average person will be hospitalized 11 times in a lifetime, many hospitals are human rights wastelands.

title: Have Jump Shot Will Travel
description: By Charles Rosen. 204 pp. New York: Arbor House. $6.95.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Angler's Decline
description: Oh, how swiftly the seasons flee!

title: NUMISMATICS
description: To thousands of collectors in and around the Greater New York area, the arrival of spring is not so much marked by robins or crocuses as by the Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention. The 19th edition of this annual event, generally known as the granddaddy of New York's major coin shows, will open to the public next Thursday, April 3, at 1 P.M., in the BarbisonPlaza Hotel, 101 West 58th Street and Central Park South.

title: WILLIAMS COLLINS
description: William Collins, who retired in 1958 as a director of the American Federation of Laborand Congress of Industrial Organizations after 45 years with the union and its predecessors died yesterday in Maplewood. N.J. He was 9 years old and lived in Clifton, N.J. He leaves a son, William Jr.

title: Oceanic Independence Is Sailing Under New Flag
description: The 683foot passenger liner Oceanic Indepedence, a regular visitor to the port years ago as American Export Lines' Independence, is now at sea en route from Baltimore to Cape Town, South Africa, under new management and with a new career as a cruise ship. The 30,293ton steamship, built in 1950 by Bethlehem Steel Company, is now owned by the Chinese C. Y. Tung interests. She was acquired from American Export last year after Congress passed special enabling legislation to permit her transfer to foreign ownership.

title: CUBA POLICY IN U.S. SLOWLY CHANGING
description: WASHINGTON, March 29By small degrees, United States policy toward Cuba is changing. Some officials are beginning to discuss the stage where Washington could contemplate resuming relations with Havana.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Tommy, Ken Russell's screen elaboration of The Who's rock opera written by Pete Townshend, is the movie that proves that there are times when much too much may be just about right, when overindulgence approaches art, when to allow oneself to become the victim is to triumph as the victor. The movie that pretends to be blasphemous is an allout Christian assault on the senses. Salvation is the message but Tommy couldn't care less about appealing to reason. It doesn't want to convert men's minds. It wants to paralyze them. It pounds you, insults you, mauls you, and drills holes into your eardrums .in case salvation turns out to be a matter of physical implantation, something the missionaries never thought of.

title: Pity the poor comic
description: I have always been fascinated by the terrible passion of the standup comic, a man whose monstrous confidence is matched only by the fixed, abject conviction that he stinks. I have known many of them over the years, good and bad, loved them all and pitied beyond measure the bad ones. The standup comic is a man who, as they used to say, does his act in one, alone, even if he gets to work with other actors in motion pictures or on television or in a play, rather than just on the tiny floor of a nightclub with a single harsh spot on him, possibly a handkerchief in one hand, a microphone in the other.

title: TV VIEW
description: Whither public television? The question, a perennial favorite is being pondered once again, and nonsensical charges are flowing freely along with nervous explanations. The latest round has been triggered by a dissenting statement delivered by Commissioner Benjamin L. Hooks of the Federal Communications Commission. In a 6to1 decision, the F.C.C. rejected a Puerto Rican group's petition to deny the license of New York's WNET/13 on the basis of discriminatory programing and employment practices. Mr. Hooks, the agency's only black commissioner, used the occasion to heap sarcastic rhetoric on the station.

title: They Can't Be Workaholics They're Having Too Much Fun
description: Beverly Sills appeared on the Johnny Carson Show not long ago, gaily described herself as a workaholic and proceeded to outline her rigorous life as an opera star. All she does, she said enthusiastically, is work, work and more work.

title: BEATRICE AUFSES
description: Beatrice Hauser Aufses, who until recently had been editor of the Harlem Hospital Medical Bulletin and the Mount Sinai Hospital Alumni News, died of a heart ailment at Mount Sinai yesterday. She was 74 years old and lived at 301 East 66th Street.

title: OUSTING OF FORD BY COURT URGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 29A 64yearold selfstyled consultant to lawyers has gone into Federal Court here seeking a ruling that President Ford's appointment as Vice President was unconstitutional and that he thus has no right to occupy the White House today.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Crete, you will find the island remote and poor in comparison with Athens, but you will also find that prices are considerably lower. Crete produces much of its own food, a factor that helps keep the cost of eating down, and inexpensive hotel rooms are in ample supply.

title: The Health Business: BuiltIn Stability
description: Some hospitals report an Increasing number of patients cannot pay for their care because they have lost their health insurance along with their jobs. Doctors and others in the health field complain that their bill collections are slowing.

title: Ann Meyers Is AllAmerican, Like Brother
description: Some victories and accomplishments are celebrated with as much fanfare as a Fourth of July parade, while others are celebrated more subtly. That incongruity was of some salvation to Ann Meyers of the U.C.L.A. women's basketball team when she left her home in LaHabra. Calif., last week en route to Arlington. Va., where she was to be named to the first Eastman Kodak Women's allAmerica basketball team. Only Miss Meyers's two younger brothers knew of her selection to the team, and that she was being flown by Eastman Kodak to the East Coast to receive her certificate during a dinner for the team.

title: The Church Offering An Annual Accounting
description: The 1974 annual report, bound in green and yellow with introductory remarks by the controller and an accountant's opinion from Touche Ross & Co. appended, may resemble the normal corporate communique but there are some important differences. For one, it was not required by the Securities and Exchange Commission. For another, there is no provision for taxes.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: There are about as many theories as to how bowling should be played as there are bowlers, and, as you probably know, there are 50 million bowlers in this country alone.

title: Easter in Crete: A Family Affair
description: EASTER is different in Greece. Not simply the date (May 4 this year), but the spirit of the celebration as well. On Zorba's elongated Mediterranean island Of Crete, the holiday atmosphere prevails for weeks on end; there is an air of expectancy akin to that before Christmas in the United Statesplus a touch of the Fourth of July.

title: U.S. Olympic Subsidy Plan for Athletes Is Greeted as a Significant Advance
description: One week before the 1972 Olympic track and field trials, Vince Matthews considered calling it quits as a quarter  miler because he could not scrape up enough money for a crosscountry trip to the site of the competition.

title: 1,000 TELEPHONES STILL IN A SNARL
description: Although most of the 175,000 telephones affected by the fire Feb. 27 on Second Avenue are working, phone officials said yesterday that 1,000 telephones were still either dead or without full service.

title: Prince Thou Art Is Winner, With Foolish Pleasure Third
C.C.N.Y. VIEWS ROLE OF NEW ARTS HEAD
description: Officials of City College said that the choice of Earle R. Gister last week as director of the Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts was designed to solve the problems involved in merging the academic world with the performing arts, a factor that had contributed to tensions causing the resignation of the previous director.

title: Chicago Alderman, 77, Works At Getting Out the Daley Vote
description: CHICAGO, March 29It is three days until Chicago's mayoral electionin reality a ratification rite for Richard J. Daley to begin a sixth fouryear term.

title: New Pastor, 25, Ready for Easter
description: Preaching his first Easter sermon holds no fears trot 25yearold Robert Meadows Rogers, pastor for the last nine months of Embury United Methodist Church in Queens Village.

title: Letters: GurusThat Was the Last Straw'
description: To the Editor:

title: An officer and a gentleman and a bully
description: If the Battle of Waterloo was won on the playingfields of Eton, the Charge of the Light Brigade became a disaster on the huntingfields of the English Shires. Lord Cardigan, whe led it, was a horseman to his fingertips. His aristocratic equine face as he sat on his horse made him look like a centaur. In a natural congruence, he took as his second wife Miss Adeline Horsey de Horsey. He learned his cavalry technique as a youth with the fashionable hunts of the Pytchley and the Quorn. And it was his headlong dash against the highest timber and the widest waterjumps, though he couldn't swim, that prefigured his reckless onslaught at Balaklava against the Russian guns in the valley of death from which only 120 hussars out of 600 returned.

title: Horseplayers' Movement Is Afoot to Resist Taxation Without Representation
description: At the risk of being called unpatriotic, growing numbers of recreational horseplayers are talking about forming a union.

title: CRITICS IN KENYA KEEP UP PRESSURE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 29A long Easter recess of Parliament is expected to bring a respite in the political tensions that have marked Kenya since a leading politician was murdered early this month.

title: 2 Districting Plans in Nassau
description: MLNEOLA  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors is expected to announce at a special meeting tomorrow that it will present two different redistricting maps for a proposed 15district legislature to a judge for approval. It is also expected to announce a change in the terms of office proposed for members of the legislature.

title: WHAT'S FAIR ON THE AIR?
description: At 1:12 P.M. on the afternoon of Nov. 25, 1964, Bob Barry, the announcer on duty at radio station WGCB, Red Lion, Pa., threaded a tape made in the Tulsa, Okla., studio of the Christian Crusade. At 1:14, he began reading a commercial for Mailman's Department Store. Sixty seconds later, he gave station identification, pushed the start button on Tape Recorder 1 and raised the level of the audio not just in time for the opening fanfare of The Battle Hymn of the Republic. The Rev. Billy James Hargis was on the air in Red Lion, York, Spry and Dallastown.

title: NancyNewman Has Nuptials
description: Nancy Livia Newman, daughter of Edwin Newman, a correspondent and commentator for NBC News, and Mrs. Newman of New York, was married yesterday in Edinburgh, Scotland, to Henry Mathew Drucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Drucker of Rutherford, N. J.

title: What It Is Greenspan Looks For
description: WASHINGTONAlan Greenspan, the chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, has been predicting that the bottom of the long recession will be reached around the middle of the year and that the economy will gradually begin to recover.

title: Dispute Over Chaplain Blocks Mass at a Rhode Island Prison
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 29Roman Catholic inmates at Rhode Island's state prison will have no Easter mass this year because of a monthold dispute between prison officials and the diocese over the role of the prison chaplain.

title: Saigon's Options
description: The disorganized military retreat and civilian exodus in the wake of President Thieu's decision to evacuate the Highland provinces has altered fundamentally the options open to the Saigon Government. In the North, around isolated Da Nang, military considerations have already largely given way to desperate efforts to rescue a mass of homeless refugees and extricate what is left of the South Vietnamese defense forces. The remaining positions on the long and narrow central coastline are precariously exposed. From a military point of view, it therefore appears that Saigon's fate hinges on the government's capacity to rally the armed forces to an effective stand north of the capital.

title: A failure to communicate
description: Since 1971, under a federally sponsored effort to standardize and simplify signing, the symbol signs common in Europe have been erected along U.S. highways in many areas. But they have met with mixed reviews from drivers and highway safety experts. For example, a big red circle and slash superimposed upon a black symbol (a truck, a Uturn, parking, a bicycle) signifies that trucks, Uturns, parking, bicycles, or whatever, are prohibited. Such signs are being mocked, on their way, no doubt, to eventual acceptance, as everything from oversized merit badges to emblems of neoNazi resurgence.

title: Crews Are Back on the Charles
description: BOSTON, March 29The reappearance of the crews on the Charles River is as sure a harbinger of spring as any robin in Boston Common.

title: Haiti, Mexico Lure 3 Teams in N.A.S.L.
description: Because of soccer's universal popularity, three North American Soccer League teams will get a chance this week to prepare for the season by training in warmer climates and making a dollar or two by playing exhibition games. Heading for Haiti tomorrow morning are the New York Cosmos and the Miami Toros, who will train in PortauPrince and play in the first Eastern Airlines International Cup tournament. There will be four games and each is expected to attract 30,000. The first two games have been sold out in the roundrobin tournament that also includes Victory, perhaps the top club in Haiti.

title: A Latin From Manhattan Stars at Last
description: I didn't get where I am today overnightoh, no, chicos! It took a long, long time. A star is horn, that's true. I mean, you have it in the cradle or you don't, but the star, she doesn't twinkle over no one night!

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  As Vic Reinemer tells it, the idea of a national power grid has been around a long time. Leland Olds talked about it when he headed the Federal Power Commission 30 years ago. But Olds said that Gifford Pinchot was the godfather of the idea, Mr. Reinemer adds.

title: Tenants in Flushing Seek Improvements
description: Tenants in the badly deteriorated, 25yearold Carlton Gardens middle  income apartment development in Flashing, Queens, pleaded with the city last week to approve a plan to spend $10million in public and private funds to rehabilitate the 500 dwelling units at Kissena Boulevard and 73d Avenue.

title: Food
description: The occasion for one of hie's great pleasureslively conversation among old friendscan be provided by a good meal. I might serve a quiche, a chicken liver terrine, a green salad and, for dessert, a caramel cream. If you accompany the quiche and terrine with a Ctes de Provence, a Beaujolais of a Beaulieu and the caramel cream with a semisweet champagne (wine should not be served with the salad, since the vinegar in the dressing would kill the wine's taste) relaxation and fellowship will follow.

title: Hardy Bamboos
description: Most gardeners usually think bamboo is exclusively an oriental and tropical plant, but it actually is native to North America, South America, Africa and the Himalayas with the greatest concentration found is Asia and adjacent islands. Some of the largest varieties grow in tropical climates, but there are hardy ones under cultiva, ton which are said to withstand temperatures to 40 degrees below zero. They can be very dramatic in northern climates as accent plants, screens, windbreaks or hedges.

title: Gary Hourihan to Wed Deborah Pierce
description: Mr. and Mrs. David C. Pierce of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Anne Pierce, to Gary Charles Hourihan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Hourihan of Mendham, N. J.

title: Where There's a Will, There's Playroom
description: Apartment  house basements, once the exclusive domain of handymen and laundresses, are reverberating more and more frequently to the sound of children's voices and the click of PingPong balls. Playrooms are going underground.

title: Liberals And the Tax Bill
description: The Democrats who control Congress may have done a good deal more than provide substantial stimulus for the economy in the tax bill they have just passed. The measure could be the beginning of a new and longoverdue course for American liberalismtoward a policy of redistributing income.

title: Old Asian Artifacts Found
description: MOSCOW, March 29 (UPI)The most ancient site of primitive man in Central Asia has been discovered near Samarkand in the Republic of Uzbekistan, the Tass Press Agency says. It said this week that impliments found at the site were estimated by archeologists as being in use 40,000 to 60,000 years ago.

title: Jazz Notes: Impresario Grant Returns
description: Norman Granz, whose Jazz at the Philharmonic concerts helped breed a generation of jazz fans from the midforties until he gave up the series in 1957, will produce jazz concerts here again in the fall although not with the frequency or on the touring scale of his old JATP troupes. Since Granz moved all of the recorded material by Duke Ellington that has not yet been released as well as the recording rights to all of the Duke's unrecorded compositions.

title: It Took a Suicide Note
description: Reforming the regulatory agencies has been one of the big yawns of this cynical city. But the suicide note of an official in the Civil Aeronautics Board, conflicts in the sworn testimony of the acting and the former chairman of the agency and an unusually aggressive Senate investigation just may have combined to upset both complacency and cynicism when it comes to Government regulation of the airlines.

title: Bach Mass Is Given In Stirring Manner By National Chorale
description: Bach's Mass in B minor, that great cathedral of sound is almost too complex to be reerected in performance satisfactorily. The National Chorale under the direction of Martin Josman tried on Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, with the usual mixed results, but also, as usual, the grandeur of the music came through.

title: What Does a Street Gang Watch on the Trick Box?
description: The South Bronx has been described as a small, crimerieden nation. Among other things, it has the highest density of street gangs in the country. Kids as young as 9 join Junior or Baby divisions, and by the age of 11 may crack a man's skull with a lead pipe just for recognition from their peers. The gangs' arsenals of weapons go beyond pipes and tire chains  considered kid stuff by the older teenaged membersto include knives, machetes, automatic rifles, pistols, and sometimes even grenades. Army bazookas and mortars. In the homes these youngsters come from, the TV set often represents the family's main link to the world outside the neighborhood. It plays day and night. So what better place than the South Bronx to discuss violence on TV and what better people to discuss it with than members of a gang?

title: StepUp in U.S. Help By LESLIE H. GELB
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Pentagon officials said today, in relaying information from the American Embassy in Saigon, that the United States will begin an accelerated delivery of spare parts and equipment to South Vietnam in a few days.

title: The Duke of Carteret
description: When the scout who had been following Joe Medwick around the New Jersey sandlots turned in his report to the St. Louis Cardinals he did not hedge, equivocate or weasel. Has great requisites. he wrote, arm, speed, punch, ambitiona great athlete. The young man's health and habits were good, the scout noted. He did not drink and was exceptionally ag gressive, decidedly hose days eCBranch Rickey was general manager in St. Louis and it was an article of faith with Branch that every human must be prone to some human frailty. He insisted that scouts report on the weaknesses of a prospect as well as his assets, and he didn't think much of a scout who could see no flaws.

title: Asian Lands Assailed
description: HONG KONG, March 29The Vietcong Government has condemned the Philippines and Taiwan for assisting the Saigon Administration in what it called the forcible evacuation of the population of Da Nang.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TOMORROW TransAtlantic

title: Wendy Stuart Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Stuart of Roslyn Heights, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Jo Stuart, to George Seisel Franklin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin of Shreveport. La. The wedding is planned for April 19. Mr. Franklin is a graduate of Franconia College.

title: Lon Nol Is Taking a Trip; Thieu Besieged
description: The situation is deteriorating rapidly for the Americansupported regimes of Lon Nol in Cambodia and Nguyen Van Thieu in South Vietnam. The Cambodian leader, whom insurgents have said they will execute if they capture him when Phnom Penh falls, is preparing to leave shortly. The life of the Government of President Thieu is in doubt: He has now sustained substantial political setbacks as well as a military rout.

title: Secretary of What?
description: After making four excellent Cabinet appointments, President Ford in choosing his fifth has fallen off the wagon with a bang.

title: Will Faisal's Policies Also Die Now?
description: The assassination of Saudi Arabia's King Faisal could hardly have happened at a worse time. The conjunction of that event with the failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy between Israel and Egypt diminishes prospects for peace in the Middle East and foreshadows more militant policies in the Arab world.

title: Reshaping Business Taxes
description: Tax cuts for individuals dominated the $22.8billion bill that the House and Senate finally agreed on last Wednesday, but corporations were hardly ignored.

title: LI Agricultural Outlook Called Bright
description: RIVERHEADThere is pleasant air of optimism about Long Island's $80millionayear agriculture industry among research scientists at Cornell University's experimental farm here.

title: Yugoslav Authorities Say Baby Ward Was Unattended
description: RIJEKA, Yugoslavia. March 29 (UPI)A hospital maternity ward here was unattended when a fire, set off by faulty wiring, swept through the. rooms and killed 25 of the 28 babies there, authorities said today.

title: City Urged to Reverse Pattern of Ruin
description: A new study contends that the city and state's fiscal crises of 1975 have brought forth the best opportunity in two decades to reverse a pattern of financial and governmental ruin.

title: Louis Hornick 2d to Wed Wendy L. Mann in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Yale M. Mann of Rydal, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Leigh Mann, to Louis Hornick 2d; son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Hornick of New York.

title: Letters
description: The easy way

title: JEWS DISPERSED BY MOSCOW POLICE
description: MOSCOW, March 29  Uniformed police pushed into the vestibule of Moscow's synagogue as Sabbath morning services ended today and ordered several hundred persons to clear out and go home, Jewish activists reported.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, management consultants, have leased 60,000 square feet of office space at 600 Third Avenue, at 40th Street. The 20year lease calls for an aggregate rent of more than $10million.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Mitchel Field Master Plan For Campus
description: GARDEN CITY  Architect's renderings of the new master plan for Nassau Community College were released here last week, as word came from Albany that the prospects were favorable for restoration of a major portion of the construction funds for the school that had been cut out of Governor Carey's budget.

title: Miss Roosevelt Fiancee Of William Floyd Weld
description: Susan Roosevelt and William Floyd Weld, graduates of Harvard Law School, plan to marry June 7.

title: Carey's Planning Nominee Ponders Tightened Spending and Wider Power
description: ALBANY, March 14  A trimmeddown state planning division, oratorically dedicated to coping with scarce resources and bureaucratically destined to seek expansion of its own power, is quietly taking shape around the corner from Governor Carey's office.

title: Troops Beat Out Civilians In Rush for Da Nang Plane
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, March 29Only the fastest, the strongest and the meanest got out today on what may be the last refugee plane from Da Nang.

title: 20 More Freed by British As Ulster CeaseFire Holds
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 29 (UPI)Twenty more members of the Irish Republican Army were freed from the Maze Prison today, completing the Easter release of 40 prisoners jailed without trial on suspicion of terrorist activity.

title: Convicted of Rape In '73, Queens Man Is Arrested Again
description: An unemployed Queens truck driver, said by the police to have been convicted of a number of rapes in Nassau County two years ago, was arrested Friday night and booked on charges of raping a woman in Flushing, Queens, last Feb. 21.

title: Teresa Rhodes Sets Marriage June 7
description: Teresa Bryan Rhodes and Eric Henry Rosenberger of the White House staff in Washington plan to be married June 7. Their engagement has been announced bv Mr. and Mrs. Sam J. Rhodes Jr. of Rocky Mount, N.C., parents of the bridetohe, whose fianc is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Andrew G. Rosenberger of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Michael Carey to Wed Kathryn McManus
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph McManus of Manhasset, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ruth McManus, to Michael Francis Carey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Carey of Levittown, L. I.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: The extraordinary growth of interest in creative photography during the past few years has not only led to a substantial increase in the number of galleries that actively exhibit photographs, it has also led to an even larger growth in the number of photographers who are trying to get their work exhibited in these galleries.

title: Screwdrivers: They Come In Many Styles
description: Although screwdrivers are undoubtedly one of the most basic of all hand tools, a surprisingly large number of people misuse them regularly. When a screwdriver is used for prying, scraping, or punching its tip is often bent, chipped or worn out of shape so that it is soon ruined for the basic function it was designed to perform  driving and removing screws, In addition, many people are not familiar with the importance of selecting the right size and type screwriver for each job, nor of the various special purpose models that are available for reaching into awkward places, increasing leverage, and making the work go faster.

title: CORRECTION
Around Besieged Cambodian Capital, Pinch Gets Ever Tighter
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 29With the Cambodian insurgent offensive now three months old, this capital of over two million people remains surrounded.

title: The World
description: The assassination of Saudi Arabia's King Faisal had created uncertainty about the future policies and leadership of the world's major oilexporting country. King Faisal was an allpowerful spiritual and political leader. His successor as King is his brother, Crown Prince Khalid, who is in dubious health and who in the past has not been noticeably interested in economics or politics.

title: Tampa Is Ordered to Stop Enforcing Obscenity Law
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 29 (AP) A Federal judge has ordered the city of Tampa to temporarily stop enforcing an antiobscenity ordinance after a magazine distributor filed suit asserting that the police had ordered copies of Time magazine off the shelves.

title: NEW MICHIGAN LAW OFFERS DRUG SAVING
description: DETROIT, March 29Starting Tuesday Michigan residents whose physicians prescribe a drug by its brand name will be able to have the prescription filled with the generally less expensive generic equivalent.

title: Moscow, Winter Over, Performs Rites of Spring
description: MOSCOW,  Surrounded by other Soviet leaders topped with conventional fur hats and fedoras, Leonid J. Brezhnev posed for photographers at a railroad station here. Pushed far back on his head at a sporty angle was a shortbrimmed, most unRussian hat, perhaps of Tyrolean inspiration. But the time he was photographed in Budapest the oddlooking hat had disappeared. Still, a Muscovite commented, that little hat must be considered a sign of spring.

title: Irate South Vietnamese Charge A Betrayal by Washington
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29A wave of antiAmerican sentiment and charges of betrayal by the Ford Administration are sweeping this tense capital.

title: Dr. Joseph D. Cooper, 57, Taught Politics at Howard
description: Dr. Joseph D. Cooper, professor of political science at Howard University and adjunct professor at the American University, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Silver Spring, Md. He was 57 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: In a recent answer in this column you told a reader to apply a vapor barrier to the dirt floor in his crawl space. I have a similar probleman unfinished floor (dirt) in the crawl spaceand I'm getting a great deal of mold and mildew, in spite of two dehumidifiers. What is the vapor barrier you referred to, and how is it applied?Mrs. C. G.. Locust Valley. N.Y.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
Endpaper
description: early Beloved: The text this Easter morning is Romans vi, 4: ... as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: This is the year of Brooklyn, but you'd never know it in New York. The season's top theatrical eventthe visit of England's Royal Shakespeare Companytook place in Brooklyn, at the handsomely restored Brooklyn Academy of Music. Generally, it is easier to get New Yorkers to cross the Atlantic to London than to cross the East River.

title: The Battle for Two Playoff Spots
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Members of Both Parties Praise Ford's Signing of TaxCut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)  Congressmen of both parties praised President Ford today for signing into law the $22.8billion tax cut despite his reservations.

title: Catcher magna cum laude
description: Casey Stengel on Moe Berg: Now, I'll tell ya. I mean Moe Berg was as smart a ballplayer as ever come along. Knew the legs wouldn't cooperate in the infield and when the catching job opened up he grabs a mask and puts it on and there he was. Guy never caught in his life and then goes behind the plate like Mickey Cochran. Now that's somethin'. But, I'll tell ya again, nobody ever knew his life's history. I call him the mystery catcher. Strangest fellah who ever put on a uniform.

title: A New Tomorrow
description: The season turns the corner and something within us responds whatever our belief or religion. The world around us responds to forces beyond our control accumulated knowledge. Life is returning and life is being renewed in every field and woodland, on every lawn and hilltop. A green and flowery world is in the bud, and the buds are starting to open.

title: SAUDI KING NAMES HIS NEW CABINET
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 29A new collective leadership took office today in Saudi Arable under King Khalid, the successor to the late King Faisal. whose personal rule was unchallenged.

title: Dance: The Eclectic Way
description: The Theater Dance Collection is a company whose dancers obviously enjoy performing and whose enthusasm communicates itself to the audience.

title: Sunday Observer
description: In an ominous and litticnoted development, the growing rift has set off fresh speculation despite outwardly optimistic indications of an upsurge in the nation's moral fiber that has deeply alarmed sources close to Secretary Kissinger.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There they stand, in serried rank, and you can't tell them apart: Nick Carter or The Baroness or whatnot. Each is written to order; each must have its combination of sadism and porno; each is written in elementary prose. New from Nick Carter is THE BLACK DEATH (Award, $1.25), which is espionage  la James Bond but on a juvenile level. This one is about Haiti. Or take No. 11 in the Earl Drake seriesOPERATION DEATHMIAKER by Dan J. Marlowe (Fawcett, 95 cents). It tries to be hardboiled stuff about murder and kidnapping, and it lovingly goes into detail about death as a way of life: The slug hit him right in the center of his fastmoving mouth. His teeth, or his palate, changed its direction, because it burst from the top of the lefthand side of his skull. Part of his brain . . .  (On second thought, life as a way of death.)

title: Johncock Bids Again For Trenton Honors
description: Gordon Johncock says he doe'n't like crowds, so dont be surprised if he tries to leave the field far behind in Sundays United States Auto Club championship car race at Trenton speeaway. And, based on his record at the 1mile Trenton track, he just may be able to post his first victory of 1975. The 38yearold Johncock has run at Trenton 21 times, winning once and finishing second five times. He also has been in the top five nine times and in the top 10 on 11 occasions. All of this on a track that he says he doesn't especially like.

title: The Settlement
description: Nearly blind since birth, Gail Kalmowitz had always feared she would become a financial burden to her family. That fear prompted her to file a $2million malpractice suit against two doctors and a hospital, alleging that, after her premature birth in Brookdale Hospital in 1953, negligent supervision of her care resulted in permanent damage to her eyes. As the trial concluded, all signs pointed to a decision in Miss Kahnowitz's favor. But while the Jury was out, Miss Kalmowitz, fearing she might be awarded nothing, settled with the defendants' insurance companies for $165,000. Moments later the jury returned. Several jurors told her she would have been awarded $900,000.

title: Canadiens Win at Home 1,000th Time
description: MONTREAL, March 29 (UPI) Guy Lafleur scored his 50th goal of the season tonight as the Montreal Canadiens broke a fourgame string without a victory by defeating the Kansas City Scouts. 41.

title: The Dark Didn't Catch Me
description: In recent years, we have been inundated by waves of nostalgia reliving the last five or six decades; as if by investigating them, we can either better understand our current dilemmas or escape from them. The main problem with these sojourns is that somewhere along the line we have forgotten, if we ever knew, what the past was really like, and therefore what we have come to envision as the Depression, for example, is often a fiction filled with cheerful, stifflipped people, charmingly costumed, living in white clapboard farmhouses with ruffled curtains.

title: Traffic Dip Persists At Newark Airport
description: NEWARK  Revenue passenger traffic at Newark International Airport continues to decline, with figures for January showing a daily average of 2,000 fewer passengers than in the same month two years ago.

title: Samuel H. Ballam 3d Marries Susan M. Hubble in Illinois
description: The Jeanne Vail Chapel on the Northwestern University campus in Evanston. Ill., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Susan Mae Hubble, a member of the graduating dass at Northwestern, to Samuel Humes Ballam 3d. who received a master's degree in management from Northwestern last year. The Rev. Hadley Williams of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Evanston performed the ceremony.

title: Why Work Isn't Work to Joyce Carol Oates
description: Why do I work so hard? The fact is that I am not conscious of working especially hard, or of working at all. A few years ago I made a decision to never again do anything I did not really want to do; for the most part I have been able to stay with this decision.

title: Correction
description: We regret that the credit for the drawings used to illustrate the story on leathercrafting in the March 9 issue of this section was inadvertently left out. The drawings were from The Leathercraft Book, by Pat Hills and Joan Wiener,  copyright 1973 by Pat Hills and Joan Wiener ($3.95 in paperback).

title: Wallace Aides Organize All Over U.S.
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 29Encouraged by Gov. George C. Wallace's consistently good showing in the political polls, 45 of his leading California supporters gathered in Los Angeles a few nights ago to set up a statewide campaign organization for 1976.

title: A look at the new heroine
description: A film critic recently observed that women as leading characters were fast disappear. ing from the screen. The rationale offered was that audiences today were divided between those who could not tolerate overly aggressive heroines and those who wanted women to be shown as victims There being no model on which all could agree, it seemed safest to remove the heroine entirely from view.

title: 2 TO FACE TRIAL IN BAR SHOOTING
description: Two Queens teenagers are to stand trial for attempted murder and robbery because a totally paralyzzed correction officer was able to identify them from their photos, even though he was able to communicate only by blinking his eyes.

title: Senate Unit To Consider ZoningLaw Revisions
description: TRENTONThe first skirmish in what promises to be a bitter and protracted legislative battle over exclusionary zoning in the suburbs will take place here Thursday. The Senate County and Municipal Government Committee will conduct a public hearing then on a proposed comprehensive revision of local landuse laws.

title: Easters Past Relived at Morris Museum
description: MORRISTOWN  In celebration of the fading custom of buying a new spring bonnet and wearing it on Easter Sunday, the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences has mounted an exhibition of 19thcentury and early 20thcentury headgear.

title: Short Wave Buffs Keep In Tune With the Times
description: Shortwave listening is a leisure time activity engaged in by thousands of people in every part of the globesome of whom are satisfied to merely listen regularly for broadcasts from easytohear countries with powerful transmitters, while others (often called DXers) prefer to spend most of the time trying to tune in on lowpowered stations from distant, rarelyheard countries.

title: State Parley Slated By Voters' League
description: MORRISTOWNThe 41st state convention of the League of Women Voters will be held at the Governor Morris Inn here on April 1213. The convention is being held on a weekend for the first time, thus enabling the broadest possible representation of members, including working women, students and mothers.

title: GOLD MINE STUDY DISCLOSES PERIL
description: A study by a Federal health agency in one United States gold mine has disclosed an abnormally high rate of lung cancer among miners who were exposed to asbestos  bearing ore similar to that mined by the Reserve Mining Company in Silver Bay, Minn.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington in last Sunday's editions of The New York Times about a libel suit against A. Britton Hume, a former reporter for the columnist, Jack Anderson, mistakenly reported that Mr. Hume, after declining to do so for several years, had disclosed in court the name of his source for a disputed news item. The source, Joy Ann Combs, voluntarily disclosed her identity to the court in a letter. The article also said that Mrs. Combs was divorced from Harrison Combs Jr., who was described in the dispatch as a lawyer for the United Mine Workers Union. Mr. Combs Jr., a former official of the union, is not a lawyer and is now employed by the United States Mining Enforcement and SafeAdministration.

title: Gillies Scores 2 Goals Within 10 Seconds
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 29Losing their awe of the New York Rangers with two powerplay goals 10 seconds apart by Clark Gillies, a rookie. early in the first period, the New York Islanders went on to defeat their city rivals, 64, before an elated capacity crowd of 14,865 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Gail Shearer Plans June Nuptials
description: Gail Shearer, a policy analyst for Consumers Union in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Christopher Palmer, a consultant on energy problems with Booz. Allen. & Hamilton Inc., in Bethesda, Md., will be married in June.

title: Stars Lift Boucha Suspension
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 29 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars have lifted the indefinite suspension of Henry Boucha from the National Hockey League club. However, General Manager Jack Gordon said that Boucha, a center, will not play the last five games on the team's chedule because of a previous injury to his eye. Boucha was suspended a week ago for violating a team curfew and has missed the last four games.

title: ANTHONY ZAGAME, A JUSTICE, DEAD
description: Justice Anthony F. Zaeame of the State Supreme Court in Queens died Friday in Kew Gardens (Queens) General Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Egon Dumlers Have Son
description: A son was born March 19 at University Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Egon Dumler of New York, where Mr. Dumler heads the law firm of Dumler Giroux. Mrs. Dumler is Gretchen Walther, a television actress.

title: Maryland Legislature Votes Bill Restoring Death Penalty
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29 (AP)Legislation restoring the death penalty in Maryland for certain specified capital crimes was enacted today by the House of Delegates.

title: Linda E. Chowenhill Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Frampton Chowenhill of Chappaqua, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Ellen Chowenhill, to Daniel Wyman Cummings, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Jack Cummings of Amherst, N. H., formerly of Chappaqua. The wedding is planned for Dec. 20.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Battle of the Garden
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dana E. Friedman Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Friedman of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana Elisa Friedman, to Donald Tracy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Tracy of Washington. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Mr. Ber4man, Especially Had Excellent Connections
description: Woven into the pattern of nursinghome scandal is the more subtle thread of political influence that was necessary to complete the design. Politicians have aided and protected the industry for years.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Hopes for a speedy passage for the taxcut bill helped the stock market post a modest advance last week in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 7.20 points for the week at 770.26 at the close of Thursday's session. The stock market was closed on Friday in observance of Good Friday.

title: State Reports Gains in Finding Welfare Fathers Who Deserted
description: The State Department of Social Services reported yesterday that its drive to find deserting fathers of welfare families had resulted in the location of 26.434 such parents in 1974 and the recovery of $26.2million in support payments.

title: Speed Is Held Key to U. S. Airlift
description: Speed is the critical factor in the United States airlift to resupply South Vietnam's armed forces, and Pentagon officials are hopeful that some of the needed supplies can be taken from stocks in the Philippines, thus cutting transport time. Defense Department sources said Saigon urgently needed artillery shells, bombs, aviation fuel and spare parts before the North Vietnamese launch an expected offensive against the capital.

title: Potatoes Given Away In Protest of Prices
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 29 (UPI)Disgruntled farmers gave away 70,000 pounds of potatoes today, saying they would rather see the poor get them than sell them to supermarkets for a penny per pound.

title: Brooklyn School Rezoning Announced
New and Noteworthy
description: BLOOD OF MY BLOOD, by Richard Gambino. (Anchor, $3.50.) How three generations of Italian Americans feel about themselves and their heritage: the content is scholarly; the style anecdotal sometimes passionate.

title: Man Asked to Mind Store Shot to Death in Brooklyn
description: A 64yearold Brooklyn man who had been asked by the owner of a candy storeluncheonette to mind the store for a few minutes died yesterday at Kings County Hospital Center of a gunshot wound an hour after he was found lying on the floor of the store.

title: IRAQIKIM CLASH REPORTED FIERCE
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 29 (Reuters)Fierce clashes between Iraqi forces and Kurdish rebels appeared to have erupted today in northern Iraq, with the Kurds making a fighting retreat before advancing Government troops.

title: Panel Prepares Report On Saving the Catskills
description: CATSKILL, N.YWhen Rip Van Winkle awoke after a 20year nap in the Catskills, he found that the mountains had not changed, but that his village had. It was larger and more populous, with rows of houses he had never seen before.

title: Ann Macy Beha Is Affianced To Robert Radloff of Boston
description: Ann Macy Beha, who will receive a Master of Architecture degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in June, plans to be married that month to Robert A. Radloff of Boston, assistant vice president of Kuras & Co., a real estate investment concern there.

title: Canada Will Gradually Shift to Metric System, Starting Tuesday
description: MONTREAL, March 27To the delight of the multinational corporations here, and to the despair of confused consumers, Canada is converting to the metric system.

title: Golf Won at 209 By Jane Blalock
description: SCOTTSDALE. Ariz., March 29 (AP)Jane Blalock, carded a fourunderpar 68 today and won the $10,000 top prize in a $70,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by a stroke with a total of 209 for 54 holes.

title: ...and Coping With Hyperactivity
description: MELVILLE  Parents or hyperactive children are learning how to cope with the problem at the Sagamore Children's Center here without necessarily resorting to medication.

title: SADAT ANNOUNCES PLANS TO REOPEN SUEZ CANAL JUNE 5
description: CAIRO, March 29  President Anwar elSadat dramatically announced tonight that he would open the Suez Canal to international shipping on June 5 and that he would renew the mandate of the United Nations force in Sinai, which is scheduled to expire April 24, for three more months.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A spokesman for the Saigon Government said radio contact with the encircled city of Da Nang had been lost, indicating that it had fallen. Another highly informed source said, however, that he was in contact with observers in a boat just off shore. But it was clear that Saigon had written off South Vietnam's second largest city. The observers said that there did not appear to be any fighting going on, but added that there was no way of knowing whether North Vietnamese troops had entered the city. [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: Knicks' LineUp
BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Memorial Set for Nathanson
description: A memorial service for Jerome Nathanson, who was chairman of the board of leaders of the New York Society for Ethical Culture from 1954 until he stepped dawn last year. will be held Tuesday at 5:30 P.M. in the society's meeting house, 2 West 64th Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington in last Sunday's editions of The New York Times about a libel suit against A. Britton Hume, a former reporter for the columnist, Jack Anderson, mistakenly reported that Mr. Hume, after declining to do so for several years, had disclosed in court the name of his source for a disputed news item. The source, Joy Ann Combs, voluntarily disclosed her identity to the court in a letter. The article also said that Mrs. Combs was divorced from Harrison Combs Jr., who was described in the dispatch as a lawyer for the United Mine Workers Union. Mr. Combs Jr., a former official of the union, is not a lawyer and is now employed by the United States Mining Enforcement and SafeAdministration.

title: P. E. Nelson to Wed Clarice A. Gilchrist
description: The engagement of Clarice Aileen Gilchrist to Patrick Edmund Nelson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Byron Gilchrist Jr. of Lewisboro, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Allen Nelson of Timonium, Md.

title: Gotterdammerung Sung at Met, Ending Afternoon Ring Cycle
description: The four parts of Wagner's Ring cycle rise like peaks, each towering higher than its predecessor. Even the final part has its own high point, in the extraordinary second act, where human passions tangle more fiercely than elsewhere, and the music is terser and more overwhelming.

title: RADIO LINK FADES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 30A Saigon. Government spokesman said today that radio contact with the encircled northern South Vietnamese port of Da Nang had been lost, indicating that the city had fallen.

title: Income Tax Delay Expected
description: TRENTON  Democratic leaders in both houses of the Legislature asserted last week that agreement on any state income tax plan faces delay and that a showdown on the proposed levy will not come until the end of next month or early May.

title: 2 G.O.P. Leaders Face Challenges
description: The usual tranquility in the patronagerich Suffolk Republican organization has been shattered by intraparty fights in Huntington and Brookhaven that are almost certain to spill over into the important town elections this November.

title: Guardsmen Patrol Town After 7 Die In Arkansas Storm
description: WARREN, Ark., March 29National Guardsmen patrolled debrisstrewn streets today to prevent looting followin ga tornado that the authorities said had killed six persons and injured 86 others. Damage was estimated at more than $10million.

title: Miss Wade Captures Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 The new Virginia Wade who said she had no idea how to beat Chris Evert, heat. Chris Evert, 75, 64, today and won the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tennis tournament at the Palestra.

title: Banks Easing Mortgage Loan Terms
description: Thrift institutions in the metropolitan area, flush with new funds deposited in recent months, have begun to ease the terms for home mongases.

title: Bunny Land in Suffolk Is Feeling the Effects of the High Price of Feed
description: YAPHANKFor the last 15 years, the Easter Bunny has been quietly living here, chewing hay, eschewing lettuce and sipping tea.

title: The Effects of the Tax Bill
description: Total Tax Reductions

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Freud

title: ALEXHARVEY,SINGER, ISEARTHY AND TOUGH
description: Alex Harveythe official billearthly end tough. And the is not the usual British export, content to bang out rock n roll clichs all night long. Mr. Harvey, a singer who made his New York debut at Town Hall on Friday, is from Glasgow, a tough town to grow up in, and those sidewalks are reflected in his hand's work. This Is particularly noticeable in Hot City Symphony, a partly successful attempt to draw a parallel between his home town and Manhattan.

title: Point of View
description: In less than a decade, the plastics industry has seen its future of glamorous potential replaced by one riddled with profound questions about the effects of its products on human life and safety. Today it is an industry with its back to the wallthe firewall, to be precise.

title: Saudis Are Pushing Plans For Village Development
description: DERAYA, Saudi Arabia, March 29This fortified oasis was the thriving capital of the first Saudi state in the 18th century.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets in the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Novelistic autobiography, autobiographical novel? No matter
description: When this book first appeared, about a year ago, I read the publisher's advance proofs and carelessly assumed it was a novel, a piece of fiction with an unusually elaborate, pretentious and alltheSame inviting title. Who could resist the combination of Zen, motorcycle and values? Like most people I know who read books, I too have passed through the Zen phase (Zen and archery), the motorcycle phase (HarleyDavidson, BSA, and one crash on a BMW), and am still, in middle age, sadder but no wiser, engaged in a sort of soft, twilight struggle to prevent my own values (economy, geology and probity) from becoming too firmly and finally petrified. A nut can be defined as a man with a rocklam head, durable but impermeable, easily cracked.

title: Miss Belury Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. N. George Belury of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Georgia Belury, to Thomas Graham Ridgely Kastendike, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Kastendike of Baltimore. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Girl, 8, Found Stabbed to Death After Assault in Bronx Building
description: An 8yearold girl was found stabbed to death yesterday morning on a landing leading to the roof of a lowincome housing project at 1285 Washington Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: Don't Sit Under The Apple Tree
description: Here's another novel which looks back nostalgically to the good old 1940's, with special emphasis on the summer of '45. (How can the summer I lost my two front teeth and learned to ride a bicyclenot necessarily in that orderbe nostalgia already?)

title: Rosalyn Drexler and her talking dog
description: Ten years of feminism and what do you get? Two stereotypes as durable as Doris Day: the Mad Housewife and the Suffering Single. The mating whine of the latter, at least, should be stifled by Rosalyn Drexter's new book, which doesn't so much lay that type to rest as put it to sleep with an injection of wit right to the heart.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Scholarly as well as popular thinking about the evolution of the malefemale relationship has been that it started with the caveman dominating his mate. That may not be so; there is now an accumulation of evidence indicating that early man and woman may have shared power.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONGRESS passed and sent to the President a $22.8billion taxcut bill providing cash rebates, higher standard deductions, home mortgage credits, investment tax credits, and an end of oil depletion allowances for large oil companies... A sharp decline in oil imports moved the United States balance of payments to a record surplus of $917million in February. . . Exports at $8.79billion were 6.6 per cent below the January level. . . The Senate approved an emergency farm bill to increase price supports and income protection. The bill faces a probable Presidential veto.

title: About the Rangers and Islanders . . .
description: Both the general manager and coach of the Atlanta Flames, Cliff Fletcher and Fred Creighton, were in Nassau Coliseum for yesterday's game scouting the two New York teams. The Flames meet the Islanders this afternoon and Tuesday. They meet the Rangers Friday. . . . The Rangers are about as healthy as they've been all season. Only Dale Rolfe and Bobby Rousseau, out for the season, were missing from the lineup. . . . Most of the signs at the Coliseum were proIslanders: Long Beach Loves the Islanders, Beat the Manhattan Misfits, We've got the Cat By His Tail, Rangers Choke Will Never Drink From Cup), Chico Is the Man.

title: 4Man Boat Of N.YA.C. Is Victor
description: Jim Dietz stroked the New York Athletic Club to a sevenlength victory yesterday in the Elite quad event of the Easter Regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach lagoon. The victors were timed in 6 minutes 31.5 seconds.

title: ERIN MARTIN OFFERS 2 NEW DANCE WORKS
description: Throughout the lugubrious length of Erin Martin's dance concert Friday night in the At Tears Studio, 330 Broome Street, my attention was drawn to the fascinating Miss Martin and her lead dancer, Juan Antonio. The two works receiving their first performances were Fashion and Lulu's Room.

title: Helping Children Who Have Learning Difficulties . . .
description: GARDEN CITY  When Clark Kretkowski was 3 years old, he threw temper tantrums, destroyed his brother's and sister's toys, broke lamps and vases in the house and tried to run away so often that his parents had to install a special lock on their door. He had a glazed stare, made strange sounds and moved about without purpose.

title: Memorial Services
description: NATHANSONJerome. ??

title: LAW ON EMISSIONS AN ISSUE ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29A threeyear controversy over equipping older automobiles in smogplagued Southern California with special fumecontrol devices took on aspects of a movie's crosscountry comedy chase this week as the State Legislature moved toward conclusive settlement of the issue.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The Pub, 955 Allwood Road (near the junction of the Garden State Parkway and Route 3), Clifton. (201) 7732110.

title: Routine CheckCashing Photos Led to Capture of Susan Saxe
description: HARTFORD, March 29 (UPI) Pictures taken of Susan E. Saxe, the recently captured fugitive, as she cashed a check in Torrington, Conn., apparently were the ones that led to her arrest in Philadelphia this week.

title: The Nation
description: Money for foreign assistance usually is hard to come by, and this year's Foreign Aid Bill was no exception: Congress has taken nine months to pass a $3.7billion aid measure, and only did so after gutting much of President Ford's $6billion program.

title: The Region
description: In a decision that has the potential for undermining the legal foundation on which suburbia is built, the New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled illegal those zoning laws that effectively exclude poor and moderateIncome persons.

title: Patchogue Likes New Bus
description: PATCHOGUEThe Village of Patchogue's municipal minibus program, designed to provide transportation to the shopping district from outlying areas and other residential areas, has been a moderate success in its first six weeks of operation.

title: The People Part of Business Taxes
description: Public thinking about proposals for tax revision will benefit from recognition that business taxes are people taxes. Too often, personal taxes are treated as one thing and corporate taxes as another. Yet Federal taxes on the earnings of corporations must actually fall upon human beings. So must Social Security payroll taxes on all employers, as well as state and local taxes imposed on business.

title: Article 1  No Title
In the Mideast, All Possibilities Look Bad
description: The failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's latest round of negotiations in the Middle East leaves open a number of possibilities, none of them promising.

title: Australia Sending Planes
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, March 30  Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced in Canberra last night that Australia was making available seven Hercules transports of the Royal Australian Air Force to help in the evacuation of Da Nang.

title: Correction
description: The New York Times regrets that in the lastminute assembly of the photomontage of faces of women and black persons used with a story about the last hired and first fired on the front page of The Week in Review for Sunday. March 9, a photograph of Roslyn Willett, president of Roslyn Willett Associates, consultants, public relations, marketing and food service, was included. Roslyn Willett is, and has been for 16 years, president of her own firm and therefore was neither recently hired nor recently fired. The photo was taken when she was chairwoman of Women's Political Caucus, Inc.

title: Private Clubs for Savers
description: A small but growing number of savings and loan associations are finding that running free private clubs for their customers has a lot more marketing impact than parceling out toasters and hair dryers.

title: Boston Globe Establishes A Book Award of $1,000
description: A book award carrying a cash prize of $1,000 has been established by The Boston Globe to honor the late Laurence L. Winship. Mr. Winship, who retired as editor of the newspaper in 1965, died March 3 at the age of 85.

title: Carey Blocks Sunrise Bypass, but Backers of Plan Still Have Hope
description: EAST HAMPTON  Although Governor Carey has killed the plan to extend Sunrise Highway 23 miles from Shinnecock Hills to Amagansett by withdrawing the state's environmental impact statement and application for $80 million in matching funds from the Federal Government, those East Enders who favor the bypass will not bury the proposal.

title: Susan Rich Engaged To Robert Morison Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Corey Rich Jr. of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Scudder Rich of Belmont, Mass., to Robert Francis Morison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Morison of Chatham, N.J.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: With emergent romanticism came an interest in things exotic, and to Europeans in the last quarter of the 18th century nothing was as exotic as the Near East. There were novels and poems about Saracens and their alien culture. Mozart wrote Die Entfhrung aus dim Serail, one of the first enduring pieces of music about the neighbors to the East. The craze lasted well into the following century. Delacroix devoted many paintings to Arabian subjects. There is the Ingres odalisque. There was the great (in its day) symphony by Felicien David, celebrating the reaches of the desert.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Yonkers woman died and a Mount Vernon man was seriously injured after their car crashed through a bridge guard rail on the Mount VernonYonkers border and plunged 50 feet to the banks of the Bronx River below, the police reported.

title: FORD APPROVES TAX CUTS, SAYING HE HAS NO CHOICE; BARS A NEW SPENDING RISE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Ford, saying he had no choice but to take it or leave it, signed tonight the $22.8billion tax reduction bill enacted by Congress on Wednesday.

title: A Big Tax Bill, And Then Some
description: The Congress has passed legislation providing tax cuts and other benefits amounting to $22.8billion, a package different in size and shape than many Congressmen and President Ford had wanted. The intent is to help get the nation out of recession, and though almost all economists and most Washington officials agreethe bill addresses that intent, nobody can be certain it will work as supposed.

title: Why the Leaders of Israel and Egypt Said No to Mr. Kissinger
description: CAIRO  From the Egyptian point of view, the outer limits of Secretary Kissinger's freedom of maneuver in his last stepbystep mediation effort had long been clear:

title: Article 8  No Title
The Spoken Poem Can Be A Kind of Theater
description: The afternoon sunlight falling through the casement windows overlooking Bedford Street picked out four men from the Muni, the city's Bowery welfare shelter, waiting to participate in a Saturday poetry reading at Chumley's in Greenwich Village. Three were black and one Hispanic  all were young. After an introduction by Frederick Bauman, who runs the weekly readings at Chumley's, they read their own poems and some by friends.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uncola Is About to Be Unounced
description: Conversion to the metric system, long urged for the United States, is becoming a reality in some fields aside from the baseball one at the Riverfront Stadium of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: ClearWater Spring Lures Crowds to Park in Edison
description: EDISONFrom Elizabeth, Newark and Irvington, among many other towns, they come to Roosevelt Park here and its rapidly running spring of clear water.

title: INEQUITIES FOUND IN HOUSING LAWS
description: Because of contradictory laws, thousands of tnants living in renovated buildings under the city's rehabilitation program are paying higher rents than theh were originally supposed to, while their landlords are still receiving a tax break.
