description: What They Are Saying

title: Naber, Skinner Set Records
description: CLEVELAND, March 29John Naber, a 19yearold Californian, and Jonty Skinner, a 21yearold South African, created the major stir tonight as the 52d annual National Collegiate swimming championships ended.

title: Mother Calls Jersey Sniper Enraged
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 29The man arrested last night following the sniper killing of two policemen had become enraged by some unknown cause during a 15minute period that he was out of his home last evening according to his family.

title: A Weakened America Is Not What Other Nations See
description: WASHINGTONIf the United States does not provide any further military aid to South Vietnam and Cambodia, Secretary of State Kissinger has said, then we are likely to find a massive shift in the foreign policies of many countries, and a fundamental threat over a period of time to [our] security.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Serious business. With the Quality Paperback Book Service, a BookoftheMonth Club subsidiary, now well into its second year, the men who run it are cheerier than ever about the venture. They have 40,000 subscribers enrolled currently, expect 100,000 this time next year. Their experience to date convinces them that the Q.P.B.S. is going to help change the shape of book publishing: more firms will be encouraged to issue trade paperbacks, volumes that can be, distinguished from their massmarket cousins by their outsize, better paper and binding, and higher price.

title: Weakfoot
description: Out chasing possum with his dog, Lonny finds that they've run to a part of the Cypress Swamp he'd promised to keep away from. And in a sudden, heartbreaking battle, he loses his dog to a savage panther, Weakfoot.

title: SARAH T. D. LUTGE
description: Sarah T. Dickson Lutge, formerly on the English faculty of Brooklyn, Smith and WellesleY Colleges, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 193 Waverly Place and in New London, N.H.

title: BRIDGE
description: Well over a century ago chess organizers solved the problem of the slow player by giving him a clock that records the time he spends in thought. Bridge organizers have never found a completely satisfactory solution, although they have tried a number of devices: monitors; score penalties; colored progressive warnings leading to penalties; and even chess clocks.

title: Parents Vow a Fight on School Zoning Changes
description: First we'll appeal to the central Board of Education, Mrs. Florence Kersner said last week. If that fails, we'll go on and on...

title: Stage: Kahn's Romeo
MURDER IS CHARGED IN HOSTAGE'S DEATH
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y. March 29 (UPI)A man accused of holding a couple hostage for more than three hours Thursday night has been charged with murder, after the police said it had been determined that a bullet from his .32caliber revolver killed one of the hostages.

title: Nonprofessionals Do a Professional Job in a Rochester Project
description: The percentage of American children who experience moderate to severe problems adapting to primary school has been. put As high as 30; using the same gauge, the figure climbs to 70 in some ghetto areas. Thirty per cent works out to 8.7 million of the current elementary school crop.

title: Hudson County Is Invoking 1877 Antilottery Law
description: JERSEY CITYHarold J. Ruvoldt Jr., who operates in a jurisdiction where numbers play sometimes seems no harder to find than a neighborhood candy store, has come up with a lawyer's equivalent of shooting fish in a barrel.

title: J. D. Pizzurro to Wed Miss Reed
description: Mr, and Mrs. Donald Vincent Reed of New York and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Reed, to Joseph Dorninic Pizzurro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Pizzurro of Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: A Voice Not Far Offstage
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq  Iraq was not party to the latest Kissinger round of ArabIsraeli peace negotiations. It is not a neighbor of the little Jewish state but Baghdad is very much concerned in the whole affair. It has taken part in previous military confrontations through forces sent via Syria and Jordan.

title: LETTERS
description: Stockholders

title: Avatar, 5 1, Wins Santa Anita Derby
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 29 (UPI)Avatar, an outsider, scored a nose victory today in the 38th running of the $127,900 Santa Anita Derby, a race that usually decides the best 3yearold in the West to challenge for the Kentucky Derby.

title: ART VIEW
description: The work of Francis Bacon has never loomed very large on the horizons of the American art world. Until the other day, I had never heard an American artist speak of it, even in passing, and the big retrospective mounted by the Guggenheim Museum in 1963 certainly left no discernible trace on American painting. The work has been much written about in American journals (often by Mr. Bacon's British compatriots), and it has been eagerly acquired by American collectors at high prices but it has remained curiously outside the interests of the artists themselves.

title: Msgr. Aloysius Coogan, 69, Pastor of City Island Church
description: Msgr. Aloysius F. Coogan. pastor of St. Man Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church, City Island, the Bronx, since 1967, died Friday in Misericordia Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Toscanini
description: George Marek, a retired R.C.A. vice president and the author of amiable biographies of Puccini, Richard Strauss, Beethoven, and Mendelssohn, has taken on Arturo Tosoanini. From Marek I learn that according to a Fortune magazine survey in January, 1938, just after the founding of the N.B.C. Symphony. Toscanini's name was known to 39.9 per cent of all the people in the United States and that 71 per cent of those millions could identify him correctly. Now, almost

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONState Senator Alene S. Ammond of Camden County, who sued her Democratic colleagues for banishing her from party caucuses, is negotiating to have her legislative adventures become the pilot for a television series.

title: Yanks Find Time for Other Florida Sports
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 (AP)The Montreal Expos reached Bob Gibson for seven hits and five runs in the second inning today and defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 54, in exhibition baseball.

title: ARTHUR DELVENTHAL
description: Arthur Delventhal, who retired as pressman in charge for The New York Times in 1970, died yesterday at his home in Teaneck, N.J., at the age of 75. Mr. Delventhal started work at The Times in 1918.

title: Coast Guard Says Budget Cuts Curb Antipollution Role
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)The Coast Guard says budget cuts have forced it to reduced by 50 per cent its participation in environment work including prevention of oil spills.

title: FloodControl Plan Faces Senate Test
description: TRENTON  A bill that could institute broad changes in the state's floodcontrol and water  supply policies will receive its first legislative test here this week.

title: LON NOL REPORTED ABOUT TO DEPART
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sunday, March 30Cambodian political sources said early today that President Lon Nol had decided to leave Cambodia for visits to Indonesia and the United States.

title: Rosewall Wins Final 75, 46, 76
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 29 (UPI)Ken Rosewall of Australia won a thirdset tiebreaker today to defeat Butch Buchholz, for the championship of the 335,000 South Invitation tennis tournament. The scores were 75, 46, 76.

title: George V. Higgins goes to Washington
description: George Higgins's first venture into political fiction reads something like the Nixon White House Transcripts. His dialogues, which make up nearly the entire book, are elliptical, digressive, confusing and often seem implausibleeven as the Nixon Tapes did. He can make you blush with embarrassment for the people you are eavesdropping onembarrassment for their intimacies overheard and also for their banality. But pant of Higgins's success is that the conversations in A City on a Hill, including several that drake your skin crawl, have the undeniable sound of primarysource material on life in Washington in the seventies.

title: Funny is money
description: At the theater in San Francisco where I saw Young Frankenstein, the audience began screaming with laughter before the film went ona sure sign of cult in action, this time the Children of Mel Brooks. The movie itself, a parodyhomage to the traditional horror genre, was not easy to see and hear over the immense wigs of a coven of campy cockettes and their crunching, yowling admirationa special transvestite Judy Garland audience. But elsewhere in America, where it is earning those bountiful millions of dollars which flow inexorably toward the hit movie, the audience includes kids who know thought of Frankenstein. Mary Shelley, the Borscht Belt, or shtick humor, as well as oldsters bred on Boris Karloff, the Lon Chaneys Senior or Junior, and Bela Lugosi. Mel Brooks made connection with Blazing Saddles,

title: Youth Sentenced to College
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29 (AP)  An 18yearold high school senior, found guilty in an $85 liquor store robbery, has been sentenced to two years in college. Maricopa County Superior Court Judge C. Kimball Rose ordered Jerome Glenn Currethers yesterday to complete two years of college as part of the terms of his fiveyear probation.

title: Law Student Fighting Ouster
description: CAMDEN  Rutgers Law School has come under intense political pressure to readmit a highly decorated disabled war veteran who has been dismissed for the third time because of academic difficulties.

title: CHESS
description: A positional pawn sacrifice is seen mostly as a device for pressing a powerful initiative in advantageous circumstances, but it can also be employed in unfavorable positions to fight for a draw. Then the idea is to keep the opponent on the defensive so that he cannot utilize his extra material.

title: Duvillard Captures Pro Giant Salom
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 29 (AP)France's Henri Duvillard won the giant slalom in the $30,000 Lange Cup pro ski competition today, putting himself in position to challenge America's Hank Kashiwa for the world pro championship.

title: Easter in France: A Pilgrim's Tale
description: ELEVEN in the morning as I walk the one main street of HouvillelaBranche, the gray stucco houses flush on the sidewalk shuttered against the sun. Although it is Good Friday, a day for pilgrims, the good Catholic women of the crossroads village eight miles from Chartres watch with tightlipped suspicion this jaunty, sixfoot American in checked hunting shirt with pack on his back. After six days of walking, I think, I should at least be near enough to see the cathedral today. But all I see are Houville's Romanesque church and a monument to the village's dead from two world wars. The women are buying fresh trout and snapper from a vending truck in the square as I follow a detour out of town, still scanning the horizon for the gray, asymmetrical towers of the cathedral high on the hill of Chartres.

title: WELDING PROJECT BEGINS ON SUBWAY
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has embarked on a 10year trackwelding project designed to make New York City's clattering subway system more like its quiet cousins In Montreal, Paris, Berlin, Stockholm and Hamburg.

title: An Expatriate's Spring
description: It is 6 A.M. in San Jos, Costa Rica. I open the drapes of our window to view the familiar drama of the day's beginning  distant mountains illumined brightly by the first fingers of light from the rising sun wearing patches of clouds like inebriated old ladies with their hats askew. Nearby are the gaudy tropical displays of bougainvillea, hibiscus. poinciana, flame vine and the firecracker plant.

title: Design: A house transcending the Shingle Style and International Style
description: Designing any singlefamily house is an increasingly difficult undertaking today, when high construction costs have drastically curtailed all residential building, and brought singlefamilyhouse construction virtually to a halt. As a consequence, the singlefamily house designed by an architect to meet a particular family's particular needs is becoming increasingly irrelevant in a social sense.

title: City Seeks Funds to Aid Brooklyn Freight Line
description: The Bay Ridge rail line across Brooklyn, once a major throughroute for 1,100 freight cars a day, is a littered and tired old track today. But it may be on the brink of a major increase in activity if city plans materialize.

title: Yes Would Make Rabin ExPremier
description: JERUSALEM  It was an offer Yitzhak Rabin had to refuseassuming, that is, he wanted to avoid the collapse of his coalition Government, a revolt within his own party and an abrupt end to his career as Premier.

title: Life History and the Historical Moment
description: Erik Erikson is probably the closest thing to an intellectual hero in American culture today. He has added striking new phrases to our languagelife cycle, identity crisis, inner space, psychohistorywords that signify new ways to interpret and confront our lives. As a psychoanalyst he has played with children and unraveled marvelous hidden depths and resonances in their play. He has evoked the joy and dread of adolescence with a rare vividness and sympathy, and disclosed new dimensions of meaning in experiences we thought we knew all too well. In his many case histories he has shown us people in their full actuality, neither horribly grotesque nor transcendently holy, with needs and fears and longings in which we

title: Book Ends
description: April. . . . is the cruelest month, wrote T. S. Eliot. What lilacs are publishers breeding in the dead land? Is everything coming up roses or crabgrass? Is spring running a little late this year? Will summer surprise us? Consider the following:

title: Judith Kinnard Engaged To Christopher Cabot
description: Judith McDowell Kinnard, a Freelance writer of Philadelphia, and Christopher Cabot, countrymusic columnist of The Associated Press and night editor of its Nashville bureau, plan to marry May 17 in Franklin, Tenn.

title: Roses Need a Good Planting Start . . .
description: Allday sunshine is ideal for roses, but they will thrive with at least halfday sunlight. Do not plant roses under trees or near other large plants since they need room for their own root systems to develop without competition. Mere should be 15 to 30 feet distance between roses and large shade tree spread.

title: APPEAL BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 28President Ford announced tonight that he has ordered United States Navy ships and other vessels to evacuate helpless refugees from coastal cities in South Vietnam and to take them to safe havens in the south.

title: HOWARD BLEIER, 49, NEWSMAN, PUBLICIST
description: Howard B. Bleier, a former newspaperman and sports publicity man, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 49 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: In Summary
description: President Ford will be forced to violate his pledge, made after the experience of Watergate, never to run a campaign independently of the Republican National Committee.

title: What's Doing in TEL AVIV
description: CITY OF CONTRASTSTel Aviv is Israel's principal city. It is a crowded, noisy, bustling metropolis that rose on sand dunes on the Mediterranean coast faster than it could be planned. With its flat, unexciting landscape, it never, matched the majestic grandeur of Jerusalem, Israel's capital, or the beauty of Haifa, the main harbor city. But because it was the only city in the world where the mayor, the bankers, the judges, the policemen, the firemen and the street cleaners were all Jews, it became the magnet for Jewish immigrants during the decades of British rule in Palestine. Now that there is a whole Jewish state, an allJewish city is no longer so noteworthy, but, as the biggest population center (386,000), Tel Aviv continues to set the pace in Israeli life. It is the home of the leading theaters, the best orchestra, the opera, the ballet, the press, the political parties and the big financial, commercial and business enterprises. It is a city of contrasts where immigrants from the casbahs of North Africa and from the centers of European civilization made impacts on the mode of life. One can shop for secondhand junk in an oriental bazaar in the cacophonic flea market in the Jaffa section or against the background of soft music in airconditioned department stores (Kol Bo Shalom at the corner of Ahad Haam and Herzl Street or Hamashbir Lazarhan at 115 Allenby Road). The main attraction for tourists is Jaffa, a former Arab city that was incorporated into Tel Aviv after Israel gained independence. The ancient section of the city has been restored as an artists' colony. Galleries, boutiques and gift shops have been built into the maze of alleys and vaulted walls. Exotic restaurants operate in the reconstructed ruins, and nightclubs offer strip shows or folk lore. Tel Aviv is the main base for tourists mainly because its location and transport facilities make it a convenient hub for travel around the country.

title: Deborah Althen Wed to Kenton T. Finch
description: The marriage of Deborah Anne Althen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis John Althen of Elgin, Ill., and Monsey, N.Y., to Kenton Terrence Finch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunter Finch of Atlanta, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Dominator, Wire Fox Terrier, Takes Group Award at Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 29A ??ire fox terrier, Ch. Aryee Dominator, who was best in show at the fall International Kennel Club fixture, took a big step tonight toward winning the spring event as well. He took the group award.

title: Solar Sohio
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) is doing its best to prove that it is a true energy company. It disclosed recently that, aided by a grant from the Energy Research and Development Administration, it would investigate the use of solar energy to provide hot water for its uranium processing plant at Grants, N.M.

title: Frazier Hits Age 30, Seeks a Bucks' Gift
description: Jean was there. So were Lisa, Gretchen, Julie, Judy and Yolanda.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Connemara Farm, you'll find Flat Rock, N.C., a little more than 25 miles southeast of Asheville, just off Interstate 26. A National Park Service sign marking the Sandburg home as a national historic site is visible on U.S. 25 in the center of Flat Rock. The sign not only directs the visitor to the correct turnoff but also to parking space.

title: King James
description: The first King of Great Britain (selfproclaimed until Parliament agreed), James Stuart has had a deservedly unenviable reputation owing to his family background, his bisexuality, his unsettled religious allegiances and his juggleandrule politics. This view of James is only slightly ameliorated by Lady Antonia Fraser, who is wellknown for her sympathetic biography of Mary Queen of Scots and her dyspeptic life of Oliver Cromwell; for she suggests, in this long, exculpatory essay that his subjects, even if they did not always obey him, were not so badly served by him after all.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: As a director, George C. Scott has gone to extraordinary, sometimes most effective, lengths to give Eugene O'Neill's All God's Chillun Got Wings room to breathe. The play, which Circle in the Square has mounted professionally for the first time since 1924, needs air about it on two counts. It is a skeletal piece, content to rough in the childhood fondness between a white girl and a black lad, leap to their total racial estrangement by the time they are graduating from high school, leap again to the tormented marriage they make when the girlabandoned by a white loveris offered the virtually slavelike adoration and care of her once spurned friend. It is more nearly a graph of nervously intimate blackwhite relations than a robust plunge into the fullness of flesh, and if it were to be played at a normal rate, line tumbling on line, it would not only be over all too soon, it would have the approximate poetic texture of a chalktalk.

title: McGovern Meets Arafat and Stresses Palestinian Issue
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 Senator George McGovern is reported to have declared here that in wake of the failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East mission the United States should address itself directly to the Palestine issue, which he described as the crux of the problem.

title: Women Athletes and the Comparison Game: What Are the Rules?
description: On a recent Friday night in Toronto's Maple Leaf Gardens, Francie Larrieu runs to awomen's world indoor record at 1,500 meters, the closest competitor nearly a quarterlap behind. The next night, in the San Diego Indoor Games, she runs to a mile world record, again bettering the 1,500meter record on the way. Her closest competitor is again a quarterlap behind. She is awarded the outstandingperformance awarda rare happening for a woman.

title: Marxist News Service Request For Press Cards Here Rejected
description: The Police Department has rejected a request for press credentials from a militant Marxist news service, the New Solidarity. International Press Service, and the organization said last week It was considering legal action.

title: Montclair Exhibit: Homage to Color
description: MONTCLAIR  The Fairfield Porter retrospective exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum assembles the work of one of America's outstanding contemporarty artists. The canvases are of remarkable quality underscoring the significance of Mr. Porter's achievement.

title: K. Keith Roe Plans Marriage To Elizabeth Brownlow Eaton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Eaton 3d of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Brownlow Eaton, to Kenneth Keith Roe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Roe of Greenwich, Conn., and Warwick, Bermuda. A June wedding is planned.

title: The High Cost of Recalls
description: There's a snake in your toolbox. It lies neatly coiled, the black strands of cable glistening in the light and at first glance it appears innocent enough. But one day, when you least expect it, it may kill you.

title: Saudi Arabia: Stability During Transition
description: The assassination of King Faisal, which sent tremors of fear through the West, would hardly have attracted sustained notice a halfdozen years ago. It is the energy crisis that has thrust to the center of world attention a desert kingdom and its tiny population of little more than four million.

title: Cavaliers Stumble In Race
description: ATLANTA, March 29 (AP) Herm Gilliam popped in 17 of his 23 points in the second half tonight, triggering the Atlanta Hawks to a 10397 National Basketball Association victory over the stumbling Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: In Summary
description: Not quite out of one budget crisis, Mayor Beame is in another that appears far more serious. The inflation prices the city must pay and recession revenues it is receiving produced a deficit of $430million in New York City's present fiscal year. The Mayor says the same combination will create a deficit four times as great, $1.68billion, in the next fiscal year, beginning July 1.

title: Janice Headlee, Joseph M. Byers Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Allen Headlee of Pittsburgh's Fox Chapel section have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Elizabeth Headlee, to Joseph Murray Byers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Buckley M. Byers of Sewickley, Pa., and Washington.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Tuesday  German Shepherd Dog Club of Greater New Haven specialty and obedience match, K. of C. Hall. 2630 Whitney Avenue, Hamden, Conn.; entries from 7:15. P.M.; judging 8; special handling class for exhibitors 7:30.
