description: A Futile Exercise

title: Auto's Future: Cutback in Size and Frills
description: DETROIT, March 29The auto industry, already shaken by the energy crisis, has been plunged into an economic crisis that has left many of its executives feeling helpless and uncertain.

title: The Physicians
description: By Henry Denker. 384 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Hirshfields Have Child
description: A daughter was born March 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Hirshfield of New York at the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Hirshfield, whose husband is a lawyer with Cravath. Swaine & Moore, is an actress known as Susan Hanley. The child has been named Lauren Kate.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Attica Trial Something of an Anticlimax
description: BUFFALOAs a question of law, the only issue in the trial of John Hill and Charles Joseph Pernasilice is whether they killed Correction Officer William E. Quinn by beating him in the opening hours of the uprising at Attica State Correctional Facility on Sept. 9, 1971.

title: New Novel
description: Motherless tykes and their vagabonding daddies have been hitting the road to nostalgia in increasing numbers lately. This one is a 100 proof specimen of the genrerich in downhome humor and as full of action as a family of boll weevils before the coming of DDT. The curtain rises on a ne'er  do  well named Casey Blue, lamming it out of a Texas Panhandle town one lap ahead of the sheriff. Casey's 9yearold daughter is nicknamed Baby Love, and his preWorld War 11 car is named Sweetheart.

title: Ben Hibbs, 73, Fortner Editor Of Saturday Evening Post, Dies
description: Ben Hibbs, former editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died yesterday of leukemia at Ads home in Penn Valley a Philadelphia suburb. He was 73 years old.

title: FRENCH BYPASSING ARABS' BLACKLIST
description: PARIS, March 29An innovation in investment banking is helping the French get around the Arabs' practice of blacklisting Jewish  controlled banks in the syndication of corporate borrowings.

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Better
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., March 29 (AP) Mamie Eisenhower's condition remained stable today at a Fort Gordon Hospital as she continued to recover from intestinal problems, physicians said. Maj. George Foster, spokesman for the Army Medical Center, said the 79yearold former First Lady had a comfortable nights.

title: And Proper Pruning to Bloom
description: Hybrid tea, grandiflora and floribunds roses require annual pruning in the spring after winter protection has been removed. There is an old saying that roses, are pruned when the forsythia blooms. In the metropolitan region, this is about the last part of March or the first part of April. In very cold zones, prune roses in late April. If the rosebushes are pruned too early, injury from repeatedfrosts may make a second pruning necessary.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N. Y. Maiden, local and green working hunters: limit and open jumpers, adult horsemanship. 8:30 A,M.

title: CrossDistrict Busing Foreseen In Wilmington Integration Order
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 29 (AP)A threejudge Federal court has asked for new proposals to integrate the city's largely black school district. One judge says the move will lead to busing across district lines.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Waller Is Affianced
description: Andrea Lynn Waller, daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Michael Van Wetterin Waller of Columbus, Ohio, and Donald Perry Lee, plan to be married July 5, according to the announcement made by Miss Waller's parents. Mr. Lee is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Lee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Col. Sanders Gives Up in Hong Kong
description: Colonel Sanders Kentucky Fried Chicken has closed its four remaining outlets in Hong Kong, less than two years after ambitious plans were announced to open 50 to 60 stores in the British colony.

title: Soviet and Mongolian Wrestlers Win
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 29 (AP)The Soviet Union captured its third straight World Cup wrestling championship with victories in its opening two matches today.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov are always in the limelight nowadaysunderstandably, for both are capable, with the drop of their names on a contract of filling a large New York theater. Without entering into the rights and wrongs of the matter, it is clear to anyone that the two Russian emigres are star in a way that, at present. American male dancers are not. Yet, a man such as Lawrence Rhodes is an uncommonly good dancer, even a great dancer. He also deserves a little celebrating. The thought lingered with me the other week when I was watching Rhodes dancing, with that animallike absorption in his own movements and that fierce emotional intensity, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the Pennsylvania Ballet. There was a special quality there I wanted to put on paper.

title: A lifetime of selfscrutiny, selfdoubt and success
description: Kenneth Clark on television comes across as a man armored against misfortune. In appearance younger than his age (he was 71 last July) he strikes many of those who watch him on public television as being Privilege personified. Some of them love it; some of them don't. But either way round they say to themselves, There goes a man who has never known what it is to be thwarted, put down, misunderstood or in want.

title: Men As Viewed by Women Artists
description: For men who have not been able to figure cut just how women see them there is an exhibition at the Queens Art Museum that might help. Sons and Others is a collection of 50 works by contemporary women artists that highlight men in a rich variety of ways.

title: Retiring Wooden Holds N.C.A.A. Title Records
description: SAN DIEGO, March 29Jahn. Wooden, at his accustomed position on the victor's podium after his 619th triumph as basketball coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, smiled and said today he would retire after Monday night's National Collegiate title game.

title: Susan Val Cleary Is the Bride Of Tor Johannes ArntJensen Jr.
description: Susan Val Cleary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Cleary of Venice, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Tor Johannes AmtJensen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. AmtJensen of Moss, Norway. The Rev. Robert E. Chable of the United Church of Christ performed the ceremony at the Far Horizons resort in Sarasota. Fla.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: By now everyone who ever reads music criticism must know both sets of clichs about the compositions of Franz Liszt, how the transcendental virtuoso wrote meretriciously selfproclaiming works in which the surface brilliance and technical ingenuity of the writing imperfectly mask the banal, even trashy substances beneath; and how, on the other hand, the great humanist and seer peered off into the unknown region, composing music of great originality, harmonic daring, coloristic imagination, motivic tautness and structural tightness, intimating in these characteristics the innovations of Brahms, Debussy, Bartk and Schoenberg.

title: A Deliciously Decadent Dead City
description: Erich Wolfgang Korngold's 1920 opera Die tote Stadt (The Dead City) is a perfect example of what used to be called movie music but in the very best sensea luminous symphonic sound, luscious romantic themes and explicitly suggestive musical effects that instantly define time, place and dramatic gesture.

title: Excerpts From Reported Vietnam Document
description: Following are excerpts from what is described as a captured Communist document, made available early this year by the United States Embassy in Saigon, which said it was drafted late in 1974. The document reportedly guides the current military campaign. Critics of the war have long questioned the authenticity of such documents, used by the United States throughout the war to support American and South Vietnamese policy. James M. Markham, chief of The New York. Times bureau in Saigon, has written, There was no way of establishing from independent sources the authenticity of the document, but its language and argumentation are similar to those of earlier Communist directiver.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: April 1New Jersey Association of Corvair Enthusiasts meeting at Dooley Chevrolet. 685 Route 202206. North Somerville. N. J. 7:30 P.M.

title: Weather and Recession Hamper Holiday Sales
description: PARAMUSMerchants in many of this area's shopping centers said last week that unfavorable weather and the economic situation had hampered Easter sales in all but soft items.

title: Sao Paulo, Opposition Center, Feels Impact of Liberalization
description: SAO PAULOWe believe in President Geisel's good intentions, and only hope he'll be able to carry them out, Senator Andre Franco Montoro declared a few days ago. Many people in this Opposition stronghold share his view.

title: Gymnastics to Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 29 (UPI)The University of Michigan, with all 12 athletes on the team qualifying for individual finals, won the Big Ten gymnastics championship today, its 12th victory in the last 15 years. Michigan won the championship with 419.8 points, followed by Minnesota with 397.9 points and Iowa, the defender in third place, with 388.8.

title: Nowhere left to flee
description: The great migrations within Western societies in the 20th century have been migrations for jobs. With an urgency typical of fleeing from war, plague or famine, people by the millions have cast away from familiar communities and customs to find places for themselves in modern industry. Joblessness moved them and continues to move them with the force of a natural disaster.

title: UC.L.A. Tops Louisville, 7574; Will Oppose Kentucky in Final
description: SAN DIEGO, March 29 The University of California, Los Angeles, reached the final of the National Collegiate basketball tournament today with a thrilling 7574 overtime victory against Louisville, and then had its moment of joy tempered when John Wooden announced that he would end his coaching career after Monday night's title game against Kentucky.

title: The City Has Assets; Cash Is Something Else Again
description: Once a month or so, representatives from the major banking syndicates gather around a little green tin box in the City Controller's office. They are there to lend money to the city. Each syndicate inserts a sealed bid into the box. The syndicate that offers the lowest interest rate is permitted to buy millions of dollars in city notes or bonds, which will be resold to investors.

title: Home Club Also Gains Affection of Nassau Fans
Food News
description: ORANGEEveryone is related at Serafina's, an Italian food store and processing plant at 182 South Center Street. The proprietor, Gennaro (Jerry) Valvano, firmly believes that it is good business to keep it all in the family.

title: 3 Pitchers Give Lift To Mets
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 29  The New York Mets' pitching situation brightened on three fronts today when Tom Seaver, Jon Matlack and Craig Swan, working miles apart, turned in impressive performances.,

title: 60 Killed in Train Crash Worst Ever in Mozambique
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, March 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  Mozabique's worst rail accident ever killed 60 people yesterday, it was reported today.

title: Sarah Frances Doty Engaged To Samuel A. Megeath 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Doty of Portland, Ore., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Frances Doty, to Samuel Addison Megeath 3d of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. A. Megeath Jr. of Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Perfectibility: False Premise, False Promise
description: So now we have to worry about aspirin. There seems no longer to be any place for a body to hide. Wherever we go, the National Academy of Sciences, the Food and Drug Administration, Ralph Nader's Health Research Group and Senator William Proxmire will track us down. And whatever we are doing when they find us is likely to be bad for our brains, breasts, livers, lungs, hearts, eyes, teeth, kidneys, chromosomes and/or sex lives.

title: Francoise O. Lepage Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Regis A. Lepage of Auburn, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Francoise Odette Lepage, to Peter Michael Keefe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Keefe of Boston and Washington.

title: Not With a BANG but a TOCKTOCK
description: The door shut with a PLOCH. The rock fell and made a noise, SDOK. SHENG went the pistol, and SPEAK went the barrel of gunpowder. Water splashes PLUFF, a whip lashes ZAFF, and swords clash SCLENG. The ringing bell does not go TINGALING but DLIN DLIN, whereas a coin falls to the ground not with a PLINK but with a SVIMM.

title: Stein Urges State to Stop Building of Nursing Homes
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein called on the Legislature yesterday to stop the building of new profitmaking nursing homes and to impose a tough new code that would link Medicaid payments to the quality of care at the existing ones.

title: Player Lauds Martin's Ability
description: The game of baseball, says the New York Yankees' Bob Oliver, is good; It's the peopie in it who are wickywacky.

title: Where Carl Sandburg Walked 'heath Stars
description: THE drive winds and climbs through the pines, the house coming into view high above, looming like a white clapboard Acropolis. Here in Flat Rock, N.C., high in the Blue Ridge Mountains, Carl Sandburgpoet, biographer, historian, newspaperman, novelist, minstrel  took his nightly walks beneath a quiet dome of stars. Might notice once again a ring of gold/ kept its circle around the moon/five hours one Tuesday night. Could sit on the front porch and gaze out through white antebellum columns at a lake below, the lake of which he said, This fake belongs to God, but He leased it to me.

title: JULIE EISENHOWER TELLS OF BIBLE HELP
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Julie Eisenhower says that Jesus Christ has replaced with love what might have been bitterness and malice in her heart.

title: Oooooooooboy
description: The 2,000yearold man was first heard from in 1950 when Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner began improvising a series of comic conversations in which Brooks impersonated the ancient man and Reiner was his interviewer. The conversations became the basis of a very popular series of record albums. Here are some bits from the first album:

title: Senator Caemmerer: Legislature's Transit Expert
description: ALBANYA bit less than half an hour before a scheduled meeting with Governor Carey's top associates about transitaid legislation, last week, State Senator John D. Caemmerer of Williston Pack was given his first glimpse of the administration bills.

title: Hampton School Opens a Store
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  the Hampton Day School, a private school here founded in 1966 to provide innovative education, opened a crafts and antiques store yesterday. All proceeds will go toward its scholarship fund.

title: Dog's Welcome Rests On Owner's Behavior
description: The behavior of dog ownersnot their dogscontinues to influence hotel and motel owners in their decision to accept or reject guests with pets, according to the Gaines Dog Re search Center, which did a survey in the United States and Canada.

title: Bid Time Return
description: By Richard Matheson. 278 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $8.95.

title: Dean Schaffer Fiance Of Kim Laurie Siegler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Siegler have announced the engagement of their daughter., Kim Laurie Siegler, to Dean I. Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin D. Schaffer. Both families are of West Orange, N. J.

title: Troops in a Town Near Saigon Shrug Off the Shelling
description: GO DAU HA, South Vietnam, March 297A South Vietnamese soldier in maroon undershorts sat in the shade of a deserted house here today as North Vietnamese shells landed around him.

title: British Taking Part
description: London, March 29 (UPI)Britain said today that her navy frigate Lowestoft had been ordered to assist in the evacuation of refugees, from Da Nang. A joint statement from the Foreign Office and Defense Department said a request for assistance in the evacuation had been received from the United States Government. The Lowestoft has been ordered not to pick up anyone in uniform or bearing arms, the statement said.

title: Census of the Future
description: Since Congress convened in January, some 500 energy bills have been introducedall of them apart from the Administration's own package of proposals. The volume of legislative efforts is a measure not only of widespread concern on the subject but of government's scattershot approach to a problem that is pressing now and certain to be acute in the years ahead.

title: Shop Talk
description: PARSIPPANYJust about everyone agrees that children should have a pet, and what could be more wonderful than getting them a kitten or a puppy? Getting them a bunny.

title: Use of Electricity In Northeast Fell 6.7% During 1974
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Electric power consumption in the Northeast fell by 6.7 per cent in 1974, a large drop, the Federal Power Commission has reported.

title: Court Settles Question Of Taste in Sandwiches
description: The case of Starlite Deli v. Blimple was chock full of legal complications and heavy on the whereas clauses, but the issue before State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Korn finally came down to one delicate question:

title: Ford Offers Assurances On Vessels for Evacuation
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 30The Ford Administration gave elaborate assurances today that the United States naval ships to he stationed off South Vietnam near Da Nang would not become involved in hostilities.

title: CONSORT ENSEMBLE DANCES AT CUBICULO
description: The Consort Dance Ensemble is a company that conceives choreography as balletically balanced, but its members dance in bare feet as modern dancers often do. One always has the nagging feeling that the dancers, though looking like moderns, hanker for the long expansive line of classical ballet. The group presented a selection of works Saturday evening at the Cubiculo that were slight but intriguing fragments.

title: S.I. BOY, 11, DROWNS WADING AFTER DOG
description: An 11yearold Staten Island boy, drowned near his home yesterday afternoon when he waded into Brooks Pond after a dog, lost his footing and tumbled into 10foot waters, the police reported.

title: ExConvict Brings Smiles to the Retarded
description: Down the halls of the state school for the retarded on Morton Street, the patients came skipping and shuffling to hug the tattered tramp figure of Ed (Skull) Murphy, his clown face smiling under the greasepaint and his arms overflowing with Easter baskets and stuffed toys.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Consolidated Edison Company feeder cable tailed for an hour yesterday morning during repair work, causing scattered power disruption in parts of lower Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island. It occurred between 2:15 and 3:15 A.M., and caused no blackouts or emergencies, according to the police. However, some computer operations were affected briefly. On Saturday night an underground cable failed in the Jamaica district of Queens for two hours, leaving 1,000 residents without power for that period.

title: ConRail Plan Threatening to Halt OneTrack Hunterdon County Line
description: RINGOESMembers of the United States Railway Association have probably never visited this small Hunterdon county hamlet a few miles northwest of Princeton.

title: Yugoslav Shot in France
description: LYONS, France, March 30 (AP)The Yugoslav Vice Consul here, Mladen Dugovic, shot four times by two men late last night as he was parking his car in a garage underneath his apartment building, was reportedly in serious condition today. The motive was not known, but investigators said the shooting may have been a political act. The gunmen fled.

title: $740Million Yearly Loss Reported in Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Errors and deceptions are draining away hundreds of millions of dollars budgeted to feed hungry Americans.

title: Hope for Accord Seen at SeaLaw Talks
description: GENEVA, March 27After years of nearly fruitless wrangling, 150 nations are finally getting down to serious negotiation here to write what John R. Stevenson, the chief United States delegate, has called a constitution for the oceans.

title: Berra Is Unruffled As Mets Lose Again
New York Club Wins
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 30The New York Lacrosse Club defeated the Huntington Lacrosse Club, 83, last night at Y.M.C.A. Field. The New Yorkers have won two straight in club competition. Billy Blanchard, an exWilliams College star, had four goals for New York.

title: Retriever Is Best at Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 30Ch. Cummings GoldRush Charlie, a golden retriever owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, Va., and Dr. L. V. Johnson, a research physicist at Princeton, was named best in a field of 3.018 dogs at the International Kennel Club fixture tonight. The event, which ended a twoday run in the Amphitheater, drew a total of 31.089 spectators, 11.809 tonight.

title: Donald Van Nostrand, 77, Ophthalmologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Donald Scott Van Nostrand, an ophthalmologist with FordhamMisericordia and Manhattan Eye and Ear hospitals, died Saturday in St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 30 (AP)Jose Napoles of Mexico retained his world welterweight boxing title last night when Armando Muniz of Los Angeles was disqualified in the 12th round for butting. Referee Ramon Berumen stopped the scheduled 15rounder and gave the decision to Napoles, although the champion was bleeding badly from both eyes and was virtually unable to defend himself. Berumen said the cuts had been caused by the challenger's head. The Cubanborn Napoles, 1461 pounds, was battered and bleeding profusely as Muniz slammed away with rights and lefts. Muniz, 145, was warned four times by Berumen about butting. Three warnings came in the third round, when the first cut appeared above the left eye of the 35yearold champion.

title: Illinois Flooding Eases
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., March 30 (UPI)Residents along the rapidly subsiding Pecatonica River began returning to their homes today. Some 500 of them were forced to flee Tuesday night when rains swelled THE river to a near record level of 17.1 feet.

title: MINE UNION'S CHIEF TO RUN AGAIN IN '77
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, said today that he would seek another fiveyear term in 1977, but that he expected some changes in union leadership in other contests.

title: Ellen Burstyn Strikes Arcs With Crowd
description: I was in a movie called Pit Stop. which was shown at driveins, remembered Ellen Burstyn. I played a mechanic married to a racing car driver. I learned how to weld in the picture. Miming the technique of welding, she said, You scrape until it sparks, and then you pull the spark up. It's called striking an arc. If you pull it too far away, you break the arc. As I was welding, I thought, what does this remind me ofin another system?

title: 8 Children Among 11 Slain
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, Monday, March 31Eight children, their parents and a grandmother were shot to death Easter Sunday in the grandmother's house, where the family had gathered for a holiday dinner the police said.

title: PATIENT NEGLECT DECRIED IN STUDY
description: Neglect and abuse of patients are characteristic of the profitmotivated nursinghome industry, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said yesterday in the third installment of his draft report for the Temporary State Cornmission on Living Costs and the Economy.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Arizona Killer of 3 Girls Dies of a Prison Stabbing
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30 (UPI)Charles Schmid Jr., who was convicted of killing three teenage girls in the nineteensixties, died today of stab wounds inflicted 10 days ago by other convicts of the Arizona State Prison.

title: Views on Easter Faith
description: St. Paul said that without the Easter proclamation of Christ's resurrection from the dead the Christian faith would be futile. Indeed, the church from the beginning based its life on that conviction. Yet mingled with this certainty are persistent ambiguities about the nature and meaning of that resurrection event. Such questions as whether there was a physical rising from the grave and the authenticity of several reported sightings of the risen Christ make Easter perhaps the most speculative day of the Christian year.

title: RETARDATION LINK TO LEAD IS FOUND
description: Mental retardation among Glasgow children has been linked in a Scottish epdimiological study to contamination of drinking water with low levels of lead.

title: The SelfDomino
description: I have believed ever since I came to Washington that it is overwhelmingly in our national interest to put the debate on Indochina behind us. So said the man whose policy has kept the issue of Indochina before us for six more years.

title: Greeks Vote in Municipal Elections
description: ATHENS, March 30 (AP)Early returns today in Greece's first municipal elections in more than 10 years showed centerleftist candidates making gains in Athens, Salonika and other major cities.

title: U. S. Wrestlers 3d in Cup Event
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 30 (AP)The United States team made a strong closing effort against the Soviet Union wrestlers, the champions, to finish third in the World Cup competition today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Thursday reported incorrectly that the State Office of the Welfare Inspector General had been abolished last month. The agency was extended in the 197576 budget.

title: Hospital in Brooklyn Open Despite Accreditation Loss
description: Linden General Hospital, a 78bed private health facility in a rundown part of Brooklyn's East New York section, has lost its accreditation and been declared hazardous, unneeded and irremediably obsolete by government inspectors. But the hospital continues to function because of an unabated flow of Government Medicaid payments that are its main source of support.

title: Ford Offers Assurances On Vessels for Evacuation
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 30The Ford Administration gave elaborate assurances today that the United States naval ships to be stationed off South Vietnam near Da Nang would not become involved in hostilities.

title: 270 Arrested in Florida As Youths Battle Officers
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP)  Vacationing youths clashed with the police briefly this morning during a rockandbottlethrowing disturbance. The police said that about 270 persons were arrested.

title: Peking Honors 2 From U.S.
description: TOKYO, March 30 (AP) Carl Albert, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and John J. Rhodes, the Republican leader, were honored at a Peking banquet this evening, China's official press agency Hsinhua reported. The representatives, their wives and some staff members arrived in Peking yesterday at the invitation of the Chinese Government.

title: In Suburbs, the Resurrection Is a Personal Religious Matter
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 30Easter dawned uncertainly today for two dozen members of the Scarsdale Congregational Church as they stood in a circle atop a wet and muddy hill at the Ward Pound Ridge reservation in northern Westchester County.

title: Library on Parapsychology Dedicated at Virginia Beach
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., March 30 (UPI)A research library housing what was hailed as one of the world's largest collections of writing on parapsychology was dedicated today by the Edgar Cayce Foundation.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The Consumers League of New Jersey, which will celebrate its 75th anniversary on April 26, is more convinced than ever of the need for grassroots activity to protect consumer interests.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Thursday reported incorrectly that the State Office of the Welfare Inspector General had been abolished last month. The agency was extended in the 197576 budget.

title: Yanks' Tidrow Breaks wand
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30The New York Yankees, who have only one more week to fool around before the major league baseball season begins, lost a player today who had been fooling around. Dick Tidrow, a valued relief pitcher, went on the shelf for 10 days to two weeks after suffering a hairline fracture of a none in his pitching hand.

title: Earl Brydges Dies
description: Earl W. Brydges. former majority leader of the State Senate, died yesterday of cancer in Lewiston, N.Y. He was 69. Details on Page 34.

title: HANOI FORCES MOVE SOUTH AFTER OCCUPYING DA NANG; U.S. SHIPS TO A VOID COMBAT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 31A speedy North Vietnamese force moved into chaotic Da Nang yesterday and met scant opposition from demoralized fleeing Government troops, according to Western and South Vietnamese military sources here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOUNG AND ABLE Something is going on, for sure, these nights in the back room of the Riviera Cafe, Seventh Avenue South and West Fourth Street. Pedestrians peering through the large lass window at sidewalk level can see young people gesticulating under bright lights. Pasted on the glass, a small poster invites you inside, no cover, no minimum, to the Off the Wall Improvisation Theater. Come and improvise with us.

title: Ceccoto Motorcycle Wins
description: LE CASTELLET, Franch, March 30 (AP)  Johnny Ceccoto, a 19yearold Venezuelan, won the 250cubic centimeter race of the Grand Prix de France today, the first event of the year in the world motorcycle championships. Ceccoto, on a privately entered Yamaha, raced at an average speed of about 93 miles an hour.

title: Poor Move From Crowded Java
description: JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, March 24The soil in his hamlet was too rocky and arid for the cultivation of rice. Those who owned land managed little more than subsistence farming. Being landless, Mr. Sastrosudarmo did not even manage that.

title: About the Yankees...
description: Pat Dobson, whose earnedrun average is 5.62, pitches for the Yankees today against the Twins at Orlando, Fla. A squad of about 18 will make the trip four hours each way by bus.... With Dick Tidrow injured and Mel Stottlemyre on waivers, the Yankees have 10 usable pitchers, two of whom may he dropped this week when the squad is cut from 29 to 25. Those on the wobbly list are Scott McGregor, Tippy Martinez, both of whom worked against Texas yesterday, and Dave Pagan.... With Billy Martin absent, the hyperactive Jimmy Piersall managed the Rangers and baited umpires from the thirdbase coaching box. Piersall streaked to the mound after Steve Hargan, his pitcher, was hit on the wrist by Dave Pagan's line drive, Hargan withdrew but was not injured.

title: Resurrection Symphony Heads an Easter Concert
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, ever the enterprising program builder, put together a marvelously appropriate one for his Easter Sunday appearance at Carnegie Hall with the American Symphony Orchestra. He began with the first New York performance of Oliver Knussen's Choral, in which the composer aimed at the effect of a sort of vision in which several funeral processions converge on one spot. And, in logical Easterly sequence, Mr. Thomas then gave a triumphant reading of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 in C minor, the Resurrection.

title: K. S. Adams, Retired Executive Of Phillips Petroleum, Dies at 74
description: HOUSTON, March 30 (UPI)K. S. Adams, retired chief executive officer of Phillips Petroleum Company, the country's 10th largest, died today in St. Luke's Hospital. He was, 74 years old.

title: About New York
description: The tour guide said the best was yet to come. Downtown, he said, made uptown pall. He was in a bus on West 46th Street, and the bus was full of tourists, all eager to capture New York. After the bus had gone around the block and turned left on Seventh Avenue, the tour guide even burst into song.

title: CAR RECALLS HELD LOSING IN IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 30New doubts have been raised about the success of efforts to recall automobiles with safety defects. The efforts are continuing on a broad scale, though they are attracting less attention.

title: COAST TRIAL TO AIR SYMBIONESE ISSUE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 30 (AP)Russell ?? and Joseph Remiro go on trial tomorrow for murder in what is expected to provide the first opportunity for courtroom scrutiny of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army, a terrorist group.

title: Larry Mahan's Adrenal Glands
description: Two things Larry Mahan said to a fellow named Douglas Kent Hall, who was doing a book about rodeo. If I'm competing at a large rodeo, he said, and I've won the first goround and I've drawn a good horse or a good bull for my next one, I really get psyched up. In fact, I get so psyched up I'm torn up inside. I just walk around and tell myself I'm an animal. I tell myself I'm an animal and I get worked up to a point where I'm so aggressive that there is no way I'm going to blow it. I refuse to let a negative thought come into my mind. I'll walk around and ask 20 or 30 guys about the horse I've drawn. And I like for guys to tell me he's a rank dude. I like this because it gets me psyched up that much more. And this creates more of a challenge for me. So if I've drawn a really tough horse, I can tell that morning how my attitude's going to run all day. This is when I'm really into it, and I know I have the confidence and I have what it takes.

title: Bronx Youth, 18, Held in Killing And Rape of a Neighbor Girl,
description: An 18yearold Bronx youth has been arrested in connection with the slaving of an 8yearold girl whose body was found early Saturday morning on a roofstair landing of the Morrisania Houses.

title: Abducted Dutch Consul Is Released in Colombia
description: CALI, Colombia, March 30 (AP)Eric Leupin, the Netherlands honorary consul here who was kidnapped Jan. 31 has been freed, authorities announced today.

title: New Tax Bill Helps Home Buyer Get Lowest Price
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Buyers of new homes not only get a tax break from the law signed yesterday by Presdent Ford, but they also get hep on obtaining the best price.

title: U.S. Olympic Swim Coach Exults After College Meet
description: CLEVELAND, March 30Dr. Jim Counsilman, who will coach the American men in the 1976 Olympic swimming at Montreal, can hardly wait. He thinks they will continue to dominate the Olympics, as they have for two decades.

title: Soviet Six Wins Title
description: GRENOBLE, France, March 30 (AP)The Soviet Union was beaten by Czechoslovakia, 43, today but won the European junior ice hockey championship. The Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Sweden, all had 41 wonlost records, but the Soviet Union was given the title because it had the best goal average.

title: Ford Decides Kissinger Will Remain Until '77
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 30  Secretary of State Kissinger and President Ford decided in a private meeting in the White House last Wednesday that Mr. Kissinger would continue in his office at least for the remainder of the President's term, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: $740Million Yearly Loss Reported in Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Errors and deceptions are draining away hundreds of millions of dollars budgeted to feed hungry Americans.

title: Pickles, Peppers and Other Puckery PalatePleasers
description: In an aura of sweet nostalgia, considering that the place is dedicated to halfsours and sours, the line on Hester Street in front of Guss Pickles Produce, Inc., runs heavily to color experts who select the hues of their pickles with a discrimination that would do credit to an interior decorator.

title: MARK E. CLEVANS
description: Mark E. Clevans, a founder and director of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies, died Saturday in Columbus Hospital. He was 82 years old lived here.

title: Corruption Is Part Of Policeman's Lot, Scholar Maintains
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UFI)A study issued by the Police Foundation today pictured corruption as a natural disease of police work.

title: PHILIP C. FAIRBANK
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., March 30 (AP)Philip C. Fairbank, who served five terms n the state House of Representatives, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: T.V.A. POST LIKELY FOR MISSISSIPPIAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 30James F. Hooper 3d, Mississippi real estate developer and dairy farmer who is the husband of a member of the Republican National Committee, is reported by Administration and Congressional sources to be the front runner for appointment to a nineyear term as a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Saigon Hope: Buying Time to Mount Defense of Capital
description: South Vietnamese infantry and artillery are attempting to establish a line north of the coastal port of Nha Trang in an effort to halt a Communist offensive developing along the seacoast, accord ing to United. States military sources. The offensive will be accompanied, the sources predicted, by a steady intensification of pressure to. test the morale of South Vietnam's forces defending the Saigon area.

title: High Court in California Scores Police Classroom Surveillance
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30Undercover police officers who sit in on college courses merely to compile intelligence reports on faculty and students violate First Amendment guarantees of free speech in the state's new invasion of privacy law, the California Supreme Court declared last week.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Braves Trade Pierce
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30(AP)The Atlanta Braves traded a first baseman. Jack Pierece, to the Detroit Tigers today for a player to be named later. Pierce, who batted .306 with Jalisco of the Mexican League in 1974 with 28 home runs, will be placed on the roster of the Tigers' Evansville farm club in the American Association.

title: Utilities' Adjustments for Higher Fuel Costs Are Under Attack
description: The controversial fueladjustment clause, used in 44 states by electric utilities as a means of immediately recovering increased fuel costs, is under heavy attack in nearly half of those states as support mounts for action to curb the rising regulatory costs of utility services.

title: Care Togetherness Is Doubted by Insiders
description: Despite their togetherness at a news conference the other day, Democrats close to Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak predict that they will continue to clash both because of the nature of their jobs and their personalities. Normally, Lieutenant Governors sink into obscurity since they have little power and because, politically, they usually owe their nomination and job to the Governor.

title: CATHOLICS EXAMINE BICENTENNIAL LINKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)A model pastoral letter on the Roman Catholic Church's relationship to the American Bicentennial is being circulated among Catholic Bishops in the United States.

title: Saudi Sets 800Million Refinery Expansion
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 30An $800million program to expand oil refineries for soaring domestic demand has been approved by Petromin, Saudi Arabia's national oil company.

title: Miss Halward Bride Of William Weintraub
description: Veronica M. Halward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Halward of Statesville, N.C., was married yesterday noon to William S. Weintraub, son of Herbert Weintraub of New York and the late Claire Stahl Weintraub. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Barclay.

title: ConRail Plan Threatens to Eliminate A 12Mile SingleTrack Line in Jersey
description: RINGOESMembers of the United States Railway Association have probably never visited this small Hunterdon county hamlet a few miles northwest of Princeton.

title: Paris: Terrifying Dubuffet Oils and a Masterpiece of Montage
description: PARIS, March 23Drama Giocoso is perhaps the most suitable definition for the 47 oil paintings by Jean Dubuffet exhibited at the Centre National d'Art Contemporain. With these canvases, the artist's hourloupe cycle, begun 12 years ago, comes to an end.

title: WILLIAM M. ROBBINS OF GENERAL FOODS
description: William Moore Robbins, who retired in 1956 as a vice president of the General Foods (Corporation, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 73 years old and lived at Old Mill Road, Greenwich, Conn.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: At least two of the six men and two corporations convicted by a Federal jury Friday night of bribery involving zoning in Fort Lee plan to appeal the verdict.

title: Ford Foundation to Halve Staff Over Next 3 Years
description: About 300 professional and other employes of the Ford Foundation, approximately half its staff, are to be laid off by Sept. 30, 1978, as the nation's largest foundation proceeds with its 50 per cent reduction in philanthropic programs necessitated by portfolio losses.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The world premiere of Agnes de Mile's first classical ballet, Summer, is scheduled April 10 during the spring series of the Boston Ballet at the Music Hall in Boston.

title: Some Papers Shrinking Pages to Cut Costs
description: In an effort to offset the rising costs of production, more and more American newspapers are shrinking the size of their pages and switching from eightcolumn width to six. Others are considering plans to do so.

title: WALLWORK URGES CAMDEN INQUIRY
description: State Senator James H. Wallwork, an Essex County Republican, called yesterday for the appointment of an independent special prosecutor to look into allegations of political corruption involving a Camden County utilities contract and a member of Governor Byrne's former law firm.

title: Views on Easter Faith
description: St. Paul said that without the Easter proclamation of Christ's resurrection from the dead the Christian faith would be futile. Indeed, the church from the beginning based its life on that conviction. Yet mingled with this certainty are persistent ambiguities about the nature and meaning of that resurrection event. Such questions as whether there was a physical rising from the grave and the authenticity of several reported sightings of the risen Christ make Easter perhaps the most speculative day of the Christian year.

title: FED CONTROL URGED IN CURRENCY TRADING
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The chairman of the House Banking Committee urged the Federal Reserve Board over the weekend to begin to supervise and regulate foreignexchange trading by banks.

title: Touch of Winter Chills Atlantic City Parade
description: ATLANTIC CITY. March 30 (UPI)  Umbrellas poked the air and winter coats hid much of the finery today at one of the country's oldest and largest fashion promenadesthe Boardwalk Easter Parade.

title: PLEA TO U.N. MADE BY SAIGON OFFICIAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. March 30Saigon's deputy premier, Phan Quang Dan, appealed to the United Nations today to establish contact with the North Vietnamese with the view of setting up channels to get food and medical supplies to refugees in Da Nang and the Central Highlands. He estimated the number of refugees in the nation at two million, threequarters of them children.

title: Foe's Sudden Gains Stun Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30  A major question here today was how Vietnamese Communist forces could accomplish in three weeks, almost effortlessly, what had been far beyond their reach for a quarter of a century.

title: Lon Nol Meets With Aides on Departure, Expected Shortly
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 30President Lon Nol met today with Government and military advisers and Buddhist religious leaders to discuss his departure from the country this week.

title: Stage: He That Plays King, Dramatic Anthology
Rangers Win; Islanders Tie, 22
description: Like a falling man grasping for a support, the Rangers found it last night in the form of the Kansas City Scouts. Slipping fast in the race for a playoff position with nine losses in 13 games, New York stemmed its downward flight with an 82 trouncing of the Scouts, with Steve Vickers scoring four goals and Rod Gilbert contributing five assists.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A small lighting shop that opened recently at 417 Bleecker Street (near Abingdon Square) is trying to please a wide variety of tastes. From among its modest stock, Lights, Inc. offers everything from traditional floral china table lamps to a Lucite curtain of light that, when hung, gives something of the effect of dozens of tiny twinkly lights suspended in air.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Unionist Assails N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The National Labor Relations Board takes an average of 316 days to reach a decision on labormanagement disputes and perhaps should be abolished, according to the meatcutters union. In an ediorial in the April issue of The Butcher Wokman, the board was assailed by Patrick E. Gorman, secretarytreasurer of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen.

title: WARNING LABELS ON DRUGS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON. March 30A petition urging the Food and Drug Administration to require warning labels for patients on some prescription drugs will be filed tomorrow by a coalition of major consumer and women's groups.

title: College Costs to Rise 6 to 8% This Fall
description: The cost of going to college will be 6 to 8 per cent higher next fall, according to a survey by the College Entrance Examination Board, which found that the largest increases will be at publicly supported institutions.

title: Safety Board Asks Greater Standards For Train Travel
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The National Transportation Safety Board called on Amtrak and the Federal Railroad Administration today to improve the crashworthiness of passenger cars and set minimum quality standards for rails on which they travel.

title: State Offers School Plan Lessening Local Control
description: The New Jersey Board of Education, seeking to comply with the State Supreme Court decision guaranteeing every child thorough and efficient education, has prepared new regulations that would lessen local Control of schools in areas such as construction and class size.

title: Nicklaus Victor by 3 Strokes
Kurds Say Their Leader And 2 Sons Are in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 30 (Reuters)  Gen. Mustafa Barzani, the Kurdish rebel leader, accompanied by his two sons, Idris and Mesut, has crossed into Iran from Iraq, a Kurdish spokesman said here today.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A short while ago we printed letter from a reader telling us we should explore what she called New York's bestkept culinary secret. It had to do with rossel borscht, which is a specialty of the Passover holiday. We had been informed by a friend of ours that rossel meant fermented.

title: Earl Brydges Dies
description: Earl W. Brydges, former majority leader of the State Senate, died yesterday of cancer in Lewiston, N.Y. He was 69. Details on Page 34.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: About the Mets...
description: Showing all their old flair, the Mets elected to lose the Cardinals in the ninth inning yesterday before a television audience back in New York. They are relaying three games home from Florida, and the third will involve the Detroit Tigers next Saturday night.... Harry Parker, who won four games and lost 12 last season, has pitched 16 exhibition innings and allowed only four earned runs. He will pitch for a regular job again on Monday against the Pittsburgh Pirates.... Dave Kingman, back in action after a flying trip home to California, hit two longdistance shots Saturday in a camp game but neither cleared a fence. He has eight home runs in 17 games plus 11 other hits. In the eighth inning against the Cardinals, he hit another to the centerfield fence and just missed No. 9.... The Cardinals, a strong rival to the Pirates for Eastern honors in the National League, are having troubles, too. They have won only nine of 22 games and have been shut out three times. Lou Brock has stolen three bases, and been caught four times.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The North Vietnamese took over Da Nang yesterday following the collapse of Government resistence and the panicky flight of tens of thousands of refugees. There were reports that North Vietnamese troops were advancing south along the coast of South Vietnam, and that the cities of Qui Nhon and Tuy Hoa were threatened. American officials and South Vietnamese were being evacuated from these coastal cities. Qui Nhon airport was reportedly packed with soldiers and families vainly seeking to get out by plane. Virtually all flights to Qui Nhon were stopped because of the panic at the airport. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Bailey Breaks Hand
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP)Bob Bailey, a Montreal Expo outfielder, suffered a fracture in his left hand today when he was hit by a pitch during an exhibition game with the Houston Astros. He is expected to be lost for at least a month. Bailey was hit by a pitch from Jim York.

title: U.S. Holds Road Show on Its Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A unique Federal Government traveling road show will be in New York Tuesday.

title: Lawyers to the Poor
description: The Legal Aid Society is a kind of law firm for the poor, defending them not only in criminal matters but also against consumer fraud ordiscrimination. It helps those who have problems with immigration, social securi ty, welfare or unscrupulous landlords.

title: The Communists of Portugal: A Force While Underground, a Power Today
description: LISBON, March 28When Alvaro Cunhal, the whitehaired 61yearold Secretary General of the Portuguese Communist party, returned to Lisbon from 14 years of exile a few days after the military coup last April 25, he was hoisted by soldiers to the top of an armored car from which he addressed his followers in front of the airport.

title: Europeans Rediscover American Stocks
description: PARIS, March 30Many European money managers are putting more of their clients funds into American securities, contending that economic prospects in the United States have improved and that additional gains can be made from what they expect will be a stronger dollar.

title: Personal Finance: Readable Policies
description: By the time I'm through reading about the party of the first part and the party of the second part, I've forgotten who I am, a woman observed recently as she read an insurance policy.

title: Brokers' Profits Soar to Peaks
description: With the stock market's trading volume up nearly 40 per cent to well over 20 million shares a day so far this year, stockbrokers are again making big money.

title: Sonics Win and Clinch First Berth in Playoffs
description: SEATTLE, March 30 (AP)Spencer Haywood scored 40 points as the Seattle SuperSonics won a National Basketball Association playoff berth for the first time with a 9888 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers today.

title: HANOI FORCES MOVE SOUTH AFTER OCCUPYING DA NANG; U.S. SHIPS TO AVOID COMBAT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 31A speedy North Vietnamese force moved into chaotic Da Nang yesterday and met scant opposition from demoralized fleeing Government troops, according to Western and South Vietnamese military sources here.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Life on land became possible hundreds of millions of years ago when the atmosphere developed an ozone layer, cutting off those wavelengths of ultraviolet sunlight that break down the nucleic acids essential to life.

title: Fighting in Ethiopia Is at a Stalemate
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 30Two months after Government troops and secessionist guerrillas clashed in largescale battles in and around the northern city of Asmara, what had been virtual civil war in Ethiopia has slowed to a stalemate.

title: Reagan vs. McGovernment
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.Many of the people in this retirement capital believe that the policies and the candidates so overwhelmingly rejected by the American electorate in 1972 have now taken control in Washington. McGovernment is upon us.

title: CHEMICAL CANCELS 100MILLION ISSUE
description: The Chemical New York Corporation announced yesterday that it had decided not to proceed with its offering of $100million of 9 per cent, 25year convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Ousted Principal Wins Case
description: COHASSET, Mass., March 30 (AP)The American Arbitration Association has ordered Richard A. Streeter reinstated as Cohasset High School principal, a job from which he was discharged two years ago. Mr. Streeter, 48 years old, who has been teaching parttime at two Boston colleges since he was dismissed, will receive back pay estimated at $35,000.

title: Memorial Services
description: NATHANSONJerome. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, April 1, at 5.30 P.M., at the Meeting House of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St., Manhattan.

title: Wooden Era At U.C.L.A. In Final Act
description: SAN DIEGO, March 30The John Wooden era in college basketball will end tomorrow night at the San Diego Arena when his 27th and last University of California, Los Angeles, team meets Kentucky in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Associattion tournament.

title: Article 1  No Title
EGYPT WILL BAR CARGO FOR ISRAEL FROM SUEZ CANAL
description: CAIRO, March 30  Israelibound cargo aboard ships of other nations as well as Israeli ships will be barred from passage through the Suez Canal when it is opened to international traffic this summer, Egyptian officials said today.

title: Bank Consortium to Lend $50Million to Petroperu
description: TOKYO, March 30 (Reuters) The LongTerm Credit Bank of Japan said yesterday an international banking consortium would lend Peru's staterun oil company Ptroleos del Peru $50million.

title: Jumper Champions Ridden by Chapot
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 30  Frank Chapot, captain of the United States Equestrian Team, rode the champion and reserve champion jumpers at the New jersey Professional Horsemen's Association show today.

title: For Further Amnesty
description: WASHINGTONThe time has come for Congress to take further steps to heal the deep wounds inflicted on our nation by the Vietnam war. Specifically, Congress should support and extend the President's amnesty programwhich ends at midnight tonight for the thousands of young men who evaded the draft or deserted the military during the conflict.

title: Hanoi Criticizes Ford For Decision on Ships
description: HONG KONG, March 30 (Reuters)North Vietnam and the Vietcong today condemned President Ford's decision to order United States naval ships to Da Nang to evacuate refugees, the North Vietnam press agency reported.

title: NUCLEAR CENTERS FOR U.S. STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has set up a 25member panel to determine by Oct. 11 whether huge regional nuclear centers might be the answer to fears about the safety of atomic power plants.

title: In Memoriam
description: HIRSCHRae J. Lovingly remembered on your birthday. Our memories are always with you.

title: Federal Judge Dismisses S.E.C. Suit Against Sorg
description: A Federal judge here dismissed a civil suit against the Sorg Printing Company by the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday involving the use of inside information by certain printers of the concern.

title: Now, Energy Policy
description: Worsening economic conditions have only widened a philosophical gulf between the Administration and Congressional Democrats as they prepare to come to grips with energy policy after the Easter recess.

title: Basque Fiesta Broken Up By the Police in Guernica
description: GUERNICA, Spain, March 30 (UPI)The police broke up a Basque fiesta today and arrested 38 persons, including two members of the Belgian Parliament, the national news agency Cifra said.

title: BARBADOS FESTIVAL PLAYS FELT FORUM
description: The Barbados Festival on Saturday at the Felt Forum found a group of performers as intent on recreating American soul music as in laying down traditional Bajan rhythms. Even the currently successful discotheque sound has taken hold in the CaribbeanKung Fu Fighting, a big disco hit, emerged almost unchanged in the hands of the Escorts.

title: Jersey Poll Shows Ford Losing Support on His Foreign Policy
description: Disapproval of President Ford's handling of the nation's foreign affairs has increased in New Jersey, according to a sampling by the Eagleton Institute's New Jersey Poll.

title: Powerful and Effective
description: Earl William Brydges was one of the most powerful and effective leaders of the State Legislature in the years before. his retirement as Senate majority leader in 1972.

title: Impasse Is Reported In State Pay Talks; Strike Threatened
description: The state announced an impasse yesterday in its wage negotiations with the Civil Service Employes Association and asked the Public Employment Relations Board to intervene.

title: Refugees Cram Rescue Vessels
description: CAM RANH, South Vietnam, March 30Thousands of refugees from Da Nang. clinging to railings, hanging onto smokestacks and packing the decks, arrived on ships today at the relative safety of this attractive deepwater port 165 miles northeast of Saigon.

title: Penguins Victors Over Stars, 4 to 1
description: PITTSBURGH, March 30 (UPI)Pierre Larouche fired from the slot on a power play midway through the second period for the goahead goal tonight in the Pittsburgh Penguins' 41 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Presidential Cooperation
description: President Ford has well served the national interest by signing the antirecession tax bill in the face of his deeply felt reservations on both fiscal and philosophical grounds.

title: Margaret Walsh Wed to Richard Sayer
description: St. George's Chapel at St. George's School in Newport, R. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Anne O'Hanley Walsh to Richard Norman Sayer. The bride's uncle, the Rev. John J. Walsh, a professor of religious studies at Holy Cross College, performed the ceremony.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Hospital in Brooklyn Open Despite Accreditation Loss
description: Linden General Hospital, a 78bed private health facility in a rundown part of Brooklyn's East New York section, has lost its accreditation and been declared hazardous, unneeded and irremediably obsolete by government inspectors. But the hospital continues to function because of an unabated flow of Government Medicaid payments that are its main source of support.

title: Backlog Dwindles For U.S. Makers Of Machine Tools
description: The machine tool industry's backlog dwindled by almost $250million in this year's first two months as orders dropped and shipments rose.

title: Earl Brydges Dies of Cancer; State Senate Republican Leader
description: LEWISTON, N.Y., March 30 (AP)  Earl W. Brydges, the former State Senate Republican leader, died early today of cancer in a hospital here. He was 69 years old.

title: Churchill Had Plan For Refugee Legion
description: LONDON, March 30 (UPI) Secret Cabinet documents from World War II reveal that Winston Churchill sought to form a legion of refugees from enemy countries to fight against Germany.

title: Easter Tradition Reigns on Fifth Avenue, Despite Chill
description: Jacqueline Kerstens donned a bonnet of three dozen sunny daffodils yesterday, then ignored ashen skies and a chilly rain to take a stroll up Fifth Avenue. Otherwise you wouldn't know it was Easter, she said.

title: Dayan Expresses Doubt On Kissinger's Method
description: Moshe Dayan, the former Israeli Defense Minister, has said that he is not sure that Secretary of State Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy is the best way to achieve peace in the Middle East, according to Newsweek Magazine.

title: Audubon at 75
description: Roger Tory Peterson, the naturalist, once called the journal of the National Audubon Society not only the most beautiful natural history magazine in the world, but the most beautiful magazine of any sort in the English language. Allow some for a personal ebullience, allow a little perhaps for professional sympathyand still there is enough merit in Mr. Peterson's description to explain the lift of spirit enjoyed by the readers of this remarkable periodical.

title: Flames Rescued by a Late Tally
description: ATLANTA, March 30  A winded Atlanta Flames team that managed only 15 shots on goal nevertheless came up with a 22 tie against the New York Islanders in a pressure game before 14,536 fans today.

title: Pope Paul Appears Vigorous As He Leads Easter Services
description: ROME, March 30Pope Paul VI, in a brief Easter message today, said that the Resurrection of Jesus should be a stimulus to all who are working for the renewal of mankind.

title: Fat Employes Offered $3 for Each Pound Lost
description: SPRING GROVE, Ill., March 30 (AP)The president of a manufacturing company, concerned about the health of his overweight employes, is paying $3 for each pound they lose. He figures the offer may cost him more than $17,600.

title: Patient Abuse in Nursing Homes Scored
description: Neglect and abuse of patients are characteristic of the profitmotivated nursinghome industry, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said yesterday in the third installment of his draft report for the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy.

title: Advertising
description: Back in 1973, when Playgirl magazine was getting started, its outside advertising representative signed up the American Tobacco Company as an advertiser for all of its back covers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 31, 1975 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Bridge:
description: The Lancia Swiss team tournament at the Americana Hotel here during the weekend attracted a field that was high in quality if somewhat disappointing in quantity. Thirtysix teams, including several from New England and Washington, competed for the right to oppose a group headed by Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna and Omar Sharif in an exhibition match in May and perhaps win five Lancia cars.

title: Foe's Sudden Gains Stun Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30A major question here today was how Vietnamese Communist forces could accomplish in three weeks, almost effortlessly, what had been far beyond their reach for a quarter of a century.

title: Erving Gets 40 Points With Sore Back And Nets Rout Spurs to Remain in First
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 30Julius Erving, playing with a sore back, scored 40 points today and the New York Nets routed the San Antonio Spurs, 130104, at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Bends Symptoms Delay Divers Return
description: HONOLULU, March 30Two divers have developed symptoms of the bends that will slow the return to a surface environment for five men in a scientific experiment at Makai Pier on the windward shore of the island of Oahu.

title: Reported Political Use of Radio Fairness Doctrine Under Kennedy and Johnson Is Causing Concern
description: A report yesterday that the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations had carried on organized, covert campaigns to harass unsympathetic radio commentators dismayed experts in communications law, most of whom said they were concerned about its impact on a key policy in broadcast regulation.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Faces of War
description: More eloquently than governments or diplomats, the faces tell the horror of war in Southeast Asia: grandmothers carried on bent backs over shellpocked roads, barefoot farmers trudging away from ancestral homes, evacuated children hoisted in cargo nets like beasts for the marketplace.

title: Nadjari Vows to Keep Job Despite Mackell Reversal
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, vowed yesterday to remain in his post despite criticism following his most recent setback, the reversal on Friday of the conviction of Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney.

title: U.S. TakeOver Is Ending State Job Safety Program
description: The staterun occupational safety and health program is ending today, passing at midnight to Federal administration. and there is widespread concern in New Jersey over some weaker Federal standards.

title: Hillary's Wile Is Killed With Daughter in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Monday, March 31 (AP)The wife and daughter of Sir Edmund Hillary, who conquered Mount Everest for the firs: time in 1953, were among five persons killed in an air crash here today, airport officials reported.

title: Angola Unraveling?
description: Portuguese officials have succeeded in negotiating a truce among bitterly antagonistic liberation movements in Angola after four days of gun battles that left more than 60 dead in Luanda, capital city of the potentially rich territory that is due to become independent November 11. But the episode offers fresh evidence of the fragility of agreements for sharing power in the transitional Government among three African groupsthe FNLA, MPLA and UNITAwhose differences are regional and ethnic as well as ideological.

title: Culture in New York...
description: Culture is a cash crop in New York; the arts are the basis of $3 billion in business annually, affecting everything from service jobs to real estate. The fact that this city is one of the creative capitals of the world does not mean, however, that it administers its artistic assets well; a recent report of the Mayor's Committee on Cultural Policy accused the city of inefficiency and impotence in its handling of cultural affairs. That includes $50 million of direct investment through official programs and budgets for which New York does not remotely get its money's worth. It seems that everyone else is getting a bite out of the big apple except the city itself.

title: Nursing Home Abuses Spur Action Nationwide
description: Grim disclosures of misery and profiteering in the care of aged Americans are emerging with increasing frequency from around the country.

title: BRANDT SAYS NATO STILL TRUSTS IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters)  Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, in a television interview broadcast today, discounted ?? that a refusal by the United States to provide military aid to South Vietnam and Cambodia would provoke European fears that the United States was pulling back from its commitments.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special New York State anticorruption prosecutor, vowed yesterday to remain in his post despite criticism following his most recent setback, the reversal on Friday of the conviction of Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney.

title: WILLIAM F. WRIGHTNOUR
description: William F. Wrightnour, a former vice president of Uniroyal, Inc., died Saturday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: EGYPT WILL BAR CARGO FOR ISRAEL FROM SUEZ CANAL
description: CAIRO, March 30  Israelibound cargo aboard ships of other nations as well as Israeli ships will be barred from passage through the Suez Canal when it is opened to international traffic this summer, Egyptian officials said today.

title: FLORENCE BARNES, 20'S AVIATOR, DIES
description: BORON, Calif., March 30 (AP)  Florence Lowe (Pancho) Barnes, the first woman stunt pilot in motion pictures, was found dead yesterday at her home in this Southern California community. She was 73 years old.

title: Ski Jump Event To W. German
description: THUNDER BAY, Ontario, March 30 (AP)Alfred Grosche, a 23yearold \Vest German, defeated 56 other jumpers to win an international ski jump 90meter competition today.

title: King Faisal's Assassin Is Declared Sane
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 30The young Saudi prince who assassinated King Faisal has been examined and declared to have been sane at the time of the killing, the Saudi Government radio said today.

title: President's Mail Is Sifted For Sampling of Trends
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Every Friday a folder containing 50 or so letters, some scrawled in a shaky hand on lined school paper, some neatly typed on proper stationery, is sent to President Ford to give him a sample of what people are writing him about.

title: Is the Tyranny of Fashion Designers Really a Thing of the Past?
description: Most men think women approach buying clothes with the glee and ver??e of a wellheeled 6yearold loose in Disneyland. Most of the women I know Identify more with Sisyphus pushing that rock up the hill.

title: Levitt Says Transit Unit Could Save $9.6Million
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt, in reports critical of Transit Authority operations said yesterday that the authority could handle its subway maintenance with less than half the present inspection force and thus save $9.6million a year.

title: Ford Foundation to Halve Staff Over Next 3 Years
description: About 300 professional and other employes of the Ford Foundation, approximately half its staff, are to be laid off by Sept. 30, 1978, as the nation's argest foundation proceeds with its 50 per cent reduction in philanthropic programs necessitated by portfolio losses.

title: Canadiens' Late Goal Ties Bruins
description: BOSTON, March 30 (AP)Guy Lafleur's 51st goal of the season in the third period lifted the Montreal Canadiens to a 22 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight in a National Hockey League game filled with penalties and tight checking.

title: Louisiana Sniper Kills Two And Then Shoots Himself
description: WEST MONROE, La., March 30 (AP)A sniper opened fire from the second story of an apartment building here this morning, killing two persons and wounding a third before killing himself, the police said.

title: I.R.A. Leader Gives Warning Of Renewed Guerrilla War
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 30 (AP)A leader of the I.R.A. Provisionals warned today that the organization would resume its guerrilla war unless the British Government withdrew its troops from Northern Ireland and promised amnesty for all political prisoners.

title: Rural Portugal Changes in the Revolution, but Not All That Much
description: GUIMARAIS, Portugal, March 26Along the righthand wall of the Cafe Doural the authoritative old menshopkeepers, landowners, doctorssit in their heavy wool suits and fresh white collars, their authority shrunken away.

title: ScaledDown Westway Urged By Regional Plan Association
description: The Regional Plan Association yesterday recommended a scaleddown Interstate System highway, in sonic stretches just four lanes wide, to replace the old, elevated West Side Highway.

title: Layer Defeats Gerulaitis in Final for 20th in a Row
description: ORLANDO. Fla., March 30 After completing a semifinal victory earlier in the day, Rod Laver returned to the court to defeat Vitas Gerulairis, 63, 64, in the final of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today. It was the fourth tournament in a row he had won.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1975

title: JUDGE BACKS HELP FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30In the face of mounting criticism over court decisions dealing with the rights of institutionalized persons, Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. says that while judges are properly hesitant about making decisions calling for the exercise of political judgment, they often have no alternative but to invoke and require adherence to the Constitution.

title: Luminous St. John Passion Sung by Collegiate Chorale
description: Bach's The Passion. According to St. John is a more concentrated, more overtly dramatic treatment of the Easter story than the composer's monumental Passion, According to St. Matthew. Richard Westenburg emphasized the quasioperatic overtones of the score Saturday night in Carnegie Hall with the Collegiate Chorale, but without distorting either its reverent or stylistic bases. This was, in short, an ideal conception of the Passion, and the orchestral and choral quality was consistently high.

title: Louisa's Centennial Fury (1875)
description: The town was getting ready for the grand row, the launching of the American centennial in 1875 in Concord, Mass. President Ulysses S. Grant, the guest of honor, was clue to open the ceremonies. There was to be a parade, speeches, and a tour of the village, capped by a grand ball.

title: COURT TO REVIEW DEATH SENTENCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30After several months of uncertainty, the Supreme Court has put a capital punishment case on its hearing schedule for the last week of arguments of the 197475 term.

title: Books of The Times
description: Last time out of the literary stalls, Alvin Toffler prodded us with Future Shock, which asked the question, Are we reaching the outer limits of human adaptability to the stresses and strains imposed by rapid uncontrolled change? His new book exposes us to another social malady eco spasmand posits a world careening toward a novel kind of economic disaster, which the conventional remedies in the economist's armamentarium can't cure. The EcoSpasm Report is a quickie book, timed to coincide with the current upsurge in economic gloom. It went in the space of 90 days from the author's brain to its appearance in the February issue of Esquire to this instantly published paperback, an expansion of the Esquire article. The Esquire piece, entitled Beyond Depression, featured a gloomy scenario that described a world in the throes of racking paradoxical socioeconomic crisesecospasms. Mr. Toffler felt, however, that because of the stringent space limitations and conventions of magazine journalism, the article was too unbelievably pessimisticToo much depression, not enough beyond, as one of his fellow futurists told him. As a futurist in good standing, Mr. Toffler just couldn't leave us clinging to that ledge (after all if the future is unmitigated disaster, what's the good of futurology?). So in the present book he throws a rope in the form of some positive options.

title: Bonds Rally as Traders Expect Monetary Easing
description: The corporate bond market, battered only a week ago, suddenly is seeing some improvement. Last Friday, after several sessions of losses and handwringing, the nearterm outlook suddenly appeared to improve, thanks ironically to drab economic statistics issued by the Federal Reserve. A decline of $1.8billion in the nation's money supply (after five weeks of growth) and a drop of $165million in loans by New York City banks combined to bring out the sun and touch off a brisk bond rally.

title: Balanced Knick Attack Subdues Bucks, 11199.
description: The Knicks went back to the adage yesterday afternoon that five can play the game better than one. The one, Kareem AbdulJabbar, pro basketball's most dominating force, scored 32 points, grabbed 11 rebounds, had six assists and four steals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Home Abuses Spur Action Nationwide
description: Grim disclosures of misery and profiteering in the care of aged Americans are emerging with increasing frequency from around the country.

title: Giammalva Victor in Easter Bowl
description: Tony Giammalva, a sturdy stylist from the tennis family of Houston was among six Easter Bowl junior champions crowned yesterday as the annual indoor tournament ended.
